Movie Title: Rebel Moon - Part One: A Child of Fire (2023)
Review-Description: Is it a story that has been told before? Yes. Were parts exceedingly slow? Yes. I was able to fast forward without losing the storyline as the storyline is pretty predictable? It's a movie about people fighting for their freedom. Yes. I agree with most that have said there was little to no character development. There is little that really bonds our hero's together, other than hey I am building this team. In part two, I hope that slow-mo is not used for the action sequences as much as this one. Visually the movie is pretty as was the epic music for the scoring. Acting is well done as I enjoy the work of most of the actors. I found it slightly hilarious that both characters that played Daario in GOT were in this movie. I am guessing from hints of this movie what part two is going to reveal. I will watch part two because I want to know if I am correct or not.

Movie Title: Rebel Moon - Part One: A Child of Fire (2023)
Review-Title: Not unwatchable... but neither is it good
Review-Description: I SHOULD have loved this movie, I am an avid Sci-Fi fan and love watching properties from Starwars, Star Trek, Star Gate, Dune, Serenity, etc. And their spin-offs. This movie clearly wants to be those... but it is just a disjointed mess. Zero character development - Characters are just thrown at you without any reasoning or explanation. We have no idea who anyone is, why they do what they do, etc. We are just expected to accept that these people exist and are willing to join together in the fight. It literally is "let's go get this guy" then they after a couple minutes of "look how cool this person is" we are expected to just accept them into the story. Slipshod world building - As with the character development, the "world" where this occurs just unfolds in a way that is confusing. Things are just thrown at you and you have to accept them. In the end, it was "this group is BAD" and "this group is GOOD", without any nuance or background. Cliche'd imagery - Half way through, we started playing the game, "where did they steal that from." the whole movie is a mashup of scenes and concepts taken from other Sci-Fi and Fantasy movies. We'd shout out, "that's from Harry Potter!" and "they took that from Firefly!" pretty much every since scene in the entire movie. Pointless story - The whole story just is a strung together set of scenes that don't seem to have a point. The final climax was unsatisfying, made worse because the poor character and world development meant we didn't really care who lived or died. Then, the whole thing ended with a huge cliche. The movie was billed as "an adult Starwars," instead, it feels more like fan fiction. We didn't turn it off, it was just (barely) entertaining enough to keep watching. And, I will likely watch the second movie. But, this was just one long missed opportunity.

Movie Title: Rebel Moon - Part One: A Child of Fire (2023)
Review-Title: Great VFX, but worn out story and lazy writing
Review-Description: This is visually an impressive movie, and it's certainly entertaining; but there's something really amiss with the story, in fact with the whole writing; as well as with the casting and acting, and with the cinematography of some of the fighting sequences. To begin on the positive side: the VFX are topnotch, from alien creatures to galactic worlds to epic spaceship-battles: it's all awesomely done and totally convincing. The score is great, and some of the actors are a real treat for the eye, be it Sofia Boutella as main character Kora, she's absolutely beautiful and has an almost regal charisma (fitting her role), or some of the impressively built male characters (like Dijon Hounsou and Stan Nair). But then my reservations. The story feels like we've seen it a dozen times before in this kind of epic galactic scifi movies: yet another universe with a dictatorial repressive central regime; myriads of downtrodden and exploited common people; and from the latter the rise of a resistance under the banner of some heroic messiah-like leader. It's Starwars, Dune and Foundation (and a whole lot of others) all put in a blender. The writing felt lazy: by using a voice-over at the start of the movie I had within 5 minutes the impression that I had missed a prequel or an episode 0, pulling me into an already fast riding train. The search for the right resistance team-members felt rushed, skipping from one weird world to the next, giving the various characters hardly any depth or even motivation for their willingness to come along. The result is a succession of short anecdotical scenes without real substance. As to the acting: Sofia Boutella constantly has to keep up an almost frozen attitude, so there's hardly any room for her to shine; and Michiel Huisman sure has more potential than this role of a non-descript hanger-on. Ed Skrein does a good job as the (almost caricaturally) sadistic Atticus, but the rest of the cast is just adequate. And another annoying thing: the potentially interesting fighting scenes are all afflicted by a weird whim of the director, to vary within one scene from regular motion to slow, to slower than slow, and to regular motion again. Who do you think to please with such mannerisms?! Anyway, maybe (as with the disappointing first episode of the new "Dune") this Part One mainly acts as an overture to the Real Thing in the expected Part Two. We'll wait and see, but for now I have my doubts.

Movie Title: Rebel Moon - Part One: A Child of Fire (2023)
Review-Title: Ignore all the low ratings and immerse yourself in this journey
Review-Description: My title says it all, sincerely . Zack is brilliant. Watcher is amazing and a masterpiece. And so is Rebel Moon. Low rating doesnt do this movie justice and rather uneducated or void of certain standard of appreciation I love the flow , its character development & characters screen time has its respective special scene moment is well used & well deserved . Action scene is not over exaggerated to a comical level but rather entertainingly dramatic enough . There's lots i could say about this movie so just go and enjoy it . Maybe should just go back to watching cartoons. Just Another Zack masterpiece.

Movie Title: Rebel Moon - Part One: A Child of Fire (2023)
Review-Title: As bad as the press says.. and then some!
Review-Description: I wanted to check, it really is an appallingly bad movie. Am I alone in seeing how this was written, designed and even story boarded with extensive use of AI? Every aspect of this movie is made up from a large amount of meaningless content without any connective tissue whatsoever. A soup of randomly collected assets. The clumsy attempt at bringing three dimensionality to incredibly flat characters through unjustified changes of mind.. The tasteless production design.. the atemporality of events. Clearly Netflix tried an AI heavy pipeline in order to more make money. The result is grotesque.

Movie Title: Rebel Moon - Part One: A Child of Fire (2023)
Review-Description: In Zack Snyder's 'Rebel Moon,' the spectacle eclipses the soul. This leap into a 'Star Wars'-like universe lands in a charmless sandbox, with Snyder's overindulgence in slow-motion for even the simplest actions serving more as a narrative hindrance than an enhancement. The characters, as deep as action figures, meander through a plot stitched together from clich√©s of B-movie westerns and Kurosawa's classics, yet devoid of their essence. This space opera, embedded with 'Star Wars' DNA, fails to evoke the sense of awe and wonder it ambitiously aims for. Visually striking it may be, yet it's a landscape emotionally barren. Unlike 'Dunyayi Kurtaran Adam,' the Turkish cult classic that playfully dabbled with 'Star Wars' themes with a tongue-in-cheek approach, 'Rebel Moon' takes itself too seriously, morphing into an expensive parody, a shadow of the cinematic titans it attempts to replicate. In conclusion, 'Rebel Moon' is a visual feast starved of substance, proving that sometimes, less is indeed more in storytelling. Snyder's fondness for slow motion only adds to the film's overbearing atmosphere, making it a cumbersome watch.

Movie Title: Rebel Moon - Part One: A Child of Fire (2023)
Review-Title: Full of potential Diaster that Sad
Review-Description:
Story 1/10
Script 2/10
Pacing 2/10
Characters 0/10
Cinematography 6/10
World building 5/10
Visuals 6/10
Sound design 7/10. As an admirer of Zack Snyder over the years it is sad to see such a failing in story, script, and wrong casting types. The world building is fine, we know that he has that potential. Unfortunately, it appears that rather than letting the characters and their story build the world and then it is informing back on its characters, it is that the world building was done with lack of attention. As well filmmakers have forced all the story and its beings into this shell. Seen through the portfolio of Snyder, I imagine it is the story writer and focusing on what is it that he is exploring, would give him freedom to play around with his artistic colours and camera movement.

Movie Title: Rebel Moon - Part One: A Child of Fire (2023)
Review-Description: I didn't watch this for the plot, since even the slim synopsis made me understand that this was a remake of Seven Samurai set in space. I hoped that Snyder could manage to inject something new into the old plot, but it was just eye candy and slow-motion fight scenes; it's really Sucker Punch all over again, with short cool sequences held together by the thinnest of threads. The actors actually try their best to roll with the punches thrown at them by the script; sometimes they fail, sometimes they succeed, but nothing they do can actually save this wreck. A note about the bad guys: in recent movies the scripts evolved from "evil emprire" or "evil Sauron" to something more complex and layered (there are movies where we actually root for the bad guy because he has the moral high ground); this movie is a huge step back towards a "main characters good, adversaries bad" simplicity.

Movie Title: Rebel Moon - Part One: A Child of Fire (2023)
Review-Description: It was decent to start with & had a bunch of good points throughout it. But really felt like an unfinished movie that had a lot left out because of its inclusive rating. Part way through it started to feel like it was pushed towards young teens who need fast pacing and lots going on, even if the story is left unfinished / characters aren't fleshed out. Not often do I get to a point in a movie where I just don't really care about what's happening anymore. Visuals & sound were very good though (watching with Atmos & Projector). Checked again before reviewing today & found there is going to be a full cut of the movie as well. (director / snyder cut) that is higher rated. Hopefully it has the same quality improvements overall like Justice League did (but not the annoying 4:3 aspect ratio). As that was a massive improvement on the theater release (which was as bad as this movie).

Movie Title: Rebel Moon - Part One: A Child of Fire (2023)
Review-Title: Stylish space opera is OK but lacks new ideas
Review-Description: Part 1 is obviously set-up; we meet the "Seven Samurai" characters and get some world-building. The characters are rather simple; the good guys have honor; no one else does. There's a giant spider woman and evil creatures that look like orcs -- feels a bit like Tolkien's LOTR in Space (although there's no MacGuffin {One Ring} so far) with Warhammer-style ships and weapons. And we have an over-the-top stereotypical Nazi villain. The word derivative comes to mind. The casting seems generally fine, but the choice of Sofia Boutella (Hotel Artemis) for a super-warrior is a bit of a stretch. She's athletic but a bit unconvincing; I like her but I think she would have been better cast as a secondary warrior or perhaps a thief; she seems a bit small to go up against some of the hulking adversaries (but granted, her character's combat skills are impressively well-rounded). This Netflix movie begins and ends on an agricultural planet (The Shire?) populated by pseudo-Viking peasants. There's a town with a space-port full of dubious characters (think Star Wars "bar" scene). Conceptually, this is only a three (3) star film. But it gets a 1-star bonus for the impressive visuals, and another for the Zach Snyder touch. That's five (5) stars total. BTW, my favorite character is the thoughtful, melancholy robot -- the only story element that lingers, sadly.

Review-Title: To be (king) or not to be
Review-Description: No pun intended - this is not the worst movie ever. At least I don't feel it is. But I doubt it will make many top lists (be it year or genre or anything else for that matter). It does look good and I reckon James Wan knows how to shoot a movie. There are quite a few jokes that do not really work - and quite a bit of editing that feels off ... just suspend your disbelief and go with the flow (of water). The ending is also a bit anti-climatic and there is not much in the way of sense ... also try not to use logic! Or think the movie applies it. Furthermore, this does not only use an actor you may recognize from a small role in the MCU ... but it also copies one particular (and very famous) ending from an MCU movie ... I swim therefor I am I guess. Not the mic drop moment the movie thinks it is. The CGI is good - but the whole movie feels a bit off. It is a nice touch that it sometimes does things without dialog, just with the actors nodding to each other ... and yet this feels weird - and not in a good sense. After watching the movie I watched the Pitch Meeting that was made for this (a real funny Youtube channel that I can highly recommend) ... the super easy, barely an inconvenience quote is easy to guess - if you have seen the movie. A weird way to end the current DCEU ... but as they would say: The King is dead, long live the King (not literally of course)

Review-Title: This movie would be ok if it wasn't the last DCEU movie
Review-Description: There is a lot of superhero fatigue today and this movie feels like another superhero movie. That's it. Just another superhero movie. This movie was a fun ride to say the least. This version of aquaman is a fun spin on the character by giving him a surfer/ biker type of style. The character stays consistent and lovable throughout the movie. You can tell Jason Momoa loves playing aquaman. The plot of the movie along with the antagonist are very generic. They hardly develop black manta's character in this movie. They just add in lines like saying "thank God for global warming." This movie knew and poked fun at the fact that aquaman is kind of a silly character at times but I don't feel as if it was unfitting. This movie is an ok superhero movie, but definitely nothing close to a fitting end to the DCEU. I mean... the last scene of this movie (THE LAST SCENE OF THE DCEU) is aquaman's brother eating a cockroach.

I read a lot of bad reviews about this film but it wasn't as bad as they say. Sure is not as good as the first aquaman film was but it's above average despite the numerous flaws. The plot is axceptable makes sense and the effects are great as momoa saves the day as always with his performance. There are parts of the movie that may get you tiresome but overall u will enjoy this sequel. At least it was way better than many of the phase IV dc entries which failed miserably like those beep new entries of shazam, the marvels, wakanda forever and that atrocius flash entry. At least this new aquaman entry is decent and u should check it out. Grade B- (7 out of 10)

I went in with low expectations, but if I'm being honest (speaking as an Aquaman hater besides the animated version on the Justice League Animated show) I liked this movie. Black Manta honestly was really, really cool in this sequel and the fight scenes that took place in this movie were what I expect superhero films to do more of when it comes to beings going toe-to-toe with super strength. The fight scenes that take place towards the end of the movie is what I was hoping for Ant-Man 3, The Flash, and The Marvels to show us so I appreciate James Wan and everyone else who worked on the editing and fight choreography. After seeing this movie, I wish this wasn't the end of the DCEU, or Jason Momoa's Aquaman. I don't know how Gunn is going to top it, but it will be interesting to see.

Review-Title: Aquaman and the Lost Kingdom review
Review-Description: Thus marking the end of a franchise, albeit in a disappointing manner. I was really disappointed that instead of getting them to cleaning up their act, and make the final entry of DCEU somewhat a better ending, it instead dives into the clich√©s of recent superhero movies, from the cheaply made CGI that served for the purpose of spectacle and nothing more, forced attempts of humor, horrible screenplay. But unlike Shazam 2, Quantumania, and The Flash, Aquaman 2 dig even deeper into the mediocrity, and ends up even worse than than the aforementioned films. Whether the result of reshoots or a genuine lack of scriptwriting competence, hence why the delays of the film releases, the outcome is nonetheless marked by significant amounts of lazy exposition, a hilariously incoherent plot, and cringe-worthy dialogues, painfully delivered by whoever participated in this. If there's anything positive that is worth mentioned, I'd come up with Patrick Wilson and Yahya Abdul-Mateen II. These two are probably the only actors who genuinely committed themselves to their roles in a serious manner. In the midst of this cinematic wreckage, they stand as the only legitimate sources of interest and charisma, delivering performances that are far more than anything this movie deserved. As for the others, I can't say much about them, other than that most of them are fed up with their presented material. And to be honest, I understand why. Overall, my enjoyment of this movie is unfortunately outweighed by my immense disappointment. It's really sad and disheartening that the creative minds behind this debacle abandoned any semblance of effort early in the production. In a proper conclusion, I'm at the point that I'm not enraged, but rather feel sorry of the miserable way to end this franchise.

Review-Title: Not perfect, but has enjoyable moments....
Review-Description: 6.5/10 (Recommend) The "Lost Kingdom" is only marginally better than the first, and not even for the story. A lot of what I liked about this film had to do with the visuals and sound, but I was also happy with the character utilization and development that was offered. There's a lot of flair going on when it comes to the fighting. It doesn't contain the most exhilarating fighting sequences, but it's enough to get my heart racing. While at times they're over the top in terms of what damage can be done to a superhero before they're exhausted. They're still entertaining and spread out enough throughout the film to keep me interested. I loved the soundtrack that went along with the film. It truly enhances the film to greater heights. The intensity of what happens next. The pulsation of the next attack. All of it go hand in hand with the music. Visually, this film is more toned down in terms of colour, but not in the vibrance or darkness when needed. With all the sea creatures that exist, the explosions that occur, and the unreal made real. This film does a perfect job in my eyes in maintaining the integrity of realism for things that are always easy to do, or are always skimmed over. I enjoyed the character utilization and development compared to the first film especially for Patrick Wilson. I didn't like him in the first film, but with better screen time here I do. As a character you can't remove Mera because of the important role she has, but her screen time seems to be less. The story isn't great, but it's not boring. Some aspects seem silly and others unnecessary, but it works out in the end. It's not as clear cut as I would like, but I can still follow what is being put down. Overall, it's still worth checking out, but not in 3D. I know "Lost Kingdom" is getting a lot of mediocre reviews, but it's not the worse superhero movie ever. Good visuals, great music, and enjoyable character development are what has really drawn me in. That's all for now. Thank you for taking the time to read my review. Until next time.... Enjoy the show!

The film through entertainting is confusing as most characters from the first film are reduced to NPCs trying to do overused cinematic tropes like Mera and Atlanna being just there as Aquaman's romantic interest and mother and Thomas Curry and Black Manta and Orm being ripoffs of Uncle Ben and Green Goblin from the Sam Raimi Spider-Man films with a few AI-generated lines and Topo being the cute animal character to sell merch. And despite Arthur narrating the events of the first film in the first seconds there is not much time for people who didn't watch it to know them and most of the sad moments feel fake and you can't really relate to the characters. It ripoffs Thor: The Dark World storyline and some entire sequences along with Star Wars and Lord Of The Rings.

Review-Title: You have got to be kidding...
Review-Description: What on Earth did I just walk in to? I attended Aquaman 2 on New Years Day with my spouse. We both liked the first one (probably I more than her) and thought it was one of the more promising WB/DC franchises but what did I just watch? 2 minutes in and all the red flags were waiving that this was going to be bad. Really bad. The CGI was so inconsistent that some scenes were excellent and others looked like someone filmed a game of Diablo II with a VHS camcorder and shoved it in. The dialogue was possibly the worst I've ever seen in a big budget film. They tried so hard to sell a Thor Ragnarok Loki/Thor buddy film at one point Arthur calls his brother Loki (just in case you didn't get it!)

Review-Title: We enjoyed this movie even more than the first Aquaman installment
Review-Description: My wife and I watched Aquaman and the Lost Kingdom (2023) last night in theaters. The storyline follows Black Manta, still hellbent on revenge, who discovers a forgotten kingdom's trident, granting him powers from beyond the grave. With the ability to attack Atlantis and unleash world-destroying powers, Aquaman must seek the assistance of his imprisoned brother to stop Manta. Directed by James Wan (Saw), the film stars Jason Momoa (Fast X), Patrick Wilson (Hard Candy), Yahya Abdul-Mateen II (Candyman), Amber Heard (Drive Angry), Nicole Kidman (Eyes Wide Shut), and John Rhys-Davies (Lord of the Rings). We enjoyed this movie even more than the first Aquaman installment. The writing is exceptional, maintaining a consistent pace with no breaks in comedy, action, or engaging story set-ups. The well-written dialogue includes fun references to Loki, Prison of Azkaban, and Castaway, providing worthwhile moments of humor. The banter between the brothers throughout the film is entertaining. The special effects, particularly in Atlantis and underwater scenes, are top-notch. Black Manta proves to be a compelling villain, and the story behind his new power is impressive. The action scenes live up to expectations, and the conclusion is a perfect way to wrap up this DC universe. In conclusion, Aquaman and the Lost Kingdom is another remarkable addition to the superhero genre. It's regrettable that this series will be coming to an end. I would score this a 7-7.5/10 and strongly recommend it.

Despite the fact, that this movie is the cotinuation of the first part, the first half hour seems to be relatively disoriented. Besides the narrative, that Aquaman has a family now and is a not so conventional king, there is not much exposition which introduce into the movie. The story is a standard fantasy plot, not really good, but not that bad. However, using the same antagonist from the first movie a second time feels uninspired and boring. All actors provide a good performance, especially Bateman and Momoa, who portray the unequal brothers, have a nice chemistry. Although the movie has its moments, for example the underwater world, it was boring overall.

Boys evenly i also imagine my character into ranbir's character that make this movie more fun. The violence and toxicity is greater than i imagine or also greater than sandeep reddy vanga previous films such as kabir singh but it is fun thing i mean the people should consider it as "just a movie" and don't spread hate about it the Bobby deol,Ranbir singh,Rashmika mandanna,Anil kapoor,Tripti dimri did excellent work and Sandeep reddy vanga also did a excellent work and it is definitely a blockbuster movie and Sandeep reddy vanga should also make movies like this .I am definitely giving it a 10 stars.

Review-Title: One of the best movie Bollywood has ever made!!!
Review-Description: I saw this movie's trailer almost 20 times because it gave a very different vibe which I usually don't get by watching any trailer. And I knew it from that day that this movie is something different and I was super excited about this movie and yesss, when i watched this movie, my godddd!!!!!, what a movie. Every single minute was filled with excitement of what's coming next, even after being so long it made me fill like "I want more!!". And I know people have a very different opinion on this movie and a lot of controversies going around that, and even in my family my sisters, my cousins,y uncle, they didn't like the movie but that's alright cause everybody have a different opinion but I will just say that this movie completed me like I'm not even exaggerating, after watching this movie this movie i feeled like I was missing on something or just somthing was incompleted which got completed, like this is so new so different and so my type, and if have this kind of taste in movie you are gonna lovvveeee thisss movie, like everything is so perfect, Ranbir Kapoor's acting my goddd, he is the best, then the OG Anil kapoor sir and Bobby deol killed it, everyone was so perfect. And this movie is the best.

I totally agree there is a message to a father who is been loved by a son.. However the movie has lots of violence and adult scenes which seems to be a bad impact on the viewers.... My message to the director is please reduce the exposure and violence a movie should always be an entertainment and a message oriented. I am sure if you consider the above suggestion .. You will certainly come up with a movie which would be loved by many viewers.. The younger generation has to learn the reality of life let's not make them more cynical.please think about this on a serious note a friendly advise to the director.

Awesome screenplay and actors nailed it throughout the movie. Cinematography plays a crucial role in a film's visual style and storytelling. Delve into the camera work, lighting, photography, and framing, evaluating how these elements enhance or detract from the movie's overall impact. Consider how the cinematography supports the film's themes and emotions. The director is the creative force behind a film, responsible for shaping its vision and execution. Analyze the director's choices, considering their impact on the film's storytelling, pacing, and overall atmosphere. Reflect on the director's previous work, if applicable, and how this film fits into their role.

I personally find a connection with the theme of the film which is the bond between a son and a father. It has been a tough bond with told and untold feelings, complaints and sorrows. Still they are one in the name of family. Ranbir's character was a trure Sigma family Man. Who atleast doesn't belong to our gendu GenZ generation. He loves his family, he cares about her sisters, his village and his brothers, he is responsible for the family and business after his father....... The revenge part was totally justified. The action was up to the mark of excellence. Don't get into the sold reviews of Leftists and Feminists! They are the only ones who got bullied (or even hurt) by this movie. It's not a typical b'wood movie, it's a Sandeep Reddy Vanga Movie. I only dislike 3 things 1- The old man character of Ranbir, skin show of the females (which was there only for 10 minutes, I can ignore this for a 3.30 hr long film) and Ranbir's Chain smoking. At last but not the least, Tripti Dimri doesn't deserve what she is getting. I loved her earlier characters but now I hate her. Now go watch this movie in theatres!

Review-Title: A Deceptive Mirage Veiled in Misogyny
Review-Description: From the outset, the film captivates with its stunning cinematography, drawing the audience into a world shrouded in mystery and intrigue. The narrative unfolds around a male protagonist whose charisma masks a sinister agenda, a trope that perpetuates the insidious belief that charm excuses reprehensible behavior. However, this very charm is wielded as a tool of manipulation, effectively gaslighting both characters within the story and the unsuspecting audience. One of the most distressing elements of "Shadows of Deception" is its endorsement of misogynistic ideals, disguised within the plot. The female characters, regrettably reduced to mere plot devices or caricatures, are subject to objectification and belittlement. Their portrayal reinforces outdated and damaging stereotypes, detracting from any semblance of a progressive storyline. A fiction, as an art form, should not serve as a vessel to perpetuate regressive attitudes or normalize the denigration of any gender. Moreover, the action sequences, while initially promising to elevate the narrative, instead derail it, plunging the audience into an over-the-top spectacle that disrupts the flow of the story. The incessant barrage of high-octane sequences overwhelms, eclipsing the depth that could have been cultivated within the plot and character development. The constant bombardment of action undermines any potential for emotional investment, leaving the audience detached and disengaged. The film's direction and screenplay, though attempting to weave an intricate web of suspense, ultimately falter in their execution. The convoluted narrative fails to offer substantive explanations or resolutions, leaving audiences perplexed and unsatisfied. The promise of a gripping storyline devolves into a labyrinth of confusion, leaving viewers grappling for coherence amidst the chaos.

Review-Title: Sick dark movie but actors did their part well
Review-Description: This is a dark, depressing and psychopath movie. I am not surprised by many +ve reviews as these kind of movies are liked by a section of people. Just did not imagine so many people are in that section. Simply put in one sentence , this is a manifestation of a writers and directors sick, perverted , violent and dark mind, venting their inadequacies. I believe movies are meant for relaxation, entertainment and appreciation of art. This movie does just a little bit appreciation for art, Acting of Ranbir, Rashmika, Anil Kapoor and may be Sunny Deol too is very good. Nothing much else to take from this.

Review-Title: Don't miss the post credit scene
Review-Description: Entertained throughout the 3 hours duration time, Ranbir kapoor nailed every scene, in some scenes he reminded me of Rauf lala (played by Late Mr. Rishi kapoor) He just reminded everyone why he is considered the best actor of this generation. Powerful fight sequence with songs playing in the background was a masterpiece by Sandeep Reddy vanga. Don't pay any attention to the critics, they can't digest the audacity of Sandeep Reddy vanga, putting in simple words. Highly recommended if you like movies like kill bill, john vick and please don't miss the credit scenes, it's crazy. Bobby Deol with a short role gave a massive performance. Loved other cast members as well.

Review-Title: This is the best movie ever made in Bollywood.
Review-Description: Perfect Direction, Brilliant Father son story, Great acting, Phenomenal movie.. A Must watch movie. This type of movies should be promoted rather than those love stories made in Bollywood. Amazing songs sung by B praak, sonu nigam specially that papa meri jaan song absolutely brilliant lyrics it has. Great acting by ranbir kapoor till now, Action VFX is also amazing, Family love brothers everyone come together to defeat the enemy. Love should be in between mother and father rather than girlfriend wife. To summarise i would say and appeal to continue making these type of movies that show love between mother and father.

I went in with zero expectations and sat through a 3.5 hour movie without touching my phone. The plot was truly refreshing. I am tired of seeing the classic heroic Bollywood movies where the hero can never be wrong. Vanga truly uncovers a beast. Ranbir Kapoor is shown to be an "animal", with some signs showing in his childhood and teenage years but really unraveling in his adulthood after a major incident. From then on, what Ranbir does is beyond imaginable. Ranbir is not shown to be a hero - he does barbaric things, goes back on his words, and doesn't respect anyone in his life. Folks who are crying about Ranbir's role really think all movie heroes are to be admired. Everyone's acting was phenomenal. Bobby Deol was GREAT, what a comeback. The interval sequence was a pleasure to watch, even though I am usually not a big fan of large action sequences. The music is great. I just wish the second half was not as dragged. I am not a big fan of Tripti Dimri's sequence. It was unnecessary and only added for the sequel. It is also funny that there is no sign of a police offer or law enforcement throughout the movie despite all the violence. But overall this was a refreshing movie. Must watch!

Movie Title: The Hunger Games: The Ballad of Songbirds & Snakes (2023)
Review-Title: A Cinematic Triumph - The Hunger Games: The Ballad of Songbirds and Snakes
Review-Description: "The Hunger Games: The Ballad of Songbirds and Snakes" delivers a cinematic masterpiece that not only pays homage to its source material but also stands on its own as a compelling and visually stunning addition to the Hunger Games film series. Director Francis Lawrence skillfully brings Suzanne Collins's prequel to life on the big screen, capturing the essence of the Capitol's opulence and the grittiness of the districts. The film seamlessly weaves together a gripping narrative, striking visuals, and outstanding performances, resulting in a movie that surpasses expectations. The casting choices are impeccable, with Tom Blyth giving a standout performance as the complex and morally ambiguous Coriolanus Snow. The evolution of the character is portrayed with depth and nuance, adding layers to one of the franchise's most iconic figures. The supporting cast, including Rachel Zegler, Peter Dinklage and Hunter Schafer delivers stellar performances that enhance the overall storytelling. Visually, the film is a feast for the eyes. The Capitol's extravagance and the stark contrast with the districts are brought to life through breathtaking cinematography and impeccable production design. The reimagined Hunger Games arena is both awe-inspiring and menacing, creating a heightened sense of tension and excitement. The pacing is on point, keeping the audience engaged from start to finish. The film successfully balances action-packed sequences with quieter moments of character development, allowing viewers to connect emotionally with the story. The soundtrack, composed by James Newton Howard, complements the film perfectly, enhancing the overall cinematic experience. What sets "The Ballad of Songbirds and Snakes" apart is its ability to delve into the complexities of power, morality, and survival, all while delivering a thrilling and visually captivating spectacle. The film doesn't shy away from the darker themes present in the source material, providing a thought-provoking and immersive experience for both longtime fans and newcomers to the Hunger Games universe. In conclusion, "The Hunger Games: The Ballad of Songbirds and Snakes" is a triumph in filmmaking. It not only expands and enriches the Hunger Games saga but also stands as a testament to the creative talent involved in its production. This movie deserves a solid 10/10 for its outstanding performances, breathtaking visuals, and its ability to captivate audiences with a story that is both thrilling and intellectually stimulating.

Movie Title: The Hunger Games: The Ballad of Songbirds & Snakes (2023)
Review-Description: They didn't allow time for suspense in so many moments, the whole thing felt rushed like it should have been two films. I appreciate it's a long film but that's because they were trying to do too much all in one film. Some of the actors were over the top and theatrical rather than displaying substance which was surprising considering the big names in this movie. Some big names in this film yet they disappointed us as they really felt to of lacked depth. I've seen them in films where they have been truly astounding yet they fell flat here. I can't help but wonder if it's because of how rushed this was, you didn't have time to become invested in any of the characters. The previous hunger games reallly felt powerful and hit a nerve, this felt showy and lacking in depth. On a positive note I liked the singing and the female lead, I just wish they given her more time to provide suspense in many moments instead of rushing through. The scene with the snakes was fantastic.

Movie Title: The Hunger Games: The Ballad of Songbirds & Snakes (2023)
Review-Title: Not true to the book - book spoilers
Review-Description: All the hunger games movies have some differences to the book but I think this one has the most, so much that it sort of tells a different story. The actors did a great job but the story felt rushed and the characters 1 Dimensional. The tributes seem a lot more vicious in the movie, consequently sending a message like Dr. Gauls reasoning was justified. Even with that, the ending where Snow ultimately ending agreeing with Dr. Gaul's lesson seems forced. While I saw the similarity between Coral's character and Cato, (which admittedly tugged at the heart strings) I think the original writing of the tributes was better. The part of the movie featuring the tributes lacked a lot of the empathy from the writers and characters, which showed a bit more humanity in the book. Coriolanus's charm and calculation, Sejanus's kindness, and Lucy Gray's wit, caution, and consideration seemed lost in the movie. Coriolanus's and Lucy Gray's romance lacked foundation. They have this connection and trust that's slowly built in the book that isn't seen in the movie, as if it were an after thought. They both seem more concerned with self preservation but Lucy Gray significantly more so from the start. This seemed to be done purposely to move the story along but this was a mistake in my opinion. Her demands in the cage and to Coriolanus, her defensiveness when Mayfair is shot. It's a lot different than her character in the book who is capable and independent but equally selfless and caring. The book highlighted how elusive and fierce Lucy Gray could be during the hunger games and this also seemed lost in the movie. I really wish the actual hunger games had played out closer to the book than the movie. The movie would've been much better had they taken this first part of the book a bit more slowly. In the book, there doesn't seem to be any moment where Coriolanus changes whereas in the movie it seems to be in the Arena and then more so in the Forest after being bitten. The part where Tigris tells Coriolanus that he's still good seemed very useless in the movie and I wish it was taken out. The book makes Coriolanus seem more human because of how we can see Coriolanus teetering on what's right and wrong. The movie doesn't show his true thoughts on his born superiority to the people of the districts and the influence the society around him has on that. That is something I think could've easily been shown more to give him some depth to his character. The contrast between what he thinks and does vs what he says is what kept my intrigue the most throughout the book and its entirely missing in the movie. Also throughout the book, you wonder whether his feelings towards Lucy Gray are genuine (and I personally leaned towards that they were) but its very unconvincing in the movie until the near end. A weird part of the movie to get invested in a relationship that is a main plot. Coriolanus's little considerations in the choices he makes aren't shown and so his character seems robotic. It seems more like things simply keep happening to him rather than him having choices and consequence. Sejanus comes off educated, reckless, and bold in the movie as he should but he lacks the same kindness that he does in the book. Not showing him bringing all the tributes sandwiches or his support and true consideration for Coriolanus in District 12 made Coriolanus's betrayal and Sejanus's death less shocking. Where Coriolanus calls Sejanus his brother was a part that truly could've helped this in the movie. Sejanus's death was disturbing in the movie because hangings are disturbing but not because of what his character meant. I think the scene of Coriolanus crying over their picture together could've been scrapped all together had they emphasized their relationship throughout. Instead, the scene where he is crying is where it finally shows how much it affects Coriolanus. A scene I think was just blatantly bad was unfortunately where Lucy Gray and Coriolanus are in the Cabin after deserting District 12. Lucy Gray spells out the situation and even asks him if he's going to leave, which she doesn't in the book. I wish there would've been more faith in the audience to put this together, it would've been more impactful and really shown their character more. Instead everything was spelled out in big letters across the screen. Coriolanus holding the gun menacingly, Lucy Gray just standing in the corner for no apparent reason watching him, Lucy Gray basically asking to be murdered 3 times with one foot out the door before she finally leaves. Coriolanus just continuing on with what he was doing as if her distrust at this point wasn't blatantly obvious. It was truly ridiculous. This scene really took away from a lot of her mystique and again, her wit, Lucy Gray being unable to calmly, quietly and quickly put the puzzle together as she did in the book. I do think the very ending, where Coriolanus returns to Dean Highbottom was the best. Peter Dinklage and Viola Davis were excellent and so were the portrayal of their characters. I left the theatre hearing people around me describe the movie as "corny". I thought this was fair thinking it was possibly just all the Snow metaphors and still thinking I enjoyed the movie nonetheless. However after further reflection it was probably just how shallow the story seemed. After I read the book I was obviously disappointed in the movie because the book was incredible. I believe if the movie needed to be longer, it should've been a little longer. This being a surprising prequel to a popular triology, it had the right to be. If impossible, I still think there are a lot of changes that could've been made and retained the same runtime while having the same impact as the book. While the movie was enjoyable, I wish more credit was given to the audience in being able to understand this story instead of creating a relatively shallow movie with a morally questionable lesson.

Movie Title: The Hunger Games: The Ballad of Songbirds & Snakes (2023)
Review-Description: Reading the novel before the movie was the perfect choice! The movie honors Collin's captivating writing. Knowing the world from the original series made the cinematic choices exciting, which speaks to the whole production team's thoughtfulness. The capitol's depiction is beyond what I pictured in my mind while reading. Davis and Blyth kept me GLUED to the screen by their acting performances and on screen appearance - props to their makeup, hair, and wardrobe team! Jason did a great Lucky in this serious movie - it is commendable to bring humor to a dystopian world! I enjoyed going to the movies with my fellow Hunger Game fan friends (even though we really missed Peeta)! It brought back great memories!

Movie Title: The Hunger Games: The Ballad of Songbirds & Snakes (2023)
Review-Description: The first act was really interesting because we are reintroduced to Panem in a more realistic but different but familiar light. Lucy Gray is a true performer and just in luck that's exactly what they needed to keep the games going. Highbottom and Dr. Gaul are seen as the dark and light symbols of the path Snow's fate is subject to. While all the characters are pretty transparent about their intentions, their values change and grow overtime and their means to the end are seen as what makes them who they are. I love that the story mimics a lot of the songs that were sung. It makes me wonder what a musical based on the Hunger Games universe would look and sound like. The ending leaves a lot of questions for the audience and I hope this is a standalone movie. The song with the scene about lucy gray and the katniss is enough for all of us to assume or imagine how things turned out. Including Snow asking Tigris what she thinks. While I don't change my views towards Snow despite hearing his story, I find it interesting that he builds up so much resentment for the world because of a girl. While this is realistic and it's happened before, it's a fascinating notion that he hates Katniss Everdeen and the districts so much because a girl broke his heart.

Movie Title: The Hunger Games: The Ballad of Songbirds & Snakes (2023)
Review-Title: Character motivations and actions are nonsensical
Review-Description: If the hunger games was all about fascist myth making and how people just come to accept it as the new way of life, why would the protagonist be less angry 10 years into the new order than 75 years? When injustice is a new, people are supposed to be more angry, less accepting of it. Katniss was appropriately angry and defiant, whereas Lucy Gray was immediately giddy (i guess we are meant to interpret it as hippie freespirit i-love-all-peoples charm), and flirting with an agent of the state that has literally reaped her into an arena to kill her. Think of how much it would take to justify why a Jewish girl might even consider thinking of an SS soldier in a romantic light, and how little this story did to that end. The trust and romance between two characters from opposing sides of a fascist occupation has to OVERCOME that very tall barrier to earn any Rebel's trust. However even though the fact that Snow is doing it for personal gain was established, it was kind of ignored to continue this bizzare unearned romance. I am also okay with the premise that not every person in a fascist system is born evil, and showing the descent of a regular citizen into this kind of evil. However, living and participating every day in a fascist state has to impact your soul that ends up showing in small ways, casual dehuminisation of the Panem citizens, growing paranoia as the bombs start, disdain for the rebels etc. Which other characters in the academy and Grandma Snow does. But exceptionally, Snow was shown to be upstanding and moral throughout the movie except in the end with a abrupt descent into betraying his friend, all the while romancing a Panem citizen outside the district borders. It was so forced, and why?? We already knew that Snow would become evil, so why not show us how it happened in a believable manner (maybe show that his time as a peacekeeper interacting with D12 citizens allowed him to dehumanize them or something..), instead of rushing it as a "twist" at the very end of a very long movie? Every story in THG was a self contained plot that will be developed upon it, but this one felt like a botched incomplete story to that is built as a premise for sequels to the prequel.

Movie Title: The Hunger Games: The Ballad of Songbirds & Snakes (2023)
Review-Title: Well.. just no... Teenage movie at best
Review-Description: I'm writing this review only because Jason Schwartzman deserves to be mentioned. In his role he is just brilliant, so thanks for at least his performance. The casting for Snow was also not bad, but the rest of the actors can be forgotten. Above all, we couldn't stand the calling of 'Lucy Gray' after what felt like the 100th time. We're generally not big fans of singing in movies, but these songs were placed so tactlessly that it felt like imitating a Disney film. The only suspenseful part is in the last section of the movie - precisely when it ends.! It seems like the whole movie is made for teenagers. Overexplained and repetitive scenes dominate. We're glad we didn't watch the film in the cinema.

Movie Title: The Hunger Games: The Ballad of Songbirds & Snakes (2023)
Review-Title: Good movie adaption, not as good as the novel by a longshot
Review-Description: It wasn't bad, but not half as good as the novel. Many things are left out, other things are portrayed differently. Considering that adapting such a complex story is really difficult, I think they did quite a good job. Pacing was too fast obviously, which isn't surprising, a running time of 158 minutes just isn't enough to cover the 500+ pages the right way. I really liked Peter Dinklage as Highbottom, he did a brilliant job imo. The portrayal of Snow and Lucy Gray's love story seemed rush and unfitting. Yes, Rachel Zegler might not be the most likeable person, but I think it's stupid to review this movie based solely on how much you dislike Zegler. I highly recommend everyone to read the novel, doesn't matter if you enjoyed the movie or not.

Movie Title: The Hunger Games: The Ballad of Songbirds & Snakes (2023)
Review-Description: Until the end I tried to understand what this movie was supposed to be about. Unfortunately the creators left that question open. The female main actress had no purpose other than singing, looking suspicious (with no reason eventually) and the main actor focused on staring into the void most of the time, making very very unlogical decisions and flipping his mind like a burger patty. Real disappointment and big waste of time. I thought till the end, there must be a conclusion, something connecting the dots. But they left the dots as they were. Far too long, no story, bad acting, boring. If you expect something like the originals, stay away. And if you happen to understand the story, let me know.

Movie Title: The Hunger Games: The Ballad of Songbirds & Snakes (2023)
Review-Description: From the first moment, this movie just offers more questions than answers or any kind of plot-thread. And after around 15mins the movie-destroyer Snowwhite/Zegler appears and starts singing... really, no joke! Random people join in like its a flashmob or something and my fingers twitched to save my brain from this horses**t. I gave it another 15min and then I really had to stop it. The CGI is just awful, explosions, animals, nothing makes sense. People burn and 2mins later they're like nothing happened. My condolences to all other actors in this movie who might ruined their careers, be doomed to b-movie for the rest of their lives because of the "Zegler Musical".

Review-Title: A Classic Action Thriller that Sets the Bar High
Review-Description: Die Hard, released in 1988, is an explosive rollercoaster ride that sets the benchmark for action thrillers. From heart-pounding moments to unforgettable one-liners, this film is an adrenaline-fueled spectacle that keeps you on the edge of your seat throughout. Bruce Willis delivers a career-defining performance as the iconic John McClane, a New York cop caught up in a terrorist takeover of a Los Angeles skyscraper during a Christmas party. Willis effortlessly blends vulnerability with sheer determination, making McClane a relatable and immensely likable protagonist. His quick wit and resourcefulness add an extra layer of charm to this character, making him a true action hero for the ages. The film's pacing is impeccable, ensuring that there is never a dull moment. The tension builds gradually, as McClane finds himself outnumbered and outgunned against the ruthless terrorist leader, Hans Gruber, portrayed masterfully by the late Alan Rickman in his breakout role. Rickman's portrayal is chilling, as he exudes intelligence and sophistication while remaining utterly menacing. Die Hard's screenplay is expertly crafted, with sharp dialogue and a well-structured plot that keeps you engaged from start to finish. The action set-pieces are jaw-dropping, with director John McTiernan's meticulous attention to detail evident in every explosive sequence. The film's iconic moments, such as McClane's daring leap off the Nakatomi Plaza rooftop or his brutal cat-and-mouse encounter with Gruber, have become legendary within the genre. The supporting cast also shines, with standout performances from Bonnie Bedelia as McClane's estranged wife Holly, Reginald VelJohnson as the sympathetic Sergeant Al Powell, and Alexander Godunov as the formidable henchman Karl. Each actor brings depth and nuance to their characters, elevating the overall quality of the film. While Die Hard may be over three decades old, its impact on the action genre remains unparalleled. Its influence can be seen in countless films that followed, making it a true game-changer in the industry. The film's ability to blend intense action with genuine emotional stakes is a testament to its enduring appeal. In conclusion, Die Hard is a classic that continues to entertain and captivate audiences to this day. Its stellar performances, thrilling action, and well-crafted screenplay make it a must-watch for any fan of the genre. With its unforgettable characters and iconic moments, Die Hard has solidified its place in cinematic history. The chemistry between Bruce Willis and Alan Rickman is electric, creating a dynamic cat-and-mouse game that keeps you hooked until the very end.

Review-Title: Classic 80s action flick still holds up
Review-Description: A friend rented out a theater the week before Christmas for a big screen viewing of this holiday classic (I dressed up like a minor character Uli) and it was fantastic to get to see this on the big screen once again and with an audience, which I hadn't experienced since high school when I saw it in the theater with my dad back when the movie first came out. The crowd was filled with quite a few twenty-somethings who'd never seen the film before (which seems unbelievable to this old Gen-Xer) but that made it even more fun to experience the film with an audience laughing and reacting to all the right parts in this almost 40-year-old movie! Everyone laughed at Theo and Karl betting in the background whether Mr. Takagi could give up the computer passcode or when Asian terrorist Uli takes a candy bar out of the display case. You could feel the audience squirm as John McClane pulled glass out of his feet. They laughed at all the right parts and cheered at all the right moments. It reminded me of how movies are best enjoyed as a communal experience. When DIE HARD first came out, everyone rolled their eyes at Bruce Willis being an action hero. Up until that point, action heroes were musclebound unstoppable he-men along the lines of Stallone and Schwarzenegger. Sure there were some non-musclebound ones too, like Clint Eastwood or Harrison Ford, but they were certainly not comedians, which is what Bruce Willis was primarily known for at this time. Before DIE HARD, he was really only known for the hit TV series MOONLIGHTING (if you haven't seen it, it's on Hulu right now) and one Blake Edwards comedy (which wasn't a box office hit). The studio originally offered the part of McClane to Stallone and Schwarzenegger, but the film is a classic because of Willis. He made McClane a vulnerable character, who does get hurt and who could be killed. Willis eventually became an unstoppable action hero like Sly and Arnold, which may be lost on audiences watching this film for the first time now, but back then, Willis was just that goofy guy from TV trying the best he could to save people from bad guys. But I haven't said anything about DIE HARD itself. Everyone knows the story, so I won't summarize it here, but if you somehow have never seen it before, stop what you're doing right now and watch it! Bruce Willis is effortlessly funny, vulnerable, and heroic all at the same time, which is a nice contrast to most action heroes of the 80s who would only wisecrack one-liners and would never dare to be self-deprecating. Though as great as Willis is, Alan Rickman steals every scene he's in as lead bad guy Hans Gruber. He gets some great lines and character touches from the script, like complimenting Mr. Takagi on his suit or when he pretends to be a hostage, but it's Rickman's refined air that elevates the film. The class Rickman brings to his character is a fun contrast to Willis' blue-collar hero. And what a killer supporting cast, that includes Reginald VelJohnson as Sgt. Al Powell, Paul Gleason playing another jerk, this time the clueless Deputy Police Commissioner, William Atherton as a nasty TV reporter, Hart Bochner as a coke-snorting executive, Alexander Gudunov as terrorist Karl, the great Al Leong (you've seen him in just about every iconic 80s action film), Robert Davi & Grand L. Bush as Agents Johnson and Johnson, and De'voreaux White as Argyle, who I don't remember from anything else, but who was apparently in THE BLUES BROTHERS and TRESPASS when I looked him up on IMDB. DIE HARD is a a witty and clever script from Steven E. De Souza and Jeb Stuart, who both mostly write passable dreck unless their films were made by solid directors like Walter Hill (48HRS), Andrew Davis (THE FUGITIVE), or John McTiernan here with DIE HARD, so I'm giving McTiernan credit to making this film what it is. Credit also has to go to ace cinematographer Jan de Bont, who shot such classics as BLACK RAIN, THE HUNT FOR RED OCTOBER, and BASIC INSTINCT, and would later go on to direct himself, with SPEED being his one standout film. Top it all off with a memorable score by 80s mainstay composter Michael Kaman (LETHAL WEAPON, THE DEAD ZONE, ADVENTURES IN BABYSITTING, HIGHLANDER, BRAZIL, etc.) and you have the makings for a classic. Overall, DIE HARD is an absolute 80s action classic, and yes, DIE HARD is a Christmas movie!

Die hard is known to be one of the most iconic and revolutionary action movies ever, which is certainly true. It revolutionised the action genre as a whole. And it was a pretty well made action movie at that. It definitely wasn't the flawless movie that everyone makes it out to be. Alan Rickman as Hans grubber Is a phenomenal preformance and deserves to go down as one of the best villian preformance. However I can't say Bruce Willis gave that great a preformance. I believe as a result started the whole genre of average action movies with lackluster acting. Was a good movie but nothing special. 8/10.

This is a classic action movie that I have watch and is enjoyable. I do like how it's about a cop have to go against a terrorist group in a skyscraper. The movie is build up really well by introducing each of the characters and who they are. I really enjoyed each of the characters like John McClane, Al Powell, and Argyle who have fun personality to them and have development. Also, the acting is done really well by each of the actors and it looks like they have a fun time in the movie. The villains are also pretty great with them being threating and the performance by each one of them. The action are both enjoyable and suspenseful with John fighting against the villain and him trying to survive in the movie. He comes up with a lot of good ideas in order to survive and is pretty smart throughout. It also gets thrilling when the explosion happened and it looks great. Overall its a fun movie to watch on Christmas.

Review-Title: The movie that made Bruce Willis an action star!
Review-Description: Die Hard is the perfect late 80's action film with great villains, plenty of action, and solid dialogue from our hero. It's everything you want in a Summer action flick even though Die Hard gets the debate that it's actually a Christmas film. Make no mistake this is not a Christmas film but an action film set during Christmas. There should be no debate on this but every Christmas it comes up. Die Hard was the launching pad for making Bruce Willis the action star that he became. In fact I miss action films like this that had plenty of action scenes and explosions that were practical. In todays World we get plenty of CGI fight scenes and over the top action. Die Hard is an action classic from the 80's and gets a very high 9 stars out of 10 from me.

"Die Hard" is perhaps the quintessential action film for the Christmas season. Where most Christmas films had opted for the predictably warm and fuzzy, and still often do; director John McTiernan had introduced a landmark infusion of action to the monotone Christmas genre, whilst still managing to keep the Christmas spirit well intact, in its own way. It's become a household classic ever since and conveys the importance of fighting against all odds, even when others doubt you. And that situations are felt most clearly by those with their feet firmly planted on the ground; John McClane's barefooted ordeals reflect this message. It's a celebration of the streetwise and the grounded underdog. Bruce Willis's breakout role as the irreverent and muscled NYPD copper John McClane was eminently career-defining, and quite possibly one of the most strikingly masculine chainsmoking protagonists of film history. A triangle of witty repartees between McClane, Sgt. Al Powell (Reginald VelJohnson), and Alan Rickman's flamboyant classically-educated West German villain, Hans Gruber, creates both tension and levity at the film's close-quarters setting, Nakatomi Plaza; as a high-octane game of cat-and-mouse unfolds. You'll also be graced by one of the most iconic one-liner catchphrases; "Yippee-ki-yay..." part of cinema lore's lexicon, and for which no caption is needed for further explanation. However a reviewer at the time of release had backhandedly suggested it as a "nearly perfect movie for our time", yet designed to appeal to audiences they'd described as "kidults"-adults with the mindset of children. Nonetheless, McTiernan masterfully combines brains, heart, and brawn in thrillingly explosive action sequences and soulful character development whilst not granting any character the privileges of infallibility or invulnerability. The film combines three subplots to form the overall plot meaning there's plenty going on at any one time and a lot of reasons to stay invested in this film for its full runtime, and to prompt repeat viewings. Deemed "culturally, historically, or aesthetically significant" by the United States Library of Congress, Die Hard was selected for preservation in the National Film Registry in 2017. An all-round blast. 8.1/10.

Review-Title: The best action movie to watch either on Christmas or anytime!
Review-Description: After watching this film with my family of four; my Mum, Dad, Brother Jordy & me for the first time on Christmas Eve here's my spoiler-free review of the original Die Hard! As usual, I'll be talking about my thoughts, my favourite moments of watching it and my Conclusion/rating! Bruce Willis stars in this action thriller that still holds up 35 years later, this was Alan Rickman's first movie he played the bad guy Hans Gruber we still miss the beloved actor to this day R. I. P. The action scenes & special effects are so cool and entertaining, even though this film was set during Christmas time it's not a Christmas movie it was released in Australia back on October 6! Overall It's going to be very interesting to watch the other 3 Die Hard sequels I don't think I'll watch Die Hard 5 but I look forward to it! That's why I'm giving this an 8/10! I enjoyed this so much that I'm excited to see the next films! Merry Christmas everyone! ;-)

Action, check. Christmas themes, check. Realistic action hero, check. Man, if it wasn't for Die Hard, action movies would have never evolved. It's the best Christmas and action movie ever. It never gets old and it still lives up to it's hype after all these years. So if you want a fun, action packed movie that brings action on ever level then give this movie your undivided attention. And of course, it provides you with one of the most iconic villains in film history. The late Alan Rickman delivers one of the best and iconic roles as the main villain. With much humor, Christmas level excitement and some of the most iconic quotes movie lines in history, Die Hard brings it. And brings it hard..

FILM: 10/10. Die Hard, a film that needs no introduction, is one of those rare action gems that effortlessly earns top marks in my book. From characters to performances, it's a cinematic masterpiece. Bruce Willis is an absolute blast, seamlessly blending action and comedy while embodying the everyman charm of his character. His improvised wisecracks hit the mark, adding an authentic layer of humour that elevates the film to legendary status. Alan Rickman, the epitome of class, crafts a three-dimensional action movie villain, a worthy adversary to Willis. Not to be overshadowed, Reginald VelJohnson owns his role with confidence, delivering classic lines that linger long after the credits roll. While Bonnie Bedelia has her moments, she's somewhat underutilised in this ensemble cast. Yet, the film's template for crafting a thrilling, smart, and endlessly entertaining action flick is unparalleled, inspiring countless imitators over three decades. Action and drama are seamlessly woven together, hitting all the right beats. The film's quotability is off the charts, a testament to razor-sharp writing and John McTiernan's directorial finesse. From start to finish, not a single misstep occurs. The cast and crew flawlessly deliver this bonafide classic, making its healthy runtime breeze by. Die Hard is the Christmas movie that never fails to grace my screen each year, marking the true start of the festive season. Now that Hans Gruber has had his fall, Christmas can officially begin, and the tradition of revisiting this cinematic masterpiece continues unabated. A true classic that's more than earned its place in the action movie hall of fame - and in my heart. FORMAT: 4K Ultra HD Blu-ray VIDEO: 8.5/10. Native 4K presentation, Detail level: Good, Colour reproduction: Good, Level accuracy: Good, Encode: Excellent, Master condition: Good AUDIO: 8/10. DTS-HD MA 5.1 audio, Dialogue reproduction: Good, Soundtrack & effects clarity: Good, Dynamics: Good, Surround sound presentation: Good, LFE content: Good MOOFIEMETER: 10/10.

The 80s was peak time for action movies and action movie stars. Die Hard is certainly on of the greatest 80s action movies, possibly one of the greatest ever action movies, definitely the greatest Christmas movie and perhaps one of the greatest movies ever made. It's a movie about love, friendship, brotherhood, forgiveness, reconciliation and enough C4 to warp Arnold Schwarzenegger. There's Rudolph and Frostie, mulled wine and a nice aged Brie, Christmas music and presents galore. One present is the surprise gift of Bruce Willis as an action star. Bit of a gamble at the time and it worked out as wonderfully as a home baked mince pie. Another gift was the sight of Alan Rickman making his big screen debut and absolutely smashing out the greatest villain in Hollywood history. The dialogue is quotable, the action terrific, the characters are either likeable or detestable exactly as they're supposed to be and I absolutely defy anyone to watch Die Hard and not try to walk around on the rug, barefoot and make fists with your toes. Anyone who says this isn't a Christmas movie is like the product of an unholy union of Ebeneezer Scrooge and the grinch. Beyond the obvious Christmas themes this movie was way ahead of its time in exploring capitalism, the media and US foreign policy and its more of a Christmas tradition in my house than Turkey.

Review-Title: Very Interesting Story and suspens is still there in this movie.
Review-Description: At start of this movie it might look fake and over fear of Deva in the mind of people's. But after interval and till end of this part I realised that The Fear Is very very Real. And All starcast Did more than Expectations. Story of this movie is mind blowing within one single watch of this movie we can't understand it. Anyone who loves this kind of movies they should watch this movie Twice. I promise your your money will not be wasted. It will worth watching this movie Twice and It will be very easy to understand its next part. Vardha's Patience is at another level even he is son of King. Sruti can be better.

Review-Title: Not a good movie/ The worst movie
Review-Description: For a starter normally there should be a difference between super hero movie and action movie. Now this movie this movie breaks that barrier where he literally obiletrates everyone with unreasonable fight like every bad guy (goons) will have Parkinsons (disease that makes people tremble all the time) every damn time when someone mentions about khansar or the seal . There is no emotions in hero's face we literally can't say either he is angry or normal or just bad acting. The fights are really boring. As a conclusion a bad dragging storyline with nothing to expect in the second part rather than another boring meaningless fight. Movie name should be low budget Maptain America.

If I say correclty Salaar is the son who born for KGF from Bahubali. Director glorifying Prabhas as an extra ordinarily strong man who can able to fight alone with the best army troops of seven or eight nuclear countries. No goosebump scenes,No sensible story,No romance,No good songs,No dance. Prabhas first cuts off the hand and then chops off the head of a villain in the middle of a fully armoured Military force with in a court room and neither the military nor the other villains move a single finger against him. With just one shoot they could have ended him and that would have been a relax for the audience from this torture. When they are sent to kill all along prabhas,Prabhas demands a tattoo artist to do tattooing a symbol in his arm by standing near the sharpness of the villain's big knief. Without any doubt I can say that Prasanth Neel's story collection has ended with KGF1 and I strongly suggest that no one should watch his films by hype and If you do, you will repent like me later.

Too much waste of time for the projection for the hero. And he does almost nothing great. 1st half was good created lot of curiosity but 2nd part falls flat. No story revealed, seems like Director wanted to drag it more longer than TV serials like a chewing gum. Was expecting a lot from secong half, but alas . Throughout the movie you get reminded of KGf because of the same type of screen play , kids talking about the hero and group trying to entice him . Even the music feels like the same at some parts. It's better to avoid it in theatres and watch it in OTT as there is nothing so special in the this part.

Review-Title: An Action Saga Which Brings Back The Euphoria Of PRA-BOSS,With A World Building...
Review-Description:
So I Finally Watched One Of The Most Anticipated Movie 'Salaar' Starring REBEL STAR Prabhas,Prithviraj Sukuruman In Main Leads Written And Directed By Prashant Neel. So If You Ask Me To Define My Experience In One Line It's One Man Show Prabhas Show,With A Perfect Neel's Elevating Screenplay. So Coming To The Plot A Gang Leader Tries To Keep A Promise Made To His Dying Friend And Takes On The Other Criminal Gangs. So Going In Detail,The Film's First Half Was Fast,Engaging With Racy Screenplay And Ends With A Bang Interval And In Second Half,Film Enters Into Main Conflict Which Is World Building,Establishing The Characters Of 'KHANSAAR' And Its Politics,And With A Powerful Climax With A Big Reveal. So Coming To Performances,As Said Its One Man Show,Prabhas's Show. He Just Killed With His Screen Presence,'DEVA' A Character Which Will Be Registered In Masses For A Long Time,A Character Which Brings Out The Prabhas That Was Eagerly Urged By Everyone. Coming To Prithviraj Sukumaran He Was Phenomenal In His Role,Playing 'Vardaraja Mannar' The Emotional Balance Carried Throughout The Film By Him Was Brilliant. And Film Has A Huge Supporting Cast Everyone Were Fit To Their Roles And Delivered Great. Shruthi Hassan Doesn't Have A Huge Scope In Her Character,May Be She Will Be Used In Next Venture. Coming To The Technicalities,Hand's Down The Best Thing About The Film Was Its Action Blocks,They Were Just Adrenaline Pumping And Whistle Worthy One's Which Was Smoothly Delivered By Prabhas,Undoubtedly 'Katteramma' Sequence Is My Most Favourite Thing In Whole Movie,It Was Just Epic. Music By Ravi Basur Was Good
Especially During Action Sequences,But Does Not Leave Heavy Impact As 'KGF'. CameraWork Was Asusual Great. I Should Seriously Appericiate Production Values Of The Film,It Drags You Into The City Of Khansaar. Editing Was Ok,Screenplay Feels Little Bit Dragged Out In The Second Half Of The Film. Coming To The Writer And Director Prashant Neel He Really Succeeded In Showcasing The World Of Khansaar And Character's Motives. But Somewhat Felt Missing In His Writing During Drama. But Again He Should Be Appreciated For Showcasing Friendship,And Bringing Out Character 'DEVA' In His Signature Style. At Last Salaar Is A Action Drama Where Prabhas's Stands Out To Be The Back Bone Of The Film. The Action Block's,Prabhas's Screen Presence,World Building Of Khansaar Make's This One A Worth Watch. Which Create's A Curiosity For The Next Part. Finally A Much Needeed Comeback Delivered By REBEL...

Personal Thoughts: If you aren't too nit-picky or judgemental of the movies you watch, it'd be easy to enjoy Salaar. The beginning was a bit shaky and had the audience rightfully confused for the first hour or so, just waiting anxiously for answers, but the answers themselves more than made up for all of it. And don't get me wrong: being confused doesn't equal couldn't enjoy. I still found the beginning fun to watch, but I liked it a lot more when things started to piece together. What really brought me in was the dynamic between Vardha and Deva, which I won't talk too much about to avoid spoiling anything. From the eyes of someone who absolutely loved KGF 1 & 2, I say this movie wasn't a disappointment in the slightest. At the very least, it has me looking forward to the next part. The acting, story, and characters made this a great watch. Definitely one of the best movies made in 2023, despite it's rocky start. In summary, if you love action-packed movies that feature loyalty in its realest sense and have a main character that's easy to adore, a movie that's filled with emotion and suspense, a movie that's close to three hours yet has you wanting more at the end, Salaar might just fit your description. Again, I'm not too picky about my entertainment, but I can tell when a movie's not good, and judging by this review, you already know what I think of Salaar P1 (it's been a while since I've seen a movie that had me this drawn in). Can't wait for part two!

Review-Title: An Epic Tale of Action, Drama, and Sequel Promise.
Review-Description: Salaar delivers a typical South Indian movie experience with intense action, a powerful hero, and a compelling storyline. Prabhas commands the screen effortlessly, complemented by Shruti Hassan's impressive contribution. The film's action sequences are a standout. The storyline, while sharing similarities with the successful KGF, introduces its own unique twists and turns, keeping viewers on the edge of their seats. In essence, Salaar is not just a film; it's an immersive journey into the heart of South Indian cinema, where larger-than-life characters, compelling storytelling, and jaw-dropping action converge. Salaar part-1 seems to set the stage for an exciting second part, making it a must-watch for fans of the genre.

Review-Title: A good comeback movie for King!
Review-Description: I'm not sure why a few people are so hellbent on giving poor ratings for this movie! Salaar is one of the best action movies I have ever seen in 2023. Though the stroy is lengthy & the director did spend much time on providing elevations to our hero whenever he got a chance, I still felt that they were kind of good & some of them were on point. I hope we will get to see more from Prithvi & other important characters in the second part. It's definitely a feast for Prabhas's fans & I think he did his best for this role. It's a good story with a few twits, definitely worthy of our time! I'll be waiting for second part!

Review-Title: It's a superb mass movie, so don't expect anything else
Review-Description: This is a superb tollywood action movie and don't understand why anyone should judge it from any other lense. Prashanth Neel goes one step further than KGF. Simply loved Prabhaas. Especially after the Adipurush fiasco. This is his home ground and he should stick to it. Really liked how the fictional city of Khansaar is created with lots of adrenaline pumping scenes. Compared to KGF, the plot and storyine is given more attention. Characters apart from the lead(Salaar), have been carefully casted. Each one is equally important and does justice to his part. Towards the end, they have done an excellent job at creating a premise for Salaar part 2. Eagerly waiting for it. If you liked KGF/Leo/Vikram, then there are high chances that you will like this one too. Go for it.

If you really want to enjoy this movie , then forget about KGF or any of the old references like Uppgramm whatever. Just focus on the story which has a lot to offer specially with the flow of events and twists in the end. If you thought this movie was bad, its probably because you had way too high expectations. I read multiple reviews where people mentioned about the heroes using knives , swords etc. Instead of guns. For godsake , its a South Indian movie which usually has over the top action scenes with knives and swords and that was clearly evident from the trailer - its not a surprise package in the theatre for people to be disappointed about action scenes - if you have problems with over the top scenes , just don't waste your money watching it in theatre - BUT IF YOU HAVE AN OPEN MIND WITH ZERO BIAS , THIS MOVIE WILL ENTERTAIN YOU FOR SURE.

Review-Title: Decent action comedy flick with a bit of True Lies and Family vacation.
Review-Description: 3.5 out of 5 stars. The Family Plan is a pretty fair action comedy film that has a family road trip with Mark Wahlberg having a secret life before them. As he was once a rogue agent and trained to kill. And a bunches of henchmen are after him. The plot is okay which involves Mark Wahlberg trying to connect with his teen kids and trying to break the news to his wife the truth. The action sequences are okay and entertaining. Mark Wahlberg did great in the role. The rest of the cast did okay as well. The villain felt underdeveloped. The humor can be cheesy with Mark Wahlberg and the baby fighting with the baby just giggling through tough situations. Overall, it was a pretty fair film with plenty of fun action but cheesy humor.

Review-Title: An enthralling tale of a retired government hitman navigating family life
