Review-Description: Diving into the intricate life of a retired government hitman trying to balance family and a covert past, this film captivates with a compelling narrative, earning a solid 9/10. However, a regrettable choice in portraying antagonists solely as individuals of African, Asian, and Italian descent introduces an uncomfortable racial dynamic. The lack of diversity in this aspect mars an otherwise outstanding plot. With a touch of sarcasm, one can't help but wonder if the filmmakers forgot to include Latino adversaries, leaving the audience questioning the film's inclusivity. Despite this misstep, the gripping storyline manages to keep viewers engaged, making it a commendable cinematic experience."

One of the Christmas event is to watch this movie at home! Although it's an Apple TV movie but the cast is good. The plot is about a normal man who have a good family and 3 kids, while it was gradually found out that he has a dark past as an assassin of the government! He was found out by the ex colleagues and needed to fight back without informing his family. The runway and fight scenes are good and there are places to laugh, such as throwing away all their phones! The baby is very cute as well! But the character of Maggie Q is not good and the final boss is his father. The plot is all u can expected and watching it would be a good way to spend your time.

This deserves better ratings. It's at least a 7/10. The script is very good. The acting is very good. The comedic elements are very good. The directing is excellent. Overall, this is a fun action comedy worth watching. I'm very picky and this did have a few minor issues but way fewer than most of the stuff being made these days. If you have an overinflated sense of superiority and you like to think that your criticisms matter more than the efforts of the people who put in the effort to create a decently entertaining movie, then don't watch this. As other reviewers have said, grab some popcorn and enjoy this movie.

If you've read any short synopsis of this movie, you don't need to see it. The story begins with an inexplicable set-up (some sort of privatized witness protection program?), kicks off with an unexplained plot twist (why are the bad guys after him NOW?), and proceeds through unbelievable series of public shootouts across the country (at no point across the country were the authorities alarmed or mobilized?). I wish I had these two hours back. If you get tricked into sitting through this garbage, bring a good book. The story will not require more than about three percent of your attention to keep up with the action.

The wife put this film on in the background whilst I was doing something else. 20 minutes in I surprised us both by suggesting this was a Marky Marky I'd actually like to watch. So we saved it for a day later, and here I am giving it 8 stars. Nothing ground breaking about the script. But refreshingly warm and charming. There's some great hits by the stunt team. Lots of great little jokes to be found. Max the baby is a stand out character. When I see this film get slammed by the critics, but a film like Extraction 2 with an even weaker story. I start to wonder if I should believe their reviews anymore. So I'm writing this review. If you considering watching it, go in with no expectation and you'll have a great time.

Review-Title: Corny, quirky, action and family love
Review-Description: Oh come on. Some people took this movie way too seriously with their ridiculously low ratings. It is what it is with no pretentious "deeper meaning". This was a fun ride. A goofy at times holiday treat. Yes, you could probably predict some of what was coming, but so what. The cast was great. And so many other fun characters in the entire movie. The baby was so cute and hysterical at times. This is a sit back with popcorn and laugh movie. If you just want to relax and enjoy a movie that is not stuffed with obligatory "stuff" and divisive messaging, this is it. It is entertainment. Don't take it too seriously.

"The Family Plan" is just another weak action-comedy, with very low quality on ideas, originality, and development, as well as the cheesy and non-organic love connection between the main characters. The story is simply about a family, and a father that hides his dark, bloody past. When things are getting out of control for him, he has to take the mission in his own hands and hide his true identity from his family. First, I had an impression that this was going to be a fun comedy that can live on its action, but turned out to be an unoriginal flick that really looks like it's written be Ai. First I got to mention the characters. I remembered maybe half of the names, because I never get connected that much (Besides the father, Sean, the main hero) that by the way carried the cast mostly. Sean as a character himself was interesting, but unfortunately not so interesting as I expected him to be. The villain he had to fight came out of nowhere and felt totally out of place, in my opinion. His backstory came more on the end, too, and I wished maybe a little peak before. Sean's wife (The Mother) was fun, yet she was very plastic and the actress could be more of a food commercial women. The kids are the most predictable characters, easily comparable to kids from other family comedies. It's always a computer dude, a weirdo and some little kid. A few of the action sequences were acceptable, yet not so great as I expected. Generic and predictable, it tried to make things interesting but ended with a cheesy clich√© that should never took have place. I got really surprised over the camera filming and overall quality, and sometimes I think that not only Apple sponsored this movie, but helped to make it with their cameras. I don't know if I liked it or not, it was a weird feeling in the filming, I don't know, something was just strange. The movie was carried by nice soundtrack, as well as nice suspense score that was good, but some of the action was so lame that the music was wasted for nothing, and that's bad, because they could use it for something much better. In the end, this is an Ai-Script, bad, plastic acting, as well as uninteresting and forgettable action. The rating was saved some more by a few good sequences and nice soundtrack overall.

Dan Morgan loves his quiet suburban life as a devoted husband, father of three and successful car salesman. But that's only half the story. Decades earlier, he was an elite government assassin tasked with eliminating the world's deadliest threats. When enemies from his past track him down, Dan packs his family into their minivan and takes off on an impromptu cross-country road trip to Las Vegas. Determined to protect his family....while treating them to the vacation of a lifetime.....Dan must put his long-dormant skills into action, without revealing his true identity..... Have you ever wondered what would happen if a studio like Apple spent loads of money on a film that was True Lies mixed with National Lampoons Vacation? Well wonder no more, because here it is, and no one asked for it, and because of that, it's pretty enjoyable fluff. Wahlberg spends his time not saying 'Hey Bro?', but doing that weird thing he does by speaking a sentence like he's asking a question. Bad guys find out about him, and try to kill him, but there's a twist!! For no good reason, the main bad guy is his dad, and that gets explained near the end by good old Basil Exposition. Maggie Q plays the Oddjob of the movie, and the whole movie is throwaway fluff that streaming channels produce that are specifically aimed at people who spend half of their time on their phone whilst watching the film, because you could go out for twenty minutes, come back, and not miss anything at all. The cast are fine, there's a pretty good set piece in a supermarket, and it all looks very nice. But I like Wahlberg, so what can you do?

Review-Title: It's a really a family plan
Review-Description: "The Family Plan" is a heartwarming comedy that explores the chaos and joy that ensue when a well-intentioned family attempts to execute a foolproof plan to reconnect. The ensemble cast delivers standout performances, with each actor bringing a unique charm to their roles. Emily Thompson shines as the determined matriarch, balancing humor and vulnerability with ease."The Family Plan" is a delightful cinematic experience that will leave audiences both laughing and reflecting on the importance of family. Whether you're part of a close-knit family or simply seeking an uplifting escape, "The Family Plan" is a must-watch that celebrates the beautiful chaos of familial love. It's so good movie.

Review-Title: This is what a monster film should be
Review-Description: Compared to the mediocre American Godzilla films, Godzilla Minus One outshines them in every aspect. The character development is some of the best in a monster movie, the audience can actually connect properly to the human characters in a way that nicely drives the film overall and there are never any dialogue scenes that are a slog to get through. The Godzilla destruction and special FX are also top notch, although there are only a handful of action scenes through the film they are masterfully crafted as Godzilla fights the films protagonists and destroys his way through Japan. Definitely one of the best monster films in recent years.

Review-Title: An impressive film to say the least
Review-Description: I have never seen a single movie with subtitles in it. I have seen a couple of the recent Godzilla MonsterVerse movies. While I don't have any problems with those films, I am honestly indifferent toward them. Honestly going into this movie I had zero expectations. Didn't know what to expect. In the end, I was...impressed. The story itself does a surprisingly good job at being self contained. It keeps itself within the borders of Japan. It also take place after the events of World War II, which provide interesting backstories for our characters dealing with grief, trauma, regret from the war itself and how to overcome it. It just happens to also have the added threat of Godzilla in the midst, which was handled really well... For being a 15 Million Dollar budgeted movie, the effects and cinematography are really well done. The way they animated Godzilla in this movie is impressive. I think if you want to take big budget action blockbusters like Godzilla, Transformers, etc., and make them good, having less is more, and in this movies case, it's better. A really good movie overall.

Review-Title: It feels way better than it is
Review-Description: The story isn't ground breaking. The effects can be kind of janky at times. The acting really funny - it harkens back to old Japanese films where they exaggerate the characters' expressions. Yet, I was engrossed for the full 2 hours. The director focused on a story and unlike Hollywood for the last couple of years, gosh was it refreshing not to be preached to or watch a 2 hour political advertisement. The entire movie is subtitled, I know it's not for everyone. So be aware. Otherwise, I thoroughly enjoyed it for what it was. A love story that unfolds behind the backdrop of monster rampaging through Tokyo. Marvelous.

I went to see this movie expecting not a lot. But then when the film finished, I was lost for words, it was incredible and I mean it. This movie came with loads of different things such as, scary scenes really sad moments and also real happy moments, ( and of course, jawdropping moments) The acting in the film were awesome. The subtitles were clear with no delays
And best of all, godzilla was super scary as should be. I would highly recommend this movie to everyone ,even people who are not really fans of godzilla,
Even though the movie is in Japanese it is still incredible for others who speak different languages. Also I hope to see a godzilla minus 1 part 2
Especially after the ending üòâ

Review-Title: Is 'Godzilla Minus One' worth your time and money?
Review-Description: This short review is to help readers living in Western countries decide whether Godzilla Minus One is worth watching. There's three things you need to know beforehand so you won't be disappointed: 1) The movie is in Japanese but has English subtitles. 2) CGI is pretty bad (although I actually prefer costumes and prostethics more than 100% computer graphics. I'd rather Godzilla looks like this than the CGI in 'The Marvels' for example). 3) The movie is dialogue heavy. Godzilla scenes are few and far between. That's how they kept a low budget - by giving you 5 - 10 minute snippets of Godzilla and then it's back to lengthy scenes of dialogue in Japan. Wrong expectations are probably the biggest reason for how divided the audience reaction has been. Keep in mind that this movie had a 9-point-something score on IMDb before it was released in Western Countries. By East-Asian standards this is one of the best movies of all time. So there's a clear distinction between how the movie has been received in different regions of the world. Being from the UK, my biggest gripe with Godzilla Minus One is that with a $15 million budget you would expect it to have far more substance than style. I was expecting top tier, edge-of-your-seat drama to compensate for what the movie lacked visually. But that wasn't the case. The plot was incredibly basic and predictable. It thinks it's deeper than it is. So overall you're left with a movie that doesn't look great, doesn't showcase Godzilla doing much (just slowly walking around, stepping on people, knocking over buildings and hurling ships) and doesn't have much substance either. On the below scale... 5. Absolute must watch in theaters. 4. Worth the ticket price 3. Shortlist and wait for streaming. 2. Could miss it entirely. 1. Complete waste of time. Avoid. ...it gets a 2.5 from me.

Review-Title: Much better than your average money grab Godzilla movie
Review-Description: It was so great to finally see a Godzilla movie that held true to the original Godzilla theme. Godzilla is supposed to represent nuclear weapons and the impact that these weapons and the violence of the second World War had on the people of Japan. This theme was powerfully demonstrated in this film. Aside from the obvious destruction and trauma caused by the monster, the film also touched on other aspects of war that had an impact on the people of Japan, such as dying and living honorably as well as rebuilding a nation. Additionally, you did not feel that there was glorification of the monster or the war, however, respect was shown for both. I would highly encourage anybody who has not seen this movie and is fond of Godzilla or monster movies in general to go see this movie (in theatres preferred!).

What can I say other than...Well Done! On a teeny budget of $15M this Toho Studio movie lacks for nothing. The action kicks off right away with a Japanese pilot touching down on a chunky island airstrip. He's questioned as to why he has returned (was supposed to be a kamikaze mission, I think. I watched a no-subtitles version). Next scene, BOOM, Godzilla! Note: Gojira = gorilla + kujira/whale. There's plenty of human drama laced into the story. The toddler gives an award-worthy performance. My goodness, when her face crumples up in a sob, you'd have to be a block of wood not to shed a tear yourself. It's refreshing to see a movie stay period-accurate; notice that all the scenes of decision-making and naval heroism are all-male. Women play a role in the plot - the main character's life is saved by a woman - just not in the attack against the monster. My criticisms of the movie are as follows:
***MILD SPOILERS***
(1) There are too many rousing speeches rallying the spirit of the troops. Godzilla conveniently disappears for large chunks of the run time. (2) One consequential scene that happens midway thru the film gets undone in the ending. That felt cheap. Overall, RECOMMENDED. Note: A second release of this movie called "Godzilla Minus 1/Minus Color" will be coming out in mid-January. Black & White, baby!

Review-Title: Exceptional movie Godzilla Minus One just gets it right üëå
Review-Description: Godzilla Minus One üëèüëèüëè It's going straight into my IMDb as a 10/10 (recency bias score, as initial watch experience...on a more critical analysis could be 9.6 to 9.8) If a movie can make you feel for the characters and poke at the emotions of an emotionless person like myself, yeah, it's getting that big recommendation from me. I loved the intensity of the music and the monster Godzilla scenes, done so well, yet it's actually not just those big scenes that do it for this one. The story, the writing (subtitles), but how they dealt with some heavy sentiments, I thought they did an incredible job. Well done. I even liked the "feel" of the movie, the texture of it, the way that Godzilla himself actually looks a bit funny üòÖ it worked. The sense of scale also worked, this Godzilla looked MASSIVE, enough to make you tremble, that sense of hopeless impending devastation, and how that was tackled, as well as some darker, sadder emotions that the movie touches on, yep, fair play, you guys got me on this one. üëè Highly recommend, catch in the cinema for the SOUNDS and scale of it, but I think it could still work on the small screen if you're waiting for that. Loved this movie.

Review-Title: The best blockbuster of the year
Review-Description: In "Godzilla Minus One," the film deeply explores the emotional side, portraying a kamikaze soldier facing the consequences of World War II and Godzilla. The dramatic depth is remarkable, delving into post-war traumas in an impactful way. Unlike North American versions of "Godzilla," it adds complexity to the characters, enriching the viewer's experience. The film's execution highlights the strength of Asian cinema, surpassing Hollywood in many aspects. The Godzilla scenes are impressive, offering a unique sensory experience. The action sequences, especially the destruction of a major city, effectively convey the villain's relentless threat. "Godzilla Minus One" indirectly challenges prejudices against Asian films, providing a positive experience for audiences weary of American blockbusters. On the downside, a slight negative point is noted in the conclusion, where there's an effort to appeal to the Western audience with a more "Hollywood-esque" ending, which felt somewhat forced but didn't diminish the film's overall impact.

10/10, not only the best movie of 2023, but in my opinion probably the best Godzilla film ever put to film. For a budget that looks incredibly budgeted and small compared to Hollywood's recent $200-300 Million bloated budgets and limitations of practical and visual effects, this movie absolutely blows the competition out of the water. Toho made the right choice to go back to basics and make Godzilla the ultimate destructive antagonistic force of nature and bringing back the monster-horror aspect that's very much needed in these movies. Like the 1954 original, the dark and serious tone works beautifully and incredibly effectively in conveying what the scene needs to. And whether on screen, off screen or implied, Godzilla's mere presence conveys that tone of dread and terror, truly retaining back the title of King of the Monsters. And the characters! It's been a long time since we've had characters in these films that we could actually care for, let alone give any interest or sympathy towards. Minus One's characters grow and are fleshed out throughout the story, and the context of being a kamakazi pilot in a post-WWII 1940's Japan. It asks questions of the value of life and vengeance for those who've lost theirs, and the guilt of actions, what we do and don't do. This film reflects back to a conflicted and broken time, but one inhabited by good and united people choosing to give their lives for something greater. It's truly a relieving and hopeful sight for what makes great cinema through the infinite muddled assembly line of cheap, poorly made, factory-produced content called film. Forget the multiverse movies, give us more of this!

Movie Title: Indiana Jones and the Dial of Destiny (2023)
Review-Title: Indy or back to the future?
Review-Description: Well, seeing young Indiana Jones was very good. Technology is amazing, that makes every actor and actresses eternal! I love that! As a movie, you know ther care lots of unlogical things but this is Indiana Jones, who cares? I have to say Sicilia scenes, from beginning to end, just perfect! Full action is over there. I love also time travel section.. . Phoebe waller Bridge is sooo cool and so suitable for her role in this movie. I hope this series can continue in some way. Final is also so sweet. Seeing Marion was good. I love happy endings. Anyway I love everything about movie, technology, characters, scenes, places. If you are a fan of Indiana Jones, I am sure you will love this too.

Movie Title: Indiana Jones and the Dial of Destiny (2023)
Review-Description: A mixed bag of a movie. It was okay in some places but there is a disconnect between what is said and what happens. Indi can jump between vehicles but has trouble climbing up a rock-face. Is he too old for this or not? Characters are introduced that are allegedly a large part of Indi's life but he doesn't have a connection to them at all; at least it doesn't seem like it. Helena is painfully unlikeable and seems more like the villain of the piece instead of the deuteragonist. Just let Indi live in the past. It's all he's ever wanted. The de-aging is passable at times, such as in long shots or when seen in relative darkness, but can falter from time to time. Hearing 80 year-old Harrison Ford's voice coming out of 46 year-old Indiana Jones is incredibly distracting. Sallah should have been in more of the film instead of just as a glorified cameo. Killing of Indi's son was the best thing that could have happened to that character.

Movie Title: Indiana Jones and the Dial of Destiny (2023)
Review-Title: Better than Crystal Skulls... if you're patient
Review-Description: Good to see Jones back in the saddle. Pacing was a tad drawn out, making the sequences feel a unnecessarily tedious. The writers obviously didn't know how to write a building historical interest into the show, so it fell back to overly long 'action' scenes without meaningful ties to the point of it all along the way. The new female co-star is not very appealing to either look at or listen to. They tried to hard to make her 'edgy' and she wound up just a straight-up, plain b*tch. Worth a watch on your platform of choice despite it all because the show winda out to a pretty good ending, for which a grudging nod can be given.

Movie Title: Indiana Jones and the Dial of Destiny (2023)
Review-Description: I don't understand those who criticise this great movie!! Indiana is just old and this movie was not about him! But he still got the lead shared with Helena what makes this movie very enjoyable and fun! The story that started with him was just like any Indiana Jones movies and the overlap to his old him was smart created. The actions in this movie may be a bit too much, specially the one who got cuffed under water by a kid with no remorse! The bad guy is in this movie also very bad and killed without remorse too. But hey, this is a Indiana Jones movie. The last one, but he did it in my opinion really great, the story, the plot, it was really enjoyable! What was also great are the old characters like Sallah and his wife... Still the same but older... Great Movie!!

Movie Title: Indiana Jones and the Dial of Destiny (2023)
Review-Description: Films may not have necessarily been better in the past, but the standout productions of the 80s and 90s often shared a common trait - a significant investment of heart. Despite varying budgets or circumstances. The film industry back then was perhaps as calculating as today, aiming to at least double every dollar spent. However, the caution in film making and storytelling today, together with the fact that most people now consider themselves hardcore critics first, rather than an audience, contributes to a scarcity of heartfelt and those charming imperfections in movies. The things we loved about Indiana Jones: Indy clumsily beating up Nazis and creepy Indian cult members over some archaeological artifact. Accompanied by John Williams' brilliant melodies, occasionally a little bit too loud and tiresome score and dialogue but... Nevertheless, it remains a masterpiece-ingenious, entertaining, and delightfully imperfect. No need to compare this final chapter to its predecessors. Streamed in 4K during a time when many believe VHS was an ancient STD, I must say, the movie sent me away on delightful nostalgic trip. The story and the actors successfully brought back some of that wonderful 'heart' from the past. A more than worthy ending. Well done James Mangold, and thank you Harrison Ford for spoiling us with great entertainment throughout the decades.

Movie Title: Indiana Jones and the Dial of Destiny (2023)
Review-Title: Films like these are SO ridiculous! Too many unrealistic situations.
Review-Description:
This movie feels very much like it's shot mostly in front of green/blue screen. I didn't know three wheeled mopeds performed better than four wheeled old sports cars, and were able to go down stairs effortlessly with three people (250kg) inside. Professional gangsters apparently can't hit a target, with an automatic rifle, from a few meters. He said 3 minute dive, but it was far more than that! Boat scene, after dynamite:
When people are within 100m from you, shooting with a gun, you don't calmy turn your head and back to them, you duck and hide; preferably BEFORE the bullets comes flying. When there is a hurry, why are they ALWAYS so slooooow!? It's just unrealistic and stupid! Who survives hours with a shot to the heart? Well not his friend, he died within seconds. Why would they fly so low, just to get shot at? They were in an airplane for fudge sake! There was no reason for them to drop that much altitude after they regained control. Are all these new movies made for dumb kids (and adults with IQ below 80)? I don't understand. It's not THAT hard to make exactly the same movies, but WITHOUT all the stoopid sht. It's just lazy and it feels like the movie industry is deliberately making bad movies, because I can't accept that they are this stoopid with these kind of budgets.

Movie Title: Indiana Jones and the Dial of Destiny (2023)
Review-Description:
So you're telling me that after Crystal Skull, which was a mess and a bit ridiculous, your next step was this? A movie where Indiana is treated terribly the whole time with bad callbacks and bad pacing. Look we all know Harrison is older and grumpier, but to give him the Luke Skywalker treatment is just bonkers to me. Why are we constantly making movies where we're ruining childhood figures? At this point in my life I would rather see remakes and retellings of these old characters than sequels. All they seem to do is take a beloved figure and ruin who they were with minor callbacks to make you go "Oh I remember that." I'd rather see a new Indy with a new adventure in a retelling that pays homage but is brand new. They've been doing it for James Bond all these years, they can do it for Indy. Now that I'm done crying about that, let's get into the movie. Indiana Jones fights Nazis for an old relic that will allow the Nazis to win WW2. All the while his god daughter shows up and robs him, tries to sell off said artifact and then they get into a wacky back and forth that disrespects a beloved character, gives us a new Short Round and is constantly like "Hey remember how you liked the car chases in the other movies? Well here's 40 of them for not a whole lot of reason." I wanted to like this movie. I wanted to give it a chance and not feel like I did with the recent Star Wars but Disney can't handle Lucasfilm properties. They can't get out of their own way and this movie is just another failure. At least Crystal Skull attempted to be different and failed that way. This movie tried more of the same with modern tropes that just takes away any enjoyment. PS
The CGI in this movie is also poop and looks worse than Crystal Skull did, you couldn't convince me otherwise.

Movie Title: Indiana Jones and the Dial of Destiny (2023)
Review-Description: This movie garnered a whole bunch of criticism and I can see why. If I didn't get Disney + for free I would have never seen this based on all the negative reviews and clips I saw of it. But I DO get D+ for free which this showed up on. So I gave it a try. This is NOT the Indy that we deserved for a final movie. Out of nowhere is introduced a character that is NEVER before mentioned in one of the previous movies and is the most insufferable and annoying person in the whole movie. The action sequences are ok and the music scores are top notch. The acting is also OK. I have to say that any upcoming movies that have Phoebe Waller Bridge as the main draw will not be any temptation for me to go to. She's fairly underwhelming. Overall, the writing and premise of this show are really not that good. As far as storytelling and keeping me 'on the edge of my seat' (a gold standard for keeping your audience engaged) it was never there. I watched the first movie and this last iteration of Indy is such a pale imitation. Why have writers and directors have lost all semblance of creativity lately??

Movie Title: Indiana Jones and the Dial of Destiny (2023)
Review-Title: So much CGI there are no real stakes
Review-Description: A sad farewell to Indiana Jones. There is so much CGI going on that the chase scenes mean nothing. Time and time again things happen too conveniently (thanks to the CGI). There are masses of green screen shots which take out the mysticism of the journey. I'd rathe the film was poorly lit but practically shot than all done on a lit set. Plot wise, its too magical and not based in reality enough. We don't want time travel, or multiverses, just go on a good old romping journey to some interesting places. It's not that difficult to write. I think too many people got involved in the story and there were too many things shoehorned in to say farewell to Indiana. Why does this happen to every great franchise?!

Movie Title: Indiana Jones and the Dial of Destiny (2023)
Review-Title: A Solid Farewell To Cinema Legend
Review-Description: After pre-ordering the DVD from Amazon and diligently avoiding all spoilers until its arrival, I decided to binge the previous 4 Indy movies and then round it off with Dial of Destiny. Overall I thought it was a solid addition to the saga and as a last hurrah for Harrison Ford as Indy, it has a certain poignancy. It mixed familiar character roles seen in the previous films with a new twist that kept things fresh. For example, every Indy movie has a female lead but - recognising Indy is now in his twilight years - rather than having the female lead as the traditional romantic interest riding on Indy's coat tails they have used this character space to introduce a savvy and bold female lead who, for a change, is taking Indy for a ride! The tone of the story is somewhat tragic in parts. What's nice is that the writers and Ford himself haven't shied away from the reality that life is complicated and involves loss, even for heroes. Right from our first sight of the older Indy telling his young neighbours to 'quiet down' to his half hearted retirement do, to Indy's resignation that he belongs in the past more than his present - there is a serious side to the rip roaring adventure; the rather existential theme of Time moving on and leaving us behind. Overall - good classic Indiana Jones action with fresh twists and realistic undertones - all of which add up to a fitting farewell to our whip cracking adventurer!

There comes a movie with which younhave high hopes. This one was such a downer that I almost slipped into depression. This movie had me ask the director "why" just why did you do something like this. If you had not something better to do, go and sleep. You'd be better off that ways and so will your audience. Mow coming to the plot. It is so weak that only AI can fix it. Because there is something too wrong with the implementation of the logic and storyline kehne ka mtlb kch bhi ho rha hai bhaiya isse zyada kya kahe k aakhir mein maya zinda hojati h aur Joshua uski chummi le leta h. Creator dharti pe laut jata h aur usi k sath movie ka the end.

Washington cements his reputation as being an awful actor. Who else, but the son of a great actor would get so many chances at big films? Janney is a caricature of herself- overplaying the awful writing tropes- yelling "mount up!" Multiple times to her subordinates. The idea of humanizing the robots makes no sense and is inconsistent- going back and forth. The "surprise" reveal was so predictable from almost the beginning. All that said, the CGI was outstanding and wasted on this film. I wonder if a rewrite of the script and changing lead actors would be any help- maybe so- but the tropes are all too prevalent.

A great development in terms of visual effects, "The Creator" keeps its audience sticked to the seat by means of action and mystery. No matter how much the storyline resorts to previously set leitmotivs ( the advent of the chosen one; the danger of artificial intelligence; the inhumanity of man), the spectator can do nothing but thank the development of such in this movie. Due to this sort of "heritage" the film is easily inserted in Sci-Fi/cyberpunk imagery -what makes it an interesting view for anyone into this kind of worlds. The weakness: perhaps, some storylines lack full development, but are coherently explained by means of flashbacks and resources of the sort. A good movie to let your imagination fly, especially if you love the genre.

Review-Title: The Reviews You've Read Are Wrong. The Creator Has a Ton of Heart.
Review-Description: I feel like many of the reviews from people here went into watching this film expecting to be disappointed. I went in, knowing about a very average reception, and found an altogether enthralling and unexpectedly emotional film at its heart. This film is gorgeous and feels so much more natural than other big-budget SFX of it's calibre. The Creator felt lived-in and gritty. Yes, this can be certainly said of other significant films from over 30 years. But The Creator looks so dense, vibrant and new. I felt the same way I do when I travel to a new country. This was achieved, without a doubt, by director Edwards and DP Fraser desire to find a new way of making a film like this and shooting it guerrilla style, almost like a documentary. I whole-heartedly believe they succeeded in creating a world that felt real. There were some fantastic set-pieces with amazing action that I never felt lost in and nearly every character that we see, apart from the odd grunt, is doing something smart. There's a major battle sequence that just filled me with dread and shocked me with how slow and almost sluggish the battle begins. The story, certainly touched on some familiar beats in retrospect. But in the moment, nearly every chapter of this film kept me guessing as to where it was going and how John David Washington's character, Joshua, was going to do what he needed to do. His performance was robust and wanted what he wanted. "Alphie", played by Madeleine Yuna Voyles is a damn marvel. I haven't been so impressed by a child actor in a long time. So, forget about reviews. In fact, forget about this review. Forget about demanding only the best from every film you go and see. Go into it without any expectations. Go along for the ride. I guarantee it'll be an experience that stays with you.

Review-Title: Visually Stunning, best of 2013, but.. that's it.
Review-Description: As almost every other reviewer pointed out, the CGI is superb and surely beats Marvel and DC CGI by far. For such a budget, my kudos to the studio, they performed magnificently. Some readers are pointing out Washington's performance, others got offended by the apparent east vs west conflict depicting the west as the bad ones (not assimilating diversity, LOL). All these are not actual flaws. Simply, the story makes absolutely no sense, both on small levels and individual scenes and also in a greater overall scale. Ok, we know this is fiction but, on any version of the future which includes AI, almost nothing of what we see makes sense existing. The writers could use some advice from experts as it seems, it's a "kids" vision of an AI dystopia and not a real one. I'm giving it 7/10 as its visually superb, well directed, decently acted but please, put some real effort to the script next time.

It's always worth commending a blockbuster movie that comes from original ideas and concepts and is not part of any IPs and franchises. The Creator is one of many movies that deserve so many praises for its purpose and potential. The greatest strength of this film is the visual elements and world building within it. I don't think I have enough praises and commendations to Gareth Edwards, whose brilliant direction has effortlessly blended breathtaking vistas, meticulously crafted CGI, and outstanding visual spectacle. It's always wonderful to see a talented filmmaker who doesn't hold back in unleashing the full potential in their creativity and visions, in returns giving us unforgettable experiences watching their work. That being said, however, this movie, for all of its' greatness, has few of it flaws While the narrative is indeed original, there are some noticeable cliches and tropes that we might have familiar before, leaving some details in the movie that are predictable. In addition, I think the characters (which included Washington, Chan, and Watanabe's characters) are only made as the means for the advancement of the story and are not characterized with full potential or written as their own character. Overall, having watched this movie, I appreciate what this movie set out to be. We do have Gareth Edwards to thank for his visual brilliance and talent that bring us fruitful results. As I said before, movies that come from the original concept deserve much support in cinema.

Knowing how rare new science fiction movies are, I was interested to see what The Creator (2023) would say about artificial intelligence. Even if we're currently seeing a rise in generative AI tools, the AI in The Creator are more like the replicants in Blade Runner (1982). And while Gareth Edwards hasn't had a lot of movies under his belt, he's proven that he can handle big franchises like Godzilla (2014) and Star Wars (with Rogue One (2016)). Unfortunately, this "original" film feels highly derivative of these previous movies in his filmography. Plot-wise, much of The Creator cribs from Rogue One. The big orbiting doomsday device that looms as a threat over key battle sequences gives off big Death Star vibes. That there's a MacGuffin that's supposed to save the world/universe which causes the main character to undergo great sacrifice is yet another parallel that's hard to ignore. Granted, many consider Rogue One to be a great film, so another military sci-fi that copies a lot of elements from it is bound to be great as well. I agree that there were some interesting technology concepts explored in The Creator, but the premise didn't click for me. Maybe the bigger issue I have with this film is how it tells us things we already know. Since it's set in a future version of our world, it just reinforces the fact that the United States can be an imposing military force in Asia for no other reason than to maintain a global domination of military might. As the Vietnam War showed us, the locals who are being targeted by the U. S. military-industrial complex have enough grit and tools to stand up to the oppression of the American military. Overall, its message seems weak despite its impressive visuals. A somewhat derivative "original" sci-fi film, I give The Creator 3.5 stars out of 5.

The problem is the script, sometimes the narrative is a mish mesh of combat events, the war against A. I. is an endless futility a metaphor the master and slaves rulers and working classes. Reminiscent of the Vietnam Nam war with the Americans against the Asian who support the A. I. bonding with humans. Does ai help the working class people of asian descent? Its a possiblity that its more of the inspiration behind man and computers the danger of A. I. becoming self aware are not really explored. Too bad, the ageless story of a lost love for the protagonist to discover where and whom his lost love is and has become the mystery of the who is the creator of the gifted child who will redeem this world. If you can stay with this film does get better. Its not cheap scify and has many visual technical effects. But still there is a romantic story in the bare bones here to watch unravel, cheers!

In a word, underwhelming. So much wasted potential in this movie. First, the good stuff. Casting and acting was spot on, for the most part. Visuals/SFX were amazing. After watching for just a few minutes, I was hooked - and I so very badly wanted this movie to be good. Unfortunately, the story is nonsensical and falls flat. The Chosen One searching for a McGuffin isn't an automatic deal breaker, but the execution in this film is poor. The action scenes have great visuals, but little suspension of belief. For example, at one point the bad guys shoot a barrage of missiles at the good guys' encampment. The missiles are highly effective, causing utter chaos and destruction. But after the first salvo of five missiles, the bad guys stop shooting and instead send droids walking into the encampment with countdown bombs attached. The audience is left scratching their heads at this questionable (and easily countered) strategy. There are other problems with the story and world building, and too many moments in the film where suspension of disbelief becomes difficult or impossible. These aren't so much "plot holes" as much as they are just incongruities. The pieces of the puzzle just don't fit together quite right.

Review-Title: Visually stunning and an entertaining story, and some d√©j√† vu
Review-Description: This movie looks great (Dune and Batman cinematographers) and I enjoyed the story. AI seemingly goes rogue and nukes humans, the humans fight back, and there's a secret weapon that can end the conflict and bring the lead's wife back. To me, this story felt like a mix of The Golden Child, Ex Machina (the ending), and Blade Runner. There were some holes that bugged me (knowing to turn the little statue, for example) and there were some cliche moments, but overall a fun movie. The characters (other than Alphie) aren't very memorable and I wasn't necessarily rooting for or against anyone. In the end, they are just machines being turned off.

Migration is an animated film, it follows a family of ducks who migrate to Jamaica. Never having migrated before due to the fear of the unknown, they find themselves, in unexpected circumstances along the way meeting both friends and foe. Mack who is the main character not only finds his sense of adventure, but learns that living life is about taking risks especially when we are afraid. It is a very colorful piece that catches your eye in every scene! Migration is a great competitor against other animated works from studios like Dream works and Disney. Most memorable quote:
"You better open your eyes before you miss it all" - Pam Mallard.

I didn't like this movie very much. Sure, it's beautifully animated, but the story is nothing new, nothing here is archetypal and deep, so the viewer really doesn't care what happens, unless the viewer is a small child. I might be a misantrope, but I'd much rather see a movie were animals behave like animals instead of having a duck family wanting to see the world with all the clich√©s that entails. Furthermore, that nasty chef is not really a good villain. He has no motivations whatsoever that we care about, and the good guys don't go slaying dragons or have cathartic experiences. Or maybe they do, but since the story is so childlike and full of clich√©s, we really don't care. My autistic friend loved it, and maybe smaller children will, too. For me I guess it's thumb down.

'Migration' is a really well-made family film. It's a simple premise about anthropomorphic ducks - the father duck, Mack (Nanjiani), wants to protect his children/chicks, Dax (Jennings) and Gwen (Gazal), and the mother duck, Pam (Banks), wants them to experience the world and gain some experience. They meet some other ducks migrating south for the winter - they're presumably in North-Eastern USA - so they decide to do the same, with quirky uncle Dan (DeVito) in tow. What follows is both a semi-familiar road-trip comedy, as well as a refreshing take on family, trying new things and helping others. There's a great support cast, as the duck family passes through New York City and meets Chump the pigeon (Awkwafina), Delroy the macaw (Key), as well as Erin the heron (Kane) and GooGoo (Mitchell) - either a goose or a white duck. There's a nice jail-break sequence for Delroy, which sets up the human antagonist, the Chef. For some reason the Chef also has a Chinook and hunts them down, leading to Dax and Gwen having to step-up. The animation is a nice mix of cartoonish and realistic, and it looks excellent, especially at the end. There's no overly-scary moments, some teachable themes, the voice cast is all good and there's consistent laughs throughout. There's also 'Mooned', the 9-min 'Despicable Me' tie-in at the start of the film, which kids seemed to love.

Review-Title: It's a fair movie, but lacks in some areas
Review-Description: After watching a trailer or two a few times, I was kinda interested in this but now that I've seen it..I'm not saying it's bad but it's definitely missing a few things. For starters, exactly who are the parents and what made the dad so paranoid?? What is his backstory? And who is Uncle Dan? Whose brother is he? What's his backstory? What is the deal with the chef? Dude has enough money for his own private military chopper yet lives in a crummy apartment. Again, I'm not saying it's bad, but the movie did feel quite short, not enough actions, the "adventures" were so-so, some scenes were on the brink of "wtf is going on now?" This movie feels like it's got a few holes in it where it could've been a decent story. So I'd give it a C.

Review-Title: A Funny and Refreshing Take in a Sea of Misses
Review-Description: Rarely do I find a movie that captivates my heart like "Migration" did. It's a safe yet heartwarmingly funny film, a refreshing gem amidst many misses in the industry. The plot was engaging, and the humor... I found myself bursting into laughter, a rarity these days. Kumail Nanjiani and Tresi Gazal's voice acting breathed life into the characters, infusing the film with a vibrant and comedic essence. Their performances offered a fresh and delightful perspective. However, despite the talent, Awkwafina's presence felt exhausting, not due to poor performance but sheer overexposure in the cinematic landscape. Overall, "Migration" is a delightful journey, offering a charming storyline and standout performances, making it a memorable watch amidst the sea of recent film disappointments.

Illumination, the studio behind the Despicable Me and Sing franchises, is thriving financially, with its Super Mario Bros. Movie being the second-highest grossing film of 2023. However, true respect and acclaim still elude the Minion-spawning animation house. Migration, a film about a family of ducks, the Mallards, led by Kumail Nanjiani and Elizabeth Banks, aims to break the labels of cheap gags and stories that appeal to a broad audience. The creative control of Ernest and Celestine co-director Benjamin Renner promises a different approach to other Illumination movies. Migration's success can be attributed to its focus on relationships and warmth, which has been absent from much of Illumination's output since the first Despicable Me. The Mallard family's journey to Jamaica is a well-crafted film that builds connections between its ducklings, enhancing the plot. The family's motivations for leaving their pond and their desire for adventure are relatable, as is the family's patriarch, Mack, who prioritizes the safety of his children over everything else. When the family faces the challenge of survival in New York City, their perception of the world is challenged. Despite being set up as a stereotypical family with a stern dad, loving mom, and a brash teenage boy with a cute younger sister, the film ensures an emotional attachment to the ducklings, making it a satisfying and formulaic film. The animation quality in Migration represents an evolution of Illumination's past work. The film begins with a beautifully rendered bedtime story, blending hand-drawn and CG elements. The CG journey is characterized by realism, with cliffs tanned with autumn leaves and New York cityscapes painted with concrete coldness and bustling life. The water animation and cloud effects are particularly impressive. These changes do not change Illumination's identity, but rather create a better version of the typical film. However, this overfamiliarity overshadows much of Migration's cool new elements. Migration, a 3D animation by Mike White, is a delightful story developed with French animation director Benjamin Renner. Renner, known for his 2012 2D film Ernest and Celestine, has joined Illumination to lead his first studio and 3D animation effort, which is sure to delight fans of ducks. The Mallard family lives a dependable life in a pond, with dad Mack (Kumail Nanjiani) hesitant to leave his accustomed life. Wife Pam (Elizabeth Banks) encourages him to relax and take their children, Dax (Caspar Jennings) and Gwen (Tresi Gazal), on a trip to Jamaica. After a heart-to-heart with Uncle Dan (Danny DeVito), Mack realizes he has been missing life's essence and agrees to take the family on a life-changing adventure.

I'm honestly shocked! Migration is a really wholesome, loveable movie! What looked like a painfully average Illumination movie turned out to be one of its best! We got a well-written family story from Mike White about getting out of one's comfort zone and accepting change with likeable characters, solid humour, and beautiful visuals. It even had some good tension and suspense! Migration isn't your usual fare from Illumination, in fact, it might very well be the antithesis to the claims people (including me) make about Illumination. There are no pop culture references. The humour is character, visual, or slapstick based (I actually laughed a lot) and the characters are really lovable. It's very sweet and the animation is stunning and extremely expressive. The visuals are really stellar - a massive step up for Illumination. It's easily their best animation. The musical score was fantastic too - John Powell did not have to go that hard with his score. The music is so fun and inventive. And the voice cast turned out to be really awesome! Migration is a wholesome, charming film for the whole family that is very funny and has a lot of heart. Went in expecting a dumb, pop culture romp and got a funny, sweet, entertaining, and gorgeously animated family adventure. Illumination created an underrated gem with this one!

Been there, seen it. This felt a little bit like Finding Nemo meets Ice Age. Scared father doesn't want family to leave the confines of the known and safe. Finally they set off on a trek, totally unprepared for what's out there. They pick up some stragglers. They have a couple of adventures. They find themselves in peril then get out of it. Meanwhile there's little pearls of wisdom that's leaned by one and all. The bad guys are really bad. The good guys are really good. But no one gets seriouslt hurt, not even the bad guys. Eventually they reach their destination and everyone lives happily ever after. Until the next adventure. Cute jokes. Mostly for kids. Some kind for the adults. Nothing risqu√© or off color. The most entertaining part was the pre movie short (a Minons story) that also seemed like a remake (of a Roadrunner Wiley Coyote short). Hi hum.

The typical laidback light hearted fun family film! I love it a lot! The characters get plenty of screen time, no one gets left out or not a chance to shine. The flight scenes are beautiful and the animation for the flying is pretty stunning as well you can really sense the weight when they fly If that makes any sense. The character designs are great. So many different locations they visit it's interesting to see how different they all look, the scenery is neat to look at. Also all sorts of bird species they meet along the way of many shapes and size if you're a fan of birds you'll definitely enjoy this film!

The first seconds are good and feels creative with the 2D sequence and adult jokes. But then it starts becoming just another Illumination film with annoying characters while taking stuff from other films like Rio (which Chris Meledandri right hand Carlos Saldanha directed) the migrating plot promoted in advertising is almost non-existent as they are already in New York in just 2 seconds after they leave their home. The Jamaican accent stereotyped red parrot character is extremely annoying and only serves as device for the No-Rio third act sequence and the villain just randomly decides to kidnap birds in a helicopter after some ducks messed up with his kitchen.

Review-Title: A Bit of a Boring Night
Review-Description: Not sure how this film managed to be so boring but it didn't really entertain. The premise is flimsy and the action is a bit dull. Just lots of gore and body parts being thrown around for dramatic effect. It's slightly funny in places but nothing to write home about. The acting is so so and the written characters are extremely cliche. The young actress in it looks a bit 13 and they're treating her like a toddler one minute and than an adult who can deal with visceral bloody scenes the next. There's not enough cohesion for me. I know what they were trying to do here but they missed the mark.

So this film ranges from an average action flick to an awkward mess. The Santa sequences were the only redeeming part for me. David Harbor really captured the disgruntled Santa character well. When he is alone on screen or facing off against the antagonist, the film is quite fun. However, the film's other characters are just abysmal. I get that the film is going for a mean-spirited character type thing, but it just doesn't work. The rich family was just irritating, except for maybe two characters. I wasn't interested in seeing them be saved. Furthermore, the villains tried to go for an over-the-top type style, but a large majority of their dialogue is just cringeworthy. I feel like if they'd explored the conflict of overwhelming wealth versus impoverished burglars, it might have worked a bit better. I mean, making the villains selfish murderers just seemed like a way to shove in more violent acts. But that's just me, maybe. Overall, I would suggest maybe skipping this one unless you are super interested in the concept!

Review-Title: Loved this. Fun action packed christmas movie
Review-Description: Violent Night completely surpassed our expectations, it was a really good time - highly enjoyable and lots of funny moments. David Harbour is great in the role and really brings it to life. The action looks good, it has fun and innovative fight scenes, and just enough blood to satisfy your desire for the bad guys to get their comeuppance. It's good for teens and above - I have a feeling younger kids may find the fights a bit too bloody - but could be a really good family Christmas movie. I'd happily watch it every Christmas and make a tradition out of it. If you like Die Hard you'll probably like this.

'Violent Night (2022)' is surprisingly earnest in its themes of Christmas magic and rekindling your Christmas spirit. What initially seems like a sardonic anti-Christmas movie soon reveals itself to be genuinely interested in spreading Yuletide cheer, although that's not to imply it doesn't also feature all the brutality, bad language and bodily fluids its concept promises. Merging 'Die Hard (1988)', 'Home Alone (1990', 'Bad Santa (2004)' and 'John Wick (2014)' (or, perhaps more accurately, some of its lesser imitators), the piece provides a stockingful of festive fun despite its undeniably derivative nature. David Harbour and John Leguizamo make up for the cast's general lack of charisma, as they're eminently watchable and sell even the silliest of dialogue. Though the piece is certainly self-aware, it's also really sincere and it establishes a strong sense of character for its central figure. In fact, Papa No√´l actually has a relatively convincing character arc which prevents his inclusion from feeling as half-baked as it may initially seem. Although the flick sometimes comes closer to feeling like 'Paul Blart: Mall Cop (2009)' than 'Die Hard (1988)' (particularly when it comes to most elements not directly associated with Santa), it features plenty of well-choreographed and exciting set-pieces that revel in all the gory mayhem you could want. The action never rises to the level of something like 'John Wick (2014)', but it's better than a lot of similar American stuff and it continues the welcome post-'Wick' trend of having clean camera work that favours wider compositions. The movie is really fun when it gets going. It has a few issues here and there, and it's arguably a little too sappy for its own good, but it's an entertaining actioner with a strong central performance and several accomplished set-pieces.

Review-Title: Die Hard Meets Home Alone Meets Friday The 13th!
Review-Description: "Violent Night" is a satirical, extremely violent dark comedy about the "real" Santa Claus looking to save a little girl and her family as they're being held hostage by a group of military trained criminals. David Harbour is simply perfect as the bad ass Santa gone all out wild on the criminals. Just imagine "Die Hard" meets "Home Alone" meets Jason from "Friday The 13th" movies, add tons of violent gory deaths with tongue firmly planted in cheek and you'll get an idea what this movie is all about. This is not masterpiece theater so if you're expecting something profound, please look elsewhere. "Violent Night" is good holiday gory fun and those of us who enjoy this type of humor (pitch black humor) will certainly enjoy it very much! 9 out of 10!

Review-Title: HO HO HO Holy Mother, that was fun!
Review-Description: Isn't it fantastic when everything you love nicely comes together? Especially around Christmas! What I like to do most during the holiday period is watching at least one - preferably more - Christmas horror movies, but the two mainstream non-horror Christmas movies that I've seen the most (that everyone has seen the most, for that matter) are "Die Hard" and "Home Alone". "Violent Night" may not be a genuine horror movie, but it's excessively violent for sure, and - moreover - it's a love letter to the two aforementioned cinematic Christmas landmarks! Tommy Wirkola, who brought us the refreshing "Dead Snow", goes mainstream with this thrill-ride of an actioner about Santa Clause - the real one - battling a small army of evil scoundrels and protecting a cute girl and her rotten wealthy family during a heist/home invasion. It's not very original, it's not particularly sophisticated, but it sure is a lot of fun. Certain ideas and gimmicks in the script are genius, like Santa having a Viking background, the casting of Beverly D'Angelo as a loathsome hag of a matriarch, or the killing of thugs with Christmas attributes like candy canes or electric lights. Other parts are clich√©d and/or sentimental (but mandatory), like the overlong "true meaning of Christmas" conversations, but that's just a minor default. The "John Wick" type of battle in the bar is d√©j√†-vu but nonetheless exciting, especially because it's to the cheesy tones of Bryan Adams' "Christmas Time". There are other jolly great songs on the soundtrack, like from Slade and Burl Ives, and a great role for John Leguizamo as √ºber-villain "Scrooge".

Review-Title: Awesome santa. Better than expected. Unnecessarily gory
Review-Description:
Is definitely NOT for under 13. Have many weird comebacks, yet enjoyable, to Die Hard and Home Alone combined. David Harbour delivers an excellent rendition of a Santa really worthy yo be a Mortal Kombat One character; John Legizamo is excellent too
After a thousand gunshots the movie somehow still hold many plot holes (pun intended), but who cares when you are enjoying Finish Him combos. The only really bad part is trying to make an action movie and go with the trend of extra violent extra gory extra ketchup blood sprinkling all over the camera and limbs and heads rolling around. I will enjoy it one more time some other christmas in the future.

Review-Title: Good concept, terrible script and execution
Review-Description: It's always terrible when you see a concept that has potential, but then is destroyed by the script and by the directing. This film is precisely and instance of that. Home Alone has more actual violence than this. Sure, Violent Christmas has violence and gore, but it's not truly violent, because there is nothing at stake, it's empty of thrills and its so incredibly dumbed down and bland that only a very very specific public will find this good. The gore is not shocking at all, the psychological violence is null, and the characters have lines that are trying to pay tribute to Die Hard or Home Alone, but just sound like they were written by a 5 year old. There is good stupid and bad stupid and this is clearly in the bad camp. Good concept, absolutely terrible execution. Makes you wonder if the script is actually good, but then the studio came in and completely destroyed it. This film could easily be PG-13, it doesn't offend or shock anyone more than home alone does. Pathetic waste of money and a good idea.

Review-Title: Die Hard when Home Alone with Santa Clause
Review-Description: This movie turned out suprisingly entertaining. It was much better than I expected. I ignored this movie for a few weeks but when I saw reviews in IMDB, I decided to watch it. And I'm glad I did. Think of this as amalgamation of Die Hard, Home Alone & Santa Clause movies. It is a very different take on Santa. A Santa whose inner animal has been unleashed. And while it is gory in many areas, it never truly takes itself seriously. The movie has plenty of comedy thrown here and there. Some good, some terrible. But all-in-all, it was entertaining. So, if you don't take this movie seriously and accept it for what it is - ie. Pure mindless entertainment - then you won't be disappointed. SUMMARY: A different take on a Christmas movie and Santa Clause. It's entertainment not for kids.

If you like Gore and action more than storylines I think you'll love this. The guy who played Santa was fantastic! He displays a depth of emotions. He truly cares about people. He's also a troubled soul, which makes him very relatable. He can also really kick his ass which is really fun. Lol This was entertaining enough that I didn't need to pick up my phone while watching it But there was quite a bit of character development with the hostages and we didnt get a Resolution of any kind with any of them when the movie ended. By the time the movie ended I really wanted to know what was going to happen with the relationships of the hostages, and we didn't get resolution with any of them. They all got to live, and Santa rode off on his sleigh, and the movie was over This was one of the most OVER THE TOP GORY violent movies I've ever seen next to that World War II tank movie with Brad Pitt and Shia LaBeouf. The home alone gimmicks added up to about not even five minutes of the movie The biggest theme of the movie are the diehard references, but it wasn't enough to make this movie a classic or a new favorite I love die hard, and I wish there was actually a lot more specific diehard references This movie went for Gore over a great storyline or great characters or great side characters It doesn't even hold a candle to die hard, which is one of my all-time favorites.

Review-Title: A good story but a bad movie
Review-Description: The actting is awful with so many nonsense moves. He modified that useless Mustang and added 4 exhaust?? Seriously? Why would anyone do that? First, it appeared with Two exhaust pipes but when he went to fight we saw it with four exhaust. In one fight scene he stabbed with a knife in the leg but he walked normally after that. And for not killing the lady with that evil laugh when he got the chance would anyone just tell me why? What's the point? Overall the movie got a great idea but the tried to do it John Wick way and they ruined the whole thing. They can make a second season with a better cast.

This film was a poor man's Law Abiding Citizen (at best). The film jumps straight into the mute protagonist in some sort of chaotic scene. The next 25 minutes is the main character mourning a child we've never seen who was killed in the crossfire of an unknown gang war. Cheap and tacky feel during the first 1/3rd of the film with no character development or character bonding possible from the audience. Due to the lack of context around the characters themselves. 2/3rd of the film is the standard montage of the protagonist suddenly training to become a killing machine in his garage. Final 3rd is the inevitable killing spree. Very bizarrely they choose to make everyone else mute. Because the protagonist is mute, as some kind of suspense/bonding tactic by the creators. But it just makes no sense.

Really boring. Had to fast forward so many times... The main character is hollow despite a much too long introduction. He has no consideration for his wife and is a living clich√©, so to speak. It reminded me the Charles Bronson Death Wish movies. It's as bad, just visually better. John Woo needed money but wasn't interested, obviously. Joel Kinnaman has been better. And the story requires more than a suspension of belief. Steven Seagal movies could feel realistic compared to this one. It's a mockery of an action movie, without any humor or irony. Just very bad. Such a disappointment... Not recommended.

Review-Title: Well it's no Die Hard. Or Face Off, come to think of it...
Review-Description: The question: Can John Woo sustain interest in an Christmas-set action movie conducted almost completely in silence? The answer: Not really, no. But he certainly gives it a bloody good go, and after the tedious first half when our grieving father (who has his voicebox blown out early, hence the title) trains himself to be a superman to avenge his dead son, there is a number of impressive fight scenes during the intense climax involving cars, guns, martial arts, knives... the works. To get there though, you'll have to wade through a whole load of soapy melodrama involving the deceased kid and the protagonist's non-existent chemistry with his wife. What makes it even more tough is the aforementioned absence of proper dialogue from the movie, so it's very hard to relate to this couple who can't even properly communicate their feelings to each other. Oh well. I can't help thinking the film would've been better if they'd ditched the stupid 'silence' gimmick and just done a straight action flick. Plus a bit more humour would've be nice... apart from the bizarre opening sequence involving hero wearing a Rudolf jumper whilst chasing the bad guys, there's not much funny here at all. 5/10 mostly for the last half-an-hour or so... once you get there, decide for yourself if it was worth it or not.

I'm sure there is a great actor in there somewhere just waiting to come out, but we have yet to see it I fear, and I so want him to be good. Unfortunately this isn't the time it happens. Whilst you maybe expecting a Robocop 2 style film to follow on from the first remake, you will be disappointed. Largely unrealistic, a run of the day sparky turns himself into John wick overnight. Ok a Temu version of John Wick! Expect lots of action scenes, but then get disappointed when they last a few seconds and your back to the main chara ter going through a Rocky 4 style training programme in his garage to emerge, well, not rocky. Just slightly better than your next door neighbour learning a bit of judo twice a week at the local YMCA. Could have cut out half the film which concentrated on the main character teaching himself how to fight and drive from you tube....we get it! Move on. Although you could have just skipped it all and muddled your way through killing all the bad guys without the training, trust me it didn't make much difference. Definitely a try hard movie, not altogether terrible just slow uninspiring. I'd rather have it been robocop 2 with kinnamon again as at least it's a take on a classic.

Review-Title: No Dialogue? Challenge Accepted Says John Woo!
Review-Description: I had intended to watch this movie in theaters, but there were too many other movies I chose to pay for in theaters and missed out. It may have been good I did. I finally saw this on a streaming service and I was blown away. First, I usually run my sound system at level 20. I thought my ears were messed up and turned it to 25 and still heard very little. I had no idea this movie has nearly no dialogue. While movies have been able to pull this off for effect and purpose, I don't see why no other character in the movie could say anything. Lots of texting and sign language. I guess John Woo was challenged to direct a movie with no actual dialogue. Second, this movie, while cliche to the max, could have been way more entertaining. Everyone loves a revenge / payback movie. However, this was a complete mess. The storytelling was all over the place, and without anyone actually talking, you, the viewer are left trying to learn how to read body language and texts. Third, this is a huge drop off for both Kinnaman who I loved in Altered Carbon Season 1 - IMO, the best single season in Sci-Fi TV history, and John Woo who directed Face / Off. Lastly, the ending of this movie was more of a comedy than anything. I really don't know if John Woo was trolling the studio for the ending or what. The action scenes were ok, but the rest of the movie was a complete mess. The only positive is it's only around 100 minutes so you can watch in one sitting.

Review-Title: Not sure there are any redeeming points to this film.
Review-Description: I generally like Joel kinnermans films, good solid actor and funny too. I think I thought this was going to be a Death Wish type movie, and have no issues with revenge vigilante films. This was definitely not what I thought. Violent, tick, story, well there is story, so tick. But ultimately this is a grim, grim film of a man in pure raw grief. Could never have a happy ending. In many ways it reminded me of 3 Billboards..... A great film, but half way through you realise that Frances mcCormand would get her revenge but never get her daughter back. We made it to the end, but it's 1 hour 44 minutes of my life that I can never get back. Nothing wrong with the activity, but a grim movie that I (and husband) disliked intensely. You have been warned.

If you can't think of anything to write perhaps don't attempt a feature length movie. This is just another gimmick in the last few years that has been tried as everyone is struggling to come up with new ideas. Maybe black and white films will make a come back next year. I like Joel, but here he is about as hamstrung as an actor can be agreeing to be in a film without dialogue. There has to be some sort of savant film maker to be able to pull this off, and Woo is more of an action director, and it just doesn't work. Sadly, even if you add in a script and additional veteran actors this is still a mess as the story is just simple. Hard Pass.

The relationship and love of the father and son are beautifully depicted in this awful film. Unfortunately, that's ALL that's good, wholesome, right, meaningful or even believable in this bloody, violent, waste of film. Totally EVERYTHING else is complete crap. According to.the Merriam-Webster online dictionary, the primary meaning of the word "gratuitous" is:
"1 : not called for by the circumstances : not necessary, appropriate, or justified : UNWARRANTED" The ridiculous car scenes, gunfight scenes and gang-war scenes in this 104 minute dreck lend a whole new meaning to the phrase "gratuitous violence". More like TOTALLY not called for, COMPLETELY not necessary, VERY inappropriate and ABSOLUTELY unjustified. Blood, gore and violence merely for the sake of blood, gore and violence and not the least bit entertaining.. It's a darn shame because the main theme of the movie (a father's revenge against his sons killers) coulda, woulda and shoulda made a great film. Unfortunately, in THIS incidence, it didn't.

A tormented father witnesses his young son die when caught in a gang's crossfire on Christmas Eve. While recovering from a wound that costs him his voice, he makes vengeance his life's mission and embarks on a punishing training regimen in order to avenge his son's death...... 20 years later, and Woo finally comes back to Hollywood, and the first thing I thought after watching this was.......why bother? When he first arrived in Hollywood for his first ten year stint, he made two excellent films, and three decidedly average. You can guess what the two great films were, as the others were Paycheck, Windtalkers, and Broken Arrow. But even those three look like The Killer compared to this rubbish. Kinnamen watches his son die, gets shot in the throat, and works out for a year. That's eighty percent of the film. And bless him, I know he's lost his son and everything, but there's no need to be such an unlikeable person, it makes the audience not really care for you. With Woo, it's a given that you expect some really good action choreography with his set pieces, and this had all the potential to be something special, but the alarm bells were ringing when the trailers stated 'from the producers of John Wick'. With a director with the calibre of Woo, it didn't need that added sell, action aficionados know who Woo is, and what he's capable of, so I know i'm not the only one who will be disappointed. There was one instance toward the end, which lasted for about four seconds, when I felt that Woo magic, but then a week later, I saw Hard target and The Killer again, and it reminded me of what a master he once was. This most definitely isn't it. What an ironic title.

Dear Tom Cruise, Thank you so much! Your performances are always a guarantee for top-quality and exceptional movies. I truly believe you are the best in the industry! The film "Maverick" was nothing short of FANTASTIC! :) You are, without a doubt, the greatest, and I sincerely hope you continue to create more movies like this. I greatly miss them! Also, a huge thanks to everyone involved in the movie, even in the smallest roles. Your collective efforts have created something truly GREAT. I mean it from the bottom of my heart
-. THANK YOU, THANK YOU, THANK YOU, THANK YOU!!!! Warm regards, Aron.

So good loved it. Love the plot and everything. It was the perfect amount of action, and you really just could connect with each character. A great movie for action lovers. This movie really puts you in the edge of your seat. It was done so well. 10/10 One of the best action movies I've seen in a long time. So if you are looking for a cool movie to watch with your action loving family I would 100% recommend this movie. It is just pure action no gore and other stuff. Just a great action movie. But there is also just enough not action where you get to know the characters and get to feel like your in the movie.

It is rare for a sequel / reboot to be this good, but they absolutely nailed it! The plot was interesting and believable, the acting was awesome, the soundtrack was incredible and the action scenes were just spectacular! I particularly liked how they handled the scene with Iceman in terms of Val Kilmer not being able to talk due to real-life medical issues. Considering Kilmer said very few words, it was a very emotional and poignant scene indeed. There are quite a lot of callbacks to the original Top Gun movie, so it's beneficial to have watched that before watching this one - you will get the most out of it if you do. But for youngsters who haven't seen the original, this is still a fantastic movie in its own right. They really did a fantastic job with this movie. Watch it!

Review-Title: A distant sequel that respects and surpasses the legacy of the original
Review-Description: Given that the original film is such an iconic piece of american cinema released in the height of the 80s and the launch platform of superstar Tom Cruise, making a sequel seemed a daunting task and at times an unnecesary one, but this film proves otherwise as the final product is a masterfully crafted movie that respects the original film and is able to surparsse it in every aspect: production,acting, dialogue,etc. In order to fully appreciate this movie, a theather is neccesary as it is the only tool that conveys adrenaline Rush of an aerial dogfight. A passion project in Tony scott's memory.

Review-Title: Borders on good but far from a classic
Review-Description: I could not brow an emotional attachment with the characters in this film as I did with the first one. Tom Cruise carries the movie most of the way through but you could near say with a bunch of cliche scenes that were a throw back from the first movie. I could say that the movie felt slapped together more for a cash grab rather than put together a great follow up script from part 1. It was the usual script where they throw the manual out the window and let's do it the way that would get 99% thrown out of a training school whether it be a teacher or student but it's ok for Maverick to work right outside the laws that everyone else is given and get away with it with no action taken. I liked two scenes in it and one was when Tom was initially in the bar and saw his ex wingman's son playing the piano and the scene where he met up with Val Kilmer. The rest was predictable and nothing new added to the story from part 1. It was good but I really felt it was more of a let's run the 2nd movie to grab some extra cash rather than bringing anything new to make it more intriguing. Good and I sat through it but wouldn't go out of my way to watch it again.

Yes offcourse there are clich√©s. Yes offcourse this is a commericial profit endeaovour. Yes the plotline isn't much. Yes, al lot of unnecessary sentiment and drama. But come on. Appreciatie it for what it is. It is a great, visually stunning action movie. It is hard to say wether it is accurate towards the navy and aviation in generaal. Most people do not know and do propably not care. Respect for tom cruise for being in such fine condition in his sixties. Even if you have no clue of topgun part one, this is still a very enjoyable Watch. Go Watch it on a big screen if possible, it adds up to tegen effect.

This is a typical American overproduction. It proves that if you throw enough cash at it, you can make any film spectacular. And truly, the special effects are stunning, time and again.
