I am somewhat in the middle, but am still ruminating.

I might be one of the last people on the planet to see this movie, I deliberately held off because of the hype. I ended up caving and I'm glad I did and let the period of high expectations pass. This meant I could enjoy it for what it is which is lots of fun. The political messages were present but not too in your face, more a sort of background thought as you leave the cinema. As a 49 year old woman I can't say it spoke to me deeply or shocked nd surprised me any way but I did get some laughs. Margot and Ryan are brilliant and I'm sure will soon be reunited in a prequel or sequel. Calling it now.

Review-Title: I'm so glad I waited until it was released on HBO Max and I can't believe everyone claims it's for adults
Review-Description: With all the hype about this movie I was really tempted to see it on the big screen. Not for kids, deep and funny? Count me in! I just didn't get around to seeing it and I'm so glad. It would obviously bore young children, but how did it not bore every other adult as well? What a lame comedy-only one scene made me chuckle, the rest of the "funny" parts made me roll my eyes. I'd say it's more of a tween movie, or even teen if you keep them under a rock. But I don't know what the excuse is for adults thinking it's an amazing, brilliant comedy. And the whole deep part was pretty lame as soon as we saw that Barbie realized that the real world isn't how it is in hers.

This is by far not the perfect movie, but I enjoyed it more than Oppenheimer, which I was not able to finish. This movie is definitely head above a lot of other media in terms of attention to little details and the costumes. Loved this side of it, and I remember seeing lots of YouTube videos that went over all the details and how they are connected to real life or to other media. It also has a really good pacing, and overall feels more like an adult fairytale. Which may not be something for everyone, obviously. I remember when it just came out a lot of people were praising the show for how females are portrayed, and bashed it for how males are portrayed. And there were some who did the reverse. I would say that both sides are correct. Not to go too much into details, patriarchy is depicted as the evil of the world, and matriarchy is the only way to save it. This is not only not true, but it is also shallow, and ignoring real examples of matriarchic rule. At the same time, the movie does touch upon real issues that men face in real life, like the need to fight for even a slither of attention. This is good, but it gets kind of brushed off at the end, almost as if it did not matter, that that's what brought about Kendome. "Kenough" shirt is a good message, but it gets overpowered by the main message, that it is enough for women to just be ordinary. Which is also a good message, but...
The movie just forgot that in reality you need equality. You need both sides to be present and finding common ground. It is ok to be ordinary for both sides, and both sides can do amazing things. To be honest, for more than first half of the movie, I thought that would be the final message, but in the end it was muddied by "women are better", which felt disingenuous and worsened overall experience. The final scene, though did even more damage, but maybe I just did not get it, since I am a guy. Either way, it was more or less an enjoyable experience. Overhyped? Probably yes. Worth a watch? Also, probably yes, if you temper your expectations.

I've watched it about few times I think and it's kinda hilarious. It always cracks me up. The acting is great especially from Will Farrell himself. He sure did a great job for playing as Buddy, a main protagonist. It's probably one of the funniest Christmas films of all time and it's probably one of the best Christmas films of all time as well. It never gets old and it will always be a timeless classic. The character Buddy himself is just mad as a hatter, isn't he? I watched it for the first time on DVD in late November 2004 when I was fourteen years old. If you enjoy watching Christmas films, you'll definitely love this.

Elf is full to the brim with Christmas spirit. It would not be the Christmas season without watching it multiple times. Will Ferrell gives 100% to the role of Buddy and the supporting cast is excellent. The filmmakers could have gone real raunchy with the movie and I'm so glad that they didn't. Rather than rely on cheap humor, the bits in this movie are quick, witty and hilarious. Along with Home Alone and a few other family favorites, this is one of the most quoted movies in my house. I haven't even mentioned the brilliance of the score by John Debney... Perfect! Take the nostalgia out of it and this movie is still, pure magic. It's a story of hope, belonging and having a positive outlook on life. Best Character: Buddy
Best Quote: "The best way to spread Christmas cheer is singing loud for all to hear." - Buddy
Best Scene: "Santa Claus is Coming to Town"
Best Piece of Score: "Main Title"

Review-Title: A Children's Movie for Children! How Refreshing!
Review-Description:
Too many of today's kiddie movies opt for adult jokes, and "slip in' offer-color humor that they think the kids won't get--too often we get kid's movies about pee, poo, farts and anything some overgrown adult-child in Hollywood will get a laugh. This film demonstrates how innocent childlike behavior that is silly can be fun, about how misplaced priorities by adults can be redirected when they tune into what the child professes and, more importantly, loves. The relationship beetween Elf Will and James Cann his father provides a perfect example---adults will appreciate that Caan is remembered for several violent Hollywood classics, but kids don't care, and completely understand when Will is shunned by his Dad--who does come around. Casting Asner as Santa is genius, and the redecoration of Gimbel's classic hilarity--
And--this is really important--the film is EXCITING!

Review-Title: My all time favorite Christmas classic!
Review-Description: Elf is such a good movie! This fish out of water story is hilarious! Will Ferrell is in his element and the whole cast as well cast and do a great job! I really have no complaints with this heartwarming film. I watch it every year, frequently on Christmas Eve. The comedy is on point, Jon Favreau hits the nail on the head I love how the North Pole is inspired by the classic Rudolph the Red-Nosed Reindeer. The message if priorities in life, with the growth of Walter as a character is a common but good message. If you have not seen Elf, you are missing out! This has become a Christmas tradition for many for a reason!

Elf is a film I watched pretty late in my life. I never grew up with it, I was always a Home Alone person, but a couple years ago, I watched Elf for the first time, and I completely fell in love with, and I watch it every Christmas since. Will Ferrell brings to life this pleasant character that brought so many smiles to so many people's faces. This film gave us lots of iconic moments, such as Buddy the elf eating spaghetti with maple syrup and marshmallows, and the "Thanks, Mr. Narwhal!". Jon Favreau is notorious for making The Lion King live action remake which was pretty terrible, but don't forget he made gems like this.

After all these years, I finally thought I should have a look at this, since so many people I know have it at the top of their Christmas movie list. I enjoyed some of it, but it is entirely predictable, schmaltzy, and doesn't really off much of a message. My favorite part was Bob Newhart explaining about the three thing that elves can aspire to. Otherwise we have the old father-who-works-too-hard bit as he ignores his son and tries (gasp) to earn money. Will Farrell is pretty funny at times, but his incessant talking and ridiculous actions started to lose me. There was never any doubt that he would be accepted, the boy would get his father back, and all would turn out well. At least now I can talk intelligently about it. I wouldn't have it in my top ten holiday films, but it's a decent film.

Will Ferrell stars brilliant in one of the best Christmas movies you will ever see. It is probably the first memory I have of him in a movie as that was the best Christmas film from when I was younger. Elf has it all from comedy to a good story and obviously a happy ending. It can be watched casually or as an endless tradition on Christmas Eve. It is hard to point out anything more that could have been done in the film. As a brief plot, Buddy the Elf (Will Ferrell) discovers that he is a human living in the North Pole with Santa's Elves. Upon discovering that he is human and has a real dad in New York, he attempts to become part of his family in time for Christmas, but obviously the way of living between elves and human is quite different. A couple of iconic scenes for me include the eating of chewing gum on the streets of New York thinking that is free candy, and also the scene featuring the dwarf as he mistakes him for an elf.

Review-Title: A Surprisingly Christmas Movie Turned Into an All Time Holiday Classic
Review-Description: This movie has turned into such an awesome holiday classic of all times now. Will Ferrell is an absolute genius in his ability to bring such warmth, humor, love, belonging, and unique character to this movie. That's what made it such a classic. Will and Faizon love were perfect in the rolls they played in each scene. The innocence of youth longing to love and be loved is something else Will brings to the scene in such a unique way in his ability to capture the hope in everyone's heart. That hope is a reality that comes to life during the holiday season with family, relatives, extended family, and special long time relationships with friends.

Review-Title: I like this movie, but not as much as others
Review-Description: I like Elf. I enjoy watching Elf. I find this movie amusing. However, I don't like it as much as many other people do, and that seems to turn them into angry elves. Will Ferrell's enthusiasm as he plays Buddy the Elf is contagious, and you can't help but smile at his innocent ignorance. James Caan also plays the part of the reluctant father so well that you wonder if he's actually going to kill Buddy. Where this modern Christmas classic starts to wear out its welcome is the ending, which unfortunately gets a little too cheesy for me. I'm happy to watch Elf every now and then, but not every year.

Review-Title: Funnyish, but is it Christmas Funny or Ferrel Funny?
Review-Description: Undeniably there are a few laughs in Elf. And it has a decent soundtrack that has lots of festive tunes to keep the yuletide feel alive. Now a few might argue with my reasoning here. But the biggest drawback for me is the rewatchability. Take Scrooged with Bill Murray as an example. I will never , ever tire of seeing the ghost of Christmas present smash Bill Murrays face with a toaster. Still laugh as hard every year. Elf unfortunately for me, made me laugh the first time. But Subsequent viewings don't bring the same enjoyment as the jokes are "seen it, heard it" and have limited replay value. I did enjoy the movie and Ferrel. Love him or loathe him, does what he does best and borders on the farcical with a style that only he can provide. Perhaps that's the problem. Ferrel's rewatchability in most of his work is not the easiest as his work depends a lot on the shock factor which diminishes each time you see it. A movie like Airplane I could watch countless times and still be amused. Elf for me is only slightly rewatchable and If it wasn't for my Daughter wanting to watch in 2023. I would have probably past it by this year.

Movie Title: Home Alone 2: Lost in New York (1992)
Review-Description: This is a very well-made and funny movie which meets all expectations. I guarantee that you will love it and it is the funniest family-friendly movie I've ever seen, besides Home Alone 1, that is. It's a very unique movie and had probably some of the best editing in a 1990s movie I've ever seen. The plot twists, character development, comedy and overall story blows me away. A lot funnier than most Christmas movies. This is coming from the perspective of a person who has very high standards and expectations when it comes to movies, especially festive movies. So sit back, relax, grab a snack of some sort and have fun watching the funniest Christmas movie available.

Movie Title: Home Alone 2: Lost in New York (1992)
Review-Description: Home Alone 2: Lost In New York picks up exactly where Home Alone left off. The movie follows faithfully the tried and tested method that brought huge success to the original, meaning that anyone who enjoyed the first movie should find this equally entertaining. Despite the obvious similarities between the two movies, there are a couple of important additions that differentiate them and should satisfy any skeptic viewers. First and foremost, this time around the action is transferred to New York, an ideal setting for a Christmas adventure. Secondly, the new members of the cast provide us with some memorable performances, the greatest of them being Tim Curry - honourable mention to Eddie Bracken's touching portrayal of Mr. Duncan.

Movie Title: Home Alone 2: Lost in New York (1992)
Review-Description: Watched this from 8pm with my girlfriend, currently 11pm and we're only 50 minutes into the film due to numerous trust exercises. She finds the boy really funny, and laughed when the robbers fell over on the pearls. She keeps giggling and pausing the film, talking about every scene asif she had created all the jokes herself. She is now eating left over Chinese and looks very happy with herself. Every character from the Angels with even filthier souls film has been googled to see which years the characters we're born, apparently its crazy that humans we're born in the 1800's, & most of them are being described as cute. She has just asked me what rating the film is, guessing it is a 12+, could anyone confirm this for me please?

Movie Title: Home Alone 2: Lost in New York (1992)
Review-Description:
REDUX (12/29/2023)
Rating: 9.2
Overall, my favorite Christmas movie as this sequel builds on the iconic elements from the first movie, in a borderline satirical way, to show how Kevin can still outsmart the Sticky Bandits on an even larger scale. Great Direction (the direction on a macroscale is grander this time around as there is a higher production budget and the movie makes an effort to show how large New York is in comparison to Kevin; the direction microscale is pretty generic to 80s family comedies; the direction of actors is great as he can bring out the humor and joy in many moments, helps set the lighthearted tone that Kevin brings throughout the movie; storytelling is very similar to other John Hughes movies), Good Acting (Great from Macaulay Culkin (Continues to bring the youthful charm the movie is known for, Great from Joe Pesci (Continues to bring the comedic charm the movie is known for), Very Good from Daniel Stern (Continues to be the good comedic relief partner that plays off of Joe Pesci), Good to Very Good from Tim Curry, Good to Very Good from Catherine O'Hara, Pretty Good from the rest of the cast), Incredible Story (The concept is very satirical because the movie makes an effort to show that the story is the same one as the first (just grander); the plot structure follows the same plot structure as the first movie; flow between sequences is like the first in that its the standard John Hughes movie; character writing was very similar to the first movie as it replicates what the characters are going through this time around), Great Screenplay (The dialogue is pretty simple as its a family movie (but it is filled with iconic lines), the movie also uses dialogue to show how this movie is the same as the first; the humor was very good and iconic (also pokes fun at how this is the same movie as the first); the foreshadowing is good as it helps with showing the message of Kevin nothing being afraid), Great Score (Continues one of John Williams's most iconic scores), Good Cinematography, Good Sound, Good Editing, Visual Effects (), Good Production Design (Makes an effort to show how grand and regal all the places Kevin stays at in NYC), Pacing was great as it was a steady pace that used its runtime very nicely, Build to the climax was great as it helped tie loose ends in Kevin's fears of being alone and with the old man; the climax is the most iconic part of the movie as it shows Kevin against the Sticky Bandits as he lays the house out with traps to defend himself and show how he is not afraid anymore, Tone was very similar to other John Hughes movies (mixed with Christmas elements), This movie has more of a nostalgic factor for me because I watched it more as a child ORIGINAL (01/05/2020)
Rating: 9.0
Great Acting By Culkin and Pesci, Very Funny, Iconic, Very Fun Movie to watch, Great Score, Great Screenplay, Great Story, Great Sequel.

Movie Title: Home Alone 2: Lost in New York (1992)
Review-Title: Hot Take (maybe not that hot): Home Alone 2 > Home Alone
Review-Description:
The two movies are incredibly similar (almost copy + paste), but I think that Home Alone 2 is the stronger of the two. While there was a chaotic energy when Kevin was left home alone, everything is elevated when he is alone in New York. The Plaza Hotel, Duncan's Toy Chest, the taxi ride over the Manhattan Bridge, standing atop the World Trade Center, the list goes on and on about Kevin's adventure in this film. While you have to suspend belief at the convenience of Harry & Marv running into Kevin again, their beatdown is absolutely marvelous. The thumping that Kevin gives to Marv specifically is legendary. The amount of brain damage or near death experiences given to that man in this film is too much to count. The pigeon lady is a bit rough around the edges, but the turtle love moment gives me the feels. The hotel staff, led by Tim Curry, is ridiculous and makes for some fantastic moments. At the end of the day, this movie is one of my favorite Christmas flicks of all time. Best Character: Marv
Best Quote: "Merry Christmas, you filthy animal." - Johnny
Best Scene: Running in the Plaza and grabbing cookies from the minibar. Best Piece of Score: "Finale"
Song: "All Alone on Christmas"

Movie Title: Home Alone 2: Lost in New York (1992)
Review-Description: They really said "oh you liked the silly, funny, childish tricks from the first movie?" And then made Kevin McAllister throw so many godamn bricks at these guys that I felt bad for the ROBBERS who were trying to steal CHARITY MONEY for KIDS IN NEED from a beloved TOY STORE. The robbers deserve financial compensation- there's something a little sick and twisted about the torture this time around, bricks, paint cans, electrical torture, fire. Is it really a happy ending if it doesn't end with Kevin, in a straight jacket, living in a facility for the mentally disturbed? I'm dubious. (Spoilers!!!!)

Movie Title: Home Alone 2: Lost in New York (1992)
Review-Description: What can I say about this classic. I must of watched this about 100 times altogether - it's an absolutely incredible film that never gets boring. This time Kevin gets on the wrong plane and ends up near your whereas the rest of his family get on the plane to Florida. We see Kevin explore New York on his own, checking in to the hotel on his own and enjoying himself to start with. He ends up bumping into the sticky bandits and that's where it really starts. I just love the way Kevin comes up with all the traps, it's just really fun to watch. I love this movie and I recommend it to everyone. The BEST Christmas film!!

Movie Title: Home Alone 2: Lost in New York (1992)
Review-Description: I probably prefer this film to the first film, and I think it's only heightened by the fact that this was set in New York, and the atmosphere of New York City is completely palpable. Since I can remember I've been totally enamoured with the appearance of lights in the dead of night, and their is a lot of those shots in this film, which I wholeheartedly appreciate. The clout that came from the first Home Alone, means that they production got to film in so many fantastic New York locations, like the Carnegie Hall and Rockafella Center. Kevin McCallister has always struck me as an incredibly clever kid, he is portrayed by the talented Macaulay Culkin, and he manages to showcase the smart as a whip personality without coming across as an arrogant. He also seems to have a magnetic charm that simply captures the affection to both children and adults alike. The aspect of the turtle doves was a nice inclusion, to be able to show to the audience the selfless nature of Kevin through his actions. Joe Pesci and Daniel Stern return to their roles as the thieves, and once again you have Joe Pesci playing the straight man, his styling of comedy in this film is brilliant to watch as he looks down upon Kevin with utter disdain. Not so much the feeling a sequel.

Movie Title: Home Alone 2: Lost in New York (1992)
Review-Description: We can criticize Home Alone for so many reboots that feel no charm to the original, but I can say that this is the only decent sequel. Home Alone 2: Lost In New York is the only sequel that feels faithful to the original and pretty enjoyable. Yeah, it does have the same plot of the first film with the same gimmicks. But it does bring out charm from the predecessor with and some clever and entertaining traps for the final act, great shots that gives a presentation of a New York City, characters that still have memorable personalities, and some new perspective of Kevin learning responsibility. I know fans of the first movie will probably like this. But keep in mind that again, this is going to be the same plot. So I will just give you a heads up on that if you're ever going to watch it. None of the sequels like this one will top the original, but at least this is the only one I can take compare to all the other stupid sequels/reboots that are made.

Movie Title: Home Alone 2: Lost in New York (1992)
Review-Title: Lazy, but it's still good like the first
Review-Description: I really don't want to like this movie. It's possibly the laziest sequel in history. The messaging, the story progression, the B plots, the jokes and when they come, even some of the traps are all the exact same as the first or slightly altered. Macaulay kulkin also phones it in, in this movie his acting is so monotone. And yet despite all of this I'd say it's just as good as the first possibly better. Yes it's just the same thing done again and yes the acting isn't as good, but the new traps are so much better in this film and for what it's worth the repeated jokes are actually kinda funnier. I really don't want to like this movie for how lazy it is, but it's hard to not say this at the very least isn't as good as the first because the first one was so well done and this is the exact same with a different coat.

Movie Title: Chicken Run: Dawn of the Nugget (2023)
Review-Description: The plot was very simple in idea, and the jokes were very simple except for the occasional funny reference or quip. Like the very mission-impossible-esque music that plays during infiltration of the farm/factory. Decent moments of suspense and suprise. However, there were many times when events in the plot could have been avoided through more logical actions. There were times when the voicing didn't match up with the mouth movements which could make it awkward to follow at times, by they were rare. However, the castings were exceptional at matching the characters, which aided in immersion. Additionally, the namings of the characters were subtle but funny. Such as, Mr Fry, who leads the chicken farm. This film is evidently aimed towards children, but doesn't have much for adults or even teenage audiences. Clich√© heavy movie that is fun, but in a basic way. The original didn't leave much room for a sequel, but it wasn't handled well.

Movie Title: Chicken Run: Dawn of the Nugget (2023)
Review-Description: Apparently this film's creators didn't bring back certain key actors from the original film for fear of controversial pasts and "old" sounding voices. If that's true, and despite whether it would've hurt or not, they worried about the wrong thing. The creators should've been more concerned with the subpar writing and directing that makes this film unwatchable a 2nd time and keeps it out of my Aardman collection. I give the animation and cinematography at least a 9 out of 10. Visually, it meets expectation. I give the story concept and voice acting at least a 7. It's sort of a typical tale of a teen rebelling against parent wishes, but at least told in a worthwhile way, and stays consistent with the action and characters to the end. The replacement voice actors do a decent job, imo. They're not as good and sometimes go through the motions (even the return actors), but they sound similar enough and don't botch it. From those angles, this wouldn't be a bad sequel. However, everything else is well below standard for Aardman. It lacks wit, heart, originality and personality. Most jokes are straightforward, flat, overtly juvenile and overdone at times. Some of the music, additional voices and sounds do not flow. They sound cheaply done and formulaic. It's as if the film's creators had no sense of what made people like the original film or any of the Wallace & Gromit catalogue. As if they expected to have an entirely new, unaware audience to depend on. One that didn't need to see the first film and is made up of easily-impressed 10 year-olds or moms whose film appreciation runs entirely through a kid-only, G-rated filter. There's nothing wrong with G-rated, but this effort abandoned every adult fan with a sense of humor, who appreciates subtlety and creativity - the way Aardman used to "craft" a film. I literally only laughed at one brief scene. I rewound it a couple times because it was reminiscent of the original film. The scene involves Rocky suggesting a rescue plan that lacks plan, then Bunty and Mac give him grief over it. Mac makes a hilarious analogy which is made even funnier by her Scottish brogue. I also thought "Reginald" was a redeeming character and played reasonably well by Peter Serafinowicz. But that was it. Nothing else stood out about this film other than how much it didn't stand out. Like someone else noted, I wanted to like this. I knew 20 minutes into that it was not going to be "great" but I watched to the end with hopes that it would at least finish "good." However, it is only just "okay" on a good day. To me, if you're going to make this effort 23 years later, why not make a proper effort? I'm also baffled by how many reviewers "understand" why Gibson wasn't recalled. He had a degree of detractors even when he did the original film. He's still a viable and good actor today, and has been churning out films the past 3-4 years, including six in 2022. Most are rubbish, but he had a few good films and spectacular performances in the past decade.

Movie Title: Chicken Run: Dawn of the Nugget (2023)
Review-Description: I watched this after having loved the original as a kid (Aardman is a favourite studio of mine). I watched in anticipation for that quirky humour, snappy and action-packed sequences and was met with ... flat and cliche jokes?? It definitely felt like it had the appearance of Aardman but like it had been shucked and shelled by an American company. Left soulless and with dumbed down to the point that it was painful. Jokes now were either too simple or soft or safe, or too over-explained. Aardman is so well known for underplaying a joke or bit and then moving right on. The music also seemed less iconic to me, the themes didn't really hit hard enough and I can't even remember what music they used now ... I read later that Nick Park was not a part of the movie and this combined with the replacement of the two main characters' voice actors really just soured the whole film for me. The daughter in this film also doesn't feel fleshed out enough, but just a carbon copy of her mum. Rocky has become so dumb and is a completely different character. Ginger's voice just lacked that unique tone that the original voice actor had too. The Incredibles setting of the factory was quite funny, and I did like the eye pad reference - that was probably the closest to Aardman's original humour - but apart from that I had to force myself to sit thru the rest just in a delusional hope that it would get better. It didn't ... that last scene was so cringe and added nothing to the movie. I'm hoping that Aardman will return to their roots - this is the weakest release so far. Netflix and streaming companies need to let studios do their thing, they know how to do it best!

Movie Title: Chicken Run: Dawn of the Nugget (2023)
Review-Description: Read a few negative reviews before giving this a try and was certainly expecting the worst. To say I was pleasantly surprised is an understatement - phenomenal follow up after all these years! I'll address the immediate elephant in the room with this movie - the original was obviously a play on The Great Escape, while the sequel is not a satire of any previous movie/story to my knowledge. I think that's a bit of a miss, but knowing that before hand hopefully sets expectations. Outside of no longer being a unique satire, the movie itself is about as enjoyable as it gets. Is the plot groundbreaking? No. Are there some plot holes and maybe a bit of head scratching over the general concept? Sure. But...they're stop motion chickens. If you're hyper-fixated on plot, I doubt you're watching. What I had to admit to within about 15 minutes is the joke writing is *better* than the original. Chicken Run is a delightful satire with a great storyline, but watching as an adult shocked me a bit due to the lack of actually funny dialogue. This sequel is absolutely full of them though, at times having non stop one-liners and puns with Arrested Development-like pacing. End of the day, this is just a phenomenally enjoyable movie. I think they could have developed a slightly more interesting/cohesive plot, but the lines and animation is so fun, who honestly cares. Great fun and will undoubtably be a great rewatch for years, just like the original.

Movie Title: Chicken Run: Dawn of the Nugget (2023)
Review-Description: Chicken run released 23 years ago and most were happy with the ending of the film but they decided to make another one. The clay models are still amazing and run very smoothly like the first film. This one is very colourful compared to the first which uses the colours black and white. The storyline of this film is not as good as the first one in my opinion but is still creative at least. The negatives of this film is some of the characters are dumbed down like rocky is very stupid. Also they got rid of some of the original voice actors because they were (too old) when there voices are mainly the same. Overall this unwanted sequel is still pretty good but not close to the original and that is why chicken run dawn of the nugget is a. 6/10 = good family film.

Movie Title: Chicken Run: Dawn of the Nugget (2023)
Review-Title: Not a bad film. Could have been much better.
Review-Description:
Dawn of the Nugget was quite a good film, it does not live up to the original (but then what sequel does) It was a good story, the idea that they had built a better chicken farm as though going from the experience from Tweedys farm. The heightened security was particularly funny thinking back to the breakout attempts of the original film. And moderising the food items produced - chicken nuggets instead of chicken pie - was a good move given the worlds fast food culture. It is a shame Mr Tweedy did not make anappearance, even if it has only been a minor role it would've been good to see the character again. The ending was very much what I had hoped, going to other films to free chickens, and possibly opens the door to a further sequel. I do not think it was necessary having so much CGI, the original film was classic Aardman and I do not see anything wrong with staying true to that? They kept several of the original voice actors (Babs, Mac, Bunty and Mrs Tweedy) but I cannot say I agreed with the choice of changing actors for Ginger, Rocky, Fowler or the rats. The voices just sdidn't seem to fit the characters (particularly in Fowlers case)
The rats also were quite a funny duo in the original film, but in this one I thought they just didn't work well together.

Movie Title: Chicken Run: Dawn of the Nugget (2023)
Review-Description: I saw the my first Chicken Run movie way back in 2000. Now 23 years later I'm seeing this excellent sequel that picks off from the first. The first film had Mel Gibson's voice acting talent as Rocky The Rooster. Here sadly he is missed. I thought he aught to reprise his role one last time... Zachary Levi(Shazam! 2019) takes over the role of Rocky. He does a decent job however Mel Gibson was way more experienced and versatile as an actor. We also see Thandiwe Newton(The Pursuit of Happyness 2006) take over the role of Ginger the chicken from the original actress Julia Sawalha(Absolutely Fabulous TV Sitcom). The plot of the animated film concerns the birth of Rocky and Ginger's daughter Molly and a new chicken nugget processing factory that opens up in the vicinity of the little island sanctuary they live on. Verdict: excellent and also worth watching again. Excellent tongue-in-cheek humor and superb direction and background music. The characterization was also well done as well as the script. Hopefully this concludes the Chicken Run movies.

Movie Title: Chicken Run: Dawn of the Nugget (2023)
Review-Description: I was waiting on this for a long time, as I was a kid when the first one come out, it was a bit of nostalgia, I seen bits of the trailer here and there and didn't want to spoil it for myself, but it was good, it wasn't as great as I thought it would be, jokes didn't land, there was a lot of lingering about, the first one is most definitely better, so much more could have been done with this, and the storyline, it wasn't bad as I said, but it wasn't what I'd hoped for, I'm not sure if there will be another one, maybe they can learn my their mistakes next time, but it was a little adventure and took me back to childhood.

Movie Title: Chicken Run: Dawn of the Nugget (2023)
Review-Description: I admit to having a soft spot for the original CHICKEN RUN. It's a family favourite around these parts, and one which holds up to repeat viewing today. This sequel, made without the involvement of Nick Park, feels like a cheap Hollywood cash-in and can't be mentioned in the same breath. The absence of Park and the ludicrous recasting of Julia Sawalha in particular didn't bode well for it, and Newton and Levi are both as bland as you'd expect. Where this really falls apart, though, is in the shallowness of the plot. It's one of those sequels where everything's bigger and fancier, but the humour falls flat and the non-stop action soon wears thin.

Movie Title: Chicken Run: Dawn of the Nugget (2023)
Review-Description: Watched this on Netflix and oh my I was surprised. The voice actors were great. The ideas of the movie were amazing. Lots of moments to laugh. The actors were unstoppable. I absolutely, ABSOLUTELY loved this movie. I've watched it five times now. FIVE TIMES. I'm addicted now. If you loved the first chicken run, you will live this. The only difference is that chicken run 1 was made my Dream Works and chicken run 2 was made by Netflix. I live this. Mrs Tweedy comes back after being exploded by a chicken pie machine. Mrs Tweedy has come back for her revenge. They should make another movie! Overall, it is a good movie.

Review-Title: A Roller Coaster of Christmas Cheer!
Review-Description: This movie is so phenomenally well done. This movie starts off introducing a young boy who has some serious doubt about the existence of Santa Clause. He can't sleep and hears the loud of horn coming from none other than the "Polar Express." He is then Introduced to come aboard from the conductor, played by Tom Hanks, to visit the North Pole, throughout the journey the boy meets new friends, has hot coaco, loses a girls ticket, and meets a hobo, also played by Tom Hanks. It's so fun to watch and keeps you on the edge of your seat as they make thier way to the North Pole, but what is so magical is what makes you start believing in the spirit of Christmas when they get to their destination. I hope you enjoy this movie as much as my family and I certainly have each year. Thanks for reading #schroyerfamilydaily #schroyerfamily #arrenschroyer #christmas #thepolarexpress #tomhanks #spiritofchristmas.

The Polar Express was a horrible movie. I watched it thinking it was going to be a really good movie, but instead I was unfortunatly wrong. It was interesting, but the animation was creepy and terrible. It just looked too real. Don't get me wrong, thsi movie has a great message, but to me the yucky animation made it less enjoyable. If this movie had better animation or if it was live action, then it would actually be a really good watch. Sadly for me that has never happened and it will neved happen. This is just a very bad and upsetting movie over all. This is a bad movie and I don't recommend it too anyone. In all, I give this movie a 1.5 out of 10.

Merry Christmas, everybody! My older brother and I have a little Christmas tradition, in which before going to bed on Christmas Eve, we watch the beloved animated Christmas film, The Polar Express. In fact, my brother still remembers when we first saw it on TV in our hotel room on a trip to Barcelona, back in Spring 2005 (when I was barely 2, and he was 5). And it still holds up nineteen years later! Based on Chris Van Allsburg's 1985 children's picture book of the same name, The Polar Express takes place at Christmas sometime in the 1950's, and centers on a young boy, simply known as the Hero Boy (voiced by Daryl Sabara, movements by Tom Hanks), who does not believe in Santa Claus. However, on Christmas Eve, he takes an amazing train trip to the North Pole, along with many other kids, and sets out on a journey of self-discovery, where he soon learns that the mysteries and wonders of life never fade for those who truly believe. In other words, it puts a strong new twist on the meaning of Christmas spirit by representing it as a test of faith. And director, producer and co-screenwriter Robert Zemeckis did a flawless job of adapting the book faithfully, and he also expanded the universe to make it into a feature-length film, by adding new situations and characters; namely a girl known as the Hero Girl (speaking voice and movements by Nona Gaye, singing voice by Meagan Moore), a lonely boy named Billy (speaking voice by Jimmy Bennett, singing voice by Matthew Hall, movements by Peter Scolari), a nerdy boy known as the Know-it-all Kid (Eddie Deezen), and the disappearing hobo (Tom Hanks). The animation is extraordinary! This was the first movie ever to entirely use motion-capture animation, and it's aged like wine. Zemeckis managed to flawlessly implement the designs from Van Allsburg's illustrations into the models, and the faces of the Hero Boy and all the other kids in the movie, even the Hero Boy's little sister Sarah (voiced by Isabella Peregrina, movements by Leslie Zemeckis) still look exactly right for their age. You really can't tell that their movements were done by adults! The color scheme and sceneries, likewise, are downright gorgeous, and Zemeckis's dynamic camera moves and editing just add to it. The only problem is that sometimes, the characters' eyes look a little dead, resulting in some mild creepiness. But when it comes to mo-cap animation, I've definitely seen worse (Mars Needs Moms, anyone?). And all of the characters are excellently developed! The Hero Boy is a very engaging and compelling protagonist. The Hero Girl, likewise, is very sweet, kind, and resourceful. Billy is also very trusting and well-developed. As for the Know-it-all Kid, though he's meant to be annoying and does come off that way at times, he's also super quotable and funny. But the Conductor (Tom Hanks) is my favorite character in the movie! He's very businesslike, and gets some of the best lines. The train's crew, Smokey and Steamer (both Michael Jeter, in his final performance before his death) are great comic relief characters (especially when Steamer breaks the throttle!). And the hobo is very helpful at times. The voice-acting is amazing! Daryl Sabara supplies a certain earnestness as the Hero Boy. As the Hero Girl, Nona Gaye demonstrates that even at 30, she has the range to play a 12-year-old girl. Eddie Deezen is fittingly nerdy as the Know-it-all Kid. Jimmy Bennett retains that classic child's innocence as Billy. But in this movie, Tom Hanks really gets to show off his fabulous vocal range! While flawlessly using his natural voice as the Conductor and as the Hero Boy's adult narration, he gives a good, gravelly voice to the hobo, and a big, deep dignified voice to Santa. Before wrapping things up, let me talk about the music. Zemeckis regular Alan Silvestri, also the genius behind the scores for Lilo and Stitch and Night at the Museum, delivered a beautiful, Christmassy score for this movie! And the original Christmas songs that he co-wrote with Glen Ballard are fabulous. "Hot Chocolate" is a very fun song that my brother and I like to sing along to, and so is the title song. In regards to the slower songs, "When Christmas Comes to Town", sung by Billy and the Hero Girl, is chillingly beautiful, and the same can be said for "Believe" in the end credits. While I rarely think highly of Josh Groban, the way he sings "Believe" just makes it a better song than it normally would be. The movie also fabulously chooses really good 40s/50s-era recordings of classic Christmas songs, including "Santa Claus is Comin' to Town" by Frank Sinatra. All in all, The Polar Express is a sublime Christmas classic for several reasons. The animation is innovative and beautiful, the characters are marvelous, the music is wonderful, the script is excellent, the pacing is perfect, and it stays fully faithful to Van Allsburg's work. As such, it's a fabulous movie, and a compulsory viewing for Christmas. Oh, by the way... "WHO IN THE BLAZES APPLIED THAT EMERGENCY BRAKE?!?!?!?!?!?!"

This is not one of the better Christmas movies but it holds a special place in my heart and u watch it every Christmas eve. I never realised how uncanny the animation is in this movie. Its so poor and unsmooth that it is kind of off-putting for a lot of the movie. Tom hanks plays half the characters in this movie as well which is a bit weird. A lot of the characters are really Annoying as well, not just the know it all kid. Also I know this happens in a lot of Christmas movies but I'll take this one. If the adults don't believe in santa then where do the presents come from? Cause they aren't putting them there. It's always really annoyed me. 8/10.

Every year this movie becomes a tradition for me and my family, every christmas eve it's played. While there is sound arguments made about it's dated cg and many other aspects of this movie, I believe it's a great well rounded and contained movie, easy to follow story line, the pay off at the end is great and it's really is just chalk full of the christmas spirit and what christmas is. With its kid friendly story but overarching idea of the "forgetting of christmas spirit" i believe makes it able to resonate well with the parents watching this movie as well. This movie needs to become a contender for a holiday classic and a must watch.

I'll bury the lede a bit. I went to Catholic school from kindergarten through senior year of high school. I attended school in the 2000s, so I'm old enough to remember when teachers would wheel in TVs on carts when we'd watch a movie. I also remember that 99.9% of the movies we watched were fluffy and generic, usually kids and bunnies going on adventures or some such nonsense, usually animated and produced by D-class studios. The image of *everyone* in my 8th grade art class falling asleep during -insert movie title here- is etched vividly into my memory. The Polar Express is one of those movies, just with a Hollywood level budget. This was the go-to for wearing your pajamas to school the day before Christmas break, gathering in the hallway, sitting on the floor and sipping hot chocolate. That's all this film is good for. It's a flaccid male appendage in cinematic form. The nameless child characters are nauseatingly opaque, especially the know-it-all voiced by Mandark, the obvious token girl and Billy. The latter two are presented as sweepingly virtuous, but really serve no purpose other than to glorify the materialistic and hyper-capitalistic tendencies of contemporary Christmastime. "When Christmas Comes To Town" has to be the closest thing to nails on a chalkboard ever put to song. This is the kind of film you put on to distract a child and absolve yourself of being present with them in the moment, irrespective of what role you play in their life (parent, teacher, etc). I truly don't understand why this became a holiday staple.

Review-Title: Leaves you feeling cold and sort of empty
Review-Description: I watched this for the first time this week and it's a film that sticks with you in an uncomfortable sort of way. I get it that these special effects were "cutting edge" at the time and yet, seeing how much further the technology has come with films like the Avatar franchise, this one just has a weird, unreality to it, like they hadn't quite figured it out, leaving us to watch these characters that are animated yet soulless mannequins, like something reanimated in a Lovecraftian fiction. Faces don't seem to move right, eyes don't quite track, mouths don't seem to be completely expressive. This is truly the "uncanny valley" on display and you never really get used to it, like these abominations could turn at any moment, spring out of the television and chase you down the street. Adding to the creepiness is that they take these inhuman characters and put them into a frigid environment of endless snow and frozen lakes, but where strangely no one ever gets cold (except for the viewer) . Perhaps these bizarre, lifeless creations are impervious to the effects of the cold? Who knows. Probably the single most troubling part of the film to me was when the three primary characters are lost wandering around the claustrophobic North Pole city, devoid of anyone except for the eerie reverb of old Christmas music echoing through the streets. Lights in windows don't reveal a warm home of elf families eating dinner or anything but rather show only abandoned record players. What sort of nightmarish landscape is this? I will give mention to the music, as Alan Silvestri did a nice job with the score and incorporating old familiar melodies, although I was left puzzled with the primary leitmotif that sounded weirdly similar to the Buddy the Elf motif from Elf (2003) a year earlier. Listen to those first 4 notes and compare them and see if you hear it as well.

Review-Title: One of my favorite Christmas movies
Review-Description: From director Robert Zemeckis, comes an amazing magical Christmas adventure. Based on one of the best selling Christmas book of the same name, "The Polar Express" tells the story about a boy who is curious about Santa Claus' existence boarding a magical train heading to the North Pole. Along the way, the makes friends with a girl, a know-it all, and a lonely boy named Billy. What I like about this movie is how the characters and movie scenes replicates the illustrations of Chris Van Allsburg's book. I even like the scenes where the kids are served hot chocolate, the Hobo and the boy skiing on the roof, the train going down glacier gulch, the wide observation car ride, the ride in Santa's sack, and Santa giving out the first gift of Christmas. This movie is one of the best Christmas movies and it is fun to watch it as a family, and see it in theaters when it is rereleased.

If I boarded this train I'd purposely loose my ticket in hopes of actually being thrown off... Yes this film is nearly 20 years old and has become a favourite among the classic Christmas films but why I don't no ? If it's anything it's a Tom Hank's fever dream...the dudes literally everywhere ! He's the train conductor, the hobo ghost man, the main boy and even Santa ! It's like a bad trip ! And I love Tom Hanks. Oh and the eyes...omg the eyes of all the children are so lifeless, their expressions blank and emotionless! I know the animation was deemed groundbreaking at the time but it's awful and somewhat unpleasant to watch because of how jarring they look. Stuff of nightmares not Christmas cheer ! Also why are they all voiced by adults - especially the annoying 'know it all' kid ! I mean seriously what child sounds like that ? Such a bizarre film.

Review-Title: A great film that deserves much more recognition than it receives.
Review-Description: This film is one of those movies that has to be seen to be believed. No pun intended. This film may not be a masterpiece by any stretch of the word, but it is by far a film that deserves its flowers much more, in ways many viewers wouldn't even recognize. Firstly, congratulations to Sho Igarashi, the Cloth and Hair Supervisor, and the team of clothing animators, for making clothing that is animated realistically in 2004. They did an amazing job, and I give a round of applause. Secondly, the Sound Crew, Skywalker Studios, needs a round of applause for the unbelievably-good usage of foley and sound effect work. Everything from the train wheels on ice to the heart-beats and ringing bells sound absolutely beautiful. And, of course, a big hand to the incomparable Glen Ballard and Alan Silvestri, who knocked the soundtrack composition work out of the park as always. Thirdly, give the choreographers and MOCAP dancers some water and a raise. The "Hot Chocolate" scene was done live in a recording studio for the motion-capture, and I can only imagine the sheer number of takes a dance that intricate would require to pull off successfully. Also, Tom Hanks singing is a national treasure. Fourthly, the coordinators at the Steam Locomotion Institute deserve all the love in the world for the impeccable work on the inner workings of steam locomotives being almost spot-on for this film. (Aside from the flux capacitor, but that was normal for Robert Zemeckis.) And finally, a round of applause to everyone behind the scenes, including the likes of set decorator Karen O'Hara, second-unit director Steven Starkey, and, of course, all of the set designers, welders, foremen, concept artists, and tech workers who had to come together to bring the spirit of Christmas to our screens. From the Looney Submarine to all of you, Thank You. And Happy Holidays.

Review-Title: "Don't get lost in this garden; you'll never be able to find your way out"
Review-Description: This is a line spoken as the characters briefly walk through a garden, never to mention or return to it again. The film is filled with 100s of these 'Chekhov Guns' that are never fired, instead existing simply as attempts to world-build. But since these little details are never followed up on or made coherent with the rest of the story or even seem to contribute to an overarching theme, the story starts to feel convoluted and uninteresting. The animation itself is beautiful, and of course that's what you expect from Studio Ghibli. The actors and music was nice too, but that's not enough to carry an entire film.

Review-Title: Ephemeral Wings: A Ghibli-Inspired Odyssey in 'Boy and the Heron'
Review-Description: 10 out of 10: 'Boy and the Heron' is a cinematic masterpiece directed by Hayao Miyazaki, showcasing a profound love for the Ghibli legacy. The film seamlessly weaves a captivating narrative, reminiscent of Ghibli's magic, with breathtaking animation and a heartfelt connection to nature. A must-watch for every Ghibli enthusiast, as it pays homage to the studio's timeless charm while adding a unique touch of its own. 'Ephemeral Wings' invites audiences on an enchanting journey, where the delicate balance between humanity and nature unfolds in a visual symphony, leaving a lasting impression on the soul.

Review-Title: A more than worthy last big film for Miyazaki
Review-Description: For me it's a 8.5-9/10. When I watched the teaser I was expecting a movie that's a lot darker and serious like Grave of the Fireflies. But they did a good job balancing comic relief and the serious main plot about acceptance of the death of his mother and the role of his new stepmother in his life. They managed to do this mix in very beautiful metaphors, and a couple of allusions to other movies. Visually stunning. The whole movie was produced so well, and it would make a perfect last long movie for Miyazaki as it brings a lot of things together. I am expecting at least one more short film by him though hopefully.

Who knows if Miyazaki will ever retire 'for real,' but this is the closest to farewell I've seen from him. It felt like the best goodbye: timed perfectly, achingly beautiful, haunting, and genuine. The artwork is, of course, masterful. Many of the landscapes took my breath away completely. The character design is classic Ghibli (very aligned with Spirited Away and Howl's Moving Castle) and weird in the best of ways. The film was more suspenseful than I expected from the description, which was a fun surprise. But the real delight of this film is in how deeply personal it is. I felt like I was seeing something private, like a pouring out of Miyazaki's soul. It was a surreal synthesis of the best of Ghibli and the fears of an artist with boundless imagination and a vulnerable inner child. The film wrestles with issues of war and human malice, belonging and sense of place, escapism versus reality, temporal relationships, and grief. I will need to watch it about 10 more times to catch even a fraction of the symbolism, but it's such a moving tale that I'm looking forward to that hunt for its meaning.

Review-Title: Something more than just learning about grief
Review-Description: I have made some reflections about this movie, which I loved. I must say, I did watch few analysis about it but was not entirely satisfied with those reviews. As a matter of fact, most of the people focused on the journey of grief, which I agree is the core of the film, but not the only meaning that is overall conveyed. I hope someone agrees with my ideas and/or has thought the same. Firstly, as in every other Miyazaki movie, there is a lot of concern about Mother Earth. Especially when we move to the other world, we take a peek at the constant respect we must show to other creatures, both those we understand, and those we don't understand, such as the Pelicans. They were inserted in an environment where they were forced to eat the Wara Wara (Pelicans are known for swallowing everything there is to eat, so the choice of the animal, I believe, is no coincidence). The scene where Mahito buries the pelican is incredibly beautiful. Secondly, the Wara Wara become human beings once they "float to the surface". As Kiriko says "It has been a long time since they've done that: we have finally given them the necessary nutrients". I hope that in this case the metaphor is that of giving our children a world where they can actually live in (the necessary nutrients), so they can build a sustainable future (a long time since that happened). Thirdly, life, death and all it comes with it. Grief in all its nuances is shown in this lyrical journey. What I liked was that Mahito was able to meet his mother in a different stage of her life, and therefore remembered her in a new and beautiful way. This enables him to accept his new mother, that has become increasingly fundamental throughout his adventure in the unknown. Moreover, the "magical amulets" are the old ladies looking over him. While he is in another world, those that are protecting him are people that care for him, in particular old people (in Japan the culture of respect for the elderly is much stronger compared to the rest of the world). This again is a message for us and the fact that the bonds created during our lives can overcome everything, moving across time and space. Fourthly, the balance of all our worlds is on a thin line, and we, just like Mahito, are responsible for it. The equilibrium between the blocks, mirrors the precarious state in which we constantly live in. The next wrong step and we risk of losing it. Lastly I thought of a couple of things which might be correct but also not, so I wouldn't take it for granted. The parrots to survive the fall of their world, are forced to enter the one where Mahito lives in. By doing this they become "standard" parrots, maybe suggesting the case of immigrants obliged to adapt to a society that is entirely different than theirs. The friendship between the Heron and the boy, which starts as a relationship where they are enemies and keep hurting each other, up to becoming friends and healing each other. As the Heron suggests, "only the person that hurt my beak can put it back in place". I've taken up this analysis without considering the artistic journey of director Miyazaki. As most say, this is probably his most profound movie, that takes up his relationship with reality and fantasy and the unity that should be maintained within it. In conclusion, the movie is beautiful, and maybe after a rewatch I will understand even better. It is both difficult and easy to see all the things that hide behind symbols and I tried my best.

The Boy and the Heron is what is considered the final work or legendary director Hayao Miyazaki and it has all the things you would expect for his final outing. The film is set during the second world war in japan from the perspective of a young boy. The boy suffers a devastating lost in the beginning and the movie goes through the stages of grief he experiences while being tormented by a strange heron. The movie starts become interesting when the boy goes on a journey through time and space. He meets new characters and challenges that helped him deal with the loss he has. The movie has many references to Miyazaki's previous work and has his style of pacing and storytelling. In some way close to the end of the movie he acknowledges that it is time to move on and let someone else take over from him.

Review-Title: An engrossing and puzzling journey that will stick in your mind
Review-Description: "Princess Mononoke" is the only other Miyazaki film that I've seen (which is clearly my loss). Just saw The Boy and the Heron in its subtitled (not dubbed) English version at one of our local independent cinemas, and it's quite an experience. To say the least, Miyazaki has an inventive mind. The overarching theme of the story is that young Mahito embarks on a journey to meet (or save?) his mother, thought by everyone to have died in a fire the year before. But that summary conveys almost nothing of what happens on screen. We are step by step taken into an increasingly bizarre wonderland of human and non-human, good and evil characters who alternately guide Mahito, or hinder him, or push him along. He's a naive boy, but not just a cipher to whom things happen: he has a will of his own and is not afraid to assert it at critical times -- but as we see, his judgment isn't always true. There's no doubt that Miyazaki has an impressive visual imagination, which is on full display here. I was struck by the extreme use of 'masking' as an animation technique: the backgrounds, landscapes, and settings both outdoors and indoors are rendered with full, lush detail and striking colors, whereas the main characters are drawn quite simply and generically, which makes it easier for the viewers to put themselves in their place amidst the action. (The exceptions are the odd characters that we would NOT identify with, like the Grandfather or the gnome-like grannies in the country house -- those are drawn in very specific detail.) And there are genuinely arresting concepts that will stay in your mind, like the corridor of doors leading into different worlds (in this movie, the multiverse is digital, not continuous!), or the fire maiden Himi. The strongest impression I came away with, though, was that as the movie went along, I could not predict what we were going to see next: the action flows from scene to scene smoothly enough, but with big and sometimes jarring changes in location and sub-theme, as if they didn't want to be held to a single self-consistent storyline. Perhaps I'm just too wedded to Western linear thinking. This story is coming from a truly different place.

Review-Title: Excruciating we had to leave yes it's time to retire
Review-Description: This was a real just chuck if all in the pot and see whats digestible. Well not much at all really, this is a red hot mess one nonsensical scene after another, no cohesive narrative it was like oh yeah lets do that next why the hell not. Tell me a single reason why we should care about anything or anyone in this film, didnt know what was going on who the females were, who the bad guys might be, or what they might have been trying to achieve. It was so irritating we stuck it out until thirty minutes from the end and couldn't stand it any more. Have seen many Ghibli films and this is very weak, anyone raving about it well...dont know what to say to you because this emperor is buck naked.

A beautifully crafted animation full of imagination and charm. This really played out like a Miyazaki greatest hits tour. We have the usual Ghibli ingredients: a young protagonist moving to a new place, an ill or deceased parent or carer, cute little creatures, seemingly evil characters who turn out to be harmless and quite endearing. I actually enjoyed the first part a lot more than when all the action took place.. It's always nice to see a Ghibli set in Japan as well and I loved seeing the landscapes.. Honestly huge credit to the artists because there were some wild moments of animation: shadows on water, reflections in mirrors, sunrises. Don't get me wrong it isn't top tier Ghibli, it's not up there for me with an Ocean Waves, Totoro or Only Yesterday. But it's very very good. If it proves to be Miyazaki's final bow than it is a wonderful way to go out.

Like genuine masterpiece. Symbolist and surrealist masterpiece, smart, a thinker but clear, very deep into grief psychology and then journey through it, journey through becoming self and a new self at a early age, difficult to portray and done perfectly. Music on the more conceptual side this time matching the film's emotional ride. Great mix of animation styles to show an era and slowly becomes more defined as the film goes on. Amazing design all over. So deep it's really quite a ride. Definitely a multifaceted message to the world, becoming, self and what's to come of both what we create and what he's created.

A really good family movie. I watched with a 5 year and a 2 years old. A lot of violence and fight scene, so that's where the youngest started to wander off. But overall fun for all. No hidden adult jokes or things that will go over children's head. It told its story fair and square. It gave good memories of many hours in front of a NES, and the 5 year before who is used to Mario kart was also full of excitement about car scenes. We watched it in Danish though, got to watch later to listen to Jack Black's Bowser. The animation itself was at times vey realistic, and very well done. No ugly Sonic here.

Let's be clear from the start : Super Mario Bros was crafted with one primary goal-to delight and cater to a massive community of fans. Embracing this premise, the film delivers an unabashed celebration of the iconic gaming universe that has been etched into our hearts since childhood. It's a whirlwind tour through a family of characters, a fast-paced homage to the games we've all cherished, even if the visitation is somewhat brisk. Undeniably, this isn't the film of the century, but it achieves what it sets out to do-it entertains, and it does so swiftly. The runtime breezes by, a testament to the film's intent to jog memories and evoke a sense of nostalgia in the shortest possible time. It's a delightful montage of familiar faces and game scenarios, a fond reminder of the diverse landscapes we've explored in the virtual realms. The film dabbles in every character and game we've encountered over the years, providing a rapid-fire trip down gaming history. While the speed might leave some wanting more depth, it aligns perfectly with the movie's objective: to spark joy, laughter, and wonder. Super Mario Bros' isn't aiming for profundity; it's aiming to tickle the funny bone and ignite a sense of marvel. In essence, the movie is a thank-you note to the fans, a gleeful acknowledgment of the shared joy that gaming has provided. It's a lighthearted, easily digestible experience that doesn't linger unnecessarily, ensuring that the audience leaves with a smile on their face. Thank you for bringing this anticipated film to life and for creating it with the intention to make us laugh, have fun, and be enchanted-mission accomplished.

When I first heard about the movie, i prayed from all my heart that it won't be a disappointment that your demolish childhood memories.. And when I actually finally watched, I cannot say anything except that i am extremely satisfied... The movie has maintained the Mario theme to the maximum level.. Including the soundtracks, the usage of magical boxes.... Adding DK.. Also the entire Mashroom World is exactly how i always imagined it.. I enjoyed watching it.. And loved how the movie was meant to show how Mario was introduced to the Mashroom World and how he had to adapt to it.. Watching the movie reignited the need to replay Super Mario again..

Review-Title: Makes the original Mario movie a masterpiece
Review-Description: The voice acting and script take away 7 points, impacting the overall experience. The graphics hold a certain charm, allowing us to envision Nintendo games on alternative hardware. However, animations fall short with standard, dull, and predictable sequences. Mario's character suffers from a voice mismatch and an inexplicable inability to perform platform jumps, portraying him as the weakest in the galaxy. The claim of Peach being the strongest, solely due to birth, raises eyebrows. Consider revisiting the original Mario Bros for a potentially more rewarding experience, despite its acknowledged shortcomings.

Review-Title: Fun and a little nostalgic Mario movie!
Review-Description: I'm late for this but I have been playing the Mario games since I was 3 or 5 and I have been waiting for a movie for a while, the live action doesn't feel real by this one does and this movie is one of the best animated movies of 2023! The way they have the lore in this is pretty good, all the power ups the rainbow road and the final battle with Mario, Luigi and bowser is perfect! The soundtrack is a masterpiece, with peaches, level complete, superstars, and more. Only issue is is that it's to fast paced and it gets old and I wanted it to be more nostalgia but it's a very good movie 9.5/10. üòÅ üòÄ

All in all a lot better than I expected at first. I did not expect to like this movie at all with all the bad video game movies we have had, but lately is is starting to change. Like with sonic this movies stays close to what the video games is about and does not try to stray further away from it than necessary. The fact that this movie is actually an origin story to Mario(and donkey Kong too) was unexpected but narratively it made a lot of sense. With the addition of all the little Easter eggs and really good western style animation a had a good time watching this movie. The plot on the other hand was very basic but that is not really the reason anyone would watch a movie like this( maybe some movie critics that don't really get it). The movie stayed consistent with its characters and Mario had a nice little arc for himself aswell. Anya Taylor Joy, who is one of the best actresses of this, is not the best voice actress and I think she was really bad as peach, while the others were good.

Watching this just gave me several geek-gasms. I didn't think a movie adaptation of such a simple and innocent video game could be packed to the brim with this much nostalgia. We get mario acting like mario within the first 10 minutes of this thing, Bowser acting a little too cruel for my taste but whatever, and so much goddamn fanservice it's borderline atrocious. I'd be open to a Wario sequel, just for the record. I have to give credit to Nintendo. It takes a special brand of courage to write something that's stupid on purpose. This degree of cheesy belongs on an omelete and I am HERE FOR IT XD This movie was so much fun from start to finish it made me feel like a kid again, if only for a brief moment ^^

I was really looking forward to this movie. My sister and I loved the SNES games in the 90s and also had the Donkey Kong games. This was such a let down. The Mario games weren't all fighting. It was a puzzle based platformer where you had to bonk enemies in the head. What is this? It's like a Tom and Jerry cartoon. There's no humour. It was boring. Just chasing and fighting and not much fun. I don't know what else to say about it, but I've got to write more. I just want the world to know how sad and disspointed I am. I guess I'll just have to go play some old games to cheer myself up. No Yoshi :(

Review-Title: Decent Kids Movie, Not So Great for Fans
Review-Description: It's a decent movie for young children, plenty of action and fun turns that'd keep most kids entertained, but for more serious fans it leaves a lot to be desired. As someone who grew up with a lot of the games and played many of the installments of the franchise with family and friends, the movie was a little disappointing. The general plot of the movie was okay, the more human background of the brothers was great, but past the introduction of the Princess it kind of falls flat. There were a handful of moments that got me excited, (the Rainbow Road scene, the Donkey Kong vs Mario scene, and the ending where Luigi and Mario team up) but there are a lot of moments where the acting and story can be a little... eh. The actors for Mario and Princess Peach weren't overall great either. The voice of Mario could have gotten away with a Brooklyn/American accent quite easily instead of the in-game italian voice, as the brothers are originally from Brooklyn, however Chris Pratt doesn't really deliver. A lot of actors in the cast fail to bring more of the character into their voice acting, leaving a lot of them to only sound like the actor/actress and not the character. Many fans had a big issue with this with Mario's voice, but it's visible in Donkey Kong and Princess Peach as well. Peach's voice actress sounds incredibly different to her in game voice, and it lacks the sweet, kind-hearted nature that Princess Peach should carry. You don't need a big celebrity name or names to make a good film. Prioritise authenticity over having a celebrity heavy cast. In the games, Princess Peach is very sweet, kind and gentle. In the movie she was changed, fitting into a more typical mould of a "Strong Woman" rather than adapting her in game personality. Princess Peach lacked most of her in game characteristics, and subsequently most of her character. Her personality is more akin to Princess Daisy rather than herself. Even in Super Smash Bros. Princess Peach still holds her sweetness and caringness in her voice, body language and attacks, she's still strong and tough, but she's still Princess Peach. There shouldn't be a need to change her. The best part of the movie overall was the soundtrack. The music was beautiful with an excellent combination of songs from different Mario games. The inclusion of the DK Rap was an excellent choice, and brought a lot of joy to me and my brother when we watched it. The non-Mario music were really good choices too. If Nintendo and Illumination decide to make another movie, which was hinted at at the end of the film, I'd like to see more true-to-the-character voicing and acting. The biggest downfall of this film was its inability to properly adapt the characters, which I acknowledge is hard and that the actors/actresses are doing their best, but there is plenty of room for improvement. A voice cast more similar to the one for the animated TV show would work much better than the cast that was chosen (no disrespect intended towards the actors/actresses)

Review-Title: It Does What It's Meant To Do In The Best Way Possible
Review-Description: They could not have made this movie any better in my opinion. It was meant to be a faithful videogame adaptation for kids, while adults still have moments like ''Oh, I recognise that from the games I used to play!''. The combination of childhood amusement and the nostalgia of adults is just perfect. The reactions in the theaters were so amazing. And yes, the story is pretty thin and not the most original, but it still is a kids movie, and this move did not have the goal to make an amazing new story, just to amuse the people watching the movie who are also familiar to the games. For me, this remains one of the best videogame adaptations yet.

If I could give zero rating to this movies. I WOULD. First of all, I liked a lot of dreamworks movies. Some of them I can watch over and over again. But I could not finish this movie in the theatre. I walked out because there are so many ridiculous jokes and too much passive aggressive information in the movie that I can't believe they put in! It supposed to be kids movie. So let the movie to be innocent. Not by adding all of those message you are trying to send out , nor those inappropriate jokes. Kids will not understand. I get it . But you know there will be no kids just walk in movie theatre by themselves. So I see how you want to pass those jokes or messages to the parents and the society. I am so disappointed by dreamworks. This company is trying to help to divided the society. You are entertainment company, bring people joy not this ! The story is boring. The music , some of them is fine. But lots of them are way too much! Too much for me as adult not even to say to the children! I wish dreamworks can do some more movies like Shrek, simple , sweet innocent movie for the kids and for the parents all together.

Review-Title: Good but not as good as the 1st two
Review-Description:
Trolls Band Together is a 2023 jukebox animated comedy featuring the voice talents of Justin Timberlake,Anna Kendrick,Kid Cudi and new cast members including
NSync,Camilla Cabello,Troye Silvan,Amy Schumer,Kenan Thompson and Daveed Diggs. Branch(Timberlake) meets a blast from his past who wants him to join Boyzone(a band that is set up by Branch's brothers). Meanwhile Poppy meets her sister Viola(Cabello) who shows up unannounced. Will this cause problems with Branch and Poppy(Kendrick). Overall it was a good film that pays tribute to the early 00s(especially having NSync who Justin Timberlake was apart of since the late 90s). The story was good too but honestly I preferred the last two films. 3 1/2 out of 5 stars.

Review-Title: Not sure of who the audience is here
Review-Description: Just saw this with my kids and we all thought it was ok. I think the one huge thing that they overlooked is that kids do not care about old boybands at all, so all of the references went over their head and the story itself was kind of forgettable. At the end, Branch out if the blue reveals that he was with a boyband other than his brothers and the *NSYNC trolls appear to sing a song. While the adults obviously got it, my kids were confused by an ending where Branch suddenly had a different band for no reason at all. If this was meant to entertain adults, the lame sexual innuendos and drug references just felt lazy and forced. It was more offensive that they think this is how we're entertained than the fact that it was in a kids movie. Just completely unnecessary. Overall, it just lacked the charm that the first one had. It didn't have a strong story and no real message other than having siblings is great if you magically have the same personality like Poppy and her conveniently new found sister. Not completely terrible, but as my kids would say, "This is a total cash grab."

I have waited so long to see this movie because I love music and great cinematography. Firstly the music was cute yet so serious. It was adorable. The cinematography was vibrant. The colours were enthralling. It was a feast for the eyes and ears. The jokes were witty and for adults too. What I love most about the trolls is that they band together and are super close, friendly and generally positive. It was a thrill picking out the voice actors from the trolls dialogue. My favourite one is Justin Timberlake. It was a sweet escape and I thoroughly enjoyed it. I would recommend to young at heart adults and children. I gave this movie 10 out of 10.

Let me tell you something pal -- this soundtrack is a freakin banger. I took my friends to this who have no idea what the Trolls Universe was and after the film everyone was signing the songs in the car, at the restaurant, and at home. The villains were iconic, the plot was everything we needed, and Keenan Thompson's character made my friend (Leshawn) bust out laughing in the theater. It's a kids movie so I expected not all the jokes were going to land, but all of them did. The adult jokes were so funny because it was so relatable. The best part especially about this type of movie is the meta-community behind it, where from the music, to the immersive art, make sure you check it out when you can.

Review-Title: simple but engaging, with enough twists and surprises to keep the audience entertained
Review-Description: This is Bing. I can help you write a template movie review for the film Trolls Band Together. Here is an example of how you can structure your review: --- # Trolls Band Together: A Musical Adventure with Heart and Humor Trolls Band Together is the third installment in the animated Trolls franchise, and it might be the best one yet. The film follows Poppy (Anna Kendrick) and Branch (Justin Timberlake), who are now officially a couple, as they embark on a quest to reunite Branch's long-lost brothers and rescue one of them from a pair of evil pop stars. Along the way, they encounter new friends, old enemies, and a lot of catchy songs. The film's plot is simple but engaging, with enough twists and surprises to keep the audience entertained. The themes of family, friendship, and music are explored with warmth and humor, and the film delivers a positive message about not letting anyone steal your talent or your joy. The character development is also well-done, as we see Poppy and Branch grow closer and learn more about each other's pasts, while also meeting new characters who have their own personalities and arcs. The film's overall impact is uplifting and fun, with a satisfying conclusion that celebrates the power of love and music. The director, Walt Dohrn, does a great job of creating a colorful and vibrant world for the trolls, with a distinctive style that blends 2D and 3D animation. The film is visually stunning, with a lot of attention to detail and creativity.
