The musical sequences are especially impressive, with a variety of genres and styles that showcase the talents of the voice cast and the original songs. The performances of the actors are also excellent, with Kendrick and Timberlake leading the way with their charm and chemistry. The supporting cast is also stellar, with notable roles by Troye Sivan, Eric Andr√©, Daveed Diggs, Kid Cudi, Amy Schumer, and Andrew Rannells. The film's strengths are its music, its humor, and its heart. The film has a great soundtrack, with songs that are catchy, funny, and emotional. The film also has a lot of jokes and references that will appeal to both kids and adults, especially those who grew up in the '90s and are familiar with boy bands and pop culture. The film also has a lot of heart, with scenes that are touching and sincere, and characters that are likable and relatable. The film's weaknesses are few and minor, such as some clich√©s and stereotypes, some predictable moments, and some scenes that might be too scary or sad for younger children. Overall, Trolls Band Together is a delightful and enjoyable film that will make you laugh, sing, and feel good. It is worth recommending to anyone who likes animated films, musicals, or trolls. It is a film that will make you want to band together with your loved ones and celebrate life.

Review-Title: Colorful, adorable, familiar and full of music
Review-Description: I have always believed that animated films for children's target audience are mainly adults, since they almost always have messages that clearly reach children but not in the way they can reach an adult. This film is about family ties, about how they can be broken but later they can always heal again based on communication. It also talks about acceptance of those we see as different, how wanting power can lead to harming others. Super colorful, happy movie, perfect for these times, which maintains the essence of Trolls but with new characters, with a lot of music, makes you want to dance and sing, with many references to famous people (in the Latin American version they adapted it to regional references) and at the same time world of Hollywood and entertainment. Movie that brought NSYNS back together (despite JT's cancellation). Film that can be enjoyed by adults and children.

This movie was adorable and fun to watch because the entire franchise has been great and because my sister was in love with these toys as a kid. The movie had some adult humor in it that I enjoyed as a 25 year old, reminds me of old Dreamwork's movies like Shrek. The movie in itself was well planned out and the music was fantastic. A few things in the movie I struggled with were the moral dilemma in Veneer and the scene where Viva and the golf ball trolls want to kill Bridgette. The cast list in the movie amazed me with how extensive it was from movie and tv stars like Zoey Deschanel to Kid Cudi to Anna Kendrick. The moral dilemma in Veneer was not well executed in my opinion, I would have either preferred a more direct positive change before the big concert or a immediate change at the end on the boat, not a progressive change. As for the scene where they want to kill Bridgette, I think the idea was great but the fact they didn't make the scene a bit longer, lessened the impact. The movies music was phenomenal and I will say that again and again. 3/3 on the Trolls franchise soundtracks. My favorite part: The final scene where NSYNC shows up and sings with Timberlake like they had use to sing together was iconic.

Review-Title: It's really fun Moreover, the music is very exciting
Review-Description:
Yes... the animation is fun, especially for children, the animation is colorful and adorable, I enjoyed it especially with the music which was really fun to listen to, I even sang along
My kids love watching this Trolls because cute yea ofc ...I also like the Trolls characters, especially Poppy and Branch,they sing well. For animations with a music genre, this film is the best in my opinion
As for the story, well... it's not bad, even though there is a forced story like Poppy's sister who just appears The story is too classic
I enjoyed this film more for the music and animation than the story.

I feel like this third Troll movie should've been the second one. Cause I see it has way more connections to the first movie than the second one. Bridget and King Gristle got their love story sequel, Poppy found her long lost sister, the big reveal of Branch's past. Compared to the second movie, which has way less connection to the first movie, this one just felt more like a continuation of the first movie. I mean, the second movie didn't even include King Gristle! But that's just my honest opinion. Anyway, moving on to the review. Just like the other Trolls movies, it's full of music. Only this time, it's all about boybands. Boyzone, N*Sync, Backstreet Boys, 98 Degrees, etc. You gotta be a music lover or a child to enjoy this movie. Otherwise, it'll felt like watching any other animated movie. To me personally, It would've been great if the members of Brozone were voiced by N*Sync members. Too bad... too bad...

I didn't grow up celebrating Christmas, but I still watched handful of Christmas movies. Mostly the 90s and early 2000s classics. I remember watching this movie back when it was first released, and felt in love with it instantly. I decided to Re-watch it, 4 yrs later and I still cried. What a lovely, charming and clever film. A lovely origin story of the wonder of klaus. I can already see myself rewatching it in the future and still crying. Esp, when the little sami girl finally got her gift. The quote, "A true selfless act always sparks another" will stick with me. Truly one of the best Christmas movies. 10/10.

Review-Title: One of my favorite movies ever
Review-Description: This movie is just phenomenal. The animation is beautiful, the characters are memorable, it's weirdly dark but also extremely wholesome. I love that it also it's left vague what's magic, and what's real, allowing your imagination to take over. It's also very funny, the villains had me laughing out loud every time they were onscreen. I also love that it takes familiar stories such as the emperor's new groove, Romeo and Juliet, and Santa origin stories and make a beautiful mix into this movie. Word needs to be spread that this movie exists, the people I've showed this too were like "how have I never seen this? It's amazing." If you love this movie as much as I do, spread the word!

Review-Title: Woooo wooo The best Christmas movie
Review-Description: In 2023 I just saw the best Christmas movie for me and with excellent animation and from Netflix. This film includes animation, drama, comedy, emotion and very very emotional. It's about Jesper, the spoiled and egocentric son of the owner of the post office. He sends his son to a town on a distant island to be the town's official postman. He tells him that he has to collect 6,000 letters in a year so that he doesn't lose his inheritance (knowing that it is almost impossible since it is a town that, due to traditions and customs of yesteryear, is divided into 2 sides Ellingboe vrs Krum), in a town where the rule is to harm the other side without reason, where the children don't go to school, Jesper discovers Klaus (A widower who tried for many years to have children with his wife but they couldn't, in all those years of waiting for a child he started making wooden toys for them) , a man who had lost his way but with the arrival of Jesper he finds him (although Jasper's initial intentions were to recover his life as a millionaire), they begin a journey that takes us to all the traditions related to Santa (giving gifts at night). Chimney, good and bad children, coal for the bad ones, leaving food for Santa, writing letters to Santa, the sleigh, the reindeer, Santa's helpers, Santa's suit, gifts around the world), how you begin to know That bad children should not be given gifts, the children of this town begin to change it by doing good actions for the other side, which begins to generate a change in the town, just as they want to know how to write and read to write letters to Klaus. Which makes the school open. It shows us how they begin the tradition of gifts on December 25. In the end Jesper decides to stay in this town, he and Klaus being the ones who gave the gifts (this with the help of the foreign girl who is the one who teaches Jasper the meaning of everything he is doing) for many years, until Klaus As an old man, one day he dies or fades away, but Jasper, without understanding how, knows that gifts continue to be delivered every Christmas and knows that he can see his friend once a year. One of the best animated films of recent years with excellent animation and a beautiful official song, it covers many topics such as wars, hatred for being "different", social segregation - by "races", fertility problems, importance of education, how education can change a people, not having a clear direction, losing the sense of vocation and finding it again, friendship, family, how children are a reflection of their parents' education, how children are born without seeing social-racial differences, they only see people the same as them. The most important thing is that one sincere act always leads to another and with this we can change the world for the better.

Review-Title: From time to time Netflix gives us something beautiful
Review-Description: From time to time Netflix gives us something beautiful: In a world of good, bad, curious, and terrifying movies, this one is beautiful. That word, said quickly but carrying a special meaning, is how I would describe this film. It allows us to see the humblest and purest origin of Klaus. It manages to make you feel warmth that wraps you on a cold night, no matter where you are. That's why it deserves a place on the list of classics we grew up with. There's nothing better than being with family, sipping hot chocolate in the morning, with no work to do or stressful things to think about, and feel like a child again.

So horribly formulaic, as others have said, poor character development and so epically predictable. Santa's story didn't need to be rewritten this badly. If you want a good spoiled brat turned good story with interesting villains go rent "The Emperor's New Groove". If you want to see decent heroics go rent "The Lion, The Witch and The Wardrobe". The animation in this one is prettier but pretty doesn't mean better. The voice talent is decent enough, but that all. The jokes are just bad and characters do a lot of things that don't make a lot of sense unless you are a depressive type and we all know how that makes for fun entertainment!

Klaus was an enjoyable film to watch. What makes a good Christmas film is something novel and interesting. Klaus keeps you entertained and wondering how things will work out. In the back of your mind you are trying to piece together how this feel good film will end. How creative to use a town in the wilderness as a setting and tell this fun tale. The tale also has some depth with a great meaningful message about acts of kindness. It is through this and the magic of Christmas that we see a hostile town transformed to a happy town. The film does not try too hard to weave in the traditional Christmas stories and legends into it but effortlessly makes references to it. Christmas movies can take a page out of Klaus's book on how to make a good Christmas film.

Review-Title: I wish all the Christmas movies were like Klaus
Review-Description: I took a chance on this and so glad I did. This is a truly original script that takes you on a journey and has something for everyone to enjoy. A little intrigue, a little romance, a little heartache with characters you will fall in love with. Great casting choices for the voices with a particular spotlight on Klaus. This movie will leave you completely satisfied and ready to watch it again and again every Christmas. I just wish all the Christmas movies coming out had this much quality in their script, story and casting. I saw in someone else's review, "in a sea full of Christmas movies, Klaus stands out" and I could not agree MORE!

Review-Title: We watch this one again and again
Review-Description: This one has become a Christmas staple in my household. We HAVE to watch it every year and every year we both laugh and cry over this movie. Not only is the animation of it top notch, the casting very good and the story surprisingly fresh for a tale as old as time, the flow of the film is absolutely perfect. It has everything from the moments you detest to the moments that you love. It has characters that you fall in love with at first sight and characters that you learn to love over the course of the film. Oh and it absolutely has characters you dislike too. All and all it is one that we keep coming back to. And honestly? It should have won that Oscar! üòâ

The film is a work of Christmas art, starting with the characters who are charismatic, the dubbing is excellent, very funny and super fun, we evolve with the characters during the film and we start to like them more and more, I loved the death scene of the Klaus' wife, we don't know the character but just from the revelation, their story makes you feel bad with Klaus, or in the scene where a member of the Krums destroys the wall between the rival clan showing that things are different now, and the best character: Jesper, he starts out as annoying (and he really is) but as time goes by in that place, living with people and increasingly caring about them, creating a butterfly effect throughout the city is the most incredible thing in the world. Film, since we saw everything he went through and faced to make this, not to mention the other characters who are great too. The script is phenomenal and the story is super interesting, it's so cool that you feel like you're in that city, you feel like a civilian from that place, like for example, the revelation of the fake gifts at the end, in many works you would know that they They are fake gifts because you see more than the characters, in that Klaus is a civilian in that city and discovers things with the characters. I loved the soundtrack and the direction is phenomenal, this film deserved the Oscar, this film is the true winner of the 2019 Oscar!

It is the fourth year I come back to see this movie and I am still excited, amazed and brought to tears. Klaus is a modern twist to the classic tale of Santa Klaus. The big-city spoiled child motive is elegantly incorporated into the story with Jasper. The whole movie is perfectly written and executed whilst the style of animation leaves you in awe. The soundtrack is blended well and succeeds in it's goal to make you emotional and immerse you into the scenes. The ending is powerful yet simple and delivers the final piece of the puzzle that "stamps" this movie's status as an absolute classic.

Review-Title: Good modern retelling of a classic story
Review-Description: Too many get caught up in absolutes. You either change everything or change nothing for a minor subset of people on either side. The old Seuss purists deride this story as not faithful, while others deride it as run of the mill with nothing new. After all, what's the point in telling the things exactly the same based on a societal viewpoint decades old, and little point in changing everything including the original message. In the end, the story is about the core of the Christmas spirit with spending and enjoying time with family and friends, not about the material goods that our capitalistic society has pushed. That is the message of Dr. Seuss' original story and of this movie. Pharrell's narration pays homage to the original animation that felt lacking in the live action Carrey movie. Cindy Lou coming from a single parent home winds up resonating with more families these days, and not the nuclear family ideal from the original story. The Grinch is still humbuggish doing mean things to in an attempt to interrupt other people's happiness. The gadgetry from Dr. Seuss' story's comes to play and fits and looks better in this movie. Finally the lyrical nature of the lines, feels like I'm listening to Dr. Seuss' stories. I'm neutral on the redo of the song. Its not bad, but I would have gone with something more along the lines of something Taylor Swift or Kelly Clarkson would sing. Things I would have done without is the whole reindeer search and screaming goat, it felt unnecessary. Instead it could have incorporated more of what Cindy Lou tried in the live action movie, while giving the Who's viewpoint of more mean deeds the Grinch had done in the past.

This movie deviates very far from the book. Very far from what Dr. Suess would have accepted. There are missing things that occured in the book that were left out of this movie. There are a few funny moments, but otherwise it isn't enjoyable. I gave it a chance. I found it very unenjoyable soon after the beginning but I kept watching to see if it would get better. It did not. What happened to the crumbs too small for a mouse? What happened to carving the roast beast? These were important parts of the book but left out in this movie. The Grinch's actions were even wrong. The way Max acts is even wrong. Where did the ram and yak come from? If you know and love the book, you're probably not going to enjoy this movie.

Everything about it was just not good. Nothing about this version was rememberable. It doesn't even have any of the classic Dr Seuss rhymes . Most the characters were a disappointment. For some reason Cindy Loo wasn't really as interesting in this version. I don't know there was no connection to any of the characters. The music was horrible just modern pop and even a rap song? The music is what should stand out and make the movie better and fun but the music was just silly and even a little ridiculous. Just no . No thank you . I don't even know how people could rate this more than five stars. I guess some people found it enjoyable but it just didn't have that spark for me .

Review-Title: Ok I like it I really it
Review-Description: First I'm not doubting that this movie strayed far from the book but somehow it worked. I like the humor, I like the animation, and I love the actor Benedict Cumberbatch for playing a likable jerk in the movie. Somehow it got me loving Fred the weird deer. I understand why some people didn't like it but I can't not like it. I say it's a treat for the kids, it's a treat for the family to like, and even adults might like it. I admit I can be a loner and it stresses me sometimes being around people and so I know how it feels when Grinch was wondering around in a crowd and he had an anxiety attack from social anxiety. Not only it touches on child trauma but it touches how easy it is to feel like an outsider when people ignore you. Enjoy this movie for the laughs and fun.

The Grinch is an okay movie. This movie is a remake of a remake. I never watched the original "movie" made in the 60's, but I didn't like the Jim Carrey Grinch movie made in 2000. Jim Carrey was great, but the movie itself just wasn't great. This movie thought, it's okay. I think Benedect Cumberland had a very nasal voice for the Grinch. The Grinch himself was just not evil like he was in the book. He was just a depressed jerk who was just really scared to go down there in Whoville. I gotta admit though, at times this movie is really funny, but every kids movie is a comedy. This movie isn't terrible, but it isn't great. I mean, it's better than the Lorax. In all I give this a 6.2 out of 10.

Well, I Figured I'd Do This Movie At This Time Of Month. Get Y'all's Snacks, Food, & Drinks, & Enjoy This Review. Well, After That Abysmal 2000 Live-Action Version, We Get This 1ne. Let Me Tell You, This Was Fabulous. Definitely An Improvement To That 2000 Version. Now If You Ask Me If I Like The 1966 Classic Or This Version, I'd Say Both. Now Let's Go For Characters & Songs. Grinch Was A Cool Character Just Like 1966 Version, Max Was At His Best Like Always (Including The Bad 2000 Version), Cindy-Lou Who Was Very Sweet Character Like In 1966 Version, Groopert Was Charming, Fred The Fat Reindeer Is Funny, & Every Other Character Were Fun, Cute, Amazing, & Hilarious. As For The Songs & OST's, The Songs From The 1966 Classic Definitely Deserved A Remastered. The OST Are Great. Well, That's My Review. Be Prepared For The Other 2. RATING: Fabulous Movie (100/100).

Review-Title: Does The Dr. Seuss Story Proud . . . .
Review-Description: I consider some TV shows and movies so "classic" that I refuse to watch any type of remake of them. "How The Grinch Stole Christmas" (1966) is one of them. Or was one of them until this weekend. While Hades will freeze over before I watch the 2000 non-animated version of the story, I saw this animated 2018 version at Peacock and decided why not? I figured I could turn it off if anything in it offended me, or if it was sacrilegious in any way, shape or form. My, my, all that worrying for nothing! This is an absolutely delightful remake of Dr. Seuss' Christmas story. In two ways it's sweeter than the original, too. One, it explains why the Grinch so hates Christmas. Two, the Grinch is not cruel at all to his dog Max. In this movie, Max is his only friend and companion. There is also a chubby reindeer named Fred, the only one in a huge herd that the Grinch could catch to pull his sled. Fred turned out to be more help than the Grinch ever realized he could be. Cindy Lou Who is not a toddler in this film, but looks about six years old. She encounters the Grinch on Christmas Eve not by accident, but intentionally, because she wants to ask Santa Claus something. Many of the residents in Whoville are very funny, especially Bricklebaum, who loves Christmas as much as the Grinch hates it. All the voice jobs are great, including the narrator. So, have no fears of watching this movie if you are a fan of the 1966 show, but don't touch the 2000 non-animated version even with a thirty-nine-and-a-half foot pole!

The movie is good especially for children. Funny and entertaining version that keeps the kids attention. This newer version has lots more Grinch interaction. He's not as mean as the original movie. The actors add a new twist on the main characters. Max is the best character. He is sweet and has genuine emotions that make you enjoy each scene he's in. However the soundtrack sucks. The rap is awful. That man cannot carry a tune to save his life! Off key and just plain bad. How this guy got a record deal baffles me. There are a few decent songs but the main artist lacks even the most basic singing abilities. Sorry not sorry!

I grew up with Boris Karloff as well as Jim Carrey. While I love Jim Carrey, it always seemed too fixated on jokes and jabs rather than the story. So with the new adaptation, I wondered if they'd remedy that. They did not. Where Boris and Jim brought life, character, and instant nostalgia, this movie only brought your run of the mill modern animation style and a few forgettable jokes. An unrelated critique was the sheer amount of new material - why? Why make Suzie-loo's mother single? Why write in a reindeer just so you can miss an iconic line from the original and the 2000's movie? ("If I can't find a reindeer, I'll make one instead.") As far as I can see, they were trying so hard to be different that they lost track of the actual story. I hope one day studios can finally take the hint that we, as movie watchers, are done with remakes. It's tired, vapid, and makes a mockery of good stories. Please, for the sake of future generations, make new material. At this point, my children will be brought up on movies/shows made prior to the 2010's, as much of what's been made since then (with exceptions) has been uninspired.

I'm not one to go crazy over a new version of a movie, especially when it was nailed so well the first time! I love the classic How The Grinch Stole Christmas, but this version is beautifully reimagined. Obviously, as a longer movie, we get more context around the Grinch. And while some find it hard to connect with, I loved this version of the story! More so because I am a mom of a preschooler, and this movie was an exceptional story for sharing the Christmas spirit with children that young. It's definitely the feel-good story of the season! Pharrell is the narrator, bringing a fresh, new take. The movie also combines the classic grinch music and classic Christmas songs with more modern songs. It's entertaining.

The animation was ok. Songs did not make my ears bleed. And the moral of the story is meaningful Though the songs were not catchy, "This wish " was actually pretty catchy to me. I am not lying but telling the truth. Even though Disney has failed, but it's still ok lah. Have to agree with the animation being not so-good though. But i will still forgive them. They threw in a few Dsney refencres though. I hope that Disney can continue to make great films like this in the future. Anyway , that's it for now. Stay happy and bye!(smile's)
Love
Goh Yi
(Ps I need this review to be shortrer) Oh and Hi.

Have to apologise. First review I've done for a movie I havnt actually watched. Probably dosnt help that this is shrouded with the worst Disney reviews and box office takings nearly ever. Based on the Trailer and my kids response,
They pretty much said "that was the most boring trailer they have ever seen!" And had zero interest in watching it. Which says a lot as they are huge Disney fans! And I agree. What were Disney thinking? Disney movies of late are big bright & cute with meaningful cultural mythological back stories. Not sure I like the new visual effects technique that brings old and new together. Just seems like a remastered 50s cart. They've failed in the marketing and delivery. What a shame. Hopefully they learn from this.

A blend of hand-drawn animation and CGI in the art style. An original story not based on a book. Not a needless sequel. A Disney movie that is not a shameless cash-grabbing remake. A straightforward villain rather than the overtired twist cliche. A young protagonist who is flawed, makes mistakes, can lose a fight, and is not an extraordinarily, way over-the-top perfect Mary Sue. Good vs evil story with themes of friendship, love, dedication. Comedy, drama, scary, hopeful. Well-written characters, fantastic songs and music. No political or sociological messages anywhere. Just pure, fresh, glorious entertainment. This movie is everything that fans and detractors of Disney Feature Animation have been asking from the studio for years. What more can they want?

I would have rated a little higher but Magnifico's wrap up felt rushed and undeserved - why didn't his wife even consider he could be saved from the dark magic? It's like she just forgot that they were in love or something. Irritating and perplexing. He seemed like he had good intentions initially, and the storytelling sets this out in some detail, but somewhere along the way he seems to have lost sight of what he was trying to achieve with his new kingdom. He's denying the free will of his people, it seems, not because he's malevolent but simply because he doesn't want the same thing to happen in his new home. Maybe I wasn't paying enough attention at the start and he truly was evil - I guess it was pretty sad that the grandpa had to go through his whole long life without fulfilling his biggest dream. I'll watch again. All the voice actors did a fine job, but Chris Pine was wonderful, had the best musical number and if Magnifico can be redeemed in a sequel perhaps I'll rethink the rating.

Review-Title: Absolutely loved it. Yes, some of the critiques are correct, but it's a beautiful love story to 100 years of Disney
Review-Description: I truly don't understand how this movie is getting so much hate...yes, there was some character development lacking, but it's a children's movie and it's already an hour and a half long. I absolutely loved Wish. I thought it was a beautiful love story to 100 years of Disney. I loved the little nods to Disney films, I loved the music, I loved the characters, I loved the laughs, and I loved the ending. I have seen it three times with my daughter and we can't get enough. I tear up during "This Wish" and at the ending every time. Ariana DeBose is a treasure. You can tell that she's a Broadway actress by the way you feel the emotion through her singing. Chris Pine was probably miscast as the singing voice for Magnifico and should have only done his speaking voice, but he can carry a tune at least. I think the only reason this movie didn't live up to box office expectations was because of Trolls coming out the week before. Anyone that's tearing Wish apart clearly is not a fan of Disney and hasn't seen some of their movies that are ACTUALLY terrible (i/e: Bolt, Chicken Little, Home on the Range).

I saw this film in the cinema with my entire family. And we enjoyed the movie from start to finish. Us as adults. Have also enjoyed the 2D and 3D effects in a film. And they merged seamlessly into each other, giving it its own magical world. Great respect for the animators. The music and songs were also very beautiful like the song. The Wish , this is the thanks I get ! Im a star. Disney has finally responded again to include a real Disney villain. King magnifico.which is wonderfully voiced by Chris Pine, which we did not expect that he could sing so well. Actress Ariana DeBose was also very good, she set the right tone in her speaking and especially in her fantastic singing, what a performance All in all a wonderful film for the whole family.

Review-Title: Entertaining, but forgettable. Just ok. Disney you can do better
Review-Description: So. For a 100 year anniversary movie, yes this movie was lacking. But from just a watchability entertainment value? It was ok. The animation is good. The Comedy and the side kick characters are great. Particularly Alan Tyduks character and his voice acting. Made it bearable. But aside from the animation and the comedic/cute characters this movie doesn't really stick in the memory. To me this movie feels like the definition of "close, but no cigar". Also let's break down the message of this movie. Usually Fairy Tales and even most Disney movies have an easily recognizable and uplifting theme or central message to them. IE Moana = Exploring is a great thing, Wreck it Ralph = Accept yourself and you're great the way you are, Elemental = Diverse people can work together and learn to love even when vastly different. Or themes similar to those concepts. So what was the actual message of this movie? Hard to tell. I think it was "Wishes aka dreams are worth being followed even if you risk getting hurt". Don't know if that's the best message to tell kids man. But here's the really weird thing about this movie- The King or the hero Asha are neither outright wrong or right. They're just particular points of view on what to do with the wishes. What I mean is the King wants to protect wishes. That's not a bad goal right? He's trying to protect people. That's not a bad thing. It's just the way and method he's going about it that are bad. Asha wants everyone to be free to follow their dreams/"wishes". She wants freedom for others. That's not a bad goal either. But what if there really are some wishes that shouldn't be granted because some people really do have fd up dreams that hurt others? Maybe some dreams really do require protection or at least guidance to work with other people. Control without consent or support is Bad. And unrestrained freedom without boundaries or guidance is Bad. Appropriate guidance and organization with freedom of desire is good. It's the synergetic combination that's the goal and the sweet spot. So ideally the King and Asha should have worked together to come up with something new and better that included both of them. So that's what, intellectually at least, makes this Disney movie really unique. The "villain" the King isn't all bad. The "hero" isn't all good. Both of them are actually BOTH 'bad' AND 'good'. I 'WISH' that the King and Asha would have come together to creates something new and better though. That's my wish for this movie. Do a Remake on this Disney. You're good at remakes. Maybe you'll get it right this time.

Review-Title: Another Boring Disney Box Office Flop
Review-Description: I was very excited for this movie. The idea of every bit of Disney magic coming together in1 giant movie sounds amazing doesn't it? Well, It's execution is just bland and boring. I really wanted them to have a story more related to When You Wish upon a star. Instead it felt like Disney doing a parody of their own movies. The characters were boring, and their development just felt very rushed. The songs also do not feel memorable and also ripped off from other Disney movie. The first song in this movie is parallel to 'The Family Madrigal' from Encanto, where the main character introduces us to the main plot, and it feels uninspired. The villain also is pretty forgettable and unoriginal. I was gonna give is a 4, but some of the humor was pretty well done, so that rounds up so a 5 (being very generous).

I saw this movie in Danish with my kids in the cinema as a Christmas present. Since we don't go to the cinema often, it was an overall nice family experience. The movie is a typical Disney movie. There were no surprises in this. I felt entertained and occasionally moved, but it was not a movie, that is gonna stick. It feels like Disney made a compilation of a lot of other Disney movies. I felt especially reminded of Vajana and Jafar and if I would reflect more on it, there will be more characters, that I will recognize. I would not neccessarely recommend this movie, but I would also not say "Don't watch it, it's a waste of time". There are definitly other movies, where time is more well spend, but there are also worse movies out there.

In an era where animated films often redefine the boundaries of storytelling and visual artistry, it's disheartening to see a studio with the pedigree of Disney deliver something as uninspired as Wish. The film, unfortunately, continues the recent trend of Disney's offerings feeling more like formulaic retreads than the innovative masterpieces we once eagerly anticipated. Wish stands as a particularly glaring example of this decline. While it boasts a visually appealing watercolor-inspired aesthetic, this artistic choice alone can't mask the movie's fundamental shortcomings. The narrative lacks the depth and nuance that once made Disney films universally appealing. Instead, we're presented with a collection of recycled elements: a predictable protagonist, a cookie-cutter antagonist, a character designed seemingly for merchandising purposes, and a soundtrack that, while competent, fails to leave a lasting impact. The primary audience for Wish is, of course, children. They might find enjoyment in the film, but it's a fleeting and superficial pleasure, akin to the temporary distraction offered by shows like Peppa Pig or Paw Patrol. There's an absence of the magic and inspiration that could make "Wish" a memorable experience for its young audience. Ultimately, the film is an example of wasted potential, showcasing high-quality animation without the compelling story or characters needed to make it truly resonate.

This is a very solid movie which I watched tonight with my family. My family- other than my little sister- had very low expectations. Adam Sandler and Bill Burr are not our favorites. But yet, this movie is very enjoyable. It's very funny at points, and really heart touching. However if I would complain about something? The music. If you didn't know before you watch it, this is a musical. The joke is that the music isn't good and the singing is bad. However, the movie overuses this joke and it gets a bit annoying. The standout character to me? The drone of the boy with hypochondriac parents.

It was cute,nothing interesting when it comes to the music though. But the plot was nice,I enjoyed the story. Definitely a good family movie. I like that they casted Adam Sandler as the lizard. He's one of my favorite actors. Has a pretty good message about confiding in someone with your feelings. Also how crying is good for your emotional well being. I really enjoyed that part. I really enjoyed the message of the movie as well as helping your friends out when they need help. Again,nothing outstanding for the music really,I don't think I'll remember any of the songs by heart. But other than that I liked it.

Review-Title: Adam Sandler is not a good cast
Review-Description:
I saw this somewhere but the only thing worse than Adam Sandler trying to be funny is Adam Sandler trying to be touching This movie had way to many jarring cuts and in the end the whole conflict is revealed to have weight makes rewatches kinda worthless The humor is gross and some scenes have bad visuals gags that make me what to gag The visual department is fine but the characters have weird proportions that aren't cartoony, just
unsettling This feels like another cash grab by Netflix and it does not Also it shows blatant animal abuse which is wild that fact they think showing two animals that need a lot more space like that is revolting Anyways im gonna go wash my eyes.

I honestly was not expecting much out of an animated Adam Sandler musical, mostly because I was thinking it was going to be a standard movie on Netflix, but I wanted to give it a chance to change my opinion on it; after watching it, I thought it was better than I thought it was going to be. The Netflix animated movie Leo (2023) was a funny and enjoyable animated musical that has good voice acting and good songs that could be funny; there is also some kind of message involving being able to talk to anyone you know about any issues you are having and help you with them. Adam Sandler does do a respectable job as Leo, though you might find his voice a bit weird, you will get used to it as you keep watching the movie; he was funny with jokes about how old he is, the years he had lived through, and usually about kids, teachers, and parents. Leo's friend, who stays in the same terrarium in the classroom, Squirtle, who was voiced well by Bill Burr, does have scenes and is usually just talking to Leo when he is talking about escaping or talking to the kids in the classroom; he does eventually help in the third act. I also liked how Leo is trying to do what he can to help the kids in the classroom, because he knows how old he is and how long he has until a certain age that is coming close. The animation is good, and the movie was funny with it having funny lines of dialogue and funny sight gags in the background or as the central focus; the songs in the movie are not bad with them also being funny, and the singing voices from Adam Sandler and the rest of the cast are good. What was surprising for me was that the movie had quite a few touching/heartfelt moments that are effective; also, what I will add is that the movie does have a liar reveal story in it that could be annoying, and the movie could have had a shorter runtime because the third act felt a bit stretched out. The Netflix animated movie Leo (2023) was better than I thought it was going to be, and though it is not a perfect animated musical, it was still entertaining and funny to watch; Adam Sandler does do a decent job as the main character, which makes the movie watchable. I am not going to say to go and rush onto Netflix to watch this, but I will say this an animated musical I would watch at least once, especially for those who were skeptical about it and did not know what to think about it.

Review-Title: Good Movie, but not sure who the target audience is
Review-Description: Netflix's 'Leo' is a captivating blend of high-quality animation and heartfelt storytelling. The film features a lovable main character, Leo, who resonates with Adam Sandler's best works in terms of emotional depth. Although its pace is leisurely and its themes more mature, the movie strikes a chord with adult audiences, offering a rich, introspective experience. While it's a family-friendly film, its slower rhythm and profound message might not fully engage children under 10. Teenagers and young adults might find the plot somewhat sappy, potentially alienating the 15-25 age group. Nevertheless, 'Leo' shines in its ability to weave a narrative that's both engaging and emotionally rich. The inclusion of Leo's buddy, Squirtle, adds a delightful touch to the story. Overall, 'Leo' is a testament to the power of animation in storytelling, appealing to those who appreciate the genre and offering a lot for families with diverse tastes and ages to enjoy.

Enjoyed the story line: A class lizard goes home each weekend with a different student in the class and helps them with an issue they are having. The characters were fantastic: the students are stereotypical and the teachers and parents are on point. Loved the main animal characters Leo and Squirtle. The musical side wasn't all that great: the songs were slow and boring. They should have just stuck to the storyline and the fun of it. A fun movie to watch as a family. There are a few "adult" humour jokes, but they go right over their heads. Would definitely recommend watching this movie. Check it out.

Leo is a nice movie! I was actually pleasantly surprised by this movie. To be honest, at first I thought this would be a terrible, low-budget, and extremely boring movie directed towards kids But I found myself laughing and even tearing up a little at the ending. The jokes were hilarious. The casting was great. The animation was amazing. As a kids movie, this is great! Your kids will be taught huge life lessons that they most likely will never forget. This is my personal opinion, but I think that this would be better as just a movie and not a musical. I didn't know it was a musical until we started watching Leo. The singing was great, don't get me wrong. Adam Sandler has a great voice, even when he's a lizard, and the students were nice too. I just think it would do better as a non-musical. Other than that, Leo is such a sweet and ridiculously funny musical that kids and adults will enjoy and maybe, just possibly, tear up at.

Ok. I went into this thinking the 'worst movie of the year'. It'll be fun to MST3000K the whole time. It didn't happen, the times I was going to make fun the movie did it for me. I don't have children but I would assume most kids will love. Plus, it's just a damn "feel good" movie. I absolutely loved it. I hate the character limit. I have nothing to else to add. I can tell you about my day! Well, I was at work and Becky started to say that Emily is not the mother of the child she is carrying! ... OMG. It was soooo awkward! I mean what is she doing carrying another woman's baby!? She has NO CLASS! ..... thank you and Goodnite..

It's just so painfully unfunny. I made a whole IMDb account because of how bad it was. Like, yeah, tell your kid to stop crying and shut up because they're being annoying, that's a great idea! A wonderful message to be sending to kids, too. It just made me irrationally angry. Animations can be rather disturbing as well. Didn't make it through the whole movie but most of it. I have no idea why all the other reviews are so overwhelmingly positive. The intent of the messages seemed good, but it definitely backfired. Hard. Watch literally anything else on Netflix. It tries so hard to make a point yet it accomplishes nothing. Most horrible movie I've ever seen.

This was a feel good movie with great messages for all ages! You won't go wrong watching Leo! My 9 year old grandson loved it every bit as much as both his parents and his grandpa & I did! We giggled & laughed & learned a great deal! Kids from 1 - 100 years old will love this! It's always awesome that Adam Sandler includes his family & best friends in his movies! We always enjoy the 80's music from our era too! Skip anything you were considering watching! Stop trying to figure out what might look good & just watch Leo! I don't normally buy movies, but I will definitely be buying this one! It's one movie you can watch over & over & not be bored!

This movie, about a Victorian-era miser taken on a journey of self-redemption, is a great fantasy movie! It's an adventurous cinematic experience filled with elements consisting of everything from horror to joy to tragedy. The animation is slightly outdated where it now looks like cut-scenes from the game Read Dead Redemption 2 (2018), but if you set your mind like it's 2009, it's actually visually stunning. The movie has a great attention to details, and there's a lot to discover during the protagonist Scrooge's journey. I personally find it less enjoyable from when Scrooge gets hunted by the coachman until he sees his own tombstone because the action feels more coincidental than purposeful, but that's only for that part. The rest is very captivating and touching. Anyway, it's noticeable that the actors do their best because their performances perfectly complete the characters, and the cinematography and the fantastic sound design make the movie a great example of an experience fitting for the big screen. The score also helps to create a diverse atmosphere that introduces vibes like Christmas in general, but also suspense and excitement. Overall, the movie contains a beautiful story with a unique experience for the Christmas holiday. This is a visually stunning and emotionally resonant movie that offers a unique cinematic experience. The animation may be slightly outdated, but the performances, cinematography, and sound design are all top-notch. A must-see for anyone seeking a captivating Christmas story.

After Tom Hanks performed multiple roles in "The Polar Express," the egomaniacal Jim Carey no doubt couldn't rest until he surpassed Hanks, at least in the number of roles played in a single movie. But as always he utterly overacted each role, putting the many fine nuances of Dickens's extraordinary classic into the background. Fortunately, he was unable to make this inconsistent travesty of the original story any worse: it was so bad, so full of preposterous variations on the original, that it would have been impossible to bring it lower. As the movie progresses, scenes increasingly diverge from the original until the beautiful messages Dickens embedded in the story are overwhelmed by pretentious and unnecessary histrionics. As I say, the worst if the 30 something versions I've seen.

Now before we get to the negatives let us just say that the animation and execution was fantastic. The style and how each visit was different from one to another was breathtaking at times. But why only 7 stars. In the book there was a very important bit of writing that goes as such. 'They are Man's,' said the Spirit, looking down upon them. 'And they cling to me, appealing from their fathers. This boy is Ignorance. This girl is Want. Beware them both, and all of their degree, but most of all beware this boy, for on his brow I see that written which is Doom, unless the writing be erased. Deny it.' cried the Spirit, stretching out its hand towards the city. 'Slander those who tell it ye. Admit it for your factious purposes, and make it worse. And abide the end.' It might just be one of the most important lessons in the book. Eb was appealed by his father which made him the person he was and by those words of the spirit he understood the "why" behind being generous, charitable and furthering mankind. It is a great lesson for this era.

Some reviewers have called this a "new" twist. Uh, no. It is, almost word for word, scene for scene, a faithful adaptation of the original book by Dickens. The good? Gorgeous scenery, intriguing camera angles and Scrooge's familiar character arc from curmudgeon to repentant soul trying to get things right. The not so good? The first two ghosts (also played by Carrey) are obnoxiously weird. Christmas Past looks like Jim Carey's smirking head floating incongruously above a wispy phantom torso. And Christmas Present is a jarring, cackling boor, with forced belly laughing at the most bizarre times. This is not a movie for young viewers. From the beginning funeral for Marley, complete with coins on the dead man's eyes, it is (as originally written) a macabre tale filled with terrifying images. The ghost of Marley is horrific. Most of the motion capture is mesmerizing, with only a few supporting characters looking flat and poorly animated. The film also cries out for a more inspiring musical score, instead relying on the crazy antics of multiple characters performed by Carrey to move the story along. Despite all this, I recommend it as a true book to movie transition, with some beautiful visuals.

Review-Title: Interesting Interpretation but animation style gets creepy.
Review-Description: Not a bad interpretation of A Christmas Carol and parts of the animation were great but then parts were rather creepy in a bad way and I don't mean the Ghosts/Spirits. Especially the children. You have great realism in parts and then AI type demon children. Strange way to make a movie. As for the dialog, kinda boring and parts of the spirits were either to vague to hear or just annoying. Jim Carrey performed okay but it's rather monotone overall. Same goes with the spirits. The movie was visually appealing but the tone was rather plain and could of been better. It's like you have one emotion and one emotion only throughout the movie. I think they were trying to go with a literal interpretation of A Christmas Carol but could of been better if not for the weird animation style and lack of overall emotion throughout the movie. Even the transformation comes across as unnatural and forced. Not a bad movie but could of been better.

British Reviewer. Although a score of 7.8/10 is quite high for an overly long, ridiculously Hollywood-ified version of Charles Dickens' novella A Christmas Carol. The sheer will and effort of Jim Carrey smashes this one out of the park and makes it a Christmas classic. Zemeckis really dragged out some shots, like the scene with the sign above the shop. The car-chase with a miniature Scrooge went on for AGES, I mean, Ebenezer is clearly terrified already by the prospect of his imminent demise. Does he really need pursuing by a carriage pulled by hell-beasts? Lastly, the grotesqueness of the characters is likely the most accurate portrayal of Victorian poor people but hilariously this is almost certainly a shortcoming of the animation style they chose to use.

The movie is about a grumpy old guy named scrooge who is not a fan of Christmas a bit. One night three ghost come and visit him. First the ghost shows him his own childhood and how it was. Then a different ghost shows the grandpa how others celebrate Christmas. Then the final ghost shows him into the future how he will be alone and spend his life alone. Then a plot twist happens and come Christmas morning the old grandpa is not grumpy anymore and now he is actually in the Christmas mood and goes around cheering and yelling to everyone saying merry Christmas and is acting like a child to everyone.

My husband finally got me to watch this with him tonight after him owning it for several years. This was the utmost boring thing ever. For the first 55 minutes, there were several 5 minute scenes that could have been only 30 seconds each. Also, I could not understand ninety percent of what anyone was saying, and could not figure out who some people were in relation to others due to that. The only good thing about this is that it finally ended. There's really nothing else to say about this but I'm required to type in a certain amount of characters. I can not see myself ever watching this again unless by force.

Review-Title: Old man is terrorized by ghosts
Review-Description: The tale of a greedy old man named Scrooge being taught a lesson on how Christmas is important is a tale almost as old as time. This rendition of the movie is probably my favorite take on this old tale. I love and hate the animation style (it gives me the heeby jeebies) but I am also a huge fan of anything that has to do with Jim Carrey so it may just be a personal bias. I also appreciate that no matter how many times this story is told they always seem to deliver the message on across, on how important Cherishing the ones around us are and how Christmas isn't all just presents and money. Instead it's showing love to our family by not only presents but just being grateful we have them.

This movie was an amazing movie to watch throughout its entire runtime. The animation throughout the movie was spectacular while also giving off very disturbing vibes throughout certain scenes. One particular scene that stood out to me and showed just how well the movie's animation and writing could be both disturbing while also entertaining would be when Scrooge was talking with the ghost of a Christmas present. Throughout the entire interaction I was both enthralled by the movements the camera used to convey motion throughout the town and at the same time horrified by the way the ghost of Christmas past interacted with scrooge during his death. The casting I thought was amazing and it's always good to see Jim Carrey not just play a comedy role but instead play a more serious, down to earth character. The only criticism I think I have to point out is that the movie's story is just like other movies out there. Someone who hates Christmas but later learns his lesson and becomes a joyful man has been used so much and probably done better by other movies that I have to deduct a single point. Other than that this movie is one that I feel like can be enjoyed by everyone in the family and I would totally recommend it for the holiday season.

My kids have been watching the original Lion King near daily after pre school. To mix things up we put this one on instead. It struggles to recapture the magic the original still has. However, that is a high bar to achieve. It looks beautiful, the voice lines are great, and the music is nice. However, it looks too realistic to then apply dialogue to. It simply doesn't work and makes it a challenge to vibe with the movie. The dichotomy of extremely realistic looking animals talking like cartoon characters is too disruptive. This makes me wonder if it was shown to a test audience at all. Or if it was just shown to the crew who worked on it, who would be reluctant to speak against it. The only thing that truly works for this film is the opening song because there's no dialogue. Even the title card for the film name felt jarring not being in red.

Review-Title: Loses the charm of the original
Review-Description: The high points were the the promise of reliving a great film of my childhood/young adult years. Alas, they were promises unfulfilled. Although I did enjoy this film I did not enjoy this anywhere near to the extent of the original. The charm was sapped out as the script writers tried to contrive original and remake and fell short. There were some poor casting choices but the acting should have been strong from at least some of the actors, yet there was no real feeling coming through, no fight, no heart, some hammy delivery. Disappointing. The visuals were great. It was wonderful seeing such life-like rendering in the animation and CGIs but it sits stiffly when the film is about anthropomorphic creatures, which then do not show the supposed feelings they are supposed to be conveying. It's a strange juxtaposition, especially when Walt Disney himself had worked so hard to get audiences to become emotionally connected to an animated story. Overall, a bit of a let down.

I'm not sure what people were expecting from the remake of an old story. Maybe they were expecting Die Hard with lions? It's a pretty faithful remake of the animated Lion King, but does miss something somewhere along the way. Visually it's pretty good, some say the animals lack expression, but you either have realism or make the animals weird with too much expression. Weirdly I thought Beyonce's voice ruined parts of the film as it just didn't seem to fit the character and her over the top shouty singing further ruining some of the music. Overall, it's ok, enjoy it and just go along for the ride.

Review-Title: A Technological Marvel That Captures the Spirit of the Original
Review-Description: "The Lion King" (2019), directed by Jon Favreau, is a visually stunning reimagining of the beloved 1994 Disney classic. Utilizing groundbreaking photorealistic animation, the film brings the African savannah and its inhabitants to life with breathtaking detail and realism, offering a new experience of the iconic story for a modern audience. The voice cast in this rendition brings a fresh perspective to the familiar characters. Donald Glover as Simba and Beyonc√© as Nala bring a vibrant energy to their roles, infusing the characters with emotional depth and a sense of maturity. James Earl Jones reprises his role as Mufasa, lending the same regal and wise presence that he brought to the original film. Chiwetel Ejiofor's portrayal of Scar is noteworthy, delivering a performance that is both menacing and nuanced, differentiating his character from the original while maintaining the essence of the villainous brother. The comedic relief provided by Billy Eichner as Timon and Seth Rogen as Pumbaa is delightful, capturing the spirit of the original characters while adding their unique touch. One of the film's most significant achievements is its groundbreaking animation technology. The animals and environments are rendered with such precision and detail that they blur the line between animation and live-action. This hyper-realistic approach brings a new level of immersion and awe to the film, making it a visual masterpiece. The soundtrack, featuring new renditions of the classic songs and a few new compositions, complements the film beautifully. Hans Zimmer's score is as powerful and moving as ever, and the new interpretations of songs like "Circle of Life" and "Hakuna Matata" are both respectful of the originals and refreshingly modern. However, the film's adherence to photorealism comes at a cost. The emotional expressiveness found in traditional animation is somewhat lost in the pursuit of realism, leading to a disconnect between the characters' emotions and their facial expressions. This sometimes results in a lack of emotional impact in scenes that were more emotionally resonant in the animated version. The narrative stays largely faithful to the original, which is both a strength and a weakness. While it ensures the story remains true to what fans love, it also means the film offers few surprises or deviations, which could be a disappointment for those seeking a new take on the story. In conclusion, the 2019 version of "The Lion King" is a remarkable feat of technology and a beautiful tribute to the original film. It captures the essence of the story and its characters while providing a new level of visual splendor. While it may not evoke the same emotional depth as the 1994 animation, it stands on its own as a visually captivating and enjoyable retelling of a classic tale. It earns a solid 8 out of 10 for its technological achievements and its ability to bring a beloved story to life in a whole new way.

Truly a beautiful piece of animation (photorealistic animation) but something lacks what the hand drawn 1994 rendition had... there was more heart in the original that I think can be impossible to find with this new style of animation, it's almost like you can't take it all in because of how much detail had gone into creating everything in screen. It's true talent, and perhaps eventually once they've done more of the work, they'll be able to find the heart like they used to have. I would've liked to have seen Jeremy Irons reprised his role as Scar, and the new characterisation of the hyenas are drastically different in this adaptation; here they are more dangerous than comedic relief.

Review-Title: Why does this movie even exist?
Review-Description: Watch the original instead. It's a shot for shot remake of the animated version. The story is exactly the same but it lacks the charm and spirit of the original. This movie also had a lot of weird casting choices like John Oliver as Zazu, Seth Rogen as Pumbaa, and Beyonce as Nala. At least they brought back James Earl Jones to play Mufasa, but its not enough to save the movie from being a complete disaster. I also can't even tell if this is supposed to be an animated movie or a live action one because the animals are CGI but the landscapes are real. The CGI is very good though, but the characters are far less appealing and recognizable than their animated counterparts. Another problem is, you can't even tell what emotion the characters are feeling just by looking at them considering they're modeled after real animals. Also, why the hell did the writers think Timon and Pumbaa singing "Be Our Guest" in this movie was a good idea? Its really annoying. This is the worst of the Disney remakes in my opinion. Everything about the original Lion King was better. It might as well be called "The Photorealistic Lion King", because that's basically what it is.

Review-Title: Uneven tempo, unnecessary addons and not grand enough
Review-Description: I am of the belief that remakes are reserved for movies that in the broad spectrum considered bad. So I was reluctant to watch this movie when it came out even though I, as a kid, hoped to see a live-action version of my favorite animated movie, which is also why this review is 4 years late. I was wondering why this movie is almost 30 minuttes longer than the original, and I thought they might expand some before only implied tropes, such as the rules of the land, other characters relationships with the lions, but unfortunately not. Many characters that had charisma are totally gone. The hyenas are not comic relief as they were and their dynamic between them is also missing. The voice acting is also bland compared to the original, only Billy Eichner and Seth Rogen are great as Timon and Pumba, and John Oliver also has his moments, though it was hard not to miss Rowan Atkinson. The spectacel of the scenery is stunning, but I still feel it pales compared to the original, such in scenes as the stampede, which seem much smaller and less impactful as well as the opening scene. The music, which to me at least, was by far the originals strong point, is sidelined with mere notes that reminds you of the original. The songs are cut short, such as Scars "Be prepared" and "Can't wait to be king", and instead we are treated with an original song by Beyonc√©, which is good, but not compared to Elton John's songs. The movie also have a very odd tempo. Sometimes we seem to dwell to much on things that could easily just be left to the imagination, and other times we don't dwell enough on what the original was so good at. Now we dwell more on Scars relationship with Sarabi whom he wants as queen, for some reason, and Shenzi, who were just another one of the hyenas, is the leader, though she has no goal or doesn't make any impact on any of the lead characters, and Banzai and Azizi(Ed's replacement), do try but their banter doesn't fit into how we think of hyenas. The original played a lot on the trope that hyenas laugh, so the movie characters constantly make fun of eachother, situations etc. It's unfortunate, since the original was great at balancing horrible sadness with funny moments. Many of the voice actors also seem oddly cast. Disney marketed the movie by stating they would try to hire only african-americans for the leads. I know they mean well, but being from a country where English is not the mothertongue means that the will be dubbed regardless plus you can't always hear from a voice where people's ethnicity originates. The only thing that always was the same regardless where you come from was the music, which in the original, I felt celebrates Africa. The African a choir which sang in both Zulu and Swahilli as well as the African tunes were something I believe really stays with a lot of people when they remember the original. So all in all, the best thing about this movie is the things that it copied from the original and didn't try to improve all to much on. For parents I will always recommend the original, not just because of quality, but also due to the tempo and the length of the remake.

The CGI and digital effects in this movie are out of this world. Makes it all look so real, it's the thing I found most impressive about the film. As a kid who grew up watching Lion King time and time again, when it came to the Mufasa-Scar battle over the canyon, a part of me hoped the storyline would change as that scene is always heartbreaking. However, if they did change that turning point scene, the entire rest of the story would be completely different. The new jokes from Timon and Pumba fit it quite well and held true to the original characters. This film is visually a nice change of pace from the original but otherwise they are virtually the same, just with a new cast and new renditions of the songs.

A good film to watch with family members. The story line is the same as in previous versions of this film. The characters are funny and well animated, however more face expressions should be shown. The acting is good, but not better than previous versions of this film. Direction of the plot has a good pace, but the end is too fast, in my opinion. It is similar to other Hollywood films. Film's cinematogrophy is good. Best angles are shown, and the colour palette is wide and general's movie aesthetics has a good quality either. Film's soundtrack is good, but not extraordinary and does not add anything new to previous versions. Film's editing gives absorb's viewers curiosity. In general, it is a good film to watch with family members.

It's one of the Disney movies that I really liked. I didn't expect to enjoy it as much as I did. The action is well-paced and the storyline is captivating. I never got bored watching it. The movie doesn't contain too many unnecessary scenes which makes it pleasant to watch. Not to mention, the visuals are outstanding, and the animals appear remarkably realistic. You could easily mistake them for real characters. I was impressed by Simba and Nala's background stories and courage. Their character development was inspiring, and I appreciated the moments of humor that were woven into their portrayal. It's a heartwarming movie which you can enjoy watching with your entire family.

I can't believe it has taken me ages and ages to finally post an imdb review for Chicken Run. Actually, what prompted me was a New York Times article I read today about why it's taken so long to release Chicken Run 2, the sequel naturally to Chicken Run. Anyway, I saw Chicken Run on DVD when DVDs were popular and cost a lot of money. Anyway, Chicken Run is lots of fun and the creators didn't have the luxury of CGI and all to relax on. Anyway, I highly recommend Chicken Run and it's hard to believe the sequel has taken so long to be released but no doubt it will be worth the wait and all init.

Review-Title: Chicken Run (2000) and its anti-capitalist subtext
Review-Description: Chicken Run is an animated film widely remembered for addressing anti-capitalist themes in its subtexts. To say that these subtexts are not included in the narrative is to watch it superficially. The anti-capitalist message is very visible, even in a children's film. These messages can be very controversial because they are in a film aimed at younger audiences. However, it is not something that will somehow influence children to follow some ideology. Those in power will remain in it and increasingly try to increase their wealth to become more powerful over those who are exploited. The characters do not believe they can live a different life, because they are limited to thinking in a different way as a result of the system in which they are inserted. In addition to these subtexts, the animation is good for managing to develop a very fun narrative with very effective comedy.

In the mid-2000s, films emerged that revolutionized the animation industry and Chicken Run has been one of them that is fondly remembered. After the Wallace & Gromit animated shorts, Aardman made its big film debut with this well-developed stop-motion film. On an artistic and artisanal level, it is a film well cared for in its production and character design. Ginger and Rocky are the best characters in the film, being very different, but who later end up forming a strong bond. Rocky is initially presented as a self-centered rooster who ends up empathizing with Ginger. Meanwhile, Ginger is a determined chicken with a strong character who shows how much she cares about her companions and how much she cares about them. The script knows how to keep the humor and seriousness that exists in the story balanced. It is a film with well-hidden social elements and critiques that make the story interesting to watch. Even the good development of the script and the emotionality make some errors present in the film easy to ignore. Chicken Run is definitely another masterpiece of ancient animation and a gem that can continue to be enjoyed to this day. My final rating for this movie is a 9/10.

Today, I re-watched this movie as it's sequel is out and I wanted to recollect the story of the original which I watched a long time ago. The story was simple and light hearted just like a children's story, the screenplay was decent, the direction was good, the animation was unique and the voice actors did a good job. The thrill elements were embedded nicely in the story which makes this movie more enjoyable. Overall, this movie was an enjoyable movie which you can watch with your family. I don't know if this story even needed a sequel as the story had a good conclusion but let's see what sequel has to offer.

"Chicken Run" is an animated delight that will have audiences of all ages clucking with laughter and excitement. Set on a seemingly idyllic farm run by the tyrannical Mrs. Tweedy, the film follows a group of plucky chickens who dream of escaping their egg-laying fate. When the spirited and determined Ginger hatches a plan to break free, the stage is set for a high-flying adventure filled with humor, heart, and daring escapades. The plot unfolds with a mix of clever wit and touching moments as the chickens, led by the intrepid Ginger and the charismatic rooster Rocky, concoct a daring scheme to achieve their freedom. The film expertly weaves together themes of friendship, courage, and the pursuit of dreams, creating a captivating story that resonates on multiple levels. The animation is charming and skillfully rendered, bringing the expressive characters and lively farm setting to vibrant life. The voice talent, including the talents of Julia Sawalha, Mel Gibson, and Miranda Richardson, infuses the characters with personality and charm, making them instantly endearing to the audience. "Chicken Run" is a feather-ruffling adventure that effortlessly balances lighthearted humor with genuine emotional depth. With its engaging storyline, well-crafted animation, and memorable characters, this film is a plucky and heartwarming gem that will leave audiences cheering for these courageous chickens. Whether you're a child or a child at heart, "Chicken Run" is a must-see animated classic that will have you rooting for the underdogs from start to finish.

This film stands out for its visual innovation, employing the stop-motion animation technique to create a more captivating aesthetic than conventional 3D animations. The narrative unfolds a captivating and creative story that seamlessly blends elements of comedy, adventure, and drama. The diverse characterization of characters, with each chicken possessing a distinct personality, fosters empathy with the audience. The film adopts a simple yet humorous style that appeals to both younger and older viewers. However, there are a few points in the narrative where the story could have delved deeper, providing a more profound and impactful experience. There's a sense that the filmmakers could have pushed further to convey a more potent message.

I do love stop motion animation, and other than the stop motion animation studio Laika having great movies, the stop motion studio Aardman is fantastic with one of the movies they made back in the year 2000 called Chicken Run. Chicken Run (2000) has a great cast, great animation, and a villain who can be scary or threatening; there are some dark themes in the movie and the way everything looks is amazing how it is animated with lots of details and funny movements. The main chicken named Ginger voiced by Julia Sawalha takes every attempt to try to escape the chicken farm, and she has the dedication to get the rest of the chickens out of the farm to safety away from the terrible owners. The rooster Rocky voiced by Mel Gibson is launched into the chicken farm with the chickens believing he can fly so he can help them escape, with funny moments and a building relationship with Ginger. Also, the other chickens on the farm are weird and funny, with there being other characters who are rats who are getting items for the many plans the chickens use to escape the chicken farm, which is built like a prison. The villains are the owners of the chicken farm with one of them being scary and intimidating, and the other being an idiot seeing the chickens planning something but the intimidating one does not believe him; with their plan of turning the chickens into chicken pies. The stop motion animation is well done with the locations having a lot of details to it, and the characters having many expressions, details, and funny ways they tend to move around, other than using clay for certain things, they also use real objects in a way that is fun to watch when they use them in their plans to escape the farm. Chicken Run (2000) is a great Aardman stop motion movie that, if you like Aardman, you should give it a watch if you have not already, it is also a good movie to rewatch; it has great stop motion animation, nice characters, funny moments, and an effective villain. This movie is just a fun and entertaining time when watching; if you specifically like animation, you will enjoy this movie, and if you like stop motion films or specifically Aardman, then you will have fun with this film.

Review-Title: An animation in the depth of my childhood memories
Review-Description: This animation is wonderful for me and full of childhood memories, most of my childhood was spent seeing and imagining these cute chicks. I am very satisfied with this animation. I remember that after watching this movie, I was thinking of making a flying car so that I could fly to the sky with it and travel to faraway places, even the plan of my so-called flying car on paper I waited, but alas, before I blinked, my childhood was over and how soon I grew up. Now my memories have come alive again and I am impatiently waiting for the second part of this movie to take me back to my childhood once again and travel in the pure world of imagination.

A movie I thought would go in one direction but ended up a bit aimless. Chicken Run is one of those claymation movies that you have to watch and while I enjoyed it, I wished it was way tighter and more affective than it ended up being. A plate was placed in front of me and I expected one thing, but the taste was not only different but also a bit too bland. A chicken farm is run by an evil woman which only focus is on profit. The chickens try to escape and are blessed with hope in the form of a flying rooster. What this movie does best is its comedy and the characters. All the characters are memorable and lovable, and the villains are fun and interesting. My favorite character and voice performance was Julia Sawalha as the lead Ginger. She brings so much sas and personality to the character, and having a strong and respectable female lead is awesome. She's such a lovable character not just focusing on her own escape but on everyone escaping together that's amazing. Other characters that I loved were the husband to the villain that was lovably dumb, the two rats and Babs the chicken being so oblivious as to what's going on at all time. The comedy is focused on the dialogue, and it works very well here. The visual gags are fine too. The character and actually the entire main focus that made the movie feel worse to me was the male lead Rocky. It's fun how we in this era of filmmaking always had to add a man just so there was one. The entire premise goes from prison escape to having fun and lying, and that's a really annoying premise when the original idea was fun too. Having to escape with everyone before we are all killed, yeah this is a kids' movie by the way. This movie could have been tighter and more focused, instead of being about a romance that doesn't matter and using so much time on a plot tread that goes nowhere. I wish this movie was something different, more like its opening promise and premise. I really loved the molded sets and backgrounds, expert the sky that looked a bit too fake. The opening on the mud on the ground and the metal fence looks so real and well done. The overall mouth and fluidity of the animation is amazing and never really seems like it stutters anywhere. The character designs are also really quirky, but don't really speak to me. The Claymation style is something that doesn't really look appealing to me, and it can look a bit ugly in my opinion. It clashes with the amazing prop department to me and makes the chickens look a worse. This movie should have been shorter than it is and with a more simple premise, it can feel long and patted also because we, the audience, know the premise is build on a lie. It is a simple premise with extra steps, and that did not speak to me at all. It also doesn't add to the outcome of the movie at all having the runaround with the male lead, and that just frustrates me. But Chicken Run is still a fun and enjoyable time. It has a lot of character and charm with amazing humor and animation, but to me needed a more compelling plot to really hit home with me.

Before the sequel which will have Thandie Newton and Zachary Levi replacing Mel Gibson and Julia Sawalha as Ginger and Rocky respectively, I decided to review the 2000 original Chicken Run which also stars Tony Haygarth,Miranda Richardson,Imelda Staunton and Timothy Spall(both Spall,Staunton and Richardson all worked in Harry Potter). The plot follows Ginger(Sawalha)who is facing eventual certain death at the chicken farm where she is held. Together Ginger and Rocky(Gibson in his 2nd animated film after Pocahontas)the rooster, decide to rebel against the evil Mr. And Mrs. Tweedy(Haygarth and Richardson) the farm's owners. Rocky and Ginger lead their fellow chickens in a great escape from the murderous farmers. Will they succeed? Overall it was a good flick. The animation is good,the story is good and the voice acting was good too.

Review-Title: Perfect for performing arts heart girlies. and boys
Review-Description: 100/10! This is definitely a movie I've been needing to start the year! I was looking for a happy movie and scrolled up to this one. I was planning on just watching the first few minutes, but then got hooked up and continued watching. Wow, this is really perfect for theater or performing arts enthusiasts out there.
