It showcases what actually happens when preparing for a show and the process. I am speechless. I think I want a performing artist guy now after I've watched the monkey guy perform. He's totally my crush now; I love his voice. I kept crying while watching the show because of how amazing their talent is and how I would love watching it live in real life. I love this movie. To more watching theater shows in 2024! Btw, Ms. Crawly is the best when keeping in charge!

An excellent sequel that only builds on the fantastic and fun dynamics that children love that were founded in the first film. The songs continue to be the perfect blend between the old and the modern, therefore meaning that they're is something for everyone in this film. The colours in this instalment of the Sing franchise (which this is very quickly becoming) is even more vibrant than the last one, with the scale that they character put their final show in if much grander and there is actual threat in this picture that comes in the form of a domineering media mogul; he tries to throw Buster off the building.

Review-Title: Not going to lie - I DID NOT expect that one
Review-Description: "Sing 2" continues the endearing journey of Buster Moon and his troupe of talented performers as they strive to make it big in the world of showbiz. Illumination Entertainment's sequel brings forth a vibrant and captivating spectacle that appeals to both young audiences and the young at heart. The animation in "Sing 2" is a visual marvel, exhibiting intricate details that elevate the characters' expressions and movements, immersing the audience in a vibrant world. The attention to detail is evident, creating a captivating experience for viewers. The heart of the film lies in its characters and their unwavering determination to achieve their dreams. The story is a delightful exploration of perseverance, resilience, and the importance of embracing one's individuality. It resonates deeply, delivering valuable messages without losing its entertaining charm. The soundtrack is an absolute highlight, featuring an array of catchy tunes and breathtaking musical performances that infuse the film with energy and emotion. Each song complements the narrative, adding depth and enhancing the overall storytelling experience. Moreover, the introduction of new characters adds layers to the storyline, bringing fresh dynamics and diverse personalities into the mix. These additions inject renewed enthusiasm into the narrative, contributing to the film's overall appeal. In essence, "Sing 2" is a well-crafted sequel that successfully builds upon the foundation of its predecessor. It seamlessly combines stunning animation, an engaging storyline, and a stellar soundtrack to deliver a wholesome and entertaining cinematic experience that resonates with audiences of all ages.

Review-Title: A masterful sequel that is at the level of its predecessor
Review-Description: The glorious sequel to Sing takes our beloved characters to another level, leaving the theater and venturing into show business on the big stage. The story is almost like the first film, but it is at a higher level seeing how the characters must adapt to a new environment. The soundtrack doesn't have as many familiar songs as the first film, but it's still one of the best things about Sing. Music continues to have great relevance in this universe, being an important element for the stage. The characters must face more difficult challenges such as Buster trying to please mobster Jimmy Crystal or disappoint Rosita, Ash trying to convince Clay Calloway to return to the stage, Johnny trying to be an acrobat dancer and Meena meeting love. Although it was a shame that Mike the mouse didn't return, it didn't affect the magnificence of this movie. This film reflects both the characters and the essence of its predecessor, being a worthy sequel with wonderful animation and amazing sequences. Sing 2 is an excellent sequel and a work of art both visually and aurally. My final rating for this movie is a 10/10.

The original crew from the first movie pack up and try to impress in the big city, which is their version of Las Vegas. It's a bit more cut throat then they're use to and Buster Moon may have bitten off more than he can chew. The sequel is just as charming, and the music is just as good. Hard to say which one I enjoyed more, because both are very well done and on par with each other. Of course having the talents of Bono, Halsey, and Pharrell doesn't hurt one bit. As an adult it's still very entertaining to watch. I mean, who doesn't love a well done talking animal movie with amazing animation and great music? I suspect only a few.

Review-Title: Great but we just watched the original idea from 90s
Review-Description: This is great and wonderful but there's a huge caveat: it's a total plot rip from the 1997 WB animation Cats Don't Dance with Scott Bakula. What's crazy is a movie as good as the aforementioned movie is not as well known as you'd think but maybe it is it's just we had not ever seen it before until 26 years later, that's bonkers if you ask me. We're not saying anything negative about either movie I just wish we had seen the WB movie before this Illumination animation. Whatever hope you all get a chance to watch and compare the two movies and enjoy both as much as we have. There are a lot of remakes so it's not a new thing.

I enjoyed the original sing. It was something new having animals audition for a singing competition and new talent. Now buster is back along with his crew as they host a show that sees a TV talent scout call them not good enough. This is the final straw for him so he takes his friends on a roadtrip to a las Vegas looking city to prove that they are good enough to a harsh Simon cowle type and his posh daughter porsha. Porsha was a good character so was the cute cat. I liked the edition of the new characters and watching busters lie get bigger makes you wonder what will happen. Overall I really enjoyed this and thought it was a worthy sequel.

It's really hard for me to get into an animated movie most of the time I fall asleep, get bored, and just quit watching but not this one let's face it soundtrack sold it, and the actors who are voicing were so good you didn't necessarily recognize them in their human forms, and the characters just came to life the story, the plot although cliched and predictable was good, and Kept the story moving, if not full of surprises there was still enough interest in the characters to watch the outcome unfold. So this was enjoyable all the way around and had a good message about following your dreams, and being willing to keep trying even when things don't appear to be working out.

Couldn't they have gotten Larry the Cable Guy instead? I'm disappointed,
so much processing power...
so many colorful characters,
it all comes down to CV padding for the rich and famous. Why dear Jeabus why
do people who have filled screens with film after film of their presence,
need to get into voice-over acting (or voice over-acting)? 1. Buster Moon is a Koala
Koalas are Australian
even if he grew up in San Fran,
why does he sound liquored on every line? Rich Hall jokes about how Tom Cruise films pretty much ran the same script & just changed the scenery
Well, the award for modern day substitute goes to...

Review-Title: Great fun film but one rockstar drawback
Review-Description: I was really surprised by the first film. Especially as a lifelong music snob (in recovery). It really helped me just enjoy pop music again. Sing 2 is impossibly, better. Just better songs, more heart, and some brilliant jokes that go over the heads of kids so keep the adults happy too. The night cleaners alone are worth the price of viewing. Johnny again is brilliant and Miss Crawley almost steals the show. Porsha has a brilliant little scene that is a tribute to Lina Lamont in Singin in the Rain. Or at least I assume it is. I like the premise of Clay Calloway, but oh man I had to knock one star off for Bonos voicing. Bloody awful. But that's the price you pay I guess for being allowed to use some of U2's songs. Even though the U2-by-numbers Your Song Saved My Life is abysmal, it also manages to fit and work. Great viewing, the moan about Bono is a minor whinge to be honest, and Miss Crawley singing along to System of a Down, is priceless.

Review-Title: A Halloween-loving dude knows about Christmas for the first time, but it's a Tim Burton movie
Review-Description: The Nightmare Before Christmas uses stop-motion as a tool to tell a fantastic story that could only be conceived in Tim Burton's mind. The premise is simple, a Halloween-loving man (?) discovers Christmas for the first time and falls in love with it, to the point he convinces everyone in town - who don't know what Christmas is either - to celebrate it together. However, as someone who only knows Halloween, his idea of Christmas doesn't align with what Christmas really is. The story is told through a set of musical numbers that usually describe the emotional state of Jack Skellington, but also cover other characters like Sally and the rest of the town. The film basically tells us what would happen if Halloween and Christmas collided. It's a fascinating tale that could only be conceived by Tim Burton.

Jack Skellington is fed up with his lot, all the ghoulishness, the gothic rot and grot, so he's left with a big frown, and found the door to Christmas Town, now he's scheming and conniving a new plot. To begin, he's taken Santa from his sleigh, this is now to be a somewhat darker day, where the gifts won't bring a smile, it's a chocolate log defile, gifts of corpses, frogs and spiders left for play. Ooogie Boogie takes the chance to muscle in, a sack that's full of bugs and evil grin, will this nightmare ever end, can the tormenting be stemmed, or will Jack reverse decay and save the day. ... or is the nightmare here stay!

Review-Title: Except for it's technical merits. This is hardly a kids movie.
Review-Description:
1993 what in the hell were they thinking. Clearly not a Christmas movie. Therefore it's a horrifical horror movie. Keep the under 10 kids far away... Beetlejuce is hilarious. This movie downright depressing. I need some Frozen to cheer me up. If you are suffering from depression do not watch this movie. Glad it took me 30 years (Disney Insider so $35 bd was free) to watch it , Glad I got it free. Totally pointless film. Glad the girl got her man but hey Santa you could made her seamless. Doubt I'll play this nightmare again. I suggest you watch this in October because it's a horror movie and keep the kids away as this is more like Sleepy Hollow and I rather like the latter. Quality: 6/10 (technical merits only)
Entertainment: 1/10
Re-Playable: 1/10.

Even though Tim Burton did not direct this film, it is impossible not to think that The Nightmare Before Christmas is his best work. This is a film with a very original idea that has all the elements that characterize Tim Burton's vision. It is a fantastic story with terrifying and charming elements at the same time. The clash between two festive dates that are very different because of how terrifying one is and how joyful the other is. The characters are quite a peculiarity and the one who steals the entire film is definitely Jack. The inhabitants of Halloween Town have all the elements of a Halloween party and Jack is a clear variant of the legendary Jack O' Lantern. Here Jack feels tired of doing the same thing every year and decides to make a change in his routine, trying to spread Christmas cheer to find a new purpose, but without taking into account the imbalance that he can cause. Another character that is also worthy of praise is Sally who is definitely the voice of reason and the love she feels for Jack makes her care about him. The characters are as quirky and unusual in personality and design as they always should be in a Tim Burton story. The stop-motion animation helps a lot with the strangeness that the characters have and that is why it is still something very admirable to see in this film. The production design and art are faithful to Tim Burton's vision in many ways. This is due to his strong participation in the production. The soundtrack composed by Danny Elfman is also another admirable element of the film. The songs are unforgettable and have become somewhat iconic for the Halloween and Christmas seasons. It is ironic that Henry Selick has been overshadowed, since he has been in charge of directing and has done a good job, not forgetting to mention that this was his first feature film. His participation was also important and this experience was what led him to make Coraline years later. It is really curious that this has been a case in which a director has been able to create his greatest masterpiece without the need to direct and only taking care of the rest of the production. All the technical details have Tim Burton's vision and essence, as does the story he created. The Nightmare Before Christmas is definitely the best film in Tim Burton's filmography, one of the best animated films in history and a wonderful classic to enjoy at Halloween and Christmas. My final rating for this movie is a 10/10.

Tim Burton wrote and co-produced this short, musical, stop-animation feature, (it was directed by Henry Slick, but has Burton's fingerprins all over it)) as an antidote to other cuddly seasonal features which are available, cleverly conflating probably his own favourite holiday season Halloween with everybody else's, Christmas. The story's quite simple and straightforward, Halloween Jack (wasn't that a line in a Bowie song?) Skellington (love that spelling!) organises Halloween for his fellow town residents but has lately become bored in the process. To rejuvenate himself, he decides to borrow a few tricks from neighbouring Christmas Town where he thinks a little mix-and-match of the two holidays might succeed. It does seem a bit like painting a moustache on the Mona Lisa and his adoring girlfriend Sally Finkelstein, who is forever trying to escape the attentions of her creator, Dr Finkelstein, tries to tell him so, but headstrong Jack carries on regardless, his master stroke, or so he thinks, being to kidnap Sandy Claws (his spelling), take his place and dispense much less wholesome toys to all the nice boys and girls. Actually in this day and age, I'm not sure old Jack wasn't onto something considering some of the videogames kids play today. Anyway, at least in 1993, he gets it wrong, spoiling every youngster's Christmas morning and at the same time jeopardising Santa himself who he's left in the care of the bad old Boogie Man. Who knows though, maybe Sally can literally pull herself together and help Jack to save the day... For me, the most disappointing feature of the movie was the rather lukewarm soundtrack provided by Danny Elfman. None of the songs stay in the memory although I will concede they do help the story along. I liked two sequences in particular, Jack's disastrous delivery of the kiddies' gifts and the showdown with the Boogie Man. The animation is excellent throughout, recalling for me anyway "The Wizard of Oz", "Yellow Submarine" and even "H. R. Pufnstuf". Perhaps I'd have liked a few more good jokes in the dialogue and a little bit darker treatment in the narrative, but on the whole, I'll take Burton's, let's call it a grey Christmas, over "The Snowman" any old Christmas Day.

Review-Title: Just don't get the Christmas Feeling!
Review-Description: Not for me or my wife and 12 year old daughter. My Daughter's thoughts were that she expected so much more as it had been recommended and lauded by so many but was left disappointed as the premise was interesting but was ruined by an over abundance of singing. My own thoughts were that the whole Halloweeners trying to understand xmas became pretty repetitive and I lost my interest quite easily as it felt like the same stuff repeated for 73 minutes. It wasnt that Seems we might be being a little petty. But it just didn't feel like a Christmas movie and certainly didn't evoke the same nostalgic feelings that numerous other xmas movies do. Maybe We are just traditionalists . Won't be added to our Christmas Watchlist.

This film has a cult following and people really seem to like it but I have never been a huge fan of it. It just does not do it for me. I wish I cld explain why but I can't. Its an ok story, but not the best. Tim Burton is a very talented director, so I do not know why I do not care for the film but I just have never loved it. It's just ok. Nothing more to say about it. It is always included with holiday films but it's just an ok film. It is not great it's just a ok topic. I would recommend if you are a Tim Burton fan and have never seen this film otherwise skip it so many better holiday movies out there.

Review-Title: Gothic stop-motion masterpiece: an essential holiday film
Review-Description: An animated Disney production from 1993 directed by Henry Selick (Coraline, Wendell & Wild), The Nightmare Before Christmas follows "Pumpkin King" Jack Skellington's doomed adventures from Halloween Town to Christmas Town and back again. Based on a story and characters by Tim Burton, the film is a stop-motion animated musical featuring the singing voice of Danny Elfman, who also wrote the score. While it wasn't a huge hit initially, it soon achieved cult classic status and is seen, to this day, as one of the best animated features of all time. Two holidays are cleverly intertwined here as Jack Skellington (voiced by Chris Sarandon), a Halloween hero, grows tired of entertaining his usual ghoulish crowd, delivering the same spooky thrills year after year. When he discovers a place called Christmas Town, he becomes enamored with the entire concept and so decides to... take it for himself. A loving yet twisted pastiche of classic Rankin/Bass specials, as well as Dr Seuss' How The Grinch Stole Christmas and other classic cartoons, The Nightmare Before Christmas lures you in quick with its delightfully macabre "This Is Halloween" tune and it never lets go as Danny Elfman offers catchy song after catchy song, making the most of each one in his own unique style. This may have been Tim Burton's idea, and it may be Henry Selick's masterpiece, but it is, first and foremost, Elfman's baby: his work here is nothing short of genius and deserved a lot more recognition back in the day. From the lonely "Jack's Lament" to the bombastic "What's This?", the beautiful "Sally's Song", the playful "Making Christmas" and the devilish "Oogie Boogie's Song", the movie never missteps and is singalong-worthy from start to finish. The animation here is, frankly, incredible. This is stop-motion at its best with every shot carefully composed, Tim Burton's art style perfectly captured and the emotions of all these bizarre characters conveyed with great care. The character design is unique, the settings are appropriately gothic and countless inventive techniques are used here to make the animation flow in harmony with the music. The film looks gorgeous, of course, but it also has a timeless, nostalgic feel that'll make you want to watch it for both aforementioned holidays every single year. We care about these characters, feel for them, and can't wait to see them naively attempt the impossible in true Halloween Town style! Few animated films manage to get everything right: The Nightmare Before Christmas is one of those rarities. Hugely entertaining, a visual treat, a truly fantastic musical and, despite its frightening look, very very funny, not to mention filled with the magic that many Christmas movies promise but so often fail to materialize. It's one hell of a sleigh ride and viewers of all ages should get a big kick out of it. Essential holiday romp.

Review-Title: Easily one of the best Halloween movies
Review-Description: The Nightmare Before Christmas is THE movie that combines two holidays. Halloween and Christmas are the best holidays of the year (in my opinion at least). This movie combines those two holidays in one. It is way more Halloween than Christmas, with the main characters literally being from a place called Halloween Town. The story revolves around the Pumpkin King Jack getting tired of doing Halloween year after year, which leads him to Christmas. I feel Jack is pretty relatable. There have been a time where I was tired of focusing on one thing all the time. I have recovered from that but still. I feel like the villain should be in the movie a little more. Besides that, I don't really have any complaints.

It's irrefutable that this film is already cult and has been a great influence on many people. Tim Burton's imagery is now recognizable worldwide and it all begins here, with the film directed by Henry Selick. The most notable thing, consequently, is the production design. The characters, the sets, the decoration... absolutely everything has Burton's trademark, which, helped with the practical effects of stop motion, gives us a beautiful visual spectacle. It's without a doubt the most notable. Now, moving on to other technicalities, the script is somewhat bland, cumbersome and boring. The edition tends to be repetitive and slow, for an animated musical. Everything has a clear justification, obviously, but even so, they are, in my opinion, negative points. As a side point, between us... was it necessary for it to be a musical? Anyway... In short, the film can be entertaining for those who like Burton's dark and depressive style, for lovers of stop motion and for those looking for something different, because without a doubt, they will find it here.

How this sweet little movie failed is beyond me the animation is clever the story is good the characters are well realised it should have been a massive hit but it was killed by sourpuss critics on the Internet before it even started. Essentially it's a modern take on the Romeo and Juliette trope a boy and girl from drastically different backgrounds fall in love to the chagrin of their parents, in this case it's a fire girl and a water boy. Set in Element city a place where diverse cultures live together in a melting pot society it demonstrates how we can all rub along together even though we have our differences. Nice sweet movie great for children, Pixar at their best.

Elemental is one of my favorite animated films. To be honest, when I first heard about a girl of fire and a water boy falling in love in an elemental city, I thought this would be cringe, predictable, weird, and so not funny. But then I decided to give it a try and wow, I was wrong! It's such a cute 'opposites attract' love story. The dialogue is so funny and the animation is just so beautiful. I love the characters and just watching them fall in love made me so happy. I liked the ending and being able to watch their journey was very satisfying. There are a lot of themes shown, such as racism, immigration, and parental expectations. In the end, Elemental makes a great movie night and I enjoyed it a lot. This will surprise you in a pleasant way and bring a smile to your face.

HOT TAKE: Elemental is amazing. Yes, pun intended but I'm so serious here, folks; this was very done and I urge you to give it a fair shot. Elemental is a modern yet fantastical odyssey of romance and self-realization clashing with the weight of ethnic and generational expectations. A colorful and cultural onslaught of imagination, relatability and sentiment, tailored by two endearing leads with irresistible chemistry. I'm usually not one for romcoms but if the leads are engaging enough, then I'm sold. Ember and Wade - voiced by fresh talent Leah Lewis and Mamoudou Athie, respectively - share a captivating journey together, one that isn't just focused on love but puts their humanity in a binding spotlight. Their relationship flows oh-so naturally and is 10x more enchanting than any prince and princess story. You know that scene from WALL-E where the robots dance outside the spaceship? Almost the entirety of Elemental follows that one gorgeous sequence's beat and it's utterly charming. The animation is quite stunning to behold; fluid, expressive and diverse. I can tell Pixar had so much fun with it while pushing the envelope; such a delight to watch. The world drips with inventiveness and attention to detail; I wouldn't pass on living in Element City. I can't leave out Thomas Newman's music, too. This is the composer's fourth collaboration with Pixar (the first since Finding Dory) and his score doesn't disappoint; lovely, often hypnotizing, and always hits the right notes. Elemental is one of the most soulful and compassionate pictures to come out of Pixar in recent years and it's getting such a bum rap for no good reason. Look, it may seem familiar on the surface but - as expected from the studio that pioneered the art form and tells personal stories - Elemental is built from real relationships and social conflicts and has moving answers to questions on affection, immigration, pressure, sacrifice, and free will. Prepare for some sniffles and tears. I felt the love that was put into it every second and that standing ovation at Cannes was well-earned. Congrats, Peter Sohn. Thanks for telling your story.

Review-Title: Creative with a romantic cultural themed story
Review-Description: 4 out of 5 stars. Elemental is a good romantic comedy family pixar film that is fun and creative with having a world built with characters that are elements. Certain elements clash with each other and has a story about how two elements Wade and Ember who are fire and water. Ember is from a family immigrant whos father wants her to follow under his footstep on owning the family shop. Wade is a water inspector who fails her shop which Ember tries to convince him to let it go. The opposites attract. They become close and she also realizes that there is more in the world about following her dreams. It is fun. Great visuals and animation. The plot is good. The film may not have any memorable characters and humor. It is still a good worthy pixar film that has a story and visuals thats worth checking out.

Review-Title: This is not a bad movie
Review-Description: Watched this with a group of children from my school on a Christmas treat. The whole cohort sat transfixed and from that point onwards this has become a major discussion point in our classroom. It's beautifully filmed, lovingly delivered and develops the story well as you move along. Yes we have seen this before - but as there are only five or six actual stories in the world that's a 'meh' argument. This isn't a 'flop' from Pixar it's a reimagining which was beautifully done. Ignore the haters - this is a film to be experienced and enjoyed and will allow each person to take away from it what they need from their perspective... well done Pixar.

Review-Title: Not the best Pixar movie, but certainly not the worst
Review-Description: I saw this film this summer, hearing nothing except that it bombed at the box office and it was panned by audiences and critics. Having only had heard bad news about this, I went in with low expectations, and walked out satisfied. PLOT: The movie is about two Fire elements immigrating from Fireland, Bernie and Cinder Lumen, who immigrate to Element City. The other elements, earth, water, and air, especially water, are extremely biased against them because fire can put out water. They start a new life with their daughter Ember in a small little neighborhood shop called The Fireplace, which Ember will take over one day. Ember has a bit of a temper. She loses her temper one day in the shop and causes a pipe to burst and a water guy named Wade Ripple falls through the pipe into the shop. Wade is a inspector in Element City, and he writes Ember some citations because her father's shop isn't up to code. The citations could shut the shop down. Ember chases Wade through the city to stop him, but is too late and he sends the tickets. Ember and Wade have to team up to fix a broken door in a culvert to cancel the tickets and save the shop, and fall in love as they spend more time together and get to know each other. Overall, the plot is very well executed, and relatively simple in concept. Other than some filler here and there, not a lot of time is wasted. CHARACTERS: Ember is a excellent protagonist. Wade is kind of a crybaby, but not annoying. Almost every character is fun and has a reason to be there. Except Clod, the little earth kid. I don't understand why the marketing team thought he would be so popular, but he's not. He's just annoying and I cringe every time he shows up. WRITING: The screenplay is very strong and well-written. Every scene has a purpose in Ember and Wade's story. Sometimes the writing can be a little clunky. Overall, a very good script. Overall, a very solid story populated with memorable, interesting characters in a colorful, fun world. Perfect for a movie night. 9/10 stars. I would recommend.

Watched it with the 9 year-old at his request, knowing little about the film. Most of the metaphors about migration, starting over in a new country with a different culture, passed him by, but this is something my husband and I have experienced and it touched me. He did ask questions and we talked a little about it, which is just what we want with a children's movie: opening up conversations without being traumatic. He was thrilled and touched by the love story, and so was I. A good time, for sure, and we both finished the movie with a warm heart. Recommend watching with kids from 7 or 8 upwards, littlest ones might be engaged by the beautiful visuals but might lose interest.

Review-Title: Elemental is Pixar's Murkiest film yet. But it's also really beautiful and emotionally compelling.
Review-Description: I love this movie. The world building is so messy, and maybe it's a bit quaint in terms of storytelling, as well as the story itself not being quite strong or cohesive, but I don't care, this is Pixars most underrated film. The characters are endearing. I love ember. Her arc is so strong and the bond between her and her father was compelling. Wade was also pretty cool, and I enjoyed seeing these two together, as they had great chemistry and very solid emotional moments. The animation was gorgeous, with so many colors, and beautiful character designs. The score by Thomas Newman was gorgeous as well, and I love Lauv's song "Steal The Show." The film was funny, but honestly that's another issue, as the movie isn't quite as funny as it thinks it is. Voice acting was really good and I think everyone should be proud of the work they put it in. This movie obviously came from a place of passion and honestly, it's so good. Flawed sure, but it's no doubt one of Pixar's hidden Gems. A little bit of old Disney/Pixar was brought back. Not a ton, but enough.

Phenomenal story line, and animation. This film was thought out so well, I could barely look away to wipe my tears. Recommend for all ages, this is not just a family film! This is now one of my favorites of all time. This film can resonate with millions for a multitude of various reasons, family origin, romance chasers, and even just as simple as a background film for your kids during dinner. I can't recommend this to be added to your watch & rewatch list enough. You won't be able to tear away your attention! Peter Sohn did a such an impeccable job writing & directing; I cried during & again after I learned his parents passed during the making of this film.

Other the main characters being earth elements, which is pretty unique, the story is very much one that has been told 1000 times. A child of immigrants grows up in a family that expects the child to take over their family business. The child (Ember) grows up with intent of running the family business, so as to not disappoint their parents. The whole time, the child is unhappy because they don't take the time to do things for themselves or do what makes them happy. Enter the lovable free spirit (Wade). He comes from a family who follows their passions but who have also suffered a tragedy (death of Wade's father). The child is initially annoyed by this free spirit but also is intrigued by them. Just to spice things up, the child of immigrants and the free spirit come from completely different backgrounds. The child of the immigrant, at the urging of the free spirit, decides to finally tell her immigrant parents that she wants to follow her passion and doesn't want to run the family business after all, expecting the parents to be angry. Surprise! They aren't angry and support her decision. The free spirit and the child of immigrants fall in love, and they live happily ever after. I'll admit that I went into this with super low expectations. Pixar has been a little hit or miss of late. I didn't hate this movie, but it really feels like the days of Pixar being the standard for animated movies is over. The story is so run of the mill and if it wasn't for the beautiful score by Thomas Newman, I would have given this a much lower rating. Thomas Newman really knows how to compose music that pulls at your heart strings. I'll also say that the voice performances were all very good and of course the animation is stunning. It's just a shame that the story wasn't better.

Review-Title: Harmony Hits the Stage: 'Sing' Takes Center Spotlight in Musical Delight!
Review-Description: Illumination Entertainment has made a name for itself as a reliable provider of quality family entertainment since the release of Despicable Me. Although Sing is Illumination's debut musical, it shares many similarities with the company's other productions. A wonderful time is had by all, even though the star-studded cast and equally star-studded song catalogue don't go very deep. Naturally, though, the entire plot serves as a vehicle for the music. From Van Halen to Beyonc√©, the production seems to have spent no money at all obtaining the rights to a long and diverse range of songs. Some become the focal point of elaborate musical pieces, while others are only included in the soundtrack.

The creators of Despicable Me present an original animated film that revives the magic of musicals. This film is a masterful work that also has an excellent soundtrack made of a very good choice of popular songs from different eras. This story is built through the lives of different characters with a common goal, which is stardom in the world of music. We have the rogue Koala Buster Moon played by the great Matthew McConaughey, who always remains optimistic trying to do the impossible to take his theater to the top. The little pig Rosita who is a responsible mother with a big dream. She is accompanied by the charismatic Gunter voiced by Nick Kroll. Ambitious mouse Mike, played by Seth MacFarlane, who has an excellent jazz voice. The punk porcupine Ash who is voiced by the great Scarlett Johansson, and is one of the best characters in the movie. Taron Egerton playing the gorilla Johnny who doesn't want to be a criminal like his father. Lastly we have Tori Kelly as Meena, the shy elephant whose opportunity to be a singer is limited by her shyness. The film offers magnificent musical moments with excellent animation that can be admired on an artistic and visual level. Sing is one of Illumination's best films and an excellent animated film that pays tribute to the world of music in a worthy way. My final rating for this movie is a 10/10.

After the success of both Minions and Despicable Me movies it is time to sing. A koala runs a show with animals singing human hit songs, as there is a mix of chases but it gets ruined but he and his friends restores it and opens up for a sequel in 2021. There is something for all here like furries, hits of all genres, nice CGI work, action, out of context and humor. But, it has a semiudark ending as the two mice are not in the sequels after being chased by the bear gang. Illumination do not fail to entertain, Oscar or Golden Globes or not just watch these movies for fun and I think Sing 2 was another hit so Sing 3 could be possible.

Review-Title: Fun And Great Animal And Musical Animated Film
Review-Description: This is a sensational animated film for all viewers to watch and really enjoy. The crew did a great job in creating this animated film. All the music and songs were exceptional and splendid. The storyline was terrific and harmonious. The cast selection was absolutely excellent and huge. They strongly committed and connected to the storyline and to their respective characters. This animated film reveals to viewers there is no shame in anyone in revealing who you truly are in a person. If anyone has a story or something to show, they are allowed to that. The main reason that I became a writer is to tell my own story and be heard. This is a great animated film for everyone to watch.

When I started watching it i wasn't supposed that it'll hit me like that, I was thinking that it's gonna be a normal cartoon movie,but it gave me goosebumps many times, and the song used in the movie and the characters who sang those songs was so amazing The movie doesn't disappoint you anywhere, all have to say that I laughed i cried i surprised and I got excited
while watching it. The characters and their nature, backstory are just wow, this is a movie that won't let you to forget it
All characters was amazing but , 'moon'hit me hard, his coming timing
And the way that how he does it works was lit , it really made me cry when his theatre got destroyed, and i also cried when he rebuilt his theatre Gotta say that,you should watch it.

Review-Title: Terrible music, not a single risk taken.
Review-Description: Prepare to hear all your least favourite and played-to-death pop songs with even MORE autotune than ever before. The movie refuses to even take a risk of allowing singing voices to be even a single cent out of tune, and it loses all soul. That's the biggest crime, this movie is absolutely devoid of soul. John C. Reilly is in this, "Walk Hard" was one of the greatest musical comedies of all time with some truly well-written original music, this is the complete antithesis of that. No laughs, nothing memorable, no new ground, just an auto-generated, auto-corrected, useless, stinking waste of time for everyone.

Review-Title: As if your life depended on it
Review-Description: No pun intended - I mean animals needing money? Also the inciting incident being quite ... well you have to suspend your disbelief to be able to go on watching. Ans to add to that: you have to dig and like Musicals to a degree .. a lot of songs (and dance numbers) thrown your way during the run time of the movie. I wouldn't have thought this would spawn a sequel, but it was quite succesful - and I finally was able to watch both movies the other day. That all being said, this is quite interesting and if you don't have issues with animals being ... well humanized (though none of them even thinks about selling their organs to get out of their financial issues ... probably wouldn't get much for them anyway) ... you can watch this and have fun with it. Even more so with the voice talent at hand ... alright alright alright ... quite fast paced ... better shape up ... yes looks like this is the one that you want ... ooh ooh ooh (no pun intended)

Review-Title: If ever a film was aptly titled...
Review-Description: A very enjoyable and charming movie musical featuring tons of covers, an electric cast of animals and a good dose of wit along the way. Definitely a family movie I can recommend. My favourite character is Mike the Mouse, mainly because of his hilariously self-centred personality but also because he has the most interesting arc in terms of character development. The formula is somewhat familiar, but you do get to care about these crooning beasts and if the big climax doesn't have you cheering to the rafters, you may very well have no heart. A well-earned 7/10 from me. About to watch the sequel... be back soon!

Delightful animated movie that will have you singing and dancing along with its charming characters and catchy tunes. The story is set in a bustling city populated by anthropomorphic animals, each with their dreams and aspirations. Buster Moon, an enthusiastic koala with a passion for theater, runs a once-grand but now struggling theater. He's determined to bring back its former glory, but the theater is facing financial difficulties. In a stroke of inspiration, Buster decides to organize a singing competition called "Singing Sensation" to attract a large audience and save the theater from foreclosure. However, a small mishap results in the prize money being mistakenly advertised as way more than what Buster can actually afford. Despite the mix-up, a diverse group of talented animals auditions for the competition, each with their unique backgrounds and dreams. Among them are Rosita, an overworked and underappreciated mother of 25 piglets; Johnny, a gorilla torn between his passion for singing and his family's criminal activities; Ash, a rebellious teenage porcupine with a rocky relationship with her boyfriend; Meena, a shy and timid elephant with a powerful voice; and Mike, a smooth-talking mouse with big dreams. As the auditions unfold and rehearsals begin, the contestants face various personal challenges and setbacks. Buster also faces mounting pressure to find a way to raise the prize money before the truth is revealed. Despite the obstacles, the contestants work hard and support each other, forming unexpected friendships and discovering their true passions along the way. As the day of the big show approaches, excitement builds, and the theater comes alive with anticipation. The grand finale of "Singing Sensation" is a heartwarming and spectacular event that showcases the talents of the lovable characters. Each contestant gives their all, but a series of mishaps and unexpected events threaten to derail the show. In a touching and uplifting climax, the characters come together to save the day, proving that true success is not measured solely by fame or fortune, but by the joy of pursuing one's passion and the support of friends and loved ones. "SIng" is a feel-good movie that celebrates the power of music, the importance of chasing dreams, and the strength of community. With its lovable characters, humorous moments, and a fantastic soundtrack featuring popular songs, "Sing" is a heartwarming and entertaining film that will leave you with a smile on your face and a song in your heart.

I saw the original Sing not long after it came out. To me it was Illumination's best effort, not great but avoiding many of the pitfalls of their other movies. I didn't give it much of a critical eye but did enjoy rooting for the characters to achieve their goals, and even gave Buster a free pass for his bankrupt morals. Sing 2 came years later and I wasn't quite as enamored with the sequel despite of it going bigger and louder, and adding some great new characters (what they did to Jimmy Crystal was criminal, he deserves better). I appreciate the generally lowkey character moments and backstories that the sequel sort of abandoned, but the truth for both movies is that Buster Moon is the biggest thorn in this franchise's side. But things started to fall in place for me once I came to accept a theory that isn't wholly original but was solidified by Buster's behavior in the sequel: Buster Moon is a villain protagonist. Sing is the story of a struggling theater producer and a menagerie of characters that find salvation to their personal struggles through the power of song. Buster Moon finds himself in dire financial straits after a long string of flops at his theater scares his benefactors into pulling out. With the bank on the verge of seizing his crumbling theater, Buster cooks up a last-ditch scheme to save it: put on a singing competition. We are then introduced to a group of hopefuls: Johnny the gorilla is a sensitive soul with a gangster father pulling him into a life of crime, but all he wants to do is sing. Rosita the pig is a housewife that gave up her dream to raise her family, an arc that might be slightly undercut by the fact that she has, no joke, twenty-five kids. Ash the porcupine must find a way to express her true self after decoupling from her unfaithful, gaslighting boyfriend Lance. Meena the elephant has a booming voice but is deeply shy and too afraid to perform when it matters. Mike the mouse is the designated jerk with a velvet voice, a schemer that must discover if singing is his true calling. Gunter the pig talks in a funny voice and dabbles in comic relief. Yeah, that one got the short end of the stick, but at least he has some moments of emotional intelligence. Besides the characters' individual struggles, the main conflict arises when the $1000 prize is misprinted as $100k by Buster's bumbling assistant Ms. Crawly. Buster then engages in a house of cards scheme by trying to woo his best friend's rich grandmother, theater legend Nana Noodleman, into fronting the prize money. Along the way, Buster commits a litany of petty crimes and shows a strong aversion to telling the truth before it all blows up in his face in spectacular fashion. Sing doesn't particularly excel at anything, but it is a comfy movie. The story is unambitious but humble and feels like there was a passion for old Hollywood movies about putting on a show to save a theater or something like that. The music selection is wide and definitely feels like it was trying to appeal to more than just kids. Character designs aren't great, with almost random proportions that make the characters feel like they were designed for a different medium before being haphazardly slapped into a CG feature without much grace or care. Zootopia is much better about designing anthropomorphic animal characters, with a world built to fit them. Sing's world is literally just our world with no regard for the wide amount of shapes and sizes for its population. I'm not sure if this generic setting is a result of Illumination's famously restrained budgets or a complete lack of desire from the creative team to do any world building. The movie flops a bit when it comes to how non-committal it is to its narratives and character arcs. Sing has what I call "passable in the moment" writing: It's mostly working when you watch it, but if you think about anything for more than 5 seconds, it just doesn't make any sense. The conflict between Johnny and his dad is the most popular arc in the movie and a prime example. When Johnny's dad rejects him for singing, there's no given reason behind his actions. He just does. And when they reconcile, it comes off as a bit absurd, because why was he against his son singing in the first place? Nobody knows! This really extends to just about anything resembling conflict in this movie. Most problems just... work themselves out. Meena's shy until she isn't. The plot doesn't explore why she's shy or some plan to overcome it... people just tell her to stop being shy until she isn't, then everything works itself out. This movie's threadbare theme of believing in yourself is quite literal, because at no point do any of these characters engage in hard work or intelligent thought when it comes to problem solving. They believe, and then everything just works out. Sing's biggest weakness is its protagonist. Buster Moon exists in a space of sentimentality and fluff, where morals sorta do but really don't matter. I think protagonists should have flaws, especially in kid-friendly material, because those characters make mistakes, learn from them, and grow into better people. The problem here is that Sing wants to have its cake and eat it too when it comes to Buster. He does unequivocally terrible things that hurts other characters but never goes through the stage of growth that includes acknowledging what you did wrong, apologizing, making amends, and taking steps to be better - and prospers in spite of this. This isn't a fluke in this movie; Buster's misdeeds continue in Sing 2 when he starts the movie off by defrauding Jimmy Crystal in what was a good faith business deal on Crystal's part. Crystal is one of the few characters to call Buster's bad behavior out and is horribly vilified by the movie in response, despite not doing much of anything villainous for most of the narrative. This is around the time I started to sour on Buster as a character. It feels manipulative that the gorilla disowned by his parent or the elephant struggling with stage fright can't succeed unless the con artist exploiting them does too. A sleazy theater owner taking advantage of a bunch of wide-eyed dreamers would undoubtedly be a villain character in any other story. His happy ending is just given to him on a silver platter - he didn't really earn it, and he learned nothing from the mistakes he made. Not every character needs to be a role model, but Buster is definitely a terrible one. Despite its many warts, I feel like Sing is the blueprint for Illumination to make better movies, because it actually tries when it comes to character and narrative. They... don't seem to be following that blueprint, but with a third Sing movie on the horizon, it's never too late to learn. With all the money they rake in, there's no reason not to try to be better beyond pure hubris.

Movie Title: Teenage Mutant Ninja Turtles: Mutant Mayhem (2023)
Review-Title: "They look like little Shreks to me."
Review-Description: FILM: 8/10. As a 43-year-old original fan of the Teenage Mutant Ninja Turtles comics, cartoons, and the live-action films from the 90s, my expectations were as low as a pizza in the sewer. Many attempts to recapture the turtle magic had fallen flatter than a deflated pizza crust. However, Seth Rogen, Evan Goldberg, and the writers behind Teenage Mutant Ninja Turtles: Mutant Mayhem pleasantly surprised me, delivering the best TMNT content in decades. Featuring actual teenagers as the voice cast adds a pepperoni twist to the turtles, infusing their characters with the energy and idiocy of adolescence. The tangents and teenage spirals perfectly capture that age, earning a ninja nod of approval. The rest of the cast, a deep roster of talent, brings the characters to life with flair. Ditching the usual focus on the Shredder and the Foot Clan, the film takes a refreshing turn with Ice Cube's Superfly and a rogues' gallery of secondary villains. It's a topping of variety that's been missing in previous TMNT projects. The animation is as unique as a turtle shell, and Mutant Mayhem does for TMNT what Into the Spider-Verse did for Spider-Man, giving it a fresh and visually captivating spin. Trent Reznor and Atticus Ross's score, like the perfect blend of cheese and tomato sauce, hits all the right notes. Their fusion of acoustic and electronic elements creates a varied soundtrack that complements each scene like the perfect pizza pairing. After enduring some disappointing Michael Bay-produced films, this reboot was like a pizza delivery in a half shell, exactly what the TMNT franchise needed. Bring on the sequel, and let the turtles keep kicking shell with their newfound freshness! A turtle power revival that's as satisfying as a slice with all your favorite toppings. FORMAT: 4K Ultra HD Blu-ray VIDEO: 10/10. Upscaled 4K presentation, Detail level: Excellent, Colour reproduction: Excellent, Level accuracy: Excellent, Encode: Excellent, Master condition: Excellent AUDIO: 10/10. Dolby Atmos audio, Dialogue reproduction: Excellent, Soundtrack & effects clarity: Excellent, Dynamics: Excellent, Surround sound presentation: Excellent, LFE content: Excellent MOOFIEMETER: 8/10.

Movie Title: Teenage Mutant Ninja Turtles: Mutant Mayhem (2023)
Review-Title: Fun flick, but I hope the sequel is better.
Review-Description: The problem with origin super hero movies is they're all the same on the surface, that's why Spider-Man Homecoming skipped Peter Parker's whole origin story because we've heard it a thousand times, but TMNT isn't quite as popular so they had to go over the basics. As a result, the characters and animation are fun, but the story could have been written by an AI. A sequel should take care of that though. In the next movie, we'll have these fun charters already established and the story can go wherever they want to take it, which is exciting! Speaking of the characters, they're super fun and acted by actual teenagers! They're pretty annoying but in a "teenaged boys having harmless fun" kinda way which I really vibed with. I appreciate the animation isn't the simple 3D Pixar animation we've been seeing for the past 2 decades, but I'd be remiss if I didn't say I thought this was the same studio that made the Spider-Verse movies, turns out they're entirely different and unrelated. I enjoy unique art styles, and they try to separate themselves from the Spider-verse films, but it's obvious that some studio exec said "I want a movie like the Spider-Verse movies" and thus we got TMNT Mutant Mayhem. That's not to say the animation is bad or anything, but to me it felt like the movie didn't have an identity. It didn't help having all the pop music needle drops either. This movie will be incredibly dated in just 10 years with all its modern references, but hey it's fun now and that's all that really matters. Overall, I'd definitely recommend the movie, but don't hold your breath for anything crazy like the Spider-Verse movies this film was so clearly trying to copy.

Movie Title: Teenage Mutant Ninja Turtles: Mutant Mayhem (2023)
Review-Title: A total disaster, polluting the Turtles for this generation
Review-Description: STAR RATING: ***** Brilliant **** Very Good *** Okay ** Poor * Awful Despite protecting the city from crime, the Turtles, and their master Splinter (Jackie Chan) must live beneath it in the sewers, as the public spurn them because they don't look like them. In the middle of this, the city is under attack from the criminal mastermind, Superfly (Ice Cube), a giant, sludgy bug who's got the local crime monopoly under his control. Cue a run in with cool, streetwise aspiring reporter April O' Neill (Ayo Edibiri), with whom they strike a deal: they'll let her into their world, in return for positive exposure in the social media world April is fluent with. I tend to be fairly loyal, with any franchise with a long established fan base, as it goes through the years, meaning different things to new generations in new incarnations. One that maybe drifted away was the Teenage Mutant Ninja Turtles, which remained fundamentally aimed at kids, without the dark potential to explore, like with the Batman films. And so Mutant Mayhem, the latest version of the original cartoon, passed me by, especially with 'permanent teenager' Seth Rogan, who I'm no great fan of, being one of the writers and producers. But, I've finally given it a go on streaming...and it's even worse than I thought, for reasons I'd never have thought. Directors Geoff Rowe and Kyle Spears are going with an experimental style with the animation, which may appeal to some, but comes off as crude and garish to those of a certain taste. But what's even worse is how they've mangled the characters and their backstories. Jackie Chan's Splinter has morphed from his original calm, restrained manner, into some funky hipster, who plays them old school hip hop tunes that came out before most of the target demographic were born, and won't remember. To be fair, the Turtles retain their original distinctive characteristics, but what is up with Donatello's voice, sounding like some infant who's just learned to talk?!? No wonder it seems voiceover artist Micah Abbey is the only one too embarrassed to have a publicity headshot. Crucially, though, the plot is threadbare, the humour has far more misses than hits, and the whole thing feels like a hideous mangling of the original version, that hints it may be time for the Turtles to put their weapons back in their holsters. *

Movie Title: Teenage Mutant Ninja Turtles: Mutant Mayhem (2023)
Review-Description: To start off it was an easy watch for me due to the music as it was clearly compiled by someone who grew up around the same era as me. The art style was really quite nice but for a poster, not for the film. It didn't work and a different style would have been much better. It's not really an all ages thing. It just wasn't suitable for adults. The dialogue was really annoying for anyone age 10+. The script was the same, very immature. I felt like there were lots of nods to different popular things to try and score brownie points with everyone, such as BTS and Attack in Titan. The whole thing was just boring and fell flat. It was quite simply a bit of boring feature length cartoon. Just nothing to like with a kids story that did nothing, kids dialogue that was annoying and a soundtrack and art style that didn't really work. Yet another disappointment. I'm actually getting so disappointed with Hollywood films that are complete rubbish, getting decent reviews that I am probably going to return to not watching films out of the US anymore. They just have no substance and keep getting worse.

Movie Title: Teenage Mutant Ninja Turtles: Mutant Mayhem (2023)
Review-Description: I wasn't quite sure what to expect watching this movie. First of all I am not a huge fan of the style of animation. So, for me it was a bit of a big strike against. But the biggest strike against it is changing the characters and the backstory. Villains weren't really villains and weren't allowed to shine. It's campy, full of cliches and quite silly. That's the part that works. Voice acting is quite good. There really isn't much for character development. The storyline is overly simplistic. Being, primarily a kids movie, that was expected. Despite all the flaws it is entertaining but it starts from what is the TMNT's.

Movie Title: Teenage Mutant Ninja Turtles: Mutant Mayhem (2023)
Review-Title: whoever wrote this needs to quit
Review-Description: I grew up with the Teenage Mutant Ninja Turtles show from the 87, saw all the movies up until this one. I was not impressed with the last 2 remakes but as average as they were at least they didn't make me upset. I don't even know where to start. They changed the origin story which might which could have been okay if it was well-written, but that was not the case. Everything seemed so bland and unbelievable. I almost lost it when there was a scene where Splinter was sitting in a couch scrolling through his cell phone like an old man having nothing else to do. The writers tried so hard to be smart and funny but to me failed at all levels. Most of the jokes didn't land and I couldn't care less or sympathize with most of the characters. This seems like one of those "modern" remakes that are so popular these days. I could almost feel Seth Rogen's touch all over the material. I still liked the animation and the voice acting was decent. Other than that it's an empty shell. Even at 100 minutes it felt so long.

Movie Title: Teenage Mutant Ninja Turtles: Mutant Mayhem (2023)
Review-Title: Teenage Mutant Ninja Turtles: Mutant Mayhem is regurgitation served as child's play. I actually feel sick after watching it. No joke.
Review-Description: Nerd Turtles (2023) is a batch of sensory overload and gross animation. Junk food for the mind. It actually made me feel sick after watching, and I don't know if that's done intentionally. I would have nice things to say about TMNT: Mutant Mayhem, but for whatever reason, it just makes me feel awful discussing the fact that I watched it, so without wasting time, here's a hot take on the movie instead: I'd probably enjoy this movie a lot more if I were a kid, but being honest, I think even the most die-hard Ninja Turtle fans know this movie didn't live up to their expectations. For one, the style is fitting, but it lacks in delivery for a number of reasons. Some of the character designs are freakishly off-putting for some reason. Not the main turtle designs, but a lot of the others. April O'Neil, at many points, had eye problems. (I'm not sure if I'm the only one who noticed that.) Another problem with making a movie in the same vein as Spider-Verse is that, while TMNT: Mutant Mayhem doesn't directly copy the style verbatim, it does strike me as being a little bit low quality for trying to replicate the personality without understanding why the personality of Spider-Verse worked in the first place. Spider-Verse 1 and 2 may have set a high bar for what could be accomplished with visual aesthetics, but they never sacrificed simplicity. On the other hand, TMNT: Mutant Mayhem tries to do it's own thing, but at the expense of battering the Ninja Turtle source material in order to fit in. There were other problems with the animation outside of this, but I'll give the movie a pass in this area. The writing is so generic, it actually makes me want to cry. There could be so much more done with this franchise, and if they do make a sequel, I'm hoping they learn from what stunk about Mutant Mayhem, because a lot of the writing had its high points and a lot more low points. There's nothing necessarily wrong with the premise, and the ideas stick to the wall, but without spoiling anything, it's clear this movie is made to hype up the next movie and not as its own stand-alone film. This is the "how do you do, fellow kids" to the Ninja Turtles franchise. I am able to tolerate this movie, I just don't want to think about it anymore. I'll give credit where credit is due and say that it didn't eat me inside, but it just makes me not want to look at another pop culture reference ever again. This movie had too many of those, to which I will add, "Am I not turtley enough for the turtle club?" If what I said was hard for you to endure, that's how I felt about this movie. *sigh*

Movie Title: Teenage Mutant Ninja Turtles: Mutant Mayhem (2023)
Review-Title: Pretty Good, Made For Kids (As It Should Be)
Review-Description: While I did think this was a pretty good effort on the Turtles, probably the best since the old movies I grew up on. The art style was excellent, very unique. There were parts where it looked almost like claymation mixed with illustration or something. This is the first time I've seen the Turtles treated like actual TEENAGERS. I said so to a couple of people who said "Didn't they always act like Teenagers?" to which I say NO. They acted like Surfers. They also made an effort to incorporate some more of the comic/cartoon characters that people are less familiar with, which I thought was nice. The movie was not without flaws. First off, there's no Shredder. I get that he's not the only villain, but I was hoping for some Shredder. The soundtrack was mostly fine, but they repeatedly used the song "Ante Up" like it was the theme of the movie and that song very flatly glorifies armed robbery. If you're going to gear your movie towards kids, maybe be a little more conscious of the messages you're sending. Also I don't mind the basic changes to April, but why did they shape her like a potato? Overall it was an enjoyable enough kids movie for an adult to get through, it had some genuine humor and writing to it which I did not expect.

Movie Title: Teenage Mutant Ninja Turtles: Mutant Mayhem (2023)
Review-Description: This film did it right. TMNT has survived for nearly forty years, and took them getting back to their roots to make them popular once more. This movie is suitable for kids and adults. Those adults who have kids now, and watched these characters their entire life. The animation is a next level, making it look like art rather than animation. And, for once, the voice actually sound like teenagers. It took them too long to figure that out. There's also an array of actors who voice many characters, it's worth taking a google search. I will probably end up watching this film again. They also don't go for the standard villain. Saving him for next time.

Movie Title: Teenage Mutant Ninja Turtles: Mutant Mayhem (2023)
Review-Description: It's cringe. I didn't expect this. This movie is just a movie for 5 years old kids, really. They will laugh, especially on that type of silly jokes about family, outdated dad and etc. I am 28 and this is a very sad thing to realize that TMNT universe is getting worser every time. All-time's best is 2003 TMNT animated series Seasons 1-5. Just try to compare it, 80's turtles, Seasons 6-7 of 2003 TMNT, Michael Bay's movie and its sequel, Nickelodeon era, and this one are on the same shame boat, it's all as bad as it can be, very silly created content. Sell the rights to Marvel, please. It may be an option to make TMNT great again.

Felt nothing but boredom from start to finish even the scenes that I think were disgusting didn't make me feel that way cause it was sooo slow and boring. No idea who wrote/directed this but I really hope this isn't how they think 2000s is supposed to be like. Oh and what's with the aspect ratio? Nice touch lmao we got the next Wes Anderson over here. Yikes. Jacob Elordi bro maybe it's cause you were too convincing as Nate Jacobs but I really didn't buy you being all compassionate and sensitive in this one. The accent didn't sound right either. Anyway you're still the only reason this movie might have found an audience. The stroy, the characters, the plot and the ending is all 1/10. Incredibly boring from start to finish. If you think Jacob Elordi is attractive then maybe you'll enjoy parts of it.

Long, long ago there was a horror film made in 3D called ' The Maze ' and in the centre there was something shocking and terrible. In this film there is something beautiful and threatening. A Minotaur statue with more sexual potency than anything else in this meandering film. I like to think this statue was going to bring down the House of the Ruling Classes, but alas statues move terribly slowly. In all seriousness ( that's a laugh ) with shades of ' Theorem ' and ' The Servant ' a handsome young man gets involved with horror of horrors another young man and takes him home to his architecturally appalling pile and introduces him to daddy, mummy and infantile sister. Familiar territory and with veiled homoeroticism a gullible audience like me gets a few Hammer horror shocks. The grave scene by the way is not that shocking and only one scene is but no more spoilers. The actors do their best, but the two leading young males seemed to walk and dance their way through, but Mulligan and Pike steal what is left to steal. Putting it gently I give it a three because in some weird way it does represent the UK today, and as an historical document for the future it maybe valid. If Cinema as we feebly know it now exists by then.

Review-Title: Deep Black Satire that breaks some cinematic barriers.
Review-Description: A deeply dark, black satire that has already ruffled a few feathers amongst some English establishment figures. This wicked class comedy is at times sharply damning of the system it stems from yet never quite manages to smash through the class ceiling and ends with a certain degree of sympathy for its intended victims. There are some fine performances here from lady of the manor Rosamund Pike, her dippy, hippy friend Carey Mulligan and Barry Keoghan as a deceptive, head-working Scouser who comes to stay for the summer, or... maybe longer. Downtown Abbey it is not: prepare to be shocked and shaken out of any preconceptions you may have about English country house dramas. There are some references to Brideshead Revisited, Women in Love, Harry Potter and other British class conscious films, yet director Emerald Fennell throws these out like confetti to throw us off the scent of what's going on. We find that out during a madcap final 20 minutes. However, Fennel has already thrown us one or two rather stomach churning clues - this is a director not shy about breaking cinematic barriers, rather like a young Ken Russell did 50 years ago; and like Russell her films are all the better for it. You have been warned.

Nothing will prepare you for the absolute mind-bend that is this film. It is raw, disturbing, amazing, and so wonderfully fantastically twisted. I can't stop thinking about it. Saltburn perfectly encapsulates the deepest darkest corners of lust, desire, and greed while shedding light on what being an outcast really looks like. The characters are as equally lovable as they are loathsome which doesn't make sense now but it will. If you are the type who loves dark, sinister, caught-off-guard kind of films, this is the film for you. I recommend this for anyone looking for a rollercoaster ride of emotions, dark themes, twisted scenes, and an overall insane experience. Please please please... do yourself a favour and watch without spoilers. Enjoy my friends.

Talented Mr...., I mean The Great Gat...., crap I mean The Social Netw.... Dammit, sorry, "Saltburn," is a phenomenally fun movie, with dark overtones scattered throughout. I have seen some mentions of this being derivative and requiring a suspension of disbelief - GOOD - enjoy it and do that. It's a hell of a movie that I enjoyed thoroughly. This movie is not "unintentionally hilarious." It is intentionally hilarious and I believe if you enter into it knowing that you will enjoy it as much as I did. To that point - my favorite part - when the police are investigating the death at the end of the movie, and they keep getting lost in the maze.... Brilliant.

"The Talented Mr. Ripley" meets "Brideshead Revisited" meets any number of homoerotic class-struggle prestige pieces. Given the advance press and buzz, I kept expecting something more, something better, but this movie doesn't go beyond the cliches. Even the "shocking" scenes that everyone talks about feel un-earned: gratuitous flashes of fetish in the middle of an otherwise paint-by-numbers exercise. Jacob Elordi is pretty. Barry Keoghan does his deadpan thing, which was disturbing and compelling in "The Killing of a Sacred Deer," but here just feels blank. Rosamund Pike and Richard E. Grant are fun as stereotyped daffy British aristos, but the other supporting characters make no impression whatsoever. The storytelling telegraphs every reveal in the first few minutes, and then feels the need for a "Sixth Sense" style flashback at the end to say, "Look! We surprised you! Bet you didn't see that coming!" Pointless and disappointing.

I had high expectations on this film. The cinematography was amazing, I enjoyed the film and each actor's performances. However, the plot lacks originality when its basically an other version of Talented Mr Ripley. The writing is so poor, with forced and unnatural dialogues which made every performance look like they were faking the scenarios. And every situation didnt make sense. I could see that Emerald Fennell had a big idea for this film, with the 2006 aesthetics and aristocratic storyline, but it didnt reach to its potential. The main character, Oliver, was at first portrayed as an innocent boy whose family is poor. In the middle of the movie we started to realize that Oliver isnt who we thouht he was, as he was manipulating people. At the end we saw a psychotic boy with an obsessive and evil plan. But what waa his agenda? To inherit Saltburn because he wanted to escape his middle class boring all american life? Or did he really love Felix, but killed him because he knew his secret? Well none of that came through the film. Instead the movie was left with unsolved questions.

Oscar winner Emerald Fennell's sophomore effort is another scabrous indictment of the jet set starring Oscar nominee Barry Keoghan. Keoghan has entered Oxford & right away he's signaled out as being not part of the in crowd. Soon enough through a fluke of fate, Keoghan makes some inroads w/the lead alpha Jacob Elordi (from Max's Euphoria) & soon enough they become besties to the chagrin of Archie Madekwe (from Gran Turismo), a friend of Eloridi's family. After they graduate, Elordi extends an invitation to Keoghan to stay at the titular named estate w/his family; mom, Oscar nominee Rosamund Pike, dad, Oscar nominee Richard E. Grant, Madekwe & Elordi's sister Alison Oliver for the summer. Once there he settles into the rhythm of this rich, out of touch clan & soon enough due to time or comfort, Keoghan soon makes headway winning all but Madekwe over but when they decide to throw him a birthday party, Elordi, who believes Keoghan comes from desperate straits, decides to take Keoghan to his own home where he finds his parents are alive & well & frankly boring & bourgeois. Elordi has had enough of his charade & decides to cut ties w/Keoghan, after the blowout bash of course, which ends up being a fatal mistake for Elordi & the rest of his tribe. Playing like a mirthful take on Patricia Highsmith's Tom Ripley character, Keoghan is the ultimate inveigler, insinuating himself into his well-off fold where his grand plans of showing the other side up becomes a bloody affair w/a proud 'cock of the walk' nude victory at film's end is an acid dipped icing on the cake. Look for Oscar nominee Carey Mulligan, working again w/Fennell, playing a tiresome friend of the family who has overstayed her welcome.

Honestly I was totally enchanted by this film... especially the dynamic between Ollie and Felix. It seems like quite a bromance until the end explains all... as much as it might seem one way... Oliver loves Felix. I was captivated enough by shots of Ollie's behind, captivated by a certain bathtub scene, a certain funerary display... but was floored when he dances naked in the end. I was not expecting that at all... I almost thought I willed it to happen, I almost felt seduced by Ollie myself... the actor Barry Keoghan is absolutely beautiful. More so I'm glad directors are starting to realize what an untapped frontier the male nude is. It is far too one sided in cinema. Is it really so necessary to expose women but never men? Obviously women aren't always nude in context... I'm glad this film wasn't scared to go in these directions. SO many Agatha Christie mysteries have a twist like this story... bravo.

**spoiler below** A movie that had the seeds of greatness but ultimately fails. Seemingly the production decided to tick as many boxes as possible of distasteful, drawn out scenes placed more for their shock value than to advance the story. The rather simple story ultimately devolves into a contrived finale where you can practically here some one whispering the virtues of the "modern" (now cliche) approach of grossing us out, making us hate a character and capping the torture by letting that bad guy we hate win. Yawn. It's been done better and more tastefully. The good? - The actors do a good job animating some one dimensional characters though. The scenery is great and the music decent. You won't be sorry you missed this one.

DREADFUL ACTING. TERRIBLY CORNY AND A SHAME SINCE THE INITIAL SCENE IN THE COFFEE SHOP WAS VERY GOOD. THE TWO MAIN STARS WERE VERY LIKEABLE BUT THE SCRIPT WAS SHOCKINGLY BAD. SOME OF THE ACTORS IN THE FILM CANNOT ACT ALAS. NOT BRYAN BROWN AS THE GUY CAN ACT BUT NOT EVEN HIM WITH THIS SCRIPT! THE PRODUCERS AND THE DIRECTOR SHOULD BE ASHAMED OF TURNING NOT A BAD IDEA INTO A CORNY FILM. IT PAINS ME TO WRITE ANYMORE AS THIS DREADFUL FILM IS NOT WORTHY OF ANY MORE CRITIQUE. I WOULD ADVISE THAT A WOMAN DID CHUCKLE THE ODD TIME BESIDE ME. SO SOME PEOPLE MIGHT ENJOY THIS GENTLE ROMCOM! ALAS NOT US.

After seeing the trailer for this movie my expectations weren't too high, however I still wanted to see it & I thought maybe the trailer was just badly edited.. but it just feels like a hallmark movie with slightly better actors. The dialogue was so terrible I found myself rolling my eyes at times but there were a few decent laughs throughout. All in all it was a decent movie & it definitely gets better as you watch it. I'm not sure I would recommend seeing it in theaters though maybe wait for it to hit streaming & judge for yourself. It's one of those I probably won't remember in a year or 2. Oh & the montage at the very end was probably one of my favorite parts it definitely had some feel good moments!

Review-Title: I wish I could see this all over again for the first time.
Review-Description: OK, maybe it's dumb fun ... and it won't win an Oscar, but it had my whole theater room fully entertained (mostly late teen girls and their moms, it seemed). It delivers the male sexy, for sure, including some moments where there were covering-of-eyes but still with a peek. And Sweeney shines, as well as the Miranda character, in both acting and presence. Some of the close dialogue was a bit stifled or trite. Glen Powell has exercise scenes on the beach, since that worked for "Maverick," right? I'm a fan of the 1993 "Much Ado about Nothing" film from Kenneth Branagh. Consider checking that out after seeing this. You'll see phrases from Shakespeare's work throughout the film in transitions and in some speech. Also, the film's made money, Sweeney is one of the Executive Producers, and so good for her. And she's certainly been busy; you'll probably be shown a trailer for "Madame Web," coming soon.

Review-Title: Attractive people in various forms of undress
Review-Description: Anyone but you is a newly released romantic comedy starring Sydney Sweeney as Bea and Glen Powell as Ben and is directed by Will Gluck. Bea and Ben just happen to meet eachother by chance in a coffee shop and immediately gain a liking for eachother. They spend an evening together but in the morning due to some crossed wires they go their separate ways with a dislike for eachother. Cut to six months later and Bea's sister happens to be getting married to one of Bens friends and so they find themselves stuck in eachothers way. This initially causes conflict that is until both characters realise it may be advantageous to both of them to pretend to like eachother. What follows is a mediocre romantic comedy with overall likeable characters but with only a few laughs. Don't get me wrong I know comedy is a really difficult genre as humour is so subjective. I just felt that this film didn't even really try thinking outside the box when it came to its jokes. Yes there's the expected typical sex jokes that always get a light chuckle out of most audiences however it's nothing you haven't heard/seen before. The film to me seemed to try to sell itself on the sole basis of having an attractive cast. It then goes a step further and has its cast appear in various forms of undress throughout the film. Sydney Sweeney almost always has a fair amount of cleavage showing for instance. Don't worry though ladies there's plenty of abs and men's bums too. It all just felt like a distraction though to a story that's about as generic as they come. A nice distraction but a distraction nonetheless. Just fine.

Review-Title: Best Movie I've Seen In A Long Time
Review-Description: This is one of the funniest movies I've seen in a long time! There were multiple times throughout I laughed so hard that I almost peed my pants, but I wouldn't leave to go to the bathroom because I didn't want to miss anything. The two leads had such good chemistry and I think that is what drove me to be so attached to this movie. Much like a Hallmark movie, it was pretty predictable, you knew they were gonna end up together but of course there had to be some type of miscommunication to drive them apart so they could come back together in a super romantic gesture. Stereotypical? Yes. But made it super fun to watch? Also yes. I think it also helped that the two leads are incredibly attractive.
