As I left the theater I decided I would absolutely buy this movie when it comes out because I already want to watch again. Highlt recommend if you're in need of a fun rom com to put you in a good mood!

Review-Title: Sydney Sweeney casts herself in a movie she's producing and fails
Review-Description: I almost didn't see this movie because I was sick of how much they were marketing it, but I miss rom-coms and haven't seen a good one in a while. This movie was hard to get through. Sydney and Glenn both have unique but odd looks to. Me, they kind of have chemistry, but I almost feel like this movie could have been better with two different leads. Sydney Is good with supporting roles but she's not lead material imo and it's physically uncomfortable to watch her try way too hard to be sexy. I think I read another comment about this in a review and I've always thought she tries to be something she isn't. The dialogue is okay, but I don't remember much, and overall, I don't love how predictable the movie is. Obviously, some rom coms can be but they're still fun to see how it pans out, but this movie was terrible. I miss old rom-coms from the early 2000s like Notting Hill, Love Actually, and a Cinderella Story. Anyone But You was awkward, kind of forgettable, and only had maybe 1 scene that was kind of interesting.

The preview made it look like a cute romcom but it was not! The writing was so so lazy and rushed. A guy full screen close up of the head of his pecker (for no reason). That shot still has me scratching my head. It was out of the blue. A shower seen that made absolutely no sense. It left me filling dirty and sad. The big romantic speech that is supposed to make you swoon had a couple f-bombs. Just made it impossible to feel the flutters or giggles a romcom is supposed to. It was more of a how sad it is if this is what they call romantic now üò¢ It had potential it could have been cute but it was disappointing üòû

Review-Title: The Marketing for this Movie Did Not do it Justice
Review-Description: The trailer and marketing for this movie put me off, but when I heard it was loosely based off Much Ado About Nothing and heard good things, we decided to check it out. Really glad we did. There was plenty of laugh out loud moments, quick moving plot, a range of characters and their connections to one another, and all in all just a bit of fun. It is a Romcom, so like you would expect of the genre, you know where it is going to end up but it was an enjoyable ride getting there. Do get frustrated with people expecting this genre to "be better", but this delivers everything you would want it to. Definitely recommend as a cheesy date night or a girls night out!

Review-Title: A delightful adaptation of a classic
Review-Description: One of the better adaptations of a Shakespeare play. Both faithful to the original text and reinvigorated by a modern twist. I wish there had been an "Against my will I am sent to bid you come into dinner" scene as that is iconic. I am fascinated with how they adapted the "Ado" in that is ended up not really having anything to do with H+C. It did feel like the Jonathan/Don John part was a little thin and perhaps was at one point more substantial, but to be fair it is one of the least motivated villains in Shakespeare so perhaps that tracks. Highlights would be the adaptation of Beau/Borachio and that the name of the bakery is Dogberry.

This is one of those movies that gets better in my head the more it lingers in there. As the movie was unfolding, I thought it was fine and had some cute and funny moments, but I didn't think too highly of it. But as it progressed towards the end and they brought everything together, it really hit for me and I've only thought of it more positively since leaving the theater. I think it hit the romantic and comedic sides equally well. The chemistry between the two leads was solid and certainly engaging, because I found myself continuously frustrated when things kept not working out between them, and when they finally did, it was done really well. And on the comedic side, there are easily 5+ scenes I can remember that made me laugh out loud and ones that I'd love to be able to watch again right now. Finally, the emotional side of things was done well too, especially how they tied everything together with Unwritten by Natasha Bedingfield and everyone singing together at the end definitely put a smile on my face.

Another fantastic movie from Mr. Lanthimos. One of the most entertaining retellings of the Frankenstein story I've ever seen. Maybe the best. That's definitely debatable. The story was marvelous and well written. It's split into acts based on Bella's (Emma Stone) journey. Speaking of Emma Stone, she was incredible here. Some of her best work imo. Her ability to show the different sides of Bella's development was astounding. Everyone is cooking honestly. Mark Ruffalo is in his bag. Really doing something new and different for him. William DeFoe is crushing as always. And even the side characters all come through with great performances. Some of the cinematography was top notch. Really felt like you were watching a watercolor painting come to life. I loved this movie. Only a 9/10 because it felt a lil long. Definitely worth a watch for fans of his work!

My Review -Poor Things
In selected Cinemas now 9/10 I suspect that there will definitely be two camps of movie goers reactions to this very R rated dream like gothic Adult fairy tale those that love its absurdity and those that loathe it . I really loved it and think that the creative team of screen writer Tony McNamara and Director Yorgos Lanthimos who gave us the Favourite in 2018 have struck lightning twice with an original and thoughtful black rom com that has its roots in the gothic genre of Mary Shelley's Frankenstein and Bride of Frankenstein. Movies for me often seems like cake baking it often depends on the ingredients as to whether I think they are successful or not . Poor Things for me has all the right ingredients a superb performance from its star Emma Stone plus an impressive supporting cast . The other vital ingredients for me in this movie is its creative team which I'll refer to later. I got flavours or little influences of past great movie makers like James Whale who directed the 1931 Frankenstein and Bride of Frankenstein 1935 ,Tim Burton's Corpse Bride 2005, and Mel Brooks humour in Young Frankenstein 1974 . I also loved the impressionistic look of this movie at times reminding me of the work of the Spanish artists Antoni Gaud√≠ and Salvador Dal√≠. The movie Poor things is based on a 1992 novel by Alasdair Gray , Its stand out performance comes from Emma Stone as Bella Baxter a young woman who is literally raised from the dead by the disfigured experimental Dr Goodwin Baxter after a successful suicide attempt. The Doctor restarts her heart in his laboratory after removing Bella's adult brain replacing it with her unborn baby daughter's brain . Of course the concept sounds gross but is it really in today's world of medical cloning cryogenics and genetic experimentation . Bella Baxter after recovering has no recollection of her previous life and is a baby in an adult woman's body. She is awkward at first learning to walk and talk and begins to develop the curiosity of all life's experiences including sexual gratification. Any healthy baby brain would begin to experience her curiosity except for the fact that Bella's body is adult so
she innocently discovers and equates sexual desire with happiness
This is where the originality of this Adults only fantasy thickens when this child nymphomaniac in an adult body meets a debauched lawyer named Duncan Wedderburn a foppish mustachioed scalawag played to perfection by Mark Ruffalo in a role that is one of the most entertaining elements of Poor Things. In an interview Mark Ruffalo said I'm getting a little bored of myself as Mark Ruffalo," he added. "I was trying to take the ship as close to the reef as I could possibly get without actually running aground. He added he thinks it was the most fun he's had in a movie and that's obvious from his performance. Let's stop here for a moment to remember Dr Victor Frankenstein because the similarities are obvious especially with the lightning strikes in the Doctors laboratory as Bella comes back to life. However from then on Tony McNamara takes us off on a totally different journey into a surreal world divided into chapters . The Beginning, Bella Baxter is born in Dr Goodwin's laboratory -Portugal Bella runs away with Duncan Wedderburn a debauched lawyer - The Boat driven by his jealousy towards Bella's suitors Wedderburn isolates Bella - At Sea - Alexandria- Bella discovers her conscience and attempts to help the poor and starving with Wedderburn's gambling winnings ,- Paris Bella discovers the oldest profession in the world when she and Wedderburn become stranded in Paris and separate after becoming penniless,, and finally London where Bella is confronted with her past life. Dr Goodwin Baxter who Bella calls God is a fascinating character study brilliantly played by Willem Dafoe . Somehow he manages to make this monstrous grotesquely scarred Doctor seem almost kind in his affection for Bella. A victim of generational child abuse the cruelty the Doctor experienced as a child from a father that treated him like a medical experiment is revealed. I could almost understand the motives for his continued experimentation. His grotesque makeup is amazing
Willem Dafoe described the makeup process, "Four hours in, two hours out every day and showing up at three o'clock in the morning, sitting in the chair, meditating and trying to deal with standing still. I also enjoyed the weird atonal minimalist score by Jerskin Fendrix which added to the many bizzare moments in this film. Two of the many memorable scenes for me were the weird but brilliant crazy dance scene where Bella discovers her musical rhythm and the Paris brothel scenes where she is employed by the sleazy tattooed madam Swiney played with delicious decadence by Kathryn Hunter. Cinematographer Robbie Ryan , set decorator Zsuzsa Mihalek , costume designer Holly Waddington and Production Designers Shona Heath and James Price have done a superb job at taking us into this surreal world of absurdity. Be prepared for an absurd adventure with weird animals like chickens with pig heads dogs with ducks heads and a goat with a human brain all part of Doctor Godwin Baxter's cabinet of curiosities. Poor Things is sure to be nominated for multiple Academy Awards and as much as I hope Carrie Mulligan who is My Favourite wins this year I would not be to surprised if Emma Stone scored her 2nd Best Actress Oscar it often goes to actresses in very unconventional roles . What a great way to start my movie year.

I wanted to like this film...but no. This film is just disturbing, and not in a good way. The film is about an INFANT who has her brain put into a woman's (the infant's mom) body. While the character may look like an adult, she is not...she is a CHILD. Let's make that clear. Immediately the child starts masturbating. Okay, uncomfortable, but maybe the director has something to say. So I stick with it. Next thing you know the child's father is offering her up to get married by his adult assistant who KNOWS that he is proposing to a child. A few scenes later Mark Ruffalo's character sneaks into her room, molests her and kidnaps her where he has rampant sex with her for several excruitatingly long scenes that span weeks if not months. It's crass and it's tasteless given that the character is a little girl with an adult woman's body, but again, while I wince, I'm assuming that it's going to all come together with some powerful social commentary that will be poignant and insightful. I'm mean, the reviews are stellar. Surely this will not be for naught...right? What is the characters big revelatory moment? She finds her agency by becoming a prostitute and - voila! - she's a complete human, a feminist at that! So essentially you have this little girl go through some seriously traumatic sexual abuse (replete with director awkwardly shows her insatiable desire for sex with adult men by having her literally beg for it constantly)...and then by "embracing" prostitution she is somehow magically "liberated" and transforms into a self-actualized being. Okay then. Not only is this some poorly thought out social commentary and character development, but it's quite warped and disturbed if you let it sink in. This just felt like some perverted guy wrapping some sordid child sex abuse fantasy with a flimsy facade of female empowerment, except that empowerment isn't earned or justified given what happens in the story. Actually, I would say quite the opposite. Add in some really heavy handed and poorly construed themes (e.g., she literally refers to her father -like figure God...really now?) and some seriously forced situational comedy and you have just an insufferable film. The only bright side for me was the art direction and costume design. All style, no substance.

Review-Title: Superb upside down and sideways take on Frankenstein
Review-Description: Based on the novel by Alasdair Gray and adapted by Tony McNamara, Yorgos Lanthimos' POOR THINGS is like a backwards and upside down take on the Frankenstein myth. As to be expected, Lanthimos was never going to do a straightforward adaptation (even of the novel), and his penchant for the bizarre and outrageousness is at the fore from the very beginning. Bella Baxter (a fearless Emma Stone) is the latest creation of Dr. Godwin Baxter (the always reliable Willem Dafoe) - "God" to his few confidants. She's the 'monster' with a young woman's body but the mind of a mere child. When one of God's students, Max McCandles (Ramy Youssef - solid), arrives to observe Bella, he's as smitten as he is horrified at the Doctor's not quite human-being. The abode is also a veritable menagerie of various mutants and failed experiments. God's castle-like home and laboratory is the first of many elaborate fantastical settings for Production Designers Shona Heath and James Price to play with. Robbie Ryan's expressive cinematography shifts between B&W and Color - and always on actual 35mm film (it's framed in a throwback 1:66 aspect ratio). Jerskin Fendrix' musical score is his feature debut and it's iconoclastic. As striking as the early scenes are, the film truly takes flight when Bella is let loose upon the world by a rakish solicitor played by Mark Ruffalo. Bella is whirled across Europe and on a cruise ship ravishly sampling all of the sensory and physical delights of the world, especially those of a carnal nature. Lanthimos doesn't shy away from Bella's wanton newfound sexuality and revels in displaying its many varieties(perhaps a bit too relishly). It's certainly the randiest Frankenstein film since Paul Morrissey and Andy Warhol's X-Rated 1974 version (thankfully, we are spared the 3D details!). Stone embraces the erotic sequences with abandon - but, approaches them with a keen purpose. This long section of the movie also serves to show Bella's maturation on an intellectual level. Her mind is genuinely expanded along with her corpus. Her transformation could be read as feminist (and on many levels, it is), but, in a genuinely clever way; Many of the film's themes link up with Mary Shelley's 19th Century source novel. The notion of a person created against their will and desiring to be free to choose one's life path is successfully distilled here. The creation must grow and challenge their maker. Bella's drive is to seek to become articulate and experienced - to become their own creator. To have a true soul. To be their own 'God'. When Bella returns to Dr. Baxter, the film becomes almost its own sequel. Another significant chapter or two, if a bit curtailed in length. There is also one last adroit twist which is a direct homage to a certain classic horror film of similar vintage to that of James Whale's 1931 masterpiece FRANKENSTEIN. Lanthimos' POOR THINGS is a brilliantly designed film in both style and substance. The thematics are in tune with the design elements and vice-versa. Some of the musical selections and over-use of distorted lenses do distract, but it wouldn't be a Lanthimos film if everything was proper and pleasing. Stone is a wonder here and the large supporting cast is mostly spot on (Ruffalo is a bit miscast) with a nice turn by Kathryn Hunter as the brothel madam (Hunter was also superb in Joel Coen's TRAGEDY OF MACBETH).

Yorgos Lanthimos is continuing to do a great job of maintaining a singular style while also doing something different with each new film he makes. I don't necessarily agree with the people who say Wes Anderson sticks to his style too much, but if Lanthimos keeps taking further creative risks the way he's been doing, I don't imagine many people will ever accuse him of a such a thing. Plot-wise, Poor Things is sort of a coming-of-age story, but in a way that's not only hard to describe, but probably better off not describing. The premise is actually kind of similar to the weird Australian cult classic Bad Boy Bubby: we spend a decent amount of time with someone who l has the appearance of an adult but a mind like that of a child, remains trapped in a single location, and then after about 20-30 minutes, they're let out into the world, with all its surprises, wonders, and horrors. Narratively there are similarities, and both films also have some very let's say graphic content, but visually and tonally, they're pretty different. Poor Things might be a tad too long. I at first thought Willem Dafoe's continued presence in the story was hurting the pacing, but I like the direction his character went in, by the end. I think the last 20 minutes hurts the overall film, though. A character emerges who it makes sense should emerge, but they spend a weird amount of time on him and it's mostly a detour before things reach an otherwise satisfying conclusion. That sequence aside, I liked this film a lot. It looks amazing, it's very funny in parts, and Emma Stone is excellent. It also might have my favourite performance Mark Ruffalo's ever given, too.

Review-Title: A mixed review, but the film ultimately prevails
Review-Description: I went into the theater knowing I was Poor Things' target audience-I like quirky characters, arthouse vibes, stunning aesthetics + themes of challenging cultural norms. In a lot of ways I felt very pandered to, but I've never watched a superhero movie that held my interest so I welcome some pandering at this point. By the end of the movie I felt I could forgive much of the "on the nose" aspects. I have to admit I was bored during quite a bit of the film. However, there are incredible moments that will stay in my memory for a long time-brilliant lines written and themes explored between the drawn-out, meandering scenes. Not to mention Emma Stone's utter brilliance in understanding her character and how to endear Bella to her audience. Mark Ruffalo's character started strong, then spun out into the pathetically absurd, but again, I collected gems from this movie that I didn't have before and feel glad I saw it overall. As far as the sex goes, I'd just say get over it. The U. S. is so afraid of its shadow, and people with raging p√∏rn addictions will give this a low rating because they don't like that the filmmakers exposed it in the light of matinee. I was much more disturbed by the (sometimes gratuitous) cutting open of dead bodies, but I recognize it's a personal preference for me to avoid seeing these things, not a moral failing on the movie's part.

The desire to be weird and avant garde meant a director who has built a career on weird and avant garde missed the entire point of the story. This really should be called, 'A Ropey Telling Of 25% Of Poor Things Missing The Most Important Point' I suspect Gray is laughing in his grave at how the culture snobs who made, and are now gushing over this have managed to sucker themselves. I'm sure he saw them coming. I suppose that's the main comedy element of the film. Seen as 'A Ropey Telling Of 25% Of Poor Things Missing The Most Important Point', it's rather fun. Though, some things did grate. Stone's acting and dialogue suggested a robot rather than a child. Most of the swearing was unnecessary and detracted - seemingly put there to force a laugh. A little more intelligence in the script would've served this particular story a bit better. I would've preferred a more conventional nineteenth century setting to juxtapose against the weirdness rather than have everything built full Willy Wonka-esque. And some of the characters and story points that were left out would've put a lot more meat on this thin gruel had they been included. Very poor. Very poor indeed.

I thought it would be a good movie for my husband's birthday. I was so wrong! The ratings were good on IMDB...don't believe it! It had great actors Mike Wilem Dafoe, Emma Stone and Mark Ruffalo. It was horrible! Gross and over done sex scenes of nasty men with Emma Stone (I am not a a prude). One couple left within 20 minutes. Emma Stones character was totally unsympathetic and gross. She was basically nude or panting through most of the film and not in a good way. It was a weird and gross movie. It was a HUGE disappointment and a waste of three hours of our time! Why?????????!!???????????????

Review-Title: Beautiful scenes, weak story, too much sex.
Review-Description: I really enjoyed the first 30 minutes of this movie, the black and white scenes, the really interesting and funny behavior of Emma as a baby in a matured body, the story of the mad scientist, it really got me hooked up. I lost all interest after that, it was too much explicit sex, too much shocking scenes, seems like she learned how to speak as an adult, but never actually matured. Mark Ruffalo's british accent is terrible, it was so hard to watch Emma's perfect phrases and him just barely getting out of that american accent. The ending felt rushed as we get to see a little bit of the life of the suiciding mother, I would enjoy to learn more about her than to see all those sex scenes. I'll give it a 4, it has some really beautiful shots and sets, other than that it feels more like a soft porn than a an actual movie.

Poor things is directed by Yorgos Lanthimos (The Lobster, The Killing of a Sacred Deer) and is supported with a strong cast, namely Emma Stone, Mark Ruffalo and Willem Dafoe. The first impression you get from this movie is bizarre to say the least. In fact, it takes some time to get used to the ambiance which is nothing short of macabre. And surely, this impression lasts throughout the whole movie; but this feeling of weirdness and incomprehension serves the plot and in this sense, is most welcome. Eventually, there comes a time where, inevitably, and without even realizing it, you are suctioned right in, never to escape again. And you are glad to be trapped in what is essentially pit of limitless pleasure. Indeed, one of the things the movie does very well is make you, along with the protagonist, embark on an adventure. Sure, you might have been to the places the protagonist went to, but those are presented in a most wonderful way. The aesthetics are magnificient and otherworldly. I do not know how they did it, but I remember being in awe and it is a feeling that I will cherish for a lifetime. It is truly a sight to behold. It is the kind of movie which makes you feel grateful to be alive.

Very disappointing. Sad that so many movies contain graphic sex scenes which gets guys to watch but requires no writing talent at all. Would have loved a movie simply focusing on Hugh Grants character. The rest was filthy talk and even graphic sex scenes. People can get that garbage at a porno web site. Takes no talent at all to write that type script whatsoever. It will get you good ratings however. Should've been named "Lewd Actually" or "Lust Actually". Sad commentary on today's devastated families through divorce because of lifestyles portrayed in this piece of trash movie. I give it 3 stars only because of Hugh Grants character.

Review-Title: A Disjointed Anthology with Shallow Love Stories and Decent Performances
Review-Description: Love Actually falls short as a good movie, presenting itself as an anthology of different stories with pieces connecting them. While there might be some likable elements in each story, it's a written mess carried by its actors, whom you might only watch because you appreciate their work outside of this film. They deliver an okay performance, but the lack of substantial material limits their impact. For a film exploring different types and ways of love, every story feels incredibly shallow, featuring characters making stupid decisions without much payoff. Despite being a Christmas film with entertaining actors, the overall lack of meaningful events may leave you questioning whether it was worth watching. It's a divisive film, and while some may really hate it or love it, I land on the 'do not care' side of the reception for this film.

Love actually is all around on Christmas. "Love, actually" is a very British comedy about love on Christmas, and the magic of Christmas and the spirit of Christmas. It's a really clever idea of having many small and completely different stories being the focus of this movie because love comes in different kinds. The clever thing is that somehow all these stories do interact woth each other but each and every one of them serves its own purpose. Emma Thompson I think speaks to the hearts of many women around the globe, and her performance is very poignant and raw and real. Hugh Grant's story is here to remind us of Clinton and Lewinsky. And Keira Knightley of course steals the hearts of many once again. Some very iconic scenes, some great pop-culture moments and a ridiculous song and performance by a great Bill Nighy. "Love, actually" is unapologetically British and absolutely ridiculous and bonkers and I love it. A perfect holiday movie.

Rating: 7.7
Overall, an enjoyable Christmas movie that is carried by its writing and performances as we get to see the unique concept of multiple storylines happening in parallel with their common goal of finding love, though it is a bit bloated from having too many subplots and suffers from many Rom-Com and early 2000s cliches. Pretty Good Direction (The direction on a macroscale is pretty good as he connects the different storylines into one overarching plot (though the world-building felt very typical to other Rom-Coms); the direction on a microscale was pretty typical to other Rom-Coms (though executed well); the direction of actors was good as it felt like everyone was connected and gave a performance that helped move the movie forward; the storytelling was pretty unique as it juggles multiple different subplots that converge to a giant ending), Pretty Good to Good Acting (Good from Hugh Grant (Uses his charm, charisma, and experience in romantic movies to aid his performance), Good from Liam Neeson (My favorite performance in the cast as he develops a strong chemistry with his son and effectively displays grief from the loss of his wife), Pretty Good from Colin Firth (Uses his experience in romantic movies to propel this performance forward), Pretty Good from Laura Linney (Felt a bit out of place, but does well in the scenes she is in), Good from Emma Thompson (Shows betrayal well and has a good range of emotion throughout the movie), Pretty Good to Good from Alan Rickman (A surprisingly comedic performance from Rickman, but he holds his own well and shows some range of emotion (at least however much he can with his mundane voice)), Pretty Good from Keira Knightley (Really just a name as she isn't given that much screen time (but still does a pretty good job with the scenes she is in)), Pretty Good from Martine McCutcheon (Works well off of Grant), Pretty Good from Bill Nighy (A very over-the-top performance that provides humor in his non-sequitur scenes), Pretty Good from Rowan Atkinson (Mr Bean), Pretty Good from L√∫cia Moniz (Has chemistry with Colin Firth), Pretty Good from the rest of the cast (Everyone plays their role well as this movie is more about an ensemble cast than a singular performance)), Good Story (The concept was very unique as the different storylines converging to one was a pretty new idea at the time (though it was heavily exploited after), there are a little too many stories (maybe could have cut the 1-2 of them to make the movie a bit tighter); the plot structure was very unique as it was multiple storylines converging to one climax (though there are some other climaxes as not all the storylines converge to the same point); flow between sequences was surprisingly good as the transitions between the different stories were seamless at times (using music and characters); character writing was good as you get a sense of what each character's struggle was and what they are looking for during the holiday season), Good Screenplay (The dialogue was pretty good and flowed well (but did have cliche Rom-Com lines); the movie has some very iconic scenes that were parodied/referenced in other forms of media; the humor was good (though did feel very 00s); the symbolism was kinda light (but its a Rom-Com so I cannot complain that much); the foreshadowing was very good as it was used effectively to help connect the different storylines together), Pretty Good Score/Pretty Good Soundtrack (Helps set the Christmas tone), Decent Cinematography, Decent Sound, Good Editing (Helps with transitioning between the different stories), Pacing was pretty good as it did not feel very slow or fast, Climax was executed well as it converges many of the storylines to one singular event (and the climaxes of the other storylines were also handled well), Tone felt exactly was the genre was (A Christmas, Rom-Com)

Review-Title: A Reminder That We Are All Looking For Love
Review-Description: When it comes to love, we find it comes in many forms and in mysterious ways. Showcasing the truest bits of love found in everyday life, Love Actually gives us multiple stories of a human struggle. Starting off a bit slow, the individual relationships are all fleshed out distinctly and create a very unique and charming tale. While each story is fairly entertaining, some of them are worth more emotional investment, leaving others feeling like perfect bathroom breaks. Although it isn't perfect, it all comes together in a beautiful ensemble in the end. Complete with an all star cast, this film is an English 'Who's Who' of celebrities, each adding a cute and fun performance to their story. It is fun getting to see these big actors interacting in such quirky ways and taking on roles that are delightfully unexpected. Love Actually takes us on a very real and human journey through the love and lives of different individuals, reminding us that it comes we are all just people, in need of love.

Review-Title: A funny yet sentimental and touching film exploring love in all its aspects
Review-Description: When you think of the word "love", what words come to your mind? Maybe it is lust, attraction and sex? Maybe it is sharing sweet and romantic moments together? Or maybe it is unbridled faithfulness and devotion over time? This movie explores all of these aspects of love and more. Interwoven within this movie are stories of people from all walks of life from the young to the old. Each person explores a facet of love like a diamond glistening brightly reflecting its light and beauty in various different ways. E.g. We see those pure moments where time seemingly slows down as a person is enraptured by someone else for the first time. We also see how power can influence and potentially corrupt the dynamic of people in romantic relationships e.g. Superiors and subordinates. The film showcases the joy of couples getting married whilst also showing the sorrows of unrequited love. The film also examines the themes of dating, casual relationships, and temptation in the face of faithfulness. Love Actually is an enjoyable film that is funny, lighthearted, sentimental, and romantic. It will appeal to people of all ages who want to experience vicariously what it means to be in love. This film will surely bring you and your loved one into a romantic mood by the end. It is an instant classic rom-com and well worth the watch! Highly recommended!

Love Actually, a film that has garnered praise for its star-studded cast and holiday charm, presents a mixed bag of emotions for viewers seeking a fresh take on romance. While the ensemble cast brings familiar faces to the screen, the movie's reliance on well-worn romantic clich√©s and its struggle to provide depth to its characters raise questions about its lasting impact. One of the noticeable aspects of Love Actually is its abundant use of romantic tropes. From the shy confessions of unspoken love to the grand gestures that seem to conveniently unfold, the film embraces these clich√©s with open arms. While some may argue that familiarity is part of the charm, it leaves others, like myself, wanting more substance and originality. The predictability of the plotlines undermines the potential for genuine surprises and emotional resonance. The ensemble cast, featuring notable actors such as Hugh Grant, Emma Thompson, and Colin Firth, is undoubtedly one of the film's selling points. However, the star power fails to translate into compelling characters. The individuals portrayed often lack the depth needed to make their romantic journeys truly engaging. It becomes a parade of famous faces navigating through storylines that, despite their potential, feel one-dimensional and fail to establish a meaningful connection with the audience. Love Actually attempts to explore the multifaceted nature of love by intertwining various storylines. Yet, this ambitious approach results in pacing issues that hinder the overall viewing experience. The transitions between scenes can feel abrupt, making it challenging for viewers to fully immerse themselves in the unfolding narratives. As a result, the film struggles to build and sustain emotional intensity, leaving moments that should resonate feeling disconnected. While the film aims to capture the complexity of love, certain relationships portrayed in Love Actually border on the improbable. From workplace romances that seem far-fetched to connections between characters that lack authenticity, the film's exploration of love often ventures into the realm of fantasy rather than genuine human experience. This contributes to a sense of detachment from the characters and their romantic entanglements. Pacing is a recurring issue in Love Actually, and it reflects the film's attempt to balance a multitude of storylines. The constant shift between characters and scenarios prevents the audience from fully investing in any particular narrative. The lack of a cohesive rhythm undermines the impact of individual moments, leaving the viewer with a fragmented sense of the overall story. In addition to pacing concerns, Love Actually faces criticism for its occasional missteps in portraying relationships. Some character dynamics perpetuate stereotypes and reinforce gender norms, raising questions about the film's cultural sensitivity. While the intent may be lighthearted, these elements detract from the authenticity the film aims to capture. In conclusion, Love Actually, with its star-studded ensemble and holiday charm, falls short of expectations due to its reliance on romantic clich√©s, pacing issues, and occasional problematic portrayals of relationships. While it has its moments of levity and charm, the overall experience is hindered by a lack of originality and depth. For those seeking a fresh take on romance, Love Actually may leave you wanting, as it navigates the terrain of well-trodden clich√©s without breaking new ground.

Review-Title: Not to be a Scrooge but how do so MANY people love this movie?
Review-Description: I've been hearing about this movie since it came out 20 years ago. Never really had a reason to watch it until this year, around Christmas time wanting to watch a Christmas movie I'd never seen before that is considered by many to be super beloved. Listen, I'm not super harsh on most movies but for the most part this just wasn't any good. The super unrealistic storylines were too much for me to bear. A bunch of characters falling in love with each other after only knowing each other a couple weeks; other characters who learn foreign languages fluently in a manner of weeks. It's just too unrealistic, even by most rom com standards. It does have some redeeming scenes like the chemistry between Liam neeson and his step son. But Wtf was up with the Keira knightley story line?!? Talk about weird and awkward af. At first I thought the two guys were gay for each other but then it turns out the one is just in love with his friends wife. And then they end up in a polygamous relationship at the end or something??? Is that what is supposed to be implied? Man, this movie is a mess and I'm not sure why people love it so much. Maybe if I saw it when it first came out I wouldn't feel this way but yeah... idk. I would recommend skipping this one I like the idea of a Christmas movie made specifically for adults but the execution of this film was bad.

Review-Title: Worst movie ever created by humanity
Review-Description: Alright, so here's the real deal about "Love Actually." It's a mess, mate. I mean, they chucked in a boatload of big-name actors, thinking that's all it takes to make a killer rom-com, but nah, it's like they just threw a bunch of random love stories into a blender and hoped for the best. First off, the plot is all over the place. You've got like, what, a million different stories going on? It's like the filmmakers couldn't decide on one good story, so they just went, "Ah, let's do 'em all!" The result? A confusing mishmash that's hard to follow. You barely get to know one couple, and whoosh, it's onto the next. The characters, man, they're like cardboard cutouts. There's little depth, and most of 'em are walking clich√©s. You've got your typical lovesick puppy, the guy who's pining for his best mate's wife (creepy, much?), and don't get me started on the whole American girls falling for the bumbling Brit thing. It's like they picked the most stereotypical traits and ran with it. And the humor? It tries way too hard. Some of the jokes are just cringey. It's like, we get it, you're trying to be funny and quirky, but it falls flat most of the time. Feels like they're trying to shove the laughs down your throat. The thing about "Love Actually" is, it's trying to sell this fairy-tale version of love, but it's so out of touch. It's like a bunch of unrealistic, soppy stories mashed together. And don't get me started on how it handles serious stuff like cheating. It's all glossed over with a cutesy bow. Visually, it's nothing special either. The whole thing just screams average. Sure, there are a couple of catchy songs, but that's not enough to save this trainwreck. So, in a nutshell, "Love Actually" is a hot mess. It's trying to be this big, warm-fuzzy, feel-good movie, but it's more like a cheesy, try-hard flick that's bitten off more than it can chew. If you're looking for a solid rom-com, this ain't it, chief.

Review-Title: Over rated but its intentions are good
Review-Description: Finally watched this one about 20 years late ha ha. There are a selection of cameo parts from some superb actors and also a selection of hammy over done sequences too. Bill Nighy's character steals every scene he is in. It must be fun to play a terrible character like that. Emma Thompson is great in everyone of her scenes. Hugh Grant does his thing. If you like his work you probably saw this years ago. Colin Firth has a part as Jamie who somehow has an epiphany involving a woman who doesn't speak English at all. This leads to the most ridiculous scenes in the movie. They say love is inexplicable but that one is a real stretch. There was one couple who shouldn't have even been in the film at all. Just Judy and John are some kind of lighting stand-in's for porn although I had to read about that as it is not obvious what they are doing and not a job one ever knew even existed. Martine McCutcheon was a nice surprise although well known to others but not to me as I don't watch TV soaps. But she was funny and seemed like a real person. Liam Neeson is now so well identified with his fictional role in those nutbar films where he goes OTT crazy it is hard to even consider him as a grieving widower which is what he plays in this movie. Thank goodness for Bill Nighy who I think gets the tone exactly right. Cynicism with a sense of humour.

This movie, about an eight-year-old troublemaker who must defend his home against a pair of burglars on Christmas Eve, is a great family movie! The story and the concept are silly, but yet so funny. We get to meet a lot of different characters where some of them are part of hilarious family dynamics. You can actually resonate with them, and that makes the movie much more enjoyable. Despite that this movie is packed with humor, it also manages to introduce individual struggles during Christmas times that makes it emotional, as well. The action and its evolving storyline are very entertaining because of its creativeness, and because of the movie's success, many scenes have become globally iconic, making the movie even more worthy. With its blend of heartwarming moments, hilarious antics, and creative action sequences, this movie is a timeless classic that has captured the hearts of audiences worldwide.

"Home Alone" is a heartwarming and hilarious family comedy that has stood the test of time since its release in 1990. Directed by Chris Columbus and featuring a stellar performance by Macaulay Culkin, this film has become a cherished part of the holiday season for audiences of all ages. The story follows 8-year-old Kevin McCallister, brilliantly portrayed by Culkin, who finds himself accidentally left behind when his family goes on vacation for Christmas. What follows is a delightful rollercoaster of slapstick humor and heartfelt moments as Kevin defends his home from two bumbling burglars. Culkin's charisma and comedic timing are undeniable, making Kevin a character audiences can't help but root for. The supporting cast, including Joe Pesci and Daniel Stern as the burglars, adds an extra layer of humor to the film. The chemistry between the characters feels genuine, contributing to the movie's overall charm. One of the standout aspects of "Home Alone" is the cleverly crafted and memorable booby traps Kevin sets to thwart the burglars. These scenes are not only entertaining but also showcase the creativity of the filmmakers. John Hughes' screenplay strikes a perfect balance between humor and heart, creating a film that appeals to both children and adults. The movie's holiday setting adds to its timeless appeal, making it a must-watch during the festive season. In addition to its comedic brilliance, "Home Alone" also delivers a valuable message about the importance of family and the realization of one's own strengths. The film's feel-good factor is infectious and has made it a perennial favorite in households worldwide. In conclusion, "Home Alone" remains a classic that continues to bring joy to audiences decades after its release. Its combination of humor, heart, and memorable characters makes it a true holiday gem that deserves its status as a beloved cinematic tradition.

The plot is fairly simple but provides a great foundation for an adventure full of laughs. Macaulay Culkin shines as brightly as it gets and is the main reason for the movie's success, while the duo of Joe Pesci and Daniel Stern add the right amount of goofiness and showcase incredible chemistry. Excellent score by John Williams as well. However, specifics don't matter that much. The major achievement of this movie is that it perfectly captures the Christmas spirit, it's hard to imagine Christmas without Home Alone, watching it has become sort of a family tradition for me - and I know I'm not the only one. It's quite possibly the only movie I've watched so many times, yet it never gets old.

Review-Title: 31.12.2023 Five hours before the New Year...
Review-Description: "Home Alone" is already a New Year's classic. I am writing a review a few hours before the New Year 2024, the time is more suitable than ever! The film is a comedy, the action takes place, as it is clear, on Christmas Eve, the idea is quite original, the actors also did their job well. I also want to say that I am not an ardent fan of this movie and do not watch it every New Year, but it is worth recognizing the cult significance and overall interest of the plot of "Home Alone". I would recommend watching this movie at least once in a New Year's mood to feel the rush of the atmosphere. It's worth it! My rating : 7.5/10.

Review-Title: "I wish they would all just disappear."
Review-Description: "Home Alone" has definitely earned its place as a Christmas season viewing staple. I saw it years ago when it came out, that was before I started doing these reviews, so I caught it with the family the other night looking for something to watch. I didn't remember how mean the members of the McCallister family were to each other when the story opened, so that was somewhat off putting. But then things proceeded to the familiar story of young Kevin (Macaulay Culkin) mistakenly left behind on a family vacation when Mom (Catherine O'Hara) inadvertently included a neighbor kid in the head count to start the trip. Most of the humor is provided by the bumbling intrusion of home invaders Harry (Joe Pesci) and Marv (Daniel Stern), who receive their comeuppance from Kevin to devastating effect more than once. Even with that, my favorite scene was the one with old neighbor Marley (Roberts Blossom) and Kevin discussing their fears while in the quiet setting of the church. It reminded me of all the worldly wisdom one could get from watching any episode of 'Leave it to Beaver'. And of course, you had not one, but two feel good endings with Kevin reuniting with his family, as well as Marley, who made up with his estranged son in time to enjoy the Christmas holiday.

A late merry Christmas from me, and I hope everyone had a nice Christmas in general. It's time to watch the same 5 movies as always because tradition, but let me be honest, I might skip this one next year. Home Alone is a concept that screams Chris Columbus, since it's an amazing child fantasy. He has always been the master of that, creating the scenarios that speak to an inner child in you, imagining that you, in this case, were home alone owning the house, doing whatever you wanted. But after rewatching it for the millionth time, the magic has worn off, as per usual when it comes to me and Columbus movies. Maybe it's me seeing more and more small things I don't like, and repeatedly seeing them just makes me want to skip to the best parts of the movie. This is still a movie I hold dear but for the future, it can run in the background. Kevin is a young boy in a big family, and after they forget to bring him for the Christmas getaway, he is left home alone. This is nice for Kevin, however some thieves might ruin this Christmas for him. What this movie drives on is its concept. It's the ultimate childhood dream to be left alone and do whatever you wanted to. Chris Columbus captures the childhood wonder and fun perfectly, and Macaulay Culkin¬¥s kids charm carries the vision. Eating whatever you want, seeing whatever you want, fight off bad guys, it's a kid's wish come true. This together with the heart is incredible. The movie has these really heartfelt speeches and conversations and combines it with humor to really make a fully rounded movie. But I must admit, it feels like a slow movie, basically because it's a concept film before a plot one. The movie goes from scenario to scenario without much connection, and the loose storytelling just doesn't speak to me. I don't know what the movie tries to do half the time, and the first half doesn't really connect with the later The acting is also a bit all over the place. While the charm of Macaulay Culkin is wonderful in this movie, the over acting doesn't really speak to me, with very repetitive gags like the scream done too many times. The standout here is the acting of Joe Pesci and the comedic timing of Daniel Stern. The later physical comedy and the comedic parring of the two really carries this movie. Course, while I find it fun what Kevin is doing in the first half, I just wait for the house invasion. That is the best part of the movie, proving that physical comedy still is amazing when done to perfection. The score is pretty good, but that's no surprise coming from my favorite composer, John Williams. It is a bit all over the place, but so is the movie. He captures every emotion perfectly here. This is a good movie to me, but a lot of empty calories and just entertainment. It don't do more than that. As per usual when it domes to Chris Columbus movies, the concept, and its elements are childhood perfection and captures the essence of having fun as a kid, but creating a strong story and doing something with the concepts are always lacking. This is a classic, and I'll watch it again no doubt, but maybe from a distance next time.

Oh, Home Alone. It's' a Christmas classic and for good reason. This film is a tale of two halves: the first is about a naughty boy who thinks his family disappeared, the second is the brutal beatdown that he gives to a couple of burglars. I find a lot of enjoyment during both parts of the narrative. Kevin's gradual regret about his "Christmas wish" is tender to watch, specifically when it comes to the relationship with his mother. The humor in this movie is phenomenal. From the destruction of Buzz's room to Kevin's quippy remarks at the grocery store,
Macaulay Culkin crushes his performance. Across the board, one of my favorite Christmas movies of all time, even though I like the 2nd one more. Best Character: Kevin
Best Quote: "I'm gonna give you to the count of 10, to get your ugly, yella, no-good keister off my property before I pump your guts full of lead!" - Johnny
Best Scene: Facing Harry and Marv
Best Piece of Score: "Somewhere in my Memory"

Review-Title: Kevin McCallister is Obviously Training Himself to be Jigsaw
Review-Description: While celebrating the holidays, classic Christmas films are a surefire way to set the mood and make spirits bright. Capturing the holiday cheer, Home Alone has been a definitive film of the season for over 30 years. With Macaulay Culkin taking on his most iconic role as Kevin McCallister, it is undeniable how charming and talented he is, especially for a child actor. Although the story is fun and entertaining, it is Kevin McCallister and the Wet Bandits (Joe Pesci & Daniel Stern) that elevate the film into its iconic level. While most of the film is fun, there are some slower bits in the middle, which separate the fast paced start and the exciting heist. With memorable performances, lots of laughs, and plenty of holiday heart, Home Alone is a fun film that consistently makes spirits bright.

While movies about Christmas are typically happy and lighthearted in nature, I don't know if I'd classify Home Alone as one of them. The movie has a more serious premise than you would expect (if you've never seen it), but also some important messages that apply to your life. The film starts with a family named the McCallisters getting ready to fly to Europe in order to spend their Christmas in Paris. The youngest son of Kate and Peter McCallister is Kevin (Macaulay Culkin), who always seems to be getting into trouble. The night before their vacation, Kevin ruins dinner after fighting with his older brother Buzz, and his mother confines him to the attic as punishment. Kevin tells his mother he is tired of always being ridiculed, made fun of, and wishes his family would go away forever. His mom tells him to watch what he says, since it might just happen. That night, the alarm clocks in the house are shorted out due to a bad storm, causing the family to oversleep. Kate and Peter wake up in a panic, discovering they only have about 45 minutes to get on their plane. They hire rented vans to go to the airport, but in the rush, Kevin is left behind. The latter wakes up and realizes he has the house to himself. Kevin goes outside and is terrified of an old man named Marley, whom Buzz said is a serial killer. Soon, Kevin's house is set in the sights of two burglars, Harry and Marv (Joe Pesci and Daniel Stern respectively) who attempt to rob empty houses around Christmas. Strangely, Harry was already in Kevin's house before his family went away, posing as a cop. As Harry and his accomplice try to scope out Kevin's house from a Dodge van, so Kevin uses mannequins and loud music to give the impression his family is still home. Concurrently, Kate realizes mid flight that she left her son at home. Once in France, she desperately tries to get a flight back to Chicago, but they're all full. Peter and Kevin's relatives stay in a hotel while Kate manages to get a plane to Pennsylvania. Once there, all the flights to Chicago are still full, but she meets a traveling band who offer to drive her there in a moving van. Back at Kevin's house, Harry and Marv find out he is the only person home, and put their plan of robbing the house into action. Kevin goes to a local church alone and comes face to face with Marley, who comes right up to him to wish him merry Christmas. Marley tells Kevin he came to the church to see his granddaughter sing in a choir, which he can't normally do as she is the child of a son who wants nothing to do with Marley. He and Kevin talk for a few minutes, and Kevin tells him he should try to make up with his son. Even if it doesn't work, at least he tried. When Kevin goes back home, he sets up makeshift traps all over the house to deter Harry and Marv, such as spreading ice all over the steps, shooting them with BB guns, and even putting Buzz's pet tarantula on them. As Harry and Marv chase Kevin through the house and up into the attic, he uses a zipline to get to a tree house in his backyard, then runs into a neighboring house. The criminals eventually catch Kevin, but Marley unexpectedly sneaks up on them and subdues them with a shovel. The cops show up and arrest Harry and Marv. Due to Marv's calling card of leaving the water running in every house they rob, the cops know all the houses they have broken into. On Christmas morning, Kevin wakes up, goes outside and learns his family is still away. Right after going back inside, Kate's U-Haul pulls up. Overjoyed at seeing her son again, the two of them forgive each other. Peter and the others then come back home after taking a flight that Kate didn't want to wait for. Kevin doesn't tell his family about what went on when they were away, then looks out his window to see Marley getting back together with his son and granddaughter. This is quite a nice movie. While Pesci and Culkin do have a tendency to overact, it's hard to imagine such a memorable movie with any other actors. Culkin's portrayal of Kevin is instantly relatable, even if you don't have siblings. We've all had to deal with animosity from family members even if we don't deserve it. I mentioned earlier that even though the movie may not appear that serious on the outside, it has many morals in it that you should think about all the time. Kevin telling Marley in the church about how he should see how his son is doing is a crucial moment, since it shows no matter what you did to someone in the past, you can always try to get back on their good side. Even if it doesn't work, you at least did something to try and fix the situation. Some people go their whole lives not talking to certain relatives because of one minor argument back in the 80s, and it's stupid. In addition, we see how unconditional the affection a parent has for their child is. Even though Kevin is left behind in the beginning by his irate mother, she is distraught throughout the rest of the film once she realizes what she did. Overall, because Home Alone has a great atmosphere and an unlikely protagonist in the form of a kid who manages to prevent two seasoned criminals from wrecking his house, I think it's an ideal thing to watch during the holidays (or any other time).

Review-Title: It's funny, but hardly one that I'd revisit every year.
Review-Description: Not really about a merry Christmas, but a family so dislikeable that permanent holiday vacations from sounds like a jolly, jolly experience to me. Certainly Macauley Culkin is fun to watch, but he's definitely neglected which leads to brattiness and acting out. His older brother is one nasty piece of work, taking great pleasure in torturing him, and the worst part of it is that his parents let him get away with it. John Heard and Catherine O'Hara get the awards for the worst screen parents ever, and the assortment of annoying family members are just horrid. I rank this higher because in spite of all I abhorred about it, I did find a little bit of a heart, particularly with the scary neighbor (Roberts Blossom) who gets to reveal his own truth, making the viewer wonder about the scary neighbors of their own childhood. As the escaped convicts, Joe Pesci and Daniel Stern are dumber than Elmer Fudd and the coyote, and realistically, they should have been deceased after a few knocks on the noggin and other painful traps Kevin sets. As for him, he'd be in a juvenile detention center for the deadly dangerous. But try not to laugh about the shenanigans Culkin gets into. Everybody in 1990 did, and decades later, it's still considered a holiday perennial.

I expected better of Raj kumar Hirani if not of SRK who started making mass films(which translates to bad films) after getting discouraged by failure at box office for Swades and Paheli 20 years back. He has continued his hit run of making corny and cringy movies and has even taken Tapsee and a great actor like Vicky Kausal to a level of bad acting that you wont belive they are capable of. In short the movie is a failed attempt to do justice to a serious issue and I thought it would have passed as just a run on the mill comedy if it wanted to be just that. But no, they had to bring the cringe. Omar no Hamar. Stay home. Save yourselves.

As my heading, it's not what you expect. I went to the cinema with great jubilation for this movie... especiallly because of how Rajkumar Hirani's movie are. Well, this one "DUNKI" typically disappointed me and the story kicked off after the second half. The stuggling journey wasn't even shown more deeply and it was just about 20mins of screen time. The challenging roads weren't more i would say and that really put me off. Also, SRK's acting wasn't top notch either.. Raju Hirani , you are more greater than this below average movie. I hope you make great movies in future. Totally disappointed.

Review-Title: A Good film with a hurriedly written ( changed?)screenplay
Review-Description: While watching the film, one gets the feeling the makers felt the movie will not stand upto PK Munnabhai series so the climax was hurriedly written. The weakest part of the screenplay was how fast the main protagonist in the film could reach England. Indian immigrants come mostly on the invitation of hotel owners, shop keepers, and simply stay on by going off radar. However let's give Raju Hirani benefit of the doubt. Taapse fits in seamlessly with Shahrukh. Raju Hirani missed the chance of developing Vicky Kaushals character and developing it into a great one. Nevertheless Vicky does a fantastic job. Sad to see Boman Irani a regular in Raju Hirani's film given next to nothing role for such a talented actor. Songs were too loud and Pritam is losing his touch. Dunki is doing well because of Shahrukh Khan but people are not talking about it. You can give the movie a miss and watch it on TV. But it's not bad watch either. It's just the film has suffered due to a week screenplay.

Raju Hirani films are so promising that they lure audiences blindly despite of any amount of disbelief shown by trailers or pre release hype. All primarily because of impeccable storytelling with great script and screenplay. Dunki is so contrasting that it doesn't even seem like RHF. Excellent performances with great music and colors but all without a script and engaging storytelling. No connection with a single character. Poor execution with even worse editing are the highlights of this movie. Pretty sure Aamir would have or may did outright reject this mess. Extremely disappointed with the team, hoping for a better movie next time.

It was a long movie that you hope will end soon. The message was pretty confusing. More like, with zero logic. Should the rich countries let the world's poor into their countries just because they are poor? What will happen if India, a rather not-so-well-off country, opens its borders? The emotion part was completely missing. Couldn't connect with the actors. And, if you are not from Punjab, please don't speak Punjabi or in a Punjabi accent. Applies to SRK too. The jokes were pretty lame. A huge amount of time was wasted on English lessons. I was thinking of English-Winglish which was such a well-done movie. Except for Vicky Kaushal, none of the key actors impressed me much. The fake display of patriotism and forcefully injected emotions didn't work for me. The only part of the story that impressed me a bit was the last escape plot. Other than that, it was a waste of money and time.

A trio of friends has problems that only migrating to London can solve. Unfortunately, the British immigration system has made it impossible for the average person to get a visa. After many hair-brained plans fail, they take the only remaining option, illegally crossing many borders and entering Great Britain. This dramedy examines the reasons and lengths individuals will go to make a better life for themselves and their loved ones. The movie's characters make it a comedy, but the story is dramatic. The film is easy to watch and moves along quickly, with only a few song and dance sequences. The film is worth streaming when it is available.

Review-Title: An issue based family entertainer Film
Review-Description:
Watched 2 Film on New Year Dunki and Sam Bahadur. Review of Film
Dunki
A journey back home with lots of love, humour, friendship, patriotism and strong emotions. Renowned director Rajkumar Hirani has done a wonderful job with these emotions, especially in the second half which is portrayed very well and the climax brings tears to your eyes. The strongest point of this film is its portrayal of the immigration problem, which shows reality about their struggles, their feelings. How they get cheated by fraud agencies take advantage of their feelings, dreams and ignorance. In the dream of a better life, so many people lost their lives. And once they reach the land of their dreams, what a harsh reality they have to face, and perhaps this is also the weakest point. How many of those who are going to theaters in search of entertainment with popcorn are aware of these problems? Even if we know, how many people can feel it? Sometimes it is the responsibility of a good director/writer to spread the message, to make the public realize the issue, which is just a news to them. There are some technical flaws, it could have been done better, it may not be Hirani's best, but overall it is a really good film with good intentions. You will laugh and cry. Everyone has acted well, but among all these good actors, Vicky's small role and his acting have created an impact. Taapsee Pannu has portrayed her acting abilities with efficiency. Vikram Kochhar, Boman Irani, Anil Grover have acted with liveliness. SRK fans will enjoy seeing his phenomenal portrayal of someone who can die for his love, but can't lie, can't defame his country. Pritam's music was good but not extraordinary. The hall was filled with families, parents bringing their children after a long time without any hesitation. After so much violence, action drama, intimate scenes, toxic masculinity, in recent releases Bollywood finally brings a pure family drama to enjoy this festive season. So, all the best to the Team Hiani. My rating is 4 Star out of 5 Star.

Review-Title: Emotional Layers: Unveiling Manu Randhawan's Impact
Review-Description: Tapsee Pannu did well playing young Manu Randhawan in the movie, but when the story jumped 25 years ahead, her acting as an older person didn't quite hit the mark. It was hard to believe Tapsee Pannu was genuinely an elderly character, and this affected the overall impact of the film. Even in a scene meant to be emotional, like her character's death, I couldn't help but be disappointed at Tapsee Pannu's acting instead of getting sentimental. Her acting skills while portraying elderly Manu Randhawan held the movie back from being as emotionally impactful as it could have been. Despite Tapsee Pannu facing some acting hurdles, there's a lot to love about the movie. The storytelling kept me hooked, and the songs makes you heart go lutt putt. Shah Rukh Khan nailed his character (as always) with his top-notch acting. And even though Vicky Kaushal doesn't have a lot of screentime, he sure knows how to tug at your heartstrings-I mean, he got me crying! Oh, and can we talk about those action scenes? Loved them! The underwater scene, the scene in the deserts of Iran, each one of them were splendid.

Review-Title: A Resonant Exploration of Dreams and Reality.
Review-Description: "Dunki," a 2023 Indian Hindi-language comedy-drama film, stands as a testament to the enduring allure of quality cinema. Directed by Rajkumar Hirani, this film not only captivates audiences with its unique storyline but also demonstrates the sustained interest in well-crafted movies, as evidenced by a nearly full theater 10 days post its release. Set against the backdrop of the "donkey flight" illegal immigration method, "Dunki" delves into the lives of a group of friends who seek a better life abroad but face the harsh realities of their decision. The narrative is a compelling mix of humor and poignant drama, reflecting the complexities and moral dilemmas of such a journey. The film's casting is a masterstroke, with Shah Rukh Khan, Taapsee Pannu, Vicky Kaushal, and Boman Irani delivering performances that are both authentic and powerful. Shah Rukh Khan, in particular, shines in a role that seems tailor-made for him, adding depth to the film's emotional core. Rajkumar Hirani's direction is flawless, maintaining a balance between the comedic elements and the grave subject at hand. His expertise in storytelling is evident in every scene, capturing the audience's imagination and empathy. The screenplay, co-written with Abhijat Joshi and Kanika Dhillon, is crisp and engaging, complementing Hirani's vision perfectly. The technical aspects of "Dunki" enhance its appeal. The editing is seamless, making for a smooth cinematic experience. The background score and songs, though not exceptionally memorable, fit well within the film's narrative fabric, enriching the emotional resonance of the story. "Dunki" is more than a film; it's a reflection of the dreams and struggles of individuals seeking a better life. It's a movie that resonates with audiences beyond the fans of Shah Rukh Khan and Rajkumar Hirani. The film's ability to hold a nearly full theater 10 days after its release speaks volumes about its impact and the connection it has forged with its viewers. In summary, "Dunki" is a must-see film that beautifully blends drama, romance, and comedy. Its poignant storyline, stellar performances, and masterful direction make it a standout in contemporary Indian cinema. It's a film that not only entertains but also inspires reflection and empathy, leaving a lasting impression on its audience.

I went to this movie two days after its release. I'm a big fan of SRK, so I really wanted to go. Here's what I liked and disliked about the movie. The movie had a really good soundtrack and it was nice to hear in the theater. The characters had good personalities and good reasons to go to London. I loved that Tapsee Pannu, an all around actress was there in the film. Sukhi(Vicky Kaushal)'s presence was so meaningful and I was sad to see him go. That leads me into what I disliked about the movie. Sukhi's funeral and Hardy(SRK) deciding to go to London by Dunki is what closed out the first half, which was a barrel of laughter and everyone in the theater including us was laughing so hard. The second half is their journey to London, so it got serious and went really slow that I wanted to sleep at one point. But that's how Raju sir's films are. To wrap things up, this was a good movie, and it was beautiful.

Review-Title: Harmless Christmas Fun Bolstered by a Great Cast and Underrated Script
Review-Description: As someone who is quite "scroogish" when it comes to Christmas movies - bah, mediocrity! - I recently took the chance to enjoy "National Lampoon's Christmas Vacation" for the second time. Surprisingly, it held up pretty well. Now, this needs to be immediately stated: your enjoyment of this movie will, quite simply, boil down to how much you can stomach Chevy Chase. Because, make no mistake about it, he is the main attraction here. From his patented physical comedy to his dry wit to his outlandish facial expressions (I'm particularly fond of the last one, in this movie), Chase has his paw marks all over this Jeremiah Chechik-directed romp. If you are a Chase fan, like I am (controversies aside), chances are you will be laughing from the opening scene to the final credits. Chase's delivery is on-point, and Clark Griswold, while very much a typical Chase character, is fun to laugh with (or at) for 90-ish minutes. The best laughs in this movie, though, come from the fantastic supporting cast. Whether you latch on to a young Juliette Lewis as Clark's moody teen daughter, Johnny Galecki as the mature (but young) Rusty Griswold, or the great E. G. Marshall as the elderly Art Smith, there are plenty of fun stocking stuffers to help elevate this film into "classic" territory. For me, however, it was the inclusion of Mae Questel (as Bethany) late in the film that had me belly-laughing on the couch. From her perfect delivery to fantastic lines (thanks, John Hughes), Bethany - despite having less than five minutes of screen time - is infectious. To make matters even better, her dynamic with her husband (William Hickey) is something that we can all relate to. Is this a deep movie that will have you sobbing due to introspection when the final credits roll? Nope. Are there some sub-par acting performances that take you out of it? Yep (looking at you, Brian Doyle-Murray). Is it the best Christmas movie ever made? Of course not. That being said, National Lampoon's Christmas Vacation does enough (whilst minimally offending) to be considered a very good yule-related expedition.

Review-Title: Celebrate Christmas with the Griswold family.
Review-Description: First they drove across country to Wally World, then they won all expenses paid trip across Europe, now the Griswold family is staying home to host a good old fashioned family Christmas. Just like when the Griswold family hits the road, nothing ever really turns the way that Clark Griswold plans. From problems with the size of the Christmas tree to unexpected guests things go comically wrong. Joining Clark and his family are both his and Ellen's parents, Uncle Lewis and Aunt Bethany, and of course cousin Eddie and his bunch. There's a lot of slapstick humor and a lot of belly laughs provided by Chevy Chase and Randy Quaid in this mostly family friendly holiday favorite. This was my introduction to the "Vacation" series. I would've been only five when this came out, so I didn't see it until its network television premiere back in 1992, and it's been a favorite since.

Review-Title: My favorite of the Vacation movies
Review-Description: Not only is this my favorite of the National Lampoon Vacation movies, but it is also one of my favorite Christmas movies out there. For someone like myself, the other movies push it a bit ethically or morally, and even though this film is a little edgy, it is much for of a family film than the others in the series. Like a classic Christmas movie, everything goes wrong throughout, and its very entertaining. Todd and Margot are one of the funniest parts of this movie. Clark is funny as ever, and the whole family being under one roof is a great source of comedy. If you have not seen this movie, you are missing out.

Review-Title: Yuletide Hilarity Unleashed: A Heartwarming Review of National Lampoon's Christmas Vacation
Review-Description: National Lampoon's Christmas Vacation (1989) stands as a beacon of holiday cheer, earning a resounding 9/10 for its seamless blend of humor and heart. Chevy Chase's portrayal of the endearing yet bumbling Clark Griswold is nothing short of brilliant, providing the film with a magnetic center around which its comedic brilliance orbits. From start to finish, the movie is a rollercoaster of hilarious mishaps and outrageous scenarios, each scene more memorable than the last. The film's strength lies not only in its ability to induce side-splitting laughter but also in its underlying warmth and familial charm. Clark Griswold's determination to create the perfect family Christmas, despite the chaos that ensues, resonates with audiences of all ages. The script, a witty masterpiece, weaves together a tapestry of comedic genius. The jokes are not just humorous; they're timeless. Each viewing unveils new layers of humor, making it a perennial favorite that stands the test of time. The characters, from the eccentric relatives to the lovable dog, contribute to the film's enduring charm. What sets Christmas Vacation apart is its ability to capture the essence of the holiday spirit. Amid the comedic chaos, there's a palpable sense of love and togetherness. It reminds us that, despite the imperfections and unpredictable events that define our lives, the true magic of Christmas lies in the bonds we share with family. For anyone seeking a festive cinematic experience that transcends mere laughter, National Lampoon's Christmas Vacation is a must-watch. It not only elicits genuine guffaws but also tugs at the heartstrings, making it an indispensable addition to holiday traditions. So, gather the family, grab some popcorn, and let the Griswolds take you on a laughter-filled sleigh ride through the quirkiest Christmas ever.

A film that can be re-watched a few times and still be funny. Clark and the Griswalds are like every stereotypical American family during Christmas time, especially with the grumpy daughter and slightly troublesome son. The film is filled with comical comedy, largely lead by the father Clark Griswald and joined by his cousin in law Eddie when he shows up half way through the film as a surprise Christmas visit. The film is still filled with a few serious and touching moments such as Clark's work bonus for Christmas, and his care towards Eddies children making sure they get presents from Santa for Christmas. However, the film is largely represented by the comedy and some of it is golden to watch.

"National Lampoon's Christmas Vacation is a holiday classic that unwraps the gift of timeless comedy. The Griswold family's Christmas chaos, led by Chevy Chase's iconic Clark Griswold, is a festive rollercoaster of humor and heartwarming moments. From the disastrous tree selection to the over-the-top house decorations, each scene is a comedic masterpiece. The film captures the relatable madness of holiday preparations, making it a seasonal favorite. Chevy Chase's impeccable comedic timing and the ensemble cast's brilliant performances deliver a sleigh full of laughter. Amid the mayhem, the movie beautifully touches on the true spirit of Christmas, emphasizing family bonds and the importance of cherishing moments together. The quirky characters, memorable quotes, and slapstick comedy ensure that Christmas Vacation remains a cherished tradition for families, providing an enduring dose of holiday cheer. It's a must-watch that embodies the perfect blend of humor and heart, making it a festive feast for the whole family."

I watch this movie with the family every year in December before Christmas Eve. I must have seen this movie at least 15 times, and I'm still not tired of it. It is without a doubt the best Christmas movie, the best in the Vacation series, and the funniest. It's also one of my favorite comedies. The acting is good. The entire cast is fantastic. The dynamic is so good between all the actors/characters, but the best is Chevy Chase as Clark Griswold. I think there is a big difference compared to the other films. This movie is much better when it comes to acting, script, and humor. In this movie, the Griswold family does not go away on vacation. Instead, they stay at home and relatives come to their house to celebrate Christmas. That does not mean it will be less chaos, rather more. It escalates more and more, and Clark gets more and more crazy, which is so funny. Whatever he does, it ends up a disaster. He really tries, and you feel for him, while you just sit and laugh through the whole movie. Fantastic movie!

National Lampoon's Christmas Vacation is one of the best Christmas movies ever made, and beloved by many. I know people who have traditions in watching it, like an elderly friend who used to watch it on Christmas Eve before going to bed. The movie follows Clark Griswald (Chevy Chase) who hopes to have the perfect at home family Christmas. Unfortunately, a rodent in a tree, dry turkey, stapling lights to the house, being trapped in the attic, and an unexpected Christmas bonus is not what he had in mind. Christmas Vacation, as the movie is briefly called, is one of the funniest Christmas movies ever. This can be attriubited to John Hughes, who wrote the script, and who would write Home Alone a year later. There are many funny scenes in the movie, such as the ones mentioned above. The cast is also enjoyable- such as Chevy Chase, Beverly D'Angelo, Randy Quaid, Mae Questel (aka Betty Boop), Julia Louis-Dreyfus, Doris Roberts, and EG Marshall- who actually passed away the very day that I was born. Probably due to the PG-13 rating (which comes from some sexual humor and a single F-bomb near the end of the movie), I didn't see this as a kid. However, in the last maybe 8 or 9 years, I have seen it quite a few times- maybe 5 or so times. I know that this review is pretty short, but this would be best enjoyed without much more detail. Just go watch it and have fun- it's a blast.

Chevy Chase as Clark Griswald is determined to have a traditional family Christmas and of course everything that can go wrong, does. Family members including the disgusting Cousin Eddie and various grumpy parents turn up whilst Clark attempts to pull a perfect holiday together with the support of his despairing wife and children who know that stubborn Clark must deliver whatever the cost. There are amusing scenes in this to be sure, particularly near the beginning around Christmas trees and lights which are quite fun, but it all soon becomes clumsy, over the top and relies too much on the use of Chase whose show it is, almost to the exclusion of everyone else.
