In the end it's a Chevy Chase centred mess with few original ideas.

I remember liking this movie a bit when i was younger. However, after rewatching this today i can honestly say that i've never seen such a bad movie ever. It has NO story, everything is just incidents after incidents that are totally predictable. The only funny thing is some of the adult jokes... in the beginning. Then it becomes too much. I don't see the humor in a man in his 40s flirting with a 20yo in front of his son. I can't see the humor in ridiculing a poor family who lives in a trailer. I can't see how animal cruelty is funny?? It seems like the script was made in an hour- i feel like this could be an assignment made by some highschoolers in AV class. If you're wondering if it's worth spending 90 minutes watching this movie-- it's not. Spend it watching a movie with good characters, real humor, and some actual build-up stories. Or you'll sit there watching a movie with no connection to the characters and just annoyance.

I'm 12 and when I was eight I loved this movie and I still do! It's a Christmas classic and a masterpiece for what it is. It's one of the most famous Christmas movies if not the most famous Christmas movie. It's characters are great and it's funny as heck. The main character is famous, the dads famous, the bully is really famous and heck the lamp is the most famous out of them all! I love the scene with Santa and I really love the scene with the lamp because it's hilarious. If I had to pick the biggest downside it would be the bullys little brother kinda thought he was annoying. Parents not to much to say but there is one scene with a little blood, infrequent language, implied f word although it says fudge instead. A Christmas masterpiece and a classic. 8/10.

A Christmas Story was an amazing movie. A Christmas Story was a funny movie with lots of funny parts. This movie is an engaging movie with engaging characters. If Fffugde was replaced with the F word, then this movie would have been rated PG-13 ( or maybe R ). One thing I didn't understand was the two scenes after the scene when Ralphie had Christmas. It just didn't make sense to me why the existed. This movie was very similar to The Sandlot. The movies both had lots of mini stories in one movie and they were also set in the past. If you like the Sandlot, then I would reccomend this movie to you. What a great movie. In all, I would give this movie a 8.4 out of 10.

What can I say. The classic Christmas story. Everyone loves this move- how could you not. Every year I watch this film because it takes me back to my childhood. The innocence of the characters. The film is based around a young man who wants nothing for christmas but a bb gun, but all he hears from adults is that he will shoot his eye out! He goes through so many different schemes to try to get this done throughout the entire film. What I love about this film is the big focus on family and how everything is centered around him, his mom, dad and little brother. I love the traditional holiday values this film has.

Cult Cuts Volume 47 (A RETURN TO THE VIDEO STORE CHRISTMAS 3) #4/4: A Christmas Story (1983) (7/10): If I'm being completely honest here, I'm not as high on this one as others are. A Christmas Story follows young Ralphie who is in your more traditional family and he is trying to get his parents to get him a Red Ryder Range 200 Shot BB Gun for Christmas and is having no luck. He is living with the ordeals of your average everyday kid; getting in trouble, wildly active imagination and the school bully. He tries coming up with multiple ways to get his Red Ryder BB Gun from attempts at subliminal messages to writing his school paper on it to asking the big man for it but all seem fruitless, will his Christmas wish come true? So I know that this is THE CHRISTMAS MOVIE for many people, but I'm just not as high on it as others are, and I think it's an excellent example of just how expectations being high from hype, because, yeah I don't think I mentioned that this is my first time seeing it. Although I do want to say that I don't dislike it in the slightest, I just don't love it either. The costumes are wonderful and so is the set design, they are filled with Christmas joy and spirit. Both Ralphie and his younger brother are likable in their own ways and you get a genuine sense of a bond between the two of them in how Ralphie helps him out and his brother is genuinely worried that dad will do something bad to Ralphie after he finds out about the fight he had with the bully. You get a strong sense of a somewhat dysfunctional family that truly cares for one another at the end of the day. One thing that I found that also didn't help with my thoughts on it is that, for a Christmas comedy, I only laughed legitimately once, and that was at the end when they were having Chinese Turkey and the employees kept screwing up the carols due to their accent. Bob Clark did a fantastic job with his second Christmas film however I still prefer his first, I just like the less is more approach and also I do want to make it clear that it doesn't just get brownie points for being my favourite genre, but I'll get into why I like it much more when I cover it here pretty soon. A Christmas Story is a classic and deserving of its place but it is just not that much my kind of thing.

This film is absolutely hilarious EVERY TIME. There are a lot of really weird negative reviews. Take things too seriously much, people? Sheesh. Just relax. The movie is set in the 1940s and was made in the early 1980s. Both were different times. Humor was different. Special effects were different. The acting is delightfully, hopefully, deliriously over-the-top. The mom's facial expressions are glorious. Ralphie's dream of the fun is timeless-we've all had a similar want that we were told was bad for us. Randy is so funny-nothing better than the scene where he is all bundled up. And their dad is adorably daft. This movie isn't for everyone, I guess, but the excessive "analysis" (if one can call it that) is ridiculous.

We love a good Christmas film here, but this one seems to have passed us by until now. We watched it last night with a bottle of wine and really enjoyed it. Very funny in parts, and with a warm and affectionate atmosphere throughout, it knocks more modern efforts for six. Darren McGavin is on top form as Dad and in fact everyone is just great. I love the way everyone in town tells Ralphie he'll 'shoot his eye out' if he gets the BB gun for Christmas, and he very nearly does! And of coures there are the local trouble-causers who get their just rewards as must always be the case. If you haven't seen this, go get it.

A Christmas Story is one of the most beloved Christmas movies ever made, and rightfully so. It's funny, quotable, and simply so entertaining that it deserves the acclaim that it has had these last 40 years. The story being told is narrated by a man named Ralphie, who is reminiscing on the best Christmas he ever had- in which he desired a Red Ryder BB Gun more than anything. Unfortunately, his Mom, teacher, and even a mall Santa tell him no, because he'll shoot his eye out. In between Ralphie's quest to get his gun, there are iconic scenes in which a friend of his sticks his tongue to a frozen pole, Ralphie gets a bar of soap for swearing, his Dad wins a sexy lamp as an award, and more. These iconic scenes are part of the charm that the movie has. There are also famous quotes, like "You'll shoot your eye out", "Fra-jeel-ay...it must be Italian!", "Ovaltine? A crummy commercial?" and "I triple dog dare you!" But apart from famous lines and scenes, there is other merit to A Christmas Story as well. One prime example is the actors who do great work- Peter Billingsley as Ralphie, Darren McGavin as The Old Man, Melinda Dillon as Raphie's Mom, Scott Swartz as Flick, and so forth. There's more that I feel like sharing, but I am worried about spoiling too much of the plot. When I was really little, I was aware of this movie's existence and wanted to see it, but my Mom thought I was too young for it since it revolves around wanting a gun and it had quite a bit of swearing. Luckily, I have had plenty of time in my teen and adult years to see it, in fact I have now seen it over a dozen times- it's that enjoyable. If your kid is under 8, that may be a little young for them to see A Christmas Story. Otherwise, this would be a great movie for families. Even 4 decades later, this still manages to charm and entertain audiences, and there is good reason. It's a holiday treasure.

Seen this a thousand times and I'll watch it a thousand more, every year Xmas readily with my wife and boy, it's classic. A Xmas tale told through the eyes of a child and his one wish: a Red Ryder a BB gun. The build up to Xmas is filled with different plot points that mesh together beautifully, delivered by a fantastic cast of characters each with their own arcs and stories, truly one of the best Xmas movies ever. From the opening monologue to the ending scene you are transported back to a simpler time, filled with attention to detail and on location, this flick captures the essence of childhood innocence and Xmas miracles: Santa knows, Santa always knows.

40 years ago, humorist and storyteller Jean Shepherd's book In God We Trust: All Others Pay Cash was adapted for the screen in the form of A Christmas Story. While only a modest hit during its November 1983 release, the film would become a cult favorite over the years thanks to numerous television airings, thus leading to stage adaptations, a followup in 1994, two later day sequels in 2012 and 2022 respectfully, and a culturally significant place in the National Film Registry. So with this film having reached its 40th anniversary this year, its status remains more important than its overall quality. Now the story of youngster Ralphie Parker dreaming of his ideal Christmas gift, a "Red Ryder air rifle.", is a story many people can relate to when it comes to struggling to keep one's hopes intact. As Ralphie has to put up with his cranky dad's odd choices and disgruntlement from school enemies like his teacher and rival bully Scut Farkus, Shepherd, co-writer Leigh Brown and director Bob Clark incorporate a melancholy feel of childhood curiosity not often seen in films today. Admittedly, perhaps the film favors its humorous setups a bit too much from its main plot since the film can often lose momentum in going from one comedic / dramatic scene to another. Most of these scenes are intended to develop Ralphie to do better, especially around his doting mother and little brother Randy, but they merely serve their purpose to the point where it mainly feels like we're watching school lessons instead of a fully realized movie. Also, the addition of certain characters like Farkus and Ralphie's school friends aren't as impactful as they could have been, although it certainly isn't all about them. Perhaps where the film succeeds the most is in Ralphie's imaginative scenarios, complete with absurd acting and fast paced editing techniques. As ludicrous as they can get, they capture the imagination any child could have in interpreting what could happen to them before they experience something in reality. In contrast to Shepherd's humorous narration as grown up Ralphie looking back on most of the scenarios, Peter Billingsley brings young Ralphie to life through genuine emotion and sly wit, arguably more so than a lot of the other child actors who are nonetheless as funny to watch as they are obnoxious. The addition of holiday themed music and merchandising further adds to the overwhelming nature one can see around the Christmas season, whether in rural Indiana or somewhere else. Arguably more memorable than composers Paul Zaza and Carl Zittrer's original music, seeing adults and children throughout the film could make anyone watching feel welcome in the holiday spirit. As absurd as the film is conceptually, its heart is still in the right place. So while A Christmas Story's narrative doesn't flow all that well due to favoring its humor over its story, it nonetheless offers just enough charming performances, witty scenarios and heartfelt holiday cheer for some amusement. Unless you're fed up with all of the film's popularity, I would say check this out at least once this Christmas season. It's by no means for everybody, but it does capture the cherished and not so cherished memories of childhood that we often don't see in film that much anymore. Besides, it's not like you'll shoot your eye out by watching this movie or anything like that.

Last night, I went to see A Christmas Story, which celebrates its 40th anniversary this year, at my local theater. And I can tell you this: whether you see it on the big screen, or in the comforts of your own home (as me and my family have done for years), it is a wonderful movie! Set in the fictitious town of Hohman, Indiana at Christmastime 1940, A Christmas Story centers on 9-year-old Ralphie Parker (played by Peter Billingsley), who wants just one thing for Christmas: a Red Ryder carbine-action 200-shot Range Model air rifle. But everyone he talks about it to, from his mom (Melinda Dillon) to his teacher, to even Santa at Higbee's, gives him the same response: "You'll shoot your eye out." Thanks in part to writer Jean Shepherd's brilliant narration as adult Ralphie, the movie has fabulous worldbuilding, and really fleshes out all the characters; especially Ralphie and his family. One thing that makes this movie timeless is that Ralphie and his family and the people they interact with don't feel like old-fashioned people; they feel like people we know even now. In particular, the sibling energy between Ralphie and his little brother Randy (Ian Petrella) reminds me of how my older brother and I acted toward each other as kids. Likewise, the acting is brilliant in this movie! As Ralphie, Peter Billingsley demonstrates remarkable talent, even for the age of 9. Ian Petrella plays Randy like the most realistic 6-year-old you'd ever meet in your life. But the two that stand out are Melinda Dillon and Darren McGavin (may he rest in peace) as Ralphie's parents. Their back-and-forth is truly magical. Darren McGavin, in particular is hilarious as Ralphie's old man. The movie also has a fabulous script, comedy and such memorable scenes and quotes. The banters between Ralphie's two best friends, Flick (Scott Schwartz) and Schwartz (R. D. Robb), are super entertaining, especially the scene where Flick is triple-dog dared by Schwartz to stick his tongue on the school flagpole, goes through with it, and ends up with a bandaged tongue. There's also the storyline regarding the old man's "major award", the famous leg lamp. Other highlights include Ralphie getting a bar of soap in his mouth for saying a dirty word ("Ohhhhhh, ffffffuuuuuuuudge!" "Only I didn't say fudge." HA!), the old man beating on the faulty furnace while swearing in gibberish, Ralphie's melodramatic fantasies, Ralphie beating bully Scut Farkus (Zack Ward) senseless while cursing up a storm, and let's NOT forget the truly brilliant scene of Ralphie visiting Higbee's Santa. That is indeed, as Roger Ebert said, the best department store Santa visit ever captured on film! And whenever we get a Christmas tree every year, my brother and I always quote the Christmas tree salesman: "Now, HERE'S a tree! This here is a TREE!" And last but not least, there's the music. True to form, Paul Zaza and Carl Zittrer wove some classic Christmas tunes into this movie's score. They also perfectly chose all the songs to use! All in all, A Christmas Story is a fabulous Christmas movie that will never age! In fact, I consider it one of THE movies to watch around Christmastime!

How the grinch stole Christmas would be utter rubbish without Jim carrey as the rest of the film is not the best. (If you complain about the town or characters looking weird that is how dr Seuss would have wanted it. The story is just the book and is represented well with a good explanation at why the grinch hates everything about Christmas. Sadly the rest of the film is not the best as annoying characters like Cindy Lou who kind of ruin the film. Overall How the grinch stole Christmas would never be any better rated because it feels cheap for some reason. That is why this film held up by a Jim Carey masterclass is a. 7/10 = good fun filled Christmas film.

Although you may not believe it, 23 years after this movie was made, I had never seen it, obviously I knew about the character but I only knew that he hated Christmas. I didn't really know the true meaning of the movie, and I think we've all been the Grinch at some point, especially given how the world is today. If it strikes me how 23 years later the film still has the same meaning, how the true meaning of Christmas is forgotten and how it has become a commercial era, a superficial era, based on consumerism. Taylor Momsen really plays a very good character, she and the Grinch with the soul of the film, without forgetting Max too, Cindy reminds us of the innocence of children, without malice, they see the good side of people, always obviously being a reflection From the upbringing that has been given, she reminds us that everyone deserves to be accepted, that everyone deserves to be accompanied at Christmas. I liked knowing the story of the Grinch, about his childhood, about how bullying caused him consequences. Although it is a film whose target audience is children, it really generates a lot of reflection. For the time, the makeup and costumes were spectacular, they won an Oscar for a reason. And Jim Carrey's performance as the Grinch is very good. I think it is a film that as one grows or depending on the stage of life in which one sees it, it will generate a different meaning and reflection.

Adapting Dr. Seuss' classic holiday children's book, How the Grinch Stole Christmas brings the not-so jolly green giant to the big screen. Giving a deeper backstory to the characters and some additional elements to the story, we get a more connected journey, with a lot of heart. Jim Carrey creates one of his most iconic roles, as the Grinch's quirkiest qualities are accentuated in some of the most entertaining ways. A lot of the comedy still holds up, but some of the jokes fall flat with time and remind you that this is a children's film. Whoville stuns with a spectacularly adorable town, looking as if it were directly ripped from a Dr. Seuss story and put on the screen. Accompanied by the delightfully wonderful 'Where Are You Christmas?', the infectious holiday cheer will follow you long after you've watched this movie. Dr. Seuss' How the Grinch Stole Christmas will always remain a holiday must-watch and, even with its imperfections, it reminds us that the deeper qualities are what matter most.

Title: "The Grinch - Christmas is Stolen" IMDb: 6.3
Metascore: 4.6
User Rating: 6.5
Rotten Tomatoes: 4.9
User Rating: 5.8 Average: 5.6 Genre:
 Family Christmas Fantasy Comedy Financial Success The film is an adaptation of the 1957 book of the same name, starring Jim Carrey as the Grinch, a green monster residing atop a mountain near the town of Whoville. A family-oriented Christmas fantasy with a touch of comedy, Jim Carrey carries the film, though his experience in the Grinch costume was reportedly dreadful. Director Ron Howard strives for the stylized chaos of Frank Tashlin and Tim Burton but leans more towards the visually overwhelming style of Joel Schumacher's Batman movies. He pits Carrey against the grotesque rat-faced mole-people of Whoville. The plot is present but not particularly strong.

"How the Grinch Stole Christmas" is a timeless classic that continues to captivate audiences of all ages. Dr. Seuss' whimsical tale comes to life with enchanting animation, heartwarming moments, and a valuable message about the true meaning of Christmas. The Grinch's journey from a holiday cynic to discovering the joy of giving is beautifully depicted, and the iconic narration by Boris Karloff adds a magical touch. This festive film is a must-watch during the holiday season, delivering laughter, warmth, and the spirit of Christmas in abundance. Jim Carrey, Taylor Momsen, Christine Baranski and Jeffrey Tambor are all simply amazing!

This is such an amazing performance by Jim Carry. The film is nostalgic and without the comedy why would there be need to make this movie? If you like the cartoon stick to that. This movie is so underrated and the costume and make up is outstanding! Lots of feels when I see this movie every year for the holidays. All the negative reviews are from boomers who are very vanilla and have no flavor. It's a cute movie and recommend for those who need a laugh, a time to feel nostalgia, and to bring Christmas cheer into your spirits. Lots of great memories made with this film. I imagine Seuss would appreciate the performance and storyline.

This movie is a masterpiece. Jim Carreys performance as the Grinch is iconic. The set pieces are so incredible that there's still being replicated at universal studios The use of practical effects and prosthetics is just amazing. I really not sure what kind of person wouldn't like this movie, unless you're a greedy CEO type that hates the idea of people diminishing the value of blatant commercialism in holiday spirit. Our family's holiday season is just not complete without a viewing of this Christmas classic. Although I'm not really one for musical numbers, I also find several of the original pieces in this movie to be very well done.

Review-Title: A fun affair for the kids
Review-Description: Now in no way am I dissing this Movie. First up, Carrey is undeniably fantastic in the title role and I really struggle to see who else could have played the part better. The costumes look amazing and are undeniably Suess. For me the reason I have only scored 6 is that I find Suess to be quite difficult to get on board with. I appreciate it for what it is . But don't quite have the attraction to it that it seems to demand from an enormous following. I think my biggest gripe is that the beauty of Suess is the clever writing and rhyming and this seems to take second place in the live action affair. Don't get me wrong it's a well made family flick and I'd suggest younger kids will love it. It just isn't high on the list for me when it comes to the xmas watchlist. A middle of the road attempt which remains enjoyable without being captivating.

Me and my family have only the best memories surrounding the Grinch. First in the animated class when I was a small child and than this fantastic version with Jim. It made my childhood memories complete and I know it did for my brother Erik too. We just felt genuinely connected to Dr. Seuss through this movie and also the cartoon movie. Jim Carrey really brought to life The Grinch and his stubborn mean heart, but how it could love once again and I think that happens to a lot of us in our hearts! It's the story of renewal and forgiveness. It's amazing God's love. Just remember we were ok born on Earth in order to LOVE GOD.

It's hard to find anything good about this lousy remake of Boris Karloff's beloved take on Dr. Suess' Grinch. Jim Carrey's over-acting and near duplication of his character in "The Mask" is painful to watch. The make-up used to create the Whos is simply grotesque and conjurs nothing of the whimsy of Dr. Suess' imagination stimulating artwork. Rather, it is more reminiscent of plastic surgery gone horribly wrong. The plot takes a decidedly political turn by ignoring the original innocence and moral steadfastness of Suess' Whos. Instead, the story is turned on end with the Whos presented as self-serving capitalists drowning in their over-consumption. Bottom line: this version of The Grinch is a far cry from the original, and more the stuff of nightmares than visions of sugar plums. Bag the remake and enjoy the original for a warm Christmastide tale of love and redemption.

Alexander Payne's 'The Holdovers' is a modern Christmas classic. An up to no good student, a strict and miserable teacher, and a grieving cook, are all stuck together in the school district for the entirety of the Christmas break in which they are forced to sleep, eat, and spend time together. This movie is about socializing, coming together with people, and most importantly, the fact that it is much better to love than to hate and a lot of us need to learn that. Whilst there is a lot more to this movie when it comes to the deeper meaning, I like to think of it as a visual representation as to why we should love and not hate. It's too often that we come to hate others when we don't even give ourselves a chance to love them. Alexander Payne did a wonderful job with this film. Though it is not the most original, the way he presents actions, words, even outside of the actors, it is very refreshing and unique and gives a feeling of originality and gives the feeling every classic does. No scene is wasted and Payne makes sure that each scene progresses the plot or delves further into each character in one way or another. Payne makes this film very heartwarming despite majority of it being conflict and arguing. The screenplay, whilst not completely and totally original, has a charm to it that any classic Christmas movie should and does have. The way each character is treated and how they treat each other creates a dynamic not only for the film but for the audience as well. Each scene brings us something new but also something that we are familiar with and it gives us comfort whilst also taking us out of our seat and not letting us get bored. Something I also love about the screenplay is the ending which is not left completely neat and perfect and only leaves the audience just satisfied enough to be content with it. And the fact that this film is far from predictable is brilliant as well, there came many times where I thought of one common and predictable way the next scene or sequence could go about and the screenplay would head in a totally different direction. The performances are all great, each do their fair share and each deliver exactly what and how they need to. Paul Giamatti specifically is brilliant in this film, the way he handles his characters temper, lack of emotions, and moods, is terrific. All is very well handled when it comes to the performances. The cinematography and production design only further develop the Christmas charm and warmth of the film. The production design gives a very grand feel at times whilst also keeping it realistic and down to earth with what was in any 1970s school. The visuals are not showy, nothing out of this world, and nothing to specifically catch the eye except for what it is representing for the film. I don't believe the cinematography needed to be necessarily special because the film is special enough as it is and that's the eye catching it has. The Christmas and warm feel that this film is translates through the visuals and production design and that's all that is really needed. The Holdovers most definitely deserves a watch and rewatch at that. A brilliant film about overcoming hate for love.

Heartworming, cosy and right movie for the period of the year. Nice story, believeble characters, very nice atmosphere amd excellent performance. Although I celebrate Ortodox Christmas, it was nice seeing this Catholic Christmas and New Year story and I have really enjoyed it. Heartworming, cosy and right movie for the period of the year. Nice story, believeble characters, very nice atmosphere amd excellent performance. Although I celebrate Ortodox Christmas, it was nice seeing this Catholic Christmas and New Year story and I have really enjoyed it. Heartworming, cosy and right movie for the period of the year.

The Holdovers was a near perfect film for me. The perfect film for the whole entire family to watch during the Holidays. Paul Giamatti puts on an outstanding performance here and how he interacts with the students that he has to watch over is bith comedic and serious. This movie is a comedy drama and balances everything very nicely. I think what works best in this film is the chemistry between all of the characters and the situations they find themselves in. Also the dialogue is very sharp here and is a standout in this movie. I would say that the Holdovers is one of the top movies of 2023. The Holdovers gets a near perfect 9 stars out of 10 from me.

This will put you in the mood of true Christmas nostalgia! Giamatti is Giamatti but Da' Vine Joy is truly a theatrical gem. Brilliantly executed from beginning to end. Memories of watching the classics during the holidays when we had Beta VHS. Love to walk away from cinema feeling a flood of emotions and this one never disappoints. "There's nothing new in human experience Mr. Tully! Each generation thinks it invented debauchery or suffering or rebellion, but man's every impulse and appetite from the disgusting to the sublime is on display right here all around you. ...If you truly want to understand the present of yourself, you must begin in the past."

Review-Title: Novice film writer knows how to create a beautiful film from a well-known concept thanks to good acting.
Review-Description: The Holdovers is a new drama comedy directed by Alexander Payne, director of About Schmidt and The Descendants. In 1970, history teacher Paul Hunham (Paul Giamatti) stays at school during the Christmas holidays. Here he is with some staff and students, who have nowhere else to go during the holidays. Paul tries to keep order among the people at school. After a few days, he is left alone with student Angus Tully (Dominic Sessa) and chef Mary Lamb (Da'Vine Joy Randolph). During their isolating state, the three get to know each other well. In this way they try to help each other with their problems and past. This entire film was shot in real practical locations of a school in Fairhaven, Massachusetts, during a holiday so the school was empty. For example, no film sets or soundstages were used for this film. This gives the film a realistic look and feel while watching. Writer David Hemingson, who is better known as a writer of various TV series, has managed to write a good story with this story. He uses well-known concepts where different characters unintentionally end up together, but knows how to incorporate the characters well into the film. During the film, the characters get to know each other better and discover what bothers them or what they love. Together they try to help each other with their passions or annoyances. As a viewer, you sympathize more and more with the characters as you learn more about them. What also makes you care about the characters is the acting of the three actors in the film. Paul Giamatti comes across well as a more grumpy loner, but throughout the film you learn why his character has become this way and that there is still a good and kind person inside him. Da'Vine Joy Randolph's character also has her mysterious storylines, but serves more as someone who tries to maintain order and balance between a grumpy teacher and problematic student. This was only Dominic Sessa's first acting role, but this is not reflected in his performance in the film. He may not have known how to use a rotary telephone, but this is more due to his young age. He also knows how to deliver heart-warming acting for characters with a less than ideal past. Together the three actors know how to provide good acting, characters that you as a viewer start to care about and empathize with more and more during the film.

Review-Title: Fantastic attention to a time period
Review-Description: The performance in this from Giamatti is outstanding. However, what really captivated me was the atmosphere of the time period. It is EXCEPTIONALLY rare in 2023/24 to see a historical-based film that adheres to the actual time period it is depicting. That alone gained a couple star here. The entire film "feels" like the 1960/70s. It isn't littered with altered dialog to conform to current social demands.. it come across as an honest portrayal of the time period - which few productions even attempt today. Overall the film is a slow grind about a relationship. It's entirely human interest. While I was engaged the entire film, and don't regret spending the time to watch this, it's not something overly memorable on the whole. But still.. it's worth watching if you are in the mood for a relatively subtle feel-good story. The biggest downside for me was the soundtrack.... it seemed honest to the time period - being more "soft rock" or "lazy stoner" tunes of the time period, nothing which conveys any excitement or interest.. more somber music in general. You know, the type of music that makes one think the performer may be half asleep or loaded up on mood suppressors. But, admittedly, I may have noticed it more because I find such music mildly irritating. So minus a couple stars because there's no repeat viewing aspect or takeaway memory from the film. And minus another due to the morose soundtrack.

Review-Title: A new Christmas movie for those so inclined
Review-Description: I tend to avoid holiday movies due to a troubled upbringing as they always make me sad. I really didn't know that this was a holiday movie or at least I hadn't thought it through since it takes place around Christmas and a, duh, Christmas school break. So there I was in the midst of this movie when it suddenly hit me it was a Christmas movie! In any event it's a nice movie with a nice cast of three individuals played by the always good Paul Giamatti as a disliked teacher, the strong film debut of Dominic Sessa as a disliked student and Da'Vine Joy Randolph who is just about guaranteed an Oscar for this when the nominations and awards come out in the coming months. She plays the school's head cook stuck with the other two over the Christmas holidays. This is primarily about the sour relationship between the teacher and student growing warmer and warmer and both learning how to be better people. Alexander Payne is a fine director and writer, though he did not write this somewhat manipulative piece and I wish he had. It might have been a bit more sharp than sentimental. Still, it's good and there are many who will appreciate this a lot.

Review-Title: Two hours of my life I will never be able to regain!
Review-Description: How this movie gets such a high rating is beyond me. The dialog is poor. The story is as boring as can be. I feel this movie could have been condensed into a 5 minute short. There is literally no character building. The acting is sub standard. By all. In fact I feel the timing between the actors seems forced. Let me break down my thoughts on some of the characters. The Kountz character was idiotic. I am still wondering if that was suposed to be the humour in the show but what the hell. The young Korean chap peeing in his bed was SO badly dealt with. Including the completely unconvincing empathy from Tully. As for Tully, why on earh do movie producers cast actors who look wayyy too old for their roles? His role/acting left much to be desired. This is not a cming of age movie. It is a dreary, lacklustre waste of time!

Paul Hunham is teaching at an exclusive boys school, Barton Academy. It is set in the late 1969-70, and the students are mainly privileged sons of wealthy parents, and often spoiled. Paul teaches ancient history, and is well versed. But he is not a people person. He doesn't change with the times, and as a result is disliked by his students and the other teachers. Yes, he is terrified of losing his job. He gives his students no slack, which is difficult for the school, as those parents expect their sons to get an easy ride to top universities, so they can avoid the draft. It is the time of the war in Vietnam and the draft, and keeping in college means keeping out of the military. There is the regular Holiday break, but a handful of students can't leave, so Paul is set to be the 'babysitter' and one especially difficult student is Angus Tully. Tully has been expelled from three other schools and the next step for him is a military school. Paul expects to run the holiday as if it were a regular school period, which becomes even harder when all but Tully get a chance to leave. With them is Mary, the school cook and a black woman whose son was recently killed in Vietnam. And she loves cigarettes. So together these three stranded persons have to deal with each other, and they have their own set of problems. And how that can work out is really the heart of the movie, and very human.

This was the perfect movie to watch during the holidays. I found all three main characters, Paul Hunham, Angus Tully, and Mary Lamb really fascinating. At first the movie starts with what feels like a teen drama, focusing on the interpersonal issues between Tully and the other holdovers, but this shifts when the rest of the crew are invited to on a ski trip and leave the punishing experience of Hunham's supervision quickly. This leaves behind Mary, Tully, and Hunham, who then form a sort of family between them. Hunham shows compassion and then bravey for standing up for Tully, and truly transforms as a character into someone I would love to follow their story. The cinematography is lovely, pacing is good, and plotline is easy-to-follow and feels natural. Would definitely recommend this one!

I watch this film every Christmas Eve and it is not only a great Christmas film, it is one of my favourite films of all time. Wallace and Davis meet the Haynes sisters and by twist of fate end up in a Vermont ski lodge owned by their old army General. There is no snow so they decide to help out by bringing their show there. Through a series of misunderstandings and mishaps there is a brilliant love story. Will there be a white Christmas by the end? Watch and find out. The musical numbers are so much fun and the comedy is brought by Danny Kaye. Harmless and brilliant fun, this film makes me feel really Christmassy every time I watch it.

Review-Title: Saved from Oblivion by One Song
Review-Description: Sentimental feelgood Christmas-themed comedies, so common today, were surprisingly thin on the ground in the fifties, even though there had been quite a few during the forties. (Hollywood evidently felt that people needed cheering up during and immediately after the war). "White Christmas" is one of the few exceptions. It borrows its title from that of a song in one of those forties films, "Holiday Inn". It is not, however, a remake of the earlier film, although both feature that song and both have the same star, Bing Crosby. During my childhood, my grandparents and others of their generation were always harping on the "fact" that in their younger days winters were much colder and summers much hotter, a "fact" which probably derived more from selective memory than it did from an accurate study of meteorological records. The song shows that nostalgia for the extreme weather of one's younger days was going strong even in the forties and fifties; frustrated by the mild winters of the present day, the singer can only dream of white Christmases like those he knew and enjoyed at some unspecified time in the past. So how do you make a film out of this concept? Bob Wallace and Phil Davis are two wartime army pals who after the war team up as a song-and-dance team. They decide to spend one Christmas in Vermont with their girlfriends, two sisters named Betty and Judy, and find that the hotel where they are staying is owned by their former commanding officer, General Tom Waverly. Waverly's hotel is not doing well, and he needs a successful Christmas season in order to stay in business. Unfortunately, however, the tourists are staying away because Vermont has been hit by unseasonably warm weather. Bob and Phil decide to stage a show at the hotel for the General's benefit and put out an appeal for all their old Army comrades to come and watch it. Finally, Bob belts out a chorus of "White Christmas" and- SPOILER ALERT!- Vermont is covered by a white blanket as the snow falls. And that's really it. It's not much of a plot, something that was commented on by a number of leading critics at the time, even though the film was a box-office success. (It was the biggest-grossing film of 1954). It was even commented on by Fred Astaire, Crosby's co-star in "Holiday Inn", who was offered the part of Phil but turned it down because he didn't like the script. The part then went to Donald O'Connor, and finally to Danny Kaye after O'Connor was taken ill. Crosby and Kaye were both talented comics, but the film doesn't really allow them much scope to demonstrate this side of their talents. Like "Holiday Inn", the film includes a "minstrel number", but unlike the equivalent scene in the earlier film this is not performed in blackface; perhaps people were starting to have doubts about this practice as early as 1954. The song-and-dance side of the film is rather better, with some well choreographed numbers showing off the talents of Kaye and Vera-Ellen. Vera-Ellen joins forces with Rosemary Clooney to perform "Sisters", probably the film's second-best-known song. (Vera-Ellen's voice was dubbed; she was hired mostly for her dancing talents). As for the title song itself, I must admit that I've never really liked it. (Too sentimental for my tastes). Nevertheless, I must admit that it has become a great favourite of many people, so much so that it has become a sort of secular Christmas carol, played endlessly on the radio (and on every shop's muzak track) every Yuletide. Indeed, it is probably this song which ensures that "White Christmas" the movie, which otherwise might have sunk without trace into oblivion, still turns up at least once during the television Christmas schedules every year. 5/10.

Review-Title: One of the best movies ever!
Review-Description: One of the best Christmas movies ever released! Great cast, music, dance, and a great storyline. I don't know if it's a spinoff from Holiday Inn, but they are both similar, with some of the same cast and music set 12 years apart. Very typical of show business people sadly deserting, changing, or leaving partners without notice and hurting each other only to forgive them as though nothing happened. For a Christmas story, it amazingly plays well. The snow showing up on Christmas eve was an important part of the movie, but it wasn't as important as the movie made it out to be except to the title song. Still, they don't make good Christmas movies like this anymore or good movies at all! It would be nice if someone designed a new movie around a good movie like this, in order to produce a real, well-produced movie again for a new America without good productions.

Christmas doesn't begin for me until White Christmas is on. This movie is one of my all-time favorites! Even if it's not Christmas. You can't beat the songs and Bing Crosby and Rosemary Clooney's voices, the actors, dancing of Danny Kaye and Vera Miles, or the touching story line. The scenery is beautiful from the opening in the camp behind the battle lines to the final snow falling setting. Edith Head is a masterful, as always in her costume creations, right down to Danny Kaye's blue dancing shoes on the bridge and masterful design to flatter all four of the main characters builds and still keep the outfits matching.

I'm a sucker for old movies. This ain't one of them. Bing Crosby seemed tired and old. Danny Kaye seemed to be trying to make up for Bing's lacklustre performance. The ladies did their best (I guess??). Was this a musical or a dance movie? Awful on both counts. What was with the dancing scene in purple? I get they are trying to showcase the dances but ???? Why? The story is flimsy, no chemistry with any of the characters. Steer clear and go to Its a Wonderful life instead. That movie has heart and a proper story. Maybe even check out Diehard. At least that has a more believable storyline. What a total disappointment of a movie.

This is my all-time favorite movie for the holidays. I used to watch it with my mom every year at Christmas time, usually several times through the season. I try to see it every year at Christmas time. Unfortunately, I'm stuck living in my vehicle, and don't have access to it. I wish it was available on Disney+ or Hulu, instead of only on Netflix. I'm also having a hard time finding it on DVD in stores. Hoping I can find a way to see it this year. My mom made it a tradition in our home growing up, I just want to keep that tradition going. It's a great movie, I hope it gains in popularity with the younger generations.

Review-Title: Probably my least favourite Christmas film
Review-Description: I fail to understand why White Christmas is still regarded as a classic. The storyline, about 2 ex-army men who team up to perform a Christmas show at a ski lodge, is hardly interesting, engaging or even festive. I've watched many classic Christmas films in my long life including Elf, Home Alone, It's a Wonderful Life, Miracle on 34th Street, Polar Express, and A Christmas Carol, to name a few. They are all way superior, entertaining and festive, whereas White Christmas is saddled with a weak plot that just never gets off the ground. Why is a show about putting on a show regarded as entertainment is beyond me! The whole plot in fact is so tedious I find it hard to maintain any interest every time I try to watch this. It is a truly boring snooze fest. I guess it probably means a lot more to those who grew up watching this from a very young age. I am also guessing it means a lot more to Americans than anyone growing up or living outside the USA. As for the title White Christmas, I think the makers should be sued under the Trade Descriptions Act. There's hardly any snow to be seen until the last few minutes. Unless 'white' actually means something else. Just saying.

Danny Kaye is much the more natural here as he ("Phil") and successful partner "Bob" (Bing Crosby) hook up with the aspiring sister-act team of "Betty" (Rosemary Clooney) and "Judy" (Vera-Ellen). The latter pair have a gig at a remote Vermont inn, and so after some shenanigans on a train they all arrive to discover it is run by the gents' former wartime CO "Gen. Waverly" (Dean Jagger). Determined to come to the aid of this decent and proud man, they concoct a scheme to quite literally rally the troops! The gist of the plot is one of loyalty and integrity, but there is plenty of daft comedy interspersed to keep the whole thing from becoming too earnest or sentimental. The dance numbers are expertly choreographed and the musical numbers from Irving Berlin including the belters "Sisters" (with a little help from Gloria Wood) and "Blue Skies" keep the toes tapping too... It's a cheery, gentle romantic comedy that puts a smile on your face and reinforces any faith in the human spirit that might need topping up. I always found Crosby a little too slick on screen, but Kaye and Clooney are great and though perhaps just a shade too long, it's still an enjoyable seasonal romp, well worth a watch with some mulled wine and the odd chocolate Santa.

Review-Title: I get the rep, if not the appeal
Review-Description: Real head-scratcher, this one. It'd be easy to write off "White Christmas" for just the songs (none of which are my cup of tea) but one thing jumped out on this particular rewatch: is this really a Christmas movie? The only reason there's snow is that they've booked a gig in Vermont in December; Bing sings the title song a couple of times, they throw on the festive red costumes and call it a day. I mean no disrespect to this movie. Its place in the annals of history and Christmas tradition are assured, and nothing I say is gonna change that. It's an American institution at this point. And I may be left completely cold by the music, dancing and performances, but damn if the colors don't pop off the screen. That Technicolor worked wonders.

If they ever have a local production of White Christmas, I could step into just about any role. LOL I've been watching it annually for at least 40 years, through TV broadcasts, VHS, DVD, and now Bluray. And I've got to tell you, if you've never seen this on Bluray it's an utterly different experience ... sharp and gorgeous. Danny Kaye gets some of my favorite lines ever in a movie, especially in the early scene where they're packing to leave on the train. He's also got my favorite dance number, outside the club where the sisters were performing ... "The Best Things Happen While You're Dancing". Another favorite, later in the film, is "Count Your Blessings". Of course, the movie begins and ends with the megahit, best-selling song of all time, White Christmas. Fantastic movie.

Review-Title: Could've had a clearer and meaningful ending
Review-Description:
Could've used more substance
The movie was eerie and scary at times but it could have shown more of the dreams. The ending was messy it could have been better I am not one of those the ending has to be happy ones but still it could've ended with more of dream ads. This film, directed by the Norwegian director Kristoffer Borgli, is a comedy/horror/fantasy with an outlandish, and thought-provoking story. The life of a hapless middle-aged university professor is upended when he starts to appear in many strangers' dreams. He savours his star status thanks to these dreams while they eventually turn into nightmares which leads his life to completely different turns. This film's Charlie Kaufman-esque world is so intriguing and captivating. Borgli's unorthodox screen play has so many layers to unpack and raises many questions. Firstly, this makes us wonder if dreams can reveal our subconscious minds and what are the underlining messages of having somebody in the dreams. This film can also be seen as commenting on how instant fame impacts on people. Paul Matthews, played by Nicolas Cage, embraces this fame with enthusiasm despite his unawareness of the reasons of his fame. His responses in a TV interview clearly demonstrate his attitude to fame. Do we embrace our sudden celebrity status with a similar attitude? Additionally, this film suggests that Paul's self-righteousness and egoism lead him to enjoy this illusional ungrounded instant fame. Interestingly, this film could be a satire of our pervasive society trends of social media influencers without distinctive skills and cancel culture. Trent, played by Michael Cera, underpins the insanity and absurdity of the movement. The irony of this is that the audience fuels these trends. Nicholas Cage is commendable as Paul Matthew, an invisible university professor with the feeling of desperation to publish his book and mounting jealousy with his colleague's success. His acting is so convincing, hilarious, and at times shamelessly cringy. In particular, Cage successfully showcased his anger, shame and frustration with humour in this film. Cage's performance makes us invest into Paul Matthew's character, despite his supercilious attitude. This film is highly entertaining with many dream sequences and funny moments. My partner and I kept discussing it over dinner after the screening.

Review-Title: A Cagey Satire That Loses Its Way
Review-Description: Dream Scenario is a movie that explores the bizarre phenomenon of a biology professor who appears in everyone's dreams, and the consequences of his unwanted fame. The movie is a satire of the modern culture of celebrity, social media, and cancel culture, as well as a commentary on the human psyche and the power of dreams. The movie's strongest asset is Nicolas Cage, who delivers a brilliant performance as the professor who is both fascinated and terrified by his situation. Cage plays the role with a mix of innocence, curiosity, and desperation, as he tries to understand why he is in everyone's dreams and how to escape the nightmare. He is also very funny, especially in the scenes where he awkwardly interacts with his dreamers, or when he tries to use his fame to his advantage. The movie's weakest point is its lack of coherence and explanation. The movie never reveals why the professor is in everyone's dreams, or what causes the dreams to turn violent. The movie also jumps from one genre to another, from comedy to horror to thriller, without a clear direction or tone. The movie tries to tackle too many topics and themes, such as fame, identity, morality, science, religion, politics, and more, but it does not develop them enough or connect them well. Dream Scenario is a movie that has a lot of potential and originality, but it also has a lot of flaws and confusion. It is a movie that will make you laugh, think, and wonder, but it will also leave you unsatisfied and frustrated. It is a movie that is worth watching for Cage's performance, but it is not a movie that will stay in your dreams for long.

The plot is very interesting! I have done nothing but you can see me in the dream! And I am just a passerby and did nothing! The appearance of Nicolas is so amazed and his act is still good ( oh he is a Oscar award winner), and as a normal man he was suddenly so famous because everyone see him in the dream! But everything comes to an end, where after contacting the young lady, everyone hates him as he killed them inside! He felt so upset as he did nothing wrong indeed! At last there is no happy ending as he needs to divorce and went to another, and there is no explanation why this happened. Not a good way to end the story in my view...

At his manic best. I agree with others , every other year he produces an outing of this magnitude and this could well be his biggest shot at gongs since Leaving Las Vegas. He cuts a weary figure with the world with his pursuit of literary status and perceives that his peers are undermining his progress. The make up and costume are particularly impressive, right down to the bald pate. When the plot of the title starts to unravel, the horror and comedic nuances work really well, but it's not the main crux and it's very well done to shift it in an unexpected direction . I'm particularly pleased that the vaults ( regards the strikes ) have opened up and released gems like this.

Review-Title: A touch of "A dream play" wth current references
Review-Description: A movie with Freddy Kruger references, how dreams and nightmares has an impact to its extreme in current real life. It is refreshing to watch a movie who uses its theme to discuss the different stages and consequences of fame without making it corny and educational (like most of Netflix-productions do...) Great acting and directing. The ending was loosing its purpose. It made me wonder why the writers didn't choose to explain the dream scenarios and instead focused on the main characters fate. But during my reflection I came to my conclusion that we don't need an explanation of the scenarios thus the movies theme. I now realized that I want to see more of how the main character coped with the situation who was established in the film and how he accepted his fate. Unfortunately, it made me pity him even more. The script could absolutely have been extended for about 15 minutes. Overall, a worth watching movie with great actors, plot, directing. Up-to-date references to our consumption of pop culture and social media with a touch of Strindbergs "A dream play". However the ending was a bit rushed and didnt seem well thought out.

A surprising blend of dark-comedy and psychological-horror defined this Nicolas Cage movie in which he played a humble family man named Paul Matthews who somehow ended up appearing in the dreams of several million people. There was no rhyme or reason behind how that was even possible, and yet Paul was where he shouldn't possibly be. One thing led to another and his newfound fame stopped being the stuff of dreams (quite literally). Instead, things gradually transformed into nightmares for everyone dreaming about him. From perceived insecurity and inherent trauma, to full-blown cancel culture followed by a witch hunt, "Dream Scenario" contained a wealth of sub-text worth appreciating. There was some interesting irony behind Paul teaching a class on Zebra fur-pattern evolution and how people dreaming about him doing them harm gradually grew into a "human herd instinct" fear. This was yet another rare and risky role for Nicolas Cage, but one that he elevated with a flawless performance. His acting in "Dream Scenario" further entrenched Cage's prowess as a brilliant cross-genre artist. A generous helping of Science-Fiction tropes and a good bit of dark-comedy blended with classic horror-genre elements to make "Dream Scenario" a recipe for filmmaking excellence. It could've gone wrong in so many ways, and yet it took all the right twists to deliver a sharp and relatable story that was equally bizarre and entertaining. I liked how they didn't just stick to the dream-scapes at the heart of this plot but also veered into Paul's psyche as a person. They captured his human side, covering his uncertainties and disappointments, including in relation to his work as an evolutionary biology professor. "Dream Scenario" went on to redefine creepy, but in a good way. The suspense was spot on. Moreover, the movie didn't feel like a clich√©, though it very well could have. I loved everything about it, including Nicolas Cage's nuanced performance as Paul Matthews, the one guy nobody would think to dream about, yet millions of random people consistently did, and how the real-life Paul became the villain in their dreamed-up stories.

Review-Title: A waking nightmare worth diving into
Review-Description: Nicolas Cage is back, this time not battling bees or stealing Declaration of Independences but facing a much weirder threat: becoming everyone's nocturnal best friend. In Dream Scenario, Cage plays Paul Matthews, a man whose face suddenly starts popping up in millions of strangers' dreams, turning him into an overnight sensation. At first, it's all sunshine and rainbows-talk show appearances, lucrative endorsements, even a fan club of sleepwalkers. But as the line between reality and dreams blurs, Paul's dream-self morphs into a grotesque, cannibalistic monster, and his waking life becomes a waking nightmare. Director Kristoffer Borgli crafts a film that's equal parts hilarious and horrifying, a twisted satire on the fleeting nature of fame and the dark underbelly of the internet age. Think Being John Malkovich meets Inception with a dash of Twilight Zone, and you'll get a taste of the bizarre brilliance that is Dream Scenario. Cage, as always, is a force of nature, inhabiting his role with gusto and delivering deadpan lines with a wink and a raised eyebrow. He's perfectly cast as the bewildered common person thrust into the limelight; his comedic timing is impeccable even as his character descends into existential dread. The supporting cast, including Julianne Nicholson as Paul's long-suffering wife, are equally stellar, adding depth and humour to the story. The film's score is a pulsing electronic nightmare, perfectly complementing the unsettling visuals and amplifying the tension. The cinematography is equally inventive, playing with dream logic and distorted perspectives to keep us guessing. But Dream Scenario isn't just about the laughs and scares. It's a film that asks questions about the nature of identity, the power of collective consciousness, and the dangers of a society obsessed with viral fame. It's a film that lingers in your mind long after the credits roll, making you question your own dreams and the reality you wake up to. Now, it's not perfect. The pacing can be a bit uneven at times, and the ending, while satisfying, feels a tad rushed and less subtle in its satire than the first two-thirds. But these are minor quibbles in an otherwise masterfully crafted film. Dream Scenario is a wild ride, a waking nightmare that's both hilarious and thought-provoking. It's a film that will leave you laughing, gasping, and maybe even questioning your own sanity. Try Dream Scenario if you are in search of a film that is unlike anything you have ever seen before; however, do not hold me responsible if you find yourself unable to sleep afterwards!

'Dream Scenario' is a unique concept, with thousands of people seeing Paul (Cage) in their dreams, just walking through, not really participating in the dream. This then turns him into a celebrity, something Paul, his wife Janet (Nicholson), daughters Hannah (Clement) and Sophie (Bird), and boss Brett (Meadows) aren't prepared for, especially as he has no control over what's happening. The film does well to purposefully not explore the how/why it's happening and focuses on the impacts on Paul. Odd that a lot of places are billing this as a comedy - I'd say it's a drama, with a few little laughs, which then diverts into mild horror at the end, as the dreams inevitability turn into nightmares. Cage is good, and not totally manic, but plays a Professor and normal dad well, who ends up at his wits end. The ending is not as dark as it could've been, but nor is it a nice comedy ending either. There's some existential questions and a you obviously get to ask "what would I do in this situation?" But mostly it's probably an indictment on modern society, especially the penultimate scene. The support cast is good - should also mention Molly (Gelula) & Trent (Cera) from the PR company who play significant parts. And always good to have a Talking Heads song to wrap things up!

There's something refreshing about the plainly weird premise of "Dream Scenario". Nicolas Cage plays a nondescript evolutionary biology professor named Paul Matthews, who suddenly appears in the dreams of his students, daughters, and people he does not know. He doesn't do anything in their recurring nighttime hallucinations of anxiety or horror, in which people sometimes float into the air or the world collapses. He more or less just strolls through the background in his sweater and glasses, sometimes flashing his dopey, pleasant smile. Paul soon becomes a phenomenon, and then a pariah when everyone's dreams co-starring Paul become violent.

Review-Title: There is so much humor, both visual and spoken. So many things made me laugh out loud.
Review-Description:
IN A NUTSHELL:
The story is about a man who is determined to win the neighborhood's annual Christmas decorating contest. He makes a pact with an elf to help him win, but there unintended consequences of chaos. The family-friendly movie was directed by Reginald Hudlin. Writing credits go to Kelly Younger. THINGS I LIKED:
It's great to see Eddie Murphy in something again. He's great, of course. Giving way to the fun special effects, he plays a much more subdued character than we've seen him do before. When is he going to start aging? Tracee Ellis Ross is fantastic in this. I loved her fun personality. Did you know she has been nominated for 58 awards and won 12, known mostly for her role in Black-ish
The adorable Madison Thomas has an appropriate name for a character in a holiday movie: The other children in the movie are named Nick and Joy. I always get a kick out of Jillian Bell and thought she was perfect in this role. She's a quirkly, likable villain. The rest of the cast is great too, and includes Nick Offerman, Timothy Simons, Danielle Pinnock, Nancy Lenehan, Timothy Simons, and David Alan Grier as Santa! There is so much humor, both visual and spoken. So many things made me laugh out loud. I love the animated figurines in the old-timey houses. It seemed super old-fashioned Christmasy to me. The special effects are really entertaining! We've seen soooo many generic holiday movies over the years, so I loved that this story is unique and original. This movie could have easily jumped into the horror genre if it had wanted to. It made me laugh that USC was mentioned so many times in the movie. My brother is a USC law school grad! That Matrix house. Ha ha
We get a musical cameo from Pentatonix. I love that group! Keep watching during the final credits for another little scene, as well as some funny outtakes. THINGS I DIDN'T LIKE:
There is a lot going on here. Sometimes, the script is too stuffed. Even though I enjoyed the movie, it felt a little too long. TIPS FOR PARENTS:
Some "light" profanity
Lots of destruction and mayhem. To see my full review, go to my YouTube channel called Movie Review Mom!

Bad movie. Waste of good actors. Terrible all around. No consistency in the plot. Don not throw away two hours of your life watching this. Eddie Murphy, if you're reading this, "You're better than this!" We were looking forward to this movie and it was very disappointing. We expected more from such a good cast. My husband watched it till the end, I couldn't bare to finish it. We had high hopes from the previews and thought it would turn into a Christmas classic but it is the opposite. The script, the plot, the movie was all over the place. It had potential but you didn't know where the story was going.

Review-Title: Mindless fun and laughter with a holiday theme
Review-Description: To be frank, this movie is stupid. But for me it fell on the right side of stupid. It called back plenty of early 2000's family-oriented comedies that hold special places in my heart. Does that element of nostalgia mixed with Christmas cheer beef up my rating? Probably. But I enjoyed it, and movies are for entertainment after all. Eddie is in classic form as I remember and love him ("Daddy Daycare" and "Haunted Mansion") alongside the loveable and whacky Tracee Ellis Ross who delivers her lines to perfection. Together they make quite a pair. The plot of this movie is simple enough. It ends up becoming too convoluted and drags on way, way too long. This movie could've been a comfortable 85 minutes instead of over 2 hours. But of course the takeaway is what it always is: Christmas is about family and love above all else. A message that is timeless.

Review-Title: Like a candy cane you hate it or love it
Review-Description: The movie has a good idea behind it but is sadly just not drawn out correctly. The humour in this film is a hit or miss as most of it is not very funny. It is Eddie Murphy so you either like the comedy or hate it. If it was Christmas Day this would not really be a movie I would ever put on as it is not rewatch able. If you had young kids you could put this on as it is a PG which can offer something for kids to watch at Christmas at least. Overall this movie is like a candy cane you hate it or you love it but sadly in my opinion it just does not hit the spot and that is why candy cane lane is a. 4/10 = worse than mediocre.

I like the idea of this movie. Kind of a Christmas Jumanji.. instead of a game being played, a Christmas decoration contract has been signed. And that contract is causing problems. It's always good to see Eddie Murphy. Yes, he's toned down a bit because it's a family movie, but that's cool. The movie ends with almost everyone having learned a good lesson. Peppermint (the fallen elf) is obnoxious, but that's how she's supposed to be. The whole movie could have been better, certainly, but it was a fun Christmas movie anyway. The cast is a good one. I watched after Christmas. I think that next year, I'll watch it again.. before Christmas.

The trailer looked brilliant, but please don't be fooled by that. I've seen and even liked films worse than this, but can I have my almost 2 hours back please?? I kept watching in the vain hope that the film would actually pick up at some point, but boy was I mistaken. This film is a complete mish-mash of every corny Christmas film I've ever seen. I don't understand how or why Eddie Murphy took this role. He can do tons better than this film. To call it corny is an understatement. Were Amazon scraping the barrel with this film or what?? I seriously hope that Amazon didn't pay a lot for the film, otherwise they'll be asking for their money back...
Not worth the time to watch it.

Even though its idiot movie but entertainer for Christmas. Who dont want to be bit idiot and believe in Christmast Miracles. Its fantasy life, you got to be believe in magic, life is magic and thats how it achieved in the movie. I Loved the movie as is, there has to be movies like this, light hearted, fun, for kids, for Christmas and for our beloved Santa Claus. If you love Christmas then you will really love this movie without any conditions. Eddie Murphy is true brand ambassador of such fun movies. I recommend all the children's to watch movie and keep the spirit of Santa Claus growing. Love Santa, Love Christmas :)

I'm glad I ignored the reviews and gave this movie a shot over Christmas. It turned out to be the ideal family-friendly film that was enjoyable for everyone. It hits that sweet spot of not being too childish and also isn't violent. It also has straightforward and easily understandable storytelling and dialogue, which was great for my non-native English-speaking parents who are difficult to please when it comes to movies. They really enjoyed it. The pacing is spot-on, and the storyline is well-structured with a good dose of humor. It isn't laugh out loud funny, but I had a few chuckles - that's fine for me as I don't need to roll on the floor laughing to enjoy myself. The characters are all great. Some scenes are a little cringy, due to the clich√©d direction they take, but that's fine for these types of movies. My only criticism is there was one scene with the Elf making reference to Christmas not being about Jesus, she was a bad elf, but IMO it's best not to include offensive things like that. Overall it's a wholesome, feel-good movie.

We are die hard Christmas fans and we really wanted to love this movie. We previously watched the movie "Genie" and my daughter loved it, but this here is one discombobulated mess! Horrible overacting, unfunny and wayyyyy too long for its own good! It could have been great, but the focus on product placement was just too apparent and the movie itself suffered from the zero chemistry from the underdeveloped and unlikable actors. The only thing this movie had going for it is Eddie and unfortunately, even that wasn't enough to save this bomb of a movie. Ultimately, this will be a forgotten movie rather than a repeatable classic. A one time watch is all this flick is worth and even then, fails at holding your attention. I fell asleep after the first hour and I never do that for great Christmas movies which this was not! All the reviews on Youtube must be bots as it seems its getting 100% likability which is why I watched it when in fact it was closer to what we see here on IMDB.

A Christmas classic it is not! Horrible acting, unfunny and unoriginal! Went in with high hopes and fell asleep an hour in! Not sure why they needed to make this mess of a movie 2 hours long as it felt like torture sitting through it! Definitely a one time watch (if you make it all the way through) but not to be repeated! My children loooooove everything Christmas, and they walked away unsatisfied with this one! Just another example of horrible writing, terrible directing, uninspiring plot, stale jokes, over-acting "in a bad way" and obvious product placement which was probably the point of this movie and nothing to do with the spirit of the holiday! Obvious attempt at a money grab!

Review-Title: What the hell did I watch
Review-Description: Boy oh boy I don't know why this was filmed. Whilst Natalie porter and julienne Moore are great actresses this was not the film for them. First of all its not a comedy or a dark comedy, I actually found it stressful watching this, kept waiting for the story to begin of when what or where they met but nothing. Just people saying they met at school when he was 17. All the family sitting at table eating too much doom and gloom. I mean was she wasn't she abused????? It just revolved around julienne moor crying like a baby, ending was rubbish, dont know why this was made. There could have been a lot more to this story which would have been enjoyable to watch but nothing. Just glad I didn't waste my money watching this at the cinema.

The performances, from Portman especially, are good, but the movie never really goes anywhere. The idea is intriguing, but it felt like the movie was building to some big emotional climax that never happened. The storyline with the son from the first marriage never went anywhere. The affair with the current husband was kind of pointless and had no real effect on the plot. Nothing really happens with any of the kids. We don't see the finished movie Portman is making have any kind of effect on the characters or her in universe career. My biggest complaint is that the film makers give us this heinous crime and then refuse to have anything to say about it. They don't take a stand to say what Moore's character did was disgusting and they don't really manage to humanize her, if they were even trying to. They just brush over the fact that this woman seduced and sexually assaulted a 13 year old. Something that big, and that central to the story should have been addressed in some way, not hand waved away. None of the characters are very likable either. In the end, it feels like a waste of time because there never was a payoff for anything.

May December is an intensely complex dark comedy masterfully directed by Todd Haynes (Far From Heaven and Carol are among my favorite films). Julienne Moore plays Gracie, a woman in her late 50's caught up in having sex with a seventh grader boy in her 30's. She went to jail and had his baby and later they married and still together 23 years later. Charles Melton plays the husband in his 30's. Natalie Portman plays Elizabeth, an actress who is about to play Gracie in a movie. She comes to town to observe and understand them. The well written screenplay is outstanding as well as the three principal actors. Moore and Portman are both Oscar winning actresses and Melton keeps up with them. All three should receive Oscar nominations as well as the script. The film is a well crafted puzzle many scenes are open to interpretation. Cocoon/butterfly and fox/predator scenes and references are well placed. This is a very adult film üé• which stays with you after you finish it and makes you think a lot about the characters and their motivations. Very highly recommended üëçüëçüëçüëç
Available on Netflix in USA and Canada, but playing in movie theaters in Turkey and Europe.

For starters, don't expect there to be lots of action or any wild happenings. This movie is more of a realistic character study, so one must pay attention to all the subtle details to really get the most of it. The movie makes a bold stylistic choice with an omnipresent repeated theme, which gives it more of a classical feeling. It is unlike most contemporary films that tend to be a lot more fast paced. Instead, May December is more reminiscent of older movies, with slower rhythm and more depth to them. Here, nothing is spoon fed to the audience, however the strong writing + acting gives us enough information to understand the different dynamics at play - and they're all interesting. As the movie goes on, the veil progressively lifts to reveal the emotional depths (or lack thereof) of the characters. However, it does so without ever giving easy answers. The realization is amazing, and the music gives the movie an ethereal feeling that reveals the layer beneath the surface. May December always plays on two fronts, with the action taking place before our eyes, and the underlying emotional motivation of the characters. In the end, what we end is a masterful character study, understated in its action because most of what it has to say is hidden in the depths of the human psyche.

This is a movie review of "May/December," directed by Todd Hayes. Hayes does an excellent job of creating a thoughtful and provocative film based on a sensational event. Although Hayes loves melodrama, he takes a non-fiction story and parallels it with a fictional story of making a film about it. The characters played by Portman and Moore are both observed objects who create a self-narrative where they are the heroes. However, in the end, they both turn out to be delusional. The scene where Moore's character makes up Portman expresses the connection. Hayes direction combines naturalist and expressionistic overtones adding the right element of distance from its outherwise sensation subject.

Todd Haynes has been brilliant in the past, but here he seriously falters. The film lacks the spark of enthusiasm that might have made up for the fact that there simply isn't an interesting story here to begin with. Deals with mental illness but only goes as deep as the glancing edge, and prefers instead to be mainly an uninsightful commentary about borderline narcissism, selfish, poor behavior, and some dull bits about acting and being an actor. Many scenes lacking in meaning and displaying only average dialogue and performances should have been cut out. Avenues that should have been pursued or at least satisfactorily explained were not, such as how and why would an actress spend days and weeks with someone they are meant to portray, who is patently uninteresting, and whose mannerisms and motivations can be imitated and deciphered very quickly? Who cares why these bland and monotonous individuals made odd life choices? It is the film's job to make things compelling or shed light on something, and nothing is really even interesting here. Each main character has flaws, but what this reveals about the human condition is zero. We simply witness tedious people having tiresome conversations which reveal far too little. We can guess, but always lurking at every moment is the dreaded "Who Cares?" No matter how hard you apply yourself to the themes covered, you will come up light, unless you enjoy medium temperature suburban drama that goes on for two solid hours with scant material to explore. Yes, we see there are some "meta" themes to pay attention to, but they are not substantial enough to make up for the lack of convincing emotion or energy.

This movie really has an interesting and thoughtful storyline with little details that made it seem like it was based on a true story. That was nicely done. Somewhat shockingly, the music was out of an '80s or early '90s movie. It gave the effect of being more like a Lifetime movie. That doesn't particularly bother me but I just thought it was extremely interesting. You don't see that in movies today. And for good reason I think. People have moved past that musical style. This was approaching a seven for me but didn't quite get there. The positive elements again were the interesting storyline and the tension among some of the characters and the development of the plot and the characterization. The drawback was again the music was a little off and the story just wasn't quite as compelling as a seven rated movie would be. It was funny in the graduation scene how they were clearly attempting to announce the graduates in alphabetical order but failed. Sloppy writing there. Also after they announced about eight students whose last name started with "A" the principal quickly said congratulations to the class of 2015 without any kind of a segue. ABOUT MY REVIEWS: I do not include a synopsis of the film/show -- you can get that anywhere and that does not constitute a meaningful review -- but rather my thoughts and feelings on the film that hopefully will be informative to you in deciding whether to invest 90-180 minutes of your life on it.
