A documentary might have delivered a more effective narrative. Nevertheless, if a feature film was the chosen medium, The Boys in the Boat proves to be a formulaic and uninspired exercise-one unworthy of cinematic endeavor.

This is a solid film from George Clooney and his team. Great storytelling, well written, edited and told beautifully, and well directed. Glad I saw it in the theater. The story will bring you to tears in the best way through amazing character journeys and lush patriotism. It's a period piece that doesn't shy away from the reality of the time. It helps paint a picture of classism and disparities of the century and sport. This film showcases the sport of rowing well including the commitment, strategy, and sheer will to win. As a former crewman, this story was told through the eyes of those who love the sport. It was that passion that came through the screen. I loved this film and will be recommending it to others. Go Huskies and Team USA.

The audience applauded at the end of the movie -- that's rare for where we're located. Cinematography is beautiful. Felt like we were there. The director, crew and writers did a great job making this. Movies are off-spring of the books. As a novelist & more, I understand the hard work of doing the transition to visual storytelling. The visual story is different from the book. Graphic Novels are not the same as a source book or movie. .... ..... .... Back to BOYS IN THE BOAT. This is a film you can watch again with other family members. You'll see something you didn't see the first time. The effort to transport us back to 1930's America succeeded stupendously. Please simply add an elegantly scripted sentence at the end of the film. "If you liked the movie read or listen to the novel".

Review-Title: In my top 10 Christmas movies to watch every year!
Review-Description: This movie never gets old for me! The TV puns are witty playing off the timeless classic and modernize it to fit the cut throat TV industry, and a desensitized generation. Bill Murray is at his best with his zany SNL throwbacks, impressions and being funny the way he used to be (although I haven't seen him in ages.) The ghosts of past & present (Carol Kane) & Bob Cathwaite are hilarious. Other role players including John Forsythe and Robert Mitchum provide good characterization. This movie is 35 years old and it never gets old as my family and I can recite the lines in this film verbatim and laugh every time.

This is, for me, one of Bill Murray's best performances, even though it is unhinged. He plays a network executive who is clearly unhappy with the choices he has made, and through the magic of Christmas he is visited by three ghosts like in a Christmas Carol. It is a retelling of it, but one that is more modern, and still firm set in the greed is good era of the 1980s. This film came out when I was eleven, and I think my parents picked up a VHS copy shortly after. I wanted to watch a Christmas movie with my kids, and they didn't want to watch Gremlins for some reason, so I chose this one. I remember every little detail, and the practical effects are amazing. The rotting corpse whose arm gets torn off is still creepy today. It's a pretty dark Christmas film, which leads to me to wonder why were the films of my childhood a bit dark, and now films for children are so antiseptic?

Review-Title: Has it's moments, but overall falls flat
Review-Description: The movie starts off decent but then falls apart at about the halfway mark. I think a modern day revamp. (for the 80's) was a great idea, and kudos with Scrooge being a ruthless, disconnected TV exec, but there was just so much more left to be desired in this version of the classic Dicken's tale. As the film goes on, it just starts to become nonsense and many scenes are just loud and irritating. The ghost of Christmas present was downright terrible and completely unfunny. I had a bit of difficulty following the film as it was all over the place and it felt like it's was just jumping from scene to scene without any direction. The biggest issue was that, for a rendition of A Christmas Carol, it lacked heart. The ending felt rushed and disjointed and seeing Scrooge's redemption, which is my favorite part of the story, was so unsatisfying. All in all, the movie is mostly unfunny, annoying, dull, and rather simple minded. It also lacks that emotion other versions really captured with this story. If you're considering watching it, I say give this one a pass.

Bill Murray is hilarious as this modern version of Ebeneezer Scrooge. The whole movie is comic genius from start to finish. And while you would think that the spirit of xmas would be lost with this approach, the movie remains nostalgic and really brings the feel good factor that is required in a xmas movie. The supporting cast are also fantastic with Bobcat Goldthwait delivering a brilliant and again hilarious performance. The Movie is defo of the era with similarities to other Bill Murray Classics such as groundhog day. By far my favourite Xmas movie and a real treat for all the family. I am very much a traditionalist when it comes to Christmas Entertainment, but if you want something that is a bit leftfield but still makes you come back for that xmas hit , year after year. You can't go wrong with Scrooged.

"Scrooged" is one of the most hilarious Christmas films ever made but it's surprisingly controversial or at least unpopular among some fans of Christmas movies. Maybe it's expectations. For those who say it's not a literal version of Dickens' story, well, it's not. It's inspired and loosely based on it. Many people complain that the character is too dark or that they can't like him enough to root for him. But this is not "It's a Wonderful Life" and Bill Murray isn't Jimmy Stewart. I don't think anyone watching any of the actual films of "A Christmas Carol" or even reading the story would say they could relate to Scrooge or see any hope for him.. When asked to help the poor by charity workers, he answers "If they would rather die, they had better do it and decrease the surplus population." Scrooge is a dark character, so far it would seem from any hope of redemption that when it comes it's all the more joyful. Secondly, "Scrooged" is basically a farce and so by its very nature everything is exaggerated. That's how a farce works. If Bill Murray's character had been a mildly grumpy man it would have fallen flat. Everything is exaggerated to its maximum effect. Bill Murray's Frank Cross isn't bad, he's horrible. As the movie begins he does something awful, then he does something even worse, then he tops even that, totally plumbing the depths of being an unprincipled scoundrel. There's seemingly no limit to how awful Frank Cross can be. Murray's deadpan delivery and general air of condescension embody the character perfectly. He plays it beautifully, too: no winks at the camera, just totally straight as the boss from hell. It's his film, he had to carry it and he did. The film was directed by action movie director Richard Donner between "Lethal Weapon I and II. The production became well known for its general air of disagreement between Donner, Murray and screenwriters Mitch Glazer and Michael O'Donoghue. Each seemed to have their own idea of the film, with the writers saying Donner did not know how to shoot comedy and not liking Murray's improvisations, which included the major speech he gives at the end. Donner thought Murray was difficult but admired his professionalism. Murray had not made a picture since "Ghostbusters: four years earlier and felt stressed by the pressure to carry the film. He also suffered some physical reactions to the artificial snow, but this might have actually improved his portrayal of Cross..Somehow it all worked out. It's a bit long here and there and Fran;s change of heart seems a bit too sudden, but that's what the story is about. The film knocks you out of any preconceived expectations by opening with Donner satirizing himself with an armed invasion of Santa's Workshop at the North Pole ("The Day the Reindeer Died":). It features an actual action star, then goes off in several other unexpected directions until you don't know what will happen next and that's the general way the whole film is. It's also loaded with unexpected casting and surprise cameos which are all part of the fun. Some of this may have lost some effect as time has gone by and new viewers may not understand some of the references, but it's still a funny film even if you don't know who all the actors are. It also satirizes the notion that any publicity is good publicity, the industry obsession with awards and the quest for network ratings. The supporting cast is excellent, even Murray's own younger brother playing Frank Cross's younger brother James. The film was a hit in 1988, though not a huge hit. Over subsequent decades it has picked up many fans and is now a holiday classic.

Coolest thing about this film is how it spins the Christmas carol formula. With hundreds of different Christmas carol films always taking place in the same time period just with different actors or different characters. This movie brings life by making it very modern, at least for the late 80s. Bill Murray plays a film producer working on a Christmas carol film whose life mirrors Scrooge. The ghosts in this film are hilarious and have some of the best scenes, the new plot twists and threads are interesting although feel slightly unrealistic, although considering how slapstick this film is that shouldn't really be a problem. My biggest gripe with this film is I just didn't find it funny, it had all the perfect jokes to be funny but nothing overly made me laugh out loud, bill Murray also shouts a whole lot for some reason. With that being said this is still a very good Christmas classic and an awesome take on a Christmas carol.

This was the most bill murray of bill murray of bill murray movies ever. Plays the same smarmy character he always plays. What you think of this movie depends on how much over the top bill murray-ing you can take. He really is a gross jerk. I feel like maybe he was playing himself. Like his old girlfriend would be so into him and immediately swoon the minute he pays attention to her (right after making out with a solid gold dancer on live tv - haha hilareous right?). It is so ridiculous. In the end he doesn't seem redeemed he just seems insane. Like seriously a mental breakdown right before he commits suicide. His assistent holds the studio at gunpoint (which def isn't funny anymore) while he makes a truly deranged speech while crying. It's more disturbing than sweet. Maybe that was the point. I'm not entirely sure. I guess I don't get it. Now I can cross it off my list. It's like how wes anderson has just got too wes anderson. This is the same. Just too much free reign bill murray. I chuckled a few times but not enough to make this any kind of classic.

It's been on my watch list for a while now. Didn't like it much when I finally sat down to watch it. Bill Murray's character just screams all the time, that's it. I understand the Scrooge-character is supposed to be unlikable but Murray's character is unlikeable in an obnoxious sort of way that it makes it hard to believe he's redeemable. The movie as a whole is very over the top, but not in a good way. Half of the lines are unintelligible due to sound editing or the actors' delivery. It felt kind of like a fever dream. There were a couple good laughs but not good enough to make me watch it again.

4/4: Scrooged (1988) (8/10): Here's a true gem, A Christmas Carol with a twist! Scrooged is a more contemporary retelling of the classic Scrooge tale. It follows, Frank, a selfish and cynical television executive who is not a fan of Christmas. He sends cheap gifts to his family and employees, airs the least Christmasy Christmas shows and movies during the holidays, fires his workers for saying that they should do something different and more wholesome for the holidays and even uses others misfortune to further himself. He is then one night nearing the holidays by the ghost of his former boss who was a legend in the business warning him that he needs to change and he will be visited by three ghosts. He is then sent down a spiral of insanity as the ghosts show him the error of his ways in order to change him from being Scrooged to a Saint. Bill Murray stars in this more modern and slightly darker version of the story and he is also joined by Bobcat Goldthwait in a more under appreciated yet very quirky holiday film. We have Richard Donner directing who was also behind The Omen, The Goonies and the Lethal Weapon movies and he is accompanied by legendary composer Danny Elfman who has worked with Tim Burton on several occasions as well as the Spider-Man Trilogy, Hellboy II, and more films. The Portrayal of Frank by Murray is great as he really shows his selfishness followed by his denial to accept that what he's experiencing is in fact real and then his mental breakdown once he fully realizes it is happening followed by him getting more and more cracked up after each encounter. Might I add that the ghosts are all fantastically designed, with my favourite overall being the ghost of Christmas Past as he has stereotypical New Yorker attitude coupled with a dry sense of humour but overall design is Ghost of Christmas Future even though we see the least of him, his screen time isn't wasted. When he is first seen and he is just taking up the various tv screens to form his face and then we see that huge skeletal hand reach out behind Frank, man that effect is so cool. The score is not one of Elfman's most notable but it's a nice little piece nonetheless. Overall the film is just the right kind of movie for the holiday season, this one is a much recommended watch.

Review-Title: Wonderful comedic adaptation of the classic
Review-Description: Charming, magical, funny and sweet. Great cast, costumes, writing. I watch it every Christmas! Carol Kane.as the ghost of Christmas present, played as a tough as nails, take no prisoners fairie, the always silly and delightful Bill Murray- endearing even when being an awful human being, sweet Karen Allen as his girfriend, and even Robert Mitchum and Buddy Hacket, John Houseman, Lee Majors...C'Mon! I can't find it playing this year, (so far at least), and I'm truly upset/disappointed. Grab an eggnog or a hot toddy, put on your silly Christmas pajama, and settle in for a goofy, fantastical night of story telling and giggles!

What a wonderful movie this was. Richard attemborough is a perfect santa. He has a warm and calm about his performance. His unsucpecting but you know its him. Maya was great too and they had a real bond. So in this film santa gets a job as a santa for a mall. But a rival toy shop wants him too, of couse nobody relized he is indeed the real santa. There are some hilarius bits here and there and it was nice seeing daphne from fraiser in it aswell. It all leads to a courtroom battle that was pretty fun to watch and had some festive cheer to go along with that aswell. Overall miracle on 34th street was a warming and sweet film.

Review-Title: Back when Manhattan actually had a white Christmas.
Review-Description: Was this remake necessary? Probably not. Is it better than the original? Definitely not. Does a 90's perspective make an impact? Definitely. It shows a much more cynical world, an even more materialistic holiday season, and definitely a forced sense of holiday spirit that in modern ideals makes Christmas 1994 seem like a dream. The perfection of this film comes through a romanticized version of New York City that has never existed, as well as the casting of the legendary actor turned director Richard Attenborough as Kris Kringle and newcomer Mara Wilson as the little girl whom one person describes as acting 38. The fault of thar is her cynical world weary mother, Elizabeth Perkins, who works planning the Thanksgiving parade (not Macy's; that was forbidden by the company loyal to the 1947 film), resentful of the fact that her husband disappeared shortly after Wilson was born. Perkins will never replace the memory of Maureen O'Hara, but in a sense it's a supporting part. Attenborough and Wilson certainly aren't going to top Edmund Gwenn and Natalie Wood, but they don't discredit the parts either. My issue with this film is in its darkness, especially through nasty drunken Santa (Jack McGee) who's truly vile as he baits Kris into striking him. Store rivals James Remar and Jane Leeves are rather cold business types, the kinds of vile business oriented robots who obviously have coal where their hearts could be. But Dylan McDermott is all charm as Perkins' love interest, and Robert Prosky is a delight as the judge. So while I don't find this horrible, it's definitely lacking the feel good message and magical elements of the original that even at its darkest didn't feel like cold Christmas pudding.

Review-Title: I swear to tell the truth, so help me God
Review-Description: Not to sound a little grinchy , but this remake for me is just a little too Chris Cringey. The whole courtroom drama part for me is so incredibly over egged and I find it hard to enjoy what is in essence a reworked version of classic Scrooge. Miserable person sees the light and every one lives happy ever after with their every want or need granted without question. Don't get me wrong It's obviously supposed to be feel good and festive which it does a reasonable job at. But I can't see past the cheesiness and the hopeless romantic storyline as it is just plain boring. The young actress whose name escapes me is undoubtedly the star of the show and does a great job as she did in a number of movies of that era. But the rest of the cast are mediocre at best. With Richard Attenborough, as good as he looks is in my opinion a little tiresome with his portrayal of the whiter than white Father Christmas. Maybe its me but I just can't get on board with a santa who is so open with his identity and also who is so easy to just give up when he gets committed. As I say the premise is hard to get on board with. Santa should be incognito and omnipotent. Not outed and pathetically fragile. Leave courtroom dramas for cop and crime shows. Not my favourite by any means I'm afraid.

Review-Title: Not necessary, but not terrible, either
Review-Description: The original Miracle on 34th Street didn't need a remake, but this version isn't terrible. I actually think Richard Attenborough makes a great Santa Claus, and Elizabeth Perkins portrays a skeptical mother pretty well. However, this new adaptation makes some unnecessary additions that don't really add anything to the story (though they certainly add to the runtime) and it changes some parts that lessen the overall impact of the movie. I'm not surprised that people still choose to watch the classic 1947 film each year instead of this, but I don't mind watching the 1994 version every few Christmases.

Review-Title: Watched back to back, you stick with the original
Review-Description: Last night I watched the original Miracle on 34th Street, then the 1973 made for TV version with Sebastian Cabot. The 1973 version was a mess, with some truly head-shaking script and production decisions that simply made no sense, and I suspect were the result of cost-cutting by the producers. Cabot did fine and David Hartman, too, other than his final courtroom scene, which was atrociously bad, but the rest of the cast were either miscast or never found their roles ... possibly rushing into filming the scenes or maybe just terrible direction. This film was a MAJOR slide down the slope from even that disaster. No Macy's? The "Cole" Thanksgiving Day Parade? Bad start to begin with. There's no such thing and people know that. Macy's wouldn't participate in this film and I suspect it's because they saw this anathema of a script. Once again, the Santa is fine and the lawyer is okay, but EVERYONE else is a disaster, from the evil rival store owner to the cold, heartless Mrs. Walker, whose first name was AGAIN changed. Why?? And yes, they changed the lawyer's name, too. Why?? In the original, Maureen O'Hara plays Walker as a sensible "modern woman", but with warmth. Elizabeth Perkins' version of Walker is a post-NOW "modern woman" who is not only cold, but mean spirited. When the lawyer proposes marriage and she tells him, with ice in her voice, that he's "a fool", I was done with this travesty. The addition of the "evil rival chain" does nothing for this story. In the original, Macy's and Gimbal's are at least friendly rivals, and let's remember this is a SANTA STORY which should be aimed predominantly at kids. The 1973 version lost that thread with vodka in the morning, and this one loses it with a complicated business plot which makes little sense and gives us too many "bad guys". James Remar and his female sidekick offer nothing to the story. They don't even bring a real sense of foreboding. Billed as a comedy, in watching the first half of this film, there was NOTHING even remotely close to giving me a smile, much less a laugh. This is what happens when lesser talents try to leech the brilliance of original writers and creators. They have no chance to improve on the original, and each misstep does nothing but corrupt what made the original a multi-generational success. Shame on Siskel and Ebert for originally approving this disaster. They got it very, very wrong ... which happened more often than you'd think.

Review-Title: A good old fashioned christmas miracle, taditional feel good film
Review-Description: I'm surprise this has such a low score on Imdb perhaps because there are no cars being blownup and huge explosions . To me this is one of the Christmas classics, (and remake of older black and white film) Miracle on 34th Street is up there with 'It's a wonderful life', 'A Christmas Carol - George C Scott version' and 'Love Actually' and a few others. Attenborough is just brilliant as Kringle and the theme is do we believe in Santa Claus This is a lovely film , for all the family, and can be watched multiple times, particularly suited to every Christmas Good old fashioned, feel good, happy ending story 8/10.

Don't, please. I said, don't! You are too late bla bla blaa! It's never too late! And I'm glad because I watched now! I wouldn't feel that before, as I felt now! So, I got chance to see many many in last time,
I've seen and many many old ones,
but haven't seen something like this one! (And don't, please don't tell me about original, I ain't youu Scroogiesssss who compare just so you could have trash talk about..) so as I said. It's.. it's miracle! It really is! Story is beautiful! Actors/Actresses, as born for their roles! It was like when you go in shooping and you chose wise, check all before you.. well they done it here! Tim is my favorite Santa Clause! But this one, this one is..
How to say that.. Tim is Santa, now we tryin to find and his replacment in new series..
But this Santa, it's like first Santa, original! The one, before all of them! Watching him as Santa is like watching some old really old too wise man, like angel in human form,
like some sensei with whom you want to spend as much as time as you have, to listen, watch, and learn! To be like him! So.. yeah, have to change my list, update to say. Others, him, her.. like couple from dream, movie! Not those today, classy, from before! Example of lady and man,
they just did too great! Little one, oh dear Lord! How ? Don't answer that! Haha! It's just magical movie! It's miracle! And I'm thankful because I've got chance,
how much, almost 30 years later..
If folks back then would knew for today's..
It would have at least 8 as raiting. This is timeless! And one of those, for reprise! Thank you all of you who made this possible! I know with this you've changed, still, and 'll do..
from views about life, to everything else! So many great messages/lessons! Thank you!

Review-Title: Never tire of this lovely, charmer
Review-Description: I challenge everyone to find any actor, any extras, any children, ANYONE in the movie who is wearing jeans. You won't. And if the actor should be wearing jeans or work clothes, it'll be a shot from the waist up. There's a scene showing dozens of children lined up in Macy's to sit on Santa's lap and tell him what they want for Christmas. Every single kid is dressed to the nines. Their parents are in business suits or beautiful dresses and coats. It's just a classy, beautiful remake of a very old, very sweet Christmas movie. Oh, and everyone's hair is perfectly cut, combed and styled. Everyone. Not a single detail was overlooked.üëèüëèüëèüëèüëèüëè. Such talent n the director, producer, crew, actors, everyone.

There's no doubt about it this movie is definitely a Christmas classic. It's fun to see a real life Santa, especially in the real world with a court case, skeptics, and drunk Santa fakes. Just about
everything in this movie is perfection, but I only have one qualm. I'm sure for its time it was perfectly acceptable, but looking at it now, the love story is atrocious. The woman makes it very clear that she's not interested in the man, he proposes to her anyway, she says no so he gets mad at her for not feeling the same way. Then somehow they end up together at the end of the film? What!? Certainly explains why some "nice guys" feel so entitled to relationships. Again, minor flaws with the movie. Overall it was a fun holiday movie, and I'll surely watch it in Christmases to come. I just know that every time I do, the Love story will forever bother me.

Review-Title: An okay remake of one of the greats
Review-Description: The original might be the greatest Christmas movie ever made. Any remake was going to be up against it. John Hughes' "Miracle on 34th Street" makes a good try but only gets so close. This movie looks great. There's one beautiful shot after another. The cast is okay, I guess. Mare Wilson and Richard Attenborough fare the best with James Remar, Jane Leeves bringing up the rear. John Hughes' script is okay too. Hughes manages to nail some scenes but a lot of the movie isn't very good. The whole thing with the evil store across the street doesn't work at all. Warts and all, this "Miracle on 34th Street" is worth the watch every once in a while. Honorable mention: the sign language scene. (I saw this movie in the theater (Movie World, Douglaston, NY) when it first came out.)

Movie Title: Harry Potter and the Philosopher's Stone (2001)
Review-Description: I never read any of the books, however I listened to audio books of Harry Potter 3-7, so I can't say how accurate this is to the book, I do however know that the first two movies are supposed to be the most accurate to their source material, anyway lets start with the review. It's been years if not over a decade since I watched the HP movies, this one was like 4 years ago. I loved those movies as a kid growing up with them and I still do. The story is great, the effects look better than most of todays and the score is also terrific. The characters are also well written and well portrayed. 9/10 free roaming trolls.

Movie Title: Harry Potter and the Philosopher's Stone (2001)
Review-Title: Imaginative tale of a boy who discovers he has magical powers
Review-Description: Harry Potter - Daniel Radcliffe - lives in half misery with his aunt, uncle, and annoying cousin Dudley. They treat Harry poorly, giving him castoff clothes and more. One day, things change. A man named Hagrid comes calling on Harry's 11th birthday with astonishing news. Harry is the son of two wizards who died trying to protect him and Harry has powerful magical abilities himself. It's bye bye to his relatives and on to to Hogwarts school for Wizards. Harry has a reputation he learns, for a lightning bolt scar on his forehead is a reminder he fought off a dark wizard named Voldemort when he was a baby! Soon Harry has good friends Ron and Hermione and is learning spells, potions and a flying broomstick game called Quidditch. BUT, there is a professor Snape who seems to have a disliking for Harry and there is a secret room where a three headed and fierce dog is hiding something precious. Can this young trio battle a dark plot which may be brewing? This beautifully presented film has so many strengths. The story, based on the famous book by JK Rowling, is imaginative and magical. The cast is a gallery of the finest British actors and young actors. Needless to say, the sets, costumes, effects and musical score are superb. My only caution is that there are some dark themes which might not please all viewers. However, most families will choose to follow Harry and his adventures many many times.

Movie Title: Harry Potter and the Philosopher's Stone (2001)
Review-Description: I was never a huge Harry Potter fan, but then again I never gave these movies a chance. After giving the first one a watch, I am very pleased with what I've seen. Although this film started off slow, once it picked up I was interested the whole time. The action in this film was actually surprising for a movie about magic, the effects for an older movie were also surprising. This movie left a lust for wanting more, something I never would have thought could come from watching these films. The acting of these young actors was also good for people so young. This film was a great first start for the franchise.

Movie Title: Harry Potter and the Philosopher's Stone (2001)
Review-Description: First time I watched this movie as a six year old kid, I thought that it was a very scary experience. Now these days, a movie like that isn't probably so scary for younger kids than back in time, with time things are getting more and more normal for kids and young. Still, it isn't about the scariness, but about the magic that "Harry Potter and The Sorcerer's Stone" contains. Based on the book by J. K Rowling, (That I really enjoyed reading) I think this is an amazing adaptation. The story becomes a fast icon in the world, and now everyone knows who the famous Harry Potter is, and I noticed the book shelfs became more empty with time, the book grossing go higher and higher, and I can't really argue, the story is developed so well, in the book and in the movie. But here it is about the movie of course. First of all, nothing is greater than some high quality music from our famous John Williams (Jurassic Park) and (Schindler's List) and the magical and convincing directing by Chris Colombus. The visual effects and scenography was on a fine level, Hogwarts castle is a rememberable building with so many hidden secrets to reveal. The acting was on a decent level, too, but the kids are playing way better than I would expect from a youngster. Harry James Potter performed by Daniel Radcliffe is a good addition to the film and he got into character. Harry's backstory with his parents makes the story even more dramatic and gets a better understanding for our main hero. Harry's two friends, Ron and Hermione, makes them the perfect trio, and they're showing friendship and courage in a good and valuable way. Since they're at school, some bullies got to be involved, and Draco Malfoy was a such a fun and menacing character as a kid. It's the beginning, so it's supposed to be the best one, but overall I think this is just a fine start and a great magical adventure. It's not bad, but it's nothing so impressive that I can give a very high rating. It's definitely a nice script, great acting and music, and something your kid can really enjoy (but for adults this may be just something decent).

Movie Title: Harry Potter and the Philosopher's Stone (2001)
Review-Description: Harry Potter and the Sorcerers Stone was an amazing movie. I loved the special affects, and the kid actors and actresses were very cute. The reason I rated it lower than I could have is because I didn't like Snape and Dumbledore. They almost whispered their lines, they were so quiet and much much more boring in the movie than in the book. In the book Professor Snape and Dumbledore were very important characters in the book, but in the movie Professor Snape and Dumbledore were unnecessary characters. Also a thing about the first 3 Harry Potter movies that I have watched is that Peeves the Poltigist is not in the movies. He is a character in the Harry Potter books that plays tricks on everyone. The filmmakers probably didn't have enough time for the troubled troublemaker. In all, I give this movie an 8.5 out of 10.

Movie Title: Harry Potter and the Philosopher's Stone (2001)
Review-Title: Solid Adaption to Kick Off a Phenomena
Review-Description: This was my first time rewatching this movie. I made a joke to Jaime, my wife, about how the Harry Potter series of movies are Christmas movies. This idea happened when bringing up Die Hard. Last year, when we brought our daughter home from the NICU, we watched the latter ones. We both had seen them and just wanted something on in the background. What is interesting here is that knowing how things play out from reading the novels and then coming back a second time to the movies, there are things that I picked out. This does well in setting up Harry Potter (Daniel Radcliffe) and helping not only us, but him learn the ways of the wizarding world. He was left in the care of his Aunt Petunia (Fiona Shaw), Uncle Vernon (Richard Griffiths) and his cousin Dudley Dursley (Harry Melling) after his parents were killed. They raise him. Now that he's 11, he's ready to join that world that they hate. There is more to the world than he realizes when he goes off to Hogwarts and meets his new best friends Ron Weasley (Rupert Grint) and Hermione Granger (Emma Watson). He also meets his new rival, Draco Malfoy (Tom Felton). He is quite behind on what he should know and has issues with Professor Snape (Alan Rickman). It is fun to go back to the beginning now that I know much more information. Jaime is also more of an expert here, which helps as well. This one isn't working with the budget that they'll have later. The CGI can be wonky. It is also fun to experience a world like this and we are there with Harry who had no idea about it either. This movie does a great job at bringing that all to life. I should also say that we have a great cast here featuring Richard Harris, Maggie Smith, Warwick Davis, Verne Troyer, John Hurt, John Cleese and David Bradley, to just name more. Not a great movie but does a good job to start this series off. Another thing that I like is that as the characters get older, what they deal with gets tougher. It stays on a level where they can manage it, which is another perk that it has going for it. My Rating: 7.5 out of 10.

Movie Title: Harry Potter and the Philosopher's Stone (2001)
Review-Description: Revisiting Harry Potter and the Sorcerer's Stone is an enchanting experience that brings back the magic that defined not only this film but the entire saga. Whether through the books or the movies, the Harry Potter series has been a source of joy, and this first installment remains a delightful journey into the wizarding world. The film's charm lies in its ability to cater to audiences of all ages. What was once a childhood favorite continues to captivate, and with each viewing, new layers and details emerge. The richness and intricacy of the universe crafted by J. K. Rowling make every return to Hogwarts a fresh adventure. As the opening chapter of the saga, Sorcerer's Stone masterfully lays the groundwork for the epic battle between Harry Potter and Voldemort. The film introduces each character, setting the stage for their individual evolutions throughout the series. Notably, characters like Severus Snape, initially perceived as the stern antagonist, reveal layers of complexity as the story progresses. The film serves as a timeless introduction to the magical world, portraying the relationships that will shape the narrative in the subsequent movies. The chemistry between the main trio-Harry, Ron, and Hermione-evolves from the first sparks of friendship into a powerful bond that becomes the heart of the series. Harry Potter and the Sorcerer's Stone is not just a film ; it's an initiation into a universe where spells, mythical creatures, and moral choices create a tapestry that transcends generations. It sparks a desire to delve into the subsequent chapters, eager to witness the characters' growth, the unfolding mysteries, and the epic battles that await. With its blend of wonder, humor, and adventure, this film is a testament to the enduring magic of the wizarding world-a magic that continues to resonate with audiences, old and new, making every return to Hogwarts a cherished and timeless experience.

Movie Title: Harry Potter and the Philosopher's Stone (2001)
Review-Description: Philosopher's stone is 1997 science fiction and fantasy, it is the story of a boy who learns on his 11th birthday that he is the orphaned son of two powerful wizards and that he also has unique magical powers. A book turned into a movie and is the first movie in the series. The series, consists of 7 books and 8 films. I think the acting is good ,it is entertaining movie. A movie that everyone of all ages can watch. I regret for not watching by now it is for years. In addition the effects of the film were also very successful. But I think excitement and curiosity begins after the second movie. I think you should definitely read the book and watch the movie.

Movie Title: Harry Potter and the Philosopher's Stone (2001)
Review-Title: Recommendation Harry Potter and the Philosopher¬¥s Stone
Review-Description: "Harry Potter and the Philosopher's Stone" sets the stage for the enchanting journey of a young wizard discovering his destiny. Adapted from J. K. Rowling's beloved novel, this movie introduces us to Harry Potter, a boy who learns of his magical heritage and embarks on a thrilling adventure at Hogwarts School of Witchcraft and Wizardry. In the beginning I¬¥d like to mention that from childhood through to now, the allure of Harry Potter's world has been an ever-constant joy. I've revisited the film countless times, each viewing rekindling the magic and nostalgia, making it a timeless favorite that feels like coming home. To conclude at its core, the film celebrates friendship, bravery, and the power of one's choices in shaping their destiny. It teaches the importance of standing up for what's right, even in the face of adversity. The story line revolves around Harry's discovery of his magical lineage, his entrance into the wizarding world, and his quest to prevent the bad forces from obtaining the Philosopher's Stone, an object granting immortality. Overall the film mesmerizes with its groundbreaking special effects, bringing to life fantastical elements like moving portraits, magical creatures, Quidditch matches, and the wonders of Diagon Alley. Belonging to the fantasy genre, "Harry Potter and the Philosopher's Stone" seamlessly fuse the ordinary world with the extraordinary, creating an immersive universe filled with spells, magical creatures, and captivating adventures. In addition the movie boasts an exceptional cast, with Daniel Radcliffe, Emma Watson, and Rupert Grint perfectly embodying the iconic roles of Harry Potter, Hermione Granger, and Ron Weasley, respectively. Not to mention the brilliant performances by veteran actors like Alan Rickman, Maggie Smith, and Robbie Coltrane, who breathe life into their enchanting characters. The star rating of 7.6/10 on imdb.com reflects the widespread appeal and admiration for the movie "Harry Potter and the Philosopher's Stone." This rating signifies a solid endorsement from viewers, indicating a positive reception and recognition of its entertainment value and storytelling prowess. Moving on to the target group of "Harry Potter and the Philosopher's Stone". It encompasses a wide range of audiences, primarily catering to both young and adult viewers alike. Its magical narrative, relatable characters, and universal themes of friendship, bravery, and the battle between good and evil resonate with children, teenagers, and adults, making it a beloved film for families and fantasy enthusiasts across generations. This movie remains a testament to the power of imagination, weaving a tapestry of magic and wonder that transcends generations. Whether it's your first time or your hundredth, "Harry Potter and the Philosopher's Stone" promises an unforgettable journey into a world where magic is real and friendship conquers all. In summary I can say that "Harry Potter and the Philosopher's Stone" holds a special place in my heart. It's more than just a movie; it's a nostalgic journey that's been with me since childhood. Watching it feels like coming home, evoking warm memories of family and moments of pure enchantment. This magical world offers an escape where one can immerse oneself completely, forgetting the outside world and diving into a realm of wonder and adventure. It's not just a film; it's a cherished part of my life's story, providing comfort and a sense of belonging with each viewing.

Movie Title: Harry Potter and the Philosopher's Stone (2001)
Review-Description: This is where children like me began to dream of a different realm, where children like us (I was only four years old when it was originally released) began to believe in a world beyond the bounds of our universe, a place filled with wizards and magic and supernatural beings. I remember growing up with this series, my obsession was limitless, I used to idolise this, my admiration knew no bounds, but that was twenty two years ago, and now, upon my return, everything appears so different, nothing like the times I was infatuated with it. I suppose that as time passed, my perception changed, as did my outlook on life, as well as my tastes and preferences in movies. Fantasy isn't a genre I fantasize about anymore, which may explain why I don't find this film as appealing as my recollections suggest. Nevertheless, it has good world-building, enjoyable performances, and, most importantly, the contagious charm and innocence that I still love and care about!

Review-Title: Eli Roth stop making horror films
Review-Description: Once again Eli Roth is set loose on the horror genre with very middling results. Can someone please stop him from making anymore as Thanksgiving is as generic as it comes. The film is littered with illogical events and has numerous horrendous plot holes. I'm not going over the plot of the film as its a simple rinse and repeat of everything that's come before it. The gory kill setups are incredibly poor and happen so fast, it felt like the writer and director just wanted to make sure they happened every few minutes to make sure the audience didn't fall asleep. The film is utter trash and an insult to true horror fans out there.

Not every year you're gifed with a thanksgiving killer movie. This however excited me, but after watching it was let down. The killing was satisfying had some school scenes but the 6 or so deaths didn't make up for the buns plot and cringe acting. After seeing a tik-toker was in a horror movie I couldn't take it serious after that. This movie had potential and the trailer was short n sweet. Which was a GOTCHA moment for me, they delivered heavily as the appetizer but the main course was spoiled. There will be no left overs lol. That part definitely made me cringe up and saying it once wasn't enough of course they had to run that famous line back and say it again, like it was an ingenious idea on the writers behalf.

I watched Thanksgiving with not too many expectations as I'm not a massive fan of the horror or slasher genre but thought I would give it a try. The first 20+ minutes were a bit confusing and I even checked if I was watching the film I thought I was, as the initial carnage is all self inflicted (in some of the better filmed parts), which sets the scene for what is to happen in this small town on the anniversary of this event. The line between seriousness and absurdity for this type of movie seems to be a fine one as we see all these gory and absurd deaths and, to me maybe it was taking itself a little bit too seriously. But the biggest problem I found was this type of 'disguise' of the perpetrator really narrowed down the potential identity possibilities (with out giving away too much, it's fairly obvious there are only a couple of realistic options). But anyway, it's a fun and enjoyable movie, and something different for this year so not a bad attempt overall. Worth a go if you are curious enough. 6/10.

Review-Title: Tasteless, store-brand version of superior Slasher films
Review-Description: I was excited for this film because the 2007 parody trailer in Grindhouse was campy and hilarious. This film is a complete departure from the OG trailer in tone and style. We thought about seeing this in the theater, and I'm so glad I didn't waste $20 but p!rated it later instead. Some moments feel jarring and out of place because establishing shots/scenes are missing. Filming basics 101: you have a setup, then a payoff. But the setup is missing over and over so the payoffs have no weight to them. The deaths happen too fast and then the film just moves on. The trampoline scene is just thrown in, but the trailer version was better. There was never any moment where the killer was in trouble or about to get caught. Whether a victim escaped the killer or not didn't matter to me because there wasn't much characterization leading up to the chases. So it's like, who cares? The gore was tasteless and frankly, MPAA should've slapped an NC-17 rating on this. Specifically the scene where he smashes a guy's head open with a meat mallet. The dumpster scene was ridiculous too, both in gore and just the physics didn't make sense. In the parade scene, the killer isn't dressed like a pilgrim anymore, but as a clown. I guess to surprise us? I appreciated the few brief humor moments. Movies like this shouldn't take themselves too seriously. Despite the funny moments, the extreme violence and depraved nature of the killings ruined the vibe. I liked the actors even if their Mass accents were over the top. The anxiety of wondering "who's next?" plays well. But ultimately, Thanksgiving is the store-brand version of superior slasher films.

Review-Title: I didn't know this was a comedy horror.
Review-Description: Sat down to watch this last night after wanting to see this movie since it came out. I came away a little bit disappointed with the whole movie. Firstly I didn't know this movie was a comedy horror, even though it's not classed as one, it certainly felt like one. The murder scenes were so over the top you couldn't help but laugh at them. As one reviewer stated on the Totally Killer review, that the problem when a movie is played for laughs, the tense and murder scene are not that frightening because of the comedy element. This I found spoiled the movie somewhat for me. Would I watch it again, no I wouldn't. Will I watch the sequel when it comes out in 2025, yes I will as I didn't hate the film but I felt it wasn't as good as I thought it would be. A struggling five star rating.

Original kills. Gory as anything. Average reason for the bloodbath set out for by the killer/s??!!! Eli Roth's movies always go a cut above the rest (no pun intended) with the gore set to MAX with some brutal killings throughout the whole movie. While the character development felt a bit shallow, it still made me care for the survivors and think about what would happen the next. The shopping scene from the beginning of the film felt like it could've been straight out of a real life scene in modern day America, given the state of play they have provided the world the past couple years. Would recommend for an easy watch with not much else to think about. Look forward to the sequel.

Okay first let's start with the positives, the movie was highly entertaining. Even with its numerous flaws it was a movie I felt I could just relax to and enjoy watching. However there are just way too many flaws. The acting is the worst part for me. It's so OTT it's like if you told your 10 year old dramatic sister to act something out. I mean casting TikTokers in movies what has the world become! Get some decent actors who actually have talent unlike tiktokers. I don't think there was one actor who I recognised or deserved to be in a film. Bobby was the only I felt did alright acting I guess. The kills were a positive. They were goofy but also so freaking gory. The oven one was actually hard to watch and the victim didn't even deserve it. Alongside people who didn't deserve it, the killer (who is the sheriff) killed numerous innocent people that had nothing to do with the Black Friday incident. I'd understand if the killer was a teen but it's out of character for the sheriff to do that and also it kind of ruins his motive. The motive was really weak imo, it was surprising don't get me wrong but if he really wanted revenge you'd think he'd want to kill everyone who was in the store right? I mean the poor security guard didn't even do anything wrong it's not like he was going to stop the horde from breaking in anyway. There was also a lot of plot holes as well. I mean the killer shows up in two places at once. It happened numerous times. The most obvious is when he is talking outside with the other sheriff yet drugging Evan and Addison Rae and chasing the main girl through the school. The other one was when the main girl jumped over the fence and then somehow the sheriff is having a fight with Bobby and knocked out on the floor. I also don't really like the misuse of characters, I mean I was expecting Mitch to be a real hero in this film with an arc but he disappears after 10 minutes then appears late on just to jump around with a sign and then run away. Also with the nerdy guy who is set up to be an important character but then is just forgotten about after the party. The movie was setting it up to seem like there are 2 killers so I was kind of disappointed when there was only 1 killer that was incredibly unbelievable. There are other things but I think I've wrote long enough. To conclude, this movie is one you can just put on for fun if you don't want to focus too hard on watching a movie however I feel this movie doesn't exactly know what it wants to be. Sure I will re watch it and watch the sequel that releases in 2025 I think. However I don't feel like I can give this movie anything above a 4, it doesn't come close to any original slashers like scream, Halloween, I know what you did, etc...

This is as predictable as it is poor.you will laugh through this more than you will jump or be scared.its like a combination of i know what you did last summer/final destination/scream except its not even on par with any of those films it tries to emulate. I should have switched it off to be honest but did,just,manage to see it through to its predictable ending. Ive a character limit to reach here but there is really no more to say on this movie,avoid it at all costs,watch paint dry or go cut the grass.anything is better than sitting through 105 minutes of this abysmal excuse of a horror/slasher.

Review-Title: This film didn't really grip me the way I hoped
Review-Description: I sense plot holes with the teasing of two killers. The footage of Gabby and Evan was moving before Yulia was killed, and unless the sheriff had the powers of transportation, there is no way he could have moved and changed outfits that quickly! Unrealistic and very disappointing. The ratings are way to high for this movie. I have no clue how it got such a high rating and I'm very irritated. This movie was hot garbage. I understand it had the 80s slasher feel but the acting had me like "they not even trying" Movie was all around bad from the acting to the reveal another boring slasher with no new ideas yawn.

The high reviews of this film are absurd. Obvious from the get go who the killer is, awful dislikeable boring characters, bored me to death half way through, like scream but without the history etc. Just wasn't all that enjoyable. Wouldn't recommend. The high reviews of this film are absurd. Obvious from the get go who the killer is, awful dislikeable boring characters, bored me to death half way through, like scream but without the history etc. Just wasn't all that enjoyable. Wouldn't recommend. The high reviews of this film are absurd. Obvious from the get go who the killer is, awful dislikeable boring characters, bored me to death half way through, like scream but without the history etc. Just wasn't all that enjoyable. Wouldn't recommend.

Classic. This movie is just so so fun. The narration and opening is whimsical and very interesting and even kinda tense. Then when the movie slowly dishes out it's plot gizmo is there being the cutest creature in cinema. Also in general the plot is just fun it's both tense and exciting as it slowly hints at the darker undertones of the movie. When the gremlins do come out the movie is so chaotic and random that it is hilarious, it's exactly my type of humour. The chaos and charisma of all the gremlins is hilarious, the cuteness of gizmo will never get old, the whacky inventions from the dad are always interesting and fun (and very relatable), the music is amazing, the creatures for the most part look amazing and very realistic, this is just a very entertaining and fun kids horror dark comedy Christmas movie.

Have only seen bits & pieces of this film years & years ago on TV, but haven't seen it all the way through! I saw this tonight via a re-release at my local! The film sees a young man who gets a pet Mogway as an early Christmas present from his father who is a product designer! But when the pet gets wet & starts to multiply do things start to go wrong & when they eat after midnight, is when things take a turn for the worst when the whole town becomes overrun by the mischief making, hyper active creatures! I found the film to be pretty good, while it's not typically the sort of Horror film I'd go out my way to watch, I still thought it was decent! The effects are pretty good for its time, despite being fake looking in areas & over the top! The story is alright & the characters aren't too bad despite lacking in a bit of depth! The runtime I'd say is a little long at 1 hour & 42 minutes & the pacing could've used some work too, but it wasn't bad! The deaths were entertaining & the ending was satisfying too! Overall, it's a good film! While not as horror like as I'd want it to be, it was decent overall! 6/10.

Review-Title: A wonderfully subversive (yet still accessible) holiday classic.
Review-Description: I remember loving this as a kid, liking it a little less when I watched it at about 18, and now going back to loving it again at 26. I can't explain how... maybe watching it on Christmas helped? Gremlins is an incredibly fun movie, with a satisfying buildup of a first half that explodes into extremely entertaining madness in its second half. Jumping around in tone from Spielberg sentimentality to horror to slapstick comedy to one character's weirdly tragic backstory shouldn't work, but it kind of does. The fact it's so all over the place might add to its charm. It's a well-written and constructed movie though, so while it can be gleefully messy, it's definitely not a mess. Also, the special effects are all fantastic, and have aged extremely well. I remember the sequel being almost as good, so I look forward to rewatching that sometime soon.

Review-Title: Capra-esque chaos with a Dante flavor
Review-Description: Joe Dante was moving up in the world. He'd met some good success with The Howling, caught the attention of Steven Spielberg, and got the assignment to bring the script by Chris Columbus script about mysterious little anarchic creatures at Christmas. He ended up creating one of those Spielberg-tinged films that helped to define a certain feel of 80s family films that had a slightly more dangerous hint to them while also embracing a certain Frank Capra-esque feel of neighborhoods. I wasn't of the generation that really absorbed it through childhood, not seeing it for the first time until I was well into my twenties, but I can easily see how it would affect those who grew up with it more fully than it hit me. In Chinatown, Randal Peltzer (Hoyt Axton), a hapless inventor, finds a strange creature not quite for sale in a little shop and ends up buying it from the owner's grandson, taking it home as a present for his son Billy (Zach Galligan). With his father being unable to sell any of his inventions and his mother remaining a housewife, the household is reliant on Billy's job as a clerk as a bank in the little town of Kingston Falls. He's smitten with his coworker Kate (Phoebe Cates) who also works at nights at the local bar, and he's at the mercy of Gerald (Judge Reinhold) at the bank as well as the wealthiest woman in town, Ruby Deagle (Polly Holliday), who is a mix between the Wicked Witch of the West and Mr. Potter from It's a Wonderful Life (a film we see on screen more than once). Things go wrong, of course, when Randal gives Billy the creature named Gizmo, and he starts breaking the three rules. He can keep Gizmo out of the sunlight pretty easily, but his young friend Pete (Corey Feldman) accidentally gets Gizmo wet, spawning five more little Mogwai. Billy takes one to the high school science teacher Mr. Hanson (Glynn Turman) who takes a blood sample for...reasons. But this all leads to both sets of Mogwai to getting their handlers to break the third rule, not to feed them after midnight, turning them from Mogwai to the titular gremlins. This is where the heart of the film is: Dante's combination of his love of 50s science fiction schlock with fun toys on screen with the Gremlins causing havoc wherever they go, first in the Peltzer kitchen where Randal's gadgets fill the place, giving the perfect place for Lynn (Frances Lee McCain), Billy's mom, putting one of them in a blender to wonderfully gruesome effect. The final half of the movie is just an escalating series of chaos as the Gremlins get beaten back, come back in heavily increased numbers, and just run amok all over Kingston Falls. The centerpiece really is the scene in the bar, a technical display of different puppets doing a wide assortment of Looney Tunes-inspired antics that really just gets lost in the puppetry and gags but is the most entertaining the movie gets. That's because the actual story is perfectly competently assembled by Columbus in the script and presented by Dante, but it's never really more than competent. It doesn't help that little subplots just kind of disappear like Judge Reinhold's character just not appearing in the film after about the third way mark even though he was obviously built to pay off with some kind of comeuppance in the final act. Billy doesn't really have much of an arc, which isn't a requirement in fiction (look at Marty McFly in Back to the Future), but he also doesn't have much of a goal other than survive the crazy night. Heck, it's not even really a goal to go out with Kate. He convinces her to go on a date with him before the chaos erupts. At least the chaos includes a fun ending for Mrs. Deagle, though. What drives the film is the technical side of things and the comedy, mostly stemming from the work of Dick Miller as a down and out schlub with Dante giving him room to just be himself. It all balances out to an entertaining little film somewhat in the style of Spielberg but undoubtedly Dante's with Dante wearing his influences on his sleeve. It's one of the things I like most about his movies, manifesting in this with the playing of It's a Wonderful Life to the presence of the Looney Tunes stuffed animals in the store late, Dante isn't afraid of paying explicit tribute to the movies and short films that he loved. It gives his films a young kid kind of energy that makes them surprisingly infectious, even if the actual narratives end up somewhat lackluster. Gremlins is a fun little 80s timepiece, Joe Dante's first effort to prove himself on a decently large scale, evidence that Spielberg had an eye for young talent, and an entertaining technical achievement. It really could have used another draft to both cut out some early stuff that got left on the cutting room floor in the edit and to give Billy something more of a specific goal to achieve through the chaos. Either that, or just lean far more into the chaos. Maybe the sequel will choose one of those two directions.

Review-Title: One of the Best Modern Horror Comedy Classics
Review-Description: In 1984, one of the most insane horror comedies was released by Steven Spielberg entitled Gremlins. Directed by cult filmmaker Joe Dante, the film was a huge hit with critics and audiences and is often regarded as one of the greatest horror comedies of the last 50 years. While it did gain infamy for its grotesque violence, which resulted in the PG-13 rating, it is still cherished to this day and spawned a sequel a few years later and a recent animated series on Max. As far as how the film holds up nowadays, it's probably one of the darkest comedies that works in what it set out to do thanks to its cartoony nature. The film follows a young man named Billy Peltzer who receives a strange creature from his father called a mogwai. When the mogwai spawns other creatures, they end up becoming small destructive monsters that all wreak havoc on Billy's town during Christmas Eve. At its core, Gremlins may seem like a cautionary allegory on consumerism, especially when the mogwai creatures are not to be handled by the ignorant American public. That being said, the film knows how to treat the mogwai as a proper pet in the form of Gizmo, who Billy looks after with certain restrictions like no bright lights or feeding after midnight. Once the other gremlins kick in however, that's when the film unleashes its cartoony slapstick and brutal violence on display. As gruesome and horrifying as the film may be, Dante knows to keep the balance between supernaturally scary and nonsensically humorous, so we are left laughing at the mayhem caused by the manic Gremlins as much as we are in horror of it all. There are very few films that have managed this blending of the genres as funnily as this one. In addition to Billy making for a charming lead in reacting to all the insanity, his girlfriend Kate Beringer is an added bonus to the film's sweet center. Zach Galligan and Phoebe Cates share cute chemistry with each other in lieu of all the frights, and it's easy to see them trying to make end's meet in a small town corrupted by the antagonistic miser Mrs. Deagle. While some characters don't leave as much of an impression as they could like Billy's condescending coworker Gerald Hopkins or Billy's inventor father, others like Billy's concerned mother, the cranky Murray Futterman, the experimenting science teacher Mr. Hanson or little Pete Fountaine all contribute some damage to the monsters or get the short end of the stick from them in different forms of comeuppance. Also, on top of a lot of crazy vocal effects for the gremlin creatures, Howie Mandel steals the show as Gizmo and can make even a small whistle or cry from the guy sound adorably heart wrenching. Add on a cunning performance from Frank Welker as the rebellious leader Stripe and you got one heck of a vocal cast. Now in regards to the phenomenal special effects work done on the gremlins, Chris Walas and team managed to blend cute and creepy in such a versatile manner. When one puts into consideration just how complicated the mechanics and puppetry was to pull off, it makes the film all the more spectacular just to see all the crazy stunts and pratfalls the gremlin creatures get to pull off. In many ways, the gremlins are more cartoony than any other depiction of the creatures in cartoons prior like Falling Hare or Russian Rhapsody, since the havoc wreaking chaos they ensue paints them as rambunctious teenagers going against society rather than merely strange creatures coming out of nowhere. Jerry Goldsmith's score conveys the dark humor and nonstop suspense flawlessly and John Hora's cinematography adds into the thrill of seeing strange creatures scramble from the shadows in lieu of the holiday season. Considering the influence of the Warner Bros cartoons at play, it's no wonder Dante and his crew took the chance to unleash their inner mania through the art of B-movie tributes. By blending horror and comedy with enough heart, frights and laughter all in 100 minutes, Gremlins holds up wonderfully as a modern Christmas classic. If you haven't seen this film before, you're curious about more of Dante's work or you're an overall sucker for wacky horror comedies, then this film is right up your alley. Now that the film is approaching its 40 year anniversary quite soon, there couldn't be a better time to check it out than this very moment. After all, you never know when something innocent could turn into something dangerous if one doesn't take their well being into consideration.

Review-Title: Comedy horror with entertainment, funny scenes and deft satiric edge
Review-Description: A young man inadvertently breaks three important rules concerning his new pet, Gizmo (Howie mandel voice), from a gift given by his father (Hoyt Axton). It unleashes a horde of malevolently mischievous monsters on a small town. The young couple Billy (Zach Galligan) and Kate (Phoebe Cates) will suffer several dangers attacked by the nasty Gremlins. Minature green monsters tear through the small town of Kingston Falls. Hilarious mayhem and destruction in a town straight out of Norman Rockwell. So, when your washing machine blows up or your TV goes on the fritz, before you call the repair man, turn on all the lights and look under all the beds. 'Cause you never can tell, there just might be a gremlin in your house. Gremlins appearing to cause chaos , as they don't execute the rules , neither warnings : ¬®don't expose them to bright light, don't ever get wet and don't ever , ever feed after midnight¬®. Mischievous. Intelligent. Dangerous. You can't get burned seeing 'Gremlins'! Steven Spielberg presents: Cute. Clever. Mischievous. Intelligent. Dangerous. We're Here!. What you see... isn't always what you get. The Gremlins Are Coming!.Take Your Batch to See the New Batch !. Look out , a new batch is on the way !. Here they grow again , we warned you !. Remember the rules !. You didn't listen !. Don't get him wet, keep him out of bright light, and never feed him after midnight. They didn't obey the rules. We're Back! Director Joe Dante presents a quite good and violent but far more campy vision, paying myriad surreal tribute to movies as well as soundtracks with great sense of amusement. Hijinks ensue as a mild-mannered bank teller releases these hideous loonies after gaining a new pet and violating two of three simple rules: No water (violated), no food after midnight (violated), and no bright light. Naturally, there're lots of mayhem , frolics , antics and jokes , this all happening at the town and the result is a gang of nasty gremlins who decide to tear up the houses and cinemas. This watchable enough motion picture was professionally directed by Joe Dante displaying their characteristic surrealist humor and sense of style . The story is nothing more than an amusing excuse to string together gags , silly sketches , ironical craziness , several cameos and fast-paced set pieces. Dante is surely right to let his visual imagination run along with likeable comedy, irony and great inventive. Including ¬®Snowwhite and the seven dwarfs¬® and other famous film parodies and other musical extravaganzas of the past. Also incorporates satire , takes on TV news and funny action, adding a lot of rapid-fire surreal sight gags. Along with ordinary starring : Zach Galligan and Phoebe Cates, appearing here and there a number of familiar secondaries and various cameos, such as : Polly Holliday, Belinda Balaski, Keye Luke, Frances Lee McCain, Dick Miller, Edward Andrews, Judge Reinhold, Chuck Jones, William Schallert, Harry Carey Jr, Scott Brady, Steven Spielberg, Kenneth Tobey Nicky Katt, Corey Feldman, Jonathan Banks .And musician Jerry Goldsmish who composes a lively and enjoyable score. Followed by a sequel ¬®Gremlins II¬®, it's inferior to original, set in a futuristic skyscraper in the Big Apple where the young couple: Zach Galligan, Phoebe Cates of now work for the money-grubbing tech-mogul John Glover, co-starred by Christopher Lee, Robert Prosky , Robert Picardo, Haviland Morris , Dick Miller , Raymond Cruz , Julia Sweeney , Keye Luke, Kathleen Freeman Lavishly Produced by Steven Spielberg , and professionally directed by Joe Dante, with originality enough. Dante's most hits took place when found himself working alongside Steven Spielberg, John Landis and Australian director George Miller for the anthology movie ¬®The Twilight Zone, The Movie¬® (1983) in which Dante directed the third segment . Steven Spielberg then hired him to work as director for ¬®Gremlins¬® (1984) which was another box-office success. He directed some episodes for the Sci-Fi series "Amazing Stories" before directing his next Science Fiction feature which was ¬®Innerspace¬® (1987) which, whilst critically well reviewed, was another box office failure. After directing five episodes of "Eerie, Indiana", Dante returned to the big-screen with the well-received ¬®Matinee¬® (1993), an affectionate period satire set in 1962 against the background of the Cold War. Dante spent the next several years working for television and directed a satire on politics with ¬®The Second Civil War¬® (1997) . Dante's next two films, ¬®Small Soldiers¬® (1998), and ¬®Looney Toons: Back in Action¬® (2004) garnered good reviews but were not commercial hits. Gremlins rating : 7/10.

I can't believe I've never watched this movie. I was an 80's movie kid but always steered away from the fantasy horror movies. I was more action and comedy. I wish I had watched this sooner, as it was pretty awesome. Classic Spielberg. The guy is a master at his craft and it shows here. His movies all have a similar awesome feel to them and you can sense it right away. What stood out most to me with this film was the animation. It was so good. There was some clay animation I think? Was it? But most of it was just good old puppetry and it worked. It was also hilarious. It didn't take itself too seriously and that was great. When the gremlins took over the town and chaos ensued I laughed out loud on a few occasions. I'm cautiously optimistic on the sequel! Hard to top this one!

Review-Title: Excellent Christmas Horror Comedy Movie from the year 1984
Review-Description: I find Gremlins (1984) is a very excellent Christmas Horror Comedy Movie, Because the main protagonist Billy is very likeable. Gizmo The cute and adorable mogwai is very likeable. Billy's pet dog Barney is very heroic and likeable. Billy's love interest Kate has a tragic backstory and I feel very sorry for her. The main antagonist of this movie is Stripe, Because of his chaotic nature, but he is enjoyable compared the most Hateable character of the festive movie. The most Hateable character of the festive movie is Mrs. Ruby Deagle, Because of her cruel attitude and the lack of sympathetic qualities, But She finally got her comeuppance and that made me laugh. It also have interesting cameos from Steven Spielberg to Chuck Jones. I'm giving this a 10/10 and Merry Christmas.

Review-Title: Still Enjoyable After All These Years
Review-Description: This film begins with a middle-aged inventor by the name of "Randall Peltzer" (Hoyt Axton) browsing in an antique shop owned by an old Chinese man known only as "Grandfather" (Keye Luke). While there he happens to notice a strange little animal that he had never seen before and, upon inquiring about it, is told that it is called a mogwai. Noticing how cute and friendly it appears to be, Randall offers to buy it but is told it isn't for sale. Somewhat discouraged, he leaves the store but is approached by the old man's "Grandson" (John Louie) who secretly hands the mogwai to him in exchange for the money Randall offered earlier. After eagerly accepting the deal, Randall is then informed of 3 basic rules for taking care of the mogwai--with the main rule being to never feed it after midnight. After acknowledging these 3 basic rules, Randle quickly hurries back home where he presents it to his teenage son "Billy Peltzer" (Zach Galligan) as a Christmas present. Unfortunately, not long afterward, Billy accidentally feeds it after midnight--and extreme chaos starts from that point on. Now, rather than reveal any more, I will just say that I remember being quite entertained by this movie when it first came out and, having now watched it again, I must say that it still retains most of its earlier charm. Admittedly, the CGI and special effects aren't nearly as novel or sophisticated by today's standards but, even so, this is still an enjoyable movie, and I have rated it accordingly. Above average.

I have loved this movie since I first saw it when it came out. What's so funny to me is my brother adopted 2 rescue kittens I had several years ago. He named them Gizmo and Gremlin. They definitely resemble the characters in the movie. Gizmo is sweet and wouldn't hurt anyone or another cat, but Gremlin has a temper at times and can be mean. I HAVE to watch this movie again this Christmas season üòä. Have watched it many times and it never gets old. Love the story and interaction between the characters and of course there are so many humorous moments too. Although we are all older now, it's become a family tradition.

The idea behind the movie itself is interesting, and some of the plot elements are unique and original. However, there was just too much skin for me. I had to look away for large chunks of film as things that were just not relevant to the plot were taking place on screen. Also, the director has apparently never talked to a senior citizen to know that human behavior and abilities change as one ages and becomes older. Not to give too much away, but the villains in the film did things that simply would not be likely or possible given their stage in life. It was interesting enough for me to want to watch the prequel. It was OK, but could've been better.

Though X doesn't necessarily bring anything new to the table, it's commendable in how it manages to pay homage to the films it's inspired by and also track its own path through. The cast impresses with the likes of Mia Goth, Jenna Ortega, and Brittany Snow among other familiar faces. Directed and written by Ti West, he's brought a strong premise and a diverse cast of characters to a centralized location and lets everything play out in spectacular fashion. There's some great kills in the film as well. Though not everything is fantastic (Jenna Ortega's character went out with a whimper instead of a bang, despite getting her head half-blown off), the film is greater than the sum of its parts. And as a growing part of a franchise, it's the best of the series thus far.

Review-Title: "People's eyes are gonna pop out of their damn skulls when they see this."
Review-Description:
FILM: 7/10. In Ti West's foray into the realm of classy slashers with X, he takes the genre on a highbrow escapade-well, his version of it. The film mirrors this ambition as characters embark on a quest to shoot a high-class porno, setting the stage for an unconventional yet intriguing experience. West succeeds in delivering more than your typical titillating slasher. Character development takes the spotlight, providing a depth rarely found in the genre. As the plot unfolds, it becomes evident that West is not interested in taming the horror; he aims to send shivers down your spine with graphic kills that punctuate the narrative. The performances across the board are nothing short of excellent, capturing the essence of the 1979 setting. Mia Goth shoulders the lion's share of the work, while Brittany Snow proves to be very effective. Kid Cudi, in a surprising turn, delivers an excellent performance that adds to the film's overall charm. However, the film misses an opportunity to explore a potentially compelling connection between Maxine and Pearl, two characters whose untapped dynamic could have elevated the narrative even further. Despite this, X stands as a highly entertaining and well-made horror film, showcasing West's ability to infuse sophistication into a genre often associated with gratuitous thrills. West's journey into classy horror is one worth taking. FORMAT: Blu-ray VIDEO: 9.5/10. 1080p presentation
Detail level: Excellent, Colour reproduction: Excellent, Level accuracy: Excellent, Encode: Excellent, Master condition: Excellent AUDIO: 9.5/10. DTS-HD MA 5.1 audio, Dialogue reproduction: Excellent, Soundtrack & effects clarity: Excellent, Dynamics: Excellent, Surround sound presentation: Excellent, LFE content: Excellent MOOFIEMETER: 7/10.

Review-Title: Tries to be too many things ends up being not much
Review-Description: The early scenes with the fixed long shot look perfectly 70's horror. That got my hopes up. Add in the creepy farmhouse and some decent moments of building tension along with a couple jump scares and I was thinking it was going to be quite good. The sex scenes are a bit more involved than the early horror, Friday the 13th, type movies; but it still follows the formula. Then about halfway through, it switches to the gross/icky type of horror movie. And around then it also becomes the very predictable horror movie. The main cast was actually really good. That gave me a lot of hope for the movie early on. The old couple was not good, especially the 'old' lady and their story line was also pretty bad. A key to good horror movies is wanting to yell at the main characters to not do something or to get out of there. But no matter how much I liked the main characters their deaths were so predictable and the old couple was so distracting that it ruined the shock.

It's so sad to see amazing films come out of A24, and then have to rate them next to this... whatever this is. To say this film was boring is an understatement. This film DRAGGED the entire way through. The timing of the kills was even off. Found myself skipping through the intense scenes because you can only stab someone so many times before it looses its shock value. There is a lack of plot this entire movie other than old people wanting to yoink each other, but they are too old so they need some young people to do it for them? It's also a highly unbelievable film as they have the old couple killing couples in their 20's/30's in very mobile ways but they are introduced being very pitiful and Ill. Wanted to see why "Pearl" is rated so highly and this was barley talked about. Guess we know why now.

Review-Title: If you wondered why people liked it... me too
Review-Description: There is truly nothing to this movie. I would say the greatest offense is that even if it was an "homage" to classic slashers, it adds nothing to nor does it reflect the best of the genre. There is no pay off. No suspense. It is utterly devoid of creativity. Plenty of people will say it was just a good ol tits'n'guts movie but there are legit better ones that don't pretend to be more than they are. This is that kid in class who pretends they DISCOVERED Evil Dead. It is painfully boring and when the only redeeming part (murders) comes to a head they are boring. That's this movies sin. It is boring.
