Review-Title: In "X', Tie West ventures into the slasher category, using as a reference the cinema of the revolutionary and subversive Tobe Hooper
Review-Description: In his newest film, "X', Tie West ventures into the slasher category, using as a reference the cinema of the revolutionary and subversive Tobe Hooper. More precisely, West focused on Hopper's first two films that received commercial appeal, namely " The Texas Chainsaw Massacre (1974)" and "Devoured Alive (1976)". Considered the pioneer of the slasher before "Halloween", the film that immortalized the figure of Leatherface is a unique piece in the history of cinema, and although not told a true story, as was announced at the time of its release, it had a categorical particularity in presenting a premise so terrifying and disturbing that it seemed to be a real record at times, about a brief trip between friends that had a brutal and suffocating outcome Following the shocking sick representation of human perversity, "Devour Alive" featured another ghastly plot in which an old owner of a roadside hotel killed potential guests and served them as food for his pet crocodile. Knowing the many interpretations of "The Texas Chainsaw Massacre" in the American cultural context, its impact as a landmark of visual change for horror, language, and also as a precursor to the generic elements that characterized the subgenre, Ti West arrived in his slasher subversive "X", which points a lot of inspiration to those who strongly influenced the niche, which also includes nods to "Psycho (1960)" by Alfred Hitchcock (as well as "Eaten Alive" composed), but still, manages to deliver a result clayey and authentic. In the wake that paved the way for an impressive recognition of Hooper's classic, it was the same one that also promoted controversial discussions for an archetype condemned in the film with regard to female representation. If the final girl originated from there, it was possible to observe a contradiction behind the image of the final girl, because she received that name after having all the misfortune and violence prolonged longer than other characters, and in the end, surviving. In this discursive liner, West focuses his story to talk about the search for female independence, the escape from the role played by patriarchy through Maxine (Mia Goth), the protagonist who aims for her emancipation and success as a porn film star. The year is 1978, and here we follow a group of young adults in the race to shake up the porn industry with a feature film with a more elaborate and authorial language than what productions used to deliver at the time. "X" is divided into two parts with very different tones. In the first, by the way, the best of them, there is the construction of a great atmosphere of expectation. In the midst of preparing the ground for a carnage announced from the first scene - basically, the entire plot is one big flashback -, Ti West displays several signs of intertextuality, that is, how much he will drink from the fertile sources of his reference. One of them is Psycho (1960), a film by Alfred Hitchcock cited as one of the favorites of the director's character with artistic ambitions, one who is committed to making "quality porn". Later on, when the killing begins, the appearance of the car partially submerged in the lake is a creative way of diversifying the nod to good old Hitchcock's masterpiece, now with something from the film manifesting itself in the narrative fabric. Therefore, intertextuality has distinct layers and ways of being. Another of them is the reappropriation of a slasher commonplace: sexual rage as an indication of who is going to die. Even the two characters who don't have sex end up dying brutally. But what changes here is the motivation of the villains. Out comes the pure juice of abstract redneck moralism and in comes sexual repression enhanced by the messianic discourse of religious people who contribute to this repression. The script signed by West points out that this violence has a source. The second part of "X" is the massacre itself. But, before talking about it, it is good to consider the curious figure of murderous hosts. Pearl (Mia Goth) and Howard (Stephen Ure) are isolated people, emotionally trapped in a distant time of glory. However, beyond this aspect that helps to contextualize the murderous rage, there is an aesthetic choice by Ti West: the clearly fake makeup that transforms two relatively young actors into cachectic elderly people. This choice is part of an apparently deliberate movement towards the artificial, a wink at the audience regarding the purely cinematic nature of what they are watching - there are many other moments in which the plot asks us to turn off disbelief and adhere to artifice. When the old men take action, the story plunges into a spiral of more or less predictable brutal deaths until only the final girl remains - a famous narrative trope in horror productions, the survivor who faces the evildoers last and who (usually) is left to tell the story. Therefore, adherence to models established by other films takes place within a new layer of intertextuality, with tradition serving as a source of nourishment and emotional inspiration. As for slave deaths, it is therefore not a question of "if" they will happen, but of "when" and "how". West's filmic structure, which is configured by the slow way in which the narrative is conducted, valuing how language can tell a story, gains points in the way in which the premise unfolds, thus showing planning (and not the sensation as in other works, from the potential being with you in favor of chaotic twists) to having pornography as a background on the female independence that "X" discusses, in addition to the degradation of humanity in the face of banal repressions and vanities. The title of the film follows the beauty of the mystery that is Maxine, being referred to as an x-factor, a difference, someone of notable and special quality. The character is enigmatic, with few dialogues, but who does not spare herself when she needs to impose her personality and preferences, and there is a shock in this profile when she is close to Pearl, the scary lady, who runs the farm alongside her husband, Howard (Stephen Ure). The way Pearl is presented draws attention due to the setting's always dim lighting, her intimidating posture and her undeniable feeling of being seduced by Maxine. While the young woman's search, in which each decision is a consequence of the strength and success of her autonomy, is what defines her trajectory, for Pearl, facing a woman who in her own youth exudes freedom, confronts her denial, bitterness and dissatisfactions that hide in her idyllic farm. Giving more strength to this dichotomy, her names become an allegory in how Pearl (pearl) sees herself, with Maxine (maximum) being the example of achievement that she did not achieve, although her name refers to something precious, lasting. Therefore, Eliot Rockett's photography was fundamental for maintaining a careful play of shadows to manifest a character lost in repressed feelings. Still on the technical side, photography and costumes stand out in recreating an atmosphere that takes us directly to the films of the 70s to this "X" - everything looks like a vintage filter). And before I say that everything seems too "artificial" or "decorated", Ti West brings out the great cast who, super comfortable in their roles, make the fun happen. The script and the construction of the characters have weight in this, with the twist that the protagonist's plot undergoes in the last moments being one of the best moments of this creation. The discussion between puritanism and "sin", a classic slasher subplot, is turned inside out by a body of well-developed characters and highlighted in excellent dialogues that subvert the roles traditionally imposed by society - something that is not surprising to us, given that it seems We are much more likely to see coherence and integrity in a bunch of porn artists than in "church rats" and religious conservatives in general. By openly gesturing to the slasher audience with such clear affiliations to the subgenre's conventions, Ti West doesn't seem concerned with the predictability factor. After the first murder takes place, the feature film simply relies on the construction of the graphic aspect of the deaths, losing a little interest in the atmosphere of suspense that had created such an interesting and rich panel in its first half. The games with the supposed clandestinely of pornographic films, with the artistic intentions of the jealous beginner filmmaker, with the clich√©s linked to the performers of productions for adult consumption, with the stereotyping of almost caricatural villains and even with the texture of the image, come out. A sequence of savage eliminations of outsiders linked to cinema. Among these deaths, there are some filmed with ingenuity and very well calculated touches of cruelty - like the lady stabbing someone until the knife gets stuck in a vertebra. There are others that are practically jokes with certain recurrences of terror - like someone who clearly shouldn't look into the holes in a stable wall. But, overall, this somewhat repetitive carnage (brief isolation of the character about to die plus conclusion with touches of nonsense) serves as much as its intertextuality weighs, the balance of which is the commotion provoked through the sharing of familiarity with the pillars from slasher.

Review-Title: More creepy than scary, elevated by performances
Review-Description: At times it feels like a film school project, at times it is really good, but mostly it's creepy more than scary. Starts off like an 80's porno but lacks real feeling or meaning. It's a mcguffun (a term even mentioned in the film). Ok some pretty hot bodies but it's as sexy as making a porno probably is. The farmer and his wife are excellently cast and again creepy as F. Brittany Snow, Jenna Ortega and Mia Goth do great jobs of very archetypal characters with little story. Snow's singing is also impressive. However the switch into horror/slasher mode lacks scarriness, you know what's going to happen and it lacks suspense. Yeah it has referential scenes like the window in psycho, the "here's Johnny" scene from the Shinning, the lake and pier from Friday the 13th and others, but they are more like signposts than adding anything. Also the male actors, apart from the farmer, don't add much other than cannon fodder. Again archetypal characters but lacking the depth the girls bring. And it just gets crepier and well yuck near the end. The ending has a nice twist though. So for the performances and parts of the movie it is good but let down by execution, lack of suspense and just being a bit too ick for me. So it's a slasher 80's flick made for our times, a decent time waster but not a classic you will want to watch again and again.

Review-Title: X is unique for sure, but it didn't necessarily work for me.
Review-Description: Finally got around to watching Ti West's highly acclaimed film 'X,' and I have mixed feelings about it. It definitely boasts a fantastic retro vibe and a creepy, dreamlike atmosphere that lingers with you. There's a palpable sense of unease and impending doom throughout, which I absolutely loved. Additionally, Mia Goth delivers a stupendous performance in both her roles as Pearl and Maxxine. Her character, Pearl, is undeniably creepy and scary. The movie also features some brilliantly unhinged kills. However, the film does suffer from a disjointed narrative and, at times, feels like a parody. It gives the impression of being a collection of scenes rather than a cohesive movie. Furthermore, there are moments where it seems to strive for excessive artistry, which can be overwhelming.

To be honest, I don't see any potential in the story as a serial or slasher, the film is imitated solidly I would praise the production for that as for Mia Goth's role playing, all talent, this girl can play anything would say the same for Jenna Ortega but i give mia goth the win in this movie unlike with the story of the film, the course of the film, I am disappointed the movie doesn't make any sense like the middle of the movie is missing or would fall asleep every 2 minutes as a slasher film or a horror or thriller, it does not deserve this title at all A24 production has certain good films this is really the worst horror this year for my taste.

Review-Title: Fans did it better... Try watching the Fazbear Frights fan version...
Review-Description: I watched the original back on Halloween Day in the cinemas (fan of the franchise since 2014), and I think while the movie was good, it wasn't much of a Five Nights at Freddy's. The only thing reminding its material was the animatronics and that's it. I was bored because despite some clues reminding of the game this pretty much was a generic ghost children film, and due to that some scenes were unwatchable due to the audio (at least for me, it felt so out of place with the score choice that killed the vibe). However, I was lucky that previews of a Re-edited version came in my way on YouTube and I reached out the editor to watch a copy of a fanedit called "Fazbear Frights Edition". To my surprise, it didn't change much to the original besides some extended kills and reconstructed moments for being more accurate to what we grew up with, but details like more Easter Eggs and the use of fanmade quality soundtrack MADE IT A BLAST! The only reason I'm writting this review is because Blumhouse or Universal should hire this editor! He managed to save this after all! Not bored at any moment, reconstructed atmosphere - A ROLLER COASTER BALANCING BETWEEN HORROR AND NOSTALGIA! So, my rating for the original is 5 out of 10, but for the fanedit 8 out of 10. Will definitely watch again. And now here's my question, how could a fan execute it better in a couple of months than a studio working on it for 9 years?

Review-Title: Five Nights at Freddy's: One of the biggest let downs of 2023
Review-Description:
Plot A troubled security guard begins working at Freddy Fazbear's Pizza. During his first night on the job, he realizes that the night shift won't be so easy to get through. Pretty soon he will unveil what actually happened at Freddy's. Cast Passable hand Josh Hutcherson leads while flanked by Matthew Lillard whose appearance is making me feel old! Other notable names include Mary Stuart Masterson and Michael P. Sullivan. Verdict I'm a hardcore gamer but I'll be honest with you I never got on the Five Nights at Freddy's train. In fact I've probably played one of the games and for a total of 10-15 minutes, I loved the idea but the execution never gripped me in fact I never really "Got" them which frustrates me. The concept however was fit for a movie but video game adaptations are historically dreadful in the vast majority of instances so any logical person will go in assuming the worst and I did. However much like the games I really wanted to like it, this to me was one of the most anticipated movies of 2023 and I went in with fingers crossed. Alas I didn't expect nor want it to feel like less of a horror film and more of a strange melodrama. Now I'm not aware of the lore behind Five Nights at Freddy's so I don't know how accurate it is but I really didn't like the plot so with that wrapped around the melodrama elements it made for a film that failed to get my attention. When the action kicks in it looks, adequate but the kills were lacking and there just wasn't enough of it. Also for an adaptation of the most famous jump scares video game, there weren't many scares let alone jump ones. FIve Nights at Freddy's is a heartbreaking disappointment and I hoped for so very much more. Rants I weirdly hoped that after watching this it would give me the kick up the backside to really sit down and invest some time into the games. Alas instead I fear more disappointment so think I'll lay that idea to rest. There's enough disappointment in the gaming world at the moment without me going looking for it. Breakdown Looks the part
Matthew Lilliard is decent here
Hutcherson always looks like he's bored
Weak kills
Pants plot
Too much melodrama.

I loved it! It had a great storyline, and I overall loved all the characters. I do think it could've been a little bit less drawn out. I think it's a great movie to sit down and watch with your 10 to 14-year-old. It's not very gory, nor does it have anything too horribly bad, but for someone in my perspective, I was very disappointed that in some points it wasn't very accurate to the game Gore wise because if you're a fan of five nights at Freddy's like me, I really wanted the movie to not hold back but it's definitely a movie for preteens they're not quite ready for a real horror, movie,. But passed all that I really enjoyed the movie, and I would definitely stand and watch it again.

I have been a fnaf fan since 2018. And now we finally have a movie about it! So I watched the movie on October 27 and it was a mixed movie, I liked the fnaf movie. I just wish it was more horror and maybe less story, there should have been more security camera scenes like in the game and flashback scenes and more of a nostalgia soundtrack, and make the movie like a PG-13 horror movie vibe. As a horror movie it's a 4/10 but as a fnaf movie 8/10 the movie is a pretty good movie for fans to enjoy like me, The horror scenes and the final battle with William afton was very good I recommend this :).

Review-Title: Good movie, not so great adaption...
Review-Description: The cinematography and a few of the actor/actresses acting was great, but there are multiple problems. First of all, we now have a game adaption of the lore, and book, AND a movie adaptation. They're all different and that just makes the story even more confusing. The main characters I really didn't think were played or written well were Vanessa, Abby, and the ghost kids. The acting wasn't the best with them, and I get their kids but Vanessa was just straight up written horribly. Josh Hutcherson did a great job playing Michael Schmidt, and his character wasn't written terribly but besides him and maybe the villains, the acting and writing wasn't great. Now Matthew Lillard was amazing, wished he had more screen time but his acting was phenomenal, and his lines were written perfectly. I won't get into too much detail with the story but here's the basics, Mike gets a job, people break in for money and to get him fired so evil aunt can take custody over his sister, Abby, and the evil aunt is a smoking addict and is pure evil. Then after they attempt to get him fired they all die from the animatronics, and Mike meets Vanessa and gets left off with a warning. They all slowly find out that "Steve Raglin," or, better known as, William Afton, took Mike's younger brother Garret and killed multiple children in the 80's. It's later revealed that he's Vanessa's dad, and then he gets spring locked. Boom, the whole movie right there. Now let me explain the game lore, (idk the books) and you'll see the difference. William Afton, Belle Afton, Elizabeth Afton, Michael Afton, and Evan/Chris Afton (we don't know his name those are just assumptions) are all a family, William is friends with a dude named Henry Elizabeth, which together they make a business titled, "Fredbear's Family Diner." William's son was scared of the animatronics, and that was good, since he wanted to make sure that he didn't go near them since they were dangerous, but he wanted to make sure that he was terrified of them so hr had his older brother, Michael Afton, scare him with them. Michael took it too far though, and placed Evan/Chris, in Fredbear's mouth. Before I continue I'd like to say there are two animatronics, Fredbear and Spring Bonnie. Now continuing on the story, his whole frontal lobe gets bitten off and he enters a coma in the hospital, (fnaf 4) and William is very mad with Michael. Next one to die is Elizabeth Afton. William made a new establishment named Sister Location. Or at least the game is titled that. There are four animatronics, Circus Baby, Ballora, Funtime Foxy, and Funtime Freddy. Then there's Ennard which is an animatronic that was made by the other animatronics. Elizabeth gets lured by Circus Baby, closer to her, with Ice Cream, so she can scoop her. Scooping is when a claw that's supposed to hand out ice cream, reaches out from their stomach and grabs a child. She got scooped and killed. Then Williams wife Belle died to Ballora, William got spring locked in a Spring Bonnie suit because ghost children that he murdered were chasing him (this was at a newer establishment that came after an improved establishment, that was after sister location. The one after sister location was Freddy Fazbear's Pizza, where a security guard there got his frontal lobe bitten off by an animatronic named mangle. (the bite of 87) And the one after that is where he got spring locked. The new Freddy Fazbear's pizza. (Aka fnaf 1) Then the last one to die was Michael Afton, who got scooped in between the years 1993 and 2023. So there you go. Two completely different stories but it's the same franchise. That's the main reason this movie wasn't an 8, 9, or 10/10. That was all, bye bye! üòÉ

Review-Title: If you don't know the lore... you'll miss the point
Review-Description:
Video game movie finally made for fans! If you don't want to invest the time in the games, watch the "Game Theory" four part FNAF timeline series on YouTube for a quick, dark, and mind bending story before watching the movie and it'll change your perspective. *Spoiler Alert* for some reason they switched character rolls. (in movie) They made Vanessa, William Afton's daughter where in game she's an innocent person used to fill the roll of a murdered girl to her grieving mother NOT the daughter of the murderer...
and Mike (in game cannon William Afton 'the murderer's son)...
Was mad an unsuspecting third party who's brother was killed by Afton in movie. Confused? K, you're normal. A video game movie made for fans, finally!

It's a good movie but it could be a bit longer. Plus isn't that scary. Now to the Pros of the movie, the animatronics look great! Even Sparky and the Spring Bonnie costume looks good! The part where the robbers break in and die was also great, Short but great! Also the start where the old night guard dies is good but not perfect, Also would have loved to see Markiplier but that was cut. Not 10/10 because the plot is not that good. Oh yes and the jumpscares, they were good but not effective and the balloon boy jumpscares were a bit scary on my first watch through but not any more though of course because I expect them now. And the red eyes aren't as bad as people thought well there only there for a few scenes. And there done if there's anything else you want to hear about it check other reviews now thinking about it no one reads through them so this is kinda pointless but eh.

I was quite pumped to see this! I haven't played the game but I was aware of it. However the trailer for this movie certainly looked like something I would be into! I toughed it out for slightly over an hour and had to turn it off! I was beyond bored to be really honest. It was a whole lot of repetitive, snooze fest scenes! I was expecting much more given the great cast list I am a fan of Josh, Elizabeth and Matthew. But I was very unimpressed by the movie overall. I was intrigued still with 1/2 questions which I asked someone that had watched it all for! And when they answered my questions I can truthfully say I'm glad I didn't bother to finish it! Complete waste of time.

A young man in debt takes a job as a security guard in a restaurant. The robot dolls there have apparently developed a life of their own. Note: I haven't played the underlying game so I can't make any comparisons. If you ignore the opening scene, there is initially little that suggests a horror film. It's more like stripped-down drama elements that dominate the film, at least in the first half hour. The scenes that are supposed to be really frightening often fail to have an impact, especially since there is almost no blood shown. In general, the plot feels more geared towards the mystery genre, as does the personal story of the protagonist. The ending, despite the fact that it seems contrived, is watchable. Somehow the film manages to entertain - at least once.

Review-Title: Good, if you go into it with low expectations.
Review-Description: I didn't watch this right away like most fnaf fans, and was informed that it was going to be more like a comedy. Going into this movie with low expectations actually made the movie more enjoyable than it would have if I went in expecting a horror show. Overall, the movie was alright. This script felt kind of off, and all over the place, but the acting was actually alright, and the soundtrack was a total banger. The scariest part about this movie is balloon boy. That dude made me scream when he came on screen. This movie felt like a comedic treat to old fnaf fans, and I personally enjoyed watching it.

Idk, i thought this movie is good bcs the rating is high for horror movie. But after i watched, i got nothing want to say. Just the same as other mediocre horror movies. Teenagers did something stupid, got terror from demon, some characters dies, and just like that. And how they using make up for the demons is kinda basic i guess. They can make more disturbing make up for the demons, maybe i can add more high rating for this movie. I think they just wanna to save budget. And last, this movie never makes where this game appeared for the first time and how that can makes the devil summoned.....

Review-Title: Great Concept Undone by a Terrible Protagonist
Review-Description: The first half of this movie is incredibly effective with the concept of a bunch of teenagers having a real medium to communicate with the dead and filming themselves use it just for a laugh. Then one of their uses of the medium goes too far and problems arrive, that is great stuff. But everything that happens after the possession gone awry is a bunch of predictable nonsense. It also doesn't help that the main character is so unlikeable and selfish that you don't care whether she lives or dies. It is not properly established if she is being controlled by demons but that's the only thing that could excuse her terrible decisions which could have just as easily been driven by a selfish desire to speak with her mom above all other peoples safety. I didn't hate watching this but the potential was there for something great and it was just not executed well at the half way point.

I should have known better than to expect some random Netflix horror to truly be excellent but based on the relatively positive reviews and claims how fresh the movie felt I was, admittedly, pretty optimistic going into it. What I got was okay, but I really don't see what's so special about this film versus every other spirit-communication-gone-wrong genre piece before this. On the surface this hand gimmick as the method of spirit communion seems fresh, but really it's just replacing the worn out Ouija board trope summons something evil with another communication mechanism. After that the rest of the movie falls in line with your typical story beats in relative lockstep. The final sin for me is the movie is frankly just not very scary. I never jumped, I was never creeped out, I was never really intrigued - but at least I was never really bored so there's that.

I found this movie to be pretty effective in how it's executed. The story is interesting with teenagers able to contact spirits with a mysterious embalmed hand. I really like the idea of holding a mysterious hand to contact spirts and then say "I let you in" so it possessed that person. It really shows how it is a bad idea to do those types of things and how they affect someone. The movie is also a subject matter of grief and obsession with the main character losing her mother and wanting to contact her. It really shows how far someone can do in order to talk to a loved one again. The movie also works as a psychological horror with the main character struggling with her grief and obsession towards her mother and that hand throughout. It also affects her mental health and cause her to do some extreme stuff later on in the movie. The ending itself is pretty good on how it ends.

Review-Title: A Refreshing and Enjoyable Horror Film with Strong Performances and Creative Storytelling
Review-Description: Talk to Me is an incredibly enjoyable watch, offering a breath of fresh air for both the horror genre and filmmaking in general. As a true directorial debut from Michael Philippou and Danny Philippou, it stands out as a great success. The film introduces a new and creative idea with a fun and energetic style, although there are some minor bumps along the way. The immersive world-building captivates viewers instantly, evoking a sense of wonder. The characters, portrayed by a talented cast, are relatable with both their strengths and flaws. Sophie Wilde's standout performance handles complex emotions with finesse. The scares are well-executed, avoiding cheap thrills and are instead blended seamlessly into the narrative. While some moments may elicit a humorous reaction depending on the viewing situation, the overall experience is enjoyable. The film strikes a balance in exploring its storyline without overexplaining or underexploring, which I feel is a great choice. Certain sequences are difficult to watch due to some intense and gruesome violence; however, I believe that because the film makes you feel this way, it adds to the experience and showcases the brilliance of how the film is crafted. Overall, it was a great film, and I would recommend everyone give it a chance.

This movie is a rare gem. It's been a long time since there was a horror movie this well made. Iam a big fan of really scarry horror. I can't stand artsy horror or slow burners. Lately that has been all that has been made. But this one stands out for real. A new take on the classic invited evil spirit. We follow a group that looses control. The tension builds up as all things goes south. It's refreshing with all of these never seen before actors. We get thrown between the different realities and its hard to know what is reality and what's not. This stands out as a really top movie these last years.

I was really excited for this movie as it was quite hyped up. As soon as the movie was on discount, I grabbed it. The premise is pretty cool, it's sort of refreshing. Apart from that, the movie is your usual horror flick. It's a decent one, but not shockingly good or groundbreaking. You turn it off, think "cool", and it's gone. No longer in mind. If you search for a horror movie for people who're not used to watching scary movies, this will be a very good choice. In my view, it's not that good of a choice for horror movie fans - at least if you want something special, the cherry on your sundae.

Review-Title: Those darn kids and their groovy party-drugs!
Review-Description: The end of the year 2023 is approaching as I'm writing this user-comment, and - as usual - many website and magazines are publishing their annual "best of" lists and rankings. The Aussie made "Talk to Me" appears in practically every list, and quite high to boot, so I tried to squeeze it into my viewing schedule before the year is over. As too often the case, sadly, I must say I'm not overly impressed with it, although admittedly it does contain a few original elements and two or three genuinely frightening and shocking moments. One of the original elements is the basic premise. In "Talk to Me", demonic/spiritual possession is presented as the newest hype in party-drug sensation. Forget taking pills or sniffing gas. It's sufficient to grab the embalmed hand relic and say the titular words, and you go into a trance where you get hallucinations of the ghosts of random deceased people that make you do all sorts of crazy stuff. The spectators obviously film everything with their smartphones and put it on YouTube or Instagram. Evidently, this is bound to go wrong, and it does when teenager Mia learns that one of her friends gets in contact with the ghost of her dead mother during his trance. Mia breaks the "rules" of the possession's maximal duration, and it has extremely painful consequences for the medium. The idea is good, Sophie Wilde's performance is intense, and there are a couple of excruciatingly agonizing moments you won't forget very soon (featuring a teenager's face and a table), but there too many defaults and unanswered questions. For me, at least. Where does the embalmed hand come from? Why aren't there any adults aware of the new hype even though it's all around the internet? I'm sure these questions, and several more unasked ones, will be answered in a long franchise of sequels, prequels, spin-offs. I will watch those eventually, of course, but I was still hoping for a more satisfying original. In this genre, I liked "Smile" better.

I've heard that most YouTuber movies/horror movies (or whatever) AREN'T that good, but this one is actually AMAZING! (For a horror movie, AND a YouTuber horror movie). Positives: The movie is VERY creepy and VERY scary which obviously horror movies are SUPPOSED to be, sadly not all horror movies success by doing that. The movie doesn't focus that much on jumpscares but more fear and suspense, which i like A LOT. The acting in the movie is very good. Especially for teen horror acting/acting for a teen horror movie, and just acting in general. The movie is creative and the story is good. The movie has a good and unexpected ending. The movie has a good length. Not too long of a movie, not too short of a movie. The movie has a good main character who you can root for. The movie has good characters. The movie has a very simple concept. The movie is VERY good for being a horror movie. The dialogue in the movie is good. The movie is fun and enjoyable to watch. Negatives: This movie MIGHT work out as a sequel (yes, they are planning to do one) but a sequel might also NOT work out. I hope that you can understand why after you've watched this movie. The movie can be a bit slow sometimes but still good and enjoyable. Sometimes, but just SOMETIMES the acting can fall a bit flat.

I was originally looking forward to this flic in that it had great reviews. The story seemed interesting with a lot of potential. Noticing it was Austilian didn't necessarily damper my intentions. Foreign movies (in English) can be harder to follow at times but still worth it. This was pretty much fast talking, jive talking gen Z hipster dialogue. Scares are far in between. Lots of boring crying and talking interspersed with sleeping, foot sucking, etc. Yeah I know there's a story here about pain and regret too, but it just doesn't seem to work. The screen play is to broken up. Maybe just to much fast jive talk or something. The very ending wasn't bad but getting there was tedious.

Movie Title: The Killing of a Sacred Deer (2017)
Review-Description: So very bad. I'd rate this a negative score if I could. The script, the dialog and direction is so very bad. Such a waste of talented actors like Colin Farrell and Barry Keoghan, even Nicole Kidman. These "artistic" horror movies are all bad. The Witch, Hereditary, Midsommar and this trash are all alike. The stories and direction are awful and it's so hard to believe that anyone finds these movies remotely interesting. Let alone good. I won't watch another movie by Yorgos Lanthimos again. If you want to watch an odd film that was done very well, go watch The Banshees of Inisherin. Martin McDonagh is a masterful filmmaker that highlights the talents of all the actors in that film, Keoghan in particular.

Movie Title: The Killing of a Sacred Deer (2017)
Review-Title: Terrible, God Awful Movie. I wasted two hours I'll never get back
Review-Description: This was a god awful film. A terrible plot with so many holes, you're literally saying to yourself "WTF?!?" every 3 minutes. Nothing made sense, nothing was explained. The only reason why I kept watching was to see if they even answered any of the questions. And the answer is no. Watching this film will leave you frustrated, angry, tired, and jealous that you didn't watch literally anything else. I sincerely regret even trying to watch this movie. I only thought it might be worthwhile due to the actors attached to it, but I will never watch another Yorgos Lanthimos film ever, ever again. What a piece of crap.

Movie Title: The Killing of a Sacred Deer (2017)
Review-Description: My Reaction / Review for The Killing of a Sacred Deer (2017): 20 minutes in and the movie has a really creepy vibe. Martin is obsessed with Steven, it seems unhealthy. Martin's mom started licking Steven's fingers, so awkward and creepy. I guess both mom and son are creepy. Martin thinks that his mom and Steven would be a great couple, that's so weird, Steven has a family and he is married. What happens to his son's legs? Martin wants Steven to kill a member of his family? He is nuts. Steven's daughter is in love with Martin? Thard disturbing, he is such a creep. Now Steven's daughter is sick too? I wonder if somehow Martin is responsible for this. Martin says to Anna that his mother and Steven have a romantic relationship? Such a liar. Steven's coworker, the anesthesiologist is a creep too it seems, disgusting. Steven is having a mental breakdown. Martin is now Steven's prisoner? I didn't see that coming, nice. The question still remains, how did the kids get sick? This family is completely falling apart. What the hell is Steven doing to his family? Is he about to kill them? He killed his son? What the hell was that ending? What's the meaning behind all of it? Why the kids got sick? Why Kim got healthy after Bob's death? Sounds like nonsense to me... Overall the movie is entertaining and disturbing but the ending ruined it for me. My rating is 7.4/10.

Movie Title: The Killing of a Sacred Deer (2017)
Review-Description: This film is a total trip - can't believe I haven't heard of it until now. I felt it was hard to get past the stilted/robotic way everybody spoke in the beginning - I'm assuming that was purposeful. And there were small gaps in the story - which again, I'm assuming was intentional and was up the the viewer to sort out. Everything eventually smoothed out and the perceived iciness amongst the family and friends became easier to translate. I'm hit & miss w/this creator's past films and this film falls somewhere in the middle. However - the casting was expertly done and it's a true testament to Kenough's talents watching him play someone much younger than his actual years, and still scare the crap out of you. This actor is also new to my awareness and I'm 'chasing' his work so I can watch more of him. He plays such odd characters - all different in their own right - but all still odd. I have to wonder if he is actually ON the spectrum and that's what makes him and his mannerisms so unique.

Movie Title: The Killing of a Sacred Deer (2017)
Review-Title: Lanthimos perfectly presents a constant psychological horror and a fantasy drama with a a discreet biblical context and also based on Greek tragedy Iphigenia
Review-Description: The film is a retelling of the Greek tragedy Iphigenia. In the text written by Euripides around 2,400 years ago, King Agamemnon kills a sacred deer during a hunt and thus incurs the wrath of the goddess Artemis, who demands a sacrifice from him: he must kill his daughter Iphigenia, or the winds will not leave the ships of the king to set sail to wage war in Troy. For Agamemnon, it was a very difficult, almost impossible choice. Lanthimos updates the dilemma (the first scene, of a heart beating during surgery, indicates in a very literal way that Steven takes other people's lives into his hands - more than he would like or feel prepared to do, in fact). Above all, the director renews the foundations of Euripides' text - in his own deeply uncomfortable, and also fascinating, way. The atmosphere established by Lanthimos around these characters has the desired instigating effect, however, unlike "The Lobster", in which the eccentricity of the ensemble still allowed space for broader issues to be explored - such as incommunicability, loneliness or brokenness. Of the pre-established concepts that guide romantic relationships - here the filmmaker offers an exercise in style that seems to end in itself. Something that would be valid if "The Killing of a Sacred Deer" was assumed as such from the beginning. The feeling that remains, however, is that, with each shot, Lanthimos aims for something much more complex. The erudite soundtrack, the traveling shots through the corridors, the enigmatic close-ups, the abrupt cuts, everything suggests a gravity, an air of importance, that never materializes. There is a clear attempt to impose a metaphysical meaning, see Martin's never-explained "powers", to this bourgeois guilt that befalls Steven's family, proving liable to divine punishment - the reaffirmation of the contrast of the Murphys' wealthy life with the boy's modest reality denotes this. However, such intentions never surpass the barrier of Lanthimos's provocative impetus, which ends up undermining the possibility of deeper reflections in favor of the need to create moments of shock, almost always effective, but often gratuitous - from the opening shot that shows a real cranioplasty to Alicia Silverstone's short cameo as Martin's mother. The tense climax, with echoes of "Gratuitous Violence (1997)", by Michael Haneke, whose latent nihilism exerts a great influence on Lanthimos, summarizes well the qualities and weaknesses of "The Killing of a Sacred Deer". Because, despite being impactful at first, it ends up not resonating with the imagined force, leaving an almost indifferent void. The visual strategy of Lanthimos and director of photography Thimios Bakatakis contributes to the effectiveness of this strange universe, obviously, the constant use of wide angles that not only deform the scenes on their sides but also expand them in their depth, leaving the characters even smaller and more fragile (and the fact that they are normally displaced to a lower quadrant of the plane is another fabulous language resource). Lanthimos creates an aseptic, hollow universe that gives voice to the muted feelings he tries to convey, so that the most important feelings here-guilt and revenge-come into natural focus. His use of an extreme plong√©e on the hospital staircase where Steven works, after a still camera sequence, is particularly beautiful, poetically combining with the existential emptiness and apathy of Farrell's character. Embodying Kubrick, the director uses and abuses symmetrical takes and tracking shots which, despite functioning as what Americans would call eye candy, often do not seem to have greater functions than the decorations they are, which only contributes to distract the viewer and give a longer duration than the tape needed to be. Furthermore, sometimes the script devolves into excessively expository texts that break the subtlety of the narrative presented. Particularly unnecessary moments are those that expose the question of culpability, making obvious what had already been marked between the lines. These are, perhaps, the only moments in which Lanthimos bows to the "need for explanations" that permeates productions that intend to go beyond their market niche, something that also briefly marks "The Lobster". It's understandable and doesn't discredit the experience, but it's a habit that the director would do well to suppress in future works to embrace once and for all the weird and bizarre side, as in "Dogtooth". The first relevant point to consider here is that it hovers between psychological horror and a fantasy drama. The award-winning script by Lanthimos and Filippou is fundamental in the slow but progressive construction of this tension, at a pace of psychological horror: it is designed to never leave the audience relieved. Even though nothing is said explicitly, forcing the viewer to search their heads for explanations for what would be happening on the screen. It is very interesting how the dialogues gradually gain drama in their tone, as the characters, small and lonely in the midst of plans that oppress them, fall into despair. Only then do we realize that the film is the agonizing story of a reckoning that borders on the surreal - and karmic. Lanthimos chooses not to provide definitive answers about his proposal. However, without this harming the development of the given topic. Its direction is dry, direct, and does not fail to show violence. The soundtrack plays an important role, as at some points in the film it increases in volume until it becomes distressing to be in the armchair watching that situation. The dialogues between the characters are devoid of emotions. Lanthimos manages to reveal to the viewer how forced and even ridiculous the repeated dialogues between people are to the point of being empty words. When Martin, the dead patient's son, begins to demand more of Steven's presence, we realize that the film goes further, creating chaos in the doctor's life that begins a chain of questioning about the attitudes of all the characters present. The plot has great surprises that deserve to be preserved, so that the viewer can really get into it. Blood is an essential element in Lanthimos' film. It appears in the first scene, is mentioned as Kim's menstruation, is involved in violence, and even in the appearance of a simple ketchup. The blood refers to Christ, to the innocence of the sacrificed deer, at the same time as it is involved in violence between men. Science, in the context of the film, serves as a counterpoint to Nature: by using it, someone who should value life destroyed one out of ego and irresponsibility. Therefore, the entire film seems to be an angry response from Nature or from some undefined deity that charges those who act in the name of the illusory power that Medicine can give to control life. Ultimately, the film reveals a disturbing coldness in its characters' decisions. With a plot that involves the viewer in doubt about the sequence of events, in "The Killing of a Sacred Deer" it is possible to be carried away by the anguish of trying to understand how fantastic the story goes and remain thinking about the film after the session. The film's atmosphere now has a discreet biblical context (hence the maxim "God gives and God takes away"), but still maintains certain characteristics of a Greek tragedy (and the symbolisms that refer to the sacrifice and dilemma of a man in conflict are examples). Steven Murphy, as the man of science, is rendered powerless by being just a man in the hands of mysterious forces; His profession becomes useless in saving his family (a detail that is, to say the least, ironic). Martin, as a result, gains the image of an Old Testament God, charged with wrath. If his father died in surgery, Steven will then need to sacrifice someone (the "sacred deer") to balance everything. In fact, these details are absolutely interesting, as they are already anticipated through the wide-angle camera angles. She, at various times, remains above Steven, as if she were God. Perhaps Lanthimos' genius lies in making surgery the film's great metaphor (it is cold and precise). Not only is Steven as cold as his profession, but the film's atmosphere, soundtrack, dialogue and acting are also cold. Everything is cold, latent and little demonstrated. Any coldness is on purpose, as that is what the director wanted to create. Notice how everything, so inexpressive, ends up "expressing" terror and pessimism. Coldness is what defines "The Killing of a Sacred Deer". As stable, calculated and "surgical" as its system is, a simple crooked line or a crescendo of music can be the prelude to chaos. And this film walks a fine line. The film ends on the right note, almost with symmetry, matching the coldness of its introduction. The heart of the first scene connects with the sacrifice in the Murphy family (but in different senses). His conclusion indicates that Martin is the representation of God. In the last scene, he is sitting on a bench in a restaurant, and is not even seen by the Murphys (except for Kim, who gives him a look). He is like God: he is there, he is felt, but he is not seen. There is no more sacrifice, and that family no longer owes you anything. Everything then ends.

Movie Title: The Killing of a Sacred Deer (2017)
Review-Description: We are pulled in by this odd pair, trying to figure out what their relationship is. It's intriguing but that's as good as the movie gets. As soon as we find out how they are connected the movie becomes pretty bland. Everyone in this movie speaks and acts like they have Asperger's. It was interesting at first to see them interact with a monotone voice and no filter but it starts to feel ridiculous the more the movie goes on. We never get any explanation as to why all the characters are so strange, they just are. There are some edgy scenes and dialogue strewn about the movie just for shock value. Such as the mom acting dead for her husband's necrophelia fetish or the dad telling his 9 year old son about how he gave his dad a handjob. The antagonist tells the father that his family will get sick and die unless he kills one of them. Okay, but how? Who knows. It wasn't poison so I'm left to believe that this kid can somehow influence these kids to think they are dying through the power of persuasion. The daughter is somehow still in love with him despite him actively killing her and her family. It's never explained why the mother never got symptoms. The movie could be cut in half with all the unnecessary crap in it. Barely anything substantial happens until the very end. There is no mystery because they literally tell you the answer half an hour in. There is no tension because until the kids' eyes start bleeding you know no one is going to die. I liked the way the family members started sucking up to the dad at the end. That brought some weight to the situation. The way he decided to choose who to kill at the end was ridiculous though. He could have fired 20 bullets before he shot one of them and even then he could hit them in a bad spot and cause unnecessary pain. Meanwhile his son is about to die and he is damaging his house for no reason. Could have just played Russian roulette. The soundtrack was good for the most part but at times it got overzealous and annoying. The acting was good. It's a well made movie but it's not a good movie. Just fine.

Movie Title: The Killing of a Sacred Deer (2017)
Review-Description: Ancient myth, disguised in American way of life. Good actors struggling to pull out some sense from the story. Maybe interesting for deeply religious, moderately intelligent and poorly informated people. I cannot understand poimt of view of Cannes Jurie board giving the prize for playwrite. Maybe in 2017 y. There were some sinister Sun activities which influenced the jurie decision. Technically, the movie is professionally made. Director is obviouslly real professional, but didn't went far from boring psychological, mild horror and plenty of sex obssesion mixture. Don't expect of me to warch this movie once more time.

Movie Title: The Killing of a Sacred Deer (2017)
Review-Title: A potentially good movie that is bogged down by Yorgos Lanthimos's artistic pretensions
Review-Description: Renowned cardiovascular surgeon Dr. Steven Murphy lives an idyllic life with his wife and two children. When he befriends a fatherless teenager named Martin, the young man proceeds to inveigle his way deeper and deeper into the doctor's life. Soon, Martin's dark intentions become apparent when Martin reminds him of a past transgression which will permanently shatter the domesticity of his household. The latest offering from Greek director Yorgos Lanthimos who collaborates once again with Colin Farrell, whom he worked with on his equally idiosyncratic The Lobster. It is no exaggeration to describe The Killing of a Sacred Deer as a deeply surreal and perturbing look at a man whose family's life is turned upside down by an unstable teenager. Inspired by the ancient Greek tragedy Iphigenia in Aulis by Euripides, like The Lobster, Lanthimos's movie is clearly experimental in nature in so much, as for reasons that appear only clear to himself his cast delivers their performances in a stilted and wooden style. The artificiality of this is only matched by Lanthimos's script which he co-wrote with Efthimis Filippou. It's pretty much robotic as if his protagonists escaped from the Stepford Wives. At the movie's heart, there is a good movie with a sublimely bizarre and surreal plot and Lanthimos manages to add a nuanced, somber and unsettling tone. There is something of a cold sterility to the Murphy household which may account for the unorthodox style of acting on display. Suffice to say that like The Lobster there is an underlying touch of the absurd to it's plot which no doubt owes a measure of debt to the avant-garde work of David Lynch, while there are hints of the Oscar winning psychological thriller Fatal Attraction. Barry Keoghan, who would later feature alongside fellow Irishman Farrell in the black tragicomedy does have something of an unsettling presence as well as a awkwardness about him as the disturbed young antagonist. However, Lanthimoas can't overcome the weight of his own artistic pretensions with the stagy style of his direction and the constrained acting by his cast bog it down considerably. Which is a shame because there was a potentially good if very strange movie that had the potential to be so much more than it actually is. Needless to say as well that the considerable talents of both Farrell and Keoghan feel wasted, and deserved better than what they are left to work with. And Nicole Kidman has done considerably better with the similarly off-kilter and dark Stoker, just seems to be infinitely bored with everything that's gone on around her. One has to wonder if her involvement is due to any artistic merit she thought the movie had or merely for the paycheck. Either way The Killing of a Sacred Deer feels like something of a missed opportunity from Lanthimoas whose seems to have fallen prey to his own overreaching ambitions.

Movie Title: The Killing of a Sacred Deer (2017)
Review-Description: This is a terrible movie that it insists upon itself. A boy threatens a father's family and then stands by and does nothing. He doesn't report it. He doesn't try and stop him. He doesnt warn his family about the weird stalker. He just lets it happen. He is complete denial. The sound and screenshots make it feels like the director is trying to copy Kubrick's style at moments but is so completely off the mark it's insulting to his work. There is no value in watching this unless you're the type that likes to "get" pretentious works; sometimes referring to smelling one's own farts, though in this case it's the director's and it's thoroughly terrible but we're told it's good and therefore must will find a way to ignore our rationale mind and conform to what everyone else says or wonderful.

Movie Title: The Killing of a Sacred Deer (2017)
Review-Title: I created an IMDB account to give this movie one star
Review-Description: I actually like weird movies, but this movie just stinks. I understand that it was probably an artistic decision or something for the director to tell his actors to show no emotion whatsoever, but it gets old so fast. The characters say some pretty off the wall stuff with no explanation whatsoever. The only silver lining would be the performance of the moon faced kid from Dunkirk....he was pretty creepy. I normally love Colin Farrell, but he was so off putting. Nicole Kidman just looked as confused as I felt watching this piece of garbage. There was some unintentional humor which I guess was a positive. When the son falls out of the hospital bed, when the daughter exclaims " Dad Bobby is dying!" When his nose starts bleeding. The climax of the movie when Colin Farrell has to make his heartbreaking decision was pretty hilarious to.

Review-Title: I am not an intellectual or a film critic, but I LOVED this movie!
Review-Description: Beau Is Afraid is shocking, confusing, gory and hilarious. It gives the viewer anxiety for sure, but breaks up the anxiety with plenty of ridiculousness and hard-to-believe action. I'm not sure I fully understand this movie, but I will recommend it and I will certainly watch it again. Another viewer called it a punch in the face. I feel like it's more of a punch in the soul. It's tragic, gross and offensive and I'm totally here for it. Every time you think it couldn't get more shocking, this movie ups the ante and leaves the viewer wondering out loud "What the hell is going on!?!" Do yourself a favor and watch it...twice.

Review-Title: I'm afraid this movie is awful
Review-Description: I'm afraid Ari Aster has lost the plot. I'm afraid he thinks he's some kind of genius, when he's anything but. I'm afraid his previous success has gone to his head. I'm afraid his movies are getting progressively worse. I'm afraid to think of how bad his next film will be. I'm afraid that Hereditary will be the best thing he ever does. I'm afraid his latest film is a cod-Freudian one note bore with nothing interesting in it. I'm afraid some people have decided Joaquin Phoenix is the next Marlon Brando, when he has about as much substance and acting ability as Adam Sandler. I'm afraid this is one of the worst movies I've ever seen.

Review-Title: Awful. Boring. Static instead of dynamic.
Review-Description: This director has done some interesting movies but they all have a bit of boredom in them. With this flick, Aster drives a car so slow, he drives it Into the ditch. Phoenix is a fine actor but he needs material that is worthy of his skills. This is the case with this effort. It is too slow. Too measured. Too flat to excite, even in the smallest increments. I could only watch minutes at a time and returned to it several times to completion. It felt like a chore. This is not entertainment. It is revelatory. It is not profound. It is an indulgent exercise in tedium. The fine actors in this movie deserve better. And they should've known better before committing to this snooze fest.

Never admit i was entertained by this movie...if dali and bosch had a heart stopping nightmare, it would seem like a dream where you'd died while having sex and had gone to heaven, compared to this...it's brilliant in its relentless ability to keep coming up with a grotesque story, scene after scene after scene...
it's like looking into an open wound eons deep. And i just couldn't turn away...not because i felt there HAD to be a resolution to it all, but because it was just. So. FAScinating. By the way, this is, in no way, a recommendation. See it if you really feel the need, but...i will NEVER understand the motivation behind making such a thing. And this DOESN'T mean it's 'bad'...for what it is, it is VERY well done. On top of all that i said...it's THREE HOURS LONG! THREE...
it makes me question my sanity, that i sat through it...granted, not in one sitting...but it might even be WORSE that i kept returning to the scene of this plane crash...

I love Joaquin Phoenix, so I watched without checking. But really, WTF? It just goes on and on, and like Beau, you understand nothing. You wonder if there was a script. You wonder if there's a story. You start to wonder if it's even real. You hope the nightmare ends well. It doesn't. It's one of those non-ending endings. It's like the movie thinks it's cool and alternative in some way. It's not. And the underlying psychosis could possibly give you nightmares just from trying to understand. Believe me, I wanted there to be meaning, depth, or purpose. I wanted my face to stop looking as dumbfounded and confused as Beau's.

Oh my gosh it's brilliant, to a point. Watching this can only be equated to what I believe 500 cups of coffee, no sleep, and functioning mental illness combined would be like. Several times I actually stopped to rewind (or, whatever it's called now, I backed up a few frames) to rewatch what I just watched, shouting "WTF just happened"...it's an adventure in madness, like a song with lyrics that take you from midnight through to 5pm the next day and you're still at the bar playing random jukebox tunes while everyone else has gone home. This movie, seriously the director or producer or maybe all of them...just said action and told the actors to just do or say whatever the heck they wanted to say or do. Joaquin does a great job being the guy he's supposed to be and if you know, you know. Unfortunately, amongst the madness some of the story really never gets there and it's one heck of a LONG movie to not quite get there. Hence, I have to stop at a 7. I wish future watchers luck...it's one heck of a ride.

Review-Title: My favorite movie of the year
Review-Description: 'Course that's not saying much in 2023. But this movie would have stood out even if the year had been full of outstanding shows. Anyhow. Beau Is Afraid is a visual delight. Each scene is filled with more details than you can hope to take in let alone make an effort to integrate with the plot. Not that there's a plot. Or maybe there is. I'm honestly not sure. Phoenix is stellar, this is the sort of stuff that he excels at (as opposed to muddled portrayals of historical figures). He is constantly on the edge of panic and disconnection from 'reality' in just the right amount to make the character feel real enough to be relatable. Rather than farcical or outlandish or, heaven forbid, dour and boring. And this is absolutely necessary for the character to be able to skip from once surreal outing to the next without alienating the viewer. But the movie is work and the time does not flash by. It's more like a 3 hour mountain climb than a pleasure cruise. The viewer, however, is wonderfully and richly rewarded for his attendance. Hereditary was a masterpiece. But then Midsommar was a misguided, shallow disappointment and I was prepared to write Aster off as a one hit wonder. But Beau Is Afraid is clearly the work of someone who knows how to make a movie.

The whole movie is a giant metaphor for boomers vs. Millennials/generation x/gen z. I think it's great because the metaphors are so strong. Everything from the giant monster to getting lost in some random fantasy with hints of rip van winkle. I think a lot of people saw this as random or confusing, but I think it's very straight forward. You got everything from the younger generation just being angry and confused all the time...literally choking to death on gender colored paint. It's just a metaphor for nonsensical fads that they're tied up in. I'm still in awe of how awesome it all is. Ari's saying if you make it past the dumb confusing gen z fads and gender confusion (literally choking to death on it...something something ad nauseam), you make past the nearly indestructible military complex that gen z-ers cry foul to, you make it past the random faceless fantasy pretending to be your life's story, you make it past the big scary peen monster literally meant to scare you into not having sex (sex education wasn't a thing for the boomers). If you get past ALL that...and you think you're ready to start doing things...then you're too late. Too old. You get chastised for trying. And then your little boat capsizes in the court of public opinion (social media)- another thing that wasn't around when boomers were young. The movie even goes on to critique how his mother's skyrocketing profits have worked to create the current social situation of ultra violent streets and even his living situation...as it's her building. Pretty wild metaphors. I liked it a lot.

Review-Title: Shall I call it a pinterest collage(?)
Review-Description: The director made a wonderful collage of Rosemary's baby and his previous two moviesü§£(which were also collaged and montages from Rosemary's baby). By that I mean it is more like a story board at its early stage but without real development(It could be a wonderful uncanny movie). Sadly It was not what I expected... You don't need 3 hours to describe the fear of aggressive control and complicated relationship with family... SIMPLY doesn't need to especially without some specific contexts. The set is so general and ambiguous(don't tell me it is not) I guess ari wanted to convey one vibe and psychological into many different families. But apparently he didn't realise perhaps the difference is more than the common. A very cheesy quote but it is so true: All happy families resemble one another, each unhappy family is unhappy in its own way.

Review-Title: Is There a Rating Lower Than 1?
Review-Description: I feel bad for The reviewer who said he gave up over three hours of his life watching this. Didn't take me that long. I can't understand people who give these kind of movies a 7, 8, 9 or 10. Are we supposed to be moved by their intellect or feel that we are less than Intelligent or knowing because we find this stuff senseless? Joaquin Phoenix has always been edgy but these character actors think they are so avant garde doing this kind of crap. You would do yourself a favor and watch a foreign film which is animated and done in a language you do not understand. You will get more out of it than you will this total and complete waste.

"Krampus" (2015) emerges as a unique work by mixing Christmas horror with fantastic elements, revealing itself to be one of the most creative and well-executed approaches to this theme in contemporary cinema. The film skillfully incorporates a children's appeal by adding doses of humor at various moments, choosing to avoid graphic presentations of deaths or disturbing content. The script, in turn, carries out a solid construction of the family drama, developing the relationships between the characters masterfully, supported by excellent performances from the entire cast. The choice of blue photography, in contrast to the design of the monsters, including the iconic villain Krampus, reveals careful visual work that captivates the viewer. The production also stands out for constructing one of the most notable Christmas themes in horror cinema, dedicating itself with care to the creation of scenarios, festive references and, mainly, the Christmas message, consolidating the film as a reference in the proposal. The ending of "Krampus" is marked by boldness and surprise. Although the childish tone prevails, the balance in the direction is evident, which seeks to please both the adult audience with moments of horror and ensure a memorable experience as a whole.

Review-Title: "Like he had for thousands of years, Krampus came not to reward, but to punish. Not to give, but to take."
Review-Description: FILM: 7/10. Returning to the 2015 film Krampus, I find Michael Dougherty, the maestro behind the delightfully twisted Trick 'r Treat, turning his attention to the holiday season. Much like his Halloween gem, Krampus serves as a refreshing counter-programming to the saccharine sweet Christmas fare, blending comedy and horror in a way that nods to classics like Gremlins. The family at the film's centre is well cast, each member contributing to the chaos in their own unique way. It's a dysfunctional family dynamic that feels authentic, adding an extra layer of relatability to the unfolding madness. There's a chemistry that makes their descent into holiday horrors all the more entertaining, with Adam Scott and Toni Collette barely containing their frustration at the family members descending on their home. Creature design is a standout feature, with the monstrous creations adding a touch of macabre whimsy to the Christmas setting. Dougherty successfully crafts a festive nightmare, where gingerbread men and demonic toys become unlikely antagonists in the battle for holiday cheer. Krampus is undeniably a fun film, leaning into its darkly comedic moments while maintaining a genuine sense of peril. The blend of horror and humor hits the right notes, creating an experience that's both chilling and amusing. It's a reminder that the festive season isn't always sugar and spice, but sometimes a dash of horror adds the perfect kick. As the credits roll, Krampus leaves you with a playful warning - if you don't believe in Santa Claus, you might just be doomed for life. It's a cheeky nod to the film's mischievous spirit, proving that holiday horrors can be a delightful gift for those who appreciate a bit of bite with their Christmas bark. A festive frightfest that keeps the holiday spirit twisted and thrilling. FORMAT: Blu-ray VIDEO: 9/10. 1080p presentation, Detail level: Excellent, Colour reproduction: Excellent, Level accuracy: Excellent, Encode: Excellent, Master condition: Excellent AUDIO: 9.5/10. DTS-HD MA 5.1 audio, Dialogue reproduction: Excellent, Soundtrack & effects clarity: Excellent, Dynamics: Excellent, Surround sound presentation: Excellent, LFE content: Excellent MOOFIEMETER: 7/10.

Review-Title: TOO CHILDISH FOR ADULTS AND TOO ADULT FOR CHILDREN.
Review-Description:
Too childish for adults and too adult for children. It's a quality mix of light horror and comedy. All star cast is fun to watch, particularly Toni Collette who is consistently great. The end makes you think and is the highlight of the movie. Synopsis:
While the holiday season represents the most magical time of year, ancient European folklore warns of Krampus, a horned beast who punishes naughty children at Christmastime. When dysfunctional family squabbling causes young Max (Emjay Anthony) to lose his festive spirit, it unleashes the wrath of the fearsome demon. As Krampus lays siege to the Engel home, mom (Toni Collette), pop (Adam Scott), sister (Stefania LaVie Owen) and brother must band together to save one another from a monstrous fate.

Review-Title: Worth a watch once, but not the classic i hope it could had been.
Review-Description: Had this one in my backlog for a while and its been 2 years since i wanted to kinda transition my Halloween horror movies season into a Christmas movies season but it just didn't occured. I really wanted to watch it this year tough and with Christmas coming i did just that on the 21st. Overall... not a bad movie, but nothing really special, yet fine for one watch. Its actually a comedy mixed with horror while keeping the Christmas atmosphere in full force. The Krampus monster himself is actually not that present. It revolves around all his minions wich all have special imaginative designs. That said they pretty much all CGI animated and they kinda look goofy at time. I guess they were inspired by Tim Burton in some way. The issue is im never sure if i should take this movie seriously or not. Is it supose to be a comedy or is it supose to be horror? Maybe its supose to be a mix of the 2 just like i think it is? Who knows. But its not "that funny" while its not scary at all. This one get the yellow heart only by a tiny little margin. Its best feature in my opinion is the snow storm, Christmas stuff and altough a bit goofy like i said, the creatures at least are pretty original.

Be careful what you wish for
Because you might just get it
Hands down one of the best Krampus movies out there
Trust me I've seen more than my share of the bad ones
Is this movie scary ? I guess it depends on what you consider scary
I could see it being a good introduction to horror for younger kids
As a adult fan of horror I doubt anyone would find it scary
But it is wildly entertaining
My favorite moments in the movie
Come from when the gingerbread cookies attack
I think part of my problem with this movie is
The movie is PG 13 and because of that
I think it limits what you get to see what you get to see on screen.

Krampus takes the traditional holiday film and turns it on its head, as Santa takes a back seat to a more devious holiday creature. Starting off like your typical Christmas film, the plot quickly starts to send shivers down your spine as you realize this has much more in store. The story is fun and exciting, with a perfectly unsettling ending to top it off and keep with its creepier elements. The cast is comprised of familiar faces and some talented children actors. While they mostly maintain a fun ride, some of the jokes can feel quite cheesy or stale, with the dialogue being almost satirical at times. As a Christmas movie, it certainly has the holiday element, but as a horror movie, the fear and unnerving nature are some of the best parts. While I didn't expect much going in, Krampus delivers a delightfully eerie tale that I have found myself running back to, time and time again.

Was it all a dream? Let's hope so. I'm hoping that when I wake up tomorrow I will forget that I ever saw this trash. The story makes next to no sense and Oscar deserving parenting is on display at all times. I'm pretty sure parents that have at least four working brain cells between them don't send their daughter out during an emergency to check on some dopey boyfriend even if he lived next door. And if the dad was an actual eagle scout he would have learned proper firearm safety and not walk around with his finger inside the trigger guard like an idiot! I think the director came up with this story after chugging a few bottles of nyquil and letting the fever dream guide his fingers on the keyboard. It wasn't funny, it wasn't horror but I did find some entertainment in watching my fellow humans display the purest form of stupidity possible.

Review-Title: A Modern Day Christmas Horror Classic
Review-Description: Krampus is one of my favourite Christmas horror movies. Like many horror films, it was dismissed when it first came out for really inexplicable reasons, but I'm happy it seems to be getting a well-deserved reassesment. Because, what's not to love here? You have a truly AMAZING cast, with great performances from Adam Scott, Toni Collette (!), David Koechner, and even the kids, who are mostly pretty solid actors and do well with the material. It has fantastic practical effects that pay homage to Rankin Bass Christmas classics, only much darker and more twisted. The story is fun and creative, subverting the saccharine wish fulfillment of most Christmas tales, for one that has a child invoking a spirit that's almost cosmic in its power and completely unstoppable. I LOVE how Krampus is presented here as a villain; not just the awesome practical creature they made, but how much power he has and fear he induces. It's just fantastic. Not to mention this movie is FUNNY. It has a great sense of humour and doesn't take itself too seriously. It validates a lot of the feelings people have about the holiday season, mainly about having to share a table and fake smile for family members you wouldn't associate with otherwise and the cynical consumerism Christmas promotes. However, like all good Christmas movies, the message is simple: family matters. Making it work regardless of your differences matter. Just when you think the film settles for a sweet, uplifting ending, it delivers one of the most bleak, brilliant ones I've seen for a Christmas horror film. Yeah, Krampus is a ton of fun. If you need a break from holiday cheer, even if temporarily, check it out.

Review-Title: A blast of stark holiday horror that beats out most kindred titles
Review-Description: The foundations are tried and true, a scenario that's been the basis of many holiday films for decades: an abundance of outwardly unlikable characters, the false manufactured cheer of Christmas set against abject cynicism about the worst aspects of the holidays in modern life, minimal representation of innocence (usually the very young) amidst a cornucopia of cringe and dreariness. To that foundation, of course, we add in this case a frightful supernatural entity drawn directly from European folklore, and presto! - 2015 horror-comedy 'Krampus.' Mind you, in this case the genre label is a bit of a misnomer; there are stunningly few outright laughs to be had in these ninety-seven minutes, and the "comedy" descriptor speaks more to the fragments of wry, black humor that marginally lighten the horror. To that point, despite how the picture was marketed, this is substantially darker than I expected, with grim atmosphere and grisly violence exceeding what some straightforward horror sometimes achieves; modicums of levity can't begin to meaningfully touch the most dour facets of the movie. I do like it, but suffice to say that this is not what I anticipated. Sparsely peppered with quick-witted lines that provide counterbalance, the preponderance of the length is characterized by shrewd use of light and shadow, incredibly unsettling unnatural movement, sounds, or visions, a tense and acutely disquieting score, and superb art direction that very distinctly cements the bleak, brutal ambience. This is to say nothing of surprisingly strong violence, imaginative and unnerving creature designs, and excellent stunts and effects; the computer-generated imagery looks fantastic, and to whatever extent the digital wizardry doesn't blend into the filmed footage, this is an instance where the disparity rather adds to the experience. Even the sound effects are plainly outstanding and further the harrowing airs about the feature, not to mention the costume design, hair, and makeup. Filmmaker Michael Dougherty, and co-writers Todd Casey and Zach Shields, concocted a wonderfully twisted nightmare that warps familiar Christmastime themes and ideas into an invigorating thrill ride that at some points rather becomes hard to watch for just how unremittingly sinister and cheerless the concatenation becomes. 'Krampus' is fun, yes, but in a manner very much unlike how it was promoted and spoken of since before its release. The narrative is sharp, potent, and stridently gloomy through to the very end; the fact that it does manage to be earnest and impactful at the same time is genuinely impressive. Equally punchy scene writing keeps us firmly locked in while maximizing the harsh, charged energy and every feeling, and much the same can be said for Dougherty's keen direction. The length passes very quickly as the tale grows ever more severe, and if anything, the casting in this rarely funny horror flick of actors largely known for their work in comedies only heightens the gripping tone and accentuates how far removed this is from how it initially presents. Case in point, Toni Collette is not known for appearing in genre titles, yet like Ari Aster's masterful 'Hereditary,' this is an exception in which her participation serves to amplify the intended effect, and emphasize the underlying gravity. Collette, David Koechner, Adam Scott, Allison Tolman, Conchata Ferrell, Krista Stadler, and even young Emjay Anthony, among others, all give splendid performances of real range, nuance, and emotional depth while being perfectly suited to the gnarly cavalcade of violence that the film broadly represents. Truthfully, I had mixed expectations when I sat to watch; I assumed I'd enjoy 'Krampus,' but I wasn't sure just how good and worthwhile it would really turn out to be. I'm pleased to say that when all is said and done, it's even better than I could have hoped.
