I think the heavy focus on horror over comedy actually serves the picture well, for it's made more fully absorbing and satisfying in its darkness; not only are the scant lighter touches more consequential in turn, but it seems as if the writers worked overtime to make the comedy smarter (that is, both more intelligent and more cheeky). The end result of all this is a genre romp that manages to hit considerably harder than it would seem from the outside looking in, or from the outset. Crafted with utmost skill and well made in all regards, it's both entertaining and riveting, and handily surpasses most other movies that try to play at the same intersection of horror and holidays. I'm so very happy with just how good this is, and for anyone who is open to the amalgamation, 'Krampus' earns my very high and enthusiastic recommendation!

Review-Title: A Funny, Frightening & Unique Christmas Classic!
Review-Description: I wasn't sure going into this movie but decided to give it a full watch and I'm glad that I did! This movie is far from the typical cliche Christmas movie. Mixed with some humor & terror. If you like Christmas, horror & comedy all in one than you'll really enjoy this one. The writer really did a great job putting this one together. No, it's not like it's Oscar worthy but it's definitely one of those movies you could find yourself watching over & over again every Christmas season. This one gave me a bit of the chills and caught me off guard quite a few times & the ending definitely left me thinking about it well after it ended. Highly recommend you give it a watch.

Naturally, I can appreciate that any persons Taste In film is subjective, for me however it just felt like someone had watched, and enjoyed the Wickerman, afterwards then wanted to make a film were a bunch of stuff happens in a similar vain, to a group of characters I didn't care about. Personally, I wouldn't watch it again. But other people I know, absolutely love this film, and it came very highly recommended. Again, doesn't make it a bad film, just ended up being I personally didn't enjoy. May one day give it another punt, but certainly won't be today, or for a while. But each to their own.

What a nonsense garbage, boring from the beginning to the end, and I have seen a lot of movies that are garbage but this tops it. I get it's a movie but like none of the characters have a brain or what is happening to them or their friends, just shows how silly humans are when it comes to cults but I guess it the writers you can blame for the lacking in that department, still not sure what happened in the end I guess she really did join a cult just because what she been through just made sense for her to feel belonged and have a home these people give it her, I thought it would went other way around but still Don't waste your time.

Review-Title: Best psychological movie to ever exist!
Review-Description: I watched this film for the first time in summer and it was a great experience. Florence Pough (sorry if I spelt her name wrong) acted very well from the very beginning and deserves several awards from this performance alone. This is easily the best psychological horror film I have ever seen. Watching it for the first time was oddly comforting due to the aesthetics and vibrant colours, however as the movie went on it became more and more disturbing. The acting in it was incredible and I loved the plot. If you're looking to watch a psychological horror that feels summery, I would recommend this film! (Also a quick warning: don't watch this while high - you will regret it)

For the last two months I've been doing the Marvel marathon, 20 movies so far. They're almost all worth watching if in the mood, but the lack of stillness in the camera, the constant cuts, quick quips, punchathons and artificial visuals get tiring after a while. Midsommar is a fine antidote: the camera is beautifully still or slow. Editing-cuts are far less frequent, allowing more time to sink into an image. The compositioning of images is masterful: photography-like. Indeed, Kubrick-like (who was initially a photographer). We also get an impactful soundtrack, excellent acting especially from the lead, good script & screenplay with plenty of quality dialogue-free sections, effectively spare FX with realistic psychedelic 'breathing' visuals, and a riveting foreboding atmosphere. There's also very weird humour, which actually made me & my lady laugh out loud a few times....tho' I imagine others might just find it weird. The film slightly drags in the final third (I watched the theatrical cut) and some of the character reactions will have you questioning its realism. The plot itself is fairly predictable...we've seen such films before. These are nitpicks as we also get a handful of strong memorable scenes. Overall a decent 8/10. Feels like a worthy tribute to 1973's The Wicker Man.

Lol.. OK I've put off watching this one now for like forever, mainly coz in my head I already predicted what it was about and the sort of vibe it would give off ( like moods in other films) and unfortunately I was 100% right. I will say in the first quatre or even less than that we get to see some beautiful scenery ( I will have to read up where it was filmed locations etc) and I did like the lead actress, she held the most potential.. and for a moment with the beautiful scenery I thought I might have made a wrong assumption on how the mood and theme of film would go & I'd be in for a nice viewing. Unfortunately none of the rest of the characters went anywhere. Even their friend who had taken them for a trip. It seemed like we d get more from him but then he quietened off. But first and foremost. The place just SCREAMED Cult as soon as we arrive in the village but like I said some nice scenery I was interested to see where it went. But unfortunately you'd really have to suspend belief too far on this, especially in regards to reactions and decisions. The film is long and slow paced aswell, making it even more unbelievable, they wouldn't of all just fled, especially after the mountains viewing & no1 would believe the London guy ditched his girlfriend & if I was her I would have clung to the Americans. This is where at least something like Hostel is rational in thinking YO!! Time to go!! Before even first person goes missing. It just became to anti climatic and stupid after the beautiful scenes and initial sacrifice. It was beyond predictable & I honestly feel they wasted a opportunity for a better film in their.

'Midsommar' (2019) Opening thoughts: It took me a long time to get round to watching 'Midsommar', due to not having time or the opportunity to watch it easily. Have always appreciated the genre it fits in, where there are many great films, and Florence Pugh showed a lot of promise seeing her for the first time in 'Little Women'. That it was also directed by the director responsible for the very good 'Hereditary' intrigued me too. The premise was one of those could have gone either way ones, it was advertised bizarrely and the critical reception was very polarising, particularly from those that didn't like it. After seeing 'Midsommar', count me in as somebody who didn't care for it. It is not an awful film and there are things done right, including an intriguing start, but the second half was a bizarre and tedious mess, so this viewer is this case more understanding of those who didn't like the film than liked. This has absolutely nothing to do with not understanding what 'Midsommar' was going to be or going for, quite the opposite, the issue is that it doesn't achieve its aims very well at all. Good things: 'Midsommar' does have good things. It is a very well made film visually, with photography that is both dreamlike and nightmarish in all the necessary places. The scenery is also absolutely beautiful, while also with a suitably ominous atmosphere. Did think too that the film started off well, with an unsettling opening that was creepy and suspenseful. The sacrifice scene was similarly suitably horrifying, with it being the scariest (and goriest) the film got. Regarding the acting, to me it was quite good considering what was given to them (which actually come to think of it wasn't much). Pugh anchors the film beautifully in a compellingly tortured lead performance. Bad things: However, there are also a lot of drawbacks. Most of the characters are incredibly thinly sketched and behave annoyingly and/or illogically. Pugh has the only character that has any development or who is interesting. Some friends thought that Will Poulter's character had the most personality, to me actually he was annoying and his presence jarred with the rest of the atmosphere. The direction did have some slickness but got very slack and muddled later on the more weird the second half became. The script has nothing memorable, is very stilted and can fall into self-indulgence. The story and pacing are the weakest aspects of 'Midsommar'. The story starts off with great atmosphere and intrigue, but post the sacrifice scene any creepiness and sense of horror pretty much completely goes. Meaning that the second half is incredibly long winded, this out increasingly (at times non-existent) and is bizarre to the point of near-incoherence. Especially the dragged out and truly daft climax that ends on an abrupt, incomplete feeling note and one of the silliest and most unintentionally funny sex scenes in recent years. Some of the intended creepy behaviours of the cult were potentially unnerving and sounded it on paper but were under-explored and/or left as loose ends or implied. A much shorter length definitely would have helped the pacing and atmosphere, the film is overlong and could have easily been trimmed by 25-30 minutes which would have tightened the pace. Which would have been achieved if scenes were made shorter and if motivations went into more detail. Closing thoughts: Overall, underwhelming. 4/10.

I loved the directors previous film Hereditary. It was fresh if perhaps a bit bloated at times but it worked due to the plot's structure. So I was pretty stoked for this one. How many pure day light horror films are there? The Wicker Man (original) of which this film pays homage too, basically remakes it. And that is where ultimately, I was disappointment. First the good: The film is beautifully shot and minus 2 scenes the entire thing takes place in bright green fields of Sweden (shot in Hungary) It accomplishes merging beauty with horror in a way I haven't ever seen before (The Flower Dress) If you're a gore hound beyond just "MORE GORE!" then you may find certain scenes shocking (the cliff scene) as I did. It's not overly gory but with a background so beautiful for the heinous actions by both villagers and visitors it's quite jarring. There is also a suicide scene that raises a good question regarding how we "civilized" people tend to push our old/sick into institutions never to be seen again. Who are visitors to judge the customs of these "sacred" people? Sadly that theme is not explored and I found every character minus Dani to be interchangeable in their terribleness In closing. It feels like the director was, poorly, trying to remake the ultimate cult classic using the same methods that worked so well for his previous hit that what we end up with is a film that is
100% predictable from start to finish. In other words I found it boring. I wanted to love it but didn't. I am very happy it was made as I think Ari Aster is an incredibly talented director who knows how to bring the terror and I look forward to his next work. I just hope he tries something unique and fun to watch. TLDR: This film follows the themes of Hereditary with zero twists, and while it is a gorgeous (and morbid) work of art- I didn't like it or hate it.

Review-Title: Weird and sometimes scary in the scandinavian midnight sun
Review-Description: This was a weird, but entertaining horror flick, that popped up on my danish TV app. As a dane, and thus a real life neighbor to the swedish settting in the film, it was quite entertaining to watch this Hollywood take on Midsommar, that pagan leftover in swedish culture, something that we danes no longer celebrate. The film is quite uneven and requires quite a bit of suspension of disbelief. Some scenes and traditions of the H√•gra are too random to not have set off our protagonists in real life. Said protagonists are paper thin in the film, it's all about the H√•gra and the setting. I will say this film is interesting from a scandinavian perspective, because it features a lot of swedish actors and a lot of blonde people. This still being normal here, particularly in places like rural Sweden. However, from an american point of view, that is increasingly diverse, I can see how this "land of the blondes" might seem very foreign. I found this reverse exocitism interesting to think about. Overall, I found the movie unnerving in parts, humorous in others. Well worth a watch.

I'm not surprised by how divisive Midsommar is. It is a trippy, 3 hour horror movie, that's more weird than scary, but has excellent cinematography, an amazing performance by the lead (Florence Pugh), and impressive attention to detail. But you've obviously seen my rating and know that I enjoyed it, so let's talk about this film. Firstly, I'll note that I rarely leave reviews for films I watch. In fact, it's almost 10PM and I need to get to bed, but this film left me thinking. The first thing I noticed about this film was the amazing performance by Florence Pugh as Dani. We really get drawn into empathizing with her early on. And not just because of her intense loss at the very start of the film (shown in a brilliant opening sequence I might add). Her amazing performance only continues on until the final smiling shot. Another thing I thought was wonderful about this film was the foreshadowing. First, the depiction of a "love story" in which the woman serves a man food with her pubic hair and a drink containing her period blood. Then, the moment when Christian takes a drink and then we see his drink is a darker, redder color than the rest. That realization only forecasts what is to come for him. But there were tons of other moments of foreshadowing. The bear. The joke that no one lives past 72. And my favorite, a subversion of prior foreshadowing. Earlier in the film pair of elders arrives at the feast and everyone else waits to sit and eat until they do. They jump to their deaths moments later. Similarly, Dani as the May Queen goes through the same feasting ritual. And this makes us fear for her even more. And this brings me to another strength of this film, keeping us in suspense. The best example of this is when they cut away before Dani makes her selection of who will die. The movie takes its time marching people into the "temple". But not Christian. Only when we later see Christian in the room with the disemboweling of the bear do we start to suspect something is off. And the last huge strength I'll talk about is the theme. This film explores the themes of loss, trauma, and letting go. And I think it does a wonderful job thinking through these issues, mainly through the character of Dani. Everything tells us that her relationship with Christian is doomed to fail: from his distance and gaslighting, to the contrast between them and the Simon/Connie duo, to the fact that he's obviously hoping to "mate" with Maja. And yet, we struggle alongside her as she fails to let him go until the final shot. So yes, this is a very strange film. It is definitely not for anyone looking for supernatural hauntings, slashers, or another hollywood franchise. But if you are willing to try something different and have the patience and the open-mindedness to accept the strangeness as it comes, you might just find yourself having enjoyed one of the weirdest films you've ever watched.

Review-Title: What a beautiful, inspiring tale. And there is SO much of it.
Review-Description: When the credits were rolling, my heart was lifted. This is a movie we don't get often. A movie about community, about empathy. A movie about the importance of traditions, and even religion. Most of all, it's about sacrifice. Be warned, though: this film takes its time. If you want something more action-paced, I recommend the very similar-themed, but less lenghty The Wicker Man. The one from the 70s. This is not about thrills. The ending is clear, long before you get there. As I said: This movie REALLY dares to take its time. Don't expect too much tension, because although it might feel tense, sometimes, it also lasts long enough - and then some - to ease out any of these feelings. God, this is such a good movie about values.

Review-Title: It doesn't matter what you read (good or bad), you must watch it.
Review-Description: People complain all the time everything is a marvel sequel, or a disney remake. Well, this is different, bold, new, fresh. The movie is good and it has rare elements and moments that will haunt you even after watching it. Same as "Terrified", the previous film by the director (there are still scenes I can't erase from my head even after years of watching that one too). There's a lot of gore, but REALLY graphic, if you're easily impressed, it's probably going to be uncomfortable for you. Some images I'm having a hard time getting them out of my head. The movie doesn't stop, it's not like those films that have like 30 minutes of boring character development. It starts and it keeps going and you'll get to know the characters as the movie progresses (great tip for filmakers nowadays, full of viewers with short attention span, A. K. A. Tiktok syndrome). It's a small town story. Solid performances, solid practical effects, decent story. Spanish speaker or not, if you're a horror fan you must watch this one.

Review-Title: Some of the best horror I've ever seen.
Review-Description: This is a seriously scary and effective horror film. I trudge through so many mediocre horror films to find the random truly great horror masterpieces...and for me at least, When Evil Lurks is absolutely one of the new horror masterpieces. The story and world created are so expansive, it kept me wondering what else was going on in this mad-scary world...so much backstory to flesh out and places it could go now with the story...so much more to learn about the Rottens and the Cleaners, etc! I'm now going to search out other films directed by Demi√°n Rugna...while I eagerly await to see where we go next in the When Evil Lurks story.

"When Evil Lurks" introduces a truly special concept that had the potential to make it the standout movie of the year. The first half of the film is captivating, drawing audiences in with its intriguing storyline and well-executed suspense. The innovative idea behind the movie succeeds in creating a unique atmosphere that keeps viewers on the edge of their seats. Regrettably, the second half takes a disappointing turn towards predictability and monotony, diluting the initial excitement. The film's potential for chaos and innovation hinted at in the beginning falls flat, leaving viewers yearning for a more dynamic and ambitious portrayal. In envisioning the film's potential, one can't help but wish for a reimagination of the concept in a grander setting, such as a bustling city engulfed in possession-induced chaos. Despite its shortcomings, "When Evil Lurks" sparks hope for a future revisit, one that could realize the thrilling experience promised by its exceptional concept. I would have given 5 out of 10 but I really hated the second half.

This film has been overhyped as one of the best horror movies of the year. I went into it expecting to be blown away and I was let down. Yes, this film has some crazy scenes that I enjoyed for how gory they were. But a good film cannot be dependent on shock value. And that's all this film was. It had a couple crazy moments but the in-between wasn't as interesting. The characters and the story wasn't compelling enough to hold my interest. I kept checking the run time waiting for it to be over. It was a bit different from typical possession movies but it wasn't far off. There were rules that had to be followed to deal with the possessed but the film doesn't take advantage of the rules it made. The film could have shown why each rule should be followed. There also weren't any high tension moments or even any scares. The film became more disappointing towards the end with the use of the children inside the school. It just made for a weak ending.

Review-Title: The Best Horror Film for YEARS
Review-Description: When it comes to horror When Evil Lurks delivers on every count, whether it is atmosphere or gore, this movie holds back nothing. I had meant to watch this film for some time, as I had only heard good things about it, so I finally sat down today to watch it. I was not left disappointed. This film delivered everything I had been waiting for from a new horror film, apart from the scares, but that is not the film's fault. I am desensitized to horror. So I am sure it holds many nail-biting moments for most. I can't fault anything, the acting was fantastic, the locations and the special effects. You need to watch this film. Yes, it has subtitles, but people need to get over that. There is a world of foreign horror out there that deserves to be indulged in. One warning though, if you can't handle horror/gore involving children then this probably isn't the film for you.

I watched this movie without text. I don't know Spanish. Just the gist of it got me the creeps. The first part of it was so discusting that I grap my mouth. I am sorry that I didn't know what that was about, but I think that old lady was trying to keep the evil contained. Correct me if I am wrong. She really begged him not to shot this discusting creature. I know that I would have shot it. But that is just me. The first half was really discusting and threw me off. I still thought I was following the point. The only thing that was ruining it for me were the painted kids. The were not believable.

I do not understand people who are raving about this film. It has good ideas for sure, but everything was executed so poorly that it reminded me of a high school production with cheap makeup and overacting children. The acting is horrific. Everyone was screaming at the top of their lungs, which was highly annoying. The main character is probably the most stupid person you'll ever see in horror movies. The production looks extremely cheap. Child actors obviously cannot act. The lore is not explained. There is no sense of horror at any point, and there is a happy end because everyone stops screaming, and you are just relieved.

Unpleasant characters who garner no sympathy, combined with a loosely constructed plot, make this movie difficult to watch. There are many positive reviews of this movie on IMDB, so this review is in the minority. How one reacts to a movie is subjective of course. But an objective fact is that the writer and director of this movie are the same person. Far more often than not this kind of arrangement results in excesses and shortcomings, presumably because there is no one to check or balance the work of the other. I saw this movie's score among fans so I had high hopes. (I never read the "critics" anymore.) This movie was a disappointment I'm sorry to say.

Review-Title: Good movie ruined by the ending
Review-Description: I was ready to recommend this movie to all my friends until I saw the last 10 minutes of it. Those last 10 minutes ruined the movie for me. A typical example of the cliche trope of the main character making the worst possible choice even though he knows better, but the movie plot needs to happen so he has to do the worst thing imaginable which does not suit the character at all. So if you can stomach a trash ending, then I recommend this movie to you. It has really good moments, but again, be prepared to have one of the most unsatisfying movie endings in any horror movie to date. A shame really.

Review-Title: Tense horror movie with interesting premises that unfortunately does not deliver a satisfying ending.
Review-Description: I enjoyed the premise of "When Evil Lurks", I think that it is an original possession story, that part ways with the usual stereotypes of this kind of horror. The evil takes over the lives of Jimi and Pedro slowly and painfully. The audience assists to this inevitable ascent of the darkness that multiple times outsmart the characters, despite all the precautions and strategies that they apply. The director took a realistic approach and some elements of the story are raw and credible. There is no unjustified over the top violence and no pointless jumpscares. The script takes the time to deepen the backstory of Pedro and his family, making him vulnerable and relatable to the eyes of the audience. The narration is fervid and there are many tense sequences that deliver some unexpected moments. This is in my opinion what made the first half great. Unfortunately the film starts to lose its appeal midway. All the tension that built up completely disappeared in the second part of the film. The protagonist takes impulsive decisions that have no logic and that will cost him dearly. In my opinion this goes against the nature of the character, that from the beginning constantly warns others how to kill the possessed, without contracting the curse. The ending is very dramatic and it leaves things open for a possible sequel (that most likely will not happen). Overall I liked the general concept of this film, but the director (who is also the screenwriter) made some decisions that prevented this film from achieving its true potential. "When Evil Lurks" could be one of the best 2023 horror movies, but unfortunately it only gets a 6. It is still a solid film, but I was expecting way better.

Review-Title: Ridiculously over the top, but had its moments.
Review-Description: I enjoyed watching it, but damn there were a lot of absolutely asinine moments and ridiculous events. I knew it was going to be stupid going in, so I told myself to ignore all the stupidity and enjoy the movie. Parts were good. Statham is always fun to watch, and the other leads were quite good, except the actress who played his daughter. Maybe not her fault, maybe her dialogue and and her role in the film. The Megs were actually well done as well as the other critters. And the action was quite fun at the beginning. And the overall production values were quite good to excellent. Parts were amusing, the dislogue was mostly fun. But, it kept getting more and more ridiculous. Both the stunts and the actions characters takes. For example, three Megs were chomping up tourists in a harbor. Meanwhile, his daughter was in a life guard tower watching the events in horror. She spots a lady struggling 100 feet offshore. She apparently has time to climb down the 40 foot tower, get to the beach, find a surfboard, paddle out to the women before she drowns or gets eaten by one of the ravenous Megs. And of course they don't chomp her as well. The way he kills the Megs is preposterous, but fun if you can manage to overlook how preposterous. It's hard to do, very hard to do. If you like Sharknado movies, this is a couple steps above those:)

Review-Title: Average sequel in which Jason Statham and friends must now face a terrible old enemy for the second time
Review-Description: Thrilling film in which a scientific team goes horribly wrong, releasing the deadliest ocean predators that have ever roamed the seas since prehistoric times. Jonas Taylor: Jason Statham continues to dedicate himself to the environmental care of the oceans and collaborates with the Hainan Oceanographic Institute, China. In this place, Haiqui, a female megalodon that the director of the center intends to train, is kept imprisoned. Technological advances are evident, and now the team of marine ecologists can embark towards the unknown depths of the sea, however when the underwater expedition begins, Haiqui escapes. Then a trench and a malevolent mining operation that explodes free extinct vicious carnivorous animals causing bloody events with lots of gory scenes. As the deep-sea scientific team encounter the largest ferocious marine prehistoric predator that has ever existed - the Megalodon and in its own way wreaking havoc. Get ready for the ultimate adrenaline rush this summer in "Meg 2: The Trench" !. Dive into uncharted waters with Jason Statham and global action icon Wu Jing as they lead a daring research team on an exploratory dive into the deepest depths of the ocean! Immerse yourself in the most electrifying cinematic experience of the year with "Meg 2: The Trench" - where the depths of the ocean are matched only by the heights of sheer, unstoppable excitement !. New Meg. Old Chum. Back for seconds. There is always another one. Terror has never run this deep...Fear runs deep. You already know that this movie is about a prehistoric mega-shark rising from the depths and terrorizing the scientists crew. An inferior and literally larger-than-life thrill ride that supersizes the 2018 blockbuster and takes the action to higher heights and even greater depths with multiple massive Megs and so much more. It's a so-so action monster monster movie with a creepy creation of tension , thrills , terror and lots of bloody attacks. The released prehistoric man-eating Megalodon that joins with others of the same species deliver the goods, as the swimmers become their next meal while the scientists must band together to stop themselves from becoming fish food. Here our heroes and heroines pitted against colossal Megs, gigantic octopus, huge toothy monitors and relentless environmental plunderers, our heroes must outrun, outsmart, and outswim their merciless predators in a pulse-pounding race against time. This is a peculiar rip-off to classic Jaws (1975) by Steven Spielberg and Piranha (1978) by Joe Dante, taking parts here and there of these films . Stars Jason Statham giving his ordinary acting as a two-fisted veteran deep-sea rescue diver must confront his fears and risk his own life and the lives of everyone trapped below. If you liked Jason Statham in the first The Meg movie, you will enjoy this follow-up with the iconic actor doing his thing, and facing more monsters than ever. The hunk starring is well accompanied by a fine cast , such as : Jing Wu, Sienna Guillory, Cliff Curtis, Sophia Cai, Page Kennedy, Sergio Peris-Mencheta, Skyler Samuels, Melissanthi Mahut, Whoopie Van Raam, Kiran Sonia Sawar, among others. The motion picture was mediocrely and with no originality directed by Ben Wheatley (The ABCs of Death, Tourists, Rebeca, High Rise, Doctor Who, In the earth, Free fire). The first ¬®Megalodon¬® (2018) by John Turteltaub with Jaon Statham, Bingbing Li, Rainn Wilson, Cliff Curtis, Ruby Rose , Winston Chao, Sophia Cai, Page Kennedy , Darri √ìlafsson, Robert Taylor, Jessica McNamee and Masi Oka has already created a mini-subgenre with imitations and rip-offs about this prehistorical animals , though some of them had been previously made , such as : ¬®Megalodon (2002)¬® by Pat Corbitt with Robin Sachs , Al Sapienza, Mark Sheppard.¬®Shark Attack 3: Megalodon¬® (2002) by David Worth with John Barrowman, Jenny McShane, Ryan Cutrona. ¬®Megalodon¬® (2018) by James Thomas with Michael Madsen , Caroline Harris. ¬®Megalodon Rising¬® (2021) with Tom Sizemore , Wynter Eddins, O'Shay Neal . ¬®Bigfoot vs Megalodon¬® (2021) by BC Fourteen, among others.

I don't think there is much more to say. Horrible. Pathetic. I just don't understand why garbage like this get made. The makers shou be embarrassed. The movie continues to get worse every minute it plays. The science has to be explained because how dumb it is
I usually like Jason, he was about all the film had. Story is horrible.. Story is horrible.. Story is horrible
CGI is really really bad. Like cartoons. Save yourself the money cause it's not worth spending money on this one. Or watch it,,, and give it a review. Maybe someone will read it and feel bad for making the movie. I wish it was as good as the first one.

Review-Title: What toxic waste has risen up from the depths of the Trench this time?
Review-Description: Meg 2: The Trench has no brains but a lot of balls to be as batshit crazy as it is. I don't know how else to say it. It's one of those sequels that has twenty ideas for a story and uses ALL of them. It features not just one giant prehistoric shark but three of them. Plus a kraken sized octopus. And we got creepy little dinosaur-like reptiles scurrying about. There's even an early scene that is clearly meant as a 'take that' to JURASSIC PARK. Bold as brass, says I. The story picks up years after the first movie and Jason Statham is raising the precocious daughter from the first movie on his own while still keeping an eye out for those pesky Megalodons. But an evil businesswoman is illegally exploiting the mega sharks' territory for profit (the fiend!!!) and now there are more megalodons plus other prehistoric monsters swimming loose towards the surface. Ben Wheatley directed this movie and he's done movies that I liked quite a bit like High-Rise and Free Fire. What I gathered from those movies was his dark sense of humor and to his credit, that remains here. There is a lot of civilian casualties in this movie and I respect that. And there's a few death scenes that are surprisingly brutal for a PG13. I can't say this is a project for thespians or method actors to get involved in. But some people know what movie they're in and are having more fun than usual. Especially Page Kennedy. He got some laughs from me. Jason Statham is one of those actors who it's hard to tell if he is bored or if it's just the accent. But he's not terrible in this, I guess. Sienna Guillory is laughably bad as the evil CEO who keeps making bad decisions that only serve to get herself killed. There is some crappy dialogue in the script though. Look not for a monologue on par with Quint's USS Indianapolis speech in JAWS or the lunch debate in JURASSIC PARK. Expect a lot of one-liners trying to be quippy but instead a lot of them are quite pithy. Though if it's Statham saying it, it's a little bit cool. As incredibly weird and goofy this movie is, there are some cool action scenes to be had. When you can see them. The trench scenes are darkly lit and it is hard to see. But once the action moves to the surface and on land, it is easier to see and more fun to watch. Especially with the different monsters that show up in the third act. This movie honestly felt even more of a throwback to the schlocky B-movie creature features we got in the 1990s than the first movie was. For better and for worse.

Review-Title: The Fast X of shark movies
Review-Description: This was a waste of time. I watched it on Netflix so it's not like I saw it in theatres or anything, but still. It was a never-ending mess of absurd nonsense. The beginning with the dinosaurs and the infiltrating of the cargo ship scenes were pretty enjoyable, but from there it quickly fell off the rails. I lost enthusiasm with the megalodon in captivity, because we can't even keep great whites in captivity. And then, the trench part. It's an "unexplored trench" and you expect me to believe that there's a whole mining base already underway down there, ran by the boss of the whole ocean discovery company? Also, the fact that they see more Megs and are immediately like, "cool, more Megs, let's follow them!" Like do you not remember what happened last time? Those underwater dinosaur guys were a dumb addition too. Dinosaurs need air to survive so it kind of doesn't make sense that they've been hiding down there away from human eyes all this time. Then there's this random giant octopus that comes out of NOWHERE and escapes through the whatever-it's-called ocean layer with the three Megs and attack a resort island with the most creative name ever. Are you ready? Fun Island. My baby cousin could have come up with that. So the sharks and the octopus attack Fun Island and the big shot bad guy last and her Spanish mercs are there for some reason and so obviously they get killed by the little dinosaurs. And so our pal Jason Statham and his eco-warrior posse complete with a guy with a big Desert Eagle among other things in his pack that can manage to kick two bad guys in the face despite being pretty out of shape. Sure. Then the Megs are killed by Jason on a jet ski he stole with some homemade stick bombs and a helicopter bomb(because of course every underwater researcher can fly helicopters) and they save the world. The end. Don't watch. Seriously, don't. The original was cool because it was new and unique. This is just taking that movie and mating it with a Fast and Furious movie.

Review-Title: Its a fun movie. Science.....who cares?!
Review-Description: Look, I don't know what people have as far as expectations for the movie industry these days, but all I expect is to be entertained. I was entertained. This movie was fun and although it was not as good as the first movie, it was still entertaining to watch. Yes, the X could've been better, but seeing is though this is a megalodon shark movie I give it some grace for jumping the shark. No pun intended. I did not come into this expecting it to be scientifically, correct if you come into this movie expecting that you are setting yourself up for failure. Just sit back. Relax and enjoy the movie .

Review-Title: This movie has an identity crisis..
Review-Description:
The first part of the movie , well more like 2/3's was trying to be a suspense/ action movie w a bit of sci-fi, and drama...then it turned into a comedy/horror failed attempt at camp flick. Essentially this film is a "what not to do when making a film in any genre 101" . I gave it a 2 or 3 stars because I actually don't even think there's anything the actors could do to save the script so the acting isn't even the worse part. What I expected and what it was...
I didn't expect this to be scary but at least have some jump scares and a bit of excitement and some cohesive story however I found myself fast forwarding through most of the first half's dialogue because it was that boring. The action scenes are pretty bad with overdone Cgi making it hard to even follow what is happening in the scene. I actually kept forgetting some scenes were supposed to be under water as it didn't resemble water at all, it looked more like bad space scenes. Another issue was the way the actors were so unaffected by things, like when their friends and family are possibly dead the rest of the crew acts so matter of fact that it leaves the viewer not caring either. It's a good movie to keep on while doing house work since there's only a couple ok scenes and the storyline is pretty dumb.

Review-Title: Meg 2: The Trench is campy ... But not in a fun way.
Review-Description: I am certain that this film was made for the sole reason of giving the actors and crew a reason to go on location in Phuket, Thailand. I expected the film to be a bit of fun or maybe have some funny moments, but nope ... that didn't happen. My viewing standards have changed over the years so maybe I simply cannot get into these sort of movies any longer. And here's a very strange observation: Anyone in the cast who had a villainous role was a poster-child for bad cosmetic surgery and/or 'roid use. The only character I liked was DJ (Page Kennedy) who is reprising his role from 2018's "The Meg". I liked him because he seemed like the only half-way believable and sane actor in the entire film. And the monsters were cartoonish.

Just got through watching the Meg 2. I thought the first one was a stretch, but maybe could happen. This one, while interesting was just so farfetched and ridiculous. That I was asking myself...how LONG is this movie. Is it over yet? That's a bad sign. I appreciate that most of the cast returned for the second movie, but the constant comedic quips and outlandish fighting scenes, like firing a .50 caliber firearm while leaping sideways to shoot a prehistoric creature is just one such instance. I know movies like to go bigger and better than the first movie, but really...it was a bit TOO much. I'm praying there isn't a Meg 3 in the works. Peace.

Review-Title: I wasn't expecting much, but yikes.
Review-Description: The first one was really quite bad, but at least seemed self aware of its mindless creature feature nature. It still had the occasional jump scare and silly "so bad, it's funny" moments. This sequel has absolutely nothing going for it. I'm being generous with a 2/10. It was boring nonsense from beginning to end. Terrible performances across the board, worse than terrible writing with wall to wall cringe worthy dialogue... I get what they were going for trying to pack in other scary creatures but meh. Lame execution and didn't care enough about any single character to respond to what crazy thing was eating who. Maybe the stupid "Chomp On This" hip hop credits song would have been funny if any part of the movie had been remotely entertaining. Instead, it made it even worse because the confident tone of it only works if any part of the film had been successful and satisfying. Do not waste your time.

This film has fallen victim of mis-listing: someone somewhere put the tags "comedy" and "thriller" beside the title, that is. It is neither though. It is a dark satire: a vitriolic portray of loathsome characters in an allegory. So, if you know what a satire is supposed to be like AND you like the genre, you'll probably like The Menu. If you don't know what a satire is, google it before watching. If you don't like what you'd find, don't waste your time on the film, as you wouldn't like it either. If you don't feel like googling, here are some clues: it's NOT funny, there's NO character development and NO catharsis. If In fact you'll probably feel annoyed, tense and a bit sick to your stomach by the end, as it DOES show mirror to the middle class wannabe connoiseurs of all kinds. So if you still watch it and you don't like that you see... well.... You've been warned.

Ive worked at the restaurant industry for seven years. Customers can truely make or break your day. This movie explores the dynamic between server and customer, with over the top drama and horror. It is such a unique movie, because they really make you feel the built up frustration of the servers and cooks. There is great attention to detail in the movie. The dishes look fly af, which I think is a great addition. In the beginning, you feel like youre experiencing the dishes with the customers. This makes the movie that much more intruiging. After Jeremies 'the mess', things take a turn. It becomes more of a 'saw' type of thing. Of course, the movie had to take this turn. However, I felt like the turn could have been more subtle. The servers are all unanimously suicidal, insane and sadistic. I understand that this could be some sort of analogy for the thoughts I used to have when having a bad day at work. Still, the movie turns bizarre at this point. All in all, I liked it. Great acting, asthonishing dishes, thrilling story. A bit over the top, but that did not spoil my appetite fortunately.

I knew there were some shocks in this movie and something with the food cooked in the movie. I was generally surprised by some of the twists and was entertained throughout. I guess the movie is a satire about the silliness of gourmet dining and how critiques and the business side of the restaurant business ruin the joy of cooking. The story is about a couple who get on a boat to a private island to eat at a restaurant by this renowned chef played by Ralph Fiennes. There are other people there including a couple who dines their regularly, business man, a movie star and his publicist on the decline, and a food critic. Throughout the movie there is a focus on the couple, where the man sseems enamored by the chef, while his date is a last minute addition to the evening. The movie goes through each course of the dinner and there is a story behind each meal. These get increasingly odd and shocking such as laser printing images on tortillas that are of relevance to the person and may make them look bad, and a chef killing himself. Once this occurs the movie becomes more of a thriller as the guests start to figure out they are in danger. The way the movie ends is odd but interesting and I got what it meant.

I enjoyed the first half, the food tasting and watching the show. But as a whole the movie leaves a bad taste, a thick toxic anti-rich people sentiment and other political messaging, with an unlikeable female lead (naturally, everyone was unlikeable but felt incorrect that she was too). A pity, it was so close to being good. Zooming out, there is probably some high IQ satirizing I just don't get. As it could probably be deconstructed into various deeper takes on society; paradoxical as a similar deconstruction (this intellectual circle jerking and food critique) was the very thing that was depicted satirically in the movie to begin with. How quaint... - see I can sound like a movie critic too, but Chef knows I really belong in the kitchen. Anyway, why do they push so hard that society only consists of two kinds of people: takers and producers (proletariat)? A peculiar dichotomy, too toxic for me, but maybe I just don't understand.

A surreal film that evoked numerous emotions within me,
High visual quality and great storytelling,
A fantastic, profound story full of surprises,
An exceptional work that is rarely matched! The output quality was professional, and the story plot was thrilling. I liked the unexpected and coherent sequence of events! I admired the portrayal of the social pressure and occupational burnout caused by capitalism on the chef! It was unexpected that there was no dialogue at the end. The girl's reaction after being rescued was not announced; it only stopped when the restaurant exploded! The movie has an underlying message, which is "you should listen to others to understand them and know how to interact with them, and you should find someone who listens to you." When the girl heard the chef and spoke to him, confronting him, it was a great gesture that saved her life.

What a waste of time. Really. Started nice. Good Atmosphere. But then it went downhill the whole time. You are waiting for a twist, for it to make sense, for anything to happen really. But it doesnt. The guests dont do nothing while people get killed, while knowing they are gonna be killed. Yeah, Sure. ü§¶ No character close to a human in this storyline. All characters are flat as F and not relatable. They act like they are aliens. And you dont care for them, since they dont do anything. Who wrote that? WTH It's like a dude on the street had one tiny idea about a point he wanted to make and then he accidentally won the lottery to produce a movie, while all authors and screenplay writers were on strike. So he just did it in his own. In one night. Reviewers here call it great satire on rich people here, cause it's "different" and depicts rich peoples obsession over art. Or that people consume Till the end even when they know this will kill them. All that stuff. Bluh bluh. It just doesnt work. The irony: these reviewers might be exactly these "art obsessed" people they are talking about. Interpreting the "overall picture" and stuff in it to make themselves important by "understanding" the movie, while others (like me) are just bored as hell. The movie is consistent in it's stupidity. What a waste of Ralph Fiennes btw. (and pretty much any actor in this movie; but hey, they got paid)

If they didn't tell white people this was a comedy they would never know.... Or is this funny to them? As I sit in between my blackness and my girlfriend (which has direct recent European ancestry) I ponder the entire world in the 43mins I could take before I started to feel like my brain cells were being destroyed, what's wrong with them? Are they the devil? Are they so deeply vile that in any scenario this waste of time of a film could be considered a comedy? Are they human? Am I human? Are they individual idiots but genus smar..... Do they understand they are the scourge of the planet that is causing everything that they from "climate change" to killing precious animals plants and other natural life with deforestation and the continuous but unnecessary drilling fracking drills and pumping of this earth. Then it hits me if I was a demon spawn an evil person then I would think this a comedy.

Review-Title: A film about the revenge of the common man
Review-Description: The film The Menu is about a chef, Chef Slowik- played by Ralph Fiennes, who invites a group of upper-class foodies to a conceptually themed dinner. Each of the guests invited or allowed, he believed enacted some sort of transgression related to entitlement and corruption of power. The film takes place at Hawthorne, on a secluded island that you must travel to by ferry. The main characters included Margot- played by Anya Taylor-Joy, Tyler- played by Nicholas Hoult, Elsa- played by Hong Chau, among several others. The menu is comprised of different lessons or courses, pertaining to his customers. Throughout the courses of the dining experience, you find out what each customer was guilty of. With each course, the Chef gives an overview of what inspired the dishes. Within each overview is a back-handed compliment to the food and the diners. The unexpecting guests have no idea what type of dining experience they are in for until the third course. This course, named "Memory" was preceded by an introduction in which his sous chef, Jeremy-played by Adam Aalderks, unexpectedly put a gun in his mouth and pulled the trigger. At this point, the guests of the restaurant knew they were in for something they did not sign up for. The obvious theme of this film is about classism, and how the elites can never be satisfied no matter how exquisite the product is. Chef Slowik has come to believe that the more money people have, the more ungrateful they are for the little things in life and his goal for his final masterpiece was to show his guests and the world what we have come to. His satirical titles and ideas behind his dishes in the film describe just how far his guests are from the "common man". The Menu is said to be similar to the film The Feast because they both have a viewpoint of punishing the elites. The film uses lighting and color to emphasize the theme. In every scene, we see vibrant colors, from the colors of the plants when they are walking on the tour, to the colors in the dishes. Everything is energetic and astonishing, as is the entire film. The film also incorporates a smooth-grain film stock which goes perfectly with the theme of classism. It displays the top of the line clarity and contrasts, only for the best, just as for the guests at Hawthorne.

I went to cinema with my sister 6 months ago just to spend friday evening. What an absolute masterpiece, i enjoyed every minute of it. I decided yesterday to watch it again. Still, an absolute masterpiece. But i have slightly different view on this. First of all, yes, it's reflects of how meaningless an absolute perfection is. An absolute pinnacle of restaurant cuisine to these snobs is like throwing pearls to pig, they just dont appreciate it. For rich couple it's just another dinner to discuss daily problems, for critics just another evening to get inspiration for next article. For finance-bros just another expensive dinner to get drunk that they can easily afford,. For that failed actor just another expensive place to bring his date. But i think Tyler is the only one who truly did enjoy it. I'm sure getting a seat there was one of the highlights of it, dude probably didnt sleep for a week looking forward to it. Same pattern could be seen on every aspect of life. Cars for example. Rich folk drive Lamborghinis-Ferraris-Maseratis. I overheard some rich kid rolling to highschool in brand new Hellcat, he didnt even know which engine is in it - just asked daddy to get him the highest trim level. But Tyler on the otherhand, probably works on a low level job and could never have such lifestyle. So after saving up a bunch of money he could finally afford a trip to Dubai, to rent a Ferrari for 24h. And you can be sure that he drove 24h straight and could remember every second of it for the rest of his life. I'm sure that rich couple have whole basement full of expensive wines, 10 high-end cars in their mansion's garage, have seen everything and every place they have desired - but still feel empty inside as they have reached absolute tip of the life and cant climb any higher.

Review-Title: A story of needing a little appreciation
Review-Description: *Includes spoilers* The plot of this film is people going to an exclusive restaurant, that is owned by a chef who has lost his love for cooking, and no one appreciates his food. Ralph Fiennes, who plays Chef, once had a large love for cooking. Slowly, his love for cooking grew smaller and all he tried to do was please people. Anya Taylor-Joy, who portrays Margot, was not originally supposed to be at the restaurant. She is able to save herself when she becomes honest with the Chef about his food. She is the only one who can truly appreciate his food, as she is also in the service industry. Tyler, portrayed by Nicholas Holt, appreciates the Chef, but in an obsessive "I want to be you" way. Part of the theme is "appreciation". Chef just wants people to recognize his talent and art. When he realizes that does not happen, he decides to take others down with him. Throughout the film, while Chef feels no appreciation, he is still searching for it. Margot, being in a service industry also, understands the need for appreciation. Lighting plays a part in this theme. In the beginning, the lighting is bright, which shows everyone is excited to go to the restaurant, the camera angles and lighting of the island show the appreciation of the agriculture. It shows how lively the island is with the crops and the animals. In the restaurant, the lighting is not as vibrant, except for in the kitchen. This helps to show that the customers do not truly appreciate Chef, although the staff members in the kitchen do. The camera angle towards the end also shows appreciation. When Margot asks for a cheeseburger, it invokes a happy memory for Chef, a time when he appreciated cooking. When Margot enjoys the cheeseburger, the camera angle is a close-up of Chef, showing his expression of feeling genuinely appreciated. Overall, this film shows how lack of appreciation can cause a person to feel lost and without purpose. The slightest bit of appreciation can make a person feel gratitude and feel like they have a purpose again.

Review-Title: "No, I'm a star! Please, I'm a star! Please, somebody help me!"
Review-Description: FILM: 7.5/10. Stuck in a mandatory two-week quarantine, Ti West did what any filmmaker would do - he wrote a prequel to a film he hadn't even shot. Collaborating with lead Mia Goth, they churned out a script for Pearl, the prequel to X, and A24 greenlit it for shooting before a single frame of X was seen. Turns out, it was a smart decision. Pearl not only stands as an excellent film in its own right but also surpasses its predecessor. Ti West and his team maintain consistency with X, yet Pearl takes a wholly different approach. While X had a grungy, grainy look capturing the essence of 1979, Pearl embraces a clean, vibrant, and pure aesthetic - a perfect reflection of how the character Pearl sees herself in the world. Unlike X's ensemble approach, Pearl places the load on Mia Goth's shoulders, and she delivers a fantastic performance. As a psychotic imitation of Judy Garland's Dorothy from The Wizard of Oz, Goth brings a unique and captivating energy to her character. David Corenswet, known for being the newly cast Superman, impresses as the Projectionist, giving me an opportunity to witness his talent beyond a single House of Cards episode. Much like X, Pearl takes its time with the horror elements, and when the terror unfolds, it's as gloriously entertaining as its predecessor. What sets it apart, however, is its effectiveness in contrasting with the vibrant experience earlier in the film. Ti West's Pearl is a smart and visually striking prequel that successfully navigates the horror genre with finesse, proving that even in quarantine, creative risks can pay off. Ultimately, it stands as a superior counterpart to X. FORMAT: Blu-ray VIDEO: 10/10. 1080p presentation, Detail level: Excellent, Colour reproduction: Excellent, Level accuracy: Excellent, Encode: Excellent, Master condition: Excellent AUDIO: 9.5/10. DTS-HD MA 5.1 audio, Dialogue reproduction: Excellent, Soundtrack & effects clarity: Excellent, Dynamics: Excellent, Surround sound presentation: Excellent, LFE content: Excellent MOOFIEMETER: 7/10.

It's a formulaic pretentious, boring movie. It has all the elements of a horror cult, but without any substance to it. Mia Goth is phenomenal, but it's such a waste to see a performance like that in a very dull movie. People seem to be impressed very easily these days considering I can only assume all the hype comes from Goth's acting, that monologue and the final smile that closes the film, but at least in my opinion those are not enough to make this movie any good and, especially, consistent. I think the first movie was ok and I'm still curious to see what Goth will pull off next time, but I don't want to see that pathetic smile ever again in my life.

I can only assume this is getting good reviews because people adore Mia Goth and can't get enough of her playing crazy people, because, as a film, this just does not work. It's not scary, lacks tension, is badly structured and poorly paced, and is in DIRE need of an editor. It feels both too long and too short, like it ends at the end of the second act. It's barely even a film - just a bunch of acting and a thin, half-arsed script, with some pretentious and undeveloped Wizard Of Oz stylings thrown in. Scenes drag on forever, way past the point of terminal boredom, just so that Goth can show off her acting. I've never felt so much impatience and fidgeting in a cinema. The ending is supposed to be disturbing, but it just ends up being comical. To put this into perspective, I thought 'X' was ok, slightly above -average but nothing special. I thought House Of The Devil was a minor classic, and I thought The Sacrament was quite effective and tense. Mia Goth is a good actor, but she always seems to play the same part. 'Pearl' just feels like an actor's indulgence.

Incredible to see people rating this pretentious fare so highly, but I guess that's modern tastes for you and I'm somehow out of sync with everybody else. This one's a prequel to the dire X and turns out to be even worse, a ridiculous 'origin' story that's so slim it doesn't require telling in the first place. Mia Goth is the star turn here and delivers a twee, over the top performance, her acting so mannered and false from the outset that I could barely bring myself to watch her. There are a few predictable deaths but they're overshadowed by the director's decision to shoot this like an old fashioned Technicolor epic for no good reason. The end result? A film utterly devoid of substance.

Review-Title: It's good. But ignore the 9 star reviews, it's not even in the top 5 Mia Goth films!
Review-Description: Look, it's fine. Arguably, better than fine - it's good. But that's it! Yes Mia Goth is terrific, as she always is, but the delirious level of praise I'm seeing in numerous reviews giving it 8 or 9 stars is frankly mind boggling, and was what spurred me to write this "everyone just calm down" of a review. To those reviewers that raved about this movie and bestowed the superlative 9 stars, I have but a simple question: have you not watched any other films before? I'm trying really hard not to be condescending (ok, not that hard), but if this flic merits 9 stars, then what on earth do any of the following films merit? Alien, The Shining, Interstellar, The Departed, The Prestige, Inception... to name but a few. Like I said, it's good. But it's not even in the top 5 Mia Goth films: The Survivalist, Suspiria, Emma, Infinity Pool, A cure for wellness. Go watch those before this!

Review-Title: "Pearl" explores the limits of a character full of traumas, dreams and frustrations who, despite everything, apparently, will never stop believing that she is a star
Review-Description: The year is 1918. Young Pearl (Mia Goth) has returned to live on her parents' farm after her husband Howard (Alistair Sewell) was drafted into the Great War. Pearl dreams of being a great dancer, famous throughout the country, so her frustration in returning to live at her parents' house, where she needs to take care of her sick father and is constantly humiliated by her mother, is enormous. When she discovers that a selection process for new artists in a dance company will be held in her city, Pearl sees the opportunity for the life she always wanted. But the consequences of her decision will go far beyond what she could imagine. Created by Ti West and Mia Goth, and produced simultaneously with "X", "Pearl" is the sequel that many fans of the previous film didn't know they needed. Overexplaining is often condemned in horror cinema, and the story of the elderly murderer in "X" really required no further explanation. But West and Goth treat the character's transformation process with so much care and affection that the minimal references covered (such as the justification of the character's anger towards blondes, or the iconic gesture of silence) work almost like fan service. Just like its eponymous protagonist, "Pearl" is a film with many layers. It can be seen as just an origin story, but it is much more than that. It is also an essay on mental health, taking into account the psychotic tendencies demonstrated by the character from the beginning, exacerbated by the cornering imposed by her own reality. Explaining who the damn villain was who turned our stomachs with such graphic deaths, the prequel to "X" is not that classic jump scare horror, but it is definitely an impeccable essay on a psychotic break. Pearl's (Mia Goth) reality could drive anyone crazy. With her husband at war, she dedicates her days back to her parents' house, where she must take care of her father - who remains in a vegetative state -, while being constantly humiliated and mistreated by her mother. Between the chores on the farm and the palliative care that takes away her energy, she dreams of the life of a star on stage and in cinema. Always between the purest and most mind-blowing fantasy and a harsh reality never desired, she tries to chart her path towards success, fame and plastic beauty. What they didn't tell you is that in an arid land, dreams born from the field don't tend to flourish. And under a very technicolor aesthetic, which harks back to the format of films from the 50s and 60s, Ti West delivers another brilliant horror that goes much further than the combo of scares that normally awaits us in a slasher horror. "Pearl" is in fact a chaotic spiral of a young woman adrift of her own existence, who perishes in a mediocre life where her identity and personality are stifled and succumbed to the pressures of an aggressive, insensitive and indifferent matriarch. But regardless of the family context that brought Pearl to us, it is undeniable that villainy already lived within her, as West makes a point of showing in her tortuous way of sacrificing defenseless animals. And this construction is fundamental to turning the elderly Pearl from "X" into a cruel and monstrous creature in the eyes of the characters and, obviously, the audience. The story takes place in the 60s, at the beginning of the 20th century. In the typical horror setting of rural, isolated and silent America, we meet Pearl (Mia Goth), a seemingly ordinary young woman in pre-Depression America. Pearl is tormented by the anguish of her husband's return from war. This anguish gives part of the tone of the film. Anxiety gives Pearl a feeling of stagnation, of being there and stuck with her family. Pearl needs to take care of her father, who needs special care. She needs to be surrounded by her mother, who judges her and weighs her relationship with the world - a classic for complex female characters. But the family does not appear to be extremely dysfunctional like in other films of the genre. With a surgical simplicity, the photography and scenography perfectly mask what lies behind this bucolic setting. Like a bad apple: rotten on the inside, but very beautiful on the outside. Here we have the interesting issue of mixing times and themes. A narrative with deep discussions about the feminine, family conflicts and psychoses, issues that derive from the culmination of crises between the different areas of a human being's mind, so explored in horror cinema from the seventies - there we have infinite iconic examples of characters who they stained the youthful imagination of the time with blood - but in a setting from the beginning of the 20th century. The focus on emotions and family relationships, a vulnerable and uncertain main character, who develops into a very subversive and adverse heroine's trajectory, and a lot of symbolic depth, transform "Pearl" into a beautiful way of making bloody cinema. The film features "gore" scenes from the beginning, but it is in the second half that things start to get even stranger. Ti West manages to make us nervous by bringing horror scenes that take place in the dark or in broad daylight, causing that nail-biting anxiety just because we are sure that what is coming is not at all good. The characterization with more colorful tones and farm settings that bring peace, and even remind us of "The Sound of Music", contrast perfectly with the slasher every time blood is spilled. But terror is also in every word and attitude of the protagonist, who surprises in several moments, such as a frightening and uncut monologue seen in the final moments of the film. Pearl ends up discovering that the film industry also relies on pornography, and this discovery is crucial to the plot's relationship with "X", which takes place more than 60 years after "Pearl". Connecting both films in a natural and almost imperceptible way, this is a derivative that stands on its own two feet and in several moments is nothing like "X". With a slightly metalinguistic approach and a different narrative development, the film focuses on the self-destructive journey of a young woman who goes crazy in the face of her reality and the impossibility of her dreams. The plot of "Pearl" is simple, only on the surface. And this is because the complexity of the narrative does not revolve around the story itself (although it contributes, of course, to the final result), but rather, its protagonist. In this sense, Ti West's film is a beautiful character study, a lesson in how to explore the different facets of a figure and what led her to become what she became. In fact, it would be unfair to praise only Ti West for the successes of "Pearl", given that Mia Goth is also one of the work's screenwriters and producers. The actress not only helped create an entire narrative conducive to the protagonist's transformation into a terrible villain, but also delivered an award-worthy performance (no wonder, many complained about her absence in the Best Actress category at the 2023 Oscars). It is impressive how the artist manages to reinvent herself throughout the narrative, going from a naive and hopeful girl to a disillusioned and broken woman, who rebuilds herself through a cold, villainous figure, who has no problem murdering her own parents, her love interest, husband and sister-in-law in favor of what she wants most: fame (or would it be freedom through fame?). Talking about how the actress alternates between periods of remission and psychotic episodes in a matter of seconds, or the show of expressions in her smile in the final scene, is redundant. But what she delivers in an 8-minute-long monologue in the last act of the film is astounding. The young woman's speech, filmed without cuts (seriously, the passage is exquisite), summarizes everything that Pearl carried within her: frustration, depression, sadness, anger, love, dreams and so on. All cards are laid out on the table with an emotion and intensity that are not so common to see, especially in horror films, which tend to focus much more on their scary plots than on the development of their characters. And we still couldn't fail to mention the next scene, with the ax sequence, which is simply harrowing. Filling its second act with a bloodthirsty that will fill the eyes of those most hungry for slashers, "Pearl" still makes room for a touch of humor and plays with the emotional fluctuations of its protagonist, transforming it into a small mix between horror and a sarcasm with an acidic and cutting humor. Violent but not at all scary, Ti West's newest film is something of a villain's journey. While making a number of connections, the film doesn't add anything genuinely new to "The Mark of Death," it's a wonderful companion piece, the kind of conceptual horror that's so meticulously well-made, it deserves to be enjoyed even as a one-off experience. A young woman face to face with the worst version of herself. The film also brings an interesting critique about fame: is anything worth it to reach the top? For Pearl, limits are non-existent and there is nothing more important than the glamor of the stage. In this sense, her blood-red clothing, used during the last act of the film, in addition to representing the deaths she carries with her, is a symbol of her passion and obsession (red usually has this connotation in cinematographic works). With a masterful performance by Mia Goth, "Pearl" is a pleasant surprise and hits the nail on the head when exploring the limits of a character full of traumas, dreams and frustrations who, despite everything, apparently, will never stop believing that she is a star.

Review-Title: My favorite film of 2022. Goth is a tour de force! (minor spoilers)
Review-Description: This is my favorite movie of 2022 hands down. I'd dare call it perfect even. Pearl is unlike any other serial killer origin film I've seen. Without doubt due to Mia Goth, who, with this and her (terrifying) role in Brandon Cronenberg's "Infinity Pool" solidifies her indie/cult queen status. I will watch anything with her in it from now on. The film is actually a prequel to director Ti West's underwhelming slasher "X" (also starring Goth though criminally under utilized) but can be viewed as a stand alone film as it's entirely different in tone, visuals, pacing etc.. in other words (other than the alligator and the husband becoming what he is in X) there's essentially no connection. Most serial killer films are about men and concentrate on anger or abnormal psychology-bizarre motives etc. It tends to get boring. Pearl doesn't have motives except to get off the farm she lives in. She isn't a psychopath or evil. She's abandoned and lives in a state of trauma. To cope with this she has fantasies of being a star. Of a perfect world for her and her husband. She thinks her dreams are coming true when she meets a projectionist who promises to show her the world. It's only when the dream of escape is shattered that she snaps into murderous rage. The pinnacle of the film (and some of the finest acting you will ever see) is a 7 minute shot of Pearl unloading EVERYTHING she feels inside to the horror of the person listening. I shall say no more. A truly iconic scene. It is sort of similar to "May" with its themes of loneliness/isolation which is a stellar film I recommend. Lastly: Ti West I've always wanted to love Ti West's films but generally find them disappointing (I did enjoy House of the Devil and The Sacrament) however this film is in a league of its own. And while Mia Goth IS the film (and also co writer) West still made it possible and does so via beautiful cinematography (It's a very colorful film) and PERFECT pacing (my biggest complaint from his previous films) The body count is low but graphic, but it isn't a slasher film. It's a coming of age character study of a girl so traumatized she turns to murder as a catharsis for her ever mounting woes.

Review-Title: Aside Lady Goth. Horror's new gold standard setter.
Review-Description: I've now seen all three of Mia Goth's extraordinary A24 movies this year. In each one she has singlehandedly carried the movie to ridiculous heights of greatness. All three are billed as horror (X as a slasher, Infinity Pool as an unhinged psychopath study and Pearl as another psychopath gestational study). All three deepen A24's reputation as the distributor of the year/decade, the greatest signifier of quality in moviemaking right now. All three mark out Goth as the leading horror female actor in history if not, increasingly, one of the great female actors of her generation full stop. It's Pearl that that confirms this most potently as her performance is jaw dropping throughout. It's the origin piece for X, but the two movies could hardly be less similar, even though the central character is the same person (60 years apart) and shot on the same farm location in Kansas. This tells the tale of young married Pearl with her husband labouring in the European trenches of WWII, her father a wheelchair stricken quadriplegic - a victim of the Spanish Flu which is a clever reference as it was written by Goth and Director Ti West during lockdown - and her raging mother, a German immigrant trapped by her crippled husband in rural America and resentful to the back teeth because of it. Goth (Pearl) wants to escape this and become a dancer but is thwarted at auditions for not being blonde enough. This triggers her inner psychopath and whilst we don't get a rampage on the scale of X we do see her nascent evil emerge. It's Goth's startling performance and Ti West's dazzling direction that marks this out as a horror of sheer class, although in truth it's not really a horror at all: not a single jump scare and very little in the way of butchery. Two scenes stand out, both featuring Goth, a long monologue to her friend and the closing credits which are reminiscent of Sinead Connor's classic pop video. This is movie making at its finest and a must see in my opinion.

I simply do not understand people's infatuation with this movie. What do they see that I don't? A pointless, predictable, pretentious flim that drags on and on. It felt like a 2+ hour movie. Mia Goth is a good actress, I'm not denying that, but she needs better material. This is a prequel to X, which was okay at best, that sheds very little light on what happens in X. Just a lot of goofing around and mugging for the camera. Apparently Ti West and Mia Goth wrote this while in quarantine to shoot X in during the pandemic. It makes sense because it felt like something that was wrote in a few days and just thrown together. Most of the "character developments" here were implied in X and really didn't need to be shown. What a waste of time.

So, I got this off an article about Martin Scorsese, telling me "80 Films the Director Wants You to See." (First off, Marty's got some unusual selections in there, including a fair amount of horror). "Pearl" is definitely unique and visually appealing, and this story of a Midwest farmgirl maniacally obsessing over fame, stardom, and a new life, seems to have developed a cult following on the edge of town outside the mainstream. I generally don't do slasher films, but I'm not above a little blood-soaked fun in my thriller-mysteries. Pearl is an angelic-faced dreamer who... well, let's say you don't want to disappoint her... or face her wrath. I thought the story was a little odd and thin, but it was like a train wreck you can't look away from. If you like your unexpected carnage plated sweetly, like apple pie or corn on the cob, this wholesome girl might be just the server for you. I was a 6.5 but I rounded up because hey, Martin Scorsese. Duh.

I'm ashamed to admit that I've never seen the movie "Black Christmas" until the other day. Especially since I grew up in that era, a HUGE fan of horror/slasher films, and also a fan of director Bob Clark (I even liked the movie "Rhinestone"). ;)
I was really impressed with it, seeing its inspiration on "Halloween", "When a Stranger Calls", and even Wes Craven's "A Nightmare on Elm Street" (the police procedural scenes, and even having John Saxon in a similar role ;) ), and some awesome camera work and film techniques, and awesome moments of pure visual storytelling on a top tier level. But I was very let down with the ending because it not only revealed a lot of idiot plot but was very infuriating that it set up a brilliant air of mystery just to never solve it and leave the main reveal out of the story, smh. Trust me, I LOVE ambiguous endings, matter of fact that's kind of my favorite way to end something (I tend to even do it a lot in my own writing), but I consider it almost criminal as a storyteller to set up a great mystery and never reveal the outcome and leave it completely unresolved. Matter of fact, the identity of the killer (and motive and backstory if felt necessary) could have been revealed and it would have made the ending even better instead of feeling anticlimactic. I would still recommend any fan of horror, suspense and/or slasher films check it out, it's definitely worth at least one viewing. It is very entertaining, and boasts a terrific cast, including Olivia Hussey, Kier Dulea, Margot Kidder, John Saxon, and an outstanding performance from Andrea Martin from SCTV fame. ~ Randall Brooks
(author of Cabin Fever)

Light spoilers ahead:. So I just watched this for the first time in my life and although I am not a huge fan of slashers I have to say... this was just a great MOVIE, period. First of all I would not call it a slasher per se (more like a mystery-horror-who done it) secondly it was smart, beautifully lit, shot and acted. It had little to no blood, but because we got to know these characters it was actually thrilling! The phone calls by Billy were DERANGED (I was actually surprised they got away with that kind of language, and I can't remember seeing a Horror made in the last decade that had similar dialogue/monologue...have we gotten soft?)
I even think the whole POV stuff was pretty groundbreaking. Remember cameras were HUGE back then and they still managed to have a guy climb up a ladder with it on his shoulder (?), Kathrin Bigalow had to invent a whole rig system for similar scenes in Strange Days! And that was 30 years later. All my issues with this film are in the third act! It's simply not believable that she wouldn't run to the policeman outside for help as soon as she learned the killer was inside the house (she didn't know he was dead in his car). Speaking of which, who killed that cop? Also, why would everyone leave the scene of the crime in the last scene and even turn the lights off and let her sleep, that doesn't make any sense, even for the 70ies. Plus, if the police actually checked all the rooms (including the attic) as soon as there was the missing persons report for the first victim, none of the other murders would have happened. These minor things aside, Black Christmas totally surprised me and I am adding it to my collection. 9/10 stars!
