As one of the first forays into the slasher subgenre, "Black Christmas" (1974) stands out by developing and influencing several elements that would become recurrent in horror cinema, solidifying its position as a macabre Christmas classic that has transcended generations. The film's plot skillfully mixes excessive and unpretentious humor with a disturbing theme, creating a unique atmosphere that combines the festive atmosphere of Christmas with moments of intense tension. The plot, centered on the killer's vulgar connections and dual personality, is constructed in an engaging way. Even without completely revealing the antagonist's appearance, the cold atmosphere of the scenes involving this bizarre character is remarkable. The script, although not overly complex, develops subplots and characters effectively, bringing life to the secondary actors. The death scenes, surprisingly, have aged well and continue to deliver impactful results, something unusual for films from the 70s. "Black Christmas" is notable for its ingenuity in transforming a seemingly simple plot into a great Christmas-themed horror production, solidifying itself as one of the greatest classics within this specific proposal.

Christmas and horror, a terrible mixture? Less than one might think, the film works as a special gem in both moods, although I wouldn't include it in my / a Christmas film collection, because the festival of festivals only appears from time to time in passing. And beware, those who are approaching maturity should definitely be excluded from watching this film: harsh language, the fundamentally disturbing mixture of premises mentioned above and, of course, the fact that we have a real slasher precursor here, despite the early year of its production. After Psycho, the Giallos and before the classic slasher wave comes somewhat lonely Black Christmas. And here various optional basics are already being practised, the killer-me perspective, yes, before Halloween, that there doesn't necessarily need to be an obvious motive for murder and that young ladies are a favourite target of the madmen. But of course we are still in the middle of the 70s. The production focuses more on suspense than on explicit bloodlust, and the killings are packaged indirectly through special camera and sound sequences. So beware again, gorehounds could definitely be disappointed here, just like those who need high tempo and constant thrills. Nevertheless, the fantastic finale should please every genre fan.

It appears many are having a difficult time conducting a review of a 1974 film through a 2023 lens, I was in grade eight when this movie came out and I can remember two classmates sneaking into the theatre to watch this movie and they quickly became folk hero's for their effort. Movies like Black Christmas and The Texas Chainsaw were gritty ground breaking terror in their day and the original films still hold up today - so when reviewing them take that in to consideration and appreciate them for what they are, disturbing poorly lit sets and poor sound quality are all part of the classic charm.

For me this is the film that is the first true slasher. It has all the tropes: a holiday, pov of the killer, a killer whose face we never see, sex, a final girl and butchering innocents for no expressed reason. Black Christmas is a very effective film and is a telling of the old legend of an ominous prank caller in one's own house. Bob Clark directed this and he got it right. The plot should be well known by now. I won't spend much time on it, but I love how this film ends with the police taking Jess to an upstairs bedroom to recuperate from her boyfriend who she believes is the killer. He's not and the poor bastard is killed because of this misunderstanding. Jess is resting on a bed. Mr Harrison, father of one of the sorority house girls, has fainted and is taken to a hospital. The camera never breaks frame. We see Jess lying in bed. Off camera we hear the commotion of the police and other officials milling about their business. Eventually an officer turns off the bedroom light in the room where Jess is resting. Camera never breaks frame. Then the house is silent. Evidently the officers have vacated the house thinking all is settled and well. The camera now pans right to a vacant bedroom where Barb was murdered. We see a sheetless mattress with bloodstains, still the camera pans right. Another bedroom; here we see a suitcase packed at the foot of a made bed. Camera pans right to the end of the hall. We see a wall ladder leading to the attic. Camera settles here. Suddenly we see a faint shifting of movement in the attic and a light. Now we are in the attic. We see Clare dead with a plastic bag over her face in a rocking chair. We see Mrs Mac, the house mother, dead swinging on a grab hook; we hear a voice 'it's me Billy'. Camera pans outside away from house. A serene scene. Night sky, Christmas lights, a lone police officer milling about outside the house, suddenly we hear a phone ring and ring. Credits roll. Very effective and creepy ending. The antagonist is never caught. The case isn't settled, but the actors think it is. Bravo, well done, that's how tension and horror are produced in a film.

Review-Title: Black Christmas will ROCK you too
Review-Description: Let me preface this post by pointing out that the reason there are so many bad reviews for this movie is because a bunch of dingus's didn't bother to check that they were reviewing the right movie. Black Christmas was released in 1974. Which I'll be reviewing. It was then remade in 2006, and remade again in 2019. And from what I've heard about the most recent remake, it deserves the harsh criticism. Now as for the original: I absolutely loved it. I saddens me that horror films like this aren't produced as much anymore. It's far easier to just throw together a cheesy, terrible plot, and accent it with cheap jump scares, cringe-worthy dialogue, and visual effects nowadays. Looking back at the films that made the genre what it is today has helped me realize, at least, how much the horror genre as a whole has devolved over the years, and helps me truly appreciate the gems that come out every now and then that defy genre norms today. Although the movie is labeled a horror/slasher film, I think it effectively utilizes terror throughout, as opposed to horror. For most those words probably mean the same thing, but without spoiling anything that happens in the film, let me explain the difference between horror and terror. Horror and terror are both types of fear: horror manifests itself in known threats more often than not, whereas terror manifests in unknown/unseen threats. It's an oversimplified distinction technically, but make of that what you will before watching the movie and you will see what difference the approach to fear makes in a "horror" film. Other than the execution, the cinematography was good, the acting was good...for the most part. There were some characters that I thought could have done better, but there were no awful actors. The pacing was quite good, although I feel they could have shortened the introduction a little. Overall it was just a great film.

I suppose a sorority can be used to host a multitude of characters, so that's what Bob Clark does here as he puts four quite different girls into an house supervised by the likably dypso "Mrs. Mac" (Marian Waldman). The house has, for ages now, being getting crank calls from a guy they call the "moaner". Some get upset by his behaviour, others laugh it off but when one of their number "Clare" (Lynne Griffin) disappears and the police are called in by her boyfriend "Chris" (Art Hindle), the sense of menace ratchets up a notch. As we get to know these characters, there are quite a few suspects and quite a few decent reasons why we might want to bump them all off. "Jess" (Olivia Hussey) is expecting a child with wayward boyfriend "Pete" (Keir Dullea) only he doesn't know it yet; give-as-good-as-you-get "Barb" (Margot Kidder) quite likes to goad their would-be tormentor ("Billy") - much to his obvious chagrin. More menacing yet is the increasingly detailed knowledge contained in the calls. "Billy" is spookily well informed. Could he be one of them? I'm not too sure what this has to have to do with Christmas, to be honest. It's just another typical slasher set amongst a student fraternity that gives everyone an opportunity to scream and make some shockingly poor under-pressure decisions. Neither the acting nor the writing stand out but the photography is quite effective at creating and sustaining a modest sense of peril as our killer nears goal. It's not really very scary, indeed time hasn't been to kind to it at all - but it's watchable if you like the genre and have taken a drink or two.

For someone who's watched as many 'slasher' films in my time (and enjoyed many a 'gore-fest' along the way!) it's taken me until 2023 to watch 'Black Christmas,' which. If the internet trivia is to be believed, is up there with horror classics like 'The Texas Chainsaw Massacre' and 'Halloween' - in bringing the 'slasher' genre to the mainstream. It's about a killer, stalking residents of a sorority house one Christmas and, er, that's about it. It's pretty simple in terms of story, but then most slasher films tend to be that way. I hear that much the major gore was cut in order to get it released - and it shows. I would imagine that almost everything contained within this film would be considered 'shocking' and 'revolutionary' in terms of on-screen scares, whereas today, it's just kind of tame. As I say, there's not much gore. And there's not much that you haven't seen in a hundred similar movies. I suppose there's something to be got out of the story in trying to guess who the killer is (I confess, I never managed to see how it would eventually end). The characters are likable enough - those who are meant to be. And there are a few 'red herrings' thrown in there for good measure. The police were suitably useless in their efforts in catching the killer, but then if they were competent the film's runtime would be about ten minutes. 'Black Christmas' is worth a watch if you like competent slasher films - there's nothing here that's bad, but, after over forty years, there's nothing here that new either.

I have heard about this Christmas horror movie before, and I have been hearing people say that they love it or think it is an underrated horror movie; after watching the movie, I can agree that it is good and that it is a bit underrated. The movie Black Christmas (1974) is a creepy, disturbing, and mostly suspenseful horror movie that uses Christmas time in an investing way; plus, each girl in the sorority house has something happen to them, most of them having to deal with realistic problems, which makes it disturbing, not just because of a maniac killer being in the movie. The girls in the sorority are going through their own problems, like one of them wanting an abortion despite her boyfriend not wanting that, but there is also a maniac killer in the attic of the sorority house with nobody knowing; it makes the movie disturbing with the real problems the characters are going through, but also it makes it creepy with the way some characters act and the killer in the house. Along with that, the characters are like teenagers doing what teenagers do, but they do act like adults surprisingly; making rational choices like calling the police or trying not to answer the phone because of the many creepy and weird calls they get. I like that we never see the killer's face because he is covered by shadows or hides in darkness the whole movie, while also giving us his point of view where we only see his hands and his shoes when walking around; most of the cinematography have long takes and camera pans around the house that works with the creepy tone. Though the movie is rated R, which is for language and frightening scenes, it is not that gory, but it has disturbing kills in the movie that are still effective and are executed in ways that fit the Christmas holiday. Black Christmas (1974) is a Christmas horror film that is worth giving a watch, though it takes its time building up to a point where it gets creepier, it is a highly effective movie that will creep you out and disturb you from beginning to end. The acting is not bad, the cinematography is well done, the antagonist hiding in the house is creepy, and the Christmas vibe with the movie works well with the horror side of the plot; this movie is underrated and is worth watching at least once.

Movie Title: Harry Potter and the Goblet of Fire (2005)
Review-Description: Adapted and based on the fourth Harry Potter book "The Goblet of Fire" is absolutely no disappointment! It's the fourth year at Hogwarts, and Harry, Ron and Hermione returns as the iconic and unstoppable trio that every Harry Potter fan loves to watch every time. This time, Hogwarts school of Witchcraft and Wizardry is getting a slight update this year. Because now, three schools are settled in together to fight each other in an epic tournament, with challenges to complete, and a great quest to finish and represent their school in honour and loyalty. This film doesn't just develop the main story greatly, but it makes small side stories to have something interesting too watch all the time. The conflict with the great and almighty Voldemort is still out there, and they did some really good and terrible scenes too represent his cruelty (Especially something we can notice in the opening scene). Hogwarts territory's are explored much more than ever in the fourth instalment, for example the lake, new areas and so. Harry Potter played by Daniel Radcliffe is showed now as a troubled, unsure and scared boy, that clearly can feel new problems coming, was great! His performance was much stronger and darker in here, his role was settled on a different level, as well as his friends, Ron and Hermione, performed by Rupert Grint and Emma Watson. Rector Dumbledore was also a character that came more in and out, but was clearly better included compared to "Prisoner of Azkaban". The new teachers are always something cool and interesting, and it was once again fun too watch them in action. Speaking of action, amazing action sequences! Great camera filming, scenography, visual effects, and build-up with great suspense. Unexpected turns and uses of camera that hasn't been used in Harry Potter before, like underwater scenes and so. The music by Patrick Doyle isn't that iconic compared to the themes by John Williams, but it's rememberable and overall well written. In the end, The Goblet of Fire was entertaining, dark, mysterious and so far the best one!

Movie Title: Harry Potter and the Goblet of Fire (2005)
Review-Title: Where grown-ups are separated from kids
Review-Description: I don't recollect the last time I have seen this movie, but probably it wasn't dubbed. I took the change with my oldest son, as his age almost matches PG's requirements and we took the journey together and it was a marvelous one - maybe it the end of it he would, finally, touch the books themselves. Harry's bunch is starting to face teenagers' stuff, boys are noticing girls, hormones are bursting out and you can see envy and competition as part of their day to day activities. Even Hermione is not reacting as her usual self to some of the situations. Clearly is reflected properly by young Emma Watson. At this movie we got another two brilliant British stars as Brendan Gleeson and David Tennant joined the cast and provided brilliant performances. Another two young and promising actors has joined for a one-time performance: Robert Pattinson and Cl√©mence Po√©sy, I got the feeling we will hear about them in the near future. The rest of the cast stayed the same and the plot became darker and more mature, as for the young love stories of the main characters. At the end of this film I could not say or remember if I ever though that one of Harry Potter's films are not great, from what I see until now, it seems that none of the movies is less then fantastic. It holds for all the runtime, made with beautiful cinematography and is a visually treat, though this one is at the dark and dark water, for some of it. The musical score is epic and the actors we grew up with, turns into young adult and talented actors, through out of the movies. Cant find any reasons not to be almost fully satisfied.

Movie Title: Harry Potter and the Goblet of Fire (2005)
Review-Title: Dynamic Duels, Internal Strife, and Mystical Marvels
Review-Description: If I were to pick a favorite chapter in this incredible saga, it would be this one. Harry Potter and the Goblet of Fire encapsulates many elements that I cherish in a film, including dynamism, conflicts, and mysteries. The eagerly anticipated Triwizard Tournament unfolds with dynamism, introducing us to the enchanting worlds of Beauxbatons and Durmstrang. The three challenging tasks showcase the magical essence of the Harry Potter universe, immersing us in a fantastical spectacle. Amidst the external spectacle, internal conflicts within our beloved trio-Harry, Ron, and Hermione-take center stage. Strains emerge between Ron and Harry, followed by tensions between Ron and Hermione. This installment serves as a crucial test of their friendship, a test they navigate with remarkable finesse, solidifying the resilience of their bond. Beyond the visible trials, the film plunges us into a web of mysteries. The primary enigma revolves around the identity of the individual who entered Harry's name into the Goblet of Fire, triggering unforeseen consequences. Another mystery centers on the mysterious figure aiding Voldemort's return to power. Additionally, the character of Alastor Moody raises questions about his true identity, with the audience kept guessing whether he has taken Polyjuice Potion. The revelation towards the end adds an unexpected twist, surprising even those familiar with the narrative. As I revisited this chapter, I found myself rediscovering forgotten details, such as the uncertainty surrounding Alastor's true form. The film successfully maintains a balance between the magical spectacle of the Triwizard Tournament and the intricate layers of the unfolding mysteries. Goblet of Fire leaves audiences on the edge of their seats, eagerly anticipating the resolution of lingering questions. Despite the sadness that comes with reaching the midpoint of the saga, the film sets the stage for the intense and emotionally charged events that await in the subsequent installments. As I eagerly approach the final four films, I find myself both exhilarated and already lamenting the inevitable hiatus until the next cinematic journey through the wizarding world.

Movie Title: Harry Potter and the Goblet of Fire (2005)
Review-Title: Superbly dark with some great laughs too.
Review-Description: A superb entry in the Harry Potter franchise. The film explores a great range of emotions in our characters as they continue to mature. The tone is dark tone yet mixed in with some comic relief too. Bleaker, greyer, skies and a cooler blue outdoor colour palette hint at troubled times on the horizon for our gang. Cracks start to appear in the friendship between characters only to be strengthened later on. The sense of threat towards Harry increases too in this film, in the first couple it seems Harry might be hurt during his adventures, adventures that he himself chooses. In this film however it seems danger is out to find Harry, to put it simply somebody wants him dead, and you don't need much imagination to imagine who. The film is set almost exclusively inside Hogwarts which I thought worked well. The casting of Brendan Gleeson was also in my opinion an inspired choice.

Movie Title: Harry Potter and the Goblet of Fire (2005)
Review-Title: You will have to choose between what is easy and what is right
Review-Description: Harry and his friends are now young ladies and gentlemen. An international Quidditch event is taking place. To get there one has to use a port key (an innocuous-looking device that transports one to a different location). Things did not go as well as planned and now a dark element has been added. Also, this year is the tri-wizard tournament in which a hero from each of three learning institutes must compete in unknown events. This is to promote friendship among the institutes. The opportunity is open to only potential contestants of seventeen years. They must enter his/her name into the goblet of fire for selection. So, you can imagine everyone's surprise to find fourteen-year-old Harry's name in the Goblet. How did his name get in the goblet? Will Harry accept the challenge? And if so, how will he fair? We get to see all the characters for the book come to life. Most of the relevant story is included. Among the parts that were left out, I was hoping for the Blast-Ended Skrewts and the male wizard wearing the dress to get plenty of air around his private parts. The series of Harry films has also matured with each rendition. It took several tries, some better than others, but this one has the feel of the book and even with the short time it plays shows the real feel of the ongoing story of the struggle between Harry and him, who must not be named. This includes the larger picture of more than just good versus evil.

Movie Title: Harry Potter and the Goblet of Fire (2005)
Review-Description: It is a phantasy play. You mean sometimes book is as film given. Story is phantastical in showing possible(!) ways of muggles and magic things. Harry taken to write down his own fail was hard to see. For me as an adult. She a horror by knowing her in another eay cause she is an actor. Action hard with life. But it is a special with the non muggled way. The way harry got waldemord costs long distance. This given away special magic stick cause it was not harry or not the right person. The slave given a sock changes his mind. It could do so. Phantasy good. Must not be in teal life. Bit it is am entertainment.

Movie Title: Harry Potter and the Goblet of Fire (2005)
Review-Title: High School Drama Meets Dragon Drama
Review-Description: "Harry Potter and the Goblet of Fire" (2005) receives a bewitching 4 stars from me, largely for its ability to blend teenage angst with dragon-taming antics in a way that makes puberty seem like a walk in the Forbidden Forest. The film introduces the Triwizard Tournament, a magical competition so intense it makes the SATs look like a game of bingo. Harry, our bespectacled hero, finds himself mysteriously entered into this tournament, and let's just say it's more pressure than finding a date to the Yule Ball. Director Mike Newell deserves a tip of the Sorting Hat for balancing the dark, impending doom of Lord Voldemort's return with the light-hearted, hormone-fueled drama of Hogwarts' students. The highlight? The underwater sequence where Harry grows gills and attempts to save his friends, proving that even in the wizarding world, high school is still about popularity contests and saving face - or in this case, saving Ron's face. The film, however, isn't without its flaws. The pacing zips through important plot points faster than a Firebolt, leaving non-book readers to puzzle over details like "Who is Barty Crouch Jr. And why does he twitch like that?" But overall, "Goblet of Fire" casts a charming spell, complete with teenage wizards, temperamental dragons, and dance floor disasters. It's a magical ride through adolescence, with just a touch of life-threatening peril - because what's high school without a little existential dread?

Movie Title: Harry Potter and the Goblet of Fire (2005)
Review-Description: Watched this for the first time in a long time and it's better than I remember. It's both easy to understand for families AND dramatic/interesting. There's good plot movement throughout with minimal fluff (although I could do without the teen drama and the dance) The story is great fun centering on the tournament. The opening with the quitich (sp?) tournament being crashed by death eaters thrusts you into the action. And sets a scary backdrop for the tournament that follows. There's always an air of menace throughout. Setting up the 3rd act with the port key trophy was clever. It was satisfying seeing Harry save Cedric and choose to win together - only to face death shortly after. It's the turning point in the HP franchise. It has the first death, a notably darker tone, and formally introduces Voldemort - who is excellently portrayed by Ralph Finnes. The CGI still holds up - despite being almost 20 years old. It's great to see Robert Pattinson here.

Movie Title: Harry Potter and the Goblet of Fire (2005)
Review-Description: Definitely a step-down from the previous one but I feel like it's not that deep. The structure and the visual elements are not that sophisticated but it's not that bad. I feel like this one is the most enjoyable, given its "light" tone and the change on a story level from the previous three with the Triwizard tournament and the introduction of new characters, adapting that tone to the growth of our characters and us as an audience. This one will always be a confort film for me; as I was younger I used to truly feel and love - I still do - the romantic tone of this one; and the devastating effects that love had on our grown up characters, somehow reflecting myself in those fights and dreamy, romantic scenarios of Hogwarts on Christmas's Eve.

Movie Title: Harry Potter and the Goblet of Fire (2005)
Review-Description: I haven't read the books because I don't want to base my opinion on a comparison to them. This movie was amazing, different from the first 2 movies, but amazing. I hate reading "reviews" where the only thing they talk about is how different the movies are from the books, and you should avoid them too. It's impossible to make a movie based on a 750 page book and keep it under 4 hours long unless you skip over some parts. If you want the whole story read the books, if you want to see magical stuff and still follow Harry Potter's story in Hogwarts from a cinematic perspective, then watch the film, it's awesome. I give this a 9/10 only because I always thought I'd see more of Ron and Hermione in the films, but that kind of faded away after the second one. Also not much of Draco Malfoy as I was expecting. Although that's not cause of a bad film or story, but because of my flash expectations, it still took a little bit of magic from my experience. The other thing that I didn't like was how dark the movie was, although it's understandable and it suits the story that we follow in this film, I always thought of the Wizarding World as something more cheerful, colorful and magical in a different way, but again, that's my wrong image of HP before watching it. I'm really excited to watch the 5th one and the rest of the movies. Already feeling kinda sad that it's gonna end for me soon. I want to live in the Wizarding World myself!

Review-Title: Quirky Dark-Comedy...Bizarre Surreal Characters & Cartoon-Like Behavior
Review-Description: Prolific Actor and Occasional Director, John Flattery Takes the Helm in this Dark Comedy that has Unmistakable "Fargo" Vibes. Actors John Hamm and Tina Fey Lead a Quirk-Character Cast of Misfits, Losers, Low-Life-Criminals, as an Awkward Coupling of Post-Marriage 30-Somethings. He, with His Wife Passing, and She with a Divorce from a Dominating Husband (that She can't seem to avoid meeting-up with). The Plot has the Mystery of 2 Murders, only Days Apart, Both Victims with the Name Maggie Moore. Everyone in this Fictional Small Town is a Character Worthy of Sensationalized Paper-Back Fiction. Exaggerated, Full of Colorful Quirks, Mostly a Step Slow with the Characters Designed to Entertain and Propel the Lurid Plot, Filled with Violence and Charmless Charm. All of it is Designed a Step-Above Reality and that Design is What Could Place it in a Sub-Genre of Crime-Fiction, You Could Call... "Cartoon-Crime-Fiction" With its Tongue-In-Cheek Display of some Ultra-Violence by Dumb-as-Dirt Criminals who Take Turns Providing Outrageous, Surprising Laughs. It's that Counterpart to the "Normal" or Usual Mystery, Drama, Romance, and Crime, Story that Sets the Type Apart. Over-Reaching, as if On-Cue, to the Events that Causes these Folks to Over-React in a what at Times Seems Like Something Out of a Cartoon. Coloring (outside the lines) and Can't Help but be Noticed by Everyone but Themselves. A Style that is Not for Everyone, but Dark-Comedy, sometimes Called Black-Comedy, has a Legion of Fans. They Love the Cult-Status that Makes these Movies a Different Experience from the Straight-Laced, Familiar, and Safe Movie Offerings that "Stays Within the Lines". For those Fans, it's... Worth a Watch For Fans of the Traditional Take... Not so Much.

This movie is a nice viewing on a popcorn and a movie kinda night. It starts off a bit slow and meandering. Cards are all laid out on the table, you're watching a decent murder investigation with no real questions because you already know what's going on. But the third act comes in hot with an OMG WTF that launches into a rather tense finale with some real stakes and a fairly satisfying ending. I think movies like this need support. It's okay to sit through a movie that isn't force feeding you "action" all the time. It's okay to let a movie marinate. It's okay to sit through the beats rather than constant jump cuts. The language was a bit much for me. But overall, a decent independent movie at a time when Hollywood needs to return back to decent original movies.

What a pleasant surprise. This is one of those movies I usually hesitate to see because the poster and description don't really appeal to me and then I find out I wouldn't have wanted to miss out on it. I agree with the reviews, it is a breath of fresh air with dialogues to die for and much better than it looked. It has that kind of witty humor that makes you laugh in such a fun way, you can't help but like totally enjoy it. Some mentioned it's rather a slow burner, but I've watched a lot of slow burners - and I'm talking here only about the good ones since this movie definitely doesn't belong to the bad category, and those good slow burners were much slower than this one. In my opinion the pace was quite good because not once did it make me feel bored. Like I said, I totally enjoyed it, I mean like REALLY enjoyed it!! It's a movie you can watch twice in case you wanna share it with your friends and go with it a second time.

Review-Title: a "wanna be" Breaking Bad murder mystery
Review-Description: Pros: 1. Romance between Hamm and Fey. Great Chemistry here. Their relationship seemed pitch perfect for their age and personality. I would love to see them again in a rom-com. They seemed natural vs that latest yell match of a rom-com of Julia Roberts in her daughter's wedding. 2. I loved the views of my Sandia Mountains. The Sandia mountains loom over everything in ABQ, and they did a great job including them in the background of many of the scenes. Cons: 1. Seemed like they tried to make a murder mystery in the Breaking Bad and Better Call Saul playbook. There are Scenes of funky architecture, dialogs inside crazy diners, murder in a 1950's era concrete apartment and another crime scene located out in the desert. Most of us from Albuquerque don't go to half these places. 2. Murder mystery? ...there was no mystery here. We know who killed who from the very beginning and so did most of the protagonists. Most reviewers mentioned that they tried to make a Cohen brothers/Fargo type story focusing on character development than mystery. 3. And lastly, an indian (from India) actor? I know there are Indians in NM, but I've lived here, worked here, and taught here most of my life and never met a single one. NM has the largest population of hispanic and native Americans and they couldn't find one to play the deputy or any other character? Some TV shows/movies go crazy with diversity, but not having a single Hispanic actor in a US Southwestern locale is like not having an Italian or African American actor in a NY scene.

Slattery got it right with this slow burn of a dark comedy. The movie succeeds in doing what ppl raved that Vengeance did last year. I was highly impressed w/this movie & it didn't get half the hype as Vengeance. I found performances spot on & nuanced. The movie flows seamlessly from outlandish situations to believable niche characters that I enjoyed. Fey & Hamm have great chemistry as a hapless divorcee & a buttoned up widower, brought together by these murders. I was delighted watching the idiotic Hubby Moore rely on original murderous deaf guy to clean up this mess, more murders. I highly recommend this movie, it's quirky, well cast, & well done unraveling mystery.

I'm surprised so many reviews are saying this movie isn't good. It's exactly what it's billed as: a dark comedy. Jon Hamm and Tina Fey are fantastic in their roles. The other actors are wonderful and don't miss a beat. You never know what's gonna happen next, which is especially gratifying in the current film landscape of sequels and reboots. I enjoyed every strange, off-kilter moment of this, and the ending is pitch-perfect. A delightful film except for the inexcusable outcome for Deputy Reddy. If you like the Coen brothers' movies, you should connect with this - it very much strikes the same notes as Raising Arizona and Fargo - lots of death and deadpan characters.

Review-Title: Slattery trying to find the laughs in manslaughter.
Review-Description: At the library saw this recent movie with Tina Fey and Jon Hamm, so thought it would be worth a shot at something my wife and I could enjoy together. Early on it starts out with some of the crime action, that many others have pointed out is a tricky pairing with comedy. It jettisoned my wife for sure. But I stuck around... The problem is not just that it's a crime/comedy, but the comedy is often pretty dry and well the crime is not embezzling, but let's say much wetter. Another problem is some of the absolutely stupid behavior by the "crooks" contrasted with the more sharp-witted dialog. Tina Fey leans hard into her ugly ducking role, but her attractive personality plus kind of belies that. Well, then there is her ex-husband with benefits, that was sort of part of the dry humor. I noticed another review thought it was John Goodman as the assassin who has some tricks up his extra-large sleeves. But no, I think it was his stunt double. The subtle work just gets murdered by the heavier overriding plot points. It's like admiring your kids chalk work on pavement drawing well within the police chalked body outline. Hard to shake that off-feeling. Maybe instead of trying to go Fargo, John Slattery (Hamm's old pal from Mad Men, in his 2nd full length each time with a star from that successful show)....maybe Slattery could have gone further into David Lynch territory. Even that might not have worked, here in the US with our requisite patriotic level of fear of some random act of violence, I think it's hard to laugh at mistaken identity womanslaughter. Bottom line the film ends up being less than the sum of its parts. Damn shame as the cast and ideas I do feel like could have been forged into something uniquely successful.

I don't see a lot of new movies because they're (in my opinion) usually overdone and too slick. In case you don't know, police departments aren't full of computer nerds and hot 20-somethings. Middle-aged Tina Fey and Jon Hamm caught my eye and the 'black comedy' description led me to give it a shot. I thoroughly enjoyed the movie. It was quirky and oddball and not Formula Hollywood at all; almost Coen Brothers. I was surprised that Tina Fey was not a write or producer, and given the lengthy list of producers, she may have just asked that her name be omitted. So it's not Billy Wilder and 'Sunset Boulevard,' but it's an engaging and entertaining tale, with (possibly unfamiliar) actors delivering spot-on performances.

Review-Title: Much, much better than it looked
Review-Description: Despite other reviews, I felt like everything actually works really well. It's light and dark, but never so serious or jokey that the tone shifts are off-putting. The writing is really effective - it's a bit of a morality piece, but each scene is so well constructed and enjoyable and never heavy-handed. Nothing over the top, all very low-key. And the lead roles are so well delivered, there's something very Fargo-esque about how everything unfolds and the quality of the performances. The sweet, effective cop, and the spiraling criminal. Perfect stay-at-home date night movie. Can't help but wish the Jon Hamm character becomes recurring.

This is not a whodunnit. We know very early in the film what the main story is: a small town business man wants to get rid of his wife. So this is a "how-catch-him." Like an episode of Columbo, the suspense is generated by watching how the detective (Jon Hamm) puts together the clues. It's a tad more complex for him because there are two victims with the same name and thus twice as many suspects, red herrings and a neat Chekov's gun. But since we know who is behind the plot (which goes a lot farther than he intended), the real attraction, as in the movie Fargo, is the characters. Hamm is wonderful as the down-to-earth but very observant police chief, supported by his odd deputy. Tina Fey gives her best acting performance ever by going against type as the self-defacing but nosy neighbor who starts out as a witness and becomes the object of a rather sweet romantic subplot. Like Fargo, there is some violence but it is not graphic by today's standards. A very enjoyable film that will not give you nightmares if you watch it just before bed.

Movie Title: Mr. Monk's Last Case: A Monk Movie (2023)
Review-Description: This is very obvious to say because why else would I be watching this, but I'm a huge Monk fan, like huge. I've watched the entire show over 6 times. It's in my top 5 shows of all time, a 10/10. It has a certain atmosphere and feel to it that not many shows can do. A formula that is fun to watch every episode. Saying Tony Shalhoub was born for this role is an understatement. I could watch 40 seasons of Monk doing his amazing detective thing and laughing along. So safe to say I absolutely love the show with all my heart. Which brings me to this movie... What a huge disappointment. This does not feel like Monk at all, regardless of how many references and known characters appearing in it. It's very dumb, generic, and boring. Other than Tony Shalhoub, the acting feels like one of those generic terrible action movies that Bruce Wills start in. It just looks bad and uninspired. Like the way his daughter acts after her beloved partner gets murdered is so stupid, she cries for a little bit at first but then soon after it's like nothing happened and she acts like she wants a murder solved for an acquaintance not a partner, you can see her like smiling after Monk says something weird on the bridge. And there are so many illogical stuff that happens it's crazy. What a coincidence that Leland works as a head of security for the evil guy. And what a miracle he survived fall of a cliff by hanging on to that inflatable doll, like that made my jaw drop of how forced and stupid that was, and of course the evil guy has to do a speech or say something witty before shooting monk, a staple in dumb movies. And how did Monk even get the evil guy arrested? I don't understand. Like ok he said what he did with the measuring tape, but that does not prove anything lol. Like no fingerprints, no eyewitness, no nothing. Just "here's what happens" like they even have no evidence on the guy that broke in the house, let alone the evil guy who was in a different place and can no way be connected to the murder. And if anyone says "oh but the laptop", he would've destroyed any evidence after seeing Monk stealing his laptop. No explanation at all of how he got arrested, no proof, just the script wanting to be over with to wrap up the movie. And that cringy ending oh my goodness! With dead people wearing white and even people he doesn't know and literally never seen and still in the freezer hahaha, talk about subtility huh? And all the dead people walking in a crowd with the generic music in the background, like can you make it any more cheesy? There are a lot of stuff to mention, and setting aside the stupid plot holes and illogical stuff, the movie just looks and feels bad, it doesn't feel like the people who made it have talent or even cared, and budget had nothing to do with it, it's just a movie made by a generic director who (surprise surprise) made absolutely nothing before this and his qualifications are "I love Monk TV show and I have a degree in movie directing"

Movie Title: Mr. Monk's Last Case: A Monk Movie (2023)
Review-Title: There should be a trigger warning.
Review-Description: There should have been a trigger warning for people who struggle with mental health issues. Why display a hotline number at the end? It should have been put in the beginning of the movie so watchers are aware of what they are about to see. This was not a comedy. It was sad, depressing and dark. There's nothing wrong with a movie that displays those issues but there has to be a clear warning for those who don't want to watch something grim and depressing. Watching people struggle with mental health issues isn't funny. This movie wasn't a comedy and it wasn't even a good movie at that. Thank you.

Movie Title: Mr. Monk's Last Case: A Monk Movie (2023)
Review-Description: The quirky, OCD, germaphopic & now-retired detective, Monk is back in this very special "last case" movie. While the final episode of the series left us with a Monk that was on the road to normalcy after finally solving his wife's murder, we find him back to his old ways as he is asked to solve the murder of his step-daughter's fianc√©. All of the ingredients that made the series great are here (funny OCD behaviors, mystified family and collaborators, serious investigative moments) and especially all (minus Sharona) of Monk's most important friends. Viewers should be aware that a strong theme of suicidal ideation runs the length of the film, fueled by Monk's continuing grief at the absence of his wife and his strong desire to be with her (in death). Rest assured, Monk's hand is staid by regular appearance of his wife, pleading with him not to go through with his plans. In the end, after the crime is solved, and as Monk prepares to overdose in a public park, both his wife and the fianc√© appear to show him how his presence in the world gave a voice to those that could not speak for themselves. The film ends with dozens of apparitions walking with him in recognition of the peace he brought to so many families through the homicides he solved, as Monk heads toward the precinct to again, offer his services in solving cold cases. Monk's Final Case is by no means riveting drama. But it's fun, touching, meaningful, and a great capstone to a wonderfully different detective series.

Movie Title: Mr. Monk's Last Case: A Monk Movie (2023)
Review-Description: I love watching Monk shows and was so hopefully for this movie version. It is extremely predictable, lacks Monk's sad-sack ending which creates the loveable loser, and has poor acting by everyone but Tony Shalhoub. Somewhat embarrassing especially with the heavy-handed Suicide prevention angle. The best Monk shows are quotable, memorable, fun and quirky. This was none of those features. I gave it two stars because I love the characters and the original actors. But that's a reminiscing review. It's still clean, mostly free from current issues (with the exception of an in your face gay character from the beginning) but otherwise a big disapointment.

Movie Title: Mr. Monk's Last Case: A Monk Movie (2023)
Review-Title: Basically a long episode of Monk
Review-Description: So I was pleased (and surprised) to see this pop up out of nowhere. If you are a fan of Monk then you will probably like this as it follows pretty much the same type of format as the TV show but with one (rather dark) overshadowing theme. Making this film so long after the series has its draw backs - there is a certain amount of exposition as people new to the show are caught up and the absence of other characters is explained. Once it gets going it is the normal cheesy detective show that I have grown to love so much. Having a longer run time doesn't really add much and there is nothing special about it being a film - but I am fine with that it is perfect as it is. This (as the title suggests) is a farewell show and it has a marked degree of poignancy. An extra star for pulling back the original cast.

Movie Title: Mr. Monk's Last Case: A Monk Movie (2023)
Review-Description: The movie was fantastic, and Tony Shaloub once again portrayed the character perfectly. People with his condition rarely ever change, so expecting a happy ending to the series to carry over into this movie would have been unrealistic. Other reviews stated they did not like it because it did not follow the series final episode. Why would it? Monk is quirky, will always be quirky, and that is what makes him loveable. I enjoyed seeing the old characters, would have been nice to see his first assistant and their adult children too just for fun. Otherwise, a perfect movie for everyone who has followed the series. Thanks Peacock for this movie.

Movie Title: Mr. Monk's Last Case: A Monk Movie (2023)
Review-Title: One Last (Touching) Stroll Down The Streets of San Francisco.
Review-Description: After the resolution all those years ago of solving the series-long mystery of who killed Trudy, I wondered how they could top it with this. The answer- they couldn't...But it was still nice to see the cast together again. Got choked up at times and while it felt more like a new run-of-the-mill episode than a final bang, certain elements and especially that one visual near the end in the field made it worth it. And all through the pandemic I, like millions of others I'm sure, wondered how Monk would react which I'm sure was a driving force behind the creation of this special. Some of the acting could've been better (although the show sometimes had hokey acting) but the returning main cast elevated it all. Long live Monk- whether he wants to or not.

Movie Title: Mr. Monk's Last Case: A Monk Movie (2023)
Review-Description: I fully realize every opportunity to make money off of nostalgia is explored and monetized but to recreate a character and leave out all that made it good before is a vast disservice to the fan base. I was very much looking forward to one more round quirky humor but wondered "how can they do Monk in a world where you are not allowed to find humor in disability, how will they take write OCD lines as funny without causing an outrage?" Answer was, they didn't. They made him a sad, depressed man without any of the quirky humor that offset the troubled mind. Monk was always the only one that didn't realize he was just fine. Now, he fully makes you believe that it just isn't worth it, solving all the cases, making any effort, you go through this without understanding fully why he is suicidal, but just wishing he would get on with it. Cringe is what is left. Over the top cringe. Skip this and remember it fondly, don't destroy your memories of Monk with this abomination.

Movie Title: Mr. Monk's Last Case: A Monk Movie (2023)
Review-Description: I enjoyed the film but missed Sharona Fleming. She was Adrian's nurse and assistant and was written off halfway through season three (apparently over a pay dispute). I adored Sharona and Monk's relationship - unlike Natalie, Sharona favored the tough love approach when it came to her boss. Despite the low pay and Monk's many phobias, you can tell she genuinely cared and wanted Adrian to get better. Although Bitty Schram returned for an episode of the show's final season, her character was never given proper closure. I can't really think of anyone I've ever talked to who liked the faulty concept of her going back to her ex and then marrying Randy. I think the writers were too lazy and she deserved much better than that. Schram's contribution to the show's success was immense and I think she deserved to be in the final episode as much as Natalie or Randy.

Movie Title: Mr. Monk's Last Case: A Monk Movie (2023)
Review-Description: 2023 has been propably the worst year of my life i reached a new personal low mostly mentally. This movie reminded me that in the times you are unable to help yourshelf you can always help others also you can think you are useless but somewhere, someone appreciates you and your effort dont give up keep fighting. Just brilliant message by the movie Also Tony Shalhoub i dont know how he does after all this years but he is still inch perfect as our beloved Detective Mr. Monk. The comedy is still there and its not over the top as its happens with newer shows/movies. If you were fan of the show this movie is a must watch.

If all the paragraphs that were cut from the final draft of Agatha Christie's stories were sewn together you would end up with something like this. If I was being kind I would call it a homage, if I was being truthful I would call it a rip-off. I admire the ambition of Ch5 to broadcast new(ish) drama to a UK audience on a limited budget but by broadcasting this at Christmas they were trying to fool us into thinking this was a genuine Christie story while we were all too drunk to notice. None of the characters were convincing, some of them barely existed at all. The story came to a sudden and unsatisfying end, I assume they ran out of plot and/or money.

No point in wasting too much time reviewing this truly horrendous mash up of a film. It is an insult to Agatha Christie, an insult to the actors and, above all an insult to the viewers. The plot meanders painfully around the Christie plot but with none of the elegance and suspense. The acting by every single member of the cast is wooden and unconvincing. Every single one of them was there for the money and nothing else it would seem. The set is pure American, no English country house has ever looked like this in it's unconvincingness. And then there are the appalling computer graphics presumably done by a student on day release. And what's with the rabbits ? Pointless and useless, like the film.

First off, the script is horrible - some of the lines and the exchanges are very amateurish, plus, with the acting so so so bad, the delivery of those lines were even more awful. Based on the outside filming, it's also obvious that this was filmed in the USA and not Britain - the manor house screamed a McMansion. That only contributed to the overall crappiness of the film. The gist of the story would definitely work if the writing (and acting) weren't so bad - it had an interesting core focus and that focus could get a good murderfest going. Alas, it was not meant to be. Even when the culprit was revealed, it was a torturous journey of enlightenment for us still watching at this point.

This is quite an odd film - as you can tell from the widely varying reviews here. It looks good, has obviously been funded well, the acting is OK, it should be a good watch, like a well-intentioned Agatha Christie pastiche, made presumably with an eye on the US market. And yet, after a promising-enough start, it starts to fall apart. I think it's the poor pacing, the lack of tension or excitement, the sluggishness, the intrusive music, perhaps. The plot wasn't particularly involved or complicated. But by the end - at the long drawn out and unlikely and undramatic denouement - the end result was a feeling of dissatisfaction. All the well-intentioned effort had fizzled out. And the final reveal of an intensive closed-circuit TV system with sophisticated monitoring facilities, multiple cameras and monitors - in 1934! - suddenly made me realize how utterly daft the whole thing had been, and the whole enterprise collapsed in ludicrous hilarity.

Extremely poor Agatha Christie rip-off!! (Of whom I'm a massive fan!) I was really looking forward to this, however it has a disappointingly long drawn-out mish-mashed plot! Absolutely dire acting - Mischa Barton seems totally out of place & awkward, very false acting abilities! Only positives are the costumes & settings, which I suspect were recored in America & not the UK! Now I've started it, feel I've got to see it through to the end - what a waste of 2 hours!!! In other words, don't bother people - no wonder it went straight to television - if it had been released to cinemas - people would've walked out in their droves!!!

Six strangers receive invites to the home of Millionaire Lewis Findley, when they arrive their host is absent, they anxiously wait to learn their purpose for being there. The first couple of minutes all seemed to point to one thing, a reworking of And then there were none, the ultimate Whodunnit, we had the strangers, the island, the invitations, that's where the similarities end. Let's be honest, it's nonsense, but if you are fan of mysteries and whodunnits, you may just get some enjoyment out of it, there are some interesting moments, and the story has a few clever ideas. For me, it had the look and feel of a stage play, entertaining enough, maybe a little rough around the edges at times. The accents are a little hit and miss, and at no point does it feel as though it's England, I've not checked the production details, but I'm assuming The States or Canada. Mischa Barton does a fine job, more Fletcher than Marple, but pleasing enough. Chris Browning stole the show for me, I enjoyed his performance. 6/10.

Predictable sub-par acting as was the plot. Each of the characters veiled history was evident from the offset. The acting was poor aside from the "gum shoe". Dialogue was very poor - trying too hard to be English I feel. The main protagonist being Misha who in her dialogue expressed a wish or insight using two "long words" which in effect meant the same, and really there was not need. The worldly men who apparently are doctors and solicitors appeared trite, ineffective, play boy'ish and rather dense - considering they were supposed to be men of learning. We DO NOT have crickets in England, so an inaccuracy on the part of the script writer and the director. Pretty poor all in all.

This is yet another version of the Agatha Christie book, 'Ten Little Indians'. Why anyone thought another version was needed I've no idea, The acting was poor and very mushy, with no outstanding performances. Whereas the original pitted the characters against each other, this version has a woman who seems to believe she is some kind of detective. The other characters just wash around each other doing nothing in particular. There is also a whole load of rabbits involved, but I have no idea what they were doing. When you have such a masterpiece as Agatha Christies original work, it is outrageous that anyone should mess it around like this.

Review-Title: Worst so called British accents I have ever heard
Review-Description: I watched this expecting it to be a bit like Agatha Christie's ' And then there were none' as the publicity seemed to indicate it was similar. Oh dear what a mess! Apart from Alex Hyde White, not one of the cast could speak with a passable British accent at all. Either it was a poor parody or otherwise it kept slipping into something else. The script was obviously written by an American with many American words or phrases that sounded quite ridiculous with a pseudo British accent. Many inaccuracies for the period the worst being that British police do not and never have carried guns except under specific circumstances - not a routine murder. Would have been far better to set this in America, then it wouldn't have grated so much.

I was so looking forward to this. Sounded just up my street but unfortunately it was dire. It started off with promise but the acting was poor as was the writing. Mischa Barton was terrible. Didn't quite carry it off. I give almost full marks though for the setting. The house and props were wonderful and deserving of a very juicy mystery. What a shame it fell flat. The outstanding star of the show was Blunder, the dog. What a wonderful doggy actor. He outshone the humans by miles. I actually give 10 stars to him. He was amazing. I've fallen for him and hope to see him in many more films. A little darling.

Review-Title: Weird and not great, although Florence Pugh shines
Review-Description: One of Florence Pugh's better performances but too bad about the rest of it. Cleverly written but weird and convoluted on screen. Set in a not so idyllic '50s community that to say the film packs a twist is not at twist at all. It's disingenuous, easy, cheeky - much like the film itself, which starts off strong before crumbling into baffling storytelling choices made worse by the revolting intentions behind them. More frustrating is that the film also offers stunning craft work, a wonderfully immersive quality. In short, It is less than the sum of Florence Pugh's performance. Despite great chemistry between Pine and Pugh and amazing production & costume design, the obvious and nonsensical plot and Harry Styles' unconvincing performance ultimately sinks up the film.

The drama surrounding 'Don't Worry Darling's' release had me quite concerned about how it would impact the film's quality. However, I found that the film succeed despite all this behind-the-scenes chaos! I absolutely adored the film's style and the way it fit into the narrative. Upon a second watch, you will notice subtle things in the film that you did not see the first time. Plus, there was some creative cinematography techniques utilised that supported these two film elements. Florence Pugh and Chris Pine gave fantastic performances. However, I feel Harry Styles performance stood out a bit compared to them. There were a few times that a different take of Harry's performance should have been utilised instead of what made it into the film. Although, I feel he did have a unique chemistry with Pugh! There are a few inconsistencies, but they did not impact the film too severely. Overall, I would definitely recommend seeing this! It is one of my favourites of the year and I enjoy non-franchise films getting support.

I honestly wasn't aware of all the real-world drama surrounding the film, and I certainly wasn't offended by it. But I have to say, on its own merits, this film just doesn't make sense in the end, mostly due to a lack of world-building. Why did the red plane appear? What was the deal with the eggs? Why did she get smooshed against the glass? Does the bus driver know he's in a simulation? Why does Frank's wife stab him? The more you think about this film the less sense it makes. Even though most of the good reviews I find seem to admit it's lacking. I think it's benefitting from its controversy because people are rating it higher in support of the message and not judging the actual film.

Florence Pugh, Harry Styles and Chris Pine are excellent in this film set in 1950's America in a secret society living in a remote area,free from civilization and society's issues and problems. A society built on deception and lies and brainwashing. Very suspenseful and lots of sexual encounters. Thanks to the strength of one wife this secret society is about to get turned upside down. This is the storyabout chaos and mis adventures of a community of people looking for a better life and pursuit of happiness for a select group of people chosen by the society's leadeship. Great soundtrack and i suggest mature audiences only.

I really was hooked and intrigued the whole time.. some of the head scratching momentd in the movie u can think of the reasons behind ... but some the movie just gives you no answers to... tooo many plot holes to be left with so little answers! The main big reveal was so shocking and great! But the ending was just so rushed and left us in the dark it feels like. But all around very intriguing movie with a great plot twist you cant see coming. I just want to know what happens after.. What happens when she wakes up does anyone come for her? What about the other women?? I will buy a book if there is one just to find out!

Review-Title: A thriller worth seeing that is reminiscent of "Stepford".
Review-Description:
A movie that is really fun right from the start for all those who are enthusiastic about the 50s. The setting is really great, the music is really fun, the great cars of the time. Everything is seen through rose-tinted glasses, and you quickly realize that this is just a facade. But that also makes it exciting, because you want to know what's behind it. Good-looking actors and actresses, beautiful fashion and the details of the set are a joy. The choreographed departure of the men, as well as the behavior of those involved, is reminiscent of "The Stepford Wives". Thriller / psychological thriller / mystery, it all fits and I wanted to know what was behind it. I was very entertained until the final resolution. The light-hearted, almost dreamlike start, which put me in an absolute good mood, then changed and even then it was interesting to see what happened and I was able to get excited. Only the resolution/the complete ending is a matter of taste, unfortunately it wasn't my cup of tea. But the acting performance of the protagonists, as well as the setting, music and of course the cars, as well as the one or other twist in the story, make me happy to recommend this movie. -------------
Conclusion:
Worth seeing.

It's probably not for everyone but a great movie if you like something a little different and a bit dark and twisted. It's Black Mirror with a Stepford Wives vibe and that is right up my alley! You know when you finish a good movie or series and you instantly want to find something else that gives you that same feeling because you didn't really want it to end but rushed through it wanting to see how it ended? This is one of those. This movie was what it was because of Florence Pugh and the rest of the acting was mediocre in comparison. This role was made for her! I love an ending that can't be guessed even if it does leave you feeling a little Ill.

Experience:
While we were watching the movie we were sitting in the cinema room. It was very cold there so we brought our jackets .But the quality of the sound was perfect. Casts
The important casts were Alice Champerls,Jack,Frack,Margaret,Bunny,Peg,The new girl:Violet,And the husbands
The soundtrack:
The soundtrack was effective for everyone. We watched in silence and there was a big tension in the room. Everyone were waiting for what's going to happen. Opinion:
We absolutely loved the whole kind of feeling of the movie. It was very interesting and thoughtful. And now we have a lot of questions about the movie for example:what will happen to Alice? What Frank's wife is going to do with the victory project? Why and how was it made? Characters:
We loved the character of Alice, she was a very good actor and she empathized herself perfectly. Harry Styles seemed perfect and nobody thought he was lying to his wife about his work at the Victory Project and her whole life. So that's the reason why we liked his acting. The other characters seemed very happy and perfect too, we think that it made an important impression of the movie's atmosphere. The creators of the movie showed Frank like something was wrong with him, but we didn't know why, because everyone honored and loved him. Background:
In the background the most important things were the characters, the heavy colors everywhere and the perfect life feeling for example in the food, the houses inside,and the garden city. Summary:
We gave this title because we think that Alice was the first woman who had the power to break the "wall of controllability" because she lived in a world she couldn't control and everyone was against her and made her believe that she is crazy. We think that the mens in the film wanted to make a happy life for their chosen wives, but the truth is that it was their dream life, because they could control everything around them and the wives and their happiness were "their". In reality it's the opposite, because nowadays women have the power and the opportunities to live their lives as they want.

Review-Title: This is one of those movies where you understand the whole story at the end.
Review-Description: I've seen it twice. The film was set in the 50's and it's about a married couple called Alice&Jack. In the village the women's role is to clean the house and cook, their husbands work on the Victory project. The leader is Frank who tries to keep everything in secret, but Alice finds out the truth. The life of Alice in the movie was calm and perfect until she started to see her visions. I liked the music because it fits to the scenes, but sometimes it was a little terrifying. The scenery and the customs were old school, they were so colorful. The first time I saw it I was confused while I was watching it, I didn't understand what was going on and why Alice started going crazy and started seeing visions. My jaw dropped when she realized where she was and that her whole life was a massive lie. Overall, I think this is the kind of movie where you understand the whole movie in the last 5 minutes. I give it a 7/10 rate.

Review-Title: Cringy plot and Harry Styles shouldn't be cast in anymore roles, he can't act lol
Review-Description: 2 stars solely for Florence Pugh's emotionally committed performance. She pours all her acting prowess into a performance that this overhyped, pretentious, sucky film doesn't deserve one ounce of. Harry Styles is not a good actor, please stick to your manufactured pop songs lmao. Olivia Wilde, please stop making films. The screenplay tries to be "original" but it's NOT; it heavily borrows from Stepford Wives, Twilight Zone, and Black Mirror themes. Very predictable plot and plot twist all around. However, the cinematography is another positive aspect but besides Pugh's great performance, there's nothing else positive from this film. The runtime and pacing just kept dragging on, could not wait for this film to finally finish. Maybe worth watching once or just not at all.

Overrated, contrived mess. This type of movie only exists for the stars that agreed to appear in it, they all play according to typecast. Jackman for instance with his fierce barking and stony face. Making the bad guys "at war with God" is just lazy, clich√©d writing. Very disappointing. I suppose this is meant to be seen as a detective movie, but it doesn't have any mystery. Everything is simply given to the viewer. In the detective genre, we expect more. There's more mystery to a detective / comedy like "the hangover". Much of the plot is directly ripped off from the far superior "The Pledge". There, Jack Nicholson shows how to extend one's range. See that instead.

This movie was an uncomfortable movie, and I like that a mystery to where one of our characters daughters is going missing in one of the other characters which is a cop has to find that's basically the premise of this whole, and yet is one of the directors best movies first of all the performances of this movie is top-notch, the best performance of the movie movie actually Hugh Jackman, which gives off a anti-hero vibe but the stuff is doing so brutal is so illegal, but we still side with him in some ways, Jake Jalal's character is that one character with all about the law, but see-through the events of this movie the see through the people who caused this, each character in each performance in this movie is top-notch makes you feel for every single character in this movie, especially the person who is blamed for the movie give us a little hands on who did it and when it revealed that the old lady did it. It makes a lot of sense coming from the background she had with her own children and how it affect her to take children. Also, we don't talk about in this movie is the fact of the character traits of both Jake Gyllenhaal character and Hugh Jackman character Jake Gyllenhaal Character see him is what we all have to know about him it's Thanksgiving, He's all alone at a restaurant, but when he gets that phone call, he'll stop at nothing to do. The job is probably the best character in this something that no parent should go through. The term that I will kill for my children or I'll do anything to make my children safe. It's all represented And Hugh Jackman character. Overall, this movie is highly skilled and I highly recommend this film to anyone who loves dark movies and gritty movies 9/10.

I am not speaking hyperbolically when I say this is one of the greatest films ever made. The storyline, the cinematography, the acting, the ending.... Absolutely immaculate. Hugh jackman not getting any sort of Oscar attention for his role is a travesty. As a parent of five, the tension felt during the entirety of the run time of this movie can't be over stated. The way it displays the different responses to grief etc will connect with any viewer and keeps you invested til the last second. It will leave you asking yourself: "what lengths would I go to to bring my child home safe?" Watch this movie. It's hard to sit through at times, but you will be glad you finished it.

A well told story with a great cast. I think that sums it up. However i'm so uncomfortable after watching this one Hugh Jackman steals the show but Jake Gylenhaal is not behind either. When you hear the word "prisoners" you might think about someone being behind bars. But it's far more complex than that. I've never thought that a 2hr 30m movie will keep on edge throught the entirety but i was wrong. Go ahead watch it. The morale factor will be tested heavily although Dylan Minette doesnt have anything to do with outcome of this movie! Paul Dano was brilliant so was David Dastmalchian!!! Not ur avg crime drama thriller.

Review-Title: That ending and detective work sure was a maze
Review-Description: 10 years later and I'm finally watching this movie. Had I known more about the premise I would have watched it earlier as the story is great. Overall the acting is phenomenal. Jake G is one of my favorite actors. The guy who plays Alex Jones (odd they chose that as his name) is great also. This was a preview of him for his future role as the riddler. Very good. All the scenes with jackman kidnapping the suspect, questioning, torturing, everything is 100% relatable I think. I'd do the same, probably worse had I been in his situation. Especially when the dude said what he did when he was released. My issue is the maze/background wasn't really explained well. Who was the weirdo in the house? Also, the cop/detective work was really bad. It took him forever to notice the medallion being the same as the pictures. Cmon. The police were canvassing the property but didn't move vehicles or use scent dogs to search or anything at Jones house? Good god. What was the connection to the snakes? Idk there's some more but this is why it doesn't get a 10. I didn't have an issue with the length either. Just too many questions and bad police work.

Review-Title: Poor, implausible, violent for the sake of it
Review-Description: A detective film where the detective misses important clues and connections that the audience saw, it's all the wrong way round. I kept wondering why no one except the one detective got involved, especially after the plot thickened with other crimes being uncovered... I was expecting some sort of tension and character exploration in the relationship between the father and the detective, but no, just a lot of shouting. The things you find out in the end are a mixture of horrible and cliched. The only thought-provoking character question was whether the level of violence is the filmmakers' fault, or whether the audience enjoy and ask for this.

This movie feels so so different from the kinds of films Villeneuve makes these days - no epic scenery, no special effects. This is the opposite of Blade Runner 2049 or Dune in so many ways. And yet...you see the precursors. From the ways he frames certain shots to the ways he uses silence and ambient sound. The human moments shine through the rain and muck here just like they shine through the spaceships and cityscapes in his other movies. This story is a dark and disturbing puzzle that's too easy to solve and too tough to watch at points, but it's also a gifted cast being directed by a gifted director.

Review-Title: A hidden truth. A desperate search.
Review-Description: I have seen some of director Denis Villeneuve's films before, and he has made great films before, so a mystery crime drama with a cool cast of actors like Hugh Jackman and Jake Gyllenhaal with a simple premise interested me; after watching the film, I thought this movie was fantastic. I thought the movie Prisoners (2013) was an investing film with amazing performances, great cinematography, investing characters, and a mystery that made me be on the edge of my seat while watching wondering what was going to happen next; I did not know what to expect from this film, but it takes a simple premise involving two families young daughters disappearing, and does something different where it feels like a new thing. Hugh Jackman and Jake Gyllenhaal give amazing performances throughout the whole movie; Hugh Jackman as Keller Dover, who is the father of one of the families who find out their daughters are missing, he goes through a lot trying to find his daughter doing certain things in intense ways where you question if this is the right way to handle the problem while also learning issues about his character that I found interesting. Jake Gyllenhaal as Detective Loki is trying his best to find out what happened to the family's daughters and where they were taken to, as he interrogates people and finds interesting clues that might connect to the incident, you are on his side, and you want to know how all of it connects; along with Detective Loki and Keller Dover having many interactions with each other questioning each other's methods and disagreements on what should be done, which I found very interesting when watching. Also, the rest of the cast such as Viola Davis, Terrence Howard, Maria Bello, and Paul Dano were all fantastic, especially with Viola Davis and Terrence Howard as Nancy Birch and Franklin Birch, who is the other family who lost their daughter. I cannot talk about whoever the antagonist is in this because it would be a spoiler, but mostly it is because every character, even the main characters have questionable problems where you wonder if they themselves are good or not. The cinematography in the movie is great with there being lots of wide shots and barely any cuts between shots, with every shot looking beautiful and giving the film a cool look and feel to it that I loved watching; plus, I will add that there is no musical score in the movie most of the time, and when there is, it makes the scenes better when they are playing out making the calm and intense moments investing and enjoyable to watch because of how well they are put together. Also, the way everything felt in the movie made it feel real, and like this could happen making the feel nerve-wracking and suspenseful. Though I did love the movie Prisoners (2013), it will be a while before I decide to rewatch this film, mostly because of the dark themes, how real it looks and feels, and what the movie focuses on; other than that, I highly recommend watching Prisoners (2013) if you have not already. Director Denis Villeneuve is a great director, and this movie proves that with great performances, cinematography, mystery, and a premise that is something we have seen before but done differently to make it feel new; though this is not a film that will be easy to rewatch frequently, I still recommend giving this film a watch whenever you get a chance.

"Prisoners" is a riveting thriller that delves into the moral gray areas of justice. Hugh Jackman and Jake Gyllenhaal shine in their roles, adding depth to the intense storyline. The film's twists and turns, coupled with strong cinematography, create a suspenseful atmosphere. As it navigates themes of morality and desperation, "Prisoners" keeps viewers engaged with its compelling narrative and standout performances. "Prisoners" is a riveting thriller that delves into the moral gray areas of justice. Hugh Jackman and Jake Gyllenhaal shine in their roles, adding depth to the intense storyline. The film's twists and turns, coupled with strong cinematography, create a suspenseful atmosphere. As it navigates themes of morality and desperation, "Prisoners" keeps viewers engaged with its compelling narrative and standout performances.

Review-Title: Oh man, it was good. Really good. Really really good
Review-Description: Oh man. Where do I begin. Maybe by the constant suspense, the heart breaking emotion, the passionate outstanding acting, the sharp, well executed constant twists. Oh man the movie was great. The scenery, setting, eerie music was just befitting of such a tragedy. I really really enjoyed it. Only negative is that I believe the ending should've been better. But oh man that twist at the end when we find out the kids are in the creepy grandmas basement. I was tripping man. But besides that it was perfect. Perfect. Everything. Down to the last minute details. They really did cook man. Although need to watch again for further appreciation of this masterpiece.

Review-Title: A piece of crap disguised as a good thing thanks to the cast
Review-Description: Practically everything here is bad, but the quartet of main actors are top notch and save some of the total catastrophe. Starting with the script, there isn't a single scene, dialogue or sequence that isn't completely clich√©, it's awkward, the scenes where the main couples interact that say so, culminating in the final scene in the new year, the most clich√© impossible. Direction and editing are weak, and for example, just remember the scene where Cameron Diaz is arriving at the house in England for the first time, walks through the snow all clumsy and collides with a tree, what was supposed to be a comical scene ends up being something embarrassing, so poorly done and dull. In addition to being clich√© and poorly done, everything is forced in the story, nothing conveys naturalness, I have rarely seen something written with so little creativity and talent, and I like some silly rom-coms, but this one has a script that is below critics. What saves here is that, who knows how, four great actors accepted this script, and they manage to hold the wave of the bad film exclusively due to their talents, it's undoubtedly pleasant to see them acting together, even in the midst of so much nonsense. And to prove what I say, that only actors save this deception, I suggest an exercise of imagination: imagine this same film, strictly the same in all the scenes, script, dialogue, settings, direction and production, but with 4 of these modern young actors from Netflix in the places of Diaz, Winslet, Law and Black, the complete tragedy that would be. I rate it 5 out of 10 due to the great interpretation work, otherwise it would be 1 out of 10.

'The Holiday (2006)' is a festive rom-com that somehow runs for over two hours, making it a good deal longer than it has any right to be.
