It follows two women who each experience a heartbreak and decide to swap houses for the Christmas period so they can go through it alone in an entirely different location. However, fate intervenes and sends them just the men they need to get over their past loves. Positioning their new relationships almost as what saves them from their old ones is a bit problematic, I suppose, but the picture mostly dances around the issue by giving the protagonists commitment issues (on opposite ends of the spectrum) which they learn to overcome. One of the narratives is far more focused on this sort of internal development than the other, as Kate Winset's plotline more-or-less just chucks in a romance with Jack Black as a little bonus (a lot of it concerns her relationship with an ageing screenwriter, portrayed by the wonderful Eli Wallach, who helps to bring her out of her shell). This is the more interesting side of the story, for sure, but it's not given as much time as the other, far more conventional side. Thankfully, that side - which chronicles the fish-out-of-water affair between Cameron Diaz and Jude Law - is sweet and bouncy and entirely watchable. It's exactly what you'd expect from a schmaltzy, feel-good romance, but it's well-executed and does exactly what it needs to. The stuff set in L. A. is more interesting simply because it's ever-so-slightly less conventional, but it still hits pretty much all the beats you'd imagine (yet is no less successful because of it). Kate Winslet and Jack Black aren't really given enough time for their relationship to blossom and, as such, it isn't all that believable they'd fall for one another. There's a scene where Kate Winslet is acting her heart out during an eloquent and sentimental speech about how broken she feels and then Jack Black just swears, says "you need this more than I do" in the most Jack Black way possible and hands her a drink. Still, it's a nice enough dynamic that it doesn't feel especially jarring when they inevitably come together as the finale approaches. That's kind of the best way to describe the piece as a whole really; it's a bit rough around the edges and entirely too safe, but it all comes together surprisingly nicely. It's a good version of a generic, slightly unbelievable thing. There are a handful of chucklesome moments, a few pieces of successful sentimentality and a general formal competence that keeps you engaged despite an often uneven and slightly strange pacing. It's definitely too long, but it's also enjoyable enough for what it is. It also serves as a decent movie to watch towards the end of the year, as it starts around Christmas and ends on New Years Eve.

This is almost a must to watch in Christmas season. I admit I am not a fan of rewatching the same movies every year, but once in a while this one sneaks in on my watch list on Christmas again. I love the story - even though it is a little cheesy. But the whole movie is carried by the good actors and actresses. Yes, Jude Law is sexy and all - but the performances of all 4 of the main characters is really really good. I like, that it includes all kind of elements in this movie, comedy, tragedy and love story. If there is a small minus to this movie, it's that the character of Iris is a little too sweet for me. And at times I wished the story would have gone just a little deeper. Overall a very entertaining movie, that is inviting for a lot of coziness on the sofa.

Review-Title: A Movie To Come Back For The X-Mas Holidays
Review-Description: I have been coming back to this movie every year during Christmas and i have no shame in admitting this is my favorite Christmas movie after Home Alone. There's something so soothing and calming effect this movie has without being overly cheesy or dramatic like most of the holiday rom-coms. The writing, the direction, the screenplay AND the acting, everything so perfectly in sync. Never felt bored for a minute. And the dialogues are so well written, nothing felt forced, they were just flowing with the pace. Coming to the cast and their performances, a lot of ppl say Cameron Diaz was just doing what she has been doing in most of her movies, but as i haven't watched much of her movies, i thoroughly enjoyed her here. But what stood out for me is a Jude Law, a Kate Winslet and a Jack Black u don't get to see very often. Most of the time Jude Law/Kate Winslet are seen in serious characters whereas Jack Black in comedy, but here, Jude Law as a rom-com hero was dream come true. And Kate and Jack as two miserable individuals with bad luck in relationships finding each other was a treat to watch, especially Kate. Like every other romantic movies, this movie is also about finding the right partner and you don't know u might find it in the most unexpected place !!!

Review-Title: starts of weird, progresses slowly, but ends perfectly
Review-Description: The Holiday stars Cameron Diaz as Amanda and Kate Winslet as Iris, two young women successful at work, but not so much at finding love. Amanda has just broken up with her boyfriend that cheated on her and Iris tries to forget her ex she's in love with who just got engaged with another woman. The two decide to go on a vacation during the Christmas holidays to forget about their troubles and agree to exchange homes with each other for two weeks. In London, Amanda meets Iris' older brother, while Iris gets to meet Amanda's LA neighbor, an acclaimed, retired Hollywood screenwriter who she befriends. The movie starts of weird with some questionable stylistic choices. The first half of the movie is pretty unbalanced with regards to the two sites of the plot and has some trouble advancing the story *warning spoiler* until Amanda gets to know Graham's daughters. The big plus of this film is the ending which brings together every aspect of the movie and even raises some doubts over what will happen using temptation as a tool.

Review-Title: Good alternative to watch at the end of the year festivities.
Review-Description: Very interesting romantic film from its script. For a movie buff, it will have several hooks that will keep you glued to the screen waiting for more. But let's not deviate. This double story of love and heartbreak contains many elements with which the audience can identify, and it is precisely where the film finds its place. The performances of the choral cast are quite dissimilar, with one pair standing out over the other. Winslet and Law knew how to integrate perfectly into their roles, but Diaz and Black didn't. The soundtrack and the meta-narrative details are an excellent complement, which entertain and become part of the essence of the story. The main negative points, in my opinion, are not minor. Direction and editing have quite noticeable errors that at certain points manage to take you out of the natural flow of the plot. Everything else is of a fairly decent level, without standing out in a good or bad way. The film entertains, excites and makes you believe in love. Recommended as a good alternative to watch at the end of the year festivities.

With Nancy Myers' films, you know that everything will be fine in the end. Sometimes I need such trivial stories and I don't care how believable they are. Especially when Kate Winslet shows up, I feel good right away because I think she's one of the top 5 actresses of the last 20 years. She plays her role in a correspondingly differentiated way, sometimes with a little too much verve, whereas Cameron Diaz falls down considerably, even if she is so likeable that you quickly forgive her for it. In addition to Jack Black's renewed attempt to play a serious role without any antics - which he once again fails to do - Jude Law makes for a clear 2:0 in the Brits versus Yanks comparison. He plays the mischievous father of two adorable little girls so charmingly that you can't help but be thrilled by his first appearance. So Nancy Myers - with a few clever cameo appearances - doesn't light a comedy fire, but a thoroughly likeable story with lots of artificial snow and an Eli Wallach in a great supporting role that goes straight to the heart. All's well that ends well.

Review-Title: Most under rated movie in the history! 10/10
Review-Description: The dialogs are just pure brilliance, every other sentence is a gem. The writing is so wonderful, it's that kind that makes you say : They don't make them like that anymore.. Quote from Miles about the song he wrote for Iris: I have only used the good notes.. All the mentions of gumption. It's soempowering, makes you want to get out there and live! Love the story, well all 3 stories in one. It actually got me to look into home exchange and it's proper real thing! Who knew! We have now done two successful exchanges! We watch this movie ever Christmas, it is best Christmas movie ever. Deserves much higher score than 6.9!

In my opinion, this film amounts to a pile on of clich√©s, some awful central performances, and a nonsense of a script. In my opinion. Things that bug me about it...... Who in their right mind would abandon their dog to a complete stranger's care for two weeks? Why the dog? Give me a reason that she has a dog in the first place. Since when was LAX north of the PCH? Why could the limo not take Amanda to the front door of the cottage but Will's car could manage it from the opposite direction? Obviously we needed to see Amanda struggling down a quaint country lane in high heels with her luggage! What woman in the world, staying in a cottage in the middle of nowhere would answer the door in the middle of the night to a drunk and then let him stay the night, let alone sleep with him? For a man so keen to keep his life compartmentalised, Will all too readily invites into his daughters' lives a woman he knows nothing about. Things are over-egged, then just for good measure, egged a little more. We see both female protagonists doing "crazy frog" dancing to well-known tracks, harking back to the more successful Hugh Grant as PM dance in "Love Actually". There's just so much wrong with it! I think this film tries to emulate other, better romcoms and comes up short.

Review-Title: A perfect romantic Christmas film of heartbreak and finding love
Review-Description: Don't we love Christmas movies? E.g. Movies that make us feel fuzzy and feel good inside? This is one such movie. This movie tells parallel stories of two women (Kate Winslet and Cameron Diaz) each both having freshly coming out of heartbroken relationships. Overcome with emotions, they impetuously decide to swap homes across the the globe to getaway and have a holiday. Unexpectedly for them, love and romance ensures. It is refreshing to see a story told from a woman's perspective. We see portrayed very sensitively the various emotions that women feel as they experience events in their life. E.g. The joys and the sorrows, the anguish and the excitement and everything in-between. Women are emotional beings more so than men. Moreover, this film explores the themes of romantic interpersonal relationships, dating and love. It is a movie for young adults who want to watch a movie about romantic love, heartbreak and finding new love. The winds of change is in the air for these heartbroken souls as their destiny of finding love unfolds. What I like about this movie is that universal themes of love and romance are explored in this movie, themes we all desire and can relate to. E.g. We see the flirting glances of budding new love, to dating and getting to know someone, how the guy makes a move and kisses her, how he makes her laugh, to boldly confessing feelings to one another. We also see how the movie explores the idea of long-distance relationships and potential complications that go with that. Also, it is interesting how we form mental pictures of people in our minds based on snap judgements on how they behave or act. Only for the mental picture to reverse and change once we get to know them better. E.g. We may think a guy is hitting on a girl when he is just saying hello. Or how a guy appears to be greeting his girlfriend when he is meeting his sister. This film touches on this play of perceptions. Having watched a few romantic movies, this movie reminds me slightly of the email correspondence in You've Got Mail as the women exchange emails with one another. There is a subtle homage to the film When Harry Met Sally when Cameron Diaz's character meets her love interest (I won't spoil it). The film also features a classic romantic scene where a person realizes the errors of their ways and starts running after their lover filled with passion. All in all, I recommend this as a solid romantic movie with a Christmas theme that will definitely put you into a feel-good romantic mood by the end of it. An enjoyable watch and highly recommended!

Review-Title: When I saw DCH I cried, but couldn't relate to the characters, 20 years later, I could relate to these guys!!
Review-Description: The core idea of authenticity being a pre-requisite for human connections is bought out powerfully. The story and anecdotes had a polished authenticity to it and that to me was the biggest plus. In movies, you emphasize a few things and that contributes to the crescendo of the climax. But in real life, even the biggest events are just another bit. Marrying that mundaneness of life in a film/ story without losing the ability to grab your attention is a tough act and the makers have achieved that :) The actors, while being true to their characters, also bring out nuances. The energy with which the character of Imaad (Siddhant Chaturvedi) dances in a scene brings out his hedonism, the insecurities of Neil (Adarsh Gourav) and the absolutely delightful feminine aspects of Ahana (Ananya Panday), which I won't even try to put in words were just beautiful.

Very good movie. Something different than the action movies that have come out recently. Very interesting insights into Gen Z life and thinking!! Soooo different than how the previous generations think and live! Ananya Panday, Siddhant Chaturvedi and Adarsh Gourav have acted amazingly well! When actors truly get into the skin of their characters the movie becomes a delight to watch. Finally Ananya got to show her talent and boy did she shine! Siddhant is my new favorite! What an actor and an amazing portrayal of a scarred youth who had to face his truth!! The message of the movie is very relevant to today's times as well. A highly recommended watch!

Review-Title: Navigating the Digital Maze: A Poignant Tale in 'Kho Gaye Hum Kahan'.
Review-Description: "Kho Gaye Hum Kahan" (translating to 'Where are we lost'), directed by Arjun Varain Singh in his directorial debut, is a poignant coming-of-age drama that eloquently captures the essence of modern youth navigating life in the digital age. This 2023 Indian Hindi-language film, streaming on Netflix, delves into the intricacies of friendships, ambitions, and heartbreaks, set against the bustling backdrop of Mumbai. The film, written by Singh, Zoya Akhtar, and Reema Kagti, stars Siddhant Chaturvedi, Ananya Panday, and Adarsh Gourav as the central trio - Ahana, Neil, and Imaad. Their performances are a standout, portraying the complexities of their characters with a raw and relatable intensity. Kalki Koechlin, Anya Singh, and Rohan Gurbaxani, in supporting roles, add depth to the narrative. One of the film's striking aspects is its initial slow pace, which gradually builds up, mirroring the uncertainties and explorations of youth. This pacing beautifully complements the storyline, providing stability and depth to the narrative as it unfolds. The background score by Sid Shirodkar and the songs by a diverse group of artists like OAFF-Savera, Ankur Tewari, and Sachin-Jigar, among others, harmonize with the film's theme. While the songs may be just okay for some, they subtly underscore the film's emotional landscape. A significant strength of "Kho Gaye Hum Kahan" is its realistic portrayal of the insecurities faced by today's generation, amplified by the omnipresence of social media. The film does an excellent job of reflecting these contemporary challenges without losing the timeless nature of youth's quest for identity and connection. The drama and romance in the film are finely tuned to resonate with current societal norms and situations, making it particularly relatable to the younger audience. It captures the essence of how relationships and aspirations are influenced and sometimes complicated by the digital world. In summary, "Kho Gaye Hum Kahan" is a well-crafted film that offers a compelling exploration of the journey of self-discovery in the age of social media. It's a narrative that speaks to the heart of the young and the young at heart, making it a recommended watch. The movie, with its excellent cast, thoughtful direction, and relevant storytelling, is a meaningful addition to the genre of modern coming-of-age dramas.

Review-Title: Overhyped and worst acting by Ananya Pandey
Review-Description: This movie is a waste of time. It is so overhyped with zero elements and subpar acting. The PR team of this movie has been working left, right, and centre to somehow make this movie come across as a hit. I had high expectations from Zoya, but I have been disappointed. The only good part was Adarsh Gourav. The movie plot is weak and Ananya cannot act. Please stop shoving these nepo kids down our throats. Not everyone can be an actor, and it is highly time that these nepo babies understand that they should stop making movies. Instead I would highly suggest watch good movies such as 12th Fail.

A really good watch after long time, Dil chahta hai vibe is recreated but speaks on today's world. Must watch, unexpectedly great performance from lead trio. Plot is not that predictable it goes like a crazy ride, which surprises with a great twist. Finally found a movie which can found relatable with today's generation which speaks on current situation. Talking about music it's really hit right at the time, explores indie pop genere smoothly also connects with storyline unknowingly. Can be a best directorial debut as such topics are handled neatly. Spoiler warning movie speaks alot about social media adiction and it's consequences.

Kho gaye hum kahan (9/10): Kho gaye hum kahan (9/10):
This is a very lightheaded movie with ananya pandey, siddhant chaturvedi and adarsh gaurav. This movie truly depicts a digital age where things that are being shown on Instagram is more important than the things in reality. And one cannot see inside himself for herself to know better. Ananya Pandey make sure that her ex would not get a good girl again while Adarsh tried to take revenge but he realise it was not himself and that was not I mean Ananya's one was not revenge. While the last one was a comedian and tried to escape from his past.

Review-Title: I hope this will definitely be included in the better films of the year.
Review-Description: Siddhant Chaturvedi steals the show in 'Kho Gaye Hum Kahan' with his captivating performance! Ananya Panday's portrayal is equally praiseworthy, adding depth to the storyline. The movie effectively addresses the challenges faced by today's youth, especially the facade of social media and its impact on real-life relationships. The music beautifully complements the narrative, enhancing the overall emotional depth of the film. A commendable movie that brilliantly captures the essence of modern-day struggles. I hope it will be a brilliant movie as per the rating it has got, are you ready for it or not?

Review-Title: A must watch for young adults
Review-Description: Life captive to screens - very well portrayed. How easily one gets sucked down the virtual life hole, is shown very well. Each character grows on you and I am sure many identify with one of them. Siddhant Chaturvedi is really good. So is Ananya Pandey and Adarsh Gourav. I liked Anya Singh too - she delivered a really important message in essaying her role! Kudos to the writer and director Arjun Varain Singh. There are 4 other writers but I guess Arjun put it all together. The music is nothing to write home about but the movie makes for excellent watching. I recommend that you watch the movie yet reduce screen time. How? Figure that out!

Review-Title: KHO GAYE HUM KAHAN:-an important film on social media culture.
Review-Description: Kho gaye hum kahan is a comedy drama romantic film directed by arjun varain singh. The film's first half is very happy go lucky. The friendship is fleshed out, the acting is all in place. We are given a peek into the three primary characters' lives, their happiness, their insecurities, their sadness. The writing never overwhelms us with the sadness and morbidity. The characters have aspirations, it gets its fuel from their friendship itself. Nearing the interval, a spat between the two male friends happens which leads to the primary crux of the film, i.e them confronting their fears. Its written very well, but definitely have some convenient plotholes. Ahana yells at neil for exposing an opportunistic, gold digger, when she herself had made a scene at her ex's birthday, who is also a very ugly person. But I like the fact that the film does not try to make its characters politically correct. They are hypocrites in their rights, knowingly or unknowingly. The standup bits of imaad are well written, extracting many chuckles. The film has many dialogues which try to explain to the viewers about the characters' state of mind. That's needless and very demeaning to the adult viewers. Monologues at the end seem to swirl around the film, serving little purpose. The chemistry between imaad and simran is very half baked. The last standup skit where imaad comes out of his trauma is one of the strongest scnes of the film. Siddhant chaturvedi and adarsh gaurav are two highly promising actors. Adarsh gaurav, especially, is the star of this film. Got a very meaty role and clutched onto it. Siddhant has a problem with crying, or maybe his character was a bit emotionally distant. Ananya panday us good, has gotten better over the years but needs to keep hardworking. Her dialogue delivery is still very outlandish. Kalki koechlin is very good, so is rohan gurbaxani. The music is great, the songs are very peppy and fresh. The cinematography is good. The camera mainly traverses closed spaces which conveys the mindspaces of the characters. They are open in the out but their souls are somewhere locked inside them, inside social media.

Kho Gaye Hum Kahan directed by debutant director Arjun Varain Singh this movie is produced by Farhan and written by Zoya Akhtar. Basically it is a typical Gen-Z story about how we compare our lives to others through social media . The Zoya's magic of making a triangle in friendships Znmd , Dil chahta hai remains gravitational constant even in this with 3 freinds
[Annaya , Sidhart and Adarsh. Top Notch Chemistry
Top Notch Writting Focusing more on younger demographics and Gen-Z style definately worth watching !!!! One thing , on a personal note Adarsh Gourav A few of the actors who i notice when it comes to noticing and following an actor from Day 1 From Rukh to Hostel Days to White Tiger to Guns and Gulaab to kho gaye hum kahaan What an Actor.

Only it's not about old fashioned women. It's about new fashioned feminism. How do I know it's a women's flick? First, because the male characters are remarkably fake. Beta and beta-lite, they both would make wonderful friends but fall far short as potential lovers. There's virtually no masculinity in the entire film (not surprising since it was written and directed by a woman). Nora, the lead, is an underwritten character who is the object of adoration because she is so...well, she doesn't have to be anything- she's a woman and therefore the prize. She values her career above all things and that's the way she was brought up- her family uproots itself from what looks like a successful life in Korea to pursue greater success. The conflict here is that because Nora has emigrated to NYC she ends up married to a nebbishy unexciting American guy instead of the far superior looking, if uncharismatic, Korean guy she would have married had her family stayed put. He's not much, but I guess in the Asian world he's a kind of Chad (and he worships her). Ah, the modern women's dilemma: she's so perfect- an educated, thin, beautiful (?), successful playwright forced to settle for an underwhelming partner yearning for Mr. Big (but not enough to mess with her career) In the end, she stays put with the guy who can help her write her plays. Watching Chad East being ubered away she sobs uncontrollably- for herself, of course- who else would she be crying for? She is both hero and victim. I actually enjoyed the film and thought it was well made creating many interesting questions that can be discussed after viewing- but, boy oh boy, is the manosphere going to have a ball with this one.

Review-Title: What if this is our past life?
Review-Description: Where do I even start?? Such a beautiful film, from the visuals to the storytelling. Watching the film you just can see they wish to be together. But life pulls them a part. The film reminded me a bit of before sunrise, one of my favourite films. It has the same idea of talking getting to know each other, walking and connecting. So if you're a fan of the before trilogy definitely give this a go. The scene of them parting ways when they were children was such an amazing shot, it was like a foreshadow into their future. It showed Nora walking up the steps to her home, Hae Sung walking kind of down the way. This felt like a glimpse to their future, going separate ways, Nora walking upwards showed in a way she would be more successful.

Review-Title: I was expecting more based on the trailer
Review-Description: I don't know what I was expecting but I for sure thought I would be deeply moved by the story based on what I had seen in the trailer. It was not the case. This is a classic story of a love that couldn't be intertwined with the cultural challenges faced by immigrants. The premise is simple and the storytelling straightforward, a handful of characters, beautiful shots of New York City, questions about fate and self identity, yet it didn't dive deep enough to pull me in. And maybe that's not the aim of the film, maybe it's just there to tell the story at a surface level letting the audience do the work for themselves. I will mention however that the film does a great job at conveying the character's emotions/inner turmoil subtly but with enough clarity to understand how they really feel. Also there are a few beautiful shots (for example the final one). Yes I felt sorry for the 3 main characters who all have to deal with a lot of doubts but the connection between the 2 childhood friends wasn't strong enough to make me cry.

Review-Title: A metaphore of immigration, identity and belonging
Review-Description: "Past Lives" beautifully captures the essence of love, destiny, and the immigrant experience. Its poignant narrative, coupled with breathtaking visuals, leaves a lasting impression. What sets this film apart is its nuanced exploration of immigration. The movie transcends the boundaries of the traditional impossible love story, delving metaphorically into the emotional struggles of those who have left their homeland. With a visually stunning backdrop between New York and Seoul, "Past Lives" invites the audience to reflect on the complexities of identity, belonging, and the relentless passage of time.

Review-Title: Great concept that you can reflect on
Review-Description: It's a reality movie away from the romantic movies romance, it sets an example from the difference between our imagination & expectations and the reality of the situation and how we act on it. We all think of the what ifs in our life or what could've been if we've done something differently and the movie here gives us a good example of that, but for me for it to be a better movie i need to understand the characters more, learn about how they feel the way they feel either through scenes or conversations and I think the movie lacked those elements. I felt like I needed to see more of their time together to understand them perfectly, still I appreciate the use of silence as a part of the conversations cause sometimes it's better than words but it was a bit too much in the movie here. Overall it's good movie with a great idea that shows a part of reality that we forget about but in order for it to be better we need to be more involved with the characters' story instead of just hearing about it most of the time.

Review-Title: A Beautiful Movie, very Deep in meaning.
Review-Description: Under normal circumstances I would not be watching this genera of movies, it is a romance story of two kids that traces their lives through adulthood, and questions the decisions they make in life, and whether if they have made different decisions, they would have been together as adults. I wouldn't say it had a sad ending, but it was neither a happy ending, they ended up exactly where they begun. It is a slow Romance movie, but the beauty of it, is that it gets you thinking of your life and all your friendships and all the what ifs as you age and get older. As a 20 year old I might not have enjoyed this movie so much because I would not have reflected on the meaning of my friendships as I would have reflected today, but as a 55 year old it has a lot of deep meaning which I did enjoy. I do not believe in past lives, but I do believe our souls are eternal or maybe a parallel universe, and I could almost have sworn that at least one of my friendships was meant to be In-Yun as Nora would have put it in the movie. That friendship was never meant to be by my character norms, and defied all of my personal logic, yet it thrived for many years and we are still best of friends, and I often questioned if our souls have crossed a common path before this current life to make this bond so strong. Yes like in the other comments for this movie we make decisions, we choose different doors that lead to different paths, and as a hindsight we would look back and ask ourselves what would have happened if we had opened or took one of the other doors. That said I loved the movie, it was well made. If you love Romance stories then by all means watch it, it is a beautiful movie.

Review-Title: Wake me when the 8.0 rating enters the movie.
Review-Description:
Decided to watch this movie solely on its rating on IMDB and waited almost 2 hours for the 8.0 rating to present itself... I am still waiting. This movie is tough to watch. It's slow with zero excitement. The movie opens with a relatable scene where strangers try guessing the lives of the main characters. This is precisely what you will end up doing to keep yourself awake. The story line is split into random
12 year timeframes where there is no real rationale for the bond that continues between the soulmates separated as kids. Was the Korean gentleman supposed to be a home-wrecker? Was the green-card providing husband supposed to give his wife a hall-pass? Was she going to make out with him before he disappears forever in his Uber? Answer: Who cares? Pick another movie.

Review-Title: A beautiful film in every way. 9.5 stars
Review-Description: I have never officially rated a film this highly--well, maybe "The Godfather," "Amadeus," "Best Years of Our Lives," and a couple of others. But Past Lives exceeded my expectations. Yes, the heavy buzz surrounding the film was an indication that it was probably very good, but, after having watched it, I was still caught off guard. The film is, in a word: beautiful. The cinematography is stunning, the location selections were well thought out, and the acting was sublime. Teo Yoo (as Hae Sung) and John Magaro (as Arthur, the husband) delivered understated yet powerful performances that showed that great acting does not necessitate verbal communication; in this case, non-verbal acting was stronger than any words could express in many of the scenes involving the trio of leading actors. The film kept me watching with rapt attention, and the tension created by the uncertainty of where the relationships were heading added a heavy layer of suspense. The experience was so captivating that I found myself thinking, "Don't mess up this great film with a terrible ending." Then came the ending -- or what I THOUGHT was the ending, which made the actual ending ... perfect.

This is very good film, exceptional performances and well structured. 2 childhood friends in Korea are separated when the family of one immigrates to Canada. Years later they reconnect online and grow close again, but they end this when their different location make it difficult to meet. Eventually they do reconnect years later, one is now married and the other travels from Korea to the US and they arrange to meet. It's difficult to watch, as clearly they love each other but their lives took different directions so they were not destined to be together. The main issue I have with the movie is why they would want to meet again. The woman is now married, the man has a girlfriend. Life has moved on for both of them, agreeing to meet like this is never going to end well, someone is going to be hurt. I don't know why either of them couldn't see that, it seemed as though he was the one pining for her. I was also puzzled as to why the woman's American husband was so agreeable for her to be meeting up with her former friend again. Was he not aware of their situation? I came away from the film with these thoughts stuck in my mind. There is truth in the film, relationships are often complicated and we think about what might have been.

It started out pretty good: scenes from the lives of the two characters in their youth as friends with puppy love. Then we learn that the girl will be leaving the country. The first thing her mother does is set up a date with the boy and his mother as a chaperone. Then proceeds to tell the other mother that they are moving away and wanted this date as a pleasant memory for her daughter, not taking into consideration what that might do to the boy's emotions. Then we fast forward to them at university age and they skype a lot. She quickly halts this as it's too much for her. Even though she has feelings for him, she cuts him out of her life and decides to match herself with a man - who she has control over. She seduces him, he trys to learn her language and hangs out with her family. There is never talk of his family. The way he lays across her in bed as a woman does to a man. The way he is afraid she doesn't love him. She has the power; even if her husband never speaks of his fears, they exist and she can feel that on some level. She even says to his face that her old friend is very masculine and typical / normal. A normal man, the very thing that is too much for her. She needs to be on top, so to speak. People comment on the noble character of the husband, but think it was the only thing he could do. To just take it, and prey that she would stay. I was angry as this film triggered my own experiences with an emotionally bankrupt woman. The way she would just stare at her Korean visitor during their time together in NYC, showed how she wanted to be near the tiger, but does not dare try to tame it.

Review-Title: Don't listen to the bad reviews!
Review-Description: Jennifer Lawrence was awesome! Our theater were laughing their a$$es off. She is so good at being funny! She needs to do more comedy. Love the raunchiness. If you don't like raunchy, then you shouldn't see it. She doesn't try so hard to be funny unlike some bad Gen Z movies (looking at you "Anything but You". I think this movie deserves more attention it got. How can anybody not like JLaw. She shines even on bad movie which this isn't one. I laughed hard on this film. Not small chuckles. I hope people see it more once it is on streaming. Omg, I don't understand the bad reviews. Maybe people think it's cool to hate her. I don't get it!

Jennifer Lawrence is a fine actress, as shown in Silver Lining Playbook (2012) and American Hustle (2013). She's broadening her range with a ranch-com, but No Hard Feelings (2023) is so poorly written, it is beneath her talents. The problem is writer/director Gene Stupnitsky. He likes ranch-coms, but doesn't make them very well, as shown by Good Boys (2019) and Bad Teacher (2011). Now in No Hard Feelings (2023), a plausible premise leads from one painfully unrealistic situation to another, cringeworthy characters unable to function socially. A raunch-com is not Oscar-worthy drama, but it can still portray realistic characters and a sensible story arc. No Hard Feelings (2023) is in many respects a rip-off of The Big Bang Theory (2007-2019), but the latter portrays nerd culture much more deftly, showing sympathy both for the nerds and for more socially adept people who live with them. No Hard Feelings (2023) had an opportunity to portray micromanaged, overly-protected Gen Zers and their difficulties leaving the nest. Instead it portrays a dweeb born with a silver spoon who squanders opportunities. The characters are reduced to tokens in contrived situations. Kaley Cuoco found a rich character to portray in The Big Bang Theory (2007-2019). Unfortunately, No Hard Feelings (2023) is not a similar opportunity for Jennifer Lawrence.

Review-Title: Movie is way underrated. Very cute and well worth watching
Review-Description: Jennifer Lawrence is great as the female lead. Her acting talent is really on display. She makes the movie believable. Based on what happens to hot destinations: Raise the property taxes so the people living there can't afford to live there and have to sell to the rich people moving in. Mathew Broderick is great as the boys father. Very understated performance. He and the woman playing his wife do a great job as helicopter parents. A lot of very funny scenes showing the generation gap between someone 30+ and kids 18 or 19. Excellent dialog, good pace, and a cute script. For entertainment value at least an 8.

This is not a real review, it should be understood more as a collection of impressions on the film. As a film it has a fairly banal plot but developed in such a way as to be very funny and above all very sweet. I recognize that this film is not a masterpiece but we must recognize its value as a romantic comedy where friendship reigns supreme and where the moral, even if classic, is developed in a very beautiful way. So it must be said that this film is a beautiful comedy developed in such a sweet way that it is truly capable of captivating the viewer at any moment, managing to never let the viewer detach from the screen.

Review-Title: Finally! A funny comedy, it's been, like YEARS!
Review-Description: I'd heard about the nudity in No Hard Feelings before I heard about the actual movie, so I wasn't necessarily expecting a laugh out loud comedy as I assumed the nudity was the actual selling feature. I was wrong. In this day & age, sex & nudity isn't hard to access but good comedy is definitely rare. I'm definitely at the age (57) where I really just want to be entertained and laugh. After I saw the trailer, my expectations grew; Jennifer Lawrence IS naturally funny and quick witted in real life (from the interviews I've seen) and she definitely has developed strong comedy chops. Needless to say they are on full display in No Hard Feelings and I'd hope to see her do more films like this. Lawrence paired with Aubrey Plaza, Melissa McCarthy, Kristin Wiig, Tina Fey etc would be dynamite, as long as Fey & co wrote the script. The farfetched premise, rich helicopter parents want to hire a girl to turn their shy, nerdy introverted son into a "man" so he can gain some confidence before college, is as outlandish & somewhat predictable as it is thin, but this isn't a documentary so just go with it. At this stage of her career, Lawrence certainly doesn't have to do nudity but she does it on her terms and it's classic. Not going to spoil it. Andrew Barth Feldman who plays the hapless & love lost Percy is the perfect stooge against Lawrence's cougar-esque Maddie. Percy's dad, Laird, played by Matthew Broderick, & Laura Benanti as Allison, Percy's mom, are a tad one dimensional but they're there to provide the premise with the macguffin being a used Buick, but it works. Former SNL's Kyle Mooney's cameo provides a lot of chuckles and he certainly left me wanting more. The comedy heavily relies on Lawrence trying to be sexy but coming off way too strong. That's not to say Lawrence isn't sexy, of course she is, but it's how that level of female sexual aggressiveness just doesn't land with the Minecraft & Fortnite generation, no matter how many Rule 34 videos they've watched based on their favourite animated shows. They're woefully under prepared for that level of hotness...and therefore hilarity ensues. And it actually does! The plot attempts to give the characters more emotional depth by revealing their backstory's which succeeds to a degree. It's not entirely heavy-handed thank goodness which could have thrown the balance if the movie off. There's laughs and heart to bring the story to its completion and I'm not going to lie, I felt a post-credit scene set in the future would have been nice. All in all, a nice surprise and from what I can remember one of the best comedy's in recent memory. Come for the nudity, stay for the laughs!

I found this movie ok. Typically I watch Action, Thrillers, that type of stuff but don't mind a rom-com once in a while. However, from the rom-coms I've seen, this comes in at the bottom tier. The storyline did have a potential of coming out better than it did but the casting other than JLaw was atrocious. JLaw did play a semi-decent role in this movie. The movie seemed rushed at times and some of the scenes seemed very dull. I feel like there wasn't a good enough steady tone throughout the movie and just felt bland at times. In my opinion, the attempt of a raunchy comedy with a heartfelt story just did not work out here.

Review-Title: "I'm Not Touching You" A 'No Hard Feelings' Review
Review-Description: We all remember the obnoxious little thing we did with our siblings and friends as kids. The thing that happened just as some game ended with someone being upset about something- just before a parent got called. The victim of childish misdeeds would ask to not be touched but in an attempt to save face and rebel against being reprimanded by a peer, the offender would hover their hand just near enough to be annoying and say, "I'm not touching you." Gene Stupnitsky and John Phillip's "No Hard Feelings" starring Jennifer Lawrence and Andrew Barth Feldman play this game of "I'm not touching you" with sexual impropriety. I dare not use the p-word, lest this becomes an allegation. Nevertheless, despite the chance to see our forever Katniss Everdeen in her most hilarious role since "Don't Look Up" we were made to grimace at all the scenes where our writers and director bring us to the brink of what, in our real world, would be a sexual misconduct case, and then says, "I'm not touching you," in that same mischief-ridden way we did as kids before we knew better. As I watched, I fought the temptation to find something on my phone to focus on. I began to obsess about how old the actor who portrayed Percy was in real life because maybe he was a young-in-the-face 30-year-old, and maybe that would make me feel less complicit in the normalization of inappropriate relationships for sporadically laughing. I fought the idea of being that person who couldn't just see something and let it be what it is without turning it into something it wasn- and that's when I realized it. It wasn't me turning it into something it wasn't. It already was that something. In recent years, men in the industry have caught hell (rightfully so) with the Me Too Movement, where their misdeeds caught up to them in staggering numbers of people speaking out about the discomfort and straight-up pain they've been made to feel in their work environments. The one true error in the movement was all of the women who weren't called to the carpet for their crimes because young men are socialized to wear attention from older women as a badge pinned to the sash of their manhood. What I expected from this film was a fresh take on 2006's showdown between Sarah Jessica Parker and Matthew McConaughey in Failure to Launch. What I got was; "let's forcefully deflower an awkward, traumatized teenager. But let's make it be because his parents are asking," so that I'm not touching you. "And then after she fails to sexually assault him properly, he'll start to like her, then it will be consensual," so still, I'm not touching you. "and then let's make sure they never actually do it because that would actually be improper and probably get us canceled" I'm definitely not touching you. "But it's cool if they get naked in his childhood bed with his parents in the other room, then he'll actually attempt to do the deed but it won't count because, in his inexperience, he didn't realize it was just her thigh" haha I'm not touching you! Let's do the thing where we reverse the roles. Had it been a 30+-year-old man and a 19- year-old high school girl, phones would be ringing, think pieces would be written, and everyone behind the project would be proverbially chased by an angry mob. The thing is if I told you the story of 32-year-old Maddie Barker and 19-year-old Percy Becker without the lights, cameras, and the Oscar-winning actress, you'd cringe. Love to the comedic stylings of Jennifer Lawrence but, why does the big screen loosen our scruples?

I don't enjoy Rom-Coms. Generally. I neither enjoy overused tropes, cheap laughs, chlich√©s and generic, forgettable crowd-pleasers. Therefore, I went in with little expectation. Even though the trailer was rather ok. The difference in all of this is made by a single factor:
Jennifer Lawrence's charisma. It's so apparent that she's also producing this movie. And seemed to have a lot of fun doing so. Minus points for the male lead (around the transition of 2nd to 3rd act), not quite fitting score sometimes and the very very clich√©d structure. Apart from that, comedic excellence. I didn't laugh tears. But from the beginning to end, it just made me feel good. The side characters are impeccable. The humour is fresh and neat. But Jennifer Lawrence shines above it all. Bravo to her. Let's hope for more producing/acting credits in the future. I am yet to see her miss a shot.

I can't remember the last time I laughed so hard but also felt so moved by a comedy. I felt like I was right there in Mauntak with Maddie and Percy. Perhaps it's my own encounters with intrusive parents and ex partners that lend a personal touch, making my affection for this film particularly profound. Is it just like a universal experience to naively fall for someone notably older in your hometown before college? Can we make a support group chat? Anyways...Andrew Barth Feldman's character struck a chord with me; his awkward moments were consistently endearing. The film's execution was great, leaving me contemplating a second viewing despite the fact I don't enjoy re-watching movies.

No Hard Feelings is a raunchy rom-com featuring Jennifer Lawrence as Maddie and Andrew Barth Feldman as Percy. The movie is based upon an actual craigslist ad and was turned into a movie. Truly this is the first comedy I have seen in years that made me laugh out loud. I believe it is a nice throwback to yesteryear in regards to classic 80's 90's and early 00's movies. There's a core formula to these types of movies that always makes them work and I just can't seem to ever get tired of. Summary
Maddie is overdue on property taxes and is going to lose the house her mom left her. Her car gets towed and has to think of something. Eventually she comes upon an ad placed by helicopter parents wanting their son to gain "experience" before college.

Unique in that Marni Nixon is credited! She plays Sister Sophia, credited as herself, no less. No need to dub Julie Andrews, who apparently could sing! Who knew! 60 years later and my 5 year old granddaughter already sings along. Definitely the loudest if not the most dulcet tones to be sure. Kind of the definition of a classic. I doubt her grandchildren will be singing along with Hamilton. This and other Roger's and Hammerstein classics define what it means to be a classic musical. While easy to to dismiss as fluff, it is based on a true story set in 1938 on the eve of the Nazis taking over Austria, and has Nazis, betrayal, escapes, life and death situations, hiding behind it's musical scrim. The music and lyrics range from filler to carry the story along, to songs that became American Standards. "Edelweiss" is so well written many assume it is the actual national anthem of Austria. There are several story lines, both young children and their parents can watch the movie and leave the theatre having experienced completely different movies. Several scenes could be stressful for young children, in stark contrast to the movies general lighthearted theme. Each time I watch, a hidden gem reveals itself, worth a 30th or 40th viewing for sure. Note the stage musical and the movie version are not the same, the movie version reorders the original, and eliminates a couple of songs. Though not as extreme as the stage and movie versions of "Chicago" for example. That said I find Robert Wises version to be the superior production. Enjoy!

Review-Title: This is how you do it!
Review-Description:
Quite simply the best, most heart warming musical out ther, (Westside story) a close second, talent, perfect cast, beautiful scenery, perfect choreography, uplifting, absolutely the best film I have ever seen. Julie Andrew's is sublime, her voice is so pure, no need for razzmatazz
, clever film effects, ai inspired score, just real unadulterated talent. Take note all newcomers, write fantastic music, gather a perfect cast, focus on the quality of the story and let magic happen. Julie Andrew's, Marnie Nixon are the voices of happiness, no auto tune, no adjustments required. If you have not seen this film, you have missed a classic.

The movie "The Sound of Music" is one of the uplifting musicals that Hollywood created in the 60s. Similar to "Hello Dolly" and "Mary Poppins", these films did not mirror the political and social upheavals of the era, but rather served as a retreat from reality into the realm of fiction. The musical "West Side Story" stands out as an exception, being the first to portray the Latino community in New York and delve into their political issues. "The Sound of Music" has been subject to criticism for its portrayal of politics. The film's protagonist, Captain von Trapp, resists Nazism, but his opposition is not rooted in its antisemitism, militarism, or authoritarianism. Rather, his primary concern is the threat Nazi Germany poses to Austrian sovereignty. Furthermore, the film has been criticized for its lack of racial diversity.

Actually, there is no need for a long comment at all. From the first second, which has a magnificent entrance to the film, it is a film that has passed into the history of cinema, filled with joy, sometimes sadness, but usually happiness. Andrews, who won acclaim with Mary Poppins, forms a harmonious duo with Plummer, while each of the von Trapp children, who are at the center of the film, are very cute. We see that the magnificent beauty of Salzburg is also crowned as a different character throughout the film. Quality songs that have been expressed musically also attract attention. It never bores a person to listen to it many times. Predictable entry-development-results do not bother at all. In fact, the film shifts to a lot of politics in the last quarter. Let's also remind that it is inspired by real events and characters that have happened. So the von Trapp family is completely real. After watching the movie, those who are curious can do some research. It can be recommended unconditionally to everyone young and old, one of the rare films that can win everyone's liking.

When it comes to timeless classics, few films have left as indelible a mark on the world of cinema as "The Sound of Music." Released in 1965, this musical masterpiece directed by Robert Wise and starring Julie Andrews and Christopher Plummer has enchanted generations with its captivating story, memorable songs, and stunning Austrian landscapes. However, even the most beloved classics can be subject to scrutiny, and in this review, we will explore the notion that "The Sound of Music" could potentially be better, examining its strengths, weaknesses, and the possibilities for revitalizing this cherished cinematic gem. Set against the backdrop of the beautiful Austrian Alps, "The Sound of Music" tells the heartwarming tale of Maria (Julie Andrews), a spirited young nun who is sent to be the governess for the seven von Trapp children, widowed Captain Georg von Trapp (Christopher Plummer)'s offspring. The film is a captivating blend of romance, music, and drama, as Maria's free-spirited nature clashes with the Captain's stern demeanor, while they both grapple with their growing affection for one another amidst the looming threat of the Nazi regime. One of the film's undoubted strengths is its memorable music, composed by Richard Rodgers with lyrics by Oscar Hammerstein II. From the iconic opening number, "The Sound of Music," to the touching "Edelweiss" and the lively "Do-Re-Mi," the soundtrack is a symphony of melodies that have become a part of our cultural fabric. Julie Andrews' soaring soprano voice and the children's harmonious choruses create moments of sheer auditory bliss that are hard to rival. The musical numbers elevate the film and provide it with a timeless quality that continues to draw audiences to this day. The cast of "The Sound of Music" is another asset that has stood the test of time. Julie Andrews is luminous as Maria, exuding warmth and charisma, while Christopher Plummer brings depth and vulnerability to the stoic Captain von Trapp. The chemistry between the two leads is palpable, and their love story remains one of cinema's most enduring romances. The von Trapp children, played by a talented ensemble of young actors, add charm and innocence to the narrative, making their journey from discipline to joy all the more endearing. The film's breathtaking cinematography also deserves acclaim. Robert Wise and his team expertly capture the stunning Austrian landscapes, with sweeping shots of lush green hills, crystal-clear lakes, and majestic mountains. The visuals serve as a visual symphony that complements the musical one, immersing the audience in the story's picturesque world. The contrast between the natural beauty of the surroundings and the encroaching threat of Nazi occupation heightens the film's tension and emotional impact. However, despite its many strengths, "The Sound of Music" is not without its flaws, and it is these areas that warrant a critical reevaluation. First and foremost, the film's pacing can be a bit uneven. While the musical numbers are undoubtedly the film's highlights, the transitions between these musical sequences and the dramatic moments can feel abrupt and disjointed. The film's nearly three-hour runtime occasionally drags, and some scenes could benefit from tighter editing to maintain a more consistent flow. Another aspect that merits reconsideration is the treatment of certain characters. The portrayal of the von Trapp family's housekeeper, Frau Schmidt, and the nuns at the abbey where Maria resides can be seen as somewhat one-dimensional and stereotypical. These characters, while important to the story, are not given the same depth and development as the main characters, leaving them feeling like caricatures rather than fully realized individuals. Furthermore, the film's depiction of the Nazi threat, while undoubtedly a central element of the story, may come across as somewhat sanitized to modern audiences. Given the gravity of the historical context, "The Sound of Music" could have delved deeper into the political and moral complexities of the era. While the film does not shy away from the looming danger, a more nuanced exploration of the characters' choices and dilemmas in the face of Nazism could have added depth to the narrative. In addition, some viewers may find fault with the film's idealized portrayal of the von Trapp family's escape from the Nazis. The daring flight over the mountains is undoubtedly a gripping climax, but it also carries a sense of adventure that borders on the fantastical. A more realistic portrayal of the dangers and challenges faced by those fleeing the Nazi regime could have made the story even more impactful. So, how could "The Sound of Music" be improved? One approach could involve reimagining the film as a limited series, allowing for a more expansive exploration of its characters and historical context. This format would provide the opportunity to delve deeper into the backgrounds and motivations of characters like Captain von Trapp and Maria, as well as to address the broader political landscape of Austria in the late 1930s. A longer format would also allow for a more gradual development of the romance between Maria and the Captain, giving their relationship a more authentic and nuanced feel. It could also provide the space to explore the emotional impact of their choices on the von Trapp children and the other characters in the story. In terms of pacing, a series format would alleviate the need to compress the narrative into a three-hour film, allowing for a more natural progression of the story and character arcs. It would also provide an opportunity to delve into the lives and experiences of characters like Frau Schmidt and the nuns, giving them the depth and dimension they deserve. In conclusion, "The Sound of Music" is undeniably a cinematic classic that has earned its place in the hearts of audiences worldwide. Its timeless music, enchanting performances, and stunning visuals continue to captivate new generations. However, a critical reevaluation reveals areas where the film could be improved, particularly in terms of pacing, character development, and historical context. One possible approach to revitalizing this beloved classic is to reimagine it as a limited series, allowing for a more in-depth exploration of its characters and historical backdrop. While "The Sound of Music" may never be perfect in the eyes of every viewer, it remains a testament to the enduring power of storytelling and the magic of cinema.

Straight away it looks great, It has that the bigger the screen the better it will look feel to it. To begin with I found singing Nuns slightly nauseating. Then Julie Andrews starts to look after the Von Trapp family and she basically brainwashes them with singing and somehow brainwashes you. As well as excellent location filming, every shot is perfectly placed. The choreography is also spectacular. Also a great placed Intermission Card (Something that should should be in movies over 150 minutes now) Then it ends with a great mid 60's style escape from the Nazis. I think anyone who tells you they don't like this has not actually watched it from start to finish and are just judging it on the clips.

I know this movie is long, but it's an endless musical nonetheless. What I liked best were the Rodgers and Hammerstein songs. They are amazing, and make the movie what it is. Another reason I like it is Julie Andrews' amazing performance as Maria, a girl who longs for a better life, I think. Maria is beautiful, has a beautiful voice, mixed with nervousness and sadness, all qualities that Andrews brings to her performances. The only film she slightly disappointed was Thoroughly Modern Millie. The choreography is superb, as is the supporting cast, from the likes of Christopher Plummer and co. I can't pick a favorite scene, but who can forget the opening and the "Do ah Dear" sequence? I also thought the kids were sweet and the movie had some clever subplots, like Liesels secret love. 10/10 for a musical, which should be in the top 250. It's number 2 on Greatest Musicals, beating out Grease.

I used to think this movie was enjoyable. Then when I learned about the true story and what the Von Trapp family life was really like, I eventually became devastated. The fact that Maria didn't really love Captain Von Trapp really doesn't sound like her marriage life was any good. Why would it? And the fact that the movie depicts that she was truly in love with him and just in denial about it at first, really is one of the worst lies ever. There's always been so much confusion on dating and marriage, and this is one issue, which I feel, many people don't seem to understand is actually very bad. This deception is very unacceptable!

Review-Title: A Once In A Lifetime Movie
Review-Description:
Superb,superb,superb,Damn I was smiling and bobbing my head all the way and lost all sense of time and place,this has to be one of the greatest movies of all time
A little fact,when they filming the silhouette scene during the ending of the film,the director had to go for the silhouette because Julia Andrews was laughing as the room was making "a raspberry sound"
The subtle expressions and nuanced micro acting of Julia Andrews especially when the baroness was telling her about love and all was perfect,the traditional dancing scene outside with Christopher Vonn trapp,you can see when he turned his back,his expression is that of uncertainty and when she takes his hand,he cracks a smile. The music was catchy and the entire movie was nostalgic and had excellent vibes even for a 58 year old movie
Another fact,most tourists who visit Austria,a majority of them say that this movie inspired them to visit Salzburg
Another fact,during the opening scenes in the mountains,the helicopter filming actually did a drawback wash making Julia Andrews to fall but because the film had already been shot,there was no need for a retake. Never did the studios or the directors think that they will ever be a sensation and we're only preoccupied with getting back their budget for the film,but they grossed more than 33 times the amount they spent in the film. This goes in the list of movies you should watch in your lifetime. I,among thousands,watches this film once in a while and it never gets boring. What a film.

The Sound of Music is really really my comfort movie. A place where I can run to whenever I need some peace of mind. The music, songs, the peaceful scenery of the mountains, dancing, laughing, running around freely, kids. There could never be a movie this goated again. Truly. And not just that, but also meaningful message in it. About kindness, compassion, hope, second chances. One day I really want to visit all the places there is in the movie. Especially the mountain and the abby where Maria sang and the mountain where Von Trapp family walking through. ONCE AGAIN, THE GREATEST MOVIE OF ALL TIME!!

What a well crafted movie. Coppola is perhaps the best female director (out there with Varda) and she was able to portray the relationship dynamic between Elvis and Priscilla in a masterful way both in the script as well as in the directing. The film tells the story that many of us wanted to see and hear for many years and Coppola nailed it. The acting is superb both by Spaeny and Elordi who manage to give life to the characters and make them their own. To me, the only negative aspect is the fact that no actual Elvis records were used and I think they should have fought harder to get them. F.

Priscilla told me.....something......i know this.......elvis knew more.......this country was taken....after ww2 the british should have invaded and made sure treason did not get in for us......not distracted by music groups...lije the beatles....elvis was right and i felt that too.....i miss elvis and the evil we hated. 35 and 66......we worked on things but a baby got in the way....danielle riley.....elvis real daughter....this ngo means non govt organization....treason one, top criminals, hurtful lying criminals....only witnessed ngo purposely breaking couples up around me because i said so cause i was being hurt.....so they did it ....witchcraft in nys....cilla from brooklyn ny...real crimes...real unfairness...not planning on watching the movie until i get a home...criminals plan and take...nys not safe...criminals who have money not taken from them win...

Review-Title: The team did a great job taking us back to the 1960s and 1970s. Even the smallest detail was included such as the makeup brands that Priscilla used.
Review-Description:
IN A NUTSHELL:
The film is based on the book "Elvis and Me" by Priscilla Presley, who also worked as the Executive Producer. It features a teenage Priscilla when she met and fell in love with Elvis. The movie was directed by Sofia Coppola. She also wrote it along with Priscilla Presley and Sandra Harmon. What's interesting is that the Elvis Presley Enterprises declined to approve of the movie and didn't give permission to Sofia Coppola to use any of Elvis' famous songs. Lisa Marie Presley hated the movie and didn't give her approval of it either. She said it made her father look like a manipulative predator. She was going to speak out against it at the movie's release but, sadly, she recently passed away. The movie has already won "Best Film" at the Venice Film Festival. THINGS I LIKED:
Cailee Spaeny does an excellent job playing a young, timid Priscilla who is treated as a possession by Elvis. He keeps her primped just like the little poodle in a cage that is gifted to Priscilla. We see her transform from an almost voiceless girl to a woman who finally learns to stand up for herself. It's amazing how much infidelity she tolerated for so long. Jacob Elordi sounds so much like Elvis Presley! I hadn't seen him or Cailee Spaeny in anything before and thought they both did a great job. Elvis was 10 years older than Priscilla. She was only 5'4" tall, making her 8 inches shorter than Elvis. They were only married for 6 years. Priscilla never remarried. In an interview, she stated that "No one could ever match him."
I appreciated the female perspective of a woman director. It was clever how the crew remade so many album covers, magazine covers, and other material with the face of the new actor playing Elvis. The team did a great job taking us back to the 1960s and 1970s. Even the smallest detail was included such as the makeup brands that Priscilla used. The hair, makeup, and costume teams did a fantastic job. Some of the frames are absolutely gorgeous to look at. THINGS I DIDN'T LIKE:
It's too bad that they weren't able to use Elvis' actual songs in the film. Instead, they used music from Sofia Coppola's husband's band "Phoenix". What kind of a man tells his pregnant wife to leave? Elvis is portrayed as a completely spoiled narcissist. The ending is kind of strange. Priscilla leaves alone...without her daughter? They shared custody after the divorce but the movie made it look like she abandoned their young daughter. Lisa Marie was only 9 years old when Elvis died at the young age of 42. Of course, Elvis isn't alive to defend this portrayal of him, yet we do know that he had many affairs and admitted that he wasn't prepared to be a father and raise a daughter. Some have complained that the film is just a money grab after the success of last year's movie about Elvis Presley. The timing is curious, of course, but more interesting is to see a film from the perspective of the other person in the tumultuous marriage. TIPS FOR PARENTS:
Kids will be very bored. So will some adults. Firearms are shown and used. Some profanity, including 1 F-bomb. Drugs are consumed in many scenes. To see my full review, go to my YouTube channel called Movie Review Mom!

Review-Title: The sad reality of having the world at your feet at a young age
Review-Description: Priscilla is the new Sophia Coppola directed film based on the book Elvis and Me penned by Priscilla Beaulie Presley and Sandra Harmon in 1985. The film is a slow burn that focuses on Priscilla and Elvis's relationship from their first meeting till their eventual divorce. As an Elvis fan one of the big criticisms I've seen of this film is that some people feel it's slanderous towards the Elvis name. I didn't however feel this way, as an Elvis fan I think it's pretty clear that the man was no angel, he had demons and these reared their head more and more as his physical health started to decline. We will never know exactly how much of any of the things you read or watch about Elvis's life actually happened as due to how popular the man was there was so much written about him and a lot of it contradicts each other. Where this film is at it's most unique is that it moves away from focusing on Elvis's career and puts the camera solely on his relationship with Pricilla. Elvis is portrayed by Jacob Elordi who was one of the main stand outs in Saltburn. I've seen a lot of criticism of his performance as Elvis and whilst he doesn't look as much like Elvis as Austin Butler did I think he got the voice down to a tee. Elvis is portrayed here as someone who exercises an immense amount of control over everything in his life. I can certainly understand how a young boy who in a very short period of time went from poverty to becoming the biggest musician on the planet would be in the mindset that the world revolves around him. This in turn has a massive impact on his relationship with Priscilla. When they first met I believe she was 14 years old and the film and Cailee Spaeny's performance do a great job of showing that innocence and showing how that innocence gets corrupted when she falls in love with this huge megastar and suddenly must grow up very quickly. She's thrown into a world that she doesn't fully understand and pays the price when things aren't going well in Elvis's life. Whilst this film is set 60 years ago at a time where gender rolls were adhered too much more strictly some of the physical violence she had to endure is unforgivable. It is however a sad story all around, a story where no one really wins. Priscilla has to leave a relationship with someone she really loves and her daughter ends up growing up having spent very little time with her father which is made even sadder following Lisa Marie Presley's passing in January of last year. You also have to think that if Elvis had also taken more time away from his career to focus on sorting out the problems in his private life that he may still be with us today. Some real food for thought.

One cannot help comparing this movie with
" Elvis" of 2022 which was on the same subject and which was far superior in all aspects. This one is about the gaps in the marital relationship between Elvis and Priscilla and not just about Priscilla alone. It could have been called " Elvis and Priscilla " instead. First the negative aspects. Nothing in the movie looks or sound real not the love or emotions or feelings. The narrative is too laid back, the dialogues are uninspiring and nothing dramatic or interesting really happens most of the time. The casting of Jacob Elordi as Elvis doesn't appear to be the best one. For one he is too tall and awkward in his dialogue delivery. For a singer, it is intriguing that he mumbles his way through most of the time. I wonder why he was directed to perform that way. The other characters are also on a low profile too. There is mention colonel at times. It is difficult to imagine an Elvis movie without his songs and this movie is exactly that.( I understand there were issues relating to permission to use.) What is actually the saving grace is the fairly good direction by Sofia Cuppola and the appealing acting of Cailee Spaeny in the title role. Both ladies have contributed to lift the movie a bit.

Review-Title: A misromance and the influence of Elvis
Review-Description: Sofia Coppola's 'Priscilla' is an artistic, dark romance showing how much power a man can have over a woman and how it can determine the rest of their life. Before going into this film, I believed this to be the story of Priscilla, not so many mentions of Elvis and the majority of the focus being on his wife. I was wrong as I underestimated how much Elvis was a part of Priscilla's life even from the young age of 14. This film goes over the life of Priscilla from the age of 14 where she is invited over to Elvis' house where Elvis immediately takes interest in her. From there, they grow as a couple despite the age gap, the rise of Elvis and Priscilla. Only for the eventually lead to the fall in their relationship. A film about the unknowingness of anyone at a young age, how much power a man can have over a woman if played right, the influence one can have over the other's life. Priscilla's life was Elvis and that speaks for itself. Sofia Coppola did an amazing job with this film when it comes to the post-script production, from the romanticized visuals, to the artificial look of all things making the sets look like a doll house, all go over the person Elvis wanted Priscilla to be even from the very beginning and also what Coppola wanted this film to be... even from the very beginning. But apart from the visuals and sets, Coppola's work with the actors and camera is very smart especially when it comes to the scenes with Elvis and Priscilla as Coppola captures more of what Priscilla is feeling and puts majority of the focus on her to see what her point of view must've looked like. The screenplay lacks. It is very constant throughout the film as not a lot happens other than the casual bipolarity of Elvis representing a break down in their relationship. The movie would've been better if they captured some other features of Priscilla's life like her karate-era or whatever was happening with her karate teacher. But instead the film was made to be very constant as for the sequences and story development. The character development is there though, but it's not hard to achieve the development of Priscilla from who she was at 14 to the grown woman she was with Elvis. The visuals of this film are probably my favorite part as for the doll-house-like sets, the romanticized look on Elvis' and Priscilla's relationship at first, the framing especially with the change in Priscilla as a character, and more. All make the film so much more of what it is and add a lot to the table when it comes to speaking about the film. What these visual do is give the film the at first build up it needs to show the high point in life for Priscilla only to dramatize the fall, which is just one of the things the visuals do. Another being giving the film that certain vibe which many films need and fail to achieve, but for Priscilla it's like it is its own genre. Priscilla definitely deserves a watch and a re-watch as it is that good. Only problem is the screenplay and how boring it was made to be, but the amazing visuals make up for it.

Review-Title: fails to tell what she felt
Review-Description: She is just a teenager, when Elvis entered her life - as young as she was, she must have had hopes, fears and dreams. We learn nothing of those or what else is going on inside of her. She remains the empty piece of paper, the unwritten human being, the entire world assumed she must have been... Unforgivable from a woman's perspective. As other mentioned: the height-difference is off-putting since it's pushing the narrative towards an even bigger difference of power as it might have been in reality, almost scratching the topic of abuse. I'm sure the real Priscilla had dreams and ambitions and was not the flat and willingless object as she's portraited here.

Review-Title: Repeated events, weak Elvis portraying, and great directing
Review-Description:
Rating: 7/10
Format: iPad @ home An adapted screenplay that is beautifully directed by the right director. The film really portrays Priscilla's own point of view from the beginning of meeting Elvis to the collapse of the relationship. However, it is 1h 52m of repeated events. I'm gonna admit it, I'm NOT FULLY convinced of Jacob Elordi as a talented actor. Most of the characters he plays in most of his films and shows are mostly cute and good looking big guys, nothing different each time. Euphoria (2019 - 2025), The Kissing Booth trilogy, and Saltburn (2023). However, his portraying of Elvis in this film is somewhat 'surprisingly' convincing to me. I would say about 60% convincing. But, I felt like having another actor would perhaps made it better for me especially towards the last 52 minutes of the film that is an absolute chaos in my opinion. Cailee Spaeny as Priscilla proved herself as a talented you g actress that must be given more roles and will definitely steal the show like she did in this film. She gave us that jealous, young girl who is in love with the most famous Rock and Roll singer in history. The film unfortunately takes a turn and loses its balance after the firs hour. It feels rushed and the build on that was happening in the first hour was finished terribly. Fast paced dialogues and events that resulted in actors getting out the worst of them due to the weak script and dialogues. I don't have much comments on Sofia Coppola's directing as it was as great as expected. Great representation of the different timelines that we jump to throughout the whole film from production and custom designs and the music score too. At most times we hear romantic songs from the 1960s and 1970s. But, when Priscilla goes through major changes in her relationship with Elvis, the music score shifts to being a modern music score (as if it's very similar to a snythwave) that gives that feeling of being trap and that this relationship will end terribly.

Review-Title: Emotionally Distant, For Better and Worse
Review-Description: Priscilla is an interesting examination of fame and how it takes a toll on stars and their spouses but it falls short in one key area. Because for almost the entire film Sofia Coppola keeps Elvis as a character at a distance. Sometimes this works in the ways it portrays the growing wedge between him and Priscilla but as an audience member it made the character feel lacking for me. The central relationship starts extremely quickly and I never quite felt that the connection Elvis feels with Priscilla was earned. As a result I never really felt like the film got of the real heart of the relationship and I found the portrayal of Elvis to be widely inconsistent and I couldn't quite pin down what Coppola was trying to say about him. Granted I don't know much about Elvis as a person but I don't feel like I should have to do research to better understand a films depiction of a real life figure. I think Cailee Spaeny and Jacob Elordi are great and even if the gradual tension building between them feels like it's missing key scenes they act it out perfectly. I wouldn't say this movie didn't do Priscilla Presley justice but the results did leave me wanting quite a bit. Not a misfire by any means but a film that absolutely falls short of its potential for me.

This movie has to be the worst movie I have ever seen in my life for many reasons. I was somewhat looking forward to it because I am so obsessed with Elvis 2022 probably the biggest fan of it. So I wanted to see this movie to hear Priscilla's side of the story but I was beyond disappointed and honestly offended. First of all, Jacob Elordi as Elvis is a terrible choice.
