However, at the same time, I felt like some of the creative choices were a little too weird and out of place - there for being weird and nothing else. A character fights someone with two dildos seemingly out of nowhere, the everything bagel thing, a man shoves a trophy shaped like a sex toy up his butt, etc. There's just some weird stuff that just is there for the sake of being weird, and it takes me out of the movie. On top of that, what drags this movie down for me is its message. Essentially what this movie comes down to is that, nothing matters in the vast universe, so you can make your life and existence anything you want it to be and that gives it meaning. As a Christian, I don't agree with this: I believe there is a purpose and there is meaning in our lives, and that there's no way to justify morality, good, and kindness apart from God's standard. I believe the message the movie gives across is a little dangerous, as what is good to one person will be evil to another. At the end of the day, this is a well-made movie, and I do think there's a lot of creativity on display. I appreciate directors going out and making something that is completely their vision. However, at the same time, I do think they went overboard with the strangeness of the concept, and I don't agree with the message the movie tries to give off. That all being said, give Raccooconie his own movie. That animatronic raccoon deserved an Oscar.

We're told we mean nothing and are just existing until we fade into black. Was this movie made to take away whatever hope we had? Is it supposed to reveal the deep truth that we mean nothing and we're just supposed to say "ok"? This movie has no deep message, it's just a big lie that you and me are specks in a void of nothing. Does it only take good acting, vfx, and fight scenes to make us believe there's no hope? We're all falling, you can either cry and find the sudden stop or grab the hand reaching out to you and accept It's help. Don't believe the lies you're being told. You matter. Everything Everywhere all at Once.

Review-Title: Cheesy it may be, love is the ultimate answer
Review-Description: I had no way to enjoy watching this overwhelming film and had a headache the first time I watched it. I even had difficulty in sorting the storyline out from tons of information. Though I got key elements from this artwork: nihilism and love. It's much more easier and enjoyable when I quickly went through this film one year later. It's a great application of the multiverse concept originally from quantum physics to Sci-Fi, with welled handed combination of philosophy and hilarious entertainment. This story happened in one day, which reminds me of Ulysses from James Joyce. Loser Evelyn is busy with messy life. The business is facing the brink of failure while taking care of judgmental father in-law and without being aware that weak and stupid husband Waymond wants to get divorced. And rebellious daughter Joy is a lesbian. Technical details don't matter anymore. Let's focus on essential ideas. Every tiny decision creates another branching universe, resulting in infinite multiverse. Look back, she run away with current nerdy husband, breaking with families. If you are pushed beyond limit, your fracturing mind experiences every world every possibility at the same time. What will happen if you know everything is just a random rearrangement, a statistical inevitability, and you are nothing special. Nothing gives you meaning. There is no objective truth anymore, you will be free from any morality and guilty. Because nothing matters. That's how Jobu Tupaki is trapped by nihilism and why builds a Bagel, for eliminating herself. The Bagel without core is the image of darkness in nihilism, no love. When Evelyn gets mind fracturing on the way to save her daughter, she jumps into different universe and experiences different life. It is fun to see such creative and funny different possibilities, cookie/small finger is Kung Fu, Hot dog finger...... She could have been a Kung Fu start, a chef, an artist... It seems her current life is the most worst one who never fulfills goals. However, in fact every life is as same terrible as others. You lose your freedom if you are a star. It's just trade off. It's always ridiculous and terrible. She is attempted to join Jobu Tupaki for disappearing forever. In last minute, she is stopped and convinced by naive husband, who gives the ultimate answer: the only thing to resist nihilism is love. Being kind, that's the key to meaning. With love, every universe is as good as this one. She has the pattern of eye with a pupil is love to cancel nihilism. One ambitious book tried to capture everything in one day. Overall it's a good movie, but I don't like the rock conversation, which is obviously preaching. There will be better ways to present those ideas. It's interesting to discuss why Evelyn and her daughter Joy (people) have different choices when facing nihilism. Is it because Evelyn has experienced love and her daughter not really? Is romantic love the only tool to defeat nihilism? What about families and friendship? Last but not least, the answer is not fully given, how to practice kindness? Why some are so kind and some are not? How big is the role of genetics?

As humanity moves forward towards becoming what Gary Zukav would call multi-sensory beings, we collectively sense that our laboratories and other traditional perceptions of reality
are increasingly outmoded. This movie bravely takes that on, and against all odds, succeeds. What to believe in when our traditional values and science just seem to lead us to trash the planet and ourselves with it? As our heroine moves from one multi-verse reality to another, for a brief moment it appears that the traditional definition of success - fame and fortune - is what winning means, even across multple realities. Then he say to her, in his fancy tux, "I would have loved to run a coin laundry in another life -- with you." And suddenly we are anchored, and we know what it is all for, the confusion and the fighting. As anyone who looks in at a loved one, even an annoying one, at the end of an long exhausting day, we know what its all for. True that! Michelle Yeoh is a bad--ss, the artistry of her discipline is breath-taking. Amazing.

Review-Title: The Matrix Meets Pulp Fiction Meets La La Land.
Review-Description: Have not been this disappointed in a movie in along time . I made myself sit through the whole thing so folks couldn't say I missed something by not seeing it through. I gave it two stars because of the brilliant acting. Otherwise it would have been 1. I actually got the point of the movie and saw what they were trying to do. But it just seemed to be written by teenage boys who grew up watching Kung Fu Movies. The Scenes with the Movie Star and her husband along with the Mom and daughter in the parking towards the end of the movie were outstanding. However the scenes with the butt plugs and the dildo were too much. Childish and silly. And the rocks talking to each other , really? The moment where one of the characters asked if they could just stop fighting really resonated with me. I thought to myself. Yes please. We got the point 30 minutes into the film. All the fighting represented the personal conflict in her life. We don't need another hour of this. I read a review where someone said maybe this is what Tik Tok has done to our brains. Maybe that would explain why anyone would vote this Best Picture Maybe if I were a Kung Fu fan I would ahev enjoyed the movie more. I wanted to see the movie about the Hollywood star . I wanted to see the movie about the Mother and Daughter crying in the parking lot. I didn't want to see hot dog hands and people trying to kill each other every five minutes . Too each his own. I need to watch a real movie to get this out of my brain.

Review-Title: Pulp Fiction Meets Matrix Meets La La Land.
Review-Description: I gave it a second star because the acting was very good. Other than that the movie is close to being my least favorite movie ever. It makes me sad to think people thinks this is brilliant. I actually got the premise of the movie but it made me think of how teenage boys see the world. The Kung Fu fighting became monotonous and boring. I got that it represented the personal conflict in her real life. The scenes toward the end where they argued and shared and cried showed that. But sitting through two rocks talking to each other and the butt plug scene were just too much. I made myself sit through the whole thing so people who like this film couldn't say that I would have liked it if I had seen the whole thing. If I had watched it in the theater I probably would have walked out at the butt plug scene. I know people think this is incredibly creative but again it was just silly and childish. I am sure if I were a fan of Kung Fu movies I might have appreciated the movie more. But still that scene and the dildo scene just made me think that adolescents had written the movie. No offense to adolescents. The line where one of the main characters said can we please stop fighting resonated with me. I thought to myself yes please stop fighting. We got the point after the first 30 minutes of fighting. The scenes with the movie star and her husband and the mother and daughter in the parking lot were brilliant. So much of the rest of the movie was just insulting and childish. I struggled through this more out of curiosity than anything else. Now I need to watch something else to try and forget how annoying and disappointing this movie was for me.

I am a Christopher Nolan fan by heart, though at the time of watching this film, I had only known of his work with respect to the 'Dark Knight' franchise. But after years of everyone around me telling me that 'Interstellar' is Nolan's masterpiece, I finally gave in. I will admit that the film does not leap out of the gates with intriguing premises, but it is instead a slow-rolling boulder of film that by the end has your jaw hanging as you attempt to wrap your mind around these concepts. I still could not tell you exactly what happens, but this film transcends scientific understanding and instead lets the decisions characters make speak for themselves. A true Nolan twist.

Review-Title: Hands down, best film ever created.
Review-Description: Almost a decade later, I still frequently come back to fragments of the film. Especially the soundtrack, to find inspiration, to broaden my mind and understanding of things, to fuel my passion for learning when I study, to just appreciate the beauty of the universe and everything in it and of course, the beauty of film making. I appreciate every intricate piece of detail and latent content hidden and showcased in this film. From the ticking on Miller's planet to Brand and Copper's conversation about love, and how it traces back to Cooper and Grandpa's conversation on Earth. The film is not only about the wonders of science, the general relativity of space time or the existence of 5 dimensional beings or higher life forms referred to as 'they' but also about love, dreams, passion, gratification, achieving greatness, emotions and human connection at its very core. Like Brand mentions Love is the only thing we can perceive that transcends space time, a mysterious source of energy, a phenomenon we cannot understand but only feel, something that drives us to surpass our limits, the film depicts that incredibly well. Cooper leaves for space out of passion not purely for humanity's sake, Murph comes back to search for the truth only out of her love for her father, Brand travels to Edmund's planet purely out of love. The space is the canvas and love is the paint, and Nolan and his crew has painted a marvelous piece of artwork. One of my biggest regrets is not watching this film at the the theaters when it first came out. I was too little then.

Review-Title: Interstellar: Nolan's Cosmic Odyssey Earns an 8/10 for Visual Spectacle, Emotional Depth, and a Journey Beyond the Stars.
Review-Description: Interstellar, a solid 8, man! Christopher Nolan's space odyssey is mind-bending with those epic visuals and a killer soundtrack. Matthew McConaughey's journey through space and time is like a cosmic rollercoaster that keeps you on the edge of your seat. The science stuff might get a bit complicated, but who cares when you've got black holes, time dilation, and those heart-wrenching moments? The emotional punches hit you harder than a gravitational pull. The whole survival-of-humanity thing mixed with family drama adds a layer of intensity that's both thrilling and tear-jerking. And that soundtrack? Hans Zimmer nails it, making every scene feel like an epic space opera. Sure, it's not a flawless 10 because some parts might be a tad confusing, but that's the Nolan touch. 'Interstellar' is like a trip through the cosmos that leaves you questioning the universe and your existence. An 8/10 because, despite its complexities, it's a space epic that captures the awe of the unknown and the power of human determination - a must-watch for anyone with a love for the stars.

What a cracker! So glad to finally tick 'Interstellar' off my theoretical list, took me far too long to get around to it but boy am I glad I finally have done - sensational film! The most obvious sign of that being the case is how the ~2hr30min run time goes by in an absolute flash... insert joke about it like being aboard Endurance here I'm obviously not able to add anything new to what many, many others have already said gushingly about this 2014 flick, so I can only say I'm sure I agree with the vast majority of whatever praise this has received. As one would expect from Christopher Nolan & Co., it's incredibly well made, sounds amazing and looks out-of-this-world (ha!) stunning. Matthew McConaughey puts in an incredible performance as lead, most notably nailing all of the emotion-filled scenes - not that I care about these things personally, but I'm shocked to see the lack of high accolades that came his way from this... he merited more! Aside from him, there are very good showings from the likes of Jessica Chastain, Mackenzie Foy and Anne Hathaway. I will note one 'but', mind. I didn't love the bits at the end involving the dimensional tesseract, don't get me wrong at all it's still superb viewing... just a noticeable drop from all that preceeds it, which honestly simply says more about how outstanding everything else prior is really. I thought similarly about (the equally magnificent) 'Everything Everywhere All at Once', for example. In short: just a nit-pick, tbh. All in all, phenomenal!

This film is another of an increasing number of films with so many 10 out of 10 reviews, that I am left incredulous when I finally get to see it. It's great to look at, once we get into space, and the story is interesting but it's also too long, the sound is dreadful (whisper whisper whisper, murmur mumble murmur, LOUD LOUD LOUD!) and the script writing is at times so Scooby Doo that it becomes a cringe to watch. There are also too few characters, such that some seem over used, in roles which would be better split, were the script to remain plausible. And overall, it's the script that is poor, not the story. I was so disappointed. Apart from the visuals, this film is nowhere near being one of the best, and the best of this genre remains 2001: A Space Odyssey.

I've watched this film over 20 times, 10/10 acting 10/10 soundtrack 10/10 casting 10/10 filming. Makes you think hard about what's out there. Easily my favourite film of all time, Christopher Nolan did an amazing job of directing it and the cast did an incredible amount of work by the looks of it. I would recommend it to anyone looking for a complex and engaging movie and to anyone who is interested in science and space exploration. It is great for all ages but i did need to watch it a few times to fully understand it. The soundtrack is a big part of this film and was composed perfectly not only adding suspense and also has a signature sound to it. Overall i think this film was incredible 10/10.

Had a hard time on starting this movie for some reasons but once i was hooked i could not get my eyes off of the movie despite of how sleepy i was because admit it, the movie was so lengthy and it had some maybe dull moments but not really boring maybe this is just me but pace was slow which is not up to my preferences. However a good movie still because visuals overall, so spectacular i would love to see this on a big screen. All that science stuff, confusing that's when i was sleepy my braincells weren't ready for this movie. But i still loved it! There's just a lot to it plus the emotions were so greatly portrayed it was moving and the ending? I loved it so much. I would rate this higher if i were smarter and was able to understand the sci-fi things going on but that's totally on me and not the movie.

If you have any idea how physics works and how space work, most of this movie is pretty hard to believe. I understand movies like Star Wars, which are set in the future, and where the premise is that you have to suspend all of your knowledge about how science works to enjoy the movie. But this movie was set near present day, and the premise of the movie was different than other movies like Star Wars Flying in and out of black holes and flying through wormholes was just a bit too hard for me to get my arms around so that kind of ruined the whole movie. I also found it a little bit too overdramatic.

Christopher Nolan's "Interstellar" is a cinematic masterpiece that delivers a heart-touching, enthusiastic, and mind-blowing IMAX experience. With breathtaking visuals and a gripping storyline, it explores the boundless dimensions of space, evoking deep emotions while challenging the intellect. Nolan's direction, coupled with Hans Zimmer's mesmerizing score, creates a symphony of sensations that lingers long after the credits roll. A journey beyond the stars, "Interstellar" is an immersive exploration of love, time, and the uncharted mysteries of the universe, leaving audiences awe-inspired in its wake.

The positives: It's beautifully photographed and the depiction of the wormhole is spectacular. Performances are delivered with conviction - Anne Hathaway and Jessica Chastain are particularly effective. The negatives: It's very long - not necessarily a problem - but if you make a 3 hour movie it has to sustain interest (and in this case tension) for that period, which, unfortunately, it doesn't. 2 hours in, I really didn't care if mankind survived. Not helped by Mathew McConaughey's slow, mumbled delivery. I guess he was going for intensity, but it doesn't come across that way. The absurdity: The robots are ridiculous - like something out of a 60s Sci-fi serial. The idea that a more advanced society would create something like that is just plain ludicrous. And the depiction of the inside of a black hole and how it helps solve the puzzle is unbelievable in the extreme. To me, it seems like Nolan had no idea how to solve the dilemma he had set. Sure, it's Sci-fi, but unless it's done for comic effect, it still needs at least a veneer of plausibility. But not here. One of those films that has an over-inflated rating and reputation, which may well be revised by posterity.

This film continues to maintain the essence of Guardians, for example the humor, the music, its objective of the non-blood family bond. This film covers the theme of ties, of the family, with a great environmental message, representing it in a real way. It is also a criticism of those who go against diversity. It gives a good closure to the trilogy but leaves the door open for the story to continue. It is a film where one laughs and cries. It really is one of the best late-stage marvel movies, with better effect than others. This movie really makes you make a connection with its characters, we feel their emotions, I like that they told us more about Rocket's story.

There is no God. That's why I stepped in." I have to admit, this is one of THE best lines ever spoken by a supervillain - it concisely captures their whole reason for being. (Seems like that would have been a perfect thing for Thanos to say.) Oddly though, for once there's no real backstory for the High Evolutionary, as there usually is for Marvel villains, but that might have been just too much material. Quite appropriately, all the attention is really on our scruffy, argumentative, and lovable heros, the Guardians. I liked that all of them, this time around, get their well deserved fair share of screen time, and if doing that means sitting through a pretty long movie, then fine. Mantis and Nebula in particular are better characters than they were before, Quill and Gamora and Drax are as good as ever, and the choice to make Rocket and his very extended backstory the mainspring of the plot was clever -- and by the end, it carried real weight. Rocket is now elevated to a tragic, substantial figure at practically the same level as Spider-Man, and that's saying a lot. The whole Guardians series owes director James Gunn bigtime, and it's a shame to see him move on (but I'm looking forward to seeing what he'll be able to do over at DC). He set in motion a group of characters that really worked, and this 3rd instalment builds very effectively on top of its predecessors. Going in to the theater I knew what I expected out of them, but we got more than that. That's a big compliment. At the same time, what was done with Warlock and High Evolutionary was kind of odd, in the end. I was disappointed that Warlock especially was kind of trivialized. He's capable of becoming a major character if they would just follow the path set out in the original comics. That one criticism aside, this is still one of the MCU's best and we can thank them for letting James Gunn do what he had in mind. At the same time, what was done with Warlock and High Evolutionary was kind of odd, in the end. I was disappointed that Warlock especially was kind of trivialized. He's capable of becoming a major character if they would just follow the path set out in the original comics. That one criticism aside, this is still one of the MCU's best and we can thank them for letting James Gunn do what he had
At the same time, what was done with Warlock and High Evolutionary was kind of odd, in the end. I was disappointed that Warlock especially was kind of trivialized. He's capable of becoming a major character if they would just follow the path set out in the original comics. That one criticism aside, this is still one of the MCU's best and we can thank them for letting James Gunn do what he had in mind.

Guardians of the Galaxy Vol. 3 blasts off with laughter, tears, and cosmic chaos! Buckle up for Gunn's emotional farewell filled with Rocket's poignant journey, Drax and Mantis's hilarious bromance, killer tunes, breathtaking visuals, and Guardians banter sharper than ever. This bittersweet love letter to the Misfits is a family story about growth, redemption, and embracing the future. Whether you're a longtime fan or a spacefaring newbie, crank up the tunes and prepare to be blown away. Don't miss this epic mission! Enjoy this movie is you are long standing fan for marvel movies very good....

You have to be either a child or someone who does not understand the depth of our world to enjoy this movie. Mindless brain rot desperately trying to make you feel something. I love marvel I really do. And if you care about these characters I get it. But you've got to take off those rose colored glasses and understand that the billionaires controlling these movies don't care. It's obvious how shallow and insignificant everything they write for these movies is. No more in any marvel movie is there a sense of danger or achievement or anything of that regard. Not so long as the multiverse exists. And this could have been fixed probably if the producers cared enough to address it, which they don't. Shallow, synthetic, and unapologetically pulling your heart strings to distract you from the lack of substance or anything of any meaning. Even the action scenes which previously have distracted the masses from the glaring blandness and dullness are derivative and uniquely boring to watch. No artistic creativity, offers nothing new and is an insult to the comic universe.

Review-Title: What a waste of time and money
Review-Description: Nothing cool or original. Seems as if Gunn did this wasted and for a paycheck. What an awful way to send off a Great franchise. Leaning on all the things that made this arc cool, yet reducing it to a cheap quick payoff. No wonder Marvel is failing and this is a perfect example. What tripe. I felt nothing from this, mote like cheated from the greatness it once was. What an utter disappointment. There was nothing to feel here. Just like this review saying it's too short but, I have nothing more to say for this waste of space wannabe so, I have to write more when I don't want to waste anymore of my time.

Review-Title: Good, but a somewhat distant third
Review-Description: This was a good movie. The scenes with Rocket and his first friends were heart wrenching. The action scenes were amazing. The end result of the movie tied up character arcs for some of them perfectly enough that there story ends with this movie, but it leaves open chances for return for others. Rocket's backstory is well told and interesting. The character growth for a few of then is beautiful. Yet...yet...this movie was underwhelming as a whole. I think it felt a bit rushed and hectic. Yes, the first two had a lot going on as well, but you didn't get the feeling they were a runaway train at any point. This one felt like it was hurtling out of control with no explanation. The plot takes off at 100 mph and never slows down, but parts if it also have little to no explanation. This is a good movie, but it doesn't quite have the charm, plot, or music of the first two. I would 100% pay for a fourth and beyond and will certainly miss The Guardians as currently constructed inside the MCU.

Review-Title: Like talking to a bigoted grandparent...
Review-Description: ...this film is emotionally exhausting and utterly unsatisfying. The characters, flattened into two-dimensional self-parodies, are permitted one of two emotional states: mawkish sentimentality, or incongruous fury. Flipping between these extreme emotions from scene to scene - and sometimes within a scene - the cast spends the entire film either weeping or yelling at each other. With no dynamic range, there is little room for story arc, though since the plot can be summarised in five words - 'Rocket's creator wants him back' - perhaps that's no bad thing; and no room at all for character development. The result is so bizarre you'd be forgiven for thinking that James Gunn had wandered off set and let an angry adolescent do the directing.

Review-Title: "We'll all fly away together, one last time, into the forever and beautiful sky."
Review-Description: FILM: 8.5/10. Embarking on my rewatch of Guardians of the Galaxy Vol. 3, I'm thrilled to report that this cosmic adventure is nothing short of an absolute blast. Director James Gunn has once again worked his magic, delivering a perfect concoction of heart, humour, and intergalactic action that defines the franchise. From the opening scene to the final credits, the film is a wild ride that never loses momentum. Rocket, voiced by the impeccable Bradley Cooper, takes center stage with a story arc that adds surprising emotional depth to this already beloved character. Gunn explores Rocket's inner struggles, making audiences feel for this CGI raccoon more than some flesh-and-blood beings. Visually, Guardians of the Galaxy Vol. 3 is a spectacle. The cosmic landscapes burst with vibrant colours, immersing the audience in a mesmerizing universe filled with strange creatures and breathtaking locales. The action sequences, whether in space or on solid ground, are a visual feast that effortlessly combines thrilling combat with the trademark humor of the Guardians. The chemistry among the cast remains as potent as ever. The familiar faces - Chris Pratt, Zoe Saldana, Dave Bautista, Vin Diesel, and Karen Gillan - effortlessly slide back into their roles, infusing each character with their unique charm. The introduction of new characters breathes fresh dynamics into the team, enriching the overarching narrative. Guardians of the Galaxy Vol. 3 strikes a perfect balance in storytelling, seamlessly blending lighthearted comedy with poignant character development. Themes of family, redemption, and sacrifice are expertly woven into a narrative that keeps you engaged and emotionally invested. While some may find certain sequences, particularly those involving Rocket, a tad gratuitous given Marvel's family-friendly approach, the film remains a gripping and impactful experience. So, strap in, hold on tight, and enjoy this final interstellar joyride with the Guardians that hits all the right notes. FORMAT: 4K Ultra HD Blu-ray VIDEO: 10/10. Native 4K presentation, Detail level: Excellent, Colour reproduction: Excellent, Level accuracy: Excellent, Encode: Excellent, Master condition: Excellent AUDIO: 10/10. Dolby Atmos audio, Dialogue reproduction: Excellent, Soundtrack & effects clarity: Excellent, Dynamics: Excellent, Surround sound presentation: Excellent, LFE content: Excellent MOOFIEMETER: 9/10.

Review-Title: One of the best films of the new phase for Marvel.
Review-Description: Guardians Vol. 3 delivers what many newer Marvel movies have been lacking of late. Granted, we are presented with characters which we have grown to love so that puts this film at an advantage. However, the most recent installment added to character's depth and continued on storylines created in the previous phase. For this reason, Guardians Vol. 3 stands as one of Marvel's better films. The most striking thing to me is the emotion and feeling the animators and Bradley Cooper were able to bring to a CGI character like Rocket. Honestly one of the more moving performances I've ever seen from voice acting and animation alone. The film left me satisfied as a conclusion to this three-part story. As usual with this franchise, the soundtrack was phenomenal. The comedic performances and the action sequences were all on par with the previous films as well. Some newer characters (Adam Warlock) felt underwhelming but this didn't take away from the overall story. In fact, I loved Poulter's performance and found it quite funny, but the character himself felt unnecessary in the overall story. The villain, The High Evolutionary, played by Chukwudi Iwuji, was one of my favorite villains in the MCU to date. Overall, this film should be a delight to anyone who has grown to love the Guardians franchise. If you're not into the MCU films then this probably won't change your view. Otherwise, you will be happy to see the familiar faces and a film that lives up to the high bar that Marvel has set for itself, something a lot of the newer films have failed to do.

Review-Title: Fast and fun or dark and serious? A confused movie
Review-Description: What distinguishes this movie from the previous two is that it has a darker side to it, relating to Rocket's backstory. This is at the same time the movie's strength and weakness. This story can get in your feels at moments, but on the other hand the reasons for why things happen remain in shadows. The psychology behind the Bad Guy's actions is not a point of focus. And that doesn't make him mysterious. It makes him shallow and uninteresting: The only thing he seems to be capable of is being angry. You could say, just sit and watch the wild ride and enjoy. But the action itself is somewhat generic and the story rather straightforward. And this time the music and the jokes do not bring this movie to a higher level. The music sometimes felt out of place. The jokes were crammed in because a certain number of jokes had to be in the movie, or so I guess. For a two and a half hour movie the story is simply not well developed enough to the point of being superficial. The interaction between the characters, the dialogue, it wasn't fresh. It didn't sparkle. More of the same. And what about those captive children? That looked so eery. And yet, it added virtually nothing to the story, because nothing was done with this fact. So you see the dark backstory gets flushed out by all the action scenes, making it almost a bit childish. The emotional moments were only there for effect.... No, this is not Star Wars where a perfect balance between fun & serious and dark & light was created. It's not a bad movie though. The visuals are outstanding, There's a lot of action. It has its moments. It' the Guardians with a twist, but that twist makes it less funny and entertaining than the previous movies. And it does not compensate for that in depth.

Review-Title: Watching for the second time, I remember...
Review-Description: I enjoyed the movie, but watching for the second time I saw there was one glaring flaw, and I'm not sure if it's the responsibility of the new director for this second film, or the actor. Jennifer Lawrence's over-acting (limited to 2 or 3 significant moments) doesn't maim the movie, but it certainly momentarily breaks the spell. First, as Katniss ascends the tube to the arena, Once (more than once?) when she's in the arena, and once more in the last couple of minutes of the film. We had the same kind of crazed in the latter seasons of Handmaid's Tale; one presumes the directors didn't have a robust imagination for alternatives than "crazed expression #24". It's as if the characters, contrary to most reasonable people I think, actually hadn't reached the point of not being surprised by anything that might occur, in spite of all that has occurred to date. Otherwise, a very good film, well done all-around.

I think this movie offers it all. That may seem strange as I have only rated a 7 but in truth I'm not sure what I would've wanted, it might just be the fact that this movie is just another part of the story that it can't deliver everything. In my opinion it is much better than the first movie as my only real complaint from that one was that the hunger games action didn't really start until the last hour. Although this film had a similar set up, I found the build up to the return to the games was much more interesting and set up a brilliant and thrilling game. This film is clearly a major set up for a larger story but I am looking forward to watching more!

An enormous step up in storytelling & filmmaking. Frustratingly bleak & hopeless with great set design. Intense, mysterious, & emotional as the plot plays out. New cast is impossible not to love. .
. .
An enormous step up in storytelling & filmmaking. Frustratingly bleak & hopeless with great set design. Intense, mysterious, & emotional as the plot plays out. New cast is impossible not to love. .
. .
An enormous step up in storytelling & filmmaking. Frustratingly bleak & hopeless with great set design. Intense, mysterious, & emotional as the plot plays out. New cast is impossible not to love.

Review-Title: Much Faster, More Visceral, and More Intriguing
Review-Description:
The First Hunger Games film did something special. It told a compelling Dystopian type story. This film took the best elements from the first film and REALLY expanded upon them. The first film introduced the idea of the games to us, but this film gave us the argument and philosophy of why the games existed in the first place. This film also did a great job with expanding the world of Panem and it's character storytelling. As far as character moments go, there were alot of great moments from both Jennifer Lawrence and Josh Hutcherson. Both of them struggling with life after the Games, and how they deal with the
savagery they've witnessed while going through another round of even more savagery in this film. Both are at there peak in this film and continue to shine and grow. Shoutout to Donald Sutherland though. We definitly get to spend more time with him in this film and we really get to see more of what drives him to do what he does, and we get to see some really awesome moments between his character President Snow, and Katniss Everdeen. The imagery and cinematography I believe have really stepped up since the last movie. There were some really beautiful shots. And the music is even more of a standout in this one. Other than that, like I said before, the action is a lot more savage than previous, and definitely more faster paced in my opinion. The Choreography and the action scenes were done really well. I know people say that this film may be the best film in The Hunger Games franchise, but in my opinion, both the 1st and 2nd could be potentially tied for first in my mind. You can't g owrong with either.

My biggest problem with the first film was its low production value look. Holy Blazes! Does this film absolutely crush it in terms of production value. Amazing effects. Fantastic sets. Great color and camera work. Did you know they used handheld imax cameras for this film? Absolutely fantastic! This movie is a visual feast. The hunger games team was obviouslyt alloted a fat ton of money! I mean come on! They won over Philip Seymour Hoffman, the absolute legend, what a great actor. He kills it in this film, and casts a great menacing shadow on this film. This film carries the same (if not more powerful) emotional levity that the first film has. Great story. Great characters. AMAZING SCORE. By gosh, James Newton Howard absolutely crushed this series film score. Some of his best work. A part of me wants to give this film a 9, its just so well done. These films continue to depict the struggle of Tyranny Order, Chaos, Revolution and Anarchy in a profound real way. I better walk away before i give this film a 9...

The first Hunger Games had some good ideas going for, and some things that made it stand out from typical young adult fantasy adventures, and it was an overall decent feature. This sequel, however, is vastly superior, and could be likened to The Empire Strikes Back to the original Star Wars. Not in quality, perhaps - but it does follow up on the original formula and turns it on its head, developing its characters in a more complex light, and is all around darker and higher on the stakes. The actors have really grown into their roles more, and Jennifer Lawrence in particular is stellar as a strong heroine. The effects and action set pices are also far superior in this compared to the original film. Overall, great sequel that elevates and already interestin formula in spectacular ways!

Review-Title: This one stands above the others.
Review-Description: Fearing an uprising over Katniss and Peeta's success at The Hunger Games, he changed the rules for the upcoming 75th games, the pair are right back inside the deadly games, only this time, the competition is much tougher. With the release of the new film just around the corner, I wanted to revisit them all, my feelings haven't changed, I still think that this is the best of the lot so far, I think it's better than the original film. I think it's a little slow to start, the impression you get early on is that it's an in depth look at life for Katniss and Peeta after the games, but when the twist comes, the film really does open up. It's not overlong, I'm glad they didn't push it out any further. There are some exciting sequences, these games really do provide a few thrills. Jennifer Lawrence is excellent as Katniss, her performance for me is superior to her previous one, she's excellent, as are Philip Seymour Hoffman and Donald Sutherland. Toby Jones, still doesn't work for me here. Best of the lot for me. 8/10.

Review-Title: Amazing film best hunger games movie
Review-Description: This movie was amazing and made the series more entertaining. The first movie of course it was good but it was a little boring compared to this one. This movie introduces many new characters enhancing the plot. The main characters have to get tangled up with characters such as Finnick and Johanna. They make the plot way more intresting, especially with Finnicks personality and how he interacts with Katniss and Peeta. This movie also builds up extremely well to the point of the next movie, mockingjay part 1. At first it just makes it seem like they're playing the games like normal and, yes it does start of with that for most of the movie. Then at the end you can see that it was all building up to throwing over the capital when Katniss is picked up semi unconscious by the crane. Amazing film definitely the best out of the movies.

Hunger Games: Catching Fire is the second installment in The Hunger Games franchise, and so far, I'm not so excited. The only reason I watch these movies is to get ready for the upcoming one now in November. But about this one. Well, it was just ok. The plot is taking place just after part one, and things are starting to get out of control when Katniss Everdeen is changing the Hunger Games, and starts to make people mad. After that it goes a while and a new Hunger Games is out once again, with the same characters from part one. So honestly, nothing new was changed, just a new game. You know they are going to survive, because it's too predictable. Some new challenges but didn't impress too much. But I have to admit that part two was better made than the original one. The stunts were creative and well done. Great camera-work and epic angles, what gave this an extra cinematic experience. Entertaining for most time, so I give most points for that. They showed a bigger connection between the friend group in the games, but I wished some more character development form the main characters. I also wished they could show more of the world outside, because they haven't showed it so much yet. And the music. Well, The Hunger Games theme is fun to listen, but not for the thousand time. They could put more variety in the music score. The nostalgic and heroic theme was getting my out of control sometimes. But overall, this wasn't such a bad movie. It got some technical and historical problems that I would change, but at the same time it was very entertaining and good action included, with a pretty cool cliffhanger at the end! So if you liked the first one, then you should watch this one, too, but don't have high expectations.

Review-Title: The Hunger Games: Catching Fire (2013) Changes that improved the franchise
Review-Description: I consider the first film in The Hunger Games franchise to be very mediocre. The steering is one of the points that bothers me the most in the previous one. However, in this second film the screenwriters and director are different. This detail completely changed the quality of the sequel, making it far superior to its predecessor. Even though it's better, it's still nothing incredible and revolutionary. It's a generic film with interesting scenes, but in the end it doesn't become anything memorable. The first act is the most interesting moment and best explores this problematic system in the universe of The Hunger Games. After the first act, we enter again into a dull story that serves as an excuse to become yet another generic action film. There's nothing special about the film, but it manages to be fun at different times.

Review-Title: Theron just can't replace old Mel. Worthington should have left his metal gag on
Review-Description: Awful. More time is spent developing the two dimensional EVIL of the tribe out to do in the lead proxies, then any kind of rationale based on the character or motives of the good guys. Why Worthington has his head imprisoned in a metal jaw, like a post apocolytic Hannibal Lector, is beyond me. No reason suffices. "The dogs bark, but the Caravan continues." Or, "In the desert sun, every step that you take could be the final one And in the burning heat, hanging on the edge of destruction" Could be replaced with "What the F*** and Who cares anyway?" The original Miller production absolutely required a crazed alpha male to center the drama, which was done brilliantly by Gibson in the three movies that were the blueprint for his billions, and Theron is a terrific actress, but she just can't carry this myth. Worthington, even blander then a young Affleck, should have left the gag on the entire movie, and the escalting flash fire brilliance of the first three movies drives right off the cliff with this awful sequel. How did Miller let this happen? Fast money. All that remains is the dust and sand kicked up by the original great movies.

Review-Title: Easily one of the best action movies ever made
Review-Description: The pace that is sustained throughout this movie is insane. It's two hours of nearly endless action. Characters were flawless. One liners and outrageous scenes aplenty. Watched it in the theaters three times. There isn't a whole lot of CGI in this film, which makes the action scenes feel gritty and raw. This translates directly into what one thinks of when it comes to Mad Max. I really love the different colors that are created throughout all the difference scenes. Charlize Theron steals the show and does such a good job. Overall, this one is definitely a movie to own. That's saying something in this day and age.

Great action movie. It really is a strange film. As Max, the craggy but full-lipped Tom Hardy doesn't look anything like Mel Gibson. It is Theron - or possibly Rosie Huntington-Whiteley, playing a sultry breeder called Splendid - who is channelling the eerily beautiful Gibson from 1979, except that probably neither is pretty enough. Fury Road is almost a silent film in it way. Dialogue is at a minimum, and when Max says anything it is usually preceded by an eccentric rumbling, mumbling mmmm sound. He is impassive, to say the least: the nearest Tom Hardy's Mad Max comes to an emotional outburst is when Splendid does something very brave while hanging on to the side of the truck. Rating 9/10.

I have to admit, after hearing positive things, and still a long time lover of Thunderdome, I sat down expecting... something, different, something else. While effects and visuals were seemingly spot on and no one gave a poor performance, I never once felt there was a through line story. The best I could see was a plot device to go from point a to b and then, because that was a wash, to turn around and do it all in reverse. I barely got to know this Max character. The Furiosa and Nux characters seemed to have more development. Color me baffled. If it weren't for the noise, and even sometimes when there was, paying attention to what little there was presented here took some real work.

Review-Title: A true masterpiece of action adventure genre
Review-Description: I don't know why the rating is below 9 . It is an outstanding movie in every aspects, whether it is the story, cinematography, costume design, action, dialogues, music, soundtrack . It will be one of the greatest movie of all time, for me it is a GOAT. I do hereby request all members to watch it, it doesn't matter what genre you would like to watch, but please do try this one. You'll enjoy every bit of the two hours. I am big fan of the dark knight but I'll place dark knight in no 2 position, first is madmax fury road. Today I watched trailer of Furiosia, the prequel to this. I hope will enjoy it on theaters.,coz I missed fury road in theaters.

I've always skipped over this title, until yesterday. WOW!!! This movie is one fun, funny, demented (that's the only word that comes to mind), when I think of the rock guitarist strapped to one of Immortan Joe's rigs in the chasing party. I was mildly taken aback when people were called called the wretched, then I looked up and laughed out loud when I looked up from my typing (Yup THEY ARE wretched). I had a perverse enjoyment seeing how the people upon the mountain lived and had a healthy glow, expressing milk, cultivating greens etc... This lent a movie the sense of the absurd. Witness meeeee! Watch this movie over and over again!

After some 30 years writer director George Miller brilliantly brings back to a new generation of moviegoers his iconic character of Mad Max, which was originally played by Mel Gibson in a breakout performance that made him an international superstar. Miller's new supercharged, visually stunning reboot is a punk-influenced dystopian vision with an angry feminist streak, it is also a non-stop relentless orgy of brutal violence, death, blood, automotive mayhem peppered with collisions and explosions, as well as unforgettable, adrenaline-pumping, kinetic action sequences that puts to shame every action blockbuster in recent memory! The plot concerns the revenge seeking desert nomad Max Rockatansky, played impressively by Tom Hardy who skillfully takes over the role from Gibson and proves to be a worthy successor. Max is roped into helping a one-armed, steely-eyed, badass female protagonist named Furiosa, played magnificently by Charlize Theron in a scene-stealing performance. She has escape with five young women from the clutches of Immortan Joe, a fearsome psychotic warlord who wears a teeth-bar mask, he is chillingly played by Hugh Keays-Byrne who played the sadistic villain "Toecutter" in the 1979 cult-classic original Mad Max. Joe with his army of murderous gonzo warriors and tricked-out vehicles race across the desert, he will stop at nothing to recover his female property and is totally hellbent on stopping them. Masterful direction by Miller, exceptional supporting performances by Nicholas Hoult, Josh Helman, Nathan Joe, Zoe Kravitz, Rosie Gunting-Whiteley, Riley Keough, Abby Lee, Courtney Eaton, but it's Charlize Theron's feminist freedom fighter that surprisingly steals this awesome film. Dazzling cinematography by John Seale, with extraordinary razor-sharp editing by Jason Ballantine and Margaret Sixel. The film has breathtaking stunt work. A cinematic work of jaw-dropping imagination and artistic craftsmanship, a total masterpiece. Nominated for 10 Academy Awards including Best Picture & Best Director: George Miller.

Review-Title: A mentally disturbed Max takes a backseat to a politically correct story amidst top notch production design and action scenes
Review-Description: When I watched "Mad Max: Fury Road" in the theater back in 2015, I was impressed by its production design and action sequences, but felt like everything else left something to be desired when compared to the original three and especially the first two movies. However, when I looked it up again on imdb.com and Wikipedia recently and saw it got overwhelmingly positive reactions, I started thinking maybe the reason I didn't like it as much when I first saw it could be attributed to my having been much younger when I watched the original films for the first time and my disappointment with Mel Gibson's absence, so I decided to see it again with a open mind. Unfortunately, though, I have to conclude that not only do I still feel the same way as I did in 2015, I actually noticed some things this time around that, the more I think about them, even made me start liking it less. "Fury Road" is a post-apocalyptic action movie, first and foremost and the good news is that its production design is absolutely top notch and the action sequences are pretty much as impressive as the ones in the second movie, which set the bar for every other car chase shot on film or digitally ever since. I didn't care for the CGI used in some scenes, but there's very little in "Fury Road" and, to be honest, I prefer the makers use computer generated crashes when possible rather than destroy real classic cars, so I can live with that. This brings me to my first problem with the film, though. In the first two movies, both the good and the bad guys drove extremely cool vehicles that they were completely crazy about: in the original film, Max had his black-on-black Interceptor, Goose his Kawasaki and even the "regular" Police cars looked good enough for car enthusiasts to have been building replicas of them for years. In part 2, the only truly cool looking vehicle driven by the good guys was the Interceptor but, although it eventually did get destroyed, it still had enough screen time to make every teenager who was even remotely interested in cars dream about owning one himself one day. By contrast, the Interceptor is only in "Fury Road" for about a minute when it gets rolled, stolen, converted, used to try to kill Max and eventually crashed by the bad guys and in total it has but a few minutes of screen time. Originally I wanted to watch this film with my stepson, who loved Tom Hardy in Venom and I was hoping it would have the same effect on him as "The Road Warrior" had on me and also get him excited about muscle cars. Having seen it again, though, I'm glad he didn't since he probably wouldn't even be interested in the first two afterwards. Allow me to explain: the original two movies were a car lover's dream to watch and their vehicles were as much characters in them as Max and the others, but in this latest installment, only the bad guys are car fanatics and they are part of some perverse V8 engine and fossil fuel worshipping cult. In fact, with the exception of Max, all of the men are presented as having some sick obsession with cars and seeing women as sex objects to be possessed and do with as they please. In "The Road Warrior" both the people living in the compound and the Humungus' gang consisted of men and women, so there seems to have been equality among the sexes, but in "Fury Road", apparently, only the men are responsible for the sorry state or the world and even revel in it while the women are trying to fix it. You can tell that this film is very much a product of its time: Max actually takes a backseat in his own movie and the real heroes and protagonists are a strong warrior woman, a feminist commune of elderly hippies riding motorcycles (out of necessity, not love, like the Goose, mind you) and a group of pregnant ladies who want to leave their possessive husband because they have come to realize "they are not things." If the movie would have come out half a decade later they'd probably have found a way to include the phrase "me too" in it somewhere. So whereas in the 70s and the 80s the Mad Max movies were a car lover's dream, in these politically correct times the message carried out by "Fury Road" seems to be: cars and their enthusiasts are mentally ill males who in their obsession have brought about the destruction of their bodies and planet, which can only be saved by women and children and the men's only hope at redemption is to help them do so. I read one review here of a fan who seems to dislike everything about "Mad Max Beyond Thunderdome" yet absolutely adored "Fury Road", but it seems strange to me how one can have such a dislike for the tribe of children in that movie, but is completely okay with those pregnant wives of Immortan Joe. At least in the third movie, an effort was made to try and figure out how kids who would have had to grow up in post-apocalyptic isolation with nothing but comic books, some pop culture and old View-Master pictures to learn from would behave, think and speak. Immortan Joe's wives are presented as holding the key to a better future, yet don't seem to have been able to form any deeper thoughts than to come to the conclusion that they don't like being treated as objects. As for Max, in the original movies he was basically an nice guy, who suffers a terrible loss when his wife, kid and, presumably, best friend all die at the hands of the Toecutter's gang after the law fails to take them off the streets, which causes him to decide to take matters into his own hands and take terrible revenge on them. Then a nuclear event takes place between the first two movies and Max, not having been able to get over the loss he suffered in the first movie, has become a loner trying to survive in a wasted world. However, even though he's lost some of his people's skills, he's still an (anti-) hero that as a younger viewer you could look up to, proof of which is how the Feral Kid behaves around him. But in "Fury Road", Max is not mad, as in angry for having his family and best friend taken from him, but as in insane. He's suffered some kind of mental trauma which is never fully explained, leaving him to see and hear things that aren't there and clearly is in need of psychological help, which, for obvious reasons, he's been left deprived of, causing him to hardly be able to function amongst other people. Although Mel Gibson's Max also isn't a hero in the conventional sense of the word, he's basically still an okay guy, who's become somewhat of a social outcast from having been alone for a long time and having had to survive in a very harsh world. He isn't always on his best behavior around other people, but there's nothing really mentally wrong with him and he is still someone you could look up to and as a kid or teenager dream of being like. The same can't be said of Tom Hardy's Max, though, who badly suffers from P. T. S. D. and only barely manages to hold it together. At first I was bummed that Mel Gibson wouldn't play him anymore, but now that I've seen the movie again, I'm actually glad he didn't since this isn't the Max I love and wanted to see more of and if this is how George Miller wants to portray him now, I'm glad it's another actor's job to do so. A different "character" that was not only underused but sadly completely missing is Australia. In the first two movies which took place in the post-apocalyptic world, the breathtakingly beautiful Australian landscapes were just as much a part and character of the films as Max and the others, but this time around I can't blame the makers for their absence. Apparently, it had been raining so much in the areas that the previous two movies were shot at that they wouldn't have been credible as a post-apocalyptic wasteland. I was happy to read the Furiosa prequel has been shot "down under" again, but, unfortunately, there was more Australiana missing from "Fury Road". With the exception of Hugh Keays-Byrne, none of the major characters are Australian and most of the accents used throughout the film are English and American. I commend George Miller for having brought him back to again play the lead villain, though. He does by far the best job of the main characters and, although Immortan Joe lacks the depth, philosophy and, dare I say it, charm of the Toecutter, he's the only actor I felt was able to recapture some of the same feel of the characters in the original films. Charlize Theron does an okay job as a warrior woman, but, in my opinion, falls short of what I think is Virginia Hey's perfect combination of beauty and toughness in "The Road Warrior". All in all, I feel like the Mad Max movies were at their best when they were still domestically produced low-budget Australian films and dealt with basic themes like friendship, love, loss, revenge or simply survival in a wasted world and didn't yet try to become mainstream blockbusters and present family friendly or politically correct values. Like I wrote at the beginning of this review, the action sequences and production design of "Fury Road" are wonderful, but everything else leaves some, or in certain cases even a lot, to be desired.

Review-Title: One of the best action films in the last 20+ years
Review-Description: It's been 8 years since I saw this film in the theaters and I can still vividly remember that overwhelming feeling of visceral euphoria. The film rarely gives you a pause to catch your breath. From beginning to end, it's engaging, breath taking, awe inspiring, and just an absolute feast for the eyes. Story wise, it's pretty straight forward. For a film like this, I don't need some brain twisting scenario to keep me engaged. One thing I really loved was the throw back to traditional FX. All the vehicles were real, all the driving was real, and it just looked so good. It was a travesty it didn't win the Oscar for best VFX. Do yourself a favor, find the biggest screen you can with the loudest sound system and watch this incredible film.

I liked Mad Max fury road very much. As a norwegian, the Norse religion elements were interesting, cool and relatable. The movie had everything except sex scenes, which is a good thing. There was great action, creativity, comedy (not tiresome), great acting, emotions, scenery and music. The bad guys are evil and animated and the goood guys equally well presented. There are twists in the story keeping us surprised, even though the action is almost non stop. Someone thought the Max actor didn't fit the character, but I disagree. I found him believable. Quiet, haunted, doing whatever it takes to survive, but clearly a good guy. Should you watch Mad Max Fury road? I think yes.

The things that I liked were that the cameos were INSANE. I just hope they don't use the whole multiverse storylines for everything though. Ezra Miller actually plays a good Flash. Grant Gustin is still better, though. Well, Ezra apologised. So, I forgive him. Michael Keaton as Batman was good. I liked all of his scenes. General Zod was scary. It's so cool and awesome that Michael Shannon returned to reprise his role. If they recasted him, well, it would make sense, because of Flashpoint, but who else could've played him? Sasha Calle was good as Supergirl. She was pretty awesome in the film, but she's never going to appear, which kind of tragic. George Clooney's cameo was pretty funny, and Barry's reaction was so priceless. His tooth fell out that he glued in earlier on in the movie. The things that I did not like was that that Ben Affleck wasn't credited for the film. The CGI is very weird, and I think that that was the aesthetic that they were going for. I wanted this movie to a 10/10. I wanted it to be my favourite movie of 2023, but the CGI really narrowed it down. The reveal for the villain could have been better. Post credits was kind of random and unnecessary. Not every movie needs a post credit scene. Final Scores:
Plot: 8/10. Pacing: 7/10. Cinematography: 6/10. Cameos: 8/10. Characters: 9/10. Costumes: 8/10. Acting: 9/10. Music: 8/10. Overall: 8/10. I really enjoyed this film. This one's a fresh on Rotten Tomatoes, and I assume it's got a high audience score, then. I don't know, that seems to happen a lot with films on Rotten Tomatoes. Anyway, this film is amazing, and you should watch it.

Review-Title: Even with all the references, "The Flash" rarely excites. The battle scenes have few textures and the action is generic and poorly finished accordingly
Review-Description: The plot begins with a powerful action scene, in which Barry Allen-Flash (Ezra Miller) is called to help the victims of a terrorist attack in a hospital. While the opening sequence already manages to give us the tone of the film, it also serves as an impetus for us to understand Barry's true intentions and the traumas he has carried for a long time - given that his mother was murdered when he was just a child and that the father took the blame and now awaits a trial that doesn't seem to have a happy ending. It is from there that, moved by the brief spark of hope in restoring a family that was torn apart by a poorly explained tragedy, Barry moves through anguish and melancholy to go back in time and prevent his mother from dying. However, what he did not expect is that his benevolent actions would trigger a series of events foreshadowing the implosion of the multiverse. What would you do if you could go back in time is the maxim that governs the feature film directed by Andy Muschietti - and a question that has certainly crossed our minds. After all, we all make mistakes and feel responsible for having acted differently and fixed what was broken. Barry, in this way, discovers that he has an ability to return to the past, breaking fragile rules of space-time to "change events" and ensure the survival of the one he never forgot. Now, it is remarkable how the protagonist is enveloped by a vigilante blindness that makes him forget the butterfly effect - and that takes him on a tortuous journey of reparation and nostalgia. However, no matter how noble his intentions may have been, the plan backfires and he opens a timeline parallel to the one he belongs to, creating a perpendicular rift in the multiverse that predicts catastrophe. For those who watched the trailers and promotional teasers for The Flash, you will probably have few surprises throughout the 140 minutes of the feature film directed by Argentinean Andy Muschietti. From the main special appearances to the apotheotic moments, almost everything had been revealed by Warner-DC's marketing department in the advertising pieces. Which, let's face it, takes a lot of the fun and emotional impact out of scenes like Batman (Michael Keaton) saying his iconic line "I am Batman". Surprising moments are really rare, usually references to other incarnations of the publisher's main superheroes in cinema and television. The plot itself shows Barry surprising himself with his ability to navigate between temporal plots and landing in the past to try to change his lonely present of orphanhood (dead mother and imprisoned father). When going back in time, he comes across his 18-year-old version, still without the powers brought by an unlikely combination of chemical elements and lightning fallen from the sky. However, the protagonist did not imagine that this world would be different from his own in certain ways, with several variants and few familiar constants. Batman is a different person, Superman Kal-el has a different destiny, but Zod (Michael Shannon) continues to come to Earth to conquer it and revive his home, Krypton. The Barry of the past is the hero who is reluctant when faced with the call to adventure, but who proves his worth along the journey of maturity. The Barry of the present is the mentor who guides his younger version to learn, thereby demonstrating the ability to be more than Batman's boy wonder - the same dramatic curve as Peter Parker, who proved to be more than Batman's boy wonder of Iron Man. Absolutely everything revolves around these parallel and complementary journeys of the Barrys, but that doesn't make The Flash a serious film about feelings, traumas and adult sensations. In addition to personal controversies, Ezra Miller had proven in other works to be an actor with repertoire, something that in this new super production is only partially valued. An irritating and loud teenager, the Barry of the past gains space and constantly supplants the seriousness of the Barry of the present, who carries the character's tragic tones. Andy Muschietti chooses to give more time and importance to the comic content, thereby sabotaging items such as: the hero's sadness aspects, the obsolescence of Michael Keaton's Batman and the strong personality of Supergirl (Sasha Calle). No wonder, Batman and Supergirl are demoted to mere occasional colleagues. Batman is still valued for its nostalgic aspect, but Krypton's daughter is compromised by the suffocation of drama. In addition to this issue, the film is tonally very strange, with an initial sequence of frantic action in Gotham City that serves to make it very clear that the Flash in this film is the Flash from Justice League, complete with Jeremy Irons' Alfred and the Ben Affleck's Batman (albeit wearing an absolutely hideous version of his costume). At the beginning, the tone is openly comical, with Ezra Miller reveling in his dramatic limitations as a court jester, with the beating itself taking on a veneer that was supposed to be hilarious, but which ends up only generating yellow smiles due to the exaggeration of the whole thing, including a newborn rescue sequence in a hospital featuring horrific visual effects of these babies. Then, in the other universe, the footprint is opposite, darker and heavier, but also more rushed and without Muschietti, at any point, really having the courage to bet his chips on it, which leaves room for inconveniences of displaced humor that they detract from the whole and deflate the drama, especially because the development of the two Barry Allens, especially the youngest, is relegated to the background and then, almost instantly, is accelerated from 0 to 100 without giving time. Another problem that weighs heavily on "The Flash", especially in the final third of the projection, is the visual effects. And it's not just a standard complaint about hero films: the thing is bad even by the low standards that Marvel has been presenting lately. The opening sequence, with Flash saving falling babies, is terrible on a PlayStation 2 level and there are several racing scenes that all feel artificial and weightless. And it's something that really hinders the experience, as it takes away the impact of key moments. There are special appearances that are made entirely (and without purpose in certain cases) in CGI that look like rubber and wax dolls with which it is impossible to create any connection. What should be nerd apotheosis becomes just something shameful. Luckily for fans and spectators, Muschietti manages to balance the poverty of the effects with a firm pulse on the progress of the story. In the end, it is thanks to his direction that "The Flash" manages to deliver something that DC has never managed before: uncompromised and unpretentious fun. The rest of the film, especially its final minutes once again in the chronosphere, is a search for references and fan service that irritatingly has become the standard for blockbusters of the genre. Out the window goes the story, which is then summarily replaced by the absolute and inescapable emptiness that are the moments that exist only for the viewer to point at the screen and identify this or that character and object more quickly than their friend next door. The cinematic experience, therefore, becomes an uninspired child's game that requires nothing from anyone other than a frankly useless encyclopedic knowledge of pop culture. Even with all the references, "The Flash" rarely excites. The battle scenes have few textures and the action is generic and poorly finished accordingly. Post-production is responsible for showing super-powered beings in battles so sumptuous that they lose sight of the human dimension of these extraordinary men and women. And, by the way, the quality of the CGI is not always consistent with the economic power of the production. An initiative full of special appearances, Flash's first solo adventure serves to introduce the concept of the multiverse to DC and make beautiful tributes to his long and sometimes sleepy journey. This journey of weak emotions includes never-before-realized cinematic versions of characters such as Nicolas Cage's Superman (one of the good ideas) and tributes to the precursors of the wave that has reigned for more than 20 years in cinema with a more industrial feel. Furthermore, there are good jokes about changes in timelines - the best of which is about the protagonism of the "Back to the Future" Saga. In fact, recharging the "flux capacitor" with lightning is another affective borrowing from Robert Zemeckis' creation. However, the solutions are lazy and difficult problems are solved with simplistic strategies - like the lightning bolt that, if replicated, could create armies of Flashes? In the end, even the resolution of "Spider-Man: No Way Home" is recycled by DC Comics. Reality almost collapses for the protagonist to learn to accept losses and understand the value of his scars. This film, at least, should be the last of DC's current phase, serving as a reboot of the universe - so it's strange to see a Batman from the past hated by fans appearing in the final scenes in a questionable and confusing participation - it's strange to think that "Blue Beetle" and "Aquaman 2" would still be released after this production.

Barry / The Flash's life is subsumed with the fact that his father is in jail for the murder of his mother. When he discovers that he can run faster than the speed of light, he decides, against the advice of Bruce Wayne, to go back in time to put things right. As we all know though, such plans are always fraught with danger, time line wise and this is no different. Whilst Barry and his past self played by Ezra Miller are largely good fun in this, there are significant sections where they are both deeply irritating which is somewhat distracting. In addition the film includes a contribution by Supergirl played by Sasha Calle giving, at odds with the rest of the film's tone, one of the most miserable performances seen since The Grapes of Wrath hit the screen. That said this is one of the more enjoyable DC superhero movies of the last few years featuring an entertaining story, fun set pieces and strong FX throughout. The big draw here though is the introduction of shots and cameos of past beloved superheroes (and some who nearly were) and a starring role for Michael Keaton returning as Batman. The man provides much kudos here as does the accompanying suit, quite beautifully realised bat cave, bat mobile and plane, even Danny Elfman's glorious music. These factors add to a fun tale that should appeal to most people, but which may not include ardent young fans into DC lore.

Review-Title: This movie is a technical showcase...Of 2003!
Review-Description: WOW...This movie is a joke. Let all the horrible story, the stupid humor, the unlogical plot holes aside. The CGI people! I have seen game intros better than this. Like in 2003. This has to be a hoax. I don't know why CGI seems to be getting worse the last years, but this movie is the ultimate example for bad CGI. I mean, the effects are so bad, they could only get that many stars in, because you sometimes simply can't recognize them. Barry didn't only go back in time to save his mother, but obviously killed all good CGI technicians, that could have worked on this movie. Loved angry Supergirl though, if she wouldn't look like her own bad painted plastic action figure.

Review-Title: One of the better DC movies in recent years.
Review-Description: The Flash has enough action, heart and humor - not to mention fun cameos - to make up for any drawbacks. Worlds collide when the director of both "IT" movies sat on the chair of the first comic book movie about the fast young teen in the DCEU. Andy Muschietti showed us a good amount of unique director chooses that enchanted the feeling from the comics. As Michael Keaton brings back the old Batman, with the same vibes, Ezra Miller pulls not one, but two fenomenal performances. The pacing was great and the screenplay was actually good for a comics film (which I am not the biggest fan of). The flash is funny, fittingly fast-paced l, and overall ranks as one of the best DC movies in recent years.

Review-Title: One of the worst movies I have ever seen
Review-Description: The Flash is really bad, it has 0 good jokes, I didn't laugh once, I couldn't remember anything when I finished the movie, it has nothing special to remember at all, it has to be one of the worst character depictions I have ever seen. The scenes from x-men were they show Quicksilver are more memorable than a whole Flash movie. There are too many plotholes everywhere so the movie also makes no sense in so many levels that it is sad how many website have shown up to try to explain this plot holes and most just speculate but offer no good explanation. I saw the movie 2 times as I could not believe it was that bad the first time and I thought I should gave it a second chance, it was a terrible idea, the movie just sucks if you are over 14 years old.

Review-Title: A missed opportunity for a good film, and a bad homage to Keaton
Review-Description:
What is good in this film? + Michael Keaton
+ Michael Keaton ! + Michael Keaton !!!! + a hommage to the 89' Batmobile
+ a hommage to Bat stuffes, the Batcave, some antagonists from the earlier DC movies
+ there are some good jokes ( 2-3 throughout the whole film)
+ there are references to unrealised DC film projects
+ the personal tragedy of Flash in his young age is represented well. (have You noticed that only the last one is connected to Flash in a movie called "Flash" ?) The negatives:
 EVERYTHING else no, I am not kidding. LITERALLY EVERYTHING ELSE. The plot goes nowhere. It builds up something, than let it go, without solution. Ezra Miller is not good enough lead. The plot is so bad, that it even cannot provide opportunity to Keaton to show, why we liked him soo much as Batman back in '89-'92. He simply cannt show why this character is interesting. And the whole thing looks like a mess, waisting the opportunity for the introduction of a proper multiverse.

The really bad
The first hour of this is practically unwatchable and the overall story is basically a badly done reimagining of one of the TV show time travel arcs. The effects are beyond horrible and no matter how much people say budget, remember that the Flash TV show did it 10x better in story, acting, and effects on a lower budget continuously. Ezra Miller can act, but the chosen style for the Flash is beyond annoying. What's with the poses before running that take longer than the runs themselves? Did I mention the effects? Every time you finally get into part of the movie, they get obsessed with focusing on the effects and it's just bad again. The good/ok-ish
About an hour in Keaton arrives and it's like a new movie. He gives us an amazing performance that elevates the film while he's in it.

The Flash (2023) is a superhero film that tells the story of Barry Allen, a science nerd who becomes the Flash. The film is full of action, humor, and heart, and it features a great cast of characters, including Ezra Miller as Barry Allen, Michael Keaton as Batman, and Sasha Calle as Supergirl. The film's action sequences are particularly dazzling, and they showcase Barry's lightning-fast abilities in breathtaking slow-motion sequences. But beneath the thrills, The Flash beats with a surprisingly emotional core. Barry's quest to save his mother fuels the narrative, exploring themes of family, loss, and the power of connection across time. Ultimately, The Flash is a triumph of heart, spectacle, and pure superhero joy. It's a film that celebrates family, embraces second chances, and reminds us that even the fastest man alive needs a little human connection. So buckle up, grab your popcorn, and prepare to be swept away by this electrifying cinematic adventure. The Flash is a must-see for superhero fans and anyone seeking a dose of big-screen magic.

Review-Title: 5*s for Michael Keaton and the Batman tribute... I'm deducting 6*s for the rest of the garbage.
Review-Description: The 75 star deduction is for seeing Aflac as the first iteration of Batman. The other 20 star deduction is for the casting of Ezra Miller who played the role like a lifeless, robotic, annoying lovechild of Leonard from the Big Bang Theory and Justin Long. Here's a tip...don't do that. Then there's a 15 star deduction for hiring the CGI team from Lawnmower Man who cannot defend this farce from the grave. Another 7 star deduction for the ripoff artist who stole parts of the scores from A Beautiful Mind and Gladiator. Oh, and the script writers...you little scamps...I deduct 17 stars. I know the storyline takes the audience back in time. Did you have to steal all of the gags from Revenge of the Nerds outtakes?
