Review-Description: Chitty Chitty Bang Bang is a film I saw as a child, and since my first viewing, I have loved it ever since! Being a big fan of Ian Fleming as a writer and novelist, I suppose it was no surprise when I found myself watching this movie over and over again. A lot like the James Bond franchise, which he created, Fleming also managed to write this fantasy film involving a larger than life plot, beautiful locations, memorable dialogue, and iconic characters, which was now suitable for adults and children to watch and enjoy. I understood from my mother, who was only 5 years old when this film came out in 1968, that the child catcher was a subject of controversy as he was deemed too scary for children. My mother being one of them. I understand how the film has a divided audience because of its edgier theme in the second have of the film, however, in my opinion, the film is fun, catchy, memorable and one I will always hold dear to my heart.

Review-Title: I grew up with this movie
Review-Description:
(1968) Chitty Chitty Bang Bang
CHILDREN/ MUSICAL/ FANTASY Loosely based on a novel by Ian Fleming co-written and directed by Ken Hughes, owners of the James Bond franchise by the name of Albert R. Broccoli decided to produce this very pretentious musical/ fantasy about eccentric inventor Potts (Dick Van Dyke) many failed attempts to become wealthy by one of his inventions, leading to one invention after the other, whose always impressing his two small children. Liked this film when I was a kid and I still liked this now, catchy song numbers, dancing is fine and the situations Although absurd is obviously intended to be nothing more than a kids movie one can get from a kid's book- I don't anything wrong with that.

I've loved this movie for decades. Yet it's only in this latest visit that I finally noticed and found myself utterly charmed by Anna Quayle's performance. How did I miss this? I rewatched about a half dozen times her duet with Gert Frobe, a dance in which he's repeatedly trying to kill her and she's largely oblivious. Her physicality and subtleness of voice and expression is a joy to behold. Especially the moment she's almost impaled from above lying on the table as some doubt about her husband's affections dawns upon her. She's never singled out, if even mentioned, in the reviews I've read. Just want to express my appreciation even if the critics won't.

This was never my favourite musical as child, but as I get older I think I appreciate it more. Sure, it has it's cheesy moments, but there is genuine chemistry between the characters on display here and coupled with some superbly catchy - and often poignant - lyrics from the Sherman twins, we are presented with a really quite enjoyable fable. The Potts family live in a dilapidated farmhouse. Grandfather (Lionel Jeffries); the well meaning but hopeless inventor of a father "Caractacus" (Dick Van Dyke) and the two children "Jeremy" (Adrian Hall) and "Jemima" (Heather Ripley). Luckily, one day the youngsters are nearly run over by "Truly" (Sally Ann Howes) the daughter of the wealthy confectioner "Lord Scrumptious" (James Robertson Justice). She might just be able to help the father make a few quid from her father with his sweets that double up as pan pipes. Meantime, the family manage to rescue an old rust bucket from the local garage, and lo and behold, enter our eponymous vehicle. It can drive, it can become an aeroplane, an hovercraft - indeed it can do just about everything bar make the tea. It's a must-have prize for the megalomaniac child-hater "Baron Bomburst" (Gert Fr√∂be - who really does enter into the spirit of the story), so the family must fight tooth and nail to stop their car, and themselves, falling into his malevolent hands. Ian Fleming demonstrates great imagination with this and Van Dyke shows off his varied skills well and engagingly. Howes over-cooks her singing at times, but the almost 2¬Ω hours this story takes really does fly by. The Oscar winning "Chitty Chitty Bang Bang"; the delightful "Hushabye Mountain"; "Me Ol' Bamboo" and Jeffries' enjoyable rendition of "Posh!" as he is gradually drowned in his outhouse all add bundles to this colourful and joyous series of well photographed escapades. Maybe it is wasted on youngsters? It certainly was on me!

This film has a nigh epic length of 2 hours and 24 minutes but as you watch the film you'll notice that most of this running time is taken up by music numbers which seem to occur every few minutes. These musical interludes, though rather catchy and clever, go on too long and don't do much to advance the story. One such number goes on and on about a candy called "Toot Sweets" only for the magical whistling candies are shown to be problematic because they attract dogs (I thought high-pitched whistles repel dogs). Another one features the villain, the dictatorial Bomburst, singing stupid pet names with his screechy wife. This does nothing for the story and since it's about the unsympathetic villain, it can hardly be considered endearing, so I can only assume this is meant to be funny, though the humor factor is rather iffy. The title song, "Chitty Chitty Bang Bang", is another catchy tune, but, again, it doesn't do much to advance the story and gets repetitive after a while (Okay, we get it, the car is great). Other than that, this film has dark overtones, in which people are threatened with decapitation. Also, children are captured and enslaved and there is a creepy character called the Child Catcher, who is likely nightmare fuel for many a young tot. The story could easily be imagined as a horror story. On the plus side, the special effects and production values are very good.

Review-Title: Utmost ridiculous whimsy - an absolute joy, a classic, a must-see!
Review-Description: When I told a friend that I was soon going to watch this for the first time, he half-jokingly warned that the more one watches, the less it makes sense. That remark bears more truth to it than I could have supposed, for this is an unending stream of such wild fancy that it splits the divide between pure imagination and straight-up fever dream. This is never more true than with the incredibly lighthearted, fleet-footed songs of Richard M. And Robert B. Sherman, and the impeccable, wondrous choreography of Marc Breaux and Dee Dee Wood, but that same duality comes across in pretty much every last regard. The incredible filming locations are made to feel rather whimsical themselves, aided to that end in light of production design and art direction that really seem to adopt the ethos of "if you can dream it, we'll find a way to include it." This also goes for the wide-ranging frivolity of the costume design, and the terrific hair and makeup; every stunt, visual effect, sound effect, and fabricated conjuration looks great at the same time that it's often a little bewildering. And still we're just scraping the surface of everything 'Chitty Chitty Bang Bang' represents, and as if to emphasize the point - what a name! For everything that fills these two and one-half hours, there's weirdly not that much plot in it. At the same time, at almost exactly the halfway mark it's like a switch has been flipped, taking us from considerable content with minimal substance, to total cartoonish silliness. This is more curious still when one realizes that the original book was written by James Bond creator Ian Fleming, the screenplay was adapted by director Ken Hughes (also associated with strange 1967 disaster 'Casino Royale') with children's book author and notorious bigot Roald Dahl - and that Albert R. Broccoli, who was behind so much of Eon Productions' 007 franchise, also produced this, with a cast including Gert Fr√∂be (Goldfinger), Desmond Llewelyn (Q), and Benny Hill (he of "Yakkety sax" fame). And still, Hughes' orchestration of every shot and scene, and Christopher Challis' cinematography, similarly embrace that same spirit of unbridled fun while at once also being stupendously smart and delicious in and of themselves. Not to be outdone, Irwin Kostal penned a score (informed by the Shermans' tunes) that's perfectly light and cheerful over every scene in which the cast give wholehearted performances of unyielding merriment and zest. 'Chitty Chitty Bang Bang' is unremitting in its extravagant ridiculousness, a cavalcade of one gag and bit after another. Yet like The Beatles' surrealist quasi-nightmare 'Yellow submarine,' it's that complete immersion in the inane that allows this to work; add a tinge of sincerity to provide an almost indifferent anchor, and the stage is set for this to be whatever it wants. Irreverent as it all is, however, every last element is guided toward the same ends, and the result is nothing less than fabulous. Everyone involved in the production turned in truly outstanding work across the board, and that includes the screenplay. Where the movie decides to have a plot, it's written with sharp intelligence; where the movie insists on just having a good time, whatever that may mean, the scene writing is robust and superbly detailed, and the rest of the craftsmanship follows suit without fail. At all points the dialogue and characters are astoundingly colorful and varied in accordance with the need of a tale in which anything goes. And so it is on down the line from start to finish, as in one way or another the feature is just a boundless bounty of bounding, bouncing, buoyant joy, realized with only utmost care and skill. I fully expected to enjoy this, based not just on its reputation but on the strong recommendation of everyone with whom I'd ever discussed it. And still I'm ever so pleased at what a delight the film turned out to be; there are few points of comparison for a title that's so utterly resolute in its assumption of every conceivable pinch of far-flung tomfoolery. Naturally Dick Van Dyke and Sally Ann Howes curry the most favor given their prominence, but everyone in the cast and crew, and indeed everyone who participated in the work's creation, are to be congratulated for whipping up such an extraordinary, enduring, impressively enthusiastic and unfaltering flight of fancy. Given such unwavering commitment to so offbeat and preposterous an affair I can understand how this won't necessarily appeal to all - but the fact unquestionably remains that 'Chitty Chitty Bang Bang' is so absolutely, wonderfully entertaining in every regard that I'd be hard-pressed not to give a blanket recommendation. This is a tremendous, almost unparalleled classic that never feels as long as its two and one-half hours, and is worth far more than that. More than 50 years later it continues to be an exquisite marvel, and when all is said and done it's simple a must-see. Bravo!

Review-Title: Chitty Offers Up a Unique Fantasy World
Review-Description: Chitty Chitty Bang Bang tells the tale a creator who is always inventing interesting, but not always practical or necessary, or overcomplicated things and a flying/swimming car is just one of his many inventions. There are a couple tuneful and memorable songs and musical numbers. There is also one of the creepiest characters to be found in any children's film in the form of the Child Catcher, brilliantly portrayed Roger Helpmann. There are all kinds of odd and unique supporting characters throughout. The film does seem to meander quite a bit at times and weakens this film which could have been greatly improved with the help of some prudent editing, perhaps 10-15 minutes worth. Either way, it's still a fun film to check out if you haven't yet done so.

I really enjoyed this movie. I have made it a habit to speak out on Disney's live action movies because I think they get unnecessary hate. I watch the original before watching the live action. Emma does a great job of playing belle. I am in love with the animation behind the other characters. It's well done and looks real. This movie followed the original almost to the t. I appreciate the extras that were thrown in. It really adds flavor to the movie. The ending wasn't perfect. However, it wasn't detrimental to the movie. Really enjoyed it. Highly recommend it. I would watch it again and excited for what else Disney has in store.

All opinions are my own. A decent remake. Locations are absolutely gorgeous and I love that they showed more of the main characters' backstories...though I feel that Belle's was poorly placed since during her time as a "prisoner", she should have been wanting to see her father, not her birthplace. They could have added it near the end as a conclusion. (Though yes it will make it end on a sad note.) Definitely very obvious that Disney tried to push 'diversity' in this movie. Yes, it's a fictional world. But they don't treat all their movies the same. Most of their budget seems to have gone to the cast or the architecture of the castle/village. The beast and wolves do not look good, especially for a movie in 2017. And that yellow gown...Seemed like they tried to copy that same magic from the Cinderella live action, and failed. It just looks so underwhelming..must be the sleeves...Same with the red robe actually, it looks cheap.

Although I have a few things I think it could be improved, like some specific parts where the scene cuts seemed a little bit rushed and even the plot transition that I honestly don't remember how it was done in the past in the original since I watched many years ago, I have to say that the music scenes were really masterfully crafted, well deserved for a Disney production celebrating 30th anniversary of this classic masterpiece of the classic cinema. The music that happens in the dinner room specifically totally surprised me for the color, the very complex integration between the dish characters and all the lighting and camera movements that was soooo soo soooo pleasing to watch! People always complain about casting and stuff, and that always can be reasonable, but I'm particularly satisfied with the casting selection and the actors. So I think 8 is a fair rating in my opinion.

My daughters loved this, so the rating is mostly based on their reaction. However, for my part, it's a worthy retelling of a classic children's story with amazing sets & costumes. The CGI was well done & the actors did their part. The Beast was intimidating but not terrifying, so our 5 year old was able to watch it with her older sister. The wolves were probably the scariest part of the movie, but even our young one didn't duck behind her blanket for them. The casting of Belle was spot on. Ewan McGregor proved, once again, that he can shine in a musical & Luke Evans was an excellent Gaston. Well done Disney.

Review-Title: I actually really enjoyed this live action version of this movie.
Review-Description: While the movie is a remake on the original and have a couple of differences with it, I really think it's a pretty great remake. The movie itself looks great with its set design and cinematography that goes with it. It really makes the movie looks beautiful on how they executed it. The story is basically the same with a couple of differences to it and I do think it done really well. I also like the casting of the movie which they did a pretty great job on the roles they were given. Emma Watson as Bella is a decent choice, but she isn't the best actress in the movie. I also think the songs are done really well and the singing is great in the movie. Now, the CGI of the movie is something that I have mixed thoughts about. The new design for the characters falls between looking pretty good to not looking impressive at all due to how they design them. As for the beast, I do like this new design for him and does have details on him.

This film are nothing like the original, in a bad way. The added scenes are bad, and do nothing for the film. I do not like any of the live action disney films. I wished they make the live action the same as the originals. This film and the singing is rally bad! I needed a pilliow everytime they started singing. CRINGE! And the voice for the clock! Can not just use the voice of gandalv. It feels so wrong! I do not like the actors either. It is so sad they feel they have to change the classics. It feels like they think they have to make it so much more fantastical. Do not change what is already perfect.

From the very beginning, Beauty and the Beast captivates the audience with its stunning visuals, expertly crafted set designs, and elaborate costumes. The picturesque French village and the grandeur of Beast's castle are brought to life in a way that immerses viewers into the magical world of Belle (Emma Watson) and the Beast (Dan Stevens). Emma Watson's portrayal of Belle is captivating, as she brings a modern and independent twist to the character. She embodies Belle's intelligence, kindness, and unwavering spirit, making her an incredibly relatable and empowering role model for today's generation. Dan Stevens brilliantly embodies the tortured and misunderstood Beast, conveying his inner conflict between anger and vulnerability. The chemistry between Watson and Stevens is palpable, making their evolving relationship feel truly heartfelt and sincere. The film's all-star supporting cast is equally impressive, with standout performances by Luke Evans as Gaston, the narcissistic antagonist, and Josh Gad as LeFou, Gaston's loyal but conflicted sidekick. These characters bring a perfect balance of humor and depth to the story, adding an extra layer of entertainment.

Beauty and the Beast (2017), a spellbinding journey that breathes new life into a beloved tale as old as time. Emma Watson's portrayal of Belle is enchanting, bringing intelligence and warmth to the iconic character. The film editing dances gracefully through the enchanting sequences, seamlessly transitioning between the whimsy of the castle and the quaint charm of the village. The film's strength lies in its vibrant and nostalgic homage to the animated classic, with a cast that brings depth to the beloved characters. While the music tugs at the heartstrings, there are moments where the pacing feels a touch too swift, racing to keep up with the magic. Cinematography bathes the audience in a visually stunning world, from the grandeur of the Beast's castle to the lively spectacle of "Be Our Guest." At 7/10, Beauty and the Beast is a magical retelling that captures the spirit of the original while adding a touch of modern enchantment.

Ok, I get it, it's a musical, but man, there's waaay too much singing, which makes the movie kind of boring. It felt like they sang for like a good third of the movie, maybe even more, and honestly, the songs were kinda meh, dull and pointless. Now, the cast, ugh. Dan Stevens in the main male role? Seriously? He didn't give off any royal vibes. And in my opinion, he looked better as the hairy beast than as the prince. And let's talk about the film set - it was gloomy and kinda dull. And don't even get me started on the character makeup - it was just plain weird, ridiculous, or even hideous, I would say.

Cannot believe this updated version is just 6-years-old now. This movie feels like it came out 26 years ago. Decided to finally have an open-mind on the Disney Cash Grab Remakes of the already-masterpieces they made decades ago. Kinda sorry I did, even though this movie is serviceable. Not great or even very good. It's definitely nothing I'd ever want to see again. The original's near perfect, in fact, I can find very little flaws. While I love 1989's The Little Mermaid more, any argument can be made why 1991's Beauty & the Beast is superior. I mean, Belle, what an incredible character and so unselfish. I loved every bit of the 1991 version and there's a very valid reason it was the first animated movie to be nominated for best picture. This updated version is just okay, I mean I didn't hate it despite the poor CGI, creepy "inanimate" characters, Emma Watson butchering my favorite Disney song, "Belle" and the terrible new songs that padded the already-too-long runtime. This 2017 version felt VERY Community Theatre and made me lighten up for the performances, as if they were actors in a neighborhood theatre pouring their hearts out. WHY do these remakes have to be ONE FULL HOUR longer when the stories are essentially the same? Yes, as mentioned, they add in cringe new songs, but other than that, I don't know why they subject us to mediocrity for even longer than necessary. The only character I liked was the updated LeFou and believe me, I've been in his longing-for-who-you'll-never-get shoes. At least I had someone to root for and was pleased with how his arc played out. I wish I could say I didn't regret seeing the 2017 take, but I kinda do. Everything was flat, dark and no one could hold a Lumi√®re to the original. Skip this. *** Final Thoughts: Really sorry this made a ton of money so Disney could open the floodgates to more embarrassing shot-by-shot "live" action meh remakes. Unless you have a complete reimagining, such as Maleficent or Cruella, I wish they wouldn't bother. (2017 version: 4/10 Stars, 1991 version: 10/10 Stars.)

Review-Title: Harmless fun - don't believe the bad reviews
Review-Description: I don't understand the bad reviews this film received. I honestly enjoyed it and found it fun. In fact it really cheered me up when I was feeling a bit rubbish. They state their intention right away by claiming upfront there are embellishments and Michael Fassbender doesn't even attempt to do Rongen's accent so it is clear this is just a bit of harmless entertainment. If you want the 100% factual story watch the documentary Next Goal Wins. There were some LOL moments and really funny lines. I would say it is a feelgood story that I would happily see with my mum, my brother or my boyfriend. If you are someone who prefers more sophisticated or satirical comedy then it may not be for you, but if you just want a good inoffensive film then I can recommend it. There are some good comedy performances from the cast and it does make you want to go and google the real people I am a Taika and Fassbender fan so maybe I am biased but I think this is more an audience film than a critic's film. I am going to go to the cinema and see it again which I rarely do so that says something.

Review-Title: Once upon a time, Taika was Waititi.
Review-Description: And now, Taika Waititi is not himself anymore. Looking for something new, special, particular and excessive, trying to make a movie potentially likeable by all kinds of person in the world, Taika created instead a low level work, neither able to let people smile in the typical Waititi style. It is sad to see a director doing steps behind instead to be better and better, but this is what this movie is, a strong step behind. I really hope that the next time we'll be able to see again the real Waititi, because what is crystal clear to me and so man Italian and Canadian movie critics is that at the moment Waititi lost is magic touch.

Review-Title: A heartwarming tale of soccer, culture, and community in American Samoa
Review-Description: Taika Waititi's Next Goal Wins isn't your average underdog sports story. It's a sun-drenched odyssey, a hilarious clash of cultures, and a heartwarming testament to the power of community. We're thrust onto the dusty shores of American Samoa, where the national soccer team holds the dubious honour of being the world's worst. Enter Thomas Rongen (Michael Fassbender), a washed-up coach with a temper shorter than a tiki torch. His mission? Whip these lovable misfits into shape for the World Cup qualifiers, a feat that seems as likely as a beach coconut spontaneously combusting. Waititi, with his trademark blend of quirky humour and genuine pathos, expertly navigates the film's tonal tightrope. Think Lost in Translation meets a soccer field when picturing Rongen's cultural clashes. Then, suddenly, the players' unwavering spirit and the island's diverse cultural heritage move you. The film doesn't shy away from the team's underdog status, but it also avoids wallowing in self-pity. Instead, it celebrates their resilience, their infectious joy, and their unwavering belief in the impossible. Fassbender delivers a nuanced performance as Rongen, a man grappling with his past demons while trying to inspire a team he barely understands. The supporting cast shines equally bright, with characters like the flamboyant Jaiyah Saelua (Kaimana), who is fa'afafine, a third gender recognised in Polynesian society, and the stoic goalkeeper Nicky Salapu (Uli Latukefu) injecting the film with humour and heart. The cinematography is a character in itself, capturing the island's breathtaking beauty and the raw energy of the game. The score, a vibrant mix of traditional Samoan music and pulsating electro beats, perfectly complements the film's emotional rollercoaster. While Next Goal Wins isn't without its flaws-the pacing occasionally stumbles, and the ending might feel a tad predictable-its strengths far outweigh its weaknesses. It's a film that reminds us that victory isn't always about winning trophies but about finding your own "next goal" and chasing it with all your heart. So, should you watch Next Goal Wins? Absolutely. It's a crowd-pleaser in the best sense-a film that will make you laugh, cry, and cheer as you root for the underdogs who dare to dream big. It's a cinematic sunshine break, a reminder that even in the face of impossible odds, the human spirit can soar like a perfectly executed bicycle kick.

Thomas Rongen is brought in to manage The American Samoa football team, his brief is to get the team to score a single goal in The World cup qualifiers. A team that was sitting at the bottom of the rankings list, and famously lost 31 nil to Australia. Instantly you'll recognise that Taika Waititi is behind this film, his style is etched all over it, and as I eagerly await the second series of Our flag means death, this hits the mark. It's not perfect, arguably it's a little slow to start, but as it develops, it just gets better and better, and by the end, I was absolutely engrossed. Funny, moving, uplifting, it's real life given a feel good twist, a great film for the whole family to enjoy. I recently read an article from an American website, which was discussing the fact that so many American parts were being played by Brits, here's another example of that, Michael Fassbender does such a great job as Rongen, proving he can do comedy very well. Well worth seeing. 8/10.

'Next Goal Wins' is Taika Waititi's 8th film as director, and is another heartfelt little comedy gem, much more similar to 'Boy' and 'Hunt for the Wilderpeople' than his other films. It's based on a true story, after the Socceroos beat American Samoa 31-0 in a World Cup Qualifier in 2001. The 'boss' of American Samoa Football, Tavita (Kightley) then hires semi-disgraced coach Thomas Rongen (Fassbender) to try to help them to score just one goal. Thomas doesn't necessarily want to be there and the reasons for his anger are slowly revealed over the course of the film. The other main character who has a nice journey is Jaiyah (Kaimana), which is portrayed very well. Sadly it was filmed in Hawaii - not American Samoa or Tonga, but still looks great and gives it a tropical Polynesian vibe. Most of the film follows common misfits-to-sporting-heroes tropes, but is still based in reality - i.e. The team doesn't go on to win the World Cup or anything! Good support cast, with Waititi favourites Rachel House & Rhys Daby present and small roles for Will Arnett & Elizabeth Moss, and the over-zealous Australians, Angus Sampson & Luke Hemsworth. The soundtrack is good, and the portrayal of American Samoan culture is done well, particularly the pre-match war dances. The pacing is also good, with it not being too long, and there's a nice balance between jokes and some of the touching/character-building moments. It's nice to see Thomas come around and the positivity and happiness all the American Samoans show him and each other. The final game is well-edited and exciting, a fitting finish.

I loved this movie so much was such a fun ride and I laughed the opening sequence for about 10 minutes afterwards. A great window into the soul of American Samoans who are shown to be kind and resourceful, made me want to buy a ticket to visit !! Loved how this movie ebbed and flowed and built with the ending so moving and the whole packed theatre cheered. Well done to the storytellers and director who made this fun and kept the tempo. The movie also broke down negative stereotypes and created a chance for empathy and compassion. I will spend hours searching the characters and the story which is a gem !

Taika Waititi has created a post-Lasso football comedy feel-good story that explores Samoan culture based around a true story. Does it feel derivative of Ted Lasso? Sure. Does that necessarily matter? Not really. It takes the blueprint and does good on it. Waititi has jumped at the opportunity to comedically share Samoan culture through this theme, being of part Polynesian descent himself. The story follows a riled up and downtrodden football coach, Thomas Rongen (Fassbender) who ends up in American Samoa to manage their national football team; in need of an overhaul in time for the world cup qualifiers. Once there, he embarks unwittingly on a journey of self-discovery. Nods are made to key aspects of Samoan culture and economics, such as tuna exports, acceptance of transgenderism, its intense religiosity, and the omnipresence of U. S. military enlistment for Samoans looking to make a livelihood. Football is seen as a sort of respite for a politically disenfranchised and isolated community of islanders. Waititi shows the warmth and soulfulness of the Samoan people alongside the timeless suspense and entertainment of football. There's a lot to love here, even if character development of the team itself was lacking, with the exception of transgender character Jaiyah (Kaimana), and arguably Nicky Salapu (Uli Latukefu). 7.5/10.

I just got back from watching this movie, and I have some really great things to say about this film. The film comes from a true story of a football team from American Samoa and in the many years the team has been going they have not scored a single goal. That is until a man called Thomas rongen comes to town after losing his job and is put on to coach the (worst team in the world) He coaches the team and shows this throughout the film and when it comes to the big match, they fear it will become the same as the match in Australia in 2001 which led to 31-0 to Australia. Later in the match the first half went by and they were losing, then the coach explained how he was hating the world because his beloved daughter died in a car accident. After half time they got back on the pitch and scored not 1 but 2 goals leading the American Samoans to their very first victory in the history of the world. I would highly recommend the following film as it is like an emotional roller coaster.

Easy viewing, lots of funny moments. Great to see films about Polynesian culture that made with actors and crew connected to the culture. Predictable storyline but still interesting, humorous and entertaining, especially as it is basically all historically correct. Loved the inclusion of Kaimana playing Jaiyah who was the first openly trans person to compete in international soccer. Apparently Jaiyah wasn't in the team in this point of history in real life, but they are a real person and I thought it was great that their story was incorporated into the movie. Taika clearly cares about this project. Hilarious dialogue that was apparently mostly improvised. Not the best movie in the entire world but good fun, enlightening and worth a watch.

Review-Title: ‚öΩ A Decently Entertaining Story, Some Chuckles, Quite a Alot of the Jokes Fall Flat, A Few Goods Laughs from Some of the Moments & Jokes ‚öΩ
Review-Description: Just Got out of a Screening of Next Goal Wins. As the Headline Says, "A Decently Entertaining Story, Some Chuckles, Quite a Alot of the Jokes Fall Flat, A Few Goods Laughs from Some of the Moments & Jokes" That's the Film. There's not alot more to Write. Standout Things I Liked about the Film - 1. The Fun Facts about the American Samoa üá¶üá∏ Vs Samoa üáºüá∏ was Interesting. 2. The other Fun Fact about the Real Life World Cup Qualifier Match of American Samoa üá¶üá∏ Vs Australia üá¶üá∫ was Brutal. I never knew that happened üòÇ 3. The way the Match between American Samoa üá¶üá∏ Vs Tonga üáπüá¥ was Retold was More Entertaining than how it was before by just Watching the Match. Overall, it was a Mildly Entertaining Watch.

Review-Title: The rise of Nike and Jordan
Review-Description: Directed by Ben Affleck and starring Matt Damon, Air is a dramatic film that at first doesn't seem to offer much. What makes this film interesting is how it chronicles the creation of a series of sports shoes and the Nike corporation's attempt to make a deal with Michael Jordan. It seems like a small thing, but it was an event that would leave precedents in the history of sports, taking the Nike corporation to the top, changing the corporate paradigm of the sports footwear industry and bringing Michael Jordan himself to stardom. The film does not show the events as such, it simply uses dialogues between the businessmen to narrate the process. Matt Damon presents a quite astute and determined character who knows how to use his wit very well. Although Chris Tucker doesn't appear much, he doesn't lose that comedic energy that made him memorable in the Rush Hour trilogy. Michael Jordan's appearance in the film is quite mysterious because it does not show his face and that may be a bit disappointing for those who knew him, either because of his basketball games or because of his participation in Space Jam. Anyway, it is understandable because of the time in which the film was made and the time in which the events take place. In addition, the film has a good soundtrack of eighties songs, giving this film an eighties feel that feels almost nostalgic. Even the introduction that begins the credits is a nice collage of television broadcasts from that time. Air is a good dramatic film with a good plot that Ben Affleck knew how to execute, showing that he is capable of directing good films and not just acting in them. My final rating for this movie is an 8/10.

Review-Title: Today's basketball shoes come in really big . . .
Review-Description: . . . boxes. During my grandparents' time, many if not most people had much smaller feet. Seven-footers were few and far between. Throughout the Twentieth Century, Society considered 72-inches to be the epitome of height--for men. Ladies were expected to limit their growth to 64 inches. Songs said that 62 inches was an even better feminine height, especially for blue-eyed gals. In the highly unlikely event that someone attained growth exceeding 78 inches, with proportionately-sized feet, he was expected to navigate life unshod. However, AIR seems to encourage the rapid proliferation of prodigious foot growth, and the humongous shoe boxes said extremities appear to require.

Review-Title: Michael Jordan drives a hard bargain
Review-Description: Ben Affleck has again proven himself a wonderful director. What could have been a big yawn is a funny, absorbing, and well-paced film. It's the story of a loser basketball show manufacturer, Nike, and one man's determination to land Michael Jordan as a product endorser. We know Jordan signed and came up with the Air Jordan shoe. What I liked about this film was that knowing what was going to happen did not make it less suspenseful - we see what Sonny Vacarro (Matt Damon) went through was impressive, not only at the company but with the Jordan family. I loved the humor - I will watch Jason Bateman in anything. He's great here, as are Chris Tucker, Ben Affleck, and Dave Messina. Highly recommended for the story and the performances.

Good film overall! I really liked this film, I'm starting to enjoy films with Ben Affleck behind the camera. For this one we're lucky enough to see him in front of the camera too, accompanied by a Matt Damon who is a pleasure to watch. The beginning of the film is a bit long, but once things get going it's a great lesson in perseverance from Nike. I didn't know the story of the Nike-Jordan collaboration before seeing the film, and it was interesting to see how it came about, and how it must have influenced future collaborations between players and brands... Special mention to the cast, which I adore: Ben Affleck, Matt Damon, Viola Davis, Jason Bateman and the others!

Review-Title: This movie is like watching paint dry
Review-Description: The story is poorly written and not engaging. The actors are ok. Unfortunately they couldn't save this boring movie. If you love watching middle aged corporate execs trying to make more money, you'll love this. Otherwise, skip it. The one good thing about this movie is the music and nostalgia. Nike, adidas, converse...a big competition for who can sell more snake oil. Selling a dream to kids about something they're never going to be able to attain. It's a great story of corporate triumph over its competitors. It's not really inspiring, funny, or even interesting. Unfortunately, I wasted two hours I won't ever get back.

Statesman here by and request for fit to scale hands down. One of the best sports films with remembered legend the all time great MJ. I thought it to be high in ratings while in theaters, it became everything and more through the timeline. With championships on the line it's evident sales went through the roof for cooperate. I learned so much about the game through general business administration. Great film! My favorite part about the movie was definitely the collab prior to the biggest sales meeting of the era. I laughed and cried and had emotions through the roof just to conclude my feelings about the sport and mental health. Way to go!

Review-Title: It's no Godfather, but it's not the worst movie ever made.
Review-Description:
I agree that the movie was very "meh," but I still enjoyed it (while making holiday cards). As Isaac Asimov famously said," There is a cult of ignorance in the United States, and there has always been. The strain of anti-intellectualism has been a constant thread winding its way through our political and cultural life, nurtured by the false notion that democracy means that 'my ignorance is just as good as your knowledge." In other words, "Don't believe everything you think." I just find it amusing how many people make assumptions, and are so certain of themselves, yet their criticism has no basis in reality "First, the storyline is very good though I don't trust its honesty based on Hollywood's track record of distorting so-called true stories."
"but much of it doesn't appear to be factual "
Here is some advice for all the wannabe film critics out there: When a film is billed "based on true events," that means...take it with a grain of salt. Filmmakers use a lot of artistic license; they are accorded leeway in his or her interpretation of something and is not held strictly accountable for accuracy. It's not a documentary. Show me ONE, just ONE movie "based on true events" that is 100% accurate. They do not exist. This is for all the cry babies who object to the fact that Jordan did not appear in the film...which, by the way, the cry babies could have looked up, but no, they wanted to complain. "MJ is a legend, he's such a god you can't show his likeness, you might be Charlie Hebdo'd."
In the midst of promoting the film, Ben Affleck has given an interview to the Hollywood Reporter, where he explained the conscious and excellent decision for the star not to appear in the film. "When you become much more than a hero, an athlete or even an icon, you start to be an idea to people. You touch them and you start to represent hope, excellence and greatness. You are unique," he began. "There was no way I was going to ask the public to believe that someone other than Michael Jordan was Michael Jordan. It was a deliberate choice. I thought he was too majestic for anyone to imitate. Jordan is too big," he continued. One guy said: "However, the film neglects to tell us that Vaccaro soon left Nike to work for Adidas."
Actually he was fired by Nike in 1991 - six years after the release of Air Jordans - but moved on to work for Adidas and then for Reebok. He and Strasser and Moore all went to Adidas, where they forged that company's floundering basketball program into Nike's biggest competitor. This is for all the cry babies who complained about the Jordans' "greed."
No, the Jordan family was not greedy. That scene was pure fiction. In reality, Deloris never insisted on Jordan getting a cut of the profits from his shoe, but she was instrumental in pushing Michael to pick Nike's offer over other, more prestigious sneaker deals. Mrs. Jordan heads several charities. In 1989, Mrs. Jordan and her son co-founded the Michael Jordan Foundation to raise money for disadvantaged children. Not only was she the President of the foundation, but she also began the Michael Jordan Education Club that encouraged students to improve their grades and attendance. Soooo greedy, huh? Michael Jordan did not receive the red Mercedes 380SL he insisted on from all three interested parties. Instead, Vaccaro pulled out two toy cars and started rolling them on the conference table. "Yet big corporations can make 'movies' like this to inject their brand into the brains of people."
"Objectionable propoganda (sic) for Nike and Jordan, and Ben Affleck should be ashamed of himself."
"This film was made by Nike, for Nike and to increase Nike's sales. " Nope. Ben Affleck did not seek Nike's approval for 'Air' - only Michael Jordan's. "It's not a history of Nike," Affleck said of his new film. "There's interviews and books about that."

Review-Title: Another winning piece of work by Ben Affleck
Review-Description: Well what can I say? I really really enjoyed this movie. Ben Affleck creating another masterpiece of a movie here, with his and Matt Damon's new company "Artists equity". Great to see Ben and Matt playing together again I have to stick with what someone said that the simplicity of the movie is also it's strength. No big sets, no big plotholes or any kind of these things, just great actors and filmmakers and you get something like this. I just don't understand that it hasn't made more money Recently I saw the (2009) movie "State of play" and thought to myself that it could've been made by Ben Affleck and Matt Damon. That's how good I think it was. I really think that Ben and Matt's production company is a great asset to the film industry. Can't wait for future projects, keep it comming.

Review-Title: Interesting Movie, Lots of Unnecessary Profanity
Review-Description: I really liked the subject of this movie as it fundamentally changed what we now know as a huge business. The casting was good, especially Viola Davis as Jordan's mother who delivered an outstanding performance. I enjoyed all the nostalgic clips as it brought you back into the period of the times. The only downside I found was the excessive vulgar language. Maybe the original individuals talked that way, but this is, at the end of the day, an entertainment and the ridiulous use of expetives didn't make it any more edgy...just crass. It has little to do with the story and a good actor can deliver the same sentiment without being so vulgar. I wanted my mother to see this film as she is a huge basketball fan and it saddened me to see her cringe while watching a story she was very interested in. Hollywood...get a grip. You're trying to shape culture with your propaganda and we all know how out of touch you are with us normal people.

Absolutely excellent. The film begins with Carroll Shelby at the helm of a race car at Le Man's. The movie quick identifies why he can no longer race for himself, and transiting into his business. The movie has nearly non- stop racing action, and manages to make all of the drama of the business endeavors as exciting as pinning the throttle down the Mulsanne straight. There is no limit of technical details, as the movie covers how the GT40 engineers overcame each pitfall of the car. You get to enjoy the progress of the vehicle, the racing, and Shelby as a brand. The acting is spot on, and the cast clearly has chemistry behind the scenes that makes this movie as great as it is. I've watched this movie with people that have no in- depth knowledge of cars, engineering, or any characters. Unanimously, the film comes through in every way you could want. My only want, is that more movies are made just like this one.

Review-Title: This masterpiece reminds me of another masterpiece
Review-Description: When watching this for the first time, it felt like I was watching The Pinchcliffe Grand Prix (Fl√•klypa Grand Prix in Norwegian) as a kid. Bale is absolutely one of the most intruiging and versatile actors. Everytime I watch him I almost have to remind myself that he's Christian Bale, and that he plays another man. He is so good in transforming and embodying another person that its almost freightning. The cast is great. The story is exhilirating. The audio is fantastic. The visuals are staggering. The racing scenes are magnificent. Btw, if you like Le Mans '66, you are gonna love Pinchcliffe Grand Prix.

The Kings of Asphalt, starring Oscar-winning actors Matt Damon and Christian Bale, is a biographical film released in 2019. In the movie, based on a true story, Ford Automobile aims to beat Ferrari in the 24 Hours of Le Mans, known as the longest race in history. For this, they begin to design a vehicle together with car designers Carroll Shelby (Damon) and Ken Miles (Bale). Even though it was about the 1966 Le Mans races, the image quality and graphics were at a high level. Night shots were especially exciting. The film's cinematographer, Phedon Papamichael, seems to have done a good job. Also, the vehicles in the movie are completely real. So they didn't come up with a computer design. This is another enjoyable part of the job. The acting was sufficient for this movie, which was static except for the racing parts. In fact, it was too much for a drama movie. Jon Bernthal, whom we also know from The Walking Dead series, was at least as good as the leading roles. It was the first time in over 50 years that a motor sports film (previously Grand Prix, 1966) won an Oscar. Oscar awards were given to the best sound editing and best editing. The first names considered for the leading roles in Kings of Asphalt were Tom Cruise and Brad Pitt. Maybe they could have won the best actor Oscar with these names. However, it is not known whether the movie would seem this sincere. Because Bale now sets the bar so high that you break away from the movie and just watch Bale. In recent years, more sports movies have started to be made. The 2013 movie Zafere Rush is one of them. They are similar in fiction to the Kings of Asphalt. Although Rush had a weaker cast, I liked this movie more because it was about the more popular Formula Grand Prix. However, none of these prevent the Kings of Asphalt from making history.

Review-Title: Ford v Ferrari a true masterpiece of filmmaking
Review-Description: 10/10 This movie is a perfect adaptation of a true story keeping almost everything and exaggerating certain elements to make it more entertaining, and the action is intense and can be chaotic but it's always clear what's going on,even though there's only one fist fight this movie has some of the best action I've ever seen in my entire life and this movie is drama is the best in any movie you empathize with the characters and you feel the drama and did it's not overwhelming and also not just dumb sappiness like lesser movies, part of what makes the drama so effective in the movie is that they draw you in with comedy not just endless drama which makes it so you can never get drawn in, however I feel I have to mention I am a bit biased I absolutely love cars and 60s cars are my favorite out of any decade of cars, but even if you're not in the cars it's a must see.

I loved the plot continuity+Pace of this film with good story structure and characters arcs. Kick it into 7000 rpm and enjoy a brief ride through history when considering watching this solid film, Ford Versus Ferrari. The exhilarating true story behind the 1966 24 hour Le Mans race serves as a story for the crossing paths between Carol Shelby (Matt Damon) and the eccentric British driver, Ken Miles (Christian Bale) and how they come together to take down Enzo Ferrari and show ford off as a top contender. Director James Mangold takes on the American story that rewrote racing history displaying some of the most exciting scenes we have seen this year in 2019. From the drivers POV to the spectators POV, we are taking a journey with all who witnessed this great victory and the events that lead up to it.

Cardboard acting , cardboard script , cardboard directing. This movie is pretty bad . Practicly all of the actors with a few exceptions act pretty bad . Sometimes it seems as if they were never into the movie . They act as if ' oh I have to do a scene , then pick up the kids from school and make dinner also " . Most of them over-act their character and then we get on top typical stupid scenes like the little boy or wife listening to the radio in a total stupid way. This is not the quality to expect like something as Apollo 13 where the acting is normal instead of over-acting and putting down stupid characters and scenes. Ever seen a racing driver riding next to each other and facing each other on full speed .....well reality is far away in this output. We also get some music that does not fit the year in question. And all this is pretty much the fault of the director .

As a 1960s race car biography movie, it is very well done. Every ratings fields nearly shine out up until the dramatic moments (a mere few seconds of those) that I wasn't expecting cause I knew nothing about the real Ken Miles and his passing in 1966 in a car testing accident. It took me by surprise and after that it was like powders of sadness were poured over the afterward scenes and even the entire film. In my opinion, a more detailed depiction of the last moments was needed to highlight the contrast between his "safe" racing (race driving) and the seemingly innocuous test drive that he probably had done a dozen times. Nevertheless, that's a superb biographical movie with a bright cast and an uncompromising flow. I'm still saddened. I don't know why. One of the rare time that the death of a character struck me. Kudos Christian Bale, kudos Matt Damon (still see your tears and feel the lump in your throat). Screenplay/storyline/plots: 8.5 Development: 9 Realism: 9 Entertainment: 9 Acting: 9 Filming/photography/cinematography: 9 VFX: 9 Music/score/sound: 8.5 Depth: 8.5 Logic: 7.5 Flow: 9 Action/biography/drama: 8.5 Ending: 8.5.

Confused plot with a lot of filler. This movie could easily be a short and sweet hour and a half. Decent acting; Christian Bale pulls off a good British accent. Some of the character's motivations aren't really clear and therefore their actions seem illogical at times. It doesn't go on to show Ford actually beating Ferrari. They could have skipped some of the character development of Bale's wife and kid and gone on to show Ford beating Ferrari. There's a fair bit of boring car racing scenes that started to put me to sleep a little, as long action scenes tend to do that for me. It's honestly just pretty bland subject matter so they didn't have much to work with to be fair. I don't think this really needed to be a movie, maybe just a 30 minute documentary would suffice, so I probably wouldn't recommend it but it's not the worst if you're stuck on a plane for 15 hours and can't find anything better to watch for example, it'd be fine, but at home where you've got the choice of anything I'd skip this.

Review-Title: this is pure art on wheels
Review-Description: Even if i found the movie always already in the best part, the whole movie works in many levels. Is a racing movie, a movie about friends, a movie about how cars can make you feel alive every time you see them, hear them and follow them...is a car movie that have everything i like, even i have watched the movie in parts, i like that is both human and machine focused. Cristian bale really make you believe what he feels as ken miles, and matt damon shines as caroll shelby. Lets just say, ken miles family, carolls shelby mechanics, even the other teams make the movie good in many ways.the races are filmed so good that i never noticed when is only cristian bale and when is a stunt car.is funny dramatic and moving.and have alot of beautiful cars, and great photography.is like, soon could be one of those movies i could watch every day.makes sense that bale is now in a racing movie, after nolan movies, he was always in the lamborghinis and the tumbler racing fast, what was interesting to me is to see matt damon plays a caroll shelby that was so real that you really feel he can build a car.

Le Mans '66" speeds into the heart of motorsports rivalry, delivering a thrilling tale set against the iconic 1966 24 Hours of Le Mans race. The film's standout performances by Matt Damon and Christian Bale paint a vivid portrait of determination and passion. While the adrenaline-pumping racing sequences dominate, the movie's real brilliance lies in its skillful use of foreshadowing. A sense of impending tragedy looms over Ken Miles' character, adding depth and weight to the climax. But, they foreshadowed his death to much to not make a big deal out of it. I like the emotion that Matt Damon shows when he spoke to Miles son but the event that killed Ken Miles is just to short and not that great. While some clich√©s and pacing issues persist, the film's emotional impact and immersive storytelling make it a compelling watch for racing aficionados and casual moviegoers alike.

An easy comedy to switch you're mind off to, it doesn't have anything super different or interesting to say and the plot moves real quick, especially at the start, but it's funny and has a heart. Ben Stiller has never really been my favourite comedic actor, and unfortunately the minders he appeared on screen I grew quite tiresome, but I guessed that was the point, since he was the antagonist. Characterisation of the other members of the dodgeball team is a little miss, and I think perhaps they could've put some more information about them each at the top. But I still think it's a fun film to watch if you're craving something simple and funny.

Review-Title: If you can dodge a wrench, you can dodge a ball...
Review-Description: Dodgeball is a very entertaining film and I seem to like it more every time I watch it. I'm always in disbelief watching this, because it's an over the top slapstick comedy about dodgeball, how can it be so funny! The pacing is really good and it feels like it's over in half an hour. The acting is good and Ben Stiller's character of White Goodman is easily one of the funniest movie villains of all time. The late Rip Torn is hilarious too in his role. Vince Vaughan does a fine job and Christine Taylor does alright too. This film also features a very funny credit scene before they started to become so widely used. Overall it's a very amusing way to spend an hour and a half.

Dodgeball is the kind of movie I can come back to after a year and still find everything hilarious again and again. This movie is the King of sports comedy films. From the loveable goofs of Average Joe's to the over-the-top villain in Ben Stiller's White Goodman, and watching Patches throw wrenches at people under the logic of "If you can dodge a wrench, you can dodge a ball". The movie delivers consistent laughs throughout and is a real feel-good comedy for all ages. Plenty of jokes the kids will get and plenty more that'll go over their heads and the adults will understand. Every time I watch this film, I seem to pick up on a new joke each time. Be sure to watch the hilarious post-credit scene with White Goodman too! It took me many views to realise it existed and it was unexpected to say the least.

Review-Title: "Nobody makes me bleed my own blood"
Review-Description: Golly Geesh this movie is hilarious. It so quotable and ridiculous but I loved it. I usually hate dumb comedy movies but the actor and writing had me committed to this movie. I rewatch this movie all the time. On my initial viewing, it was okay to me. But on another watch I was all in. I can't say it enough. This is hilarious. I can see if some people might not like it. Some comedies are not for everyone. But come on gotta love the 2000 comedy. Hurt every bodies feeling all the time. Did not care. Looking at the main actors you might get an idea of how the comedy might go. It gives hot chick, white chicks, and horrible bosses vibe.

Review-Title: Not worth your time. Except you have a lot of time.
Review-Description: First things first, I must admit something Yes, the film is funny. But I feel like everyone here is overrating it. I watched it and had 2 good laughs. 2 good laughs isnt bad at all but for a movie which is made purely for the purpose of comedy it wasn't enough for me. The dodgeball scenes are too silly for me and I can't watch them without cringing a little. There are many great movies out there, but this one isn't really it. I actually have seen this movie twice. First time was in gym class. My classmates shared my opinion, except one. My own twin. So he forced to Re- watch it. I didn't change my opinion. I would like to give this 5 stars, but I feel like that's unfair when there are movies with 5 stars that I liked even more. And I also think the overall rating should be dragged down a little. But I am just a internet guy whose opinion doesn't matter.

Review-Title: A Hilarious and Inspiring Sports Comedy
Review-Description: "Dodgeball: A True Underdog Story" is an uproarious sports comedy that hits its target with precision. This film is a delightful blend of slapstick humor, witty dialogue, and an underdog narrative that keeps you engaged from start to finish. The film boasts a talented ensemble cast, led by Vince Vaughn and Ben Stiller, who deliver exceptional performances. Vaughn's relatable charm as Peter LaFleur, the struggling gym owner, provides a solid anchor for the story, while Stiller's over-the-top portrayal of White Goodman, the egotistical fitness guru, steals every scene he's in. The comedic timing and physical comedy in "Dodgeball" are impeccable. The gags and slapstick humor are cleverly executed, resulting in moments that will have you laughing out loud. The film's exaggerated characters and absurd situations add to the comedic charm, creating a fast-paced and entertaining experience. However, what sets "Dodgeball" apart is its unexpected heart. Beyond the laughs, there's an inspiring message about teamwork, perseverance, and embracing one's true self. The film manages to balance its comedic moments with genuine emotional beats, making it a well-rounded and satisfying experience. Visually, the film captures the energetic spirit of dodgeball through dynamic and engaging sports sequences. The dodgeball matches are creatively choreographed, filled with adrenaline-pumping action and suspense. The lively soundtrack complements the on-screen action, further enhancing the overall viewing experience. While some may argue that the film relies on familiar sports movie tropes, "Dodgeball: A True Underdog Story" distinguishes itself with its clever humor, memorable characters, and an infectious spirit that leaves you rooting for the underdogs. It's an entertaining and feel-good comedy that will keep you entertained from start to finish. In summary, "Dodgeball: A True Underdog Story" is a laugh-out-loud comedy with heart. With its stellar cast, hilarious moments, and a positive message, it stands as a memorable and enjoyable sports comedy that hits the bullseye. Whether you're a fan of sports films or simply looking for a good laugh, this movie is a definite winner.

The film combines outrageous humor with an underdog story, creating a unique and entertaining experience. Vince Vaughn shines as Peter LaFleur, the laid-back owner of Average Joe's Gym. His deadpan delivery and witty comebacks add a perfect dose of sarcasm to the film. On the other hand, Ben Stiller's portrayal of White Goodman, the pompous owner of Globo Gym, is pure comedic genius. Stiller's over-the-top performance and larger-than-life personality make for an unforgettable antagonist. The plot revolves around Peter's desperate attempt to save his gym from foreclosure by entering a high-stakes dodgeball tournament. The tournament scenes are filled with high-energy action and slapstick comedy, keeping you engaged and laughing throughout. The supporting cast, including Rip Torn as the eccentric Patches O'Houlihan, adds even more comedic value to the film. What sets "Dodgeball" apart is its clever writing and memorable one-liners. The dialogue is sharp, filled with clever puns and pop culture references that will have you quoting the movie for days. The film also cleverly satirizes the fitness industry and the obsession with physical perfection. The chemistry between Vaughn and Stiller is undeniable, and their on-screen rivalry is pure gold. The comedic timing and improvisation between the two actors are spot-on, creating many laugh-out-loud moments. The supporting cast, including Christine Taylor, Justin Long, and Alan Tudyk, also deliver strong performances, adding depth to the story. While the film primarily aims for laughter, it also carries an important message about teamwork, friendship, and embracing one's true self. The story reminds us that success doesn't always come in the expected package, and that even the most unlikely heroes can emerge victorious. "Dodgeball: A True Underdog Story" is a comedy gem that will have you rolling in the aisles. With its clever writing, memorable characters, and uproarious humor, this film is a must-watch for fans of comedy and sports movies alike. So grab your dodgeballs and get ready for a laughter-filled ride that you won't soon forget.

Review-Title: A scene stealer named Ben Stiller!
Review-Description: Once you've peeled all the layers of goofball comedy that cover the heart of Ron Shelton's "Dodgeball: A True Underdog Story" -and as a true underdog film indeed, it's got a heart and at the right place- you get to the core of its spirit, which is the clash of two schools of gym-related philosophies: fulfillment of physical narcissism VS; male-bonding escapism, "become a better man" or "be yourself and have a good time". Ego vs. Friendship, "Globo Gym" vs. "Average Joe's". The film doesn't aim high (in a good sense) for it doesn't take much effort to root for the more relatable misfits that hang out in a dilapidated gym club... but just because you're escaping from life's daily hardships doesn't mean they won't come biting you some day. You've got to earn your freedom and a little competition never hurts. In a way, the rubber ball works as the film's existential allegory : sometimes you just can't dodge all the hits, you've got to take them and learn to hit back. The first ten minutes of the film set the tone through a hilarious commercial. You've got a cocky and arrogant successful gym franchise owner, a body and self-confidence building guru named White Goodman, played by a Ben Stiller at the top of his game. From his hair-mullet to his horseshoe moustache and his "we're better than you" slogan, you know this is someone who's trying to compensate past demons. In fact, he doesn't deny it himself: six years before, he was a morbidly obese loser. Peter La Fleur (Vince Vaughn) is more laid-back and amiable, so careless that he must raise 50.000 dollars to pay his mortgage and prevent what's left from his gym to be bought out by his rival. It's not even the loss that concerns him but that his buddies would lose their little haver. And what a colorful gallery of lovable schmucks! Justin Long is an awkwardly shy and clumsy high school student who joined a cheerleading team to impress his love interest, Stephen Root is an equivalent of his iconic "Office Space" Milton. Alan Tudyk is Steve "Pirate" Cowan who takes his "being a pirate" so seriously that it quickly ceases to be a matter of puzzlement but rather an inspirational self-acceptance model. As two of Peter's employees, there's also Joel David Moore and Chris Williams and finally, we have Christine Taylor -Stiller's wife- as Kate Veatch, an assigned tax lawyer who, despite her tremendous skills, can't join the team (the bank is sponsored by Globo Gym so it would be a conflict of interest) but something about Goodman's seduction skills inevitably led her to becoming a pivotal member of the Average Joe's team. It's one thing to pretend to read a dictionary, inflate the 'crotch' zone and pull a 'Basic Instinct' but another to fire a woman to better date her or deliver some embarrassingly bordernline-harrassment lines. In fact the only redeeming quality of Goodman is that he's so hilariously obnoxious that we enjoy laughing at his incapability to read the signs. I mean, once you've made a woman throw up in her mouth, what's left? With such a great villain, Vaughn doesn't have to force himself to be likable, not that he doesn't play it smooth either with Kate. She ultimately joins the team and after winning a regional match against Girl Scouts (the twist is hilarious), they enter the official tournament in Vegas, and gags ensues as rapidly as balls get thrown at players. And so we get the obligatory unorthodox training sessions from Patches O'Houllian, a former champion played by Rip Torn, some hilarious moments that would make any 80s baby recall the "Simpsons", from the classic "you made me bleed my own blood" to the hilarious spoof of 50s politically incorrect 50s educationals clips with a fun performance from Hank Azaria as a young Patches. Add to that an unrecognizable Missi Pyle as a foreign athlete with an impossible name, hilarious cameos from David Hasselhoff, Chuck Norris or William Shatner and last but not least, some awkward interactions between other "Office Space" star Gary Cole and Jason Bateman as the show's commentators, "Dodgeball" never leaves thirty seconds going without a gag or a funny line. But it all comes down to the rivalry between Vaughn and Stiller, the insecure Napoleon surrounded by thugs with the name of Blade, Laser, Blazer or Me'Chell, and the dude who's so humble and modest you don't even notice that he towers over everyone. Vaughn doesn't play Peter as a good but rather a straight man, and with all the zaniness surrounding him, he's as well-cast as the stoic and no-nonsense Bob Hoskins in "Who Framed Roger Rabbit". Some of his verbal interactions with Stiller are just funny because he doesn't even try to outsmart his opponent while the other tries so hard he fails lamentably. "Dodgeball" took me back to a bygone time where humor could allow itself to be as raunchy, vulgar and outrageous as it gets without ever making it a vital concern to be offensive to a community: the early 2000s. Movies that allowed two straight guys to make gay jokes in "The 40-Year Old Virgin" or a blackface to be a plot element in "Tropic Thunder". It's fair to say that such movies would be impossible to make for there are guidelines now that infected the creative process up to the casting. Some Youtubers even conceded, while reacting to their first viewing that it was the early 2000s and I was saddened not to detect a hint of nostalgia. Maybe it's a generational thing but as a proud early Millennial, I could savor the humor of "Dodgeball" like a good old South Park episode for it's not just funny, it's also very smart. You earn your happy ending with laughs, heart-warming moments and clever twists. Let's hope the sequel lives up to its predecessor...

Review-Title: How to use the five d as rules of dodging
Review-Description: This film came out it's rib tickling funny comedy in yrs. Ben stiller and Vince Vaughn pitted against each other as little gym owner vs Goliath gym owner you,ll laugh dodge duck dive dip dive and laugh a lot as the two business owners settle their difference in a dodgeball comp in Las Vegas as average Joe's owes a lot of tax and the prize money is the bonus and when their team learns of the rules and when training starts painfully with a legend adda champ patches o,houilhan peter lefleur (Vaughan)as purple cobras gym led by egomanical white Goodman who wants everything in this over top underdog rags to riches tale with balls out fun. 7/10 a big hit with a budget of 23 million.

Review-Title: Silly Sports Comedy Hits the Small Screen!!
Review-Description: Dodgeball: A True Underdog Story is the tale of a gym owned by an everyday sort of guy that, because of bad finances, might lose his gym to a man who runs a neighboring lucrative. This man is named White Goodman who is played by comedic genius Ben Stiller (Meet the Parents). The owner of the gym with bad finances is a man named Peter La Fleur who is played wonderfully in this movie with great dry comedic timing by Vince Vaughn (Rudy). After being informed by a bank lawyer named Kate Veatch, played nicely by Christine Taylor (Zoolander) that Peter's finances on his gym are not up enough to par to keep the gym Peter rallies a group of friends from the gym to find some ways to find the $50,000 to save his gym from faltering on the mortgage. The best idea that Peter and friends can come up with is playing competitive dodgeball with a chance to win a $50,000 pot if the team is good enough to make it all the way to make to the Las Vegas Finals an win it!! While the hilarity of the movie starts as soon as the movie begins the fun really begins as the group starts to play dodgeball!! Dodgeball is a terrific movie!! Stiller as the obnoxiously overdriven gym owner is just as funny as Peter the laid back gym owner!! Whoever picked this cast did a superb job, there's even a cameo by Jason Bateman as a color commentator for TV of the dodgeball games that Average Joe's Gym plays in - that's the name of Peter's gym team. Bateman's commentary is almost completely irrelevant, making it completely hilarious. On a side note, the uniform colors of gold and maroon picked by Average Joe's Gym were a tribute to the Hickory Huskers of the movie Hoosiers, a small fact that I learned on a retrospective about this movie a few years back. The acting is good but the comedy is the key in this film with this being a comedic movie. Rawson Marshall Thurber did a fantastic job directing a wide ranging group of talent in this comedic gem. Marshall Thurber also did a spot on job writing a purely unique story that is an original and is still fun to see to this day!! Theodore Shapiro did a nice job with the soundtrack, it supported when need be and was timely as well. Carol Ramsey did a fine job costuming all of the various characters in the movie. Dodgeball: A True Underdog Story received a PG-13 rating when it was released in 2004 so it is perfect for those 13 and up looking for a good laugh. 7 out of 10 stars!!

Review-Title: Hilarious! Couldn't have been created by Hollywood
Review-Description: This movie is so hilarious! This is about a washed out coach that is trying to get his old career alive again, but he is struggling with the modern world. Reconnected with his old male athletes, they're competing 15 years later in the professional basketball competition. Having found a way with the assistance of his daughter and being helped by a career focused journalist, they're playing yet again for the championship. This time they are playing in the female league. Throughout the whole movie I was laughing. Having transmen play in a women competition, they're crushing all records, one after the other. Hollywood could never make a movie like this with references to the new Snowwhite movie.

They tried to mock trans athletes but it's only mocking how clueless the writers are of trans athletes and sports in general. Airbud had a better storyline than this trash. When a movie tries too hard to be offensive and less time being funny, it just looks like a straight to stream type of movie. I will not be shocked when Daily Wire's movie production department goes bankrupt from making bad movie after bad movie. If they want to succeed, hire actual writers to make their movies instead of letting hacks who couldn't write a Hollywood movie script. Unless they're just using ChatGPT, which would make sense.

Pretty bad, the pacing is terrible and the movie is incredibly bloated, it is nearly two hours long. Not funny or triggering, something about trying too hard to make something triggering or offensive makes it the opposite for me. This movie also has some of the most obvious and explicit editing/audio mistakes I have ever seen in a film. I want to point out that Ben Shapiro and Jeremy Boreing themselves admitted that the original plan for this movie was to be a documentary. They said they tried to get men to play in women's sports and failed. It turns out the fake world they have built isn't real and women's sports have rules and standards when it comes to transgender players. If you have no sense of humor and like 2000s comedies, or you are middle-aged and can't stop thinking about trans people, this movie might be for you.

This is the type of movie that's gets more funny when you are watching with friends. It has several quotable lines, and my husband and I will sometimes quote lines to each other. I was worried it would be just okay, but I was pleasantly surprised. No, the acting isn't the greatest, but it's not really required for a social commentary/ commentary. TLDR will make you laugh, will make you think, and surprisingly heartfelt. The cameos of Ben Shapiro, Michael Knowles, and Matt Walsh especially are the highlight. Oh, and Tyler Fischer. Freaking hilarious. He made me laugh more than probably anyone.

Wow - from start to finish the acting was remarkable given the actors mental conditions - it's hard to think, let alone speak, with the disabilities that these actors clearly suffer from so painfully. I wish I had known it was "written" by Daily wire, or even who Daily wire was for that matter before committing that much of my life to suffer through it. Now I can see that the concept of the movie was scooped gingerly out of the Daily wire toilet, which is apparently where they find all of their best ideas about fear mongering, bigotry and division. The movie is kind of like watching a confused bloke poke the tips of his fingers together shaking his head in scared confusion. Given that this is their first direct to internet movie we must cut them some slack and give them some advice... so I gave them an extra star. Daily wire should stick to what they do well... from what I can tell this is "making money from idiots"... but there is enough of that already in the US, so instead they should find the closest cliff and help guide evolution back in the right direction. It's almost as funny as my late Dad's Cancer.

It was the funniest movie since the last American Pie and way more thought provoking, with way more truth bombs than I expected. This should be watched as a family with questions answered throughout. It even contained a few truth bombs for conservatives to ponder about ourselves. If your liberal, consider skipping this because I don't believe movies should blindside you when you come for entertainment. If your liberal and open minded, you will enjoy the other side of the coin. This movie isn't for young children, as it could cause more confusion than it clears up. Watch this with some alcohol or late at night for the best results, as it is slapstick.

Review-Title: A film so badly done it can't even hit its intended target.
Review-Description: It's a poorly produced, poorly acted film where the jokes are basically Conservative grievances communicated in a funny voice and/or with a funny face but nobody has the talent of Jim Carey to pull something like that off. It's also tragically ironic that it targets trans people but wildly overshoots the mark and ends up being more of a denigration of women's sports in general than a film criticising the presence of trans women in sports. Perhaps that was the intention of the writers, but that would imply they had enough talent to pull off multiple intentions at the same. Did anyone who blatantly gave this 10/10 because of the subject matter notice this? Unsurprisingly no. It's also hard to only view this as a silly comedy when it was clearly made with hateful intent. It was made with the same attitude a bully has when telling jokes at the expense of their victims and if that's not a problem for you, well that says it all. Just an unpleasant experience all round.

Review-Title: Its ok if you understand what your going to watch
Review-Description: It was ok , had some funny moments for sure, it's kind of like an after school special from back in the 80/90's had a baby with The cannonball run movies, you'll know what I mean when you watch it. It has some moral lessons that I personally agree with, but everyone has their own opinion, I'm trying not to go there with my review. I realize this movie was done on a very small budget, so if you can get past that, and know what you're getting into you'll probably enjoy it. It's Family friendly even with the subject matter. You can tell they had fun making it and didn't take them selves serious. It's worth a watch at least once. It is what it is .

Review-Title: Probably would have been funny in the 90's, but eh, not now. Just boring.
Review-Description: South Park made this joke a couple of years ago and it was hilarious, heck, it's still as funny as ever. However, Daily Wire made a full feature movie just about it and there are jokes better told in a certain length than try to stretch it as long as possible. Furthermore, the acting wasn't very good, the comedy in itself could've worked for a 90's movie no problem, it's just that shtick has gotten tiresome, boring, and unoriginal. The Right says the Left can't meme, yet here we are where DW made a not-so funny movie and South Park did it far better in just 20mins, or even just 1m30s if you count just that one epic scene with him and Strongwoman.

Folks, it's a low budget movie. Literally. So let's not get excited thinking we have a 'knock it out of the park' classic on our hands. It was amusing and I appreciated that it wasn't super 'Christian'. That wasn't the point. The point was to make fun of an absurd twilight zone we are in with men in women's sports. Acting was fine, script was fine. The ending was on point. Honestly it was a relief to have a chuckle at this nonsense. That's the point of a comedy, to be a little offensive and true and get a laugh. I haven't watched much comedy lately because it's just so redundant. It's worth a watch, but manage your expectations.

I was born in 2011 and I first saw it when I was 3 or 2 can't remember. And I just wanted to say I still freaking LOVE this film and the animation is amazing. This might possibly be my favorite Pixar movie and maybe (I know this sounds insane) better than Toy Story (my opinion) freaking Toy Story! It's plot is funny and apparently is kind of like rocky?
