(This is insane because I'm 12 and have never seen rocky I know I'm sorry). The Cars look great and even though I'm not a 2000s kid it's still part of my childhood. Mater is adorable and hilarious. McQueen is super selfish at the beginning but he grows out of it and then is really caring and even gets a girlfriend! (Bro got that McQueen rizz) Great movie and a Pixar classic that is a masterpiece in my heart and I love it. Parents there is not really that much to say about this because while there are a couple if adult jokes your kids won't understand and they'll be fine. There's like two not even violent parts. If your kids can handle Other kids movies they can most certainly handle this. This is a great Pixar masterpiece and in my top 20 favorite films! 9/10.

So the shiny, red, "Lightning McQueen" is determined to make it to distant California to compete in the "Piston Cup". Along the way he stops off in the small town of "Radiator Springs" where he manages to tear up their road. His punishment? Well they have a giant tarmac laying machine, so he has to get it to resurface the road before he can be on his merry way. This isn't an easy task, and in order to finish that job he's going to have to find some allies. That's not so easy for this cocky and tunnel-visioned character, but as he gradually starts to listen, learns and make friends, he realises that there is much more to life than this one race! There's a gently bubbling moral to the story - learning to value the more important things in life like friendship, teamwork and self-reliance, and the characterisations of "Sally" - a lithe and stylish Porsche and "Mater" - a tow truck that looks like it's held together by Wrigley's and good will, help drum this message into "Lightning' and the watching audience. There's plenty of colourful and vibrant action alongside quite a bit of humour (and puns!) from the writing to keep it going and although I found this a bit wordy - and perhaps just a little too focussed for internal (US) consumption, it's still an enjoyable start to what I assume will become quite a flexible franchise.

Wow, I Found So Many Bad Reviews On The 2nd Movie. I Thought These Movies, Including Cars 2 Were Amazing. I Used To Watch This & Cars 2 When I Was Little, I Loved Them A-LOT, & I Still Do. But Cars 3 Was The Best Trilogy Of This Franchise. Lightning McQueen Is A Brave Race-Car. Tow Mater The Tow-Truck Is The Best Character. Sally Carrera Is Nice. Flo Is Not The Best, Just Decent. Ramone Is Amazing, Especially When He Changes His Paint Every 1nce In Awhile. Luigi & Guido Are Good Characters. Fillmore Awesome. Sarge Is Not The Best, But Great. Sheriff Is Amazing. Doc Is A Good Character (R. I. P). Red The Firetruck Is Relatable, When He's Shy. Lizzie Is Funny. Frank Is Hilarious, Especially When He Chases Down Lightning McQueen & Mater At My Favorite Part. Chick Hicks Makes A Good Villain. The King Is While Not The Best, But Amazing. The Tuner Cars Boost, DJ, Wingo, & Snot-Rod Are Badass. This Movie, & Cars 2 Were Nostalgic/Nostalgia. I Think Cars 3 Was The Best Cars Movie. Yes, I Think A 3-Quel Coming Out At Age 10 Is Better Than The Childhoods. Anyways, That's My Review. I'll Review The Other 2, Soon. RATING: Amazing Movie (100/100).

Review-Title: "The Film That Made Me Who I Am"
Review-Description: Ok so just hear me out. Disney Pixar Cars is my all time favorite Disney Movie, yes it's not the best but it's still a great film and a fun one at best. It has a great story with Lighting McQueen who is a hot shot rookie racer who comes across an abandoned town and has to get used to the scenery around it which makes him miss his race, but in the end he learns a lot and it makes him realize that there is more to racing than just winning. The animation is beautiful and the characters are extremely likable and relatable. But the reason why I love this movie so much is because it made me who I am, and that's a race car driver. When I was young, this movie was a huge part of my childhood, watching it a lot with my family, playing with the toys, video games, and going to Disneyland to ride the Cars ride. This movie means so much to me as it taught me many things about not just racing, but good human qualities like being a good friend, learning from the best and accepting change. This movie also got me into my biggest hobby and that's racing. I became a huge NASCAR fan after the movie when I learned more about it and I instantly became hooked. But the biggest this movie has done is that it made me an actual race car driver. Racing has been a huge part of my life and it's been a dream of mine to become a race driver, and this movie did just that. It inspired me to become a driver, learn more about cars and try to follow your dreams of becoming a champion. Overall, I'm so grateful that this movie has done for me in the long run, as it made me who I am today. Cars is indeed a great film to watch especially for kids and families alike and this movie crosses the finish line and is a winner to everyone who watches it! And always remember, there is more to racing than just winning, and without your friends, your trophy is just an empty cup. Ka Chow!

This is an outstanding instalment to begin the series for everyone to watch and really enjoy. The crew did a fine job with the storyline. The storyline had it all. The cat selection was sensational. They committed and connected to the storyline and to their respective characters. This instalment reveals to viewers the true definitions of multiple specific aspects of life that can help anyone through the difficulties that they may be facing. My life has always been real difficult. Whatever I try to do about it, it does not work. This is a spectacular instalment to start off an astonishing series for all viewers to watch and enjoy.

Review-Title: I liked it and I disliked it
Review-Description: For most of my reviews, I have plenty of things to say but I really don't how much to say about this because I just think there qualities but is has so much little problems taking it down I didn't like the first half, it was screaming right at you're face that its made for children. A cocky main protagonist and an antagonist and a lot of those children's movie cliche you can think. The side characters weren't really anything special and so is radiator springs plus McQueen is such a jerk for a long time that makes the first half just plain out the opposite of enjoyable. The 2nd half gets much better but it's still isn't Pixar level good. McQueen isn't a jerk anymore but his love for that blue car isn't really fleshed out and their chemistry isn't anything special. I thought the ending was pretty wholesome though Rating: 6.7/10.

Review-Title: If you keep talking to yourself people will think you're crazy. I wasn't talking to you
Review-Description: McQueen, a young person who's currently really popular, and doesn't respect his elders or history, leading to themes things changing over time, appreciating what you have now, and acknowledging that some things were better before they changed, of course has to learn it's not all about winning and to let go of his ego. When we meet him, he is taking credit for others' help, and not treating the equivalent of service workers well, as he himself is a celebrity with lots of fans, like a sports star. He gets community service. This also has more empathy for immigrants than A Bug's Life, from the same studio. By now, you know what Pixar brings to the table: emotionally resonant story, talented voice actors, memorable characters, detailed and highly effective animation that uses color and lighting really well, jokes for adults and ones for kids, very exciting action, and a fun world - here, all people and various other living creatures, including bugs and farm animals, are cars and other vehicles. I recommend this to everyone. 8/10.

This film has its flaws but it's still a very solid film and a childhood classic for most people. The part I most appreciate about this film after watching it at an older age is the theme of old ideas, places and even people being replaced with more modern alternatives. A main plot point of the film is that route 66 was once a place full of life and offered the cars a place socialise and enjoy driving through, until it was eventually replaced by an interstate that just made the journey a bit quicker, but simultaneously lost all of the social enjoyment the drive would once have. This plot point in a way mirrors the world we live in today. It reminded me about blockbusters, which was a tangible place to search for films and socialise, and how it was gradually taken over by streaming services and eventually shut down. The same thing is happening with shops and restaurants, where most people want to have things ordered online and to their doorstep instead of going to the place itself. While these modern alternatives might be easier and more ideal, are we losing what made these activities so enjoyable in the first place? "Cars didn't drive on it to make good time, they drove on it to have a great time" I feel like cars has surprisingly aged very well, and each time I watch it, I find the route 66 aspect of the film more relatable and very relevant, even if that wasn't the pure intention of the film. Each time I watch it, it gets better. With all this being said I did watch it on Disney+

Wow, where do I even begin with Cars (2006)? This movie exceeded my expectations in every way possible and left me feeling so incredibly entertained and satisfied. Pixar has once again proven that they are masters of storytelling and animation. When I first heard about Cars, I have to admit, I was a bit skeptical. How could a movie featuring only vehicles, with no human characters, keep me engaged for a full two hours? But Pixar managed to do just that, and more. Director John Lasseter's attention to detail is truly remarkable. Every car and truck in the movie becomes a unique character with its own personality. The way they bend and gesture in ways that are true to their construction is just incredible. It's these small details that make the world of Cars so immersive and believable. And speaking of the world, the story itself is filled with charm and heart. Yes, it may contain a well-traveled theme, but it's delivered in such a way that it feels fresh and meaningful. I found myself genuinely caring about Lightning McQueen's journey and rooting for him every step of the way. Now, I'm not a racing fan by any means, but that didn't stop me from enjoying this movie. You don't need to be a racing enthusiast to appreciate the story and the characters. The film goes beyond the world of racing and delves into themes of self-discovery, friendship, and the importance of slowing down and enjoying life. It's a message that resonated with me, and I'm sure it will resonate with many others as well. Visually, Cars is a feast for the eyes. The animation is stunning, and the attention to detail is mind-blowing. The scenery is so beautifully rendered that it's hard to believe it's not real. From the reflections on the cars to the weeds growing out of cracks in the sidewalk, every little detail has been meticulously crafted. It's a visual spectacle that left me in awe. But impressive visuals alone are not enough to make a great movie. Thankfully, Cars delivers on all fronts. The characters are well-developed, and the story is engaging. Pixar took the time to give us a movie that is not just visually stunning, but also emotionally resonant. They didn't succumb to the pressure of making a shorter film to cater to shorter attention spans. Instead, they stayed true to their vision and created a movie that is both entertaining and meaningful. Cars started off with a disadvantage in my eyes, but it quickly won me over. It made me care about its characters and their journey. It made me reflect on my own life and the importance of slowing down and enjoying the journey. It made me want to take a road trip and explore the unknown. It made me appreciate the scenic route. In the end, Cars is a testament to Pixar's ability to create movies that go beyond entertainment. It's a movie that makes you care about something other than yourself, even if just for a little while. It's a movie that reminds us of the power of storytelling and the magic of animation. Pixar has once again made it look simple, but we all know that creating a movie as wonderful as Cars takes a tremendous amount of talent and hard work. I can confidently give Cars a rating of 8 out of 10, and I highly recommend it to anyone who appreciates a well-crafted story and breathtaking animation.

I have watched this movie countless times since it's release and I am still not sick of it yet. When my daughter was born we introduced her to it and she requested AGAIN AGAIN. Even after all those agains I could again and again still which says a lot about the quality of the movie. All the characters are great and work really well together. Owen Wilson as the stuck up McQueen is perfect for this role. The story is pretty good and it's funny to see the cars world vs the human world. There are some questions that have occurred to me over the watchings like where do baby cars come from. But I will ask an adult about that later. For now I will just recommend this again and again.

Review-Title: Two men, two worlds, one goal
Review-Description: The movie is based on the duality of its two main characters, who are both giving it their all to win the Olympic gold medal. Harold Abrahams faces an internal conflict, he runs to overcome his identity, he wants to be known as a runner rather than as a Jew. Eric Liddell, on the other hand, knows and accepts exactly who he is and where he stands, he runs to further embrace his faith and honour his Creator. Despite the major differences in their background, their mentality and their state of mind, it's clear that they are both decent, virtuous men, products of a bygone era and that could explain why I found it hard to relate with them and lost interest fairly quickly. Even though I wasn't familiar with the real life events, the predictable outcome didn't help in that regard either. The highlight of the film is Vangelis' wonderful music and the main reason the opening scene remains ever so iconic, his Oscar was well-deserved. The running scenes are well crafted, though I couldn't help but laugh with Eric's running style. Britain looks as green and as beautiful as ever. The movie succeeds in depicting nicely both the time (early '20s) and the place (the atmosphere of Cambridge in particular).

Review-Title: A great film of international and personal rivalry in sport.
Review-Description: A great film of international and personal rivalry in sport. You're genuinely interested in the two different athletes and how they relate to each other, why they run. The soundtrack is pretty memorable too. I really did enjoy this movie a lot. It sort of grows on you and by the time we get to the Olympics it really has picked up. The costumes, production design help take you back to the 1920s. There were a few small details and inventions which I had a gripe with but some artistic license I guess is what you expect in a historical film. I'd recommend this film to people of all ages, regardless of their interest in sport or not.

These British films that end up winning Best Picture always end up feeling so out of place. If I were transported back to before the ceremony, my guess on winner would probably have been Atlantic City or On Golden Pond, just based on the Academy's recent proclivity to awarding films with big movie stars in films that focused mostly on performances by those stars. A film about characters overcoming obstacles to win a sports event, especially one with such a focus on one of its main character's devotion to his Christianity, feels as out of place as A Man for all Seasons was. The film is really about Harold Abrahams (Ben Cross), whose funeral bookends the film, and Eric Liddel (Ian Charleson), but we get a curious focus on both Aubrey Montague (Nicholas Farrell) and Lord Andrew Lindsay (Nigel Havers) at the same time. Lord Lindsay does something important later for Liddel, but there's a fair amount of screentime dedicated to both of the latter two characters despite none of the actual dramatics being about them. Anyway, all four are amateur runners of the British Empire. All but Liddel are students at Cambridge, while Liddel is a noted rugby player who takes up running as his passion in preparation for the 1924 Olympics. The central character beats are that Abrahams is a Jew in a time and place where antisemitism was still accepted in the upper crust of society and that Liddel is a devoted Christian (raised on a Chinese mission and dedicated to returning to it) who has to choose between his dedication to his God and his dedication to his athletic pursuits. I do think the film is a good one, but I see both of these, as presented in the film, as making mountains out of molehills. Abrahams is enrolled in Cambridge and not barred from anything he wants to do, just subjected to the occasional snide comment about his Jewishness while never denied anything. Liddel faces no conflict between his faith and his athletic competitions until late in the film, and it's introduced and solved within minutes. I know that the producer, David Puttnam, was looking for a story about men who would not yield to outside pressure to violate their beliefs (in the vein of A Man for All Seasons), but this is small beans. Anyway, the story is about the handful of men pushing themselves to their limits in order to win their athletic competitions. Liddel has a great moment where he's pushed to the ground near the start of the race, gets up, and then pushes himself to his absolute limits to win. Harold watches this race and feels the need to enlist the aid of Sam Mussabini (Ian Holm), a running coach, a decision that makes the deans of Cambridge none too happy in a scene that could have been hard cut out of the film and no one would have noticed. It does have an ironic coda later, but it should be noted that their protestations have nothing to do with Harold's Jewishness and everything to do with his hiring a professional coach, and not even Harold brings up the idea that the excuse is a screen for some sort of motive against his ethnicity and religion. Instead, he goes off and starts seeing the singer Sybil (Alice Krige), who adores him. Of course, the film is a multi-year journey as they prepare for the Olympics, and the Olympics dominate the final third of the film as they go to Paris, meet the Prince of Wales, the eventual Edward VIII, (David Yelland), and Liddel has his moment of strength when the 100-meter heat is scheduled for a Sunday, and he refuses to race on a Sunday. The scene around the British legation, including the Prince of Wales, trying to pressure Liddel into racing on Sunday despite his beliefs, is a good one for sure, but the obstacle is introduced and dispatched (by Lord Lindsay) so quickly that it almost feels like an afterthought rather than a central dramatic tenet of the film. The dramatics are where the movie doesn't succeed very well, but as a portrait of two men pushing themselves to the physical extreme, it's kind of great. The exhaustion of the effort, the passion put into it, the sacrifices made are all wonderfully demonstrated and dramatized on screen. Liddel's real central drama isn't around running on Sunday but in conflict with his sister Jennie (Cheryl Campbell) who thinks that Eric is dedicated too much time to his training instead of his work as a mission in Scotland (before he goes back to China, of course), as well as Harold in conflict with Sybil and Sam, his efforts never quite being good enough for the latter but taking him away from the former. It's also an interesting portrait of a time when post-modernism was taking hold in culture but the cultural institutions hadn't embraced it yet. The sense of traditionalism was still strong, as evidenced by people like the Master of Trinity College (John Gielgud), but the dedication to the concept of nationhood was already fraying, as evidenced by the early interaction with WWI veterans, scarred by the war. It's a handsome film that can't quite bring its central dramatics to the heights of something like, yes, A Man for All Seasons, a story about a man who put his life on the line for his beliefs and paid for it compared to a film about a young man who put his athletic career on the line for his beliefs, and then found a way around it. It works more as a portrait than as a dramatic retelling of the events around the British running team at the 1924 Olympics, but that portrait is really quite good. Still, its win at the Oscars feels so out of place.

It is the 1924 Paris Olympics. Who will represent Great Britain? The decision will not only be based on athletic abilities but social standing and religion. Everyone has his or her agenda from the promoters to the runners themselves. In the end, compromises must be made but for the final chosen there can be no compromise to win. This is a movie that holds your attention on several levels. Many of the actors are easily recognizable but they do not overshadow the characters they represent. The scenery is switched from Scotland countryside to Cambridge, and France (actually shot in England). Of course, as depicted in the cover picture the most notable is the run along the beach (West Sands Beach, St Andrews, Scotland, UK.) Then the music, most noticeable in the beach scenes but permeated the movie will stay with you for years (Original music by Vangelis.) The story is based on true events with scriptwriter Colin Welland bringing what would just be facts to life making you feel that you are back in the time and taking part in the race.

Review-Title: Ephemeral Sports Spectacle Receives a Visual and Musical Overhaul
Review-Description: With its remarkable cinematography, authentic period production design, innovative musical score, and stellar performances, "Chariots of Fire" appears, at first glance, to be a well-deserving recipient of the Academy Award for Best Picture. Yet, when you peel back the layers, turning a small slice of sports history into a grandiose cinematic affair feels like a rather feeble excuse for making a feature film. Let's be honest; an event like the 1924 Olympics is about as ephemeral as they come. Even in its time, the achievements of the central figures, British track and field stars Harold Abrahams (played by Ben Cross) and Eric Liddell (portrayed by Ian Charleson), hardly qualify as legendary. While Abrahams did secure a win in the 100-meter race and Liddell claimed victory in a group event for the 400 meters, both men participated in other races during the Olympics and didn't always finish first. Oddly enough, the film's script conveniently glosses over this fact. Nevertheless, "Chariots of Fire" manages to weave a compelling narrative that momentarily distracts you from the realization that you're watching a movie about a somewhat forgettable footnote in sports history. Between the two protagonists, Abrahams emerges as the more intriguing character. As a Jewish student at Cambridge facing subtle discrimination, he takes up running to prove his worth to his country despite the disdain from some stuffy faculty members (the legendary John Gielgud shines in his role as a prejudiced academic). Liddell, a Scottish Christian fundamentalist, experiences a more internal struggle as he grapples with the compatibility of his faith and competition. The pinnacle of conflict arrives when he refuses to run the 100 meters due to it falling on a Sunday. The issue finds resolution when a teammate graciously gives up his spot in the 400 meters. Apart from a scene where Liddell bests Abrahams in a pre-Olympics race, the two protagonists share limited interaction. The romantic subplot involves singer Sybil Gordon (played by Alice Krige), whose role essentially boils down to being a glorified cheerleader for Abrahams, who, let's face it, wrestles with significant angst. It's worth noting that the film's creators mixed up the character of Sybil with Sybil Evers, who later became Abrahams' real-life wife. Ian Holm portrays the other enthusiastic cheerleader in Abrahams' corner, Sam Mussabini, his highly competent trainer. Director Hugh Hudson took a bold gamble by enlisting Vangelis to compose the film's score. The music, though anachronistic for the period, manages to work wonders. The iconic opening scene on the beach, with runners synchronized to Vangelis's synth score, remains etched in cinematic history. Last but not least, the film's production design, replete with magnificent costumes and painstakingly recreated historical settings, particularly the 1924 Olympics, stands out for its impeccable attention to detail and authenticity.

Still I give it a 6 and not a 5, because it does have some things going for it. The wonderful and unique soundtrack by Vangelis for example. And then there is also good acting and great cinematography. There's always something nice for the eyes to see or the ears to hear. However the characters seem to be missing something and feel bland. The story sounds good and inspiring in theory and it isn't bad, it's just that it was simply too stretched out and predictable. I found myself watching the remaining time a lot and asking myself just when the story will make some interesting points or manages to make me invested... sadly it didn't. With all the good reviews and awards this movie received, I just hoped for some more. I'll still say go watch it, as maybe I'm an exception here. It's still worth a look.

Others more talented than I have analyzed this film to the nth degree. They come at it from an example of pro-Christianity to the foibles of a world where we are controlled by such things. I also read that there are numerous inaccuracies in this film, concerning the two principle players. A little bit of Hollywood. But the problem is that the Hollywood diminishes the effect of the film, in my opinion. If the guy knew well ahead that his race was going to be on a Sunday, then the business of a last minute decision is bogus. Also, there is a degree of generosity given to the Olympic committee that simply would not have taken place. It is about courage to an extent, but I hesitate to give it too much credit. If you buy into a religion then buy into it. Don't make these guys martyrs because they can't run a race. No one will die. No one's life will be destroyed. They continue to have the adulation of their fans. I think the only part that bothered me was the snooty Oxford guys and their anti-semitism, enjoying the challenges of the Jewish guy.

The opening bars of the Oscar-winning Vangelis score coupled with the shot of the athletes running along the beach, barefoot, at St. Andrews is amongst the most iconic opening scenes from any film, but somehow the rest of this strays all too often into mediocrity thereafter. It tells the story of two British athletes who strove to thrive at the Olympiad in Paris in 1924. Harold Abrahams (Ben Cross) comes from a Lithuanian Jewish background. Who is welcomed to Cambridge University, but never quite accepted. The other is Eric Liddell (Ian Charleson), a devout Christian who comes from missionary stock and who believes that he must serve God before himself - and that includes not running any races on the Sabbath. Both of these men have considerable athletic skills, and the story intertwines their efforts to get to the Games, whilst both must deal with their differing priorities and challenges. It's this middle portion of the film, the prologued character development phase, that all plods along too slowly. It has too little pace and too many characters, and that just drags the film down. The last fifteen minutes liven up considerably though, not just with the events on the track - but amongst those determined to ensure that the whole team attains success making sacrifices and compromises along the way. It has a classy look to it, the costumes and settings are top drawer, but I found the leading performances rather disjointed and at over two hours long, I did struggle to stay engaged.

Review-Title: Never run on empty, only on full.
Review-Description: Still as amazing a sleeper of a period drama over 40 years since I first saw this upon the original release. It's still a genuine sleeper, the surprise hit of the year, winning the Academy Award over several blockbusters and artistic hits. Today, it's best known for the unique musical score written by Vangelis, perhaps simple to certain ears but so much more when you hear it in context with the story. It's 1924, and a promising young group of British athletes are preparing for the Olympics. The film focuses on two, Ben Cross and Ian Charleson, with slightly more focus on Cross who is Jewish and faces subtle anti-Semitism everywhere he goes. Much praise went to Ian Holm, receiving the film's only acting Oscar nomination for his role as Cross's stern but devoted coach. No nonsense in his efforts to see Cross go the distance as a top notch runner, it's a very commanding performance that is filled with subtlety. Also important to the story (and beating Holm at the Oscars) is John Gielgud as one of the top dogs at the university Cross and Charleson attend. It's the type of role he could probably play in his sleep, but he gets every detail right, creating another unforgettable performance. As a drama of determined discipline and loyalty to their dreams, this film is practically perfect, including several terrific Gilbert and Sullivan performances. Some familiar faces, not well known at the time, makes another highlight, and the tension rises through early competition, training sessions and finally the Olympics themselves, nearly a century ago. By the time this film is over, you'll be getting chills every time the theme music is heard, getting more emotional each time especially since it is altered throughout depending on the intensity of what's happening.

This movie is about two runners who are running a sprint at 1924, Paris Olympic Games. It's veru emotionnal because with one runner, we cas see how religion affects his life. This movie also shows how religion can be a strength for him. I think it's quite good because, this film reflects two sports identities. Two different reasons for running but only one goal. We also saw the competition, the work, the sacrifies, the excitement etc. In the sport world. In overall I liked it but it's not a film I recommend and that I will go to see at the cinema, becauseit's an old movie and it's not an amazing movie, it's just a good film. Yes for me, it's a boring film but realistic so for that, on a scale of 0 to 10 I give this film a 5.

In my 18 years on this earth, I have watched countless great movies. This movie, oh, this movie changed me. I wish I could take back the 1 hour and 45 minutes I wasted on this movie. I wish I could go back to the person I was before this movie. This movie single-handedly broke me. I have watched terrible movies before but this one takes the cake. I thought I could handle it because, hello Channing Tatum, but even with all of his hotness, the movie was still so hard to watch. The main character made me want to skin my scalp and staple it back on. Please save yourself the trouble and don't watch it. I wouldn't wish this movie on my worst enemy.

When I started this movie, I was extremely bored and just watched whatever YouTube had for free. This made me really judgy and I hated it within the first 10 minutes because it was predictable and boring and, let's be honest, the coach at Cornwall had a point. But as the movie went on, I began loving the characters and, well, Channing Tatum was in the movie and well...üëå. The character's were so funny and didn't feel disconcerted from the movie. You'll be cheering for the two main characters as they fall in love, you'll cheer as they play soccer(and I don't even like soccer), etc. Long story short, the movie was sweet, hilarious, and yes it was predictable like all romance movies but you still love it anyway. I recommend this movie.

Review-Title: A bit disappointing but still fun
Review-Description: She's the Man is based on a very silly concept that it uses well to create some fun, but it does feel a little too stretched to really impress. The highlight of the film is the fantastic lead performance from Amanda Bynes, who really shines as both Viola and Sebastian. It's a performance full of great comedy and physical acting, and it really brings the film together. There are some solid supporting performances, even if they are all a little overacted, with Channing Tatum as the stand out. As mentioned the story is very silly but fun, nothing more than that really. It maybe could have been taken further and the concept used to create a bit more chaos and fun. It's all very predictable but it works. Like a lot of movies from this era, it does have a good feel and tone to it which is welcome, and it does make for a light hearted and breezy film. Overall I was expecting a little more from She's the Man, but it is still fun nonetheless.

This film begins with a high school student named "Viola" (Amanda Bynes) being informed that her chances of winning a college scholarship for soccer have been destroyed due to the sport being cut from the program. Still wanting to be able to demonstrate her skills to college recruiters, Viola then goes to the boys' soccer coach, but he not only dismisses her request, but also humiliates her in the process as well. Even worse, her boyfriend "Justin" (Robert Hoffman) also joins in the laughter. Infuriated by this, Viola immediately breaks up with him. Not long afterward, she learns that her twin brother "Sebastian" (James Kirk) is secretly heading out of town for two weeks and--since he is living with their dad and is set to attend a different school not far away--she decides to masquerade as a guy and try out for the boys' soccer team there instead. Obviously, this subterfuge presents enough challenges on its own, but what she doesn't count on is the fact that Sebastian's girlfriend "Monique" (Alexandra Breckenridge) is looking for Sebastian and has a habit of appearing out of nowhere at the worst possible times. Neither does Viola factor into the equation the possibility that she might fall in love with one of the soccer players named "Duke" (Channing Tatum). Or for that matter, that Duke might have a crush on the prettiest girl in school named "Olivia Lennox" (Laura Ramsey)--who quickly becomes attracted to Viola's version of Sebastian. Now, rather than reveal any more, I will just say that I was expecting this film to be nothing more than a remake of the movie "Just One of the Guys" which came out 19 years earlier. And as such, I wasn't expecting it to be nearly as entertaining. To my delight, I turned out to be quite wrong, as I found this movie to be just as good with Amanda Bynes putting in a really good performance all along the way. That being said, I can understand it if there are some viewers who prefer "Just One of the Guys" over this as it came out first and seems more original. Be that as it may, I found this movie to be quite entertaining and I have rated it accordingly. Above average.

Review-Title: Typical Teen RomCom from the early 00s.
Review-Description: I've heard this movie mentioned by a few friends as very fun, and I'm thinking that is more the nostalgia speaking. It is fairly pleasant and mildly entertaining, I'll admit but "very fun" it is not. It's also definitely a product of its time, completely corny and predictable with some questionable jokes. There are definitely better movies to watch in that genre from that era so if you have to be picky about what you're watching I would say you can skip She's The Man, you wont' be missing much. But if you need something in the background you don't really have to think about much, knock yourself out.

Within the plethora of teen movies of this period, it's easy to dismiss and overlook them. However, I was pleasantly surprised after watching this film at how fun this movie is. It's well written and is exactly what it should be - a fun, tangled case of mixed up identities. The performances of the actors, including Bynes and Tatum, is fun too and there are some genuinely funny moments. Finally, it's refreshing that there are actually some queer moments that aren't shied away from - from Sebastian/Viola slapping girls on the asses, to Viola's gay best friend, Paul, canoodling with his own football player at the end. It was good film!

Review-Title: "...and when I close my eyes, I see you for who you truly are, which is UUUG-LAY."
Review-Description: Entertaining comedic timing from Amanda Bynes, effortlessly shining in the lead role as Viola and showcasing her versatile comedic range. Her impersonation of Viola's twin brother, Sebastian, is silly and really funny (the fake Jamaican accent she uses to sound cool had me laughing so much). Channing Tatum is equally awesome in a more subtle supporting comedy role as the roommate-friend turned love interest, sharing a sweet chemistry with Bynes in her dual role. The sexism and gender politics in sports theme is well crafted through the storyline. Also, big praise to whoever hand-selected this film's brilliant soundtrack; meshes seamlessly with each scene's vibe and atmosphere. A must-watch sports rom-com from the 2000s and one of Bynes BEST films! A good pick too if you're looking for a feel-good film to watch.

Review-Title: Amanda Bynes is a comic genius
Review-Description: Almost all child actors have problems because of the crazy lifestyle of working as an adult with adults, so it's good that she's retreated to finding a normal life away from Hollywood. But in addition to Shirley Temple, Bynes has been my favorite young actor. Amanda Bynes is a comic genius. She plays everything moment by moment. If you listen to the script, you can imagine how the majority of actors would say the line. What she does with each line is deliciously funny and original. All of the other actors are great, too. The writing is well thought out, cute the way they incorporating Shakespearean names into this modern homage to Twelfth Night.

I've watched this movie 3 times in 3 different stages of my life and still find it funny and romantic. Yes, it's corny at times but still cool and enjoyable. A real comedy that makes me laugh outright. It's a movie that will definitely make you happy and put a smile on your face. Don't think this is a movie for teenagers only. It's great to watch with your family or even on a date or even on your own. Very fast paced, not a dull moment and filled with different characters though some probably with exaggerated acting but still not annoying. Recommend to watch. I won't be surprised if I will watch it again and still find it funny.

The plot and character intro lasts all of 9 minutes. The only time I laughed was at how bad everything is. Pointless scenes and forced jokes that just don't land it's just embarrassing. Seriously go watch Just One of the Guys.

Great Movie, the film has many great moments, including Rockys unique training method, Rockys relationship with Adrian which gets better as the movie moves along, the fight itself is superb to watch, Thou Rockys style of taking so many punches isn't good, Bill Conti's music is superb and adds to the scenes, big praise on Stallones performance and story, Carl weather's is superb as Apollo and alot like Muhammad Ali, and the perfect showman, Rockys attitude outside the ring is very commandable, he is loyal to people he is close with, relationship with Mickey very up and down especially losing his locker, then Mickey trains him very well.

I watched it again last night, this time on some Italian channel, dubbed. I can't recall how many times this masterpiece blew my mind but I recall very well the first time I had seen it, a decade after its release, on TV... And before yesterday, 9 years ago, I had seen it on DVD with who was my beloved at the time, for whom it was a first. Why are these even worthy of mention, you might ask. I do think it is important for us to be able to enjoy a film at very different stages of our lives. When you're a kid, you'll look up to Rocky as the young man you wanna be. When you're of middle age, you'll understand better how Burt Young's character felt. And probably when we are much older, we may identify with Mikey who was lamenting about being 76, still chasing a chance, a dream. John G. Avildsen is the guy who set the standards for popularizing the most precious emotions. You just cannot neglect Karate Kid or Rocky. These are more than films. They are citadels of audiovisual culture. Watch Rocky, and then just look at a pic from some recent Sylvester Stallone movie. The difference of quality and grace is abyssmal. It just blows your mind to see that, the man who rose to fame with such a gem is today appearing in "products" that are literally nothing compared to Rocky. I won't say I don't understand it. Nor do I condemn Sly's current path. Maybe it's inevitable. Maybe it's normal that, after Rocky, you can never reach so high. There's so much to say about this movie. Yet, we don't even need to put our feelings into words. The score does it for us. The climax we reach by the ending, the victory of the guy who on paper actually lost the confrontation, the love and affection he has for the woman he has gained the heart of along the way... Rocky is not just a movie. It's that sports game you can watch again and again, knowing the result, just out of your desire to relive the emotions leading to it. There are several movies we can choose as "the best ever". And each have their power points. But to each, you can approach also in a pedantic manner and argue this or tat could have been handled better. Borrowing an analogy of Alan Watts, only to apply it to this masterpiece: "Have you ever seen a misshaped wave? Or a wrong cloud? There are no such things. They come with nature exactly as they are supposed to." To me, Rocky is to cinema what a wave or a cloud is to nature. It's perfect. Just perfect, and impossible to imagine in a different way of existing. What we feel for the protagonist of the film is the exact same as what we feel for the brains and souls behind it. Respect, respect, respect.

Review-Title: A Classic, but a very average film
Review-Description: Heard about this film for a very long time but hasent been able to watch yet until today. Heard it was gonna be good and it should, due to the very high rating on imdb. Heard it is a must watch, if your into film. Early into the film, I directly felt that i really don't understand the very high rating at all and i don't understand whats so special about it. Nothing unique to it. Pretty bad manuscript aswell at some moments. Sylvester Stallone does a average performance in his role, of some regarded to be one of his best ever. A extremely boring and slow film. Filming starts pretty bad and shaky, but gets much better the longer into the film. Good soundtrack. A Classic, but a very average film. Watchable, but do not expect too much.

Sylvester Stallone at his best, an easy but exciting plot, a controversial and borderline character. This is the recipe that makes Rocky one of the most watched, famous and appreciated films of all time. As I often say for masterpieces, raise your hand if you've never seen Rocky, look around you won't find anyone. A semi-desperate Italian boxer who scrapes by on fake jobs, in a squalid house with 2 turtles for company, will find himself facing the world heavyweight champion in Philadelphia in front of his people. Well, a sort of male Cinderella, a dream that comes true and that will change the life of both the character and the interpreter Sly forever. There's also boxing but that's marginal... Top film!

Sylvester Stallone wanted to make it in Hollywood, but he couldn't get cast in anything other than...stuff he'd rather forget he was ever near. So, he wrote his own screenplay, heavily influenced by Elia Kazan's On the Waterfront, and got it funded by the independent producers Irwin Winkler and Robert Chartoff, and they hired the largely unremarkable young filmmaker John Avildsen to direct. The result is a tender character piece that, especially when combined with its rousing score by Bill Conti, ends up a fun, touching sports film that never loses sight of what it's about: its central character. Rocky Balboa (Stallone) is semi-pro boxer with little technique but a lot of heart who wins more than he loses, but he can't get any particularly good fights since no one will manage him or really believes in him. He's alone in the world, trying to get the mousy, shy girl who works in the pet shop, Adrian (Talia Shire) to laugh at his corny jokes while working as a leg breaker for the small time loan shark Tony (Joe Spinelli). He has no real friends, the closest being Adrian's brother Paulie (Burt Young) who spends most of his time trying to convince Rocky to get him a job with Tony to get him out of his meat packing job. Essentially, the first hour of the film is a portrait of Rocky, his lonely life, and his early courtship with Adrian. It's a warm portrait of a bum, a guy who has something within him to make something of himself, but who has never applied himself quite right, as Mickey (Burgess Meredith) ends up saying, that he has wasted his potential on a little life in service of someone like Tony. He's also kind of dumb with the kinds of street smarts that at least allow him to acknowledge that he's made bad decisions in the past about who he had spent time with, as he outlines in a little rambling speech to a girl hanging out with the wrong crowd. He gets his chance, though, when the heavyweight champion of the world, Apollo Creed (Carl Weathers) has spent too much time and too much money prepping for a bicentennial fight that is at the risk of cancellation because his opponent has a broken hand. With only five weeks to train, he can't get anyone ranked to commit to the fight, so he and the promoter George Jergen (Thayer David) decide on finding a local boy in Philadelphia to fight, zeroing in on Balboa for little reason more than his nickname, the Italian Stallion. He's reticent about the prospect. Rocky understands his limits and Creed's status as the best in the world, but it becomes too good of an opportunity to pass up. I think one of the keys to how this film works is the timing of certain events. The first is that Adrian and Rocky have their moment coming together, learning to open up to each other and fall in love, before Rocky gets his shot. This cements her as the one person he knows he can trust, as contrasted with Paulie who only seems to get helpful afterwards, hoping for a slice of the guaranteed $150,000 payout from the fight, or Mickey, who had told him off before the offer and comes begging to be his manager afterwards. After years of being rejected and used and insulted, Rocky has trouble trusting anyone, and he does eventually find ways to bring people in. And that's really the point of the film. It's not the literal fight with Creed, it's Rocky discovering his connections to other people who do genuinely love him, namely Adrian. It's about him discovering for himself that he's not a bum and that he could go the distance against Creed, last all fifteen rounds. It's not about winning. It's about proving that he belongs in that field, that he hasn't wasted the last six years of his life fighting to get nowhere. It's weird how a film where the hero doesn't actually win a fight can end up so affirming. I will say for a moment, that I found the direction rather pedestrian at best. I wouldn't really comment on it much normally, except that Avildsen won Best Director at the Oscars. I have no problem with Rocky winning Best Picture, I'd probably have voted for it, but I cannot imagine Avildsen deserving that Best Director award, especially up against Syndey Lumet for Network. I often at least partially attribute good performances to directors who can help mold the work of actors, so I cannot dismiss him completely here. The actors are all very good, and that's part of the package, but this really does feel like, overall, Avildsen getting a raw and very good script fall into his lap and largely just not screwing it up. I'm fine with that as a result, but it just kind of irritates me that Avildsen beat Lumet. I don't think that Avildsen's direction is a drag on the film, though. It's nothing special, but the strength is the script and performances, and they really get a lot of help from Conti's score. I have a major soft spot for Conti's music (like on Huston's Escape to Victory), and it's largely absent from the first hour, only getting an early show during the opening credits before slowly filtering in towards the buildup to the fight. Of course, the fight itself isn't the point, it's Rocky proving himself, and that's the ultimately victory. That it becomes so satisfying is really wonderful. Just, please, don't make any sequels, Sly. Rocky doesn't need it.

Rocky remains a motivating cinematic masterpiece that continues to inspire audiences. However, there are moments where the film's pacing feels a bit sluggish. The training sequence is an absolute standout, a testament to the film's ability to invigorate and drive the story forward. Additionally, the score is nothing short of extraordinary, perfectly complementing the emotional depth of the narrative. What truly sets Rocky apart is its portrayal of the titular character as an underdog and, dare we say, something of an idiot. His ultimate victory, not in the ring, but in life, underscores the film's poignant message. Rocky's resilience and determination serve as a powerful reminder that it's not about how hard you can hit but how hard you can get hit and keep moving forward. This distinction sets Rocky apart from Apollo, who is only seeking to boost his image through the fight. Rocky's enduring spirit and will to keep moving forward is what makes this film an enduring classic.

Review-Title: The Enduring Magic of 'Rocky' Despite Boxing's Decline
Review-Description: Rocky's rocky road to glory, both on and off the screen, makes for an impressive modern-day fairy tale. The tale of Sylvester Stallone winning an Academy Award for Best Picture with his first-ever screenplay is legendary. We all rooted for the underdog who overcame his troubled past to find his self-worth. But was the boxing ring the right stage for this pyrrhic victory? Stallone's script is simplicity itself, but credit must also go to director John Avildsen, who brought a cinema verit√© style to Rocky, making it feel like a gripping docudrama. In the early drafts, Rocky was a darker, less likable character, but Stallone wisely softened him. Despite moonlighting as a loan shark collector, Rocky refused to physically harm his deadbeat clients, revealing his heart of gold. Rocky's inner demons stem from doubts about his potential as a boxer. Burgess Meredith as Mickey, a former boxer turned trainer, berates Rocky for not working hard enough. Rocky's character and the audience are touched when Mickey gives his locker away, symbolizing his disappointment. Stallone's plotting shines when he cleverly shows how Rocky gets his shot at the heavyweight title. After the top contender is injured, champion Apollo Creed, excellently played by Carl Weathers, decides to give an underdog a chance for a publicity stunt. Rocky, initially reluctant, must face his doubts and fears. The evolving relationship between Rocky and Mickey adds depth to the story. Mickey, now willing to manage Rocky, is rejected at first, but their heartwarming reconciliation is a defining moment, cleverly shot at a distance to emphasize their embrace. While Rocky's boxing journey is thrilling, the film is more a love story. Talia Shire's understated performance as Adrian, a pet store employee initially portrayed as a spinster, adds a sensitive touch. The growing romance is tenderly handled, and Shire's best scene is the powerful confrontation with her brother Paulie, played by the late Burt Young, who also happens to be Rocky's best friend. Paulie represents the darker side of Rocky's insecurities, unable to control his anger at his own lot in life. His overbearing presence and strange emotional attachments to his sister hint at a more complicated relationship with possible incestuous feelings toward her. In its time, the climactic showdown was an adrenaline rush. Watching Creed and Rocky face off in the heavyweight championship was a visceral experience. Rocky's loss but indomitable spirit "going the distance" proved iconic. Today, the film may seem dated. Boxing has lost some of its luster, with no larger-than-life figures gracing the sport as in years past. More critically, the idea of redemption and triumph through the brutality of boxing has lost some of its shine, especially when we look at the post-career health of many fighters. Muhammad Ali's tragic battle with neurological damage serves as a sobering example. Despite these shifts, all the performances in Rocky hold up remarkably well, especially Stallone's, who never quite equaled this feat in his long career. As a modern-day fairy tale, Rocky remains an impressive cinematic achievement, even if the boxing metaphor feels a bit punch-drunk nowadays.

One of Sylvester Stallone's best films put him on the map, and launched a very successful franchise. Stallone wrote and stars as Rocky Balboa, a down-and-out fighter getting beat up in smoky clubs for chump change. He has a love/hate relationship with his friend Paulie (Burt Young), loves Paulie's sister Adrian (Talia Shire), and enforces payments to loan shark Gazzo (Joe Spinell). Heavyweight champion Apollo Creed (Carl Weathers) is looking for a title fight to celebrate the nation's bicentennial, but his opponent drops out. He and promoter Jergens (Thayer David) cook up a plan- give any mook a shot at the champ, in the name of the American way. Balboa is chosen, and Creed goes about the financial business of being a champ, not taking Rocky seriously. Rocky enlists the help of Mickey (Burgess Meredith), a gym owner who saw Rocky's potential many years before, but the two never acted on it. As the fight draws near, Rocky's relationship with Paulie deteriorates as his love for Adrian takes center stage. I had not seen the original "Rocky" in decades. I highly recommend the crisp widescreen DVD transfer, which puts all the videotape releases to shame. I literally forgot what a dark and grim film this is. Rocky's Philadelphia neighborhood is a bit run down, his apartment is a pit, and director John G. Avildsen captures it all perfectly, which is strange considering the almost comic book style of the sequels. Stallone does a fine scripting job. While Rocky's relationship with Adrian takes a while, and the volatile Paulie is never explored too much, Stallone seems to know what the film audience wants. I always thought the fight at the end of the film was longer, but it barely makes ten or fifteen minutes. Weathers' Apollo is not as big a jerk as I remember, until he gets into the ring and must put on his show. Adrian could not be mousier, even with Mickey ears and a tail, but her transformation is believable without being jarring. Young and Meredith also turn in fine performances, not yet the one dimensional characters the sequels would turn them in to. "Rocky" is not a excellent film. It is certainly a strong film, full of solid acting, writing, and directing. While I cannot fault any one ingredient for keeping it from being perfect, I do highly recommend it.

I had been putting off watching this since the subject matter isn't really something that I am interested in, but I ultimately found Rocky to be an inspiring tale of determination and resilience. The movie is filled with inspirational scenes and quotes that have become a part of the culture. Rocky's "Eye of the Tiger" training montage is truly iconic, so much so that it has been parodied countless times throughout the year in pop culture. The movie also features memorable performances from Talia Shire and Burgess Meredith. Stallone does a solid job too, I can see why this has become a long running franchise that still continues today.

I had no high expectations before watching Rocky, actually we could say that I had some preconceptions about it, being a gen z girl, but man, was I wrong! This movie kept my attention high from start to finish, and got me to keep thriving for the protagonist, impersonated by an amazing Silvester Stallone. Rocky, as I found, is not the stereotypical macho figure you might think: even though he is a boxer with the classic ''tough guy" look, he often shows his most sensitive and fragile sides, which makes him a role model in many ways. I really liked the way they developed his love story with Adriana, because this side storyline was made almost as important as the main one, creating some balance and avoiding making it an action movie. Even though the movie came out in 1976 it is still perfectly enjoyable and the values it conveys are still relevant to our society nowadays, which to me makes it a timeless classic.

Forget its 2010 reboot/remake, this is probably one of the best 1980s films of all time. About years ago I watched some bits of it on TV3 (now Virgin Media One) and I thought I never saw any 1980s films like that before in my entire life. In late 2014, I watched the whole film on DVD. It's brilliant and the acting is very good especially from Ralph Macchio, Pat Morita, William Zobka snd Elizabeth Shue themselves. It never gets old and it will always be a timeless classic. I'd say it's definitely way better than its 2010 reboot/remake which is kinda boring and it's not great as its original 1984 version. If you are a fan of karate films, you'll like this.

A Superb film. The Karate Kid comes onto 4K blu ray with a lovely authentic transfer. The film retains all the grain and grit of a film shot in the 80s. Colours look lovely and natural, scenes shot at night get quite grainy but those filmed in the bright sunshine of California pack lots of colour and detail. The acting is superb, the casting also is great, the teenagers all actually look like teenagers in this film. Everything just feels nice and natural, the editing is good, the clothes and music are so 1980s. The lighting and fog on the beach when the boys on their motorbikes make their entrance, with the music playing alone is so iconic. There is some clever subtext in this film about family and also social class. There's also a strong underdog element to the film and the fight choreography is fantastic. The dialogue feels natural and casual, never rehearsed or forced.

It's a solid movie, Miyagi is a great character, he's got fantastic dialogue. Daniel isn't perfect. He's a bit prickly and ungrateful to Ali, it's a part of his defense mechanism, but it does make for some uncomfortable scenes. The movie doesn't impart any profound life lessons on viewers, but there's enough to be heartwarming and enjoyable. Action in this movie is OK. It's just barely passable, but this was made in the 80s, so I'll take what I can get. Soundtrack is pretty solid, some good tunes matched up to the scenes. Ending and resolution are abrupt, probably the weakest part of the movie but at least it makes for a happy ending.

This is a 80s Classic Film. Ralph and William were fantastic in this film. The way Ralph was trained in the film was pretty cool. The the other two came out pretty good as well. What really blew me away was 30 years later they decided to put out a tv show. At first I was like don't mess up the film's. But they did not i love how they put in clips of all three films threw the tv show. The young kids in that show were also great young actors. I also liked how Ralphs daughter was a fighter and his son did not want to fight at all. I also liked how the truth came out in the bully back in the 80s. Then decided to help out Ralph the one he hated back in High School. The new show and the Old films fit perfect together in so many ways. Even with the Old time Bullies that were in the Army Cadets and stuff. It is crazy how life just goes on and on. It reminds me so much of the truth if you really think about it. Just look at the three films and the new show and think back about your childhood. There is a lot of truth in that film and tv show if you think about it.

In the karate kid it was great because it goes by a normal story a teenager is school getting billed months later with karate exercises and skills meet again with the bully now the movie I mostly liked it because there was a seaqrel and many of the same characters return to the Cobra Kai series I just love that because they learn about there past and actually become friends like chozen and Daniel also johnny the thing that I mostly hated was the part of how when they went to different country's they made the country's and they stereotyped it so Im kind of against that another thing that wish was there was that maybe Daniels uniform can fit his size better.

Review-Title: More than just an iconic 80s movie
Review-Description: The Karate Kid is not just an iconic 80s movie. It's a well-made film which tells a timeless story that has stayed in the hearts & minds of viewers since it was released. I'm surprised by how well it holds up. This movie even kept my youngest kids engaged almost the entire time. Ralph Macchio is absolutely relatable as the timid Daniel LaRusso and William Zabka plays a villain you love to hate. Most of the magic, though, comes from Pat Morita as Mr. Miyagi. He portrays a mentor for the ages, full of wisdom & warmth. It's nice to see that The Karate Kid is still able to compete with modern movies.

I can¬¥t remember if I was reviewing this one before, but I can correct this one with nostalgia blindness. Daniel Larusso moves to California where he gets bullied, and he teams up with Mr. Miyagi to get his revenge at a karate championship. I am no karate expert, but which kid and teen did not love Asian countries, martial arts and Halloween dances? The movie is not showing the right message, and the movie is meme and parody worthy. But, the songs and music are classics the right way. This is a movie for the families that want some old school martial arts fun, but not some serious stuff like the Color Purple.

This franchise was in my watchlist for a long time and today I finally decided to start watching the franchise movies. For me, the movie was full on entertainment. It was same 80s flicks with an addition of karate in it. The story was simple, lovely and effective, the screenplay was good, the direction was good but could have been more better and the performances were good. You connect with the both lead actors. One thing I wanted to talk about was the climax which felt rushed to me, it could have been 10-15 minutes more longer. Overall, it's a good movie and you should definitely give this movie a try.

Review-Title: Kind of tame in today's standards considering what we can watch these days
Review-Description:
(1984) The Karate Kid
DRAMA ACTION Popular during it's time, self- indulgent teen flick with a too simplistic story line starring Ralph Macchio as Danial who's antagonized by another fellow martial arts student Johnny (William Zabka) after he falls for his girlfriend, Ali (Elisabeth Shue). Daniel then gets taken under an older Japanese elder, Miyagi ( Noriyuki 'Pat' Morita) whose actually a karate instructor. To say anything more is ridiculous because you can pretty much know how this story is going to turn out. After looking back at it, this film is very tame in today's standards because I seen more effective martial art movies than this, where the action is plentiful and the training is vigorously harder to do. The more I think about this film the more simplistic it reminded me something from a ''Sunday Afternoon Special'

Review-Title: A Splendid Film For All Viewers to Enjoy and Learn
Review-Description: This is a sensational film. This is a film for all viewers to watch and enjoy. The cast selection was brilliant. The storyline was truly great and reveals to viewers multiple things. The cast really committed to the storyline and to their respective characters. The chemistry and connection between was really strong. This film reveals to viewers that it is possible for anyone to do anything in life. It also reveals the full limits of strength and courage. I have had a lot of troubles in my life. I was bullied too much growing up. This film also reveals to viewers the reality of growing up. This is an absolutely tremendous film for everyone to watch, enjoy, and learn.

Review-Title: This Story Exemplifies the American Dream
Review-Description: To start this is not the best film I have seen or even in that category but the emotions it brought in me were do strong that I had to rate higher then I would have if I based it on just as a film alone, probably would have rated it an 8. This film is the perfect example of what the highly touted iconic words "The American Dream" stands for. You got a very highly skilled football player who had a very bright future, finds a beautiful & supportive significant partner, but then everything came crashing down early on & along the way hes lost in his downward spiral, barely hanging on & struggling. We get to see the hardships endured by Kurt, while he forges deeper bonds with so many around him. Whether minor characters or major characters you get to witness enter his life & its as if each of them were meant to be Gods hand in pushing Kurt on the right track, no matter if its just simple words of encouragement or new opportunities that come knocking. Who doesn't love an underdog story anyway?? We always hear the successes n glamour of big sports stars but its not everyday u get to see a film dedicated to showing what it was like for them in their path climbing upwards & it has the love stories, the friendship bonds, it is so inspiring honestly while watching this. To be clear Football isn't even my top 3 sports I like lol & though I do watch the Super bowls & sometimes the playoffs too, but after watching this film it totally makes me want to watch football lol. Though I obviously logically knew how the film plays out, but I felt shivers & chills course through my body, full of excitement & energy as you watch the underdog trying to claw its way back up with everything to lose on the line & making his last push towards success... it was heartwarming honestly. Oh ya Great acting by uh the Shazam guy & awesome acting by the woman that plays his wife. If you lookin for something to pick yourself up when you're in a slump, losing faith, on a losing streak... I totally recommend this film to boost yourself up because while some of the facts of this film dont line up exactly to how his career actually started but I think thats not important cuz the main point of the story is showing what perseverance can do for someone even when they are at their rock bottom with no hope in sight, sometimes a Hail Mary can light their life up in 1 moment.

Who pays to all these members giving it 9-10 !?!?!? It is 100th time of these kind of stories in a movie even though this one is based on true events. Movie is maybe 4*, bad plot, very bad actors, only camera is okish. Check what masterpieces from Denzel have 7+ and then come back to this junk, it is done so poor, cant believe 20k people gave it 7. Avoid it even if it is free, go watch some rerun of some good movie. There is barely any good movies out here these days but as a rule, if it is on Netflix then it is pure junk, Netflix movie has like 1 of 1000 that it can be called good movie, everything else is wasting time.

Review-Title: If you love sports stories and want an uplifting movie, this is it
Review-Description: We've always loved sports movies, often baseball, but American Football works just as well. Not huge stars, although well known (Shazam, The Piano) and of course the wonderful Denis Quaid, but great casting and they work well together. It's a love story too, so something for the romantics amongst us, but like the name of the film, it's a story of adversity and living your dream. It's a super little film and we are so glad we found it. Especially after some of the dire movies that have been showing recently, and the constant super heroes that we see (I'm not adverse to DC or Marvel), but sometimes, you just want something well acted, with a great story, likeable characters - a film you can invest in without browsing on your device. Enjoy!

Such an inspiring movie for anyone that feels like the underdog in any dream they are aspiring to achieve! Believe in yourself and others will believe in you too! Never give up! Give God the Glory when he blesses you with your dreams! This movie brought me to tears of joy! I love football and enjoyed every moment of this movie! It is a must watch. I am not sure why it is not rated much higher. It deserves ten stars! With every dream comes challenges and sometimes we have to change paths to get there but we eventually get there with God's help! God is with you every step of the way! Thank you for this üçø, I loved it.

Just endure long introduction, this beginning will help you understand the present and empathize with it. Great sports drama! This is an inspiring picture! A dream can come true, you just need to believe and not give up. The hero will have difficulties and, most importantly, this is a story about a real person! When I remember this movie, I want to cry tears of joy, but don't believe me verbatim. :) The viewer together with the hero of this film will be confused, then he will struggle with life's difficulties, and then he will win! - A real classic hero's way! This is one of the best Zachary Levi movie roles!

I'm a sucker for sports movies, I truly enjoy them despite the common tropes and clich√©s that they fall into. American Underdog is different I would argue because the theme of faith makes up the foundation of the film, while not being overwhelming or preachy. Sporting an all-star cast that all give great performances, this film manages to avoid most of the cheesiness often associated with both sports and faith-based films. Sharing the inspiring story of Kurt Warner and his quest to make it to the NFL, this story of perseverance and heart will make for a great time with the family. What were your thoughts on the film?

Review-Title: VIEWS ON FILM review of American Underdog
Review-Description: As a guy who watches an immense amount of NFL football, I couldn't help but be amazed at the story of Kurt Warner. Kurt went undrafted and when he couldn't get a pro team to sign him, he ended up stocking shelves at a grocery store in Iowa. Now Warner is in the Pro Football Hall of Fame after winning a Super Bowl, playing in two more, and becoming a two-time, National Football League MVP. 2021's American Underdog is a biographical flick about this real-life, victim/hero. You watch it and think, maybe said hero deserved a more epic tribute. American Underdog runs 112 minutes. Its story minus the romance factor (Warner and wife Brenda), is pretty straight-forward, like almost identical to Kurt's wiki page. "Underdog" is also directed by two people in brothers Andrew and Jon Erwin. Andrew and Jon opt for a glossy look, a miscast Dennis Quaid (as coach Dick Vermeil), and some Disney undertones (even though the film's distributor is Lionsgate). They go for the schmaltz too but their "Underdog" never feels compelling enough or old-world like say, Rudy (another flick about weaker sports parties). Then there's the football scenes of aw-shucks Kurt (played by Zachary Levi) flinging the pigskin around and getting hit like a brick at the same time. There's not enough of them and they feel pedestrian, like Levi just nonchalantly made some nifty plays. I mean where's the struggle in the pocket? And where's the grit? And where's the nasty, gridiron optics that Jack "Cap" Rooney went through? Nada, no where to be found. Bottom line: if you want to gather the family around, make some popcorn, and ogle at a few dewy-eyed moments between a QB legend, his in the cards plight, and his loyal lady, then American Underdog is the movie for you. If you want something more than a feel-good, TV-like vehicle transitioning on the come up, well you won't have a "dog" in this fight. Natch.

Based on a true story, American Underdog is a wonderful and uplifting story about QB Kurt Warner's struggles and challenges he had getting to the NFL. Growing up, Kurt Warner always dreamed of playing in the NFL. He watched Super Bowl XIX and he decides that he will play in the NFL and win a Super Bowl and MVP. So years later Kurt is the quarterback for the University of Northern Iowa. He plays 5 years and he has very good stats as the starting quarterback. He is so sure he will be picked in the NFL draft... But one team after another, every team passes him over. Kurt went through several NFL tryouts with various teams but to no avail. So Kurt goes to work for a local grocery store. But he never gave up, and gets a offer to play Arena Football. Kurt became a star QB of that league. He even made the Arena Football Hall of Fame. Soon Kurt's fame spread and reaches the NFL scouts. Finally the door is open to his dream. Dick Vermeil, coach of the Rams goes against his entire staff and signs Kurt Warner as the Rams backup quarterback. "I just want my shot. I want one chance to prove that I'm good enough" - Kurt
When the Rams starting QB is injured, Kurt steps in and becomes the starter. Oh and not just a starting QB, Kurt won a Super Bowl, Super Bowl MVP, and NFL MVP. As much as Kurt loves playing football and receiving all the awards. He placed his family first and gives them credit, having the people you love to stand by you through all the struggles. "It doesn't mean anything if you don't have someone to share it with" - Kurt
I really enjoined this underdog movie. A bit rare and unique for a football movie... And even if you are not a football fan, this is a really awesome feel-good underdog story. I do wish there more films like this.

As a European i can see this as a 'true' American story. Just a shame that the left out the part where he played in NFL Europe with the Amsterdam Admirals. I was at all the games but guess it was a phantom on the field and not Kurt Warner...
True story it is not, it is shortened and adapted for making an entertaining movie. So when you watch this keep that in mind. Fact is he did not come on the team the season they went to the superbowl. That was his 2nd season with the team and between 98-99 he played the season in NFL Europe. It is said his wife hated the godless city of Amsterdam so it could be 1 of the reasons they left that part out.

Review-Title: Real Life Sports Success Story Meets the Silver Screen!!
Review-Description: Based on the life of NFL Hall of Famer, MVP, Super Bowl MVP, and Super Bowl champion Kurt Warner is a jarring and almost unbelievable story of a young man from the Midwest and his dogged determination never to give up on his football dream!! Well played by Shazam's Zachary Levi, Warner wasn't even necessarily the star of his college football team, Northern Iowa, a school that really doesn't get much attention from the NFL our it's team's scouts. That didn't deter Warner though, and after winning over his wife Brenda played very well by X-Men's Anna Paquin, his journey through life and the many twists and turns to ultimate glory began including barely a cup of coffee with the Green Bay Packers, a stint with the Arena League's Iowa Barnstormers, even a job at a local HyVee grocery store to pay the bills that eventually led to Warner signing with the then St Louis Rams and ultimate glory as a Super Bowl champion in 1999!! This is the type of movie that makes you feel good, stays with you, and inspires you never to give up even when the odds look daunting!! It also reminds you of the importance of family & friendship & how important they are in making dreams come true!! Good acting, realistic football action with some possible performances by former NFL players Hall of Famer Ray Lewis & fellow Hall of Famer & former St Louis Ram Marshall Faulk mixed with actual game footage make this the second best football movie of all-time slightly behind 1990's Rudy and above Al Pacino's Any Given Sunday in my opinion!! 7 out of 10 stars!!

Come to me with these, come with a biography. When I looked at the cast of the movie and saw Brad Pitt, of course I watched it without hesitation. Actually, I had a prejudice. Because I have never played or watched the game of baseball in my life. I know the rules and the game, but I don't follow it at all, so I thought I might get bored, but it didn't bother me for a moment. These guys do the job of biography well. I'm already interested in biopics. The movie was very good. The best thing about biopics is that what happened is real, what is said is real, you can go and look at the photos. After every biography movie, I search for a long time on Google to see what the characters in the movie I watched are doing now. I did. Watch a really good sports movie.

After being defeated by the New York Yankees in the 2001 play-offs, losing three of his key players to bigger contracts at richer clubs, and then being refused more funds for new players by the club's owner, Oakland Athletics general manager Billy Beane (played by Brad Pitt) hires an inexperienced Yale economics graduate (Jonah Hill) and starts utilizing hard statistics (now known as sabermetrics) to recruit specialized talent who are seemingly over the hill or has another defect which have made them unattractive to other clubs. Will this novel and - to many - controversial approach pay off? In form and structure, Moneyball is a familiar underdog story which have been known to work ever so well many times before on the big-screen. However, this is no Rocky with lots of action and simple, emotional dialogue. And it's no Youngblood style of film in which the game itself is simplified to attract "regular" viewers. On the contrary, Moneyball is something as rare as a sports film about numbers and tactics. It's not only based on real-life people and events, but it also treats and presents these people and events accordingly, and not through a conventionalized archetype-filter. A film as technical and theory-oriented as this one may sound inaccessible to outsiders, but as a typical European soccer-fan with minimal knowledge about the game of baseball, I say on the contrary. This is a breath of fresh air in a world of movie-making which often underestimates its viewers. Moneyball is a detailed and fairly fast-paced account from an environment about which the filmmakers are never afraid to be specific and comprehensive. And this works as a perfect counterweight to the heart and moral of the story, which is undeniably simplistic, but also inherently beautiful. Brad Pitt gives arguably the best performance of his career as real-life GM Billy Beane. His performance has a drive and a carefreeness which I haven't seen in Pitt for years, and combined with appropriate mannerisms and a clearly deep understanding of the character, he gives the film the momentum it needs.
