With her charm & beauty she had every man eating out of the palm of her hand! & she even got the unattainable wealthy bachelor to fall in love with her & she didn't even have to put out! She loved her family in her own way. I mean she truly was my idol! I live by the phrase she would say in the movie, "I won't think about that now, I'll think about it tomorrow!!" I'm soo happy that Hollywood will never ruin it with a remake. I was a weird child I think because no little kid would love or even watch a movie like this.. & it's the same thing for the movie, "Robin Hood:Prince of Thieves. I was 4 when it came out & I'd watch it every time I was at my grandparents. That's another movie little kids would never sit through & fall in love with.. I watch Gone with the Wind every Nov. 5th (today) cause Vivien Leigh's bday was Nov. 5th & mine is Nov. 4th! & if I ever have a daughter, I'm naming her Vivien Leigh Rose!

Review-Title: A Timeless Movie About Love and Being Strong
Review-Description: "Gone with the Wind" is a well-known film that takes us back to the time of the Civil War and what happened afterward in the American South. It's based on a book written by Margaret Mitchell in 1936 and was turned into a movie directed by Victor Fleming. The movie is all about love, being strong, and dealing with tough times during a war. Many people have loved this movie for a long time, and it's considered an important part of the history of movies. The main character in the movie is Scarlett O'Hara, played by Vivien Leigh. Scarlett is a determined Southern woman who has to deal with all the troubles of the Civil War and what came after. She's strong-willed, but she can also be ruthless when it comes to protecting her family's plantation, Tara. In the movie, she has a complicated relationship with Rhett Butler, played by Clark Gable. Rhett is charming, but he can also be cynical. The movie shows how their relationship changes as the story goes on. This movie is famous for its big and impressive scenes, especially in the beginning. It shows the grandeur of Southern plantations and the beauty of the South. The movie's look was groundbreaking for its time because it used a color technology called Technicolor, which made everything look even more vivid. One of the most famous scenes in the history of movies is when Atlanta is burning. This scene shows how much effort went into making this movie. A major theme in "Gone with the Wind" is about change. Scarlett's character starts as a self-centered and materialistic young woman but changes as she faces the challenges of the Civil War. She becomes a survivor who can handle anything. Her character represents how the South changed because of the war. This theme meant a lot when the movie was released during the Great Depression, and it still means something to people today. The movie also looks at love in different ways. Scarlett has unrequited love for a man named Ashley Wilkes, and she has a complicated relationship with Rhett Butler. These relationships show that love can be really complicated. Rhett's famous line, "Frankly, my dear, I don't give a damn," is one of the most famous lines in movies. It shows how his relationship with Scarlett changes. "Gone with the Wind" is also famous for how it shows the American South. It shows the beauty of the South, but it also doesn't hide the terrible parts of the Civil War. However, the movie has been criticized for not showing the history of slavery in the South accurately. It's also criticized for how it shows Black characters, which was a reflection of the time when the movie was made. Even though "Gone with the Wind" is loved by many, it's also important to remember that it has problems when it comes to how it shows race and the South. But even with these issues, it's a movie that people still enjoy and talk about.

This is by far one of the best films i have ever watched. Yes, i know the time length can be difficult to commit to, but it is worth every minute. This is one of the few films that have me stuck to my seat and quite frankly, i would've loved for it to go on forever. The character development is wonderful to watch play out, all actors bring their all to the table and even the small details like the setting, design and appearance of actors was just perfect. I have re watched this film once a year and it never fails to impress me. I have forced friends to give it a chance and watch it with me and midway thru they refuse to even get up for a water break cause they're just as amazed as i was watching for the first time. I will never stop recommending this film, it brings so many genres to the table and the story is just phenomenal to witness.

Let me talk about the parts of Gone With The Wind that have aged well first. This is a bonafide, epic, Hollywood classic, big budget film. The scene where Scarlet O'Hara walks among the wounded confederate soldiers alone is breathtaking. This was decades before CGI so when you realize every one of them had to be extras in costume just for that one dramatic shot, it blows you away. The cinematography is incredible and the acting, for its time, is extremely impressive as well. And there's even a bit of humor woven into the script. Not a lot, but every once in a while you get a scene that makes you smile or chuckle and you know you're watching a well written story that, at its heart, about survival at any cost. Here's what hasn't aged well. 4 hours? Seriously. A 4 hour film? Did people have nothing else to do in the 1930s? I mean, even fast forwarding through the overture, intermission and exit music it's well over 3 and a half hours. Easily an hour longer than it needed to be. But the main thing is the blatant racism. This film glorifies the antebellum south and sugarcoats slavery like it's FOX News (relax, it's a joke). For me, it's difficult to fully enjoy a movie like this knowing it only helped stereotype African Americans as an inferior race and Whites as the pinnacle of civilization, especially when you think about the fact that nothing is as uncivilized as owning another human being. I mean, there's a scene about halfway through the film where the war is over and the white people are forced to pick their own cotton, and they're all standing around complaining about how difficult the work is, and I'm screaming at my TV, "But you had no problem forcing your slaves to do it you f%&king evil pieces of sh$t!" And if that scene had been presented with an ounce of irony or even awareness by the filmmaker of hypocrisy I might have appreciated it. But it was not. When you refer to the union army as the "evil aggressor" and spend most of the movie lamenting the fact that southern charm and civilization are lost for good, you're coming down on the side of slavery and racism and that part was difficult for me to get passed. Rhett Butler's treatment of Scarlett O'Hara hasn't aged well either. Threatening a woman that you're going to crush her skull to get her to stop thinking about another man, while holding her head in a vice grip, is ugly behavior. If that's the "civilization" this movie celebrates than I'm glad I wasn't born a "southern gentleman." In the end, I admired Scarlet O'Hara. She's a tough woman and pragmatist. She will do anything to hold onto her plantation and return it to its former glory, even if that means marrying a man she doesn't love. Even in the end, her crocodile tears when Rhett is leaving her fade away when she realizes she can come up with a plan to bring him back because "tomorrow is a new day." That's the survival part of this movie that I appreciated and it's the movie's most redeeming quality.

Gone with the Wind is a classic movie that deserves to be seen by every film lover. It is a sweeping epic that tells the story of the turbulent romance between Scarlett O'Hara, a headstrong Southern belle, and Rhett Butler, a charming rogue, against the backdrop of the American Civil War and Reconstruction. The movie is based on the best-selling novel by Margaret Mitchell, and it features an outstanding cast, led by Vivien Leigh and Clark Gable, who deliver unforgettable performances. The movie also boasts stunning cinematography, lavish costumes, and a magnificent score by Max Steiner. Gone with the Wind is a movie that transcends time and generations. It is a masterpiece of storytelling, emotion, and spectacle that captures the essence of a historical era and a human drama. It is a movie that will make you laugh, cry, and fall in love with its characters. It is a movie that you will never forget. Gone with the Wind is a classic movie that you should watch today.

To get it out of the way, I couldn't choose between whether this film was a 9.75 or 10. This is due to the ending not being what I wanted, but I am giving it a 10 because overall, the ending definitely was amazing. Either way, I am not going to argue with people who consider this a masterpiece or as their favorite film, because this film definitely is a masterpiece. Though I do wish Rick and Ilsa had their happy ending with each other, this does remind me that one of the most important things about loves is that the woman is as safe as possible in any situation or circumstance. I have to probably place this in my top 5 favorite films of all time, along with Singin in the Rain, City Lights, It's a Wonderful Life, and Titanic.

An absolute classic of a film, the restoration work done has an amazing end product. Full of memorable lines and iconic images. The film manages to be immensely entertaining and captivating. It's a film of great strengths, you have patriotism as a theme, Rick so Masculine, Ingrid so feminine it's wonderfully cast. The story takes place in Morocco during WWII, the place were introduced to is a complex one, full of hustlers, spies, secrete police, tricksters, refugees and rumours swirling around. There's also a swell of different nationalities, Arabs, French, Americans, Germans, Czechs and Bulgarians. Rick is brilliant character, tough, sardonic, cynical, witty yet it's also suggested to us this might just be his body armour and underneath is a 'rank sentimentalist.' His life changes when an old flame he very much loved back in Paris walks into his bar in one of the most memorable scenes in cinema. As mentioned the film is so quotable, there's too many good lines to even list. The music is also superb in this film and the scene of the French National Anthem being sung might just be the best one in the film. I saw this film for the first time in 4K yesterday and it's just stunning. The level of clarity, depth and detail now in the picture is outstanding, it's like a new film made yesterday almost. It also gives you such a deep appreciation for the cinematography in the film, the use of smoke and shadow and light and contrast, the way light and shadow fall across a characters face, the gleam of their eyes, it's one of the best looking films you'll ever see I think. There's a reason this film is a classic, it's also superbly paced, I don't think there's one wasted scene in the movie, everything works, it's such a well oiled machine in terms of story construction. This is a film to treasure.

Review-Title: A Timeless Romance in a Turbulent Time
Review-Description: Casablanca, a film wrapped in the warm embrace of nostalgia, deserves its classic status. I would give it a solid 7 out of 10, not for its intricate plot but for being the Humphrey Bogart of movies - charming, a bit mysterious, and undeniably entertaining. Let's talk about the narrative twists. The plot might not stand up to rigorous scrutiny, but then again, Casablanca is more about capturing the essence of a turbulent era than meticulous storytelling. The "letters of transit" might sound like a convenient plot device, but they serve their purpose in keeping the tension alive. Choosing Casablanca as a backdrop for a love story amidst political chaos might seem curious, but it adds a layer of complexity to the characters. Renault's questionable ethics reflect the moral ambiguity of the time, even if it doesn't align with modern standards. The supporting cast is a vibrant mix of characters, from the rival nightclub owner Ferrari to the duplicitous police chief Renault, played with finesse by Claude Rains. Dooley Wilson's rendition of 'As Time Goes By' adds emotional depth to the film. Bogart and Bergman share undeniable chemistry, even if their characters are not as fully fleshed out as one might hope. Paul Henreid as Laszlo embodies the spirit of resistance, though his post-US plans remain a mystery. Casablanca, with its rose-tinted glasses and melodramatic crescendos, is a love letter to a bygone era. While it may not be a cerebral masterpiece, it captures the essence of wartime romance and sacrifice. Woody Allen celebrated Bogart's performance in 'Play It Again, Sam,' paying homage to Casablanca. This connection adds another layer of appreciation for a film that continues to enchant audiences with its timeless allure.

Spoilers. Observations. Reflections. Opinions. The enemy couldn't win. You could see this with Le Marseillaise triumphing over that teutonic song entree. You could see the love of freedom, in the audience's eyes. You could see this in a scene where Bogart shoots the bad guy. The words of the French anthem go something like this: Wake up, you citizens. We have the glory. We are strong. We are tough. Man your battle stations. We will water our farm fields with the blood of our enemies. This is why you see the tears in the audience's faces when they sing their anthem against the song of the enemy. This is why you know that they would beat the enemy, and that the good guys would win. You could tell the outcome of the film from this hint. Yes, you could predict the end of this movie. I hate black and white films, but in this one I will change my mind. This one is played against the background of international conflict, and apparently did better in the neutral coloring genre. Besides, in 1939 you had two color blockbusters -- one about the American South and the other one about a fantasy neighborhood way up in the clouds. War is ugly. Black and white fits here. There are no fabulous song and fancy dance motifs here. Of course, my regular favorite films are absolutely full-color song and dance films. Film observations: Bergman clothing sensational. Bogey dressed quite well. You could tell that there were rich people in the casino. No poor people could afford to be there. The letters of transit were the actual stars of this film. The people were just accessories, lol. 10/10.

Not many times have I gone out of my way to write a review here but this masterpiece certainly makes it worth it. I won't bore you with the details of what goes on the movie, however, I'll tell you what it can do to you. It makes you remember how lucky we are to live in an era where there is no war, at least not a world war that is. It allows you to value your loved one, even more so that you already do. Even if you don't have a special someone at present time, it clearly explains what unconditional love can be. The acting is just wonderfully performed, so is the script. A true work of art that will be regarded for centuries to come as one of the best romantic movies of all times if not THE BEST.

The film unfolds in the titular Moroccan city, a haven for refugees seeking escape from the ravages of war. At the center of the narrative is Rick Blaine, played by Humphrey Bogart, a cynical nightclub owner with a mysterious past. When Ilsa Lund, portrayed by Ingrid Bergman, re-enters Rick's life, old wounds are reopened, and the story takes a poignant turn. The chemistry between Bogart and Bergman is electrifying, and their performances elevate the film to a level of cinematic artistry seldom matched. The iconic line, "Here's looking at you, kid," uttered by Bogart, has become synonymous with classic Hollywood romance.

The film "Casablanca", which was released back in 1942, is certainly a classic cinematic work that still remains an integral part of American culture. Director Michael Curtis has created a unique atmosphere where the historical context is combined with an intriguing plot. At the center is Rick Blaine, beautifully performed by Humphrey Bogart, who leads a secluded life in the neutral city of Casablanca, located in Morocco during World War II. Acting in the picture is definitely one of the main strengths of this work. Humphrey Bogart perfectly conveys the emotions of his character, capturing his complexity and inner experiences. His laid-back charisma and impeccable playing style create the unique appeal of Rick Blaine. Especially impressive is his interaction with Ilsa Lund, whose image perfectly freezes in the viewer's memory. Thanks to Ingrid Bergman's good acting, Ilse's image turns out to be organic and definitely succeeded for the actress. I still can't understand why this duo didn't take the Oscars for the best male and female roles. Despite my reserved attitude to the picture as a whole, I think that Bogart and Bergman played well and could have become winners. And if the first one received a nomination, then Ingrid was not even awarded such an honor. A pity. The picture will certainly pose a lot of questions to the audience about who and how should have behaved in this story. Where and whose place, how to be, torn between feelings and duty, finally, what will happen after the choice is made, first of all, in the soul of the heroes. The film, directed by Curtis, will allow viewers to decide for themselves what is right and what is not. Despite all the positive aspects, it is worth noting that the picture seemed boring to me. I understand that my expectations played a negative role. I have heard a lot of extremely positive reviews about this film, and when I got to know the picture myself, the film seemed ordinary and not very remarkable. Despite the presence of romantic and dramatic moments, "Casablanca" sometimes slows down the pace, which can be explained in the historical context and the nature of the characters. However, this feature can hardly be defined as a disadvantage, since it is part of its unique atmosphere and helps to delve into the specifics of the events and experiences of the characters. But I, probably, as a modern viewer, saw a negative side and a protracted narrative in this. In conclusion, I would like to say that the film is a vivid example of classic Hollywood cinema. The acting of Humphrey Bogart and Ingrid Bergman impresses with its strength and emotional depth. But everything else passed as if in the background. However, it is worth noting that "Casablanca" was and remains one of the most important works of cinema and undoubtedly deserves recognition and admiration. Let the film look quite simple and even predictable today, the picture will definitely find its audience. After all, this is a classic. 6 out of 10.

Review-Title: "Of all the gin joints, in all the towns, in all the world, she walks into mine."
Review-Description: FILM: 8.5/10. Diving into 1941's Casablanca was like uncovering a hidden treasure chest in the cinematic seas. Much has been said of the film in the past eight decades, and for good reason. Sitting down to watch this classic, I quickly found myself immersed in a bygone era of wartime intrigue and timeless romance, where fedoras were a staple and every shadow held a secret. As the story unfolds, Humphrey Bogart's portrayal of Rick Blaine struck a chord with me-world-weary yet undeniably charismatic. His chemistry with Ingrid Bergman as Ilsa Lund is the stuff of cinematic legend. Their on-screen dynamic balances the desires of their characters perfectly with the realities of war. The supporting cast is a treasure trove of memorable characters. Claude Rains as the charmingly corrupt Captain Renault adds a amusing layer of wit to proceedings, and who could forget Sam's soulful tunes at Rick's Caf√©? The film's dialogue is a masterclass in wit and sophistication, with lines that have etched themselves into the very fabric of movie history. That's even more impressive given that no one involved knew they were making cinematic history. To the screenwriters this was merely one of six films they churned out in 1942. Casablanca may be a love story at first glance, but ultimately it's a tale of morality amongst the backdrop of a harrowing time in the world's history. The setting, a melting pot of conflicting interests and cultures, is perfectly captured in the microcosm of Rick's Caf√©. The theme of sacrifice and that haunting, often repeated melody of "As Time Goes By" will stay with you long after the credits have rolled. In a world where flashy CGI often steals the show, Casablanca stands tall as a beacon of well-crafted storytelling. Here's looking at you, Casablanca. FORMAT: 4K Ultra HD Blu-ray VIDEO: 10/10. Native 4K presentation, Detail level: Excellent, Colour reproduction: Excellent, Level accuracy: Excellent, Encode: Excellent, Master condition: Excellent AUDIO: 9/10. DTS-HD MA 2.0 mono audio, Dialogue reproduction: Excellent, Soundtrack & effects clarity: Excellent, Dynamics: Good, Surround sound presentation: N/A, LFE content: N/A MOOFIEMETER: 8/10.

There is no parts of this movie that didn't feel unnecessary or bloated. The meticulous attention to detail is at a level that every film maker can only hope to strive for. Every scene was important to the story, every character had a moment to shine, and every line was well thought out and executed to near perfection. Humphrey Bogart as Rick Blain is masterful in his role, allowing all the subtleties in his performance to make a huge impact in his character progression from a cynic to a 'sentimentalist'. Ingrid Bergman as Ilsa Lund brought a charisma and innocence to her role that can make just about anyone fall in love with her. Together their performances brought to life one of the greatest love stories in cinema history. I can go on and on about the excellent performances from Paul Henreid and Claude Rains etc., but I would just become a broken record at that point. I urge most people who have yet to see this movie to do themselves a favor and watch it ASAP! It is a must watch for all movie lovers.

(19420 Casablanca
WAR DRAMA Sarcastic dialogue in films was used earlier but never quite as effective as this film! If there is ever a film that reinvented how dialogue is spoken in films it would have to start with this one! I also respect how the film allows other actors of other ethnics to use their own actual language or their own foreign accents! Fictional plot starting with the Nazis takeover over France with stubborn bar owner Rick (Humphrey Bogart) mixing it up with old flame Elsie played by Ingrid Bergman unveiling his past! All performances are top notch- though the story could've been heightened at the end.

Review-Title: Nolan's heart was in the right place at least
Review-Description:
*I know what Nolan was trying to do, make a war film with as little cgi as possible. He wanted everything to be in front of the screen. We have to applaud him. Execution wise, this movie is boring, slow, and even at less than 2 hours it feels 30 minutes too long. *There is no story, no characters, and Dunkirk looks very very bare. Just watch that "Dunkirk-scene" from the movie "Atonement" and you will see that it is done way better in "Atonement." *This movie is just boring but Nolan can't help but add his "magic" to it. He just can't make a straight forward film anymore, he has to make different timelines, he has to try to make everything "Memento-like." Not everything needs that back and forth thing, just make a straight up story. 5/10
Good directing and acting, but boring film, action scenes are boring, no story, no characters, and Nolan really needed to add come CGI for his Dunkirk films to show more troops. It just looks so bare.

Visually thrilling with amazing performances achieved through minimal dialogue, replaced instead with superb sound design, the scream of the enemy planes in the sky above the evacuating troops in particular stood out. Characters and Structure
Dunkirk stars Harry Styles, Tom Hardy, Mark Rylance, Keneth Branagh, Fionn Whitehead and many others, the main cast is nearly entirely British. The film tells the story firmly from the perspective of those British forces caught up in the disaster, the strafing of beaches and ships for example is filmed purely from the perspective of those under attack looking up at the planes. It never cuts so that we see the German pilots in their planes looking down on their targets nor do we see allied generals and politicians in a war room, spoon feeding the audience information. There are only two characters of seniority that really deliver any exposition about the wider context of what's unfolding and even their dialogue is brief. Nolan's approach during the beach and sea sequences is almost equivalent to a camera gliding along the surface through the events as they happen, this gives it a kind of rawness and realism which a more traditionally structured film couldn't do. The focus here is purely on a handful of characters and their life and death struggles, several times machine gun fires rips out from an unseen enemy, just like our characters we never get a good sense of the other side's perspective. The sequences of boats sinking filmed from inside their interiors for me surpasses Tiatnic (1997) in terms of its nightmarish power. There is an amazing close shot of a ship in the inky black of the night lit up by the red and orange of a fireball bursting out of it's hulk. Harry Styles is sort of our main protagonist, right from the go he is running for his life. Without much dialogue what we learn about him comes mostly through watching his actions and expressions. He seems to be a perfectly ordinary young man caught up in a horror he couldn't have imagined. For all the ear-piercing noise and hellish fighting some of the most profound moments are the still quiet ones of soldiers stoically waiting their turn, characters sat gazing mournfully at the rough sea, perhaps too exhausted to do anything else, hoping tomorrow they will have better luck. It's a film about people just clinging on, quite literally in several sequences. It's lack of dialogue in favour of visually storytelling is on par with Mad Max Fury Road (2015) another Tom Hardy film. War films can tend to fall into two different kinds of structures, there is the Sands of Iwo Jima/The Dambusters/American Snipper/Hacksaw Ridge kind which introduce you to your character/s, then in the 2nd act take you through their training before the 3rd act is the climactic battle you know has been coming. The other approach is to pretty much open and close the film in the middle of the war, Saving Private Ryan being such a film. Unlike a Oliver Stone movie this doesn't seem to be an anti war theme nor is it a jingoistic affair. Its simple matter of fact approach just tells the story. Cinematography and Score
The score I loved and think it really suited this material. Hans Zimmer does an excellent job of combining traditional score with more ambient sound to create a grittier sounding music than you'd otherwise get. The cinematography does a fine job balancing a filmetic look with at times a more documentary style. There wasn't any excessive colour grading that I could see, it all looked nicely balanced and natural. The film's colour pallet is of course made up of lots of sandy yellow, and khaki green, this fits nicely with the greyer colours of the evening with the blue sea and dark interiors of the ships. The tone of the film is sombre, at times desperate and naturally lacking in any humour or levity. The film was shot on location at Dunkirk at uses thousands of extras as well as real aircraft and ships to create it's impressive sequences. In an age which is increasingly going digital Nolan shot this on real film. Other thoughts Soldiers of all nationalities in our media and culture can often be portrayed purely in terms of projecting power, impossibly fierce, fearless killing machines. Dunkirk shows us exposed, vulnerable and sometimes frightened traumatised troops stuck in a dire desperate situation. The effect of this choice is characters feel real, not Hollywoodised movie characters who yell out witty dialogue to eachother between reloading or unstoppable baddass types who charge around implausibly dodging bullets while pumping lead into their enemies. As you'd expect part of the story allows time for the civilian effort to rescue soldiers from Dunkirk. Mark Rylance is given a big part here. In a way the film does make you question whether in 2017 a similar response would follow from people in the UK if lots of other people found themselves needing help. If a sense of shared purpose and unity ever existed or such a thing as a national spirit then it's hard to believe it is just as alive and well today. The film also made me question a bit too whether people today would be hard enough to go through something like this. A delay on the M5 the other day had a woman on the news in hysterics over the fact her dogs in back were very hot. Half the audience at the cinema I'm afraid were overweight, mostly dressed in shorts and t-shirts, munching on their food as they watched the men on the screen struggling in the waves. A man in his 50s at the front of the cinema had even stripped down to his vest by the time the film was over, have we become so unhealthy now that sitting down in spacious cinema for two hours can make a person this hot? In terms of negatives with the film, I don't have many. There's quite a lot of cutting between short sequences which I haven't noticed quite so much in Nolan's other work, it was a times a bit grading. I found a bit of the dialogue from Mark Rylance hard to follow, incidentally he probably has the most lines in the film. It's stated to this man lost his son into the third week of the war, not impossible but I'd be surprised considering 1939 was known as the Phoney War, a period of near total inactivity on the Western front.

Review-Title: Rating Too High or Too Low
Review-Description: I will admit my subject title is misleading. However just how in the name of all that is good, can a website that facilitates people who adore cinema, be the arbiter of a 7.8 for Dunkirk (at time of writing) is frightening. 7.8 means its on par with Love Actually!!, I accept to each there own. But what next..... Love Actually is mildly entertaining in parts, but it's no masterpiece, of storytelling and narrative. RT rating at least try's to strikes a balance of those that want to be entertained and those of us that want to be challenged and entertained. Dunkirk is a 9 at least, and it's foolish to suggest otherwise.

This 2017 film Dunkirk was the best war movie I have ever seen as well being a world war 2 us GI reenactor / history buff. The uniforms of the soldier in the movie was very authentic and not farby. I would like to give a shout out on the cast and crew of doing a fantastic job on this film and the research they put into this historical film. The battle of Dunkirk took place in the 40s. The airplanes in the film is phenomenal as well as the boats that are rescuing Allied forces. If you have not seen this yet it is the best movie to watch. It is a Great War drama to watch. I hope all of y'all enjoy.

From the first seconds of the film, the viewer's attention is inextricably riveted to the screen. War tension, fear, pursuit, shooting. This is not a simple war film, with lots of shots, attacks and shouts of 'Hurray!' No, 'Dunkirk' is a film about the soul, about how war affects the human soul and about what people are capable of when there is no way out. The idea of the plot unfolding from three different angles (land, water, air) is simply amazing and shows us the picture of military operations as broadly and realistically as possible. Thousands of soldiers who are exhausted and dream of only one thing: to return home. Enemy planes targeting ships filled with wounded and water claiming thousands of young lives. Incredible cinematography by Hoyte Van Hoytema conveys human emotions and genuine anxiety. The body shakes from every explosion, from every shot. Close-ups, long shots - everything looked simply unsurpassed and alive. This film is filled with emotions. There is very little text here, but a lot of action. Every movement of the facial muscles is filled with one or another emotion that simply cannot be conveyed in words. Separately, it is worth noting Hans Zimmer and the mood his music gave to the film. Tension, hope, struggle, luck, anger, loss and victory. It was all amplified hundreds of times thanks to the magic of music. What's really nice is that Nolan, along with famous actors (Kenneth Branagh, Cillian Murphy, Tom Hardy), put young guys at the head of the plot. But the film does not boast of big names, because it is not about individuals. The film tells the story of hundreds of thousands of soldiers and the steadfastness of the people. 'When the soldiers can't go home, the house comes after them' - and it's amazing. Each story told, which ultimately comes together, allows us to feel the tragedy and joy of this historical event. 'Dunkirk' is a quality film that captures the viewer's imagination and once again reminds us that war is evil.

Review-Title: A War Thriller That Redefines The Genre!
Review-Description: Christopher Nolan's masterpiece Dunkirk, is one of the greatest war films ever crafted, period. The sheer amount of filmmaking artistry to relive the heart-rending moments of Operation Dynamo & the miracle of deliverance thereafter, deserves momentous praise, with its affecting themes conveyed through technical feats over embellishments. The film then honors the fact based stories, and what an achievement it was. In Dunkirk, the esteemed filmmaker captures the perils of war flawlessly, with tantalizing frames that brims with genuine drama, whether from land, sea or air. These frames showcase the most harrowing moments of the escape from Dunkirk, staged to perfection, that the immense fear, hopelessness & desperation of his characters resounds to its audience, without the need for dialogue & expositions. Nolan as well, veers away from manufactured sentimentality & false heroics, guaranteeing a spectacle whose most compelling feats, are in the filmmaker's chosen details. Nolan's directorial marvel peaks further in the RAF Spitfires & German BF Fighters dogfights, whose insane camerawork ushers exhilarating point of views that renders the action as original and authentic as can be. Apart from the fantastic direction, Dunkirk as well satiates the technical prestige Nolan films are known for. Hans Zimmer's sound design for instance, was impeccable, elevating the spectacles & tension of each riveting plot piece. The cinematography deserves mention as well, with striking images that serves to both dazzle & horrify. The use of practical effects over CGI offers transporting realism, an uncommon treat for war aficionados with a craving for factual representations. Overall, Dunkirk is Nolan's honest-to-goodness tribute that showcases the realities of war, and its psychological consequences. It then redefines the genre that is so used to aesthetically pleasing heroes with personal dramas, emotional arcs, & orchestrated valorous deeds. In its place are the most suspenseful & immersive sequences, unafraid to depict its star studded characters as random & expendable, terrorized by the bleakness of the situation. My sole criticism on Dunkirk, is its unconventional, multiple timeline approach that was needless. Beyond that however, is pure artistry!

As far as war movies go, this one is on the weak side. There is no reason to get attached to any of the characters because we know nothing about them. The death of the young boy, George, meant nothing to me. He said like 3 sentences before his death, so who cares. Dunkirk is all flash and no substance - It tells an incredibly inaccurate story of the evacuation from Dunkirk and between all the meaningless combat spectacle they still found a way to make this movie pro war-machine propaganda. Extremely flat and predictable performances by the main cast, Tom Hardy in his most wasted role to date, same could be said for Cillian Murphy. The musical score is also just terrible. It drones on and on and on throughout scenes, and overstays it's welcome more than once. Take away the dramatic music, and you're left with nothing in more than a couple of sequences. All in all, a thoroughly disappointing movie.

The movie has many major flaws like how there's no character development. Nobody is memorable and nothing really happens during the movie. There is no story nor plot and the only stakes are the other nameless characters die ye hat we have no attachment to. It's entertaining, sure, but when it stacks up to other films from Nolan it's really kind of a disappointment. I feel if they would've fleshed out the characters and had storys and trauma a bit more, it would've had a amazing chance to be up with some of his best works, because in theory Christopher Nolan making a World War II movie sounds amazing but I genuinely cannot tell you any of the characters names and just about nothing happens. I get the movie was trying to go for the message that even surviving in war is difficult, but it was pretty boring except for a few moments that do shine. 5.4/10.

They spend way too much time being on the water or running towards the water with Jaws music in the background and a grey sky up above for there not to be a shark included. This movie could've been GREATLY improved with a lil megladon thrown in the mix. Sound track is pretty rad for a WWII movie. Felt more like Sharknado IV than Saving Private Ryan and the blue tint on everything is literally giving Twilight. The single best part of this movie is when they showed a whale because whales are dope. Whales aren't as dope as sharks, but they're pretty chillasaurous rex. Don't waste your time with this movie. There are no sharks to gander upon.

So just watch this movie and feeling like i am glad that i watch this movie. Movie scene ending starting overall such a great experience i have feel movie is showing that sirvivial is imp and understand in war is also imp nolan shows this perfectly the way he shoot the scene putting in suspense and many things i like the plot the twist the ending emotional ending the music the cinematography and editing colour grading have best i was watching this in English I don't understand but i feel the movie after understanding the movie i like the way they show overall you should try this movie in a life.

I feel like 1917 does a good job at showcasing the fighting during World War I. It shows the trenches as well troop morale during the war. I feel like people have more interest in the second world war than the first and there's way more WWII content out there than of WWI. This one is a piece of the WWI content out there I like to see more of. World War I is what the second one is based on and I'm surprised to not see it adapted into film as much as WWII has. I hope that it gets adapted more down the line. Side rant over, time to talk more about this film. It focuses on the British side of the war. It takes place near the end of the war, in the year 1917. There's a lot of action in it, way more action than talking. It's based on the stories told by writer-director Sam Mendez's grandfather, in which some creative liberties taken. Overall, a solid WWI film.

Only just seen this film at Christmas 2023, and I cant think of a more enjoyable film I've seen this year. Admittedly there's not a lot of competition at the moment. The main measure for me is, was I completely entertained the whole time? And thats a definitely yes. A simple story really, not great depth, but that didn't matter, I really appreciated the way it was beautifully filmed and edited. The acting whilst fairly simple, was sparse but spot on. I also enjoyed the slower, walking scenes, building tension, adding realism. Yes there are a few times, that, in reality, you know it's not logically correct but it's a film, depicting reality the best it can. It's a film you can watch more than once, just watch it through again only looking at the camera angles and how it was filmed and cut. Just a brilliant stand out film.

Many films have, indeed, been made about The Great War, but the master director Sam Mendes' Oscar nominated masterpiece, may indeed be one of the best. It is a very indepth look, featuring a highly emotional, somewhat unconventional and extremely well written and expertly paced script - accompined by some stellar acting, and twists and turns of a life time. The cinematography, cuting and editing is stellar, very unique and very beautifully put together. The film looks very great and is cut in a very realistic and unqiue way. Heavy on metaphors and allegories. Overall, definitely an incredible war drama, ever recommended for any lover of film, and very much deserving of its many awards. One of Mendes' best!

Review-Title: An Engrosing Journey Start to Finish
Review-Description: 1917 is a harrowing journey directed by Sam Mendes that follows two British soldiers, Lance Corporals Blake (Dean-Charles Chapman) and Schofield (George MacKay) who are given a critical mission of delivering a message to a battalion of soldiers before their imminent advance on the German forces. From start to finish 1917 reinforces the central themes of the futility of war and its complete insouciance for human life. This is achieved by Chapman and MacKay's commendable performances as they convey both the physical and emotional toils that is war. The camaraderie resulting from their critical mission between the lead cast adds a poignant layer to the narrative of the film and reinforces the film's underlying themes of friendship and sacrifice. While Chapman's and MacKay's performances should be noted, the deluge of side characters that the main cast encounters offer exceptional performances. Most notably Andrew Scott's ephemeral but highly diverting performance as Lieutenant Leslie. Andrew Scott embodies the pessimistic indifferent lieutenant so common amongst war films and supports the central theme of the film. As Lance Corporal Blake and Schofield prepare to embark upon their journey, Lieutenant Leslie sows doubt among them by way of sarcasm and prayer knowing quite possibly that the chances that Lance Corporal Blake and Schofield are killed are high. A most notable aspect of 1917 is its tremendous use of its innovative and seamless single-shot technique made possible by cinematographer Roger Deakins. The seamless single-shot technique creates an immersive experience for the audience by having the film unfold in real time. This technique gravitates the audience towards the chaos and urgency that is so prevalent throughout the film. With moments of silence and intense action all in one shot, the technical marvel achieved with the film elevates it to a masterpiece in editing and camera work. Along with the skillful single-shot technique, Thomas Newman -the film's music composer- blends wonderfully with Mendes' production design. Together, 1917 offers a rich atmospheric experience. Whether the main cast finds themselves navigating no man's land in moments of silence or eluding the gunfire and bombings of war, the music offered creates an emotional impact for the viewer and highlights and brutality of conflict throughout the film. Overall, 1917 delivers a cinematic triumph reminiscent of many immersive war films such as Dunkirk (2017) and Saving Private Ryan (1998). 1917 will no doubt leave an indelible mark on the war film genre with its clever use of editing, camera work, and astounding performances while leaving the audience with thought-provoking questions on the futility of war and its brutality.

Review-Title: Its intimate nature makes a compelling anti-war movie
Review-Description: It's a narrowly focused war drama that takes place on April 6-7, 1917, in Northern France. It follows two British soldiers on an urgent mission to cancel an attack against the Germans six miles away, which is a trap. General Erinmore (Colin Firth) orders Lance Corporal Thomas Blake (Dean-Charles Chapman) and Lance Corporal William Schofield (George MacKay) to carry a message to Colonel Mackenzie (Benedick Cumberbatch) canceling a planned attack by the 2nd Battalion on the Germans on the morning of April 7, as he has learned the Germans have set a trap. Thomas Blake is single and unmarried, with an older brother, Joseph (Richard Madden), in the 2nd Battalion. Will Schofield is older and more cynical, having survived the Battle of the Somme in late 1916. "1917" follows the two men on their harrowing journey through No Man's Land and German lines in the next 24 hours, and we learn if the mission was successful. The cinematography is brilliant and very striking, as it appears in the film as two long takes for the entire movie. Chapman and MacKay are superb. The ending is beyond belief but probably necessary in most war movies. Fortunately, there are no large battle scenes. We only see three or four actual deaths, but they are very personal. The results of war are graphically portrayed in the scenes from No Man's Land and at one river crossing. The intimate nature of "1917" makes it a compelling anti-war movie.

This movie stuck with me for so long. It was one of the best cinema experiences that I have ever had. Everything from the cinematography to the performances of the actors (George Mackay is brilliant in this) and from the music to the editing, it is all awe inspiring! The war movie genre has always interested me, but this movie re-defined to me what a war movie is. Instead of focussing on showing the horrors and gore of war, Sam Mendes chose to show us the more human side of war. The story of one man, with all his emotions, and the tremendous task that is at hand. This movie is for me a 10/10.

Review-Title: The movie that leaves you breathless
Review-Description: My original thought before watching 1917 was that this movie was going to be a boring, non-combact movie. I never expected to be standing on my feet waiting to see what happens next! The combat in this movie is insane and unlike many war movies out there, 1917 doesn't overload you with it. I would say through that this movie is not for anyone under the age of sixteen due to the fact of the amount of violence there is. Of course that is just my opinion. Another thing I loved about 1917 is the connections you get with the characters. With many movies you don't get that anymore. That is not the case with 1917!

The movie 1917 portrays the story of two soldiers who are forced to call off their attack on Germany during World War 1. From a technical standpoint, the film is impressive, featuring a smooth and continuous camera shot that follows the soldiers for 110 minutes. The cinematography is stunning and effectively captures the emotional turmoil of the soldiers and the brutality of war. The movie is immersive and evokes a sense of walking alongside the soldiers. 1917 is incredibly suspenseful, and its intensity can be compared to many horror films. The set and music add to the war scenes and help to create a sense of the historical period. Although the performances of the two lead actors are decent, they could have been more nuanced. Their lack of detailed expressions cost them recognition at major award ceremonies. Although the plot is well-crafted, some of the sub-stories feel empty, and the dialogue in certain parts seems unnecessary. Despite these minor flaws, 1917 is a unique and valuable experience that accurately depicts the horrors of war.

I can truly say that this is a film masterpiece and I can also truly say that it's the best war movie I've ever seen. They way that Sam Mendes creates the no-cut type of movie is absolutely astonishing! I absolutely loved everything about this movie, by the stories I've heard and by the photos/videos I've seen I can say that this film is amazingly accurate, it's sad at the right bits, it shows the living conditions of life then and so much more. You can tell by this cinematic masterpiece that WW1 was a wicked and twisted war, filled with ups and downs (mostly downs) I liked how the director showcased how sad loosing a friend through battle really is, he shows us that even though you would really want to stay with your late friend but u cannot because u have a country to serve. I would highly recommend this to anyone who likes a good war movie.

Sam Mendes is a genius. He is amazing. Many scenes are extraordinary. Tomas Newman is a great composer but not for this kind of film. If the music was the appropriate this would have been the best war film ever. There are only a few war films I can compare with. All of them had a better score. All had well known actors but in this film acting is very good. Colours are fantastic and scenes all over the film are great with a senses of something different than we saw on other films. Camera is moving very good and clearness of the scenes is something you can notice even from the beginning of the film.

Kingdom of Heaven is a great movie accurately telling the historical story of the crusades and the history of the Kingdom of Jerusalem. The dialogue fits a confident tone throughout the movie as well as one of greed and anger when the Templars are being shown. The sound design and scenery create a sense of reality. The battles show the desperation of both sides and how chaotic and gruesome medieval warfare was. Although these are definitely pluses, I would have liked to see more involvement with King Baldwin the 4th and how he has defended Jerusalem as well as his relationship with Salahudin. The Queen of Jerusalems story was breaking to see in the end when she fell into a depression instead of pushing through it and making some sort of impact on the kingdom.

Review-Title: One of the best medieval movies of all time
Review-Description: This was absolutely an amazing film. The battles where so good and realistic especially the final battle for Jerusalem. I really love the strategic battle and the tension of who will win the battle. I also love the ending of it, it just has something with it that makes it so good. I also love the acting especially Orlando Bloom does great work in this movie. I really love how he plays balian and how his character evolves thru the movie. I also really love the negotiation scene between Saladin and Baldwin. Overall this movie is just great and really does a great job with the battles that take place. 9/10.

Ridley Scott is good at scale, and here he shows just how good. A story about the crusades, Jerusalem, and the deep conflicts of the medieval world could be romanticised one sided and have no historical clarity, but here, real history and authenticity are given a chance, whilst of course mixing in a degree of dramatic licence and wistfulness. In many ways this is often visceral and balanced in its outlook, sweeping and often spectacular, but the film does have its issues; Orlando bloom is underwhelming in the lead, but just about gets by, and I found the dialogue a little unclear at times, but the theme, the dangers of religious fanaticism, are acutely observed, and the crusaders, a confused rabble with equally confused motives, are portrayed accurately, well balanced by a fair portrayal of the opposing Muslim forces. Generally there are no goodies and baddies. It's impressive, and well worth a look.

"Kingdom of Heaven", is a sweeping historical epic that transports audiences to the tumultuous times of the 12th century during the Crusades. With a stellar cast, breathtaking visuals, and a compelling narrative, the film explores religious conflict, honor, and the complexities of leadership. Set against the backdrop of the Holy Land in the late 12th century, the film follows the journey of Balian of Ibelin, played by Orlando Bloom, a blacksmith who rises to prominence as he discovers his noble heritage. As Balian becomes embroiled in the political and religious tensions of the time, he finds himself amid the epic struggle for Jerusalem. One of the film's undeniable strengths lies in its stunning cinematography and production design. Ridley Scott, known for his visual prowess, delivers a visually immersive experience that transports the audience to the dusty landscapes of the Holy Land. The grandeur of the medieval cities, the epic battles, and the detailed costumes all contribute to the film's authentic and captivating atmosphere. The cast's performances are commendable, with Orlando Bloom clearly portraying Balian's transformation from a reluctant hero to a leader torn between conflicting ideals. The supporting cast, including Liam Neeson, Jeremy Irons, Eva Green, and Ghassan Massoud, contribute nuanced performances that add depth to the characters and the narrative. The film does not shy away from addressing the complexities of religious conflict. It explores themes of tolerance, honor, and the consequences of blind fanaticism. "Kingdom of Heaven" presents a balanced view of the Crusades, portraying the virtues and flaws of characters on both sides of the conflict. This nuanced approach adds depth to the narrative and elevates the film above a simplistic portrayal of good versus evil. However, some critics argue that the film's ambitious scope leads to a lack of in-depth character development, particularly in the case of Balian. The pacing may also feel uneven sometimes, with certain moments rushing through crucial plot points. Nevertheless, the film's grand scale and thematic depth compensate for these minor shortcomings. In conclusion, "Kingdom of Heaven" is a visually stunning and thought-provoking epic that explores the complexities of religious conflict and the human condition during a turbulent historical period. Ridley Scott's masterful direction, solid performances, and compelling narrative make this film noteworthy in the historical epic genre. Despite some pacing issues and a sprawling history, "Kingdom of Heaven" is a captivating cinematic experience that resonates with spectacle and substance.

This movie is no stunning thing nor anything groundbreaking. It is a fun movie, a really good source of history if you ask me(for it's time). Personally I would think like giving it a 9 if the pacing wasn't so amazingly horrible. It's more like reading a tale than watching a movie. In only 40 minutes of the movie(HUGE SPOILERS ALERT) We see Balian's wife dead, we learn Balian has lost his child too, We see Balian meeting his father whom he hadn't even heard before although a general, Balian kills a priest, Godfrey basically dies and the whole lot of his crew with him aswell, Godfrey completely dies, Balian is annointed king, Balian sails to Jerusalem , Balian's crew and ship is destroyed, Balian loses a horse, Balian finds the horse, Balian kills a great warrior of Syria, Balian travels to the holy lands and Balian meets the king. Now I just spoiled half the movie and all this happened within 40 minutes. It was kind of dissapointing. The acting was amazing especially from Jeremy Irons on a career play, the battles were nicely done. The CGI is pretty much really bad and we see the reason why I personally sat and watched that movie (King Baldwin IV) given really small amount of time. It'sdefinetely worse than many movies of it's kind like Troy, Braveheart, The gladiator etc. But it is not bad honestly. I recommend if you like the Crusadial history or these type of movies.

Review-Title: Portrayal of Christianity leaves a lot to be desired - some iconic scenes, beautiful and Leper king is the man
Review-Description: This film could have been better - but it's length, jump around and especially ridiculous portrayal of Christians in the film hurts it. I thought Orlando Bloom acted well, Liam Neeson as a wise mentor is ALWAYS good. The film is shot beautifully, looks amazing and goes for the epic and works. But the star in my eyes is the Leper King (Baldwin IV), his quotes, leadership and courage (and faith) overall is great to watch. Just watch extracts of that on youtube (even though hes not perfect). But I just don't want to watch Christian bashing. The crusades weren't good for either side but Christians were FAR from the only bad guys. Ridley Scott should have done better.

I saw the directos cut. So basically its a solid movie. The pros: Huge armies, Jerusalem, Medival France,... look is good But there are some things weird:
 orlando bloom is the incarnation of the good Leader. Good looking, well beaved, high morals, always on the rright path... the bad ones are bad, rally bad... black and white, not a lot in between. The character arc is non existent. The only one who get a character arc is orland blooms love interest... she is the most interesting character by far orlando has one facial expression throughout the whole movie lepracy is extremely contagious, people hold the kings hand, kiss his hand, touch his mask... thats silly, it would basically kill them the fight sceenes are not so well choriographed. It is cut cut cut... the romance is really cheese orlando is a genius... he orders that wells are being dug... nobody ever thought of this before! His dad owned that property for years orlando is the only survivor of the ship and a horse... no way where did orlando learn to fight? At the beginning he has no clue and in the end leads the army... why is the father returning back home after 20 years. He does not approach Orland and says hey, I am your dad, I am sorry, I have influence and property and wealth in jerusalem, join me. No. He on his way back to Jerusalem stopps and says can you fix our horses, he apologises but Orlando does not immediately follow him, he turns arround and says ok well good bye... its just weired the second most important leader in the arab army travels alone through the desert and in the middle of nowhere meets Orlando... with 1 Bodyguard with him... sure.

"Kingdom of Heaven" is a sweeping historical epic that transports viewers to the heart of the Crusades with breathtaking visuals and a compelling narrative. The acting, led by Orlando Bloom, is engaging, as characters grapple with questions of honor and faith. The film editing keeps the story moving at an engaging pace, allowing the audience to become fully immersed in this tumultuous period. The music by Harry Gregson-Williams adds depth and emotion to the epic battles and personal struggles. The film's strength lies in its exploration of the futility of war, the clash of cultures, and the enduring pursuit of peace. While it may have moments of historical inaccuracy and a sprawling narrative, the cinematography captures the grandeur of the medieval world with stunning detail. With an 8/10 rating, "Kingdom of Heaven" is a captivating journey through a tumultuous era, offering both spectacle and substance for those who appreciate epic historical dramas.

Review-Title: Religion is a powerful toy of politicians
Review-Description:
"What is the value of Jerusalem? ; Nothing" I think the hidden voice in the film was well heard by everyone; Killing and bloodshed caused by religion
I think the film was a good narrator for the storytelling of this period of time, although it was made from the perspective of the West, but there was still an insistence on sticking to what really happened in it, and there were additional quotes and sub-narratives in the main line of the historical narrative. Were not involved
In history, Saladin has been mentioned in a good way (apart from his religion). What we see in this movie is dignity. Humanity and peaceful coexistence is a priority and is more important than religious differences. (Impossible wish)
The actors of this movie are all excellent, especially David Thewlis, although his dialogues were few, but his acting is always amazing, his voice tone is amazing. This movie is definitely one of the greatest historical-religious movies, if you watch it carefully, it is not difficult to understand the events (the director's cut must be watched) And again: "What is the value of Jerusalem? ; Nothing"

(2005) Kingdom Of Heaven
HISTORICAL FANTASY At the beginning of the film, nothing much happens as the Liam Neeson character as Godfrey de Ibelin, a leader of a small group of ailing crusaders stops by at a random village to stock up before continuing to move on again. But before he leaves, he sees what appears to be his only son Balian (Orlando Bloom) as the village blacksmith and offers him to join them. At first becomes reluctant until he became invoked with rage, killing one of the corrupted monks who stole and wore a necklace once around the neck of his just deceased wife who committed suicide and was supposed to be buried. After running away and eventually catching up with his father, his father becomes gravely injured when a sneak attack came in full circle when the village army were coming to retrieve Balian to stand trial for the murder of one of the so-called monks. The Liam Neeson character eventually dies but as a last resort knights his only son to take his place leaving and telling him that he has ownership of some land somewhere in Jerusalem and wants him to go there. This is where the real the movie starts and I become more tired just watching it! Ridley Scott whose last successful film was "Gladiator" solidifying actor Russell Crowe on the map was attempting to redo what he did for him to doing the same type of movie again but with Orlando Bloom is slow, boring and predictable. This film has been done already and it's called "Gladiator" why not make something different this time and that's why the film didn't perform well because it's the exact film but with a different setting, using different actors. To pin point the turning point why "Kingdom Of Heaven" is similar to "Gladiator" is that, although both characters could've chose the path to become great leaders in an uncorrupted and civilized way, they ended up turning it down, allowing the villains or the corrupted to take over resulting to thousands of undeserving needlessly deaths kind of make me hate the main protagonist even more.

Movie Title: All Quiet on the Western Front (2022)
Review-Description: I have read the original source novel (which many of the critics seemed not to) and seen the original 1930 film and upon reflecting on my thoughts once the film had finished, I kind of wish I hadn't. Both the source novel and the original film convey the ultimate sense that war is futile, on all sides and its widely viewed as the ultimate ant-war story. Where those sources excel is the unwavering simplicity of it all. The book focuses on the troops from the German infantry side but also on how troops were viewed back in Germany both before they went, during and when they came back. It is simple in its narrative but that by no means takes away the message it so skilfully conveys. Where this adaptation excels, is the unsettling no holds barred approach. Unsettling score, bloody close ups, clarity of how futile it all is, and the palpable sense of unfairness for a whole generation. It's not perfect though. For me, the last 40 minutes or so, whilst we'll made, tell us nothing. Veering away from the source text, what we actually get here is a message that has been conveyed many times in war before (that the powers in charge have no sympathy for their men) and it feels like it is trying to say more than it actually does. I think whilst this is good, the source novel and original form are perfect. This is not.

Movie Title: All Quiet on the Western Front (2022)
Review-Title: A Stark and Poignant Adaptation: Netflix's 'All Quiet on the Western Front' Captures the Futility of War
Review-Description: Netflix's 2022 adaptation of "All Quiet on the Western Front" is a remarkable cinematic achievement that profoundly conveys the essence of Erich Maria Remarque's classic novel. The film is a harrowing depiction of the senselessness and inhumanity of war, brilliantly capturing the core message of the source material. The film excels in illustrating the sheer absurdity and contradiction inherent in war. It portrays the experiences of young soldiers propelled into the chaos of conflict by ambitions they don't fully comprehend and a sense of duty that becomes increasingly meaningless. The narrative powerfully conveys the idea that war is like an unfathomable fever, illogical yet somehow inevitable. One of the film's most striking aspects is its ability to communicate the horror and utter irrationality of war. It's a poignant exploration of the senselessness of conflict, particularly resonant in the current global climate. The film doesn't just tell a story of war; it immerses the viewer in the visceral reality of the front lines, making the horror and futility felt in a deeply personal way. The adaptation is timely, serving as a stark reminder of the ongoing relevance of Remarque's message. The film's portrayal of the last hours of the war is particularly impactful, showing soldiers being led to slaughter even as the end of the conflict nears. It's a powerful commentary on the ongoing human cost of war, irrespective of its causes or conclusions. "All Quiet on the Western Front" is a film that does more than depict historical events; it questions and challenges the very nature of war. It's a necessary and haunting reminder of war's devastating impact on the human spirit and the absurdity of conflict as a means of resolving disputes. This adaptation is a must-watch for its honest, brutal, and unflinching portrayal of one of humanity's greatest follies.

Movie Title: All Quiet on the Western Front (2022)
Review-Title: Only the dead have seen the end of war
Review-Description: This film stands as a testament to the harrowing realities of war, transcending mere storytelling to offer a poignant portrayal of the complexities inherent in the human condition amidst conflict. At its core, the film (guided by an accomplished director) masterfully depicts the camaraderie, love, hatred, hubris, egotism, and the sheer stupidity that characterize the theater of war. The camaraderie shared among soldiers in the trenches emerges as a central theme, providing a glimmer of humanity in the darkest of circumstances. The film vividly captures the deep bonds formed between soldiers, bound by a shared struggle and an understanding born of facing death together. Their solidarity becomes a lifeline, offering solace and support in the face of unimaginable horrors. Through the camaraderie, the film showcases the resilience of the human spirit amidst the turmoil of war, highlighting the strength found in unity. Love, in its various forms, also finds its place amid the desolation of battle. The longing for normalcy and the enduring power of connections to loved ones left behind. These glimpses of love serve as a reminder of the profound loss experienced by those thrust into the maelstrom of conflict. Hatred, both for the enemy and the war itself, permeates the narrative. The dehumanization of the enemy becomes a necessary coping mechanism. The internal conflict, torn between duty and revulsion for the senseless bloodshed, exposes the moral ambiguity inherent in warfare. Hubris and egotism, prevalent not only among commanding officers but also within the ranks, underscore the folly and absurdity of war. The disillusionment experienced by the soldiers, witnessing the callousness and incompetence of their leaders, breeds a profound sense of cynicism. The film skillfully portrays the absurdity of commands issued from afar, divorced from the grim realities faced by those on the front lines, highlighting the tragic consequences of unchecked arrogance and ignorance. Moreover, the film does not shy away from depicting the sheer stupidity and futility of war. The juxtaposition of the idealistic fervor that initially drives the young soldiers to enlist with the grim reality they face on the battlefield lays bare the tragic irony of conflict. The systematic destruction of a generation's hopes and dreams through the brutal machinery of war serves as a scathing indictment of the folly of human aggression. All Quiet on the Western Front transcends a mere anti-war narrative but is a timeless commentary on the human condition itself. Its unflinching depiction of the horrors of war, coupled with the exploration of profound themes and the senseless nature of conflict, make our reality true.

Movie Title: All Quiet on the Western Front (2022)
Review-Description: One of the most incredible war stories on film, especially of World War I. It is visceral and intense. It is bloody and full of war horrors. If you want a real depiction of what war is like, and what it does to men in battle, this is a great example of that. World War I was exceptionally bloody based on the style of warfare and the means used to kill the enemy. This is from the German viewpoint. But equally, it shows the human cost. It shows the Germans, like everyone else that was in that theater, our regular people trying to survive from one minute to the next that is often a commonality amongst warriors. This does not get into the history behind the war, and why it started And so forth. This is a human, in the mud, ground level, experience. Nothing to do with generals, making grand decisions, except for a few moments here. It focuses on ground level troops in the infantry, where all the blood and guts are real. Just remake his right up there with the best of all war films.

Movie Title: All Quiet on the Western Front (2022)
Review-Title: Very raw and powerful if somewhat heavy handed war film
Review-Description: A film of young men's dreams and illusions of glory and victory horribly crushed. The film opens in freezing woodland with some foxes in their den, the cameras pans down from above the forest and we see it full of dead soldiers while gunfire rings out and the camera glides across the warzone. The film's battle sequences are expertly shot with all the smoke and cloud and rubble and shells landing around the characters. The film is largely told in one large flashback beginning in 1917 with several young friends eagerly joining the army full of high moral. I'm a bit surprised they were in such a state in 1917, 1914 yes but anyway. The production design is great in this film, the streets, the props, the costumes, you don't for a second question any of it. We also experience the battlefields, the ruined villages, the soaking trenches, the music is also brilliant with this hard industrial clanging sound to it as the soldiers march towards the front line. The film is extremely well acted, I saw it in it's original German language and I thought it was really well cast. As well as the experience of the soldiers we also follow a character in 1918 on a mission to bring the war to the end, his role is to negotiate an armistice and has just 3 days to agree to the French terms. The film lets us know this man is fully aware that the lives of all the soldiers still left in the Germany army may rest on his ability to negotiate a surrender. The film does a good job though at hinting at the power struggle taking place within Germany, the Kaiser and the army have effectively be running the country since the war began, and the army leadership is in no mood to compromise, a particularly callous and mad general seems to believe that just one more successful German attack will lead to a breakthrough and the end of the allied advance, even as his army collapses around him he orders more units to the front. The film gets great little details right too like the thinness of the men who are fighting by the end, the mud they often end up caked in when crawling through the trenches, the longing for good food and the thoughts of women and home dominate the lives of these men who are engaged in a fight to the death now. Not all details are perfect though, German soldiers didn't have to run into farms to steal food and then leg it before they were shot, German soldiers were expected and even encouraged to loot French farms and towns which fell under their control and the French were powerless to stop them. The details are horrific, the dead soldiers and horses littering the landscape, men are reduced to almost animal like instincts, thinking only of killing and eating. The wounded engage in a desperate struggle to survive, men carry comrades for miles only for them to die within minutes of safety, again and again we are reminded how futile it all is, some characters are killed unexpectedly, it's all some random. The film is very heavy handed in contrasting the filth and agony the lowly soldiers live with against the command HQ where the general staff live in luxury and comfort. We even get a scene of the general assured that a factory making riddle saddles will have a long and productive future. The not so subtle point is he's a man now with ideas about 50 years out of date. The truth though is both sides did their best to embrace new technology and innovations, no one solution could have ensured a quick victory and a low number of casualties once these mighty great industrial powers were engaged in all out war across such a vast front. The German general worked night and day for 4 years during the war with the weight of the country resting on his shoulders, when his son died in the fighting it broke him, nobody was spared the pain of the war, despite what this film tries to suggest. In this though the mad commander yet again orders his men to the front for one final attack despite everyone knowing it's madness. But then war is madness I suppose is its message. I do recommend this film as one of the best WWI films out there in terms of recreating the combat experience, this is a world without women or comfort or even humanity for these men, all that matters is the killing goes on.

Movie Title: All Quiet on the Western Front (2022)
Review-Description: This movie is overall a very good movie with good story telling and good cinematography while also showing the brutality of war which not a lot of movies show while the movie is a bit disturbing some times it has some moments which are very sad also it hold up pretty good for being a war movie though it can be a little bit unrealistic at times it has most of what a movie needs simply because the people who made the movie they knew what they were doing to make an anti war movie (also if you want to know what an anti war movie is it's basically where it show that war is bad and the lives lost are meaningless.

Movie Title: All Quiet on the Western Front (2022)
Review-Title: Great movie but also very sad
Review-Description: I very much enjoyed the movie it's a great film I love how each important scene is packed full of action it's also a very gory one but not to gory which makes it feel some what real and us the people watching it makes like we were really there in 1914-1918 but the ending is very sad and I was shocked at what happened and it really made me think about how horrible that war was and how tons of peoples friends died and they had to be there to see it. Other than that 10/10 I would watch again for definite and I will recommend it to other people for them to watch this film and enjoy it as much as it did.

Movie Title: All Quiet on the Western Front (2022)
Review-Title: The horrors both sides faced in WW1
Review-Description: All Quiet on the Western Front is a great movie. The movie is the story of a german soldier in WW1 and how difficult it was even for the central powers. I only watched the new one but I have planned on watching the old one also. It is German so you will need subtitles if you speak English and don't know german. The story is really moving and at one point it actually almost made me cry. The sadness the main character felt when slowly his friends started to die is really touching and I started to feel it also. I know there are some people that say the older one is better, but I think that if I watch the old one now, I will still think the new one is better. When I watched this, I started to emphasize the German side also. It is a side of both World wars that you never see but WW1 was a different ballgame. WW1 was a horrific war with millions dying just because they stood up in a trench. But in every story we only hear about the British, French, and American point of view. This movie does a really good job at showing that the Germans and their allies also faced the horrors of the trenches.

Movie Title: All Quiet on the Western Front (2022)
Review-Title: All quiet on the western front review
Review-Description: Personally for me this movie is a well deserved 10 star because of how great this movie was, it had a great plot, good start, good ending, good acting, and good characters. This is the best war movie that i have watched out of all of the ones i saw, it had really close calls and really panicky and tough situations and made you feel at danger and had you really paying attention and the timing for everything was perfect they pulled it off as best as they could, and you can tell that they put a lot of time and effort into this movie because they pulled off every scene perfectly and not sloppy. This movie was also very tragic because the main character had to see things that he wouldnt be able to recover from. Honestly this movie was a well deserved 10 star because of how everything just came together perfectly and the movie shocked you more and more even when you thought you saw enough. In all i could say that this movie was magnificent and well deserved 10 star no complaints, its a must watch!

Movie Title: All Quiet on the Western Front (2022)
Review-Title: when people call war hell, you'd better believe them
Review-Description: I've never read Erich Maria Remarque's book, although I've previously seen Lewis Milestone's Academy Award-winning 1930 adaptation starring Lew Ayres. Now I've seen Edward Berger's Academy Award-winning "Im Westen nichts Neues" ("All Quiet on the Western Front" in English). Talk about a gut punch. This movie lays bare the saying "war is hell", making clear the futility of war (never mind that the Versailles Negotiations set the stage for World War II). One can see a contrast between the horrors of the battlefield and the generals' comfortable residences. This movie - or the 1930 version - could easily be a double-viewing with Stanley Kubrick's "Paths of Glory". All in all, everyone should see this. With all the wars that have dominated the 21st century, movies like this one become all the more important.

Review-Title: It doesn't matter who it's to, only who it's from
Review-Description: A compelling murder mystery set in and around Wind River, the Wyoming Indian reservation, a place so awful to live in that one character says that now that she has put it behind her, you couldn't drag her back there with a rope - and she has family still living there that she loves. I guess at this point Jeremy Renner has it in his contract that he has to shoot a living thing in every role, preferably with a sniper rifle? I mean, I'm not complaining; it's just an observation. There is an aging Western anti-hero quality to him; he doesn't necessarily follow the rules, an archetype that has been popular in America for over half a century.
